The company will make further announcements as necessary and advises shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its shares.

site_title: US: Wall St rally falters as oil prices skid
summary: US stocks faltered on Thursday as oil prices fell 2%, snapping a two-day rally, and investors shifted focus from Brexit to broader economic factors. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.19%, the S&P 500 gained 0.05%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.04%. The market had previously recovered from a two-day panic selloff after the UK's Brexit vote, which resulted in a $3 trillion loss in global markets. Investors are now focusing on the performance of the global economy, with data showing the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits rose to 268,000.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust's move to take manager in-house gets unitholders' nod
summary: Croesus Retail Trust's plan to take its manager in-house was approved by unitholders at an extraordinary general meeting. The trustee-manager will use S$22.1 million from a preferential offering to finance the internalisation. CEO Jim Chang stated that the trust will benefit from adopting an internalised structure, focusing on sensible transactions, cost reductions, and enhancing market valuation. The trustee-manager will provide updates on the internalisation in due course.

site_title: Emerging markets escape fairly lightly from Brexit shock: IIF
summary: The "Brexit" shock has had relatively little immediate adverse impact on capital flows into emerging markets, with net inflows seen in Asia and modest outflows in Europe. However, volatility is expected to continue over the summer as the British economy tips into recession. The British vote to leave the EU has triggered significant turmoil in global financial markets, with euro bank shares down nearly 20% and sterling down almost 10% against the dollar. Emerging Europe, South Africa, and Latin American currencies have been most affected, while currencies in emerging market Asia have seen only minor weakening.

site_title: MAS names Peter Bellew as its third chief in two years
summary: Malaysia Airlines has appointed Peter Bellew as its third CEO in two years, succeeding Christoph Mueller, who resigned unexpectedly. Bellew takes over on July 1, following a three-year turnaround plan that included 6,000 job losses and cuts to long-haul destinations. The airline is on track for a full-year profit in 2018, having recently reached break-even. Bellew's appointment aims to ensure continuity in the turnaround plan, which has cut capacity by almost a third.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines Bhd (MAS) has promoted chief operating officer Peter Bellew to head the state-owned carrier after its former chief executive officer resigned unexpectedly.

site_title: Electricity tariffs up by 9.2 per cent from July to September
summary: Electricity tariffs in Singapore will increase by 9.2% from July to September due to higher natural gas costs. The average increase is 1.59 Singapore cents per kWh, compared to the previous quarter. This change will affect electricity prices for the next three months, as announced by SP services.

site_title: Top banker calls for clarity on British position on EU talks
summary: A top British banker, John McFarlane, is calling for clarity on the UK's position in EU talks following the country's decision to leave the EU. McFarlane, chairman of TheCityUK, said Britain needs a new international model for financial services and stable leadership to navigate post-Brexit negotiations, which could take years to reach a deal. The UK will need to respect EU citizens' freedom to move to Britain for continued access to the single market, a point of contention for pro-Brexit campaigners.

site_title: Philippine Airlines income jumps more than six-fold
summary: Philippine Airlines reported a 560% jump in its "comprehensive income" for 2015, reaching US$134.42 million, driven by low fuel prices and expanded routes and aircraft numbers. The airline's comprehensive income in 2015 was a significant improvement from a US$229.71 million loss in 2013. PAL's president attributed the recovery to carefully calibrated expansion programs and the growth momentum of the industry. The airline's operating expenses increased slightly to US$2.237 billion.

site_title: UK economic growth slows in first quarter
summary: UK economic growth slowed to 0.4% in the first quarter, unchanged from the previous quarter but marking a slowdown from the fourth quarter of 2015. The slowdown was attributed to business investment faltering due to uncertainty before the Brexit referendum. This marks the second consecutive month of economic contraction, posing a fresh blow to UK Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Passing your business and wealth to the next generation
summary: Asian family businesses often overlook succession planning due to cultural taboos and founder reluctance to relinquish control. Procrastination can lead to wealth loss and disputes among family members. Estate and succession planning involve creating a holistic plan with a team of experts, including accountants, lawyers, and wealth planners. This plan should include a will, trusts, insurance, and collective investment fund solutions to address family needs. Identifying a competent successor, specifying core values, and using trusts to manage wealth are essential. A successful plan should start early, with the first generation, to ensure wealth sustainability and family harmony.

site_title: Sim Lian buying shopping centre in Western Australia
summary: Sim Lian Group has acquired Dalyellup Shopping Centre in Western Australia for A$31.56 million, with the centre valued at A$31.8 million. The freehold shopping centre has a gross lettable area of 6,446 square meters, anchored by a Woolworths Supermarket. The acquisition will be funded by a combination of internal funds and bank borrowings, with SLG Property Trust II set to take ownership through SLG Dalyellup Trust.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: UK homebuilders ready for whatever Brexit brings
summary: UK homebuilders have shown resilience despite the 27% decline in their stocks following the Brexit vote. 11 of 13 listed homebuilders maintained investment-grade credit health, with McCarthy & Stone Plc being the exception. The housing market's health is closely tied to the UK's economic prospects, making the industry a key indicator.

site_title: 13 detained over Istanbul airport attack
summary: Thirteen suspected Islamic State jihadists were detained in Istanbul over the deadly airport attack, which killed 43 people and injured over 200. The attack, on Tuesday, was carried out by three suicide bombers from Russia, Uzbekistan, and Kyrgyzstan. Authorities are investigating whether the attack was planned in advance, with CIA director John Brennan stating it bore the "hallmark" of the jihadist group. The government is under pressure to reassure tourists that Turkey is safe, with the vital tourism industry hit hard by a string of deadly attacks in the past year.

site_title: Manila baker in free cake give-away after Duterte win
summary: A Manila baker, Eliaquin Labang, is giving away over 7,000 slices of cake to those who register online throughout Rodrigo Duterte's six-year term as Philippine president. Labang initially promised 5 million pesos worth of cake if Duterte was elected, citing the president's efforts to combat crime. Despite initial criticism, Labang has changed his mind and now offers 50 slices twice a month to registered individuals, after his initial offer went viral and was met with thousands of requests.

site_title: Leoni to cut 1,100 jobs at car wiring systems division
summary: Germany's Leoni to cut 1,100 jobs at its car wiring systems division, aiming to boost annual earnings from 2017. The move is part of a cost-saving effort to improve profitability, following a year of declining profits due to a glut of orders and high labor costs. The division generates 60% of the company's revenue and will see a marginally improved result this year before a sustained increase in profitability starting in 2017.

site_title: Japan automakers recall 1.3m cars at home over Takata air bags
summary: Japanese automakers are recalling 1.3 million cars at home due to potentially faulty Takata air bags, which can explode with excessive force. The recall affects vehicles from Mazda, Mitsubishi, and Fuji Heavy Industries, with additional recalls planned overseas for over 1 million cars. The US government has classified around 100 million Takata air bag inflators as defective worldwide, linked to 150 injuries and 14 deaths, mainly in the US.

site_title: Ex-London mayor Boris Johnson rules out bid to be next British prime minister
summary: Former London mayor Boris Johnson has ruled out a bid to be the next British prime minister, citing "circumstances in parliament" following David Cameron's resignation. Johnson, a prominent Brexit supporter, had been considered a top contender to replace Cameron. He made the announcement after consulting colleagues. Johnson's decision comes as the UK navigates the aftermath of its EU referendum.

images.alt_text: Former London mayor Boris Johnson, who had been considered one of the favourites to replace David Cameron as Prime Minister, said on Thursday he would not be standing.

site_title: Red Bull apologises to Indonesia over offensive ad
summary: Red Bull has publicly apologized to Indonesia for shooting a commercial at the 9th-century Borobudur temple without permission from authorities. The video, featuring a "free running" athlete, sparked outrage due to its disregard for the temple's "No Climbing" signs. Authorities had previously warned the crew, but the video was uploaded online in March. Red Bull met with government officials in June and agreed to place formal apologies in national newspapers, and has also been asked to shoot a new video explaining the importance of protecting holy sites.

site_title: SMRT unit and United Technical Services invest in automated vehicles maker
summary: SMRT International Pte Ltd and United Technical Services (UTS) have invested in 2 Getthere Holding BV, a Netherlands-based company designing automated vehicles. SMRT acquired a 20% stake worth $6 million, while UTS increased its holding to 11%. The investments aim to enhance 2getthere's technological capabilities and support projects in the Middle East and Asia-Pacific. 2getthere plans to accelerate its contribution to Dubai's goal of making 25% of trips driverless by 2030, and SMRT expects growing demand for automated vehicles in Asia.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 11 points higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 11.87 points to 1,654.08. Trading volumes reached 1.46 billion lots valued at RM2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 387 to 385.

site_title: Chiwayland secures Sydney land parcel for A$40m
summary: Chiwayland International has acquired a 114,270 square metre land parcel in Sydney for A$40 million, with plans to develop 400 apartments and 364 townhouses in three phases, expected to be completed by 2020. This is the group's seventh property development project in Australia since 2014, with a total investment of approximately A$320 million. Sales of townhouses and apartments are slated for the second half of 2017 and 2018, respectively.

site_title: Yanlord to develop Nanjing site with China Merchants Property, Poly Real Estate
summary: Yanlord Land Group Limited has entered into a cooperative agreement with China Merchants Property Development Co Ltd and Poly Real Estate Group to develop a 170,000 square metre site in Nanjing's Gulou district. The site was acquired through a public land auction for approximately 4.82 billion yuan. Under the agreement, Yanlord will obtain a 33% stake in the project company. This marks a significant development project for Yanlord in China, with the site valued at around S$976.5 million.

site_title: Greater tax deductions from July 1 for firms that encourage staff volunteerism
summary: Singapore businesses will enjoy a 250% tax deduction on wages and related expenses for employee volunteerism from July 1, 2016, to Dec 31, 2018, for services provided to Institutions of a Public Character. The initiative aims to promote philanthropy and volunteerism, and the government hopes to foster a culture of caring in Singapore. To be eligible, businesses must participate in the Business and IPC Partnership Scheme and receive agreements from IPCs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall as post-Brexit recovery stalls
summary: European stocks fell on Thursday, marking a stall in recovery from the Brexit sell-off. The STOXX 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indices declined 0.6%, with the FTSE 100 and DAX indices also falling 0.3% and 0.5% respectively. Banking stocks were among the worst performers, with shares in Deutsche Bank, Santander, and Royal Bank of Scotland losing ground. The declines were attributed to US stress test failures and a Morgan Stanley downgrade.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher, tracking global rally
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.06% to 15,575.92 on Thursday, following a global rally, as investors anticipate fresh Bank of Japan stimulus to counter the impact of Brexit. The Topix index, however, lost 0.15% to 1,245.82. The move is seen as a sign of optimism despite uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the EU and ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Euro-area inflation rate turned positive before Brexit vote
summary: The euro-area inflation rate unexpectedly turned positive in June, rising 0.1% from a year earlier, ahead of the Brexit vote. This marks the first increase since January and exceeds economists' median estimate of unchanged prices. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi had expressed confidence in a slow inflation pick-up in the second half, but the latest data suggests this may now take longer to achieve due to the UK's vote to leave the EU. Output is expected to drop by up to 0.5% below projections over the next three years.

images.alt_text: Inflation unexpectedly returned to the euro area in June, suggesting that central-bank stimulus may have been starting to filter through to the economy before Britons chose to leave the European Union.

site_title: La Nina weather should boost 2017 palm oil yields, support prices
summary: La Nina weather is expected to boost palm oil yields in 2017, potentially leading to a rebound in global supply after a severe dry year due to El Nino. The cooling Pacific Ocean pattern will bring rain to Southeast Asia's palm plantations, supporting oil output from Indonesia and Malaysia, which produce 90% of the world's palm oil. Analysts predict a 7-10% increase in global output, with Malaysia's production reaching 20 million tonnes and Indonesia's at 34 million tonnes. This could lead to higher demand and support prices, despite rising output.

site_title: Oil prices dip on oversupply concerns
summary: Oil prices dropped in Asia as supply concerns eased, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling to $49.43 a barrel and North Sea Brent to $50.01 a barrel. The improved supply outlook comes after a looming strike in Norway was called off and global market turmoil following the UK's Brexit vote begins to ease. Traders worry that oil prices above $50 a barrel could encourage producers to restart production, adding to the market's oversupply.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rally to build on Brexit recovery
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.75% on Thursday, extending a recovery from last week's plunge, amid speculation of central bank stimulus measures to offset the EU's Brexit impact. The Hang Seng Index closed at 20,794.37, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.07% and the Shenzhen Composite Index inched up 0.05%. The rally follows a broader global stock market recovery, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Including universal life insurance as part of your legacy-building plan
summary: Entrepreneurs in Asia are often hands-on in managing their businesses, but planning for the continuity of the business when it passes to subsequent generations is crucial. A recent study found that 67% of family-owned businesses in Southeast Asia have made arrangements for succession, but 22% lack a plan. Universal life insurance (ULI) can address legacy planning concerns, providing a guaranteed death benefit, accumulating cash value, and ensuring business liquidity. ULI can be used for wealth equalization, wealth creation, and tax planning, making it an attractive solution for entrepreneurs.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines appoints Peter Bellew as new chief executive
summary: Malaysia Airlines appoints Peter Bellew as new chief executive, effective July 1. Current CEO Christoph Mueller will go on leave and step down from the board immediately. This move ensures continuity in the airline's turnaround plan and restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines Berhad (MAS) has appointed chief operating officer Peter Bellew as its new chief executive, with effect from July 1, the airline said on Thursday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Moody's downgraded Singapore's banking system outlook to negative due to worsening operating conditions and rising risks to asset quality and profitability. Fullerton Healthcare launched a SGD $100m bond offer backed by an ADB fund. Public carpark charges will be raised by 10-20 cents per half hour from Dec 1. Singapore's total bank lending in May rose due to stronger demand for manufacturing loans. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is looking to clarify the use of cloud technology by banks.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher as blue chips enjoy large window-dressing push
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 88 points to open at 2,880 on June 30, driven by large volume and blue chip gains, but failed to hold momentum, closing at 2,840.93. This mirrors the pattern seen on May 31, where the index surged but closed with a net loss. The STI is down 1.5% for the first half of the year, but has bounced 4% since the Brexit vote in early June. Window-dressing is suspected to have played a role in the market's recent behavior.

site_title: Australia, NZ shares end higher, join global rally after Brexit shock
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.77% to 5,233.4, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index gained 1.37% to 6,897.53, following the UK's Brexit vote. Global markets regained some losses, with the benchmark having recouped two-thirds of its fall. The UK's Brexit shock led to sharp falls in shares, but markets have since rebounded, with the Australian and New Zealand markets recovering in part.

site_title: Singapore to decide soon on US$1b deal for military helicopters
summary: Singapore will soon decide on a US$1-billion purchase of new military helicopters, replacing 32 ageing Super Pumas, after a civilian Airbus Super Puma crash delayed the decision. The city-state is evaluating between Airbus Helicopters and Leonardo Finmeccanica, and will also study tactical lift helicopters to replace its Boeing Chinooks. Singapore's defence budget is increasing amid regional tensions, with the country also upgrading its air capabilities and setting up a battalion-sized Army Deployment Force to protect against terror attacks.

images.alt_text: Singapore will decide "soon"on an estimated US$1-billion purchase of new military helicopters which it had delayed after the crash of a civilian aircraft made by one of the bidders, Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen said on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise further at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.47% at the open on Thursday, driven by a global market recovery from last week's Brexit-fueled decline. The Hang Seng Index reached 20,736.85, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.11 points.

site_title: Electric vehicle car-sharing from mid-2017
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Economic Development Board (EDB) announced the launch of BlueSG, a nationwide electric vehicle (EV) car-sharing programme in mid-2017. Initially, 125 cars and 200 charging points will be deployed, with plans to increase to 1,000 EVs and 2,000 charging points in four years. A membership is required, and users can return the car at their destination. The programme aims to provide 80% of stations in HDB and residential areas, with 20% available for any EV.

site_title: China: Stocks flat as post-Brexit rebound leads to profit-taking
summary: China's stocks ended flat on Thursday, with the CSI300 index rising 0.1% to 3,153.92, and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.1% to 2,929.61 points. The rebound after last week's heavy selling triggered by the Brexit vote has lost steam, with no good news in sight. The sectors were mixed, with consumer and healthcare shares gaining, while resources, infrastructure, and transportation shares fell. Investors now await factory and service sector activity surveys for more clues on China's economy.

site_title: OECD anti-tax avoidance efforts gain traction at Kyoto meeting
summary: More than 80 countries and jurisdictions gathered in Kyoto to push for global efforts to stop corporate tax avoidance, following a G20 agreement last year to endorse OECD's steps to tackle tax avoidance. The OECD/G20 project aims to address Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS), allowing companies to move profits out of taxed countries. This meeting marks the latest step in the OECD's efforts to tackle BEPS, which has sparked public anger over companies like Starbucks and Google. The meeting's outcome is not specified in the article.

site_title: Conservative May pitches anti-Boris case for Britain's top job
summary: Theresa May, Britain's interior minister, has announced her candidacy to replace Prime Minister David Cameron, who resigned after the country voted to leave the European Union. May, known for her handling of security issues, made a coded attack on rival Boris Johnson, suggesting he lacks understanding of the struggles faced by ordinary people. The Conservative Party will elect her successor by early September, with Johnson expected to be a major contender. May's message aimed to appeal to voters who feel disconnected from politics, positioning herself as a serious leader who can tackle the country's divisions.

site_title: Top Sukuk arranger seeks South Asia partners as momentum shifts
summary: CIMB Islamic Bank, the world's largest Islamic bond arranger, plans to venture into South Asia, exploring opportunities in retail and corporate Shariah-compliant services in Bangladesh, India, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan. The bank aims to form joint operations with local partners after 2018, seeking to capture more business beyond its traditional base in Malaysia. Despite having some of Asia's largest Muslim populations, South Asia remains largely uncharted territory in the $2 trillion Islamic finance industry, with past efforts in India and Sri Lanka facing opposition and stalled plans.

site_title: Thai factory output rises for third straight month in May
summary: Thai industrial output rose 2.6% in May, marking a third consecutive month of growth, driven by increases in auto, air conditioner, and rubber product production. However, exports declined 4.4% year-over-year, and capacity utilization rose only to 67.45%. The recovery remains fragile, with exports contracting for the third consecutive year. The central bank forecasts a 2.5% decline in shipments this year, despite an expected 3.1% economic growth.

images.alt_text: Thailand's industrial output rose for a third straight month in May but the recovery remains fragile with both exports and domestic consumption sluggish.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up tracking overseas markets, rate decision awaited
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.1% on Thursday, driven by gains in overseas markets, ahead of the central bank's expected rate cut. Most economists predict a fourth consecutive rate cut to shore up flagging growth, bringing the discount rate to fresh six-year lows. The decision is due after the market close.

site_title: Malaysian opposition leader Lim Guan Eng charged with graft
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Lim Guan Eng has been charged with two counts of abuse of power, including approving a land deal and purchasing a bungalow at below market price. He pleaded not guilty and was granted RM1 million bail. The charges are part of a crackdown on opposition leaders, with critics accusing the government of targeting those opposed to Prime Minister Najib Razak's administration. The move comes amid investigations into 1MDB and Najib's personal finances, with Najib denying any wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: Malaysian authorities on Thursday charged a senior federal opposition leader with two counts of abuse of power, a move government critics say is part of a crack down on those opposed to Prime Minister Najib Razak's administration.

site_title: GLP to sell its share of JV project with Mitsui Fudosan for 15.5b yen
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) will sell its 50% stake in the GLP-MFLP Ichikawa Shiohama joint venture project with Mitsui Fudosan for 15.5 billion yen (S$208 million). The sale, completed in September 2016, crystallizes 4.9 billion yen of development profit and generates a 23% net levered property internal rate of return. GLP plans to reinvest the proceeds into development in Japan, maintaining its focus on modern logistics facilities.

site_title: Airport attack hits Turkey tourism industry when it's down
summary: Turkey's tourism industry faces a severe blow after a deadly bombing in Istanbul, killing at least 41 and wounding over 200. The attack, attributed to Islamic State, comes as the industry was already struggling, with tourist arrivals plummeting 35% from the same month in 2015. Industry experts predict a 35-40% drop in income in 2016, with the current-account deficit expected to widen again this year, climbing back to 5.1% of GDP by 2018.

site_title: Japan factory output dives in knock to recovery
summary: Japanese industrial production declined 2.3% in May, the first drop in three months, exceeding economists' expectations of a 0.2% decrease. The weak factory output follows a trade deficit in May and flat retail sales. The data is a worrying sign for Japan's fragile economy, which has been struggling with low growth and deflation.

site_title: Bank of China to sell assets to Hong Kong unit for HK$6.9 billion
summary: Bank of China Ltd is selling its Malaysian and Thai assets to its Hong Kong subsidiary, BOC Hong Kong (Holdings) Ltd, for HK$6.9 billion. The sale includes Bank of China (Thai) Pcl for HK$3.1 billion and Bank of China (Malaysia) Bhd for around HK$3.8 billion. The deal aims to restructure the bank's businesses in Southeast Asia and enable BOC Hong Kong to transform into a regional bank, according to CEO Yue Yi. The transactions were first flagged in May last year and are expected to be completed in the near future.

images.alt_text: Bank of China Ltd will sell Malaysian and Thai assets to its Hong Kong subsidiary for HK$6.9 billion (S$1.19 billion) as the fourth-largest mainland lender restructures its businesses in Southeast Asia.

site_title: RHTLaw Taylor Wessing merges with Vietnam law firm to deepen reach
summary: RHTLaw Taylor Wessing LLP has merged with Vietnam law firm PBC Partners & RHTLaw to form RHTLaw Taylor Wessing Vietnam. The move aims to deepen the firm's regional cross-border practice, aligning with the Asean Economic Community blueprint 2025. This merger follows their alliance in 2014 and marks a significant expansion of the firm's presence in the Southeast Asian market. The new entity will provide comprehensive legal services to clients in Vietnam and the wider region.

site_title: Netflix CEO says firm continues to look into entering China
summary: Netflix CEO Reed Hastings stated that the company continues to explore entering China, despite the country's stringent regulations and censorship challenges. This move aims to counter slowing US growth and expand the service globally. Hastings' comments follow a weaker-than-expected forecast for US and international subscription growth in the second quarter, highlighting the need for expansion. Netflix is also looking into various investment opportunities in Asia to improve its offerings.

site_title: No sign of Brexit hit to emerging market asset flows - IIF
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) reported that the UK's vote to leave the EU, or "Brexit," had a minimal impact on emerging market asset flows, with daily outflows totaling $210 million on "Brexit Friday." This compares to a $2.7 billion outflow in 2015. The IIF noted that asset flows have since recovered, indicating a relatively minor effect of the Brexit vote on emerging markets.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks end up on global risk rally
summary: South Korean won and shares rose on Thursday, driven by a global risk rally. The won strengthened 0.7% against the dollar, marking a 3.5% monthly gain, while KOSPI closed up 0.7% at 1,970.35 points. Foreign investors purchased 187.6 billion won worth of KOSPI shares. The rally followed a boost in Wall Street and global oil prices, supporting appetite for riskier assets.

site_title: Engine failure, errors by crew led to deadly Taipei crash: report
summary: A Taiwanese passenger jet crash that killed 43 people in February was caused by engine failure and flight crew errors, according to a final investigation report. The TransAsia Airways Flight GE235 clipped a bridge and plunged into a river shortly after takeoff, with only 15 survivors. The crew failed to identify the malfunctioning engine and shut down the other engine, leading to a stall-induced loss of control. The accident was the result of multiple contributing factors, including pilot errors and inadequate procedures.

site_title: US regulators probe SoftBank over misconduct claims
summary: US regulators are investigating SoftBank over misconduct claims related to former president Nikesh Arora, who quit in June. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is examining potential conflicts of interest and questionable behavior. SoftBank's disclosures to investors are also under scrutiny. Arora, who stepped down after being cleared of misconduct allegations by an independent board group, had previously been seen as Masayoshi Son's heir apparent. The inquiry is a preliminary step and does not guarantee further action against the company or its former executive.

site_title: South Korean household debt burden grows, no default risk seen for now
summary: South Korea's household debt burden grew 11.4% in the first half of the year, outpacing disposable income, according to the Bank of Korea. Household credit reached 1,223.7 trillion won as of March, with delinquency rates improving since 2013. However, the bank warned that prolonged low interest rates could lead to further debt growth and cautioned that low-income households may default on debt. Despite this, the bank deemed the risk of mass defaults "very low."

site_title: Three-quarters of US drivers say they'd cede wheel to robot: survey
summary: A survey of 1,517 US drivers found that 73% would want autonomous vehicles to take over all their driving needs, with 90% willing to let a driverless car handle their commute if they could occasionally take the wheel. This contradicts recent studies showing a lower willingness to give up the wheel. The survey also found that 41% preferred Silicon Valley to develop the software for autonomous vehicles, while 27% and 25% preferred US and Japanese automakers, respectively. By 2020, the market for autonomous-related components is expected to surpass $20 billion, with self-driving cars potentially saving $325 billion in fuel costs and reducing accidents.

site_title: Duterte sworn in as the Philippines' 16th president
summary: Rodrigo Duterte, a 71-year-old authoritarian leader, was sworn in as the Philippines' 16th president on June 30, 2016. His six-year term will focus on a "war on crime" with plans to reintroduce the death penalty, issue shoot-to-kill orders, and offer bounties for the bodies of drug dealers. Duterte has also proposed night curfews for children and a ban on alcohol sales after midnight. His administration has sparked controversy and criticism from human rights groups, with concerns about links to vigilante death squads and extrajudicial killings.

site_title: 10 ways Duterte plans to change the Philippines
summary: Rodrigo Duterte was sworn in as Philippine president after a landslide election victory, pledging to make 10 significant changes during his six-year term. These include: implementing a federal system to decentralize power, ending decades-old rebellions, slowing population growth, addressing economic inequality, and introducing strict laws against corruption and crime. Duterte also plans to change the constitution, improve internet connectivity, and strengthen ties with China, while also dealing with issues such as the death penalty, karaoke bans, and late dictator Ferdinand Marcos' burial.

site_title: Fashion meets technology at new Berlin exhibition
summary: A new exhibition, "Fashion Fusion", has opened in Berlin, showcasing innovative young designers who combine fashion and technology. The exhibition offers cash prizes, including 20,000 euros, to the best designs. Featured items include a body odor-neutralizing yoga outfit and a dress with lights and light-reflecting jewelry. The exhibition aims to encourage the merger of fashion and technology industries.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on global rally as Brexit shock eases
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday, following a surge in Europe and New York, as investors became increasingly optimistic that the UK's Brexit shock would not have a severe impact on the global economy. The pound held onto most of its gains versus the dollar, while other higher-yielding currencies also benefited from speculation of monetary easing measures. Asian markets rose, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul each gaining between 0.4-1.1% as traders followed strong leads from the US and Europe.

site_title: Support seen for Spring Singapore to enforce Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act: MTI
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) reported strong public support for Spring Singapore to administer the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act, citing a four-week consultation that ended on June 15. Respondents expressed support for giving Spring investigative and enforcement powers, as well as measures to monitor and penalize errant retailers. The proposed amendments aim to provide greater protection for consumers and enable informed purchasing decisions. The CPFTA (Amendment) Bill is expected to be tabled in parliament by the end of this year.

site_title: MAS looking to clarify use of cloud technology by banks
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is developing a new policy for cloud computing in the banking sector amid growing concerns over the use of cloud services. MAS Chief Fintech Officer Sopnendu Mohanty stated that banks need clarity on cloud technology to manage rising infrastructure costs. He also noted that startups are disrupting traditional banking infrastructure, while banks must collaborate with fintechs to build more agile technology. The new policy aims to address these concerns and provide clearer guidelines for banks to adopt cloud computing effectively.

site_title: FLASH: Public car park charges to be raised 10-20 Singapore cents per half hour from Dec 1
summary: Singapore public carpark charges will increase by 10-20 cents per half hour starting December 1, according to the government's announcement. This change aims to align charges with inflation rates and improve the country's carparking system. The exact amount of the increase will be determined based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation rate. The new charges are expected to take effect on December 1, 2016.

site_title: Global M&A drops by a third in Q2 as mega deals seen too risky
summary: Global mergers and acquisitions (M&A) dropped by 32.5% in Q2 2016 to $839 billion, the lowest value since 2014, due to concerns over regulatory and tax risks, as well as national security. Mega deals have become too risky, causing company executives to reconsider complex transactions. The US, Europe, and Britain have seen a decline in M&A activity, with some deals being abandoned or terminated. Despite this, Chinese companies continue to drive M&A activity, with $121.1 billion in outbound cross-border M&A so far this year.

site_title: Moody's downgrades outlook on Singapore's banking system to negative
summary: Moody's downgraded the outlook on Singapore's banking system to negative due to worsening operating conditions, rising risks to asset quality and profitability, and slower economic and trade growth. The agency expects real GDP growth to slow to 1.6% in 2016 and 1.5% in 2017. Moody's also cited high leverage of domestic firms, energy-related industries, and shipping as concerns for banks' asset quality and profitability, with potential for problem loans to rise and net interest margins to fall. The credit rating agency rates three local banks and one international bank with negative outlooks.

images.alt_text: Moody's Investors Service has revised the outlook on Singapore's banking system to negative from stable due to worsening operating conditions and rising risks to asset quality and profitability.

site_title: Australia job vacancies fall May quarter: ABS
summary: Australia's job vacancies fell 1.9% in the March-May quarter, marking the first drop in nearly two years. Total job vacancies dipped to 169,400, with private sector vacancies decreasing 2.5% to 153,000. Public sector vacancies rose 4.5% to 16,400, the highest since early 2012. The decline suggests labor demand may have plateaued, according to analysts who value the vacancies series as a reliable leading indicator of employment growth.

site_title: Public carpark charges to be raised by 10-20 Singapore cents per half hour from Dec 1
summary: Singapore's Housing & Development Board (HDB) and Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) will raise public carpark charges by 10-20 Singapore cents per half hour starting December 1, 2016. Short-term parking charges outside the restricted zone will increase to 60 cents per half hour, while charges within the restricted zone will rise to $1.20 per half hour. This marks the first increase in 14 years.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rise, partly recouping Brexit falls
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose for a second consecutive session on June 30, 2016, regaining 1.36% after a 5.2% decline following the UK's Brexit vote. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 70 points to 5,212.4, recouping half of its losses. Analysts attribute the recovery to a market looking to retrace losses from the Brexit shock.

site_title: North Korea leader Kim Jong Un gets new 'top post'
summary: North Korea's Supreme People's Assembly has unanimously elected Kim Jong Un as chairman of the State Affairs Commission, effectively making him the supreme head of state. This move solidifies Kim's absolute control over state policy, replacing the National Defence Commission as the country's highest governing body. The decision marks a break from his father's legacy and cements Kim's position as a supreme leader, with three vice-chairmen under him overseeing military, party, and governmental affairs.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks join global rally, recover losses from Brexit
summary: Seoul's won and stocks rallied after the Brexit vote, recovering losses. The won rose 0.7% to 1,152.5, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) gained 0.4% to 1,964.62 points. Foreigners returned to local equities, and exporters sold US dollars, supporting the won. The rally was also driven by a rise in global oil prices and US stocks. However, the won is still expected to post a loss for the month and quarter.

site_title: South Korea May factory output growth fastest in 3 months, beats forecasts
summary: South Korea's industrial output rose 2.5% in May, beating forecasts, driven by car and semiconductor production. This is the fastest growth since February, but faces risks from weak investment and poor exports. Despite a 4.3% year-on-year increase, analysts warn that factory activity remains volatile unless interest rates are lowered again. The central bank has already cut rates, and the government is providing fiscal stimulus to boost growth. Exports have been falling since January last year, and June data is due.

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare launches S$100m SGD bond offer backed by ADB fund
summary: Fullerton Healthcare Corporation has successfully launched a SGD 100 million bond offering, backed by the Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The offering consists of two tranches, with a 5-year tranche priced at 2.45% and a 7-year tranche priced at 2.75%. The funds will be used to strengthen the group's financial position and reduce reliance on bank borrowings. This is the first SGD bond issue in the healthcare sector supported by CGIF's credit guarantee, with CIMB and OCBC leading the bond issuance.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.05 points to 1644.260 on Thursday, driven by a gainers-to-losers ratio of 93 to 48. The index saw a volume of 40.69 million lots worth RM14.44 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rally at open, extend global gains
summary: Tokyo shares rallied 1.19% at open, extending global gains amid fears about Britain's EU vote impact. The Nikkei 225 index jumped to 15,752.71, while the Topix index rose 1.18% to 1,262.42. The rally follows a similar trend in global markets, with US stocks also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: UK car production up 26% in May
summary: UK car production rose 26% in May, reaching 150,802 vehicles, driven by strong demand for exports. This growth is partly due to the industry's reliance on tariff-free access to Europe, which is now uncertain. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) urges the government to maintain economic stability and ensure free access to the EU market to sustain the sector's competitiveness.

images.alt_text: British car production rose by 26 per cent year on year in May thanks to particularly strong demand for exports, but momentum could be halted by a loss of tariff-free access to Europe, an industry body said on Thursday.

site_title: Ringgit, won join relief rallies driving gains in global stocks
summary: Malaysia's ringgit and South Korea's won rose for a third consecutive day, driven by a rally in emerging-market assets after the UK's Brexit vote. The ringgit is close to erasing losses since June 23, while the won rose after beating forecasts for factory output data. Crude oil prices rebounded above $50 a barrel, alleviating concerns about Malaysia's oil revenue. The currency gains are attributed to global central bankers' support and a lack of capitulation in markets.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's ringgit and the South Korean won rose for a third day as a rally in emerging-market assets continued after last week's selloff in the wake of the UK decision to leave the European Union.

site_title: Gold slips as risk appetite sharpens on dwindling Brexit angst
summary: Gold prices declined by 0.4% to $1,314.18 an ounce due to increased risk appetite as Brexit angst dwindled. The metal jumped to a two-year high in June after the Brexit vote, but is now heading for a second quarterly gain. Gold has risen 24% this year as demand for haven assets surged and interest rate bets were factored in. Asian shares rose for the second day, with markets breathing a sigh of relief following central banks' readiness to act if required.

site_title: Funan to close for three years for redevelopment
summary: Singapore's Funan DigitaLife Mall to close for three years for redevelopment. The mall, operational for 31 years, will host a "thank you" party for tenants, shoppers, and staff before closing on Thursday night. CapitaLand, the mall's owner, will undertake a three-year redevelopment project. Funan is considered the definitive IT mall of the last three decades and holds a special place in the hearts of Singaporeans.

site_title: China facing hard work to meet annual budget targets: People's Daily
summary: China faces a challenging task to meet its annual budget targets due to a significant rise in fiscal expenditures, which rose 13.6% in the first five months of the year. Expenditures in May increased 17.6% from a year earlier. Finance Minister Lou Jiwei expressed concerns, stating that meeting full-year budget targets will require "a lot of hard work" amid a broader economic slowdown.

site_title: US dollar edges down, sterling steadies after traumatic month
summary: The US dollar edged down 0.1% to 95.642 against a basket of currencies, near a 3.5-month high, after a traumatic month following Britain's Brexit vote. Sterling steadied at 1.3456, while the euro fell 0.2% to 82.67 pence. Investors await clarity on the UK's economic outlook, despite hopes that the worst is over for currencies and equities.

site_title: Singapore May bank lending up on higher manufacturing loans
summary: Singapore's total bank lending in May rose to S$592.8 billion, up from S$589.8 billion in April, driven by stronger demand for manufacturing loans, which increased to S$29.1 billion. Housing and bridging loans also grew to S$186.5 billion. This increase marks a reversal from the decline in April, where lending declined due to the previous month's manufacturing loan drop.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence rises to 6-month high in June
summary: New Zealand business confidence reached a six-month high in June, according to an ANZ Bank survey, with 20.2% of respondents expecting the economy to improve over the next year. This represents an increase from 11.3% in the previous poll. Additionally, 35.1% of respondents expected their businesses to grow in the next 12 months, up from 30.4% last month. Inflation expectations also rose to 1.49%.

site_title: Singapore shares open 61 points higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 60.98 points to 2,853.71, driven by a Wall Street rally and easing Brexit worries. Over 235 million shares worth S$413 million were traded at 9am, with 113 counters up and 29 down. The 5-day rally continues ahead of GDP data, while investors remain optimistic despite US tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Brexit due to 'decades' of British blame: EU official
summary: A senior EU official, Cecilia Malmstroem, attributes Britain's decision to leave the EU to decades of British officials blaming the EU for their country's problems, rather than a proposed trans-Atlantic trade pact. Malmstroem says the Brexit is not linked to the EU trade pact, citing a lack of transparency as a reason to dismiss this claim. Despite the UK's exit, both sides express a willingness to finalize the trade deal.

site_title: IMF will lower growth forecast for German economy after Brexit
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is expected to lower its growth forecast for the German economy due to Britain's decision to leave the European Union. The IMF's assistant director, Enrica Detragiache, stated that the uncertainty surrounding the new economic relationship between Germany and the UK will hurt growth prospects. The IMF had previously forecast a 1.7% growth rate for Germany in 2016, but is likely to revise this downward. The decision is expected to reduce German exports and slow growth by up to half a percentage point next year.

site_title: Amazon expands private label push with expansion into food
summary: Amazon has expanded its private-label food offerings with the introduction of organic "Mama Bear" baby food and "Happy Belly" coffee, available exclusively to Prime subscribers. This marks the company's first foray into the food industry, as it seeks to control the product path from creation to purchase. Amazon already sells over 3,000 private-label products across various categories. The move aims to boost loyalty and profits, aligning with Amazon's long-term goal to offer the largest selection of products worldwide.

site_title: Pound, euro maintain climb in post-Brexit market pause
summary: Financial markets experienced a rebound in post-Brexit sentiment, with the pound and euro rising against the US dollar. The euro reached $1.1124 and the pound rose 0.9% to $1.3455, after a period of selling. Investors' fears about the global economy's impact from Brexit appear to be receding, with markets showing a "pause in the selling" rather than a significant improvement. The US dollar eased back after a surge earlier in the week.

images.alt_text: The pound and the euro extended gains Wednesday but remained far below their levels before Britain voted last week to quit the European Union.

site_title: China growth rebounds in Q2, but may not last: survey
summary: China's economy rebounded in the second quarter, driven by higher government spending and a strong rebound in the services sector. Private investment growth, however, remains at a record low, and economists question the accuracy of official statistics. The rebound is expected to be short-lived, with CBB CEO Leland Miller expressing concerns that China's willingness to rebalance the economy is lacking, and that the country is unlikely to maintain its current growth trajectory.

site_title: China Beige Book shows rebound from recent lows as services gain
summary: China's economy showed a sharp reversal from recent weakness in the second quarter, according to the China Beige Book, with services and construction driving the growth. The report, released by CBB International, indicates a moderate growth rebound, echoing that of a year ago. Services are seen as a sustainable source of growth, while construction is considered a temporary boost. Despite the improvement, output, new domestic orders, and payables weakened over the past year, and the economy is projected to slow to 6.6% in the second quarter and 6.5% in the following two quarters.

site_title: Facebook to put friends, family ahead of media
summary: Facebook is changing its algorithm to prioritize posts from friends and family over media outlets, potentially hurting news organizations that rely on the platform for traffic and advertising revenue. The update aims to show users the most relevant stories, rather than relying on trending topics. The move comes after Facebook faced scrutiny over allegations of suppressing certain viewpoints, but the company says it's committed to neutrality. The change may impact 1.6 billion users, with 66% of US Facebook users getting news on the platform.

site_title: After Brexit, Asia should strengthen its regional safety net
summary: The UK's exit from the European Union, known as Brexit, has sent shockwaves around the world, causing financial markets to jitter and sparking concerns about global economic instability. Asian markets have also been affected, with the Nikkei falling by 7.9% and the Hang Seng declining by 2.9%. To mitigate the impact, Asian countries should strengthen their regional safety net, which includes the Asean+3 Regional Financial Safety Net (RFSN). This network, comprising the Chiang Mai Initiative Multilateralization and the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office, can provide a cushion against future financial crises.

site_title: North America leaders mount strong defence of trade despite threats
summary: North American leaders, including US President Barack Obama, Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto, and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, defended free trade despite growing concerns about its impact. They criticized US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, who has vowed to renegotiate or scrap the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). The leaders emphasized the importance of their economic relationship and warned against isolationism and populism, which they say would harm prosperity.

images.alt_text: Canada, the United States and Mexico on Wednesday mounted a fierce defence of free trade, vowing to deepen economic ties despite an increasingly acrimonious debate about the value of globalisation.

site_title: UK parties head for leadership battles amid Brexit fallout
summary: Britain's main opposition Labour Party is set for a leadership battle following the EU referendum, with Angela Eagle announcing her challenge against leader Jeremy Corbyn. Eagle, a former pensions minister, has joined a growing revolt within the party, with over 20 people resigning from Corbyn's opposition policy team. This mirrors a similar fight for control of the ruling Conservative Party, which is also reeling from the Brexit fallout.

images.alt_text: Britain's main opposition Labour Party headed for a leadership battle, mirroring a fight for control of the ruling Conservative Party, after the decision by voters to leave the European Union last week led to upheaval in Westminster.

site_title: Canada's hottest real estate market to end self regulation
summary: British Columbia, Canada, will end self-regulation of the real estate industry to address concerns of unethical practices stoking home prices in Vancouver. The move follows an independent panel's recommendations to impose tougher oversight and transparency. Fines for brokerages engaging in misconduct will be raised to up to C$500,000, and agents will no longer be allowed to represent both buyers and sellers. The government will also start working on taxing owners of empty properties and appoint a new superintendent to oversee regulation. This comes amid record home prices and concerns of a housing market bubble.

images.alt_text: Canada's province of British Columbia will end self regulation of the real estate industry as government officials move to rein in unethical practices that may be stoking home prices in Vancouver, one of North America's fastest-appreciating cities.

site_title: Obama to campaign with Clinton, Trump shrinks gap
summary: US President Barack Obama will campaign with Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton for the first time on July 5, as a new poll shows the presidential election between Clinton and Republican Donald Trump narrowing to a 2-point margin. The joint appearance comes with Clinton aiming to become the nation's first female president, despite Senator Bernie Sanders' refusal to bow out of the nomination race. A recent poll by Quinnipiac University shows Clinton leading Trump 42-40%, with 61% of respondents believing the election has increased hatred and prejudice across the country.

site_title: Chinese companies relisting at home attract swarm of quick-hit investors
summary: Chinese companies are taking advantage of funds offering a mechanism to cancel overseas listings and relist in Shanghai or Shenzhen, attracting quick-hit investors. These firms can enjoy higher valuations due to China's regulatory framework. Companies such as Chongqing New Century Cruise and Giant Interactive Group have seen significant gains after relisting in China. However, regulators are concerned that retail investors could be in over their heads, and tightening rules have been implemented to curb speculation around shell companies.

site_title: Oil halts 2-day rally after US supply erases post-Brexit slump
summary: Oil futures declined 1.2% in New York after advancing 7.7% over the previous two days, halting a two-day rally. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 4.05 million-barrel drop in crude stockpiles, the sixth straight decline to the lowest since March. Crude prices have climbed 80% from their 12-year low in February due to global supply disruptions and falling US output. Despite uncertainty from the Brexit referendum, oil demand is expected to continue growing as US vacationers take to the road.

site_title: Futurist author Alvin Toffler dies at age 87
summary: Alvin Toffler, a renowned US author and futurist, has died at his home in Los Angeles at the age of 87. He was best known for his world best-sellers "Future Shock" and "The Third Wave," which predicted social change, technological developments, and economic shifts. Toffler's work influenced world leaders and moguls, including Mikhail Gorbachev and Carlos Slim, and his book "Future Shock" has sold over 15 million copies worldwide. He is survived by his wife of over 60 years, Heidi Toffler.

site_title: UK consumer confidence tumbles after Brexit vote
summary: UK consumer confidence plummeted after the Brexit vote, falling to its lowest level since May 2013, according to a survey. The YouGov/CEBR Consumer Confidence Index dropped to 104.3 from 111.9 in the first three weeks of June. Experts warn of a recession, citing hurt retail sales and household spending, particularly on big-ticket items. Bank of England Governor Mark Carney is set to address concerns, following his previous warning of a recession if the UK leaves the EU.

images.alt_text: Confidence among British consumers fell sharply in the days after the country decided to leave the European Union, according to a survey published on Thursday which gave a first glimpse of how the shock referendum result has affected households.

site_title: US: Stocks extend rally after Brexit rout
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive day, driven by easing concerns over Britain's EU exit and its economic impact. The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 1.6% to 17,694.68. European markets also rallied, following a two-day slump after the UK voted to leave the EU. The US stock market extended its rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Windows 10 anniversary update set for August
summary: Microsoft will release the Windows 10 Anniversary Update on August 2, marking the one-year anniversary of the operating system. The update promises improved security, enhanced capabilities for the Microsoft Edge browser, and the addition of Microsoft Ink, which supports digital pens for tasks like writing and math problems. The update also allows virtual assistant Cortana to handle more commands and syncs with Xbox One consoles to play video games, making Windows computers easier to set up and use in schools.

images.alt_text: Microsoft on Wednesday said it will mark the one-year anniversary of Windows 10 with a major update to the software powering more than 350 million computing devices.

site_title: Abu Dhabi plans merger of sovereign funds Mubadala, IPIC
summary: Abu Dhabi plans to merge its sovereign funds, Mubadala and IPIC, to consolidate assets worth around $135 billion and debt of $42 billion amid the oil price slump. UAE Deputy Prime Minister Mansour bin Zayed Al Nahyan and Oil Minister Suhail Al Mazroui will oversee the deal. The merger aims to strengthen the emirate's financial position and is part of a broader strategy of consolidation.

site_title: World's largest uncut diamond fails to sell in London
summary: The world's largest uncut diamond, the 1,109-carat Lesedi La Rona, failed to sell at an auction in London after bids fell short of the reserve price of US$61 million. The gemstone, discovered in 2015 by the Lucara Diamond Corp, was predicted to sell for over US$70 million. The auctioneer was unable to persuade bidders to exceed the reserve price, resulting in the diamond's failure to sell.

site_title: New Zika diagnostics needed for babies: researchers
summary: Researchers are calling for better diagnostics to identify brain-damaged babies born with Zika virus. Two studies in Brazil found that over 100 babies infected with Zika in the womb had normal-sized heads, making it difficult to diagnose microcephaly. Existing tests, such as skull measurements and rash checks, are not sufficient to detect all Zika-affected children. Doctors are advised to screen for brain abnormalities using ultrasound exams and improve detection of Zika virus in blood. A new wave of Zika infections in southeast Brazil may lead to a second wave of microcephaly births.

site_title: Hollande bullish on French economy
summary: French President Francois Hollande is optimistic about the French economy, predicting growth of 1.6% this year and 1.7% in 2017, with at least 200,000 new jobs. He attributed the expected rebound to household spending and warned of potential negative effects from the UK's Brexit vote, calling for a swift European response. Hollande's comments come as his government faces record-low approval ratings and mass protests ahead of next year's presidential election.

site_title: Japan plans July fighter jet tender seen worth US$40b as China tensions simmer
summary: Japan plans to launch a fighter jet tender in mid-July worth up to $40 billion, seeking to bolster its air defenses amid tensions with China over disputed maritime borders. The F-3 fighter jet program, expected to involve US firms Boeing and Lockheed Martin, will replace existing Mitsubishi F-2 jets and operate alongside Lockheed F-35 fighters. Japan is also open to importing existing jets or producing them under license, and the final decision is likely in summer 2018, with deployment due in the 2020s.

site_title: Brazil has 'total confidence' in Olympics security
summary: Brazil has expressed "total confidence" in its ability to ensure security for the upcoming Rio Olympics, with a heavy police presence and international cooperation on intelligence gathering expected to counter potential terror threats and violent crime. Over 47,000 police officers and 38,000 soldiers will be deployed, with background checks on nearly 394,000 people completed so far. Authorities have also implemented measures to secure airports and prevent attacks involving aircraft, following recent attacks in other countries.

site_title: Commodity currency gains shore up A$, NZ$
summary: Commodity currencies, such as the Australian and New Zealand dollar, surged higher on Wednesday after the Brexit referendum, as investors sought safety and riskier currencies rebounded from their previous decline. The New Zealand dollar rose over 1% and the Australian dollar gained 0.6%, while sterling recovered from its biggest one-day fall in history. Analysts attribute the recovery to a decrease in interest rate expectations from the US Federal Reserve, which has led to a 10% chance of a cut by September.

site_title: Britain's Theresa May launches bid to succeed PM
summary: Theresa May, Britain's interior minister, has launched her bid to succeed Prime Minister David Cameron as the country navigates the aftermath of its vote to leave the European Union. May, a conservative leader, supported remaining in the EU but played a low-key role in the campaign. Her bid aims to unite Britain, with a focus on working-class voters, ahead of the expected transition of power in early September. May's hardline stance on immigration and her stern demeanor have drawn comparisons to former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

site_title: After Brexit, UN 'more important' to Britain
summary: Britain's membership on the UN Security Council has become more important for asserting London's global power following the Brexit vote, according to British Ambassador Matthew Rycroft. Britain will retain its veto power and lead diplomatic efforts on key issues, including Libya, Yemen, and Somalia. Rycroft expects Britain to be more active at the UN as a prime forum for international engagement and pledged cooperation with European countries to counter Russia's influence. The move reflects Britain's shift in foreign policy following the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: SingPost AGM: chance to ask about goodwill issues
summary: SingPost's annual report reveals interesting numbers ahead of its upcoming AGM, including assumptions underlying goodwill for several acquisitions, including freight forwarders Famous Holdings and e-commerce firms TradeGlobal and Jagged Peak. Despite slashing average cash flow growth rates, the company did not book impairments on goodwill, sparking concerns about the robustness of its estimates. The report also shows that goodwill now makes up a significant portion of SingPost's balance sheet, with TradeGlobal and Famous Holdings being the biggest contributors. Shareholders will have a chance to question these numbers at the AGM.

site_title: Drugmaker AstraZeneca pushes to protect Crestor from generic competition
summary: AstraZeneca is attempting to extend the market exclusivity of its best-selling cholesterol-lowering drug Crestor by 7 years by getting it approved to treat a rare disease in children. The company argues that this approval is entitled to the Orphan Drug Act, but critics say it is an abuse of the law, as Crestor is primarily used to treat high cholesterol in adults. The FDA has yet to decide on the matter, which could impact the introduction of generic competition to the drug on July 8, potentially weighing heavily on AstraZeneca's bottom line.

site_title: Smartphone users face more scrutiny as Beijing cracks down on apps
summary: Beijing has introduced new laws requiring app stores and providers to establish users' identity, monitor and report banned content, and verify developers' legitimacy. The regulations, posted on the Cyberspace Administration of China's website, aim to increase scrutiny on smartphone users in China, with over half a billion users potentially affected. The move is part of the Chinese government's efforts to tighten control over online content and maintain social order.

site_title: STI bounces back to pre-Brexit level
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore surged 36.2 points to 2,792.73 on June 29, 2016, rebounding to its pre-Brexit level. Banks, Jardine Cycle & Carriage, Thai Beverage, and Singtel contributed to the rise. Despite the index's strength, the market saw limited gains, with 262 rises versus 135 falls, and notable short-covering. Investors may have anticipated the end of the quarter and second half of 2016, but the market's resilience was also influenced by the potential for central banks to implement easier monetary policies.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, Santander fail US Fed stress test
summary: US operations of Deutsche Bank and Santander failed the annual stress test conducted by the Federal Reserve, citing weaknesses in capital planning and risk management. Deutsche Bank failed for the second year, while Santander failed for the third year. The Fed granted conditional approval to Morgan Stanley to return funds to shareholders, while 30 other large financial institutions received full endorsements. The Fed's report highlighted improved resilience of the US financial system, but noted significant issues in internal audits and risk management processes at the two European banks.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that US operations of Germany's Deutsche Bank and Spain's Santander had failed an annual stress test, citing weaknesses in their capital planning and risk management.

site_title: Elite 8 set for showdown; tough to predict final 4
summary: The European Championships in France have narrowed down to the Elite 8, with teams ready to resume their quest for the Henri Delaunay trophy. Iceland, a dark horse, defeated England 2-1 in a stunning match, while France, the host nation, has wobbled into the quarter-finals. Wales and Belgium are also looking strong, with Wales facing Belgium in their next match. The standout fixtures include Iceland vs. France and Germany vs. Italy, with Germany seeking to break their losing streak against Italy.

site_title: Financial strength of some insurers here could be sapped in short term
summary: Singapore's financially strong insurers may see their capital adequacy ratios (CAR) decline in the short term due to prolonged Brexit-related market volatility. Insurers with significant equity holdings, such as those offering universal life policies, are most vulnerable. To mitigate this risk, insurers are considering financial reinsurance and derivatives. Despite this, some insurers, like Aviva Singapore, have already seen significant CARs, ranging from 204% to 267%. The impact on insurers' financial strength is expected to be manageable, but will be closely reflected in their reported solvency capital ratios under Solvency II requirements.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Geo Energy Resources sold All Win Holdings to PT Autum Bara Sejahtera for $10 million. Second Chance Properties reported a 27.59% drop in net profit to $3.14 million due to property valuation losses and lower revenue. Singtel completed a trans-Pacific submarine cable system, the Faster cable, which delivers 60 terabits per second of bandwidth. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall.

site_title: Lessons for Asia from Brexit: be careful with deep integration
summary: Asia should adopt a pragmatic approach to deeper economic and political ties, avoiding ideological extremes, following the lessons of Brexit. While the UK's exit from the EU has created a mess, Asia can learn from the EU's mistakes and pursue a "golden mean" of cooperation. A strict pragmatism is needed to balance economic benefits with potential risks and ensure that Asia's approach to regional integration is guided by careful consideration rather than emotional reactions. This approach can help Asia achieve more stable and sustainable economic and political ties.

site_title: Conversion programme launched for PMETs to join logistics industry
summary: Singapore has launched a Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) for Professionals, Managers, Executives, and Technicians (PMETs) to join the logistics industry. The 2-year programme will provide training and support for 150 PMETs in logistics roles, with 10 firms committed to the programme. The government will cover 70% of trainees' salaries, with enhanced support for long-term unemployed or aged 40+ PMETs. The move aims to help logistics companies leverage technology and talent to deliver cheaper, better, and faster services.

site_title: M'sians to pay up to 8% more for piped natural gas
summary: Malaysians will face a 8% increase in piped natural gas bills starting July 1, with prices rising from RM18.20 to RM19.70 per million British thermal units. The hike, which affects businesses as well, is expected to further burden the economy despite unchanged electricity tariffs. The price increase is the latest blow to the country's struggling economy, which has been impacted by a diminishing ringgit.

site_title: Islamic State blamed for Turkey airport attacks
summary: At Istanbul's Ataturk airport, coordinated suicide attacks killed at least 41 people, including 13 foreigners, during a busy travel time. Islamic State is likely responsible, according to Turkish Prime Minister Binali Yildirim. The attack further worsens Turkey's tourism crisis. Thirteen nationalities were affected, including Saudis, a Chinese national, and a Ukrainian.

site_title: Media firms losing control of news to tech platforms
summary: Media firms are losing control of news to tech platforms, with social media companies filtering and delivering news through automated feeds and algorithms. Facebook, Google, and other tech companies are becoming dominant forces in the news ecosystem, while news organisations are joining the wave of social news, sacrificing editorial control. This shift has led to concerns about the quality of news and the potential for algorithms to suppress conservative viewpoints, as well as questions about transparency and accountability.

site_title: Short-term nimbleness key to navigating volatile markets: Dymon Asia
summary: Dymon Asia Capital's chief investment officer, Danny Yong, attributes the firm's remarkable outperformance to its ability to spot and capitalize on short-term market opportunities in volatile conditions. Yong believes the global economy is headed for a "catharsis" driven by trends such as the US dollar's secular uptrend, weak economic growth, and "reverse globalisation". Central banks' efforts to stimulate demand have been ineffective, and governments may eventually need to coordinate fiscal spending to pump up demand. Investors must be nimble and adapt to these changes to navigate the markets.

images.alt_text: Markets today are buffeted by unprecedented macroeconomic conditions, and making money in the turbulence requires investors to be nimble and to distinguish long-term convictions from short-term opportunities, said Danny Yong, chief investment officer of Dymon Asia Capital.

site_title: VW's diesel settlement in US clears only one of many hurdles
summary: Volkswagen agreed to pay up to $14.7 billion to settle US claims related to its diesel emissions deception. The settlement includes $10.03 billion to buy back affected cars and $2.7 billion for environmental compensation. However, the company faces more scrutiny globally, particularly in the US and Europe, with ongoing criminal investigations and potential additional compensation for European owners. The settlement's final cost may be higher, with some estimates suggesting it could reach $24.3 billion.

images.alt_text: Although emissions rules in Europe are more lenient than in the US, Volkswagen may still have to pay up there, with the increasing outcry from millions of European VW owners and politicians for compensation.

site_title: EgyptAir black box confirms smoke on board: probe
summary: EgyptAir Flight 804 crashed on May 19, killing 66 people, with data from one black box revealing smoke alarms sounded and soot found on the wreckage. The Airbus A320 made a 90-degree left turn and a 360-degree turn before hitting the sea. Investigators confirm high temperature damage and soot on the front section of the aircraft, consistent with ACARS messages of lavatory and avionics smoke. The search for remains continues, with both Egyptian and French judiciary opening investigations into the incident, which may have been deliberately downed.

images.alt_text: Data from one of the black boxes of a crashed EgyptAir plane showed smoke alarms had sounded on board, while soot was found on the wreckage, an Egyptian-led investigative committee said Wednesday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks recoup more Brexit losses as commodity shares rise
summary: European stocks rose for the second day, recouping some losses from the Brexit vote, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index climbing 3.1% and the FTSE 100 Index reaching its highest level since April. Mining and energy shares were among the best performers, as investors seek clarity on the UK's plan for secession. The UK's Prime Minister David Cameron said it will be up to his successor to formally activate the EU exit mechanism, scheduled for early September.

site_title: LHN nominee to buy Beach Road carpark property for S$26m
summary: METROPOLITAN Parking Pte Ltd, a nominee for LHN Group, has exercised an option to buy a carpark property on Beach Road for S$26 million. The property is located at Golden Mile Tower and will be operated by Metropolitan Parking, with internal resources funding the purchase. LHN Group's shareholders will contribute to the operation and purchase through equity capital and bank borrowings. The acquisition is expected to have minimal impact on earnings per share and net tangible assets. Metropolitan Parking will be funded by LHN Group's IPO proceeds and will be managed by its shareholders in a joint venture.

site_title: Fight globalisation and Brexit angst with truth
summary: A recent Brexit vote in the UK highlights global anxiety over the impact of globalization, with many nations experiencing growing concerns over integration. The decision reflects deeper issues of individual identity and sense of place in the world. While nations are better off from globalization, the internal distribution of benefits and costs is never equitable. The media's role in fueling anxiety and xenophobia has also been exposed, with politicians exploiting these fears for their own gain. Experts argue that more truth-telling is needed to address the complexities of globalization and its effects on individuals and nations.

images.alt_text: The Brexit vote, more than underscoring specific concerns of the British about the European Union, highlighted growing worldwide anxiety over the impact of globalisation.

site_title: Sparks expected at Imperium Crown's Thursday EGM
summary: Shareholders of Catalist-listed Imperium Crown (IC) will debate at the company's EGM on Thursday whether the entire board should be removed and replaced. The meeting was called by shareholders Tan Geok Bee and Yeo Wee Kok, who hold over 10% of IC's shares, due to dissatisfaction with the company's performance under the current board. The shareholders also dispute the company's decision to appoint a new executive director, contradicting an agreement made earlier. The EGM will be held at Suntec Convention and Exhibition Centre on June 30.

site_title: No single market a la carte for UK: EU leaders
summary: EU leaders have agreed that the UK cannot access the single market after Brexit without accepting the bloc's rules on free movement, including freedom of movement. The 27 leaders met without British Prime Minister David Cameron and agreed to give Britain time to absorb the shock of the Brexit vote before triggering a divorce. A summit on September 16 will discuss further fallout from the Brexit vote, with European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker setting a clear timetable for triggering Article 50, the EU treaty clause that begins the two-year withdrawal process.

site_title: Imax brings the million-dollar screening room home
summary: Imax Corp has introduced a million-dollar home screening room experience, allowing high-net-worth individuals to watch new releases in a private, high-quality cinematic setting. The 60-foot-wide, curved screen and 95-seat auditorium can be installed in a dedicated room, with costs ranging from $400,000 to $1 million. The service, called Imax Private Theatre, offers immersive sound and images, as well as additional features like gaming and karaoke. The initiative targets ultra-high-net-worth individuals in China and the Middle East, where a growing demand for premium entertainment experiences is driving growth for the exhibitor.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. The US stock market opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected H2 revenue, similar to H1 operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.
