This compact Opel model is lighter, weighing in at just 1,233 kg

site_title: Asian currencies spared - for now
summary: Asian currencies avoided significant fluctuations following the UK's EU split vote, but strategists warn of further weakening due to lingering uncertainty. The Asian markets' relative stability contrasts with turmoil in the UK and European economies. Policymakers are urged to address expected volatility in regional currencies.

images.alt_text: Asian currencies were spared much of the turmoil their British and European counterparts experienced on Friday.

site_title: Alone
summary: Golf player Bryson DeChambeau had a positive experience despite missing the cut at the Shell Houston Open. He shot seven over par for two days and expressed confidence in his abilities, stating he knows his game is good, even if he's not hitting the ball well. DeChambeau's optimism suggests he remains focused on improving his performance.

site_title: Crowds enquire at money changers, but few buy £
summary: People in Singapore flocked to money changers after the UK's "Brexit" decision, but few bought the British pound. Many money changers suspended trading or said they were out of stock, with some offering unfavorable exchange rates. Some individuals, like a Singaporean student, took advantage of the weakening pound to buy more pounds for their Sing dollars, while others, like a local, planned to invest in local stocks instead. The pound's value dropped to S$1.88 at the close of the Singapore market on Friday.

images.alt_text: People flocked to money changers on Friday after news of "Brexit" broke, sending the pound down - but for many, it was only to check out the pound-Sing dollar exchange rate.

site_title: Najib sacks critics Muhyiddin, Mukhriz from Umno
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak sacked former Deputy Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin and Mukhriz Mahathir, son of former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, from the ruling party Umno. The move came after the pair criticized Najib over graft allegations related to 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB). Najib, facing intense pressure, announced a Cabinet reshuffle, although a timeline was not provided. The sacking follows a landslide win for the ruling coalition in recent by-elections and state elections, prompting speculation about potential snap polls.

site_title: Rule No.1 in the sand
summary: A common mistake among golfers is setting up for bunker shots as if they were pitch or chip shots, pushing the hands ahead to hit the ball first. In reality, for a greenside bunker shot, the goal is to hit the sand first, allowing the ball to bounce and lift. This technique can help reduce the risk of chunking or hitting the sand too hard, resulting in a more controlled and predictable shot. By hitting the sand first, golfers can better control the trajectory and spin of the ball.

site_title: Modern golf and getting kids into the mix
summary: Golf is struggling to attract young players, with many kids giving up after finding the game too boring or slow-moving. According to golf enthusiasts, their kids have attended driving ranges but quickly lose interest. This trend is concerning for the sport's future, as golf's growth and popularity are heavily dependent on the involvement of younger generations. To address this issue, golfers and instructors are exploring new ways to make the game more engaging and accessible to kids.

site_title: Go defensive as UK-exposed stocks slide
summary: Singapore stocks slid on Friday after the UK's vote to leave the European Union, with companies linked to the British pound taking a hit. Analysts say yield stocks and those linked to gold prices are likely to outperform in the wake of the Brexit. Key companies affected include ComfortDelGro, GL Ltd, City Developments (CDL), and Sembcorp Industries, with some analysts predicting a 5-10% drop in the pound could dent CDL's revenue by 0.4-1.2%. In contrast, miners like CNMC Goldmine and Anchor Resources are expected to benefit from higher gold prices.

site_title: Regulators query London base for merged Deutsche Boerse-LSE
summary: Regulators and a senior German politician have raised doubts about a merged Deutsche Boerse-London Stock Exchange being based in London, following Britain's vote to leave the EU. The combined company, valued at $30 billion, was set to be headquartered in both London and Frankfurt. Despite assurances from the exchanges that the deal would go ahead, regulators and politicians are questioning the feasibility of a London base, citing concerns over the UK's future relationship with the EU.

site_title: Would you like some booze with your books?
summary: Barnes & Noble is revamping its store design to include larger café areas offering wine, beer, and expanded food menus, as well as table service, in an effort to boost traffic and grow food and beverage sales. The retailer aims to make its stores more experiential, with plans to add more seating, host events, and expand its merchandise offerings. Investors responded positively to the plans, with the company's stock rising almost 8% on Thursday. The company expects flat to one percent growth in sales this year and plans to close just eight stores.

site_title: The best and worst of Euro 2016 at half-time
summary: Euro 2016 has reached its halfway mark, with 16 teams remaining after the completion of all group stage matches. Wales has emerged as the best team, topping a tough group with six points and six goals. Iceland's surprise run continues, while Sweden has been the biggest flop, failing to register a shot on target in their first two matches. Fan violence in Marseille was a notable worst moment, and Dimitri Payet's goal against Romania was a standout performance. The most exciting match was Hungary's 3-3 draw with Portugal, which saw both teams fight back multiple times.

site_title: The big questions raised by Brexit
summary: The UK's Brexit referendum has amplified broader European politics, highlighting trends of national and local identities rising, a divide over global prosperity, and questions about the future of European integration. The vote has also raised concerns about the future of the transatlantic alliance, the liberal international order, and how smaller European nations can engage with major powers like the US and China. The outcome has created openings for Russia and China to subvert the West, and has sparked domestic insurgencies in major powers, with potentially widespread strategic and economic consequences.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CDL, a Singapore property developer, reported its UK exposure to be 12% in terms of revenue, assets, and debt as of Dec 31, 2015. The company remains confident in the UK economy's long-term fundamentals. China Environment shares were suspended due to the resignation of two executive directors and the requirement to refile financial statements. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times.

site_title: After Brexit, what next?
summary: The UK has formally triggered Brexit, with two years to negotiate its way out of the European Union. The country's next prime minister will be responsible for negotiating the terms of the UK's departure, with options including the Norwegian Model, a free trade agreement, or trading under World Trade Organization rules. Key issues include regulating the UK's annual $575 billion trade with the EU, accessing the EU's $13.6 trillion single market, and preserving the UK's financial services sector's "passporting" rights. The outcome will depend on negotiations with EU leaders, who may prioritize a pragmatic approach over a favorable deal for the UK.

site_title: A technology company that delivers
summary: CHASSasia, a technology company with over 25 years of experience, continues to expand rapidly in South-east Asia, operating across various industries. The company, valued as a managed service provider, aims to ensure customers fully appreciate their technology investments. CHASSasia has a direct entity presence in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and Brunei, and has been recognized by major IT brands. The company has won the SME100 Awards 2016 and will continue to innovate and simplify technology for great customer experiences, focusing on people, process, and technology.

site_title: Mini-movie inside a game
summary: Uncharted 4: A Thief's End combines narrative, cinematic, and gameplay elements, featuring a mini-movie experience where players control Nathan Drake as he navigates through a quest to find the pirate republic of Libertalia. The game boasts rich motion capture, immersive gameplay, and puzzle-solving, but lacks realistic physics. With its beautiful presentation, heartwarming narrative, and engaging gameplay, Uncharted 4: A Thief's End is a standout title in the action game franchise, although it may be too good to last.

site_title: SIA debunks speculation of majority stake in Virgin Australia
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has denied speculation of taking a majority stake in Virgin Australia (VA), stating its interests are best served through an independent VA. SIA has pledged to support VA's A$852 million cash call and could see its stake rise to 25.9% if it mops up other shares not taken up by VA's major shareholders. The move comes as VA taps its major shareholders, including HNA and the Nanshan Group, to strengthen its balance sheet and pare debt.

site_title: Southwest postpones delivery of 67 Boeing 737 Max jetliners
summary: Southwest Airlines has postponed the delivery of 67 Boeing 737 Max 8 aircraft by up to six years, affecting $1.9 billion in spending on planes. The airline is also accelerating six 737-800 orders to 2018 from next year to cover the early retirement of its oldest 737s, marking its second aircraft order book shakeup since 2013.

site_title: Fakes can be better than the real thing? Don't buy it!
summary: Alibaba's founder Jack Ma sparked controversy when he claimed that many counterfeit goods are now of better quality than genuine articles. However, experts argue that this is flawed as counterfeit products often fall short in dimensions such as serviceability and perceived quality. Counterfeits may mimic the genuine products in terms of performance and features, but they lack the after-sales support and social status associated with genuine brands. This highlights the issue of counterfeit goods being sold on Alibaba's platform, despite the company's efforts to combat them.

site_title: Brexit aftermath: UK will need to negotiate new agreements with trading partners, says MTI
summary: The UK's exit from the European Union has left it exposed to new trade agreements with its trading partners, including Singapore. The UK will need to negotiate new agreements to maintain its market access and avoid tariffs. This development is expected to have a significant impact on the UK, the EU, and the global economy. The UK's economic growth has also slowed, with its economy shrinking for the second month in a row, adding to concerns about the country's economic stability.

site_title: BNM intervenes after ringgit slides: analysts
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) intervened in the currency markets after the ringgit slumped 2.5% to 4.1207 against the US dollar on Friday, following Britain's decision to leave the European Union. Analysts predict further losses for the ringgit, which could reach 4.50 to the US dollar, as emerging markets are hit by the Brexit domino effect. Despite BNM's support, the Malaysian stock market rebounded 0.36% after an initial loss of 1.5% on Friday.

site_title: France says new Europe needed after Brexit "explosive shock"
summary: France's leaders say the European Union has suffered an "explosive shock" following Britain's vote to quit the bloc, calling for a new Europe that focuses on security, defense, investment, and jobs. President Francois Hollande and Prime Minister Manuel Valls aim to ensure member states control their own affairs and tackle growing disillusionment. The FN party, led by Marine Le Pen, hails the Brexit vote as a "victory for freedom" and demands a French referendum on EU membership.

site_title: All fired up to be the best
summary: Vanguard Fire Systems Pte Ltd has become a leading supplier in the fire alarm, emergency, and security industry in Singapore, holding a 30-40% market share. Established in 2005, the company has achieved success through a disciplined team, stringent hiring process, and active participation in statutory bodies. Vanguard was chosen as one of the prestige winners of the SME100 Awards 2016, boosting its profile and confidence. The company plans to continue hiring quality staff, developing high-end technology products, and expanding its service line to reach the entire South-east Asia region.

images.alt_text: The award will boost his team's confidence and further enhance their competitive spirit, said Mr Goh.

site_title: VW will pay US$10.2b in emissions cheating case
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to pay $10.2 billion to settle its US emissions scandal case, the largest payout by a carmaker in history. The settlement will compensate owners of 482,000 vehicles with two-litre diesel engines that had cheating software designed to evade emissions tests. Owners will receive between $1,000 and $7,000 per vehicle, with about three-fourths of the funds going to car owners. The settlement includes $6.5 billion in fines and $3.7 billion in compensation for car owners.

images.alt_text: PAYBACK TIME: Exhaust system of a Volkswagen Passat diesel car. The firm has promised to fix the cars free of charge to keep them from spewing 40 times the legal limit of harmful nitrogen oxides.

site_title: Market watchers split on whether to jump into UK real estate
summary: Market watchers are divided on whether to invest in the UK real estate market amid Brexit uncertainty. Some caution against jumping into the market due to expected price falls, while others see the weakness of the pound as an opportunity for gains. The UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high, but a consensus has not emerged on when foreign investors should enter the market. The uncertainty has created a mixed outlook for the UK property market.

images.alt_text: UK property prices are expected to fall as the country enters a period of uncertainty after a vote for "Brexit" - but no consensus has emerged among market watchers as to when foreign investors should pile into UK real estate, given the weakness of the pound.

site_title: UK and Europe to see loss of growth because of uncertainty: Tharman on Brexit
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam of Singapore warned that the UK and Europe will experience a loss of growth due to uncertainty following the Brexit referendum. He noted that the UK's vote to leave the EU was largely driven by socioeconomic factors, with the less educated and those feeling left behind voting to leave. Tharman predicted that the UK's economic woes will also affect the rest of the world, including Asia, and warned of a period of uncertainty that will hurt global growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Britain has voted to leave the European Union, marking a significant blow to the European project. Noble Group received strong support for a rights issue, while Singapore Airlines denied plans to acquire a majority stake in Virgin Australia. Singapore's manufacturing output rose 0.9% in May. The city-state was designated as the secretariat of the Port Authorities Roundtable. Markets in the region tanked after the Brexit vote, with the Singapore stock market closing weaker.

site_title: US stocks tumble on Brexit vote; Dow off 2.5%
summary: US stocks plummeted on Friday after Britain's surprise vote to exit the European Union, with the Dow sinking 2.5% to 17,558.67 points. The S&P 500 fell 2.6% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 3.0%. Analysts described the reaction as negative but relatively orderly, citing high levels of uncertainty and dismay. The selloffs were smaller in the US compared to international markets, with investors taking a wait-and-see approach to the Brexit outcome.

site_title: Trump says British EU exit a model for his campaign
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump has drawn parallels between the UK's Brexit vote and his own campaign to shake up Washington, saying it's a "great thing" and a model for his insurgent campaign. Trump believes the economic shock from the vote will ebb over time and that more European countries may want to break with the EU. He also predicted that Americans will have a chance to "re-declare their independence" and reject the "global elite." Trump's comments came after the UK voted 52% to leave the EU, with Scotland voting 62% to remain.

site_title: Thousands of Londoners demand independence after Brexit
summary: Thousands of Londoners signed a petition calling for their city to remain in the European Union after Britain voted to leave in a referendum. The petition, which garnered over 40,000 signatures, urges Mayor Sadiq Khan to declare London independent and apply to join the EU. Despite the UK's 52% vote to leave, 60% of Londoners voted to stay in the EU. Mayor Khan stated that London must have a voice in the country's exit negotiations, and he plans to push the government to ensure the UK remains part of the single market.

site_title: Design front runners
summary: The annual Red Dot Award recognized 79 innovations as the "Red Dot: Best of the Best" out of 5,200 entries. This year's winners showcase cutting-edge creations in various product categories, with the coveted award going to products that demonstrated exceptional design and innovation. The award also included 107 Honourable Mentions, highlighting the intense competition in the contest.

site_title: US consumer sentiment fades at end of June on economic outlook
summary: US consumer sentiment fell to 93.5 in June, down from May's 94.7, due to concerns about the economy's progress and the UK's Brexit vote. Despite this, consumers remain optimistic about their current financial situations, with the proportion of Americans in a better financial situation holding at 49%. Expectations for inflation and nominal income gains also remained upbeat. The report's current conditions index increased to 110.8, while consumer expectations dropped to 82.4. The decline in sentiment is attributed to concerns about slower economic growth and a higher jobless rate.

site_title: From beer to drugs to cars: Global business laments EU vote
summary: Britain's vote to leave the EU has sparked global business concerns, with share prices plummeting and long-term disruptions predicted in various industries. The pound has fallen to its lowest level since 1985, impacting British Airways, car manufacturers like Ford, and potentially leading to job cuts. Aerospace and pharmaceutical companies also anticipate disruptions. The uncertainty has raised fears over economic growth, with the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Central banks move to calm jittery markets after Brexit shock
summary: Central banks worldwide, including the Bank of England, US Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and People's Bank of China, have offered financial backstops to calm jittery markets following the UK's vote to leave the EU. The move aims to prevent market liquidity from drying up and to mitigate the economic impact of the Brexit shock. The pound has plummeted to a 31-year low against the dollar, and European shares have tumbled, but markets are stabilizing. Central banks are prepared to take additional measures if needed to cushion the economy, including interest rate cuts and quantitative easing.

site_title: Brexit may force ECB into more policy easing: analysts
summary: Britain's decision to leave the EU may force the European Central Bank to provide more stimulus, analysts say. Market turmoil and plunging confidence in Britain and the eurozone could weigh on inflation, prompting potential rate cuts and asset purchases. The ECB is expected to assess the impact at its September meeting and may lower its eurozone GDP forecast for 2017 to 0.5-1.0%. Analysts predict a possible 10 basis point rate cut and further asset purchases, but the ECB is unlikely to take hasty action.

site_title: May's manufacturing output up 0.9%
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output rose 0.9% in May from a year ago, exceeding economists' expectations of 1%. The growth was largely driven by the biomedical manufacturing cluster, which saw a 13.2% increase. However, other clusters, such as transport-engineering and chemicals, experienced declines. Despite this, some economists, like Kit Wei Zheng, expect Q2 GDP to record marginal positive growth of less than 1%. Others, like Selena Ling, are less optimistic, citing underlying weakness in non-biomedical manufacturing. The sustained growth momentum for the full year remains unclear.

images.alt_text: Despite the slowdown in the growth of manufacturing output in May, economists are hopeful for an above-satisfactory performance for the second quarter, largely because of the high growth in April.

site_title: POSH confirms second deal for Shell Prelude project
summary: POSH confirms a second deal for Shell's Prelude project, winning a contract to provide accommodation support for the Prelude floating liquefied natural gas facility. The contract, awarded to POSH Semco Pte Ltd, involves deploying a 750-person semi-submersible accommodation vessel, POSH Arcadia, for accommodation support during the facility's hook-up and commissioning phase. POSH CEO Gerald Seow stated that this marks the company's second contract award for the project, following a joint venture appointment in January 2016. The value of the contract was not disclosed.

site_title: Shanghai exchange plans to launch stainless steel, scrap futures
summary: The Shanghai Futures Exchange plans to launch futures products for stainless steel and scrap steel, aiming to provide market participants with instruments to hedge risks. The move comes after a surge in Shanghai rebar steel futures in April, which prompted exchanges to curb speculation. The launch of these futures products is expected to help Chinese steel mills manage risks and avoid speculation, according to the China Iron and Steel Association. A timeline for the launch has not been provided.

site_title: Brexit vote pushes UK 5-yr CDS to nearly 4-yr high
summary: The UK's decision to leave the European Union led to a surge in the cost of insuring exposure to debt from the country, with five-year UK credit default swaps (CDS) jumping to 56 basis points, the highest level in nearly four years. This represents a 23 basis point increase from the previous day's close. The move reflects market uncertainty and increased risk associated with the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: G7 to cooperate on market moves after British vote to leave EU
summary: G7 finance leaders vowed to monitor market developments and cooperate on financial stability after the UK's vote to leave the EU. They acknowledged potential excess volatility and disorderly exchange rate moves, but expressed confidence in the UK's resilience and authorities' ability to address consequences. The G7 reaffirmed their commitment to close cooperation and consultation on market moves, aiming to maintain economic stability.

site_title: WPP chief predicts a slowdown of the world economy after Brexit vote
summary: WPP CEO Sir Martin Sorrell predicts a global economic slowdown after the UK's Brexit vote, citing cautious client behavior and a potential loss of influence in western European markets. He forecasts a slowdown in growth rate, likely to be even more conservative than current forecasts from the World Bank or IMF. This could lead to incremental job losses in the UK and creation of jobs in other European countries.

site_title: Swiss central bank intervenes to stabilise Swiss franc after Brexit vote
summary: Switzerland's central bank intervened in the foreign exchange market to stabilize the Swiss franc following the UK's vote to leave the European Union. The Swiss franc strengthened significantly, trading at 1.06 francs to the euro, after the result became clear. The bank stated it would remain active in the market to stabilize the situation. The move came as the UK's Brexit vote put upward pressure on the Swiss franc, considered a safe-haven currency.

site_title: Britain's financial sector reels after Brexit bombshell
summary: Britain's financial sector is facing uncertainty and potential job cuts after the country voted to leave the European Union. The 'Vote Leave' campaign's victory led to a 13.4% average fall in the top five British banks' share prices and 12-14% drops in elite wealth managers. The EU's 'passporting' regime, allowing UK firms to sell services across the bloc, may be at risk, prompting concerns of thousands of job losses and a potential shift of operations to other European cities.

site_title: Gold surges to 2-year high as investors seek shelter from Brexit
summary: Gold surged to a two-year high after the UK voted to exit the European Union, with prices rising as much as 8.1% and futures trading volume seven times the average. The pound's decline against the US dollar boosted gold demand, and gold mining companies such as Randgold Resources Ltd. advanced. The result prompted Prime Minister David Cameron to resign and sent shockwaves through markets, with European stocks and US futures sliding. Gold is up 24% this year due to low interest rates and the US central bank's likely decision to keep rates on hold.

site_title: Indonesia says coal on hold for Philippines after 7 sailors abducted
summary: Indonesia has suspended coal shipments to the Philippines until Manila secures its waters following the kidnapping of seven Indonesian sailors. The sailors were taken in separate attacks, and the group responsible is unclear. Indonesia, which supplies 70% of the Philippines' coal, is concerned about piracy in the Sulu Sea area, similar to Somalia. The halt will remain in place until the Philippines government guarantees security, according to Indonesian Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi.

site_title: Weak US core capital goods orders point to subdued business spending
summary: US non-defense capital goods orders excluding aircraft, a proxy for business spending plans, fell 0.7% in May, down from a revised 0.4% decline in April. This suggests business spending will remain a drag on economic growth in the second quarter. Orders for durable goods declined 2.2% in May, following a downwardly revised 3.3% increase in April. The manufacturing sector, which accounts for 12% of the US economy, continues to face challenges due to a surge in the dollar, sluggish global demand, and lower oil prices, leading to lower equipment spending.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.93 points to close at 1,634.05, with 2.23 billion lots valued at RM2.36 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 179-760.

site_title: China's yuan slumps to over 5-yr low on Brexit, central bank suspected of intervention
summary: China's yuan slumped to a 5-year low against the dollar, reaching 6.6285 to the dollar, amid global market turmoil following Britain's Brexit vote. The People's Bank of China intervened, offering dollar liquidity, and the currency later pared losses before closing at 6.6140. Traders suspected state-owned banks were involved in the intervention. This move aims to support the currency, which had fallen 0.7% from Thursday's close, its weakest since January 2011.

site_title: Brexit adds to London housing market's growing list of woes
summary: The UK's vote to leave the European Union has dealt a significant blow to London's housing market, with prices expected to fall 5-10% in the coming years. The pound's decline has reduced investor confidence, leading to a decrease in demand and an oversupply of properties. Developers are offering discounts to institutional investors, and home prices in prime central London have dropped 0.1% in May. Experts predict a prolonged downturn in the housing market, with some warning that it could take 150 years to sell off the current inventory of unsold homes.

site_title: US: S&P 500 futures slump after Britons vote to leave EU
summary: US stock futures plummeted 5% after Britain voted to leave the European Union, triggering overnight circuit breakers and sparking global market turmoil. The historic referendum has raised concerns about economic damage, with investors seeking refuge in the dollar and other safe-harbor assets. US short-term interest rates futures rose, and the VIX volatility index surged, as investors anticipate potential Fed interest rate cuts to shield the economy.

site_title: S&P prepares UK Ratings downgrade as Britain votes to leave EU
summary: S&P Global Ratings is set to downgrade the UK's top credit grade to "at least one notch" below AAA, following the country's vote to leave the European Union. The move comes after the 52-48 EU referendum result, which has led to global market volatility, a plunging pound, and a surge in UK government bonds. The downgrade is seen as a binary outcome, with Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warning of potential recession and economic growth slowing in the first quarter.

site_title: Singapore stocks close weaker after Brexit vote
summary: Singapore stocks plummeted on Friday, June 24, 2016, after the UK voted to leave the European Union, with the Straits Times Index falling 2.1% to 2,735.39. The Nikkei crashed 8% and the Hang Seng Index dropped 3% as the British pound hit a 30-year low against the US dollar. The market's decline was largely driven by the "risk off" sentiment, with the entire market experiencing 89 rises versus 341 falls. The losses marked a 1% decline for the week.

site_title: Beyond clean arteries
summary: A study highlights the risks of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), a condition where the heart is swollen, has damaged heart muscles, and decreased pumping function, often leading to death. DCM can be caused by viral infections, excessive exercise, thyroid hormones, pregnancy, and certain medications. Patients with DCM are at risk of poor heart pump and abnormal heart rhythms, which can be life-threatening. Improving diagnosis and treatment, such as implanting automatic implantable cardioverter defibrillators (AICDs) and monitoring heart rhythms, can significantly reduce the risk of sudden death. Early detection and treatment can improve outcomes, with death rates declining over the past decade.

images.alt_text: SAFE PROCEDURE: A computed tomography scan of the heart will reveal whether the patient has dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).

site_title: FLASH: MAS ready to curb excessive volatility in Singapore dollar after Brexit
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is prepared to intervene to curb excessive volatility in the Singapore dollar following the Brexit referendum. The move aims to stabilize the currency and mitigate the impact of the UK's decision on the global economy. The MAS has been closely monitoring the situation and is ready to take measures to maintain financial stability.

site_title: London office prices seen falling 20% after Brexit vote
summary: London office property values may fall by up to 20% within three years of the UK's Brexit vote, according to Green Street Advisors LLC. This is due to businesses relocating and the economy stagnating. Retail property values could drop by 10-15%. The pound's plunge and Prime Minister David Cameron's resignation fueled concern, leading to a 16.9 billion-pound drop in UK commercial real estate investments in the first half of the year. Investors are entering a period of heightened uncertainty, with some companies considering relocating employees to EU locations.

site_title: Paradise Group slapped with S$530,000 fine for tampering with gas meter
summary: Paradise Group, a restaurant chain, has been fined S$530,000 by the Energy Market Authority for tampering with gas meter installations at its restaurants. The company was found guilty of 29 charges of tampering gas meters and dishonestly consuming gas. Inspections at 24 restaurants uncovered similar tampering work. The Energy Market Authority deemed the theft of utilities unacceptable, resulting in other consumers paying more, and warned that tampering with meters poses safety risks.

site_title: Brexit: Spain proposes 'shared sovereignty' over Gibraltar
summary: Spain has proposed sharing sovereignty over Gibraltar with the UK after Britain's vote to leave the European Union, a move seen as a potential step towards reasserting control over the British overseas territory. Acting Foreign Minister Jose Manuel Garcia-Margallo suggested a "determined period of time" of British-Spanish co-sovereignty before Gibraltar's return to Spanish control. The move has raised concerns among Gibraltarians and Spanish workers who rely on jobs in Gibraltar, with unemployment in border towns already high.

site_title: Australia's ties to Britain to stay 'intimate' after Brexit: PM Turnbull
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull stated that the country's relationship with Britain will remain "very strong and intimate" despite the Brexit vote. He expressed confidence that negotiations for a free-trade deal with the European Union will not be affected. Turnbull acknowledged a period of uncertainty and instability in global markets but assured Australians that the impact on trade deals would be "very limited" in the short-term.

site_title: UK PM Cameron says will step down by October after Brexit vote
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron announced his resignation by October, following the country's vote to leave the European Union. He stated he would not be the leader to guide the country through its next destination, and a new leader should be in place by the time the Conservative Party's annual conference takes place in October. Cameron, visibly emotional, did not provide a detailed timeline for his departure.

site_title: Crashing pound draws queues at Singapore money changers
summary: The pound's historic low against the Singapore dollar and US dollar following Britain's EU exit led to long queues at money changers in Singapore, with people seeking favourable exchange rates for holidays and school fees. The pound briefly hit a 31-year low against the US dollar. Money changers struggled to cope with the sudden demand, with some putting up "out of stock" signs. Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong cautioned that the next few years will be uncertain for Britain and Europe, while online retailers experienced increased shopper traffic due to the weak pound.

site_title: FLASH: Singapore GIC is prepared for a period of heightened market uncertainty
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) is preparing for a period of heightened market uncertainty following the UK's Brexit vote. GIC is diversifying its portfolio to mitigate potential market volatility. Meanwhile, other news includes Vietnam reacting to the US Trump tariff announcement, the Asian garment industry bracing for higher US tariffs, and China's GDP growth expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares drop sharply on Brexit
summary: Australian shares plummeted 3.17% and New Zealand stocks fell 2.25% on Friday following the historic Brexit vote, wiping A$50 billion off the Australian exchange. The S&P/ASX 200 index and S&P/NZX 50 index experienced their biggest single-day falls since September 2015. Global markets were roiled by the UK's decision to leave the European Union, with investors seeking safe-haven assets. The decline was attributed to concerns over economic uncertainty and market volatility.

site_title: Switzerland sets up Brexit hotline for worried citizens
summary: Switzerland has set up a 24/7 hotline to address concerns from citizens and businesses about the UK's vote to leave the EU, amid expectations of currency fluctuations and potential influx of international funds. The hotline aims to provide information on the current regulations and their impact on Swiss citizens and companies. The Swiss franc has already seen a surge in value following Brexit polls, and Switzerland is prepared for a possible influx of funds from international investors.

site_title: Brexit' shock more bad news for Japan PM's stumbling 'Abenomics'
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic revival program, "Abenomics," suffered a fresh blow as the UK's vote to leave the EU sent the yen soaring, threatening to make companies and consumers even more cautious. The yen surged above 100 to the dollar, prompting concerns about exports and recession. Abe warned of real effects on Japan's economy, while policymakers worry about the impact on exports and economic growth. The yen's rise may also hurt corporate profits and dampen consumer sentiment, already weak spots in the Abenomics mix.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's limping "Abenomics" revival programme suffered a fresh blow on Friday when Britain's vote to leave the European Union sent the yen soaring and threatened to make companies and consumers even more cautious.

site_title: Europe: Stocks in free fall after Brexit vote
summary: European stocks plummeted after the UK voted to leave the European Union, with the FTSE-100 index down 5.0% and banking stocks losing nearly a quarter of their value. The eurozone also suffered, with the Paris CAC-40 index falling over 10%. Sterling dropped 10% to its weakest level since 1985, while investors sought safety in government bonds and gold, which hit a two-year high.

site_title: German business confidence rises in June
summary: German business confidence rose in June, with the Ifo institute's business climate index increasing to 108.7 points, the highest level since November 2015. The current business situation improved slightly, while the short-term outlook improved significantly, with the outlook sub-index climbing 1.4 points to 103.1 points. The results were largely unaffected by the outcome of the British EU referendum, which occurred before the poll was conducted. Ifo president Clemens Fuest described the German economy as "buoyant."

site_title: Asia: Stocks head for worst rout since 2011 on Brexit shock
summary: Asian stocks plummeted 4.4% as the UK voted to leave the European Union, marking the steepest slump in five years. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped to 124.36, with Japan's Topix plummeting 7.3% and the Hang Seng Index losing 4.4%. The vote has raised concerns about global growth and has led to a surge in currency volatility, with the yen surging past 100 US dollars. Central banks across Asia have pledged to take action to avert financial-market liquidity issues.

site_title: Pound dives 9.2% against Sing dollar on Brexit news
summary: The pound plummeted 9.2% against the Singapore dollar following Brexit news, with a low of S$1.8085. This is down 7.78% against the Singapore dollar and its lowest since September 1985 against the US dollar at US$1.3305. The currency's volatility reflects the uncertainty surrounding Britain's exit from the European Union.

site_title: Yen soars past 100 per US dollar as UK vote spurs rush to safety
summary: The Japanese yen surged past 100 per US dollar for the first time since November 2013, reaching a high of 99.02 as a result of the UK's vote to leave the European Union, sparking demand for the currency as a safe-haven asset. The yen gained 7.2% against the greenback, its best performance this year, amid concerns about global growth. Investors and analysts predict increased pressure on the Bank of Japan to intervene to weaken the currency, but officials have declined to comment on potential intervention.

site_title: EU's Tusk says 27 EU leaders determined to keep unity after Brexit
summary: European Union leaders, led by Donald Tusk, are determined to maintain unity despite Britain's vote to leave the 28-nation bloc. Tusk stated that the EU is prepared for the outcome and there's no way to predict all the consequences. He called for calm and proposed an informal meeting of the remaining 27 leaders to discuss handling Britain's decision. Under EU law, the UK has two years for negotiations on the terms of its divorce. The EU leaders will meet on Tuesday in Brussels to discuss the future of the Union.

site_title: No favours for UK, must leave EU in two years, says centre-right chief
summary: European Union leaders, led by German Chancellor Angela Merkel's representative Manfred Weber, have stated that the UK should leave the bloc within the two-year timeframe set by the EU treaty. Weber emphasized that there will be no special treatment for the UK and that full sovereignty comes with no access to the single market. The EU will respect the UK's decision, but it is expected to maintain a tough stance on Brexit negotiations, with Weber stating that "leave means leave" and the times of cherry-picking are over.

images.alt_text: The European Union will offer Britain no special treatment and it should leave the bloc within the two years set by the EU treaty, the German leader of the main centre-right bloc in the EU parliament said on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei plunges almost 8% in Brexit bloodbath
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index plummeted 7.92% on June 24, 2016, its largest one-day drop since Japan's 2011 earthquake, following Britain's decision to leave the European Union. The Nikkei 225 fell to 14,952.02, and the broader Topix index dropped 7.26%. This was a significant market bloodbath triggered by the Brexit news, which had a major impact on global financial markets.

site_title: MAS ready to curb excessive volatility in Singapore dollar after Brexit
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is prepared to curb excessive volatility in the Singapore dollar following the UK's "Leave" vote in the EU referendum. The MAS said it remains within its policy band, but is ready to take action if market volatility increases. The central bank has been in close contact with banks and regulators to maintain the resilience of Singapore's financial system. The Singapore dollar has already fallen 6.5% against the British pound to S$1.8085. MAS will continue to monitor the situation and provide additional liquidity to the banking system if needed.

site_title: London: Stock market plunges 8.0%
summary: London's FTSE 100 index plummeted 7.7% to 5,851.01 points after Britain voted to leave the EU, with bank and housebuilder shares collapsing by around 28-32%. Taylor Wimpey lost 32%, while Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland each fell roughly 28%. The decline was the largest since 2008.

site_title: Singapore GIC is prepared for a period of heightened market uncertainty post-Brexit
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is prepared for market uncertainty following the UK's Brexit exit, despite being 7% invested in the UK. GIC manages $344 billion in assets and has a diversified portfolio, with Deputy President Lim Chow Kiat stating the fund is "prepared for a period of heightened market uncertainty."

site_title: GIC's UK property exposure faces test after Brexit shock
summary: Singapore's GIC, a sovereign investor with $344 billion in assets, is exposed to the UK property market after Brexit, with 7% of its portfolio invested in the UK, estimated at $24 billion. Despite the shock, GIC's long-term view and focus on beating global inflation will guide its investment strategy. Chief economist Leslie Teo expressed a sanguine view on the post-Brexit environment, but noted concerns over high risks and low returns. Other Asian state investors, such as Temasek Holdings and China Investment Corp, also have significant UK investments, but GIC's exposure is the largest among Asian state investors.

site_title: China: Stocks fall over 1% on Brexit; capital controls limit selling
summary: China's stocks fell over 1% on June 24, 2016, due to the UK's vote to leave the EU, which shocked global financial markets. Despite the decline, China's tight capital controls limited selling, unlike other Asian markets. The CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.3% and 2.4% respectively, while Shenzhen's start-up board ChiNext slumped over 3%. Analysts attribute the relatively subdued reaction to Chinese investors taking advantage of the market's panic for bargain hunting, but warn of potential volatility in the coming weeks.

site_title: Singapore PM Lee says too early to tell consequences of Brexit
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the UK's decision to leave the EU is a turning point, but it's too early to determine the consequences. He believes the decision reflects anxiety over immigration and a desire for British sovereignty. Lee warned that disengaging from the global community could lead to less security, prosperity, and a dimmer future for many countries.

site_title: Quick takes: It's official, Britain votes for Brexit
summary: Britain has voted to leave the European Union, with the "Leave" campaign securing 51.8% of the vote. The outcome has led to Prime Minister David Cameron's resignation. Experts predict economic losses for the UK and EU, with potential impacts on property markets, multinational corporations, and small and medium-sized enterprises. The vote's implications for China, particularly in terms of Chinese companies relocating their European headquarters, are also significant. The outcome has sparked uncertainty and volatility in markets, with gold prices surging as investors seek protection.

site_title: Hong Kong shares tumble on Brexit vote, then pare losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.9% on June 24, 2016, following Britain's vote to leave the EU, but recovered some losses in afternoon trading. Analysts say the market overreacted initially, but eventually realized the Brexit impact would be minimal. The market will continue to watch reactions in the US.

site_title: Britain votes to leave EU, Cameron resigns
summary: The United Kingdom voted to leave the European Union, with 52% of voters opting to leave and 48% choosing to remain, in a historic referendum. Prime Minister David Cameron resigned, citing the need for fresh leadership, and the pound plummeted 10% against the US dollar. Global markets fell, and the EU faces significant economic and political damage. site_title: Britain votes to leave EU, unleashing global turmoil
summary: Britain has voted to leave the European Union, with 52% of the population opting for Brexit in a historic referendum. site_title: Asia markets collapse as Britain looks set to leave EU

site_title: Brexit voters spurn Obama pitch, testing 'special relationship'
summary: British voters have rejected President Barack Obama's plea to stay in the European Union, spurning his efforts to sway the nation's decision in favor of staying in the bloc. The decision is seen as a blow to US diplomacy and trade negotiation, and will require the US to adjust to the new British reality.

site_title: Oil tumbles as investors seek safety after UK votes for Brexit
summary: The UK's vote to leave the European Union led to a global flight from risky assets, causing oil prices to tumble. The pound's plunge to its lowest since 1985 also affected industrial metals. Morgan Stanley and Societe Generale warned of a stronger US dollar and slower economic expansion, which will impact oil prices in the near-term. A second weekly drop in oil prices was expected.

site_title: Asia central banks, policymakers wade in to calm markets on Brexit vote
summary: Asian central banks intervened in currency markets after the UK voted to leave the EU, with the Bank of Korea suspected of selling US dollars to curb the won's fall and the Reserve Bank of India likely selling dollars through state-owned banks. A senior policymaker at the Reserve Bank of India stated the central bank is prepared to deal with any market volatility resulting from the Brexit decision.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Barclays, HSBC downplay Brexit threat
summary: Goldman Sachs, Barclays, and HSBC, three of the world's largest banks, downplayed the threat of a catastrophic hit to Britain's banking sector following the country's vote to leave the European Union. The banks, which had planned for either outcome for months, expressed confidence in their ability to adapt to the change. Goldman Sachs CEO Lloyd Blankfein stated that the bank's primary focus remains serving its clients, while Barclays' CEO Jes Staley said the bank's strategy remains unchanged. HSBC Chairman Douglas Flint described the vote as a "new era" for Britain and its businesses.

site_title: Cameron to remain British PM after Brexit vote: minister
summary: The UK's Prime Minister David Cameron will remain in office despite the country's Brexit vote, according to Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond. He stated that Cameron will stay on as PM and carry out the instructions of the British people. The decision comes after the UK voted to leave the European Union in a referendum held on June 23, 2016. Cameron had initially stated he would step down by October, but Hammond's comments suggest he will continue to lead the country.

site_title: Update: Britain votes to leave EU
summary: Britain has voted 52% to 48% in favor of leaving the European Union, with 16.8 million votes for "Leave" and 15.7 million for "Remain". site_title: Singapore dollar falls most in 7 months on UK vote results
summary: Singapore's dollar fell 1% to S$1.3504 against the US dollar, its largest drop in 7 months, following early UK referendum results showing a close outcome on whether to leave the EU. site_title: Singapore designated as Port Authorities Roundtable secretariat

site_title: Our turn for a referendum, says French far right FN
summary: France's far-right National Front party, led by Marine Le Pen, has called for a referendum on European Union membership in France, citing Britain's recent vote to leave the bloc. Le Pen had previously stated that if she wins the 2017 presidential election, she would hold a referendum on leaving the EU. This move comes as Le Pen is seen as the front-runner among likely candidates ahead of the election, despite polls suggesting she may lose the run-off.

images.alt_text: France's far right National Front party called for a referendum on European Union membership in France on Friday as Britain voted to leave the bloc.

site_title: Sterling hits lowest in 3 decades, yen surges as Brexit stuns markets
summary: Sterling plummeted to its lowest level in 3 decades following the UK's Brexit vote, triggering a rush into safe-havens like the yen and dollar. site_title: Noble Group shareholders show strong support for rights issue
summary: Noble Group has received 98.87% approval for a renounceable underwritten rights issue, with shareholders supporting the move to reposition the company's balance sheet. site_title: Seoul: Stocks at near 4-mth low, won at 3-wk low on Britain's leave
summary: South Korea's stocks and won plummeted on Friday after Britain voted to leave the European Union. site_title: Yen soars to almost two-year high on early Brexit vote results
summary: The yen surged to nearly two-year highs after early results from the UK's EU referendum favored a "Leave" vote, with the currency climbing 3% against the US dollar. This surge threatens to undo the Bank of Japan's monetary easing efforts. site_title: Ringgit set to drop most since 1998 as UK result favours Brexit
summary: Malaysia's ringgit plummeted 2.5% to 4.1207 per dollar, its largest decline since 1998, as the UK's Brexit vote favored leaving the EU, sending investors fleeing to haven assets. site_title: Quick take: Leaders must now work together to ensure smooth transition: EU-Asean Business Council
summary: Leaders from the EU and UK must work together to ensure a smooth transition following Britain's vote to exit the European Union. The EU-Asean Business Council expressed confidence in the long-term trade and investment relationship with Asean, despite the outcome. The UK and EU will continue to engage with Asean, with Europe being the largest source of foreign direct investment and one of Asean's largest trading partners.

images.alt_text: British leaders and their European counterparts must work together "positively and quickly" to ensure a smooth transition in order to give confidence to the business communities in the UK, Europe and ASEAN following Britain's vote to exit the European Union.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing output up 0.9% in May
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output rose 0.9% in May, surpassing economists' estimates, driven by a 13.2% expansion in the biomedical manufacturing cluster. The electronics cluster also saw a year-on-year increase, while other clusters, such as transport engineering and general manufacturing, declined. The biomedical cluster's growth was largely due to the pharmaceuticals and medical technology segments, which expanded by 14.2% and 9.2% respectively. Despite this, output fell in other clusters, including transport engineering, which dropped 17.2% year-on-year.

site_title: Big US banks pass stress tests even with harder scenarios
summary: US banks pass annual stress tests, with 33 banks meeting minimum capital levels in severe economic conditions. The Federal Reserve's new, more stringent test assumptions did not deter banks from passing, with overall capital levels improving and loan losses projected at $385 billion. The Tier 1 common equity ratio fell to 8.4%, above the 4.5% minimum set by regulators. Capital levels have risen and credit quality has improved since the Fed started stress testing in 2009, with bad loans rolling off the books.

site_title: Traders hold off bets in volatile market as results favour Brexit
summary: Traders are holding off on large bets in the volatile market as the UK's European Union referendum results show a stronger-than-expected "Leave" vote. Sterling plummeted to a record 9% drop to $1.3537, while the yen surged past 100 to the dollar. The lack of liquidity in trading is exacerbating price moves, with markets expecting a potential Brexit. Investors are bracing for a "liquidity drought" that could amplify price volatility, with some banks warning of constrained ability to provide currency liquidity.

site_title: UPDATE: STI down on early results of EU referendum
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.50% to 2,752 in early trading following early results of the EU referendum, with 348.5 million shares worth S$378.6 million changing hands. The market reaction was attributed to concerns over Britain's "Leave" camp leading in the vote.

site_title: Stress levels flashing red in funding markets after Brexit vote
summary: The UK's vote to quit the EU has sent shockwaves through global markets, with stress levels flashing red in funding markets. The FRA/OIS spread, a gauge of bank borrowing costs, hit its most extreme level since 2012, while the pound plummeted to its lowest in 30 years. The yen surged past $100 for the first time since 2013, and Treasuries saw the largest surge in seven years. Investor appetite for risk decreased, and demand for havens increased, indicating potential policy maker action to ease market turmoil.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hard hit by Brexit jitters
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars plummeted 3.0% and 2.5% respectively on June 24, 2016, amid Brexit uncertainty. Investors feared the UK's potential exit from the EU would destabilize the single currency and affect global markets. Meanwhile, New Zealand government bonds gained, and Australian government bond futures rallied as investors sought safe-haven assets. The Brexit results were still being rolled in, with partial voting returns suggesting Britain was on the brink of leaving the EU.

site_title: BOE says will take all necessary steps to ensure stability
summary: The Bank of England announced it will take necessary steps to secure monetary and financial stability after the UK's vote to leave the European Union, which led to a 10% fall in sterling's value. The BOE has previously warned of a potential hit to the economy and inflation due to the pound's expected decline. The decision triggers a shock to the economy, with sterling hitting a 31-year low against the US dollar. The BOE is closely monitoring developments and working with domestic authorities and overseas central banks to mitigate the impact.

site_title: Gold posts biggest rally since 2008 on shock Brexit vote
summary: Gold surged 8% to its highest in over two years after the UK voted to leave the European Union, marking its largest rally since the 2008 global financial crisis. Investors sought safe-haven assets, driving up gold prices. The Brexit outcome sets an uncertain path for Britain and undermines European unity efforts since World War II.

images.alt_text: Gold jumped as much as 8 per cent to its highest in more than two years on Friday, after Britons shocked markets by voting to leave the European Union, driving investors toward safe-haven assets such as bullion.

site_title: Oil dives as early vote results indicate a Brexit
summary: World oil prices dropped 4.23% as early vote results indicated Britain's likely exit from the European Union. Results from 200 areas showed "Leave" with 51.69% of the vote, surpassing "Remain" with 48.31%. Several world leaders warned of a recession with global spillover effects. Oil prices fell to $47.99 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and $48.85 a barrel for Brent North Sea crude. Traders are shifting to safe-haven currencies like the dollar and yen, further depressing oil prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks swing as Brexit vote results begin
summary: Hong Kong stocks experienced a wild swing on June 24, 2016, as initial results from the Brexit EU membership referendum began to emerge. The Hang Seng Index initially plummeted 2% but recovered to close 0.22% lower. The results of the referendum were seen as uncertain, with Britain voting to leave the EU.

site_title: Yuan withstands global currency rout as Brexit concern mounts
summary: China's yuan maintained stability against global currency volatility, despite early results in the UK's EU referendum showing a higher vote for Brexit. The yuan slipped 0.2% to 6.5913 per dollar, while the pound sank 5.8% and the euro lost at least 1%. Analysts predict a negative short-term impact on the yuan if a Brexit occurs, citing the significant trade relationship between China and the EU. The yuan has fallen against most major global peers in the past month, including losses of over 6% versus the South African rand.

site_title: SIA not securing majority stake in Virgin Australia
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has denied reports it was considering a majority stake in Virgin Australia, stating an independent VA is best for its interest in the Australian market. SIA has not contemplated taking a majority stake in VA, with its current stake at 20.09%. The airline's decision comes after recent reports suggested SIA was aiming to acquire a 51% stake in the Australian airline. SIA's interests in the Australian market are best served through an independent Virgin Australia, according to the airline.

site_title: HSBC leads losses in Hong Kong as tumbling pound hurts earnings
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 2% as HSBC and Standard Chartered led declines due to the tumbling British pound, which fell to a record low after the UK referendum on European Union membership suggested a "Leave" victory. The Hang Seng Index slid, with HSBC and Standard Chartered plummeting 5.4% and 7.2%, respectively. Many companies in Hong Kong have ties to the UK, including Li Ka-Shing's empire, which could be hurt by a "Brexit." The market is expected to remain volatile, with investors advised to wait on the sidelines until the Brexit vote result is known.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks dropped, led by HSBC Holdings Plc and Standard Chartered Plc, as early results in the UK referendum on European Union membership sent the British pound tumbling and threatened earnings for companies with links to the country.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks fluctuate wildly as Brexit vote results come in
summary: South Korea's won and stocks experienced wild fluctuations on Friday following the Brexit referendum results, with the won dropping 0.4% to 1,154.9 to the dollar. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.2% to 1,982.42 points. The close contest in the Brexit vote, with the UK narrowly opting to leave the EU, sent markets into turmoil.

site_title: From trade to migration: how Brexit may hit the EU economy
summary: The EU's chief concerns over Britain's vote to leave the group are both political and economic. Britain's departure will result in a huge economic impact on the EU, with a shortfall of at least 5% of the total EU budget. Germany, the largest member, would have to provide the most extra cash, while the rest of the EU would experience a trade impact, financial flight, and uncertainty, potentially reducing UK growth and EU goods exports. The EU may also face a loss of foreign direct investment and potentially higher inflows of EU migrants to some countries.

images.alt_text: The European Union's chief concerns over Britain's vote to leave the group are political but losing its second-largest economy will have a huge economic impact as well.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.040 points to 1639.840. The trading volume was 17.5 million lots worth RM8.7 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 52 to 47.

site_title: Lyft wins approval of driver settlement from US judge
summary: US District Judge Vince Chhabria granted preliminary approval to Lyft's $27 million settlement with California drivers who claimed they should be deemed employees, not independent contractors. The settlement, which represents 17% of drivers' reimbursement claims, will allow drivers to avoid the risk of an adverse jury verdict. Drivers will remain independent contractors, and the ruling preserves Lyft's flexibility. The decision comes after a similar lawsuit involving Uber drivers in California and Massachusetts is under review.

site_title: "Leave" scents victory in Britain's EU vote, pound crashes
summary: Britain's "Leave" campaign leads in the EU vote, securing 51.6% to 48.4% with 282 of 382 voting districts reported. The pound crashes to a 30-year-low, plummeting 9% to a record low below $1.35. A "Brexit" would have significant international implications, potentially fueling anti-EU movements, weakening the European Union, and creating uncertainty for companies and investors. The outcome marks the start of a two-year divorce process.

images.alt_text: Supporters of leaving the European Union seized the lead on Friday in the vote count from Britain's bitterly contested referendum, setting sterling on track for its biggest ever fall on world markets.

site_title: Britain votes to leave EU in historic divorce: BBC
summary: Britain has voted to leave the European Union, with 51.5% of voters supporting Brexit, while 48.5% remained in the bloc. The outcome will have significant economic and political implications, including the potential loss of access to the single market and the need for new trade agreements. Sterling plummeted, and the euro fell nearly 4% against the US dollar. World leaders, including US President Barack Obama, had urged a "Remain" vote, citing economic benefits of EU membership. The decision marks a historic shift for Britain and sets it on an uncertain path.

site_title: Pound heads for biggest drop on record as Brexit chances build
summary: The pound experienced its largest-ever drop, 4.7%, as early results in Britain's EU referendum suggested a potential "Leave" victory. This decline surpassed the 1992 Black Wednesday drop of 4.1%. Sterling traded in a range of over 10 US cents, and the FTSE 100 Index futures contracts slid 5.8%. The pound has fluctuated significantly since the campaign began, reflecting the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit outcome.

images.alt_text: The pound headed for its biggest-ever drop, leading a decline in UK assets, as early results in Britain's European Union referendum pointed to a potential victory for the "Leave" campaign.

site_title: South Korea mulls law to keep office out of the home
summary: South Korea is considering a bill to ban bosses from contacting employees at home, amid growing complaints about the country's work-life imbalance. The proposed law, sponsored by 12 lawmakers, aims to prevent firms from sending work-related messages outside official working hours. This comes as the country struggles with an already onerous work culture, with the average worker clocking in 2,124 hours in 2014. The bill, similar to those proposed in France and Germany, seeks to protect workers' personal lives from workplace intrusion.

site_title: Asia: Stocks advance as UK Brexit vote results trickle in
summary: Asian stocks rose, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index advancing 0.7% to 130.93, driven by early results from the UK referendum on European Union membership showing greater support for leaving the bloc. Japan's Topix climbed 0.5%, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index added 0.3%. Traders remain nervous ahead of the final decision, with concerns over the economic impacts of a Brexit and potential destabilization of global markets.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down; early Brexit results put 'Leave' camp ahead
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.8% on Friday, led by a 0.9% drop in the electronics and financials subindices. Early Brexit results showed the 'Leave' camp ahead, with the main Taiex index closing at 8,604.82. The Taiwan dollar softened to T$32.320 per US dollar. Shares of China Airlines dropped 0.1% after flight attendants went on strike over working conditions.

site_title: Japan's ruling coalition headed for hefty win in upper house poll: surveys
summary: Japan's ruling coalition is expected to win a majority in the July 10 upper house election, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) potentially gaining enough seats to revise the post-war constitution for the first time. The LDP needs 57 seats for a majority, and a solid victory will keep lawmakers in line. A Mainichi newspaper poll shows 45% opposed to constitution revision, while the opposition Democratic Party is trying to prevent a two-thirds majority needed for the process. Abe has downplayed the goal of revising the constitution.

site_title: BOJ board divided on next move, some fret over weak prices in June
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers are divided on whether to expand or scale back its stimulus programme to address weak inflation. The disagreement, led by dissenters criticizing Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's policies, underscores the challenges of ending deflation with aggressive money printing. Despite Kuroda having a majority to push through any proposal, the rift highlights the difficulties in sustaining economic growth. The BOJ's next move remains uncertain, with no clear direction on how to address the country's stagnant prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens higher as Britain EU results roll in
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday as Britain's EU vote results trickled in, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.59% and the Topix index gaining 0.70%. The results, which are expected to confirm the UK's exit from the EU, are seen as a boost to global markets. The Nikkei 225 index reached 16,333.87, while the Topix index reached 1,307.84. The rally is expected to continue, with investors awaiting further updates on the EU vote.

site_title: Finance firms seen investing US$1b in blockchain this year
summary: Financial and technology firms are expected to invest over $1 billion in blockchain technology this year, according to a Greenwich Associates survey. The main obstacle to widespread adoption is a "vested interest" in legacy systems. Banks, brokers, and exchanges are leading the development of blockchain, aiming to reduce costs, shorten settlement times, and improve payments. Asset managers are taking a back seat, but a majority of participants believe blockchain has the potential to change markets within the next five years.

site_title: Fed could get more positive after strong 2-3 months: Kaplan
summary: Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan suggests the Federal Reserve could shift its cautious tone on the US economy if economic data strengthens in the next two or three months, potentially leading to a more positive outlook. This follows a poor May jobs report, which initially led the Fed to focus on the dangers of weaker potential economic growth. Kaplan's comments imply that recent economic data may be enough to alter the Fed's stance, potentially leading to a more optimistic assessment of the US economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher on Friday, rising 3.46 points or 0.12% to 2,797.31, following initial results from Britain's Brexit referendum. This optimism mirrored gains in Tokyo and US stocks, with the S&P 500 adding 1.3% to 2,113.32. The rally came ahead of Singapore's GDP data release and amid split views on the Federal Reserve's future interest rate hikes.

site_title: SE Asian Islamic State unit being formed in southern Philippines: officials
summary: A Southeast Asian unit of the Islamic State has reportedly formed in the southern Philippines, with Abu Abdullah, a Philippine militant leader, being chosen as its regional head. The group's claim was made in a video posted on social media, urging Muslims to unite under Islamic State's leadership. The authenticity of the video cannot be verified, but experts say it shows a shift in strategy, with supporters being asked to stay home and launch attacks in South-east Asia instead of the Middle East.

site_title: Ex-JPMorgan banker on the run 8 years lands in US court
summary: A former JPMorgan Chase private banker, Hernan Arbizu, pleaded not guilty to 15 counts of embezzlement and fraud after being accused of stealing over $5.3 million from customer accounts at UBS AG and JPMorgan. Arbizu, who had been on the run for eight years in Argentina, surrendered to US authorities and is in plea talks with the government. A trial date of December 5 has been set, and Arbizu's lawyer declined to comment on the circumstances of his client's return to the US.

site_title: Gold whipsawed as early Brexit results hurt outlook for 'Remain'
summary: Gold prices swung between gains and losses after the UK's vote on EU membership, with early speculation of a 'Remain' victory followed by a rise in doubt. The metal initially fell 0.5% to $1,250.89, then surged 1.1% to $1,271.13, before trading 0.8% higher at $1,266.58. Analysts predict volatility if the outcome is close, with gold potentially falling to $1,200 or $1,176 if 'Remain' wins.

site_title: Leave camp leads in early UK referendum count
summary: The UK's referendum on leaving the European Union showed an early lead for supporters of Brexit, with 52.4% of the vote in favor of leaving and 47.6% against, based on early results from 13 voting districts. However, the outcome remains uncertain, and opinion polls had predicted a Remain victory. The pound initially rose but then plummeted after a strong vote in favor of leaving was reported in Sunderland, before recovering. The result has significant implications for the UK economy, the EU, and global markets, with potential consequences for immigration, trade, and sovereignty.

site_title: Third of hospitals in developing world lack clean running water: study
summary: At least a third of hospitals in developing nations lack clean running water, according to a study examining 430 hospitals. This leads to unsanitary conditions and further disease spread. The study found varying water availability, from 20% in Sierra Leone and Liberia to over 90% in India, Malaysia, and Guinea. The lack of clean water poses significant challenges for surgeons, with some relying on rain barrels, and can lead to preventable deaths, such as those of half a million babies per year.

site_title: Yen soars to almost two-year high as UK releases early vote results
summary: The Japanese yen surged to a nearly two-year high against the US dollar, reaching 103.07 yen per dollar, after early vote results from the UK's EU referendum showed a more favorable outcome for the 'Leave' campaign. The pound dropped 2.2% to US$1.4560, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars also fell. The yen's 2.9% rise was its strongest since August 2014, driven by concerns over global growth and potential interest rate changes if Britain leaves the EU.

site_title: VW to pay US$10b in US over emissions scandal: source
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to pay US$10 billion to settle a US civil case over its diesel emissions-cheating scandal. The settlement will compensate owners of around 480,000 2.0-litre diesel cars up to US$7,000 in cash each, and fund a program to fight air pollution. Volkswagen had installed software that tricked emissions tests, allowing vehicles to spew up to 40 times the permitted amounts of nitrogen oxides. The company has set aside 16.2 billion euros to cover the costs of the scandal.

site_title: Michael Kors' McLaren deal fuelling push for menswear
summary: Michael Kors is expanding its menswear business through a partnership with McLaren-Honda Formula 1 racing team, with plans to create a limited-edition men's leather jacket and feature Michael Kors branding on racing gear. The move aims to boost revenue to $1 billion and reach 500 locations globally. Investors have responded positively, with shares rising 26% this year. The company is also accelerating the rollout of its menswear line and introducing smartwatches to combat slowing sales growth.

site_title: Missile test could give North Korea ICBM by 2020: US think-tank
summary: North Korea's recent test of a medium-range missile, the Musudan, has been deemed a "partial success" by a US think-tank, potentially paving the way for the development of an operational intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) capable of striking the US mainland by 2020. The test demonstrated the propulsion system and guidance system of the Musudan, which has a theoretical range of 2,500-4,000 km. Despite the success, the Musudan cannot be considered a "reliable" weapon, and its development is likely to be driven by propaganda rather than engineering.

images.alt_text: North Korea's test of a new medium-range missile could help the nuclear-armed state develop an operational intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) capable of striking the US mainland by 2020, a US think-tank said Friday.

site_title: Collaborative robots open new fronts in automation
summary: Collaborative robots, or "cobots", are set to revolutionize industrial robotics by making automation accessible to small and medium-sized companies. These inexpensive, easy-to-use, and safe robots can perform tasks such as picking, packaging, and welding, and can be adapted to new tasks with ease. The global cobot market is expected to grow from $116 million to $11.5 billion by 2025, with Universal Robots, a pioneer in the field, experiencing rapid growth and sales. Larger companies are also taking notice, with logistics giant DHL ordering cobots from Rethink Robotics for testing in its warehouses.

site_title: Are fears of mass unemployment in China overblown?
summary: China's labor market may provide more jobs for laid-off workers than expected, despite its slowing economy. The working-age population is shrinking, and the number of workers willing to migrate is decreasing, leaving jobs available for those willing to travel. While China is expected to lay off 5-6 million state workers, economists suggest the jobs market can handle the unemployment pressures. Many laid-off workers, including those in Shanxi province, have found new jobs relatively easily, often at similar or lower salaries. Experts believe the core issue is finding suitable jobs, and lowering expectations for pay or roles can make it easier to find employment.

images.alt_text: Despite its sputtering economy - or perhaps because of it - China's labour market may be able to provide more jobs for laid off workers than many think.

site_title: Polls point to UK staying in EU, Leave campaigner pessimistic
summary: The UK's referendum on leaving the European Union closed on Thursday, with polls suggesting Remain would win by a margin of 52-48%. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage expected to lose, citing high turnout and Remain's lead. The pound rose above $1.50, and markets are bracing for volatility. A Brexit would strip the EU of its second-largest economy and military power, and could fuel anti-EU sentiment across the continent. Prime Minister David Cameron's career is at risk if Remain wins, and Scotland may hold an independence referendum if the UK leaves the EU.

site_title: Soccer: No Brexit here as Britain embraces the Euros
summary: Britain's three Home Nations, England, Wales, and Northern Ireland, have advanced to the knockout stage of Euro 2016, a remarkable achievement considering the country's Brexit vote. Wales and Northern Ireland, both making their European championship finals debut, will face each other, while England is expected to join them in the quarter-finals by beating Iceland. The draw sets up potential semi-final matchups against Croatia, Portugal, or Switzerland, with Wales' odds to win the trophy decreasing from 33-1 to 20-1.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise ahead of Britain's EU referendum result
summary: European shares rose for the fifth consecutive day, driven by firmer banks and miners, as investors expect Britain to vote to stay in the European Union. The Stoxx 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indexes rose 1.5% and 1.3%, respectively, their highest points in about two weeks. The gains follow a sell-off in the previous week, with bookies and markets favoring the "Remain" camp, which could support stocks and the pound if it wins the vote.

site_title: Fiat waiting to investigate car in death of 'Star Trek' star
summary: Fiat Chrysler plans to investigate the role of a Jeep Grand Cherokee in the death of Star Trek actor Anton Yelchin, who died after the car rolled backwards and pinned him against a concrete mail box. The automaker had previously recalled 1 million vehicles due to a design issue with the automatic transmission gear shifts, which allowed cars to move freely even when in "park" gear. Fiat Chrysler is waiting to examine the specific vehicle involved in Yelchin's death and has announced a software update to effectively immobilize the cars if there is no driver in place.

images.alt_text: A Fiat Chrysler executive said Thursday said the automaker plans its own investigation into the role of a Jeep Grand Cherokee in the death of Star Trek actor Anton Yelchin.

site_title: Major Hong Kong blaze claims the life of second fireman
summary: A firefighter, Hui Chi-kit, 37, died Thursday after battling a three-day fire in Hong Kong, the second fatality in the blaze. The fire, at a self-storage unit, broke out on Tuesday and has claimed the life of a senior station officer. Two others were hospitalized with serious injuries, while nine others were discharged.
