Firefighters struggled to contain the fire due to its size and the high temperature, with temperatures reaching extremely high levels in each storage unit, separated by metal sheets.

site_title: Pound dives as first Britain EU vote results come in
summary: The pound plummeted in early Asian trading as initial results of Britain's EU membership referendum suggested the leave vote performed better than expected, with the currency briefly falling below $1.43 and to 79.17 pence to the euro. The results showed significant margins in favor of leaving the EU in Sunderland, but a smaller margin in Newcastle-upon-Tyne. The yen surged nearly three percent on the dollar in response to the uncertainty. Markets had been expecting a decisive "Remain" victory, but the results underscored the tightness of the race.

images.alt_text: The pound dived in early Asian trading Friday, tumbling from 2016 highs as initial results of Britain's European Union membership referendum suggested the leave vote performed better than expected.

site_title: US Democrats end marathon gun control sit-in
summary: US Democrats ended a 24-hour gun control sit-in at Congress on June 24, 2016, after House Speaker Paul Ryan adjourned the House for a two-week recess in response to the protest. The sit-in, led by Rep. John Lewis, aimed to pressure lawmakers to act on gun control measures following the Orlando nightclub massacre. Despite the protest's conclusion, Democrats vowed to return with renewed vigor when the legislature resumes on July 5, and expressed support from the public and the White House, including President Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton.

site_title: Maersk's new CEO appointment raises prospect of break-up
summary: Maersk's new CEO, Soren Skou, has been tasked with investigating the possibility of breaking up the company into separate entities to increase agility and synergies. Chairman Michael Pram Rasmussen stated that the group's size may hinder its ability to adapt to the changing market, and the board plans to report on its progress by the end of the third quarter. The appointment has sparked a 10% increase in Maersk shares, with investors betting on a potential break-up.

site_title: Deutsche Bank clears labour hurdle for 3,000 German job cuts
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to cut 3,000 full-time jobs in Germany, meeting over 90% of its planned cuts, after meeting with labor representatives. The bank, under CEO John Cryan, aims to eliminate 9,000 jobs globally, including 4,000 in Germany, as part of its restructuring efforts. Cryan has also scrapped dividends and sold assets to boost profitability, with a focus on digital and mobile banking services. The bank will discuss further job cuts in a second round of talks, with a third round scheduled for later this year.

site_title: Oil swings on UK vote amid weekly gain on sliding US supply
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday before fluctuating amid uncertainty over the UK's Brexit vote outcome. US oil production declined to its lowest level since 2014, while inventories dropped for a fifth week. Crude prices advanced 90% from February's low as global supply disruptions eased. West Texas Intermediate fell 0.5% to $49.86 a barrel, while Brent rose 2.1% to $50.91 a barrel, driven by a 3.9% weekly gain. The UK's early opinion polls suggested voters chose to remain in the EU, fueling market volatility.

site_title: Scientists get best measure of physics fundamental
summary: Scientists have made the most precise measurement yet of Planck's constant, a fundamental quantum physics constant, which could redefine the kilogramme, the world's standard unit of mass. The new measurement, 6.62606983 times 10^-34 kilogrammes per square metre per second, surpasses the required 20 parts per billion accuracy for the kilogramme's redefinition. This breakthrough could lead to a new, more accurate standard for mass, potentially replacing the 127-year-old platinum and iridium cylinder, "le Grand K," which has been the basis for all kilogramme measurements.

site_title: Foundation sues Airbnb for using Child's name
summary: A charitable foundation representing Julia Child has sued Airbnb for allegedly using her name without permission to promote a free stay at her former vacation cottage in Provence, France. The foundation claims Airbnb used Child's name in a contest without permission. The lawsuit was filed in the California Superior Court in Santa Barbara County on Tuesday.

site_title: Early read on China economy in june shows smaller firms hurting
summary: China's economy appears to be stabilizing in June, despite strains on small companies. Private indicators show a decline in manufacturing indexes and sales managers' sentiment, while a separate survey of larger companies indicates improving conditions. The government is boosting investment to support the private sector, but this may favor larger, state-owned corporations. This strategy risks missing out private companies, which are reluctant to spend due to debt. As a result, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Gems among plays by 20-somethings
summary: Joel Tan's play "Café" has been hailed as a standout at the recent The Twenty-Something Theatre Festival, blending elements of drama and horror to critique Singapore's strict social systems. The play follows two women's mundane conversation as their surroundings deteriorate, eerily mirroring real-life societal pressures. Director Chen Yingxuan's expert handling of tone and visual elements amplifies the tension, culminating in an unexpected and profound finale. The play's success is a highlight among the festival, which also featured promising but uneven works by other playwrights and directors.

site_title: Taiwan's largest airline grounds most flights as staff strike
summary: Taiwan's largest airline, China Airlines, grounded most of its flights due to a strike by hundreds of flight attendants over changes to working conditions. The strike, which began at midnight, affects flights out of Taipei's Songshan Airport and Taoyuan international airport. The airline had initially planned to cancel only eight flights, but later suspended all flights due to safety concerns. The strike coincides with Taiwan's president's first foreign trip on a China Airlines flight to Panama and Paraguay, and the company's management team is under pressure to negotiate with the workers and restore normal service.

site_title: Iran's huge jet orders signal ambition to join airline elite
summary: Iran has signed a deal to purchase 109 Boeing jets, part of a larger order of 230 planes, signaling the country's ambition to join the airline elite. The purchase, worth billions, would create a fleet three-quarters the size of British Airways and larger than Etihad Airways, and is expected to make Iran Air a major player in global air travel. Analysts say the move is driven by Iran's large population and strategic location, and aims to establish the country as a hub for intercontinental journeys.

site_title: Supreme Court tie blocks Obama's immigration plan
summary: The US Supreme Court ruled 4-4, blocking President Barack Obama's immigration plan, which aimed to shield millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation. The decision, issued with the court under-strength due to Justice Antonin Scalia's death, leaves the lower court rulings in place and puts the policy in limbo. The ruling is seen as a setback for Obama and Democrats, who had hoped to create a pathway to citizenship for millions of workers. Republicans celebrate the decision, calling it a victory for the Constitution and rule of law.

site_title: UBS gives IRS records of US client's S'pore account
summary: UBS, the largest Swiss bank, has agreed to hand over records on an American client's account in Singapore, ending a legal fight with the Internal Revenue Service. The client, Ching-Ye Hsiaw, had an account from 2001 to 2011. The IRS sought the records to determine Hsiaw's income tax liabilities from 2006 to 2011. This move marks a shift in the US fight against offshore tax evasion, which has previously focused on Switzerland. The IRS and Justice Department are committed to detecting and dealing with offshore tax evasion, and the records will aid in auditing taxpayers with offshore assets.

site_title: Armed man killed by police after storming German cinema
summary: An armed man stormed a German multiplex cinema in Viernheim, killing himself after police responded with gunfire. No hostages were injured, and authorities said there was no link to terrorism. The assailant was described as confused, and security sources believed he may have fired blanks. Police initially reported several shots fired and dozens of wounded people, but these claims were later denied. Authorities are investigating the type of weapon used and are still trying to determine the man's identity and motive.

site_title: Widening racial wealth gap in US very disturbing: Yellen
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed concern over the widening racial wealth gap in the US, calling it "extremely disturbing." The wealth disparity has led to significant losses in full-time employment for blacks and Hispanics, with median household incomes for blacks recovering only 88% of their 2007 level by 2014. Yellen warned that the gap could reshape consumption patterns and suppress economic growth, citing research that links inequality to reduced consumer spending.

site_title: City buzz
summary: A city buzz article highlights various events and activities, including a G-Shock x Futura collaboration, a new concept store, and a review of Thevar 2.0, a mod-Indian cuisine restaurant. Additionally, the article mentions partnerships such as NCSS with Sophia Women for financial literacy and CMC Markets with Sophia Women for financial education. It also touches on corporate purpose, zero-waste initiatives, and design solutions for unusual home layouts.

site_title: £ hits 2016 high as odds stack against Brexit
summary: Sterling reached a 2016 high as odds shifted in favor of the UK staying in the European Union following opinion polls that showed 52% of British voters would remain in the EU, while 48% would leave. Euro and US dollar/yen surged against the pound. Bookmakers' odds also favored the "Remain" camp, increasing pressure on the Brexit campaign.

site_title: US: Stocks rise with global markets amid UK referendum on EU
summary: US stocks rose, mirroring global markets, with the S&P 500 Index gaining 1.3% to a 2-month high, amid uncertainty surrounding the UK's EU referendum. Bank stocks led the rally, with JPMorgan Chase & Co and Citigroup rising 2.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also surged 1.3%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index added 1.6%. Investors await the UK vote's outcome, which may impact interest rates, with traders pricing in even odds for a rate increase by December.

site_title: Private equity may not fit retail, but regulated access beats a ban
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has proposed rules on securities crowdfunding, allowing retail investors to participate in private equity through certain rules. This move aims to provide greater access to private equity while mitigating risks. The MAS has also adjusted its rules to better define retail investor participation and closed a loophole allowing unlicensed platforms to reach such investors. This approach is seen as a better way forward than a total ban, as it allows regulators to limit the impact of failures and create a framework for retail investors to participate in private equity.

site_title: Now is not the time to sell China short
summary: China is navigating a transition from a manufacturing-based economy to a consumption-led one, despite slowing growth. The government aims to achieve 6.5% average annual growth between 2016 and 2020 through investments in regional development, higher-value goods production, and infrastructure improvements. China's economic rebalancing is underway, with the services sector growing at high single-digit percentages, driven by innovative industries like e-commerce. Despite concerns, Beijing is well-equipped to manage the transition, and the risks are manageable, making it not the time to sell China short.

site_title: Sales of new homes down in May from 8-year high
summary: US new home sales declined 6% in May to a 551,000 annualized pace, the lowest since April's 586,000 rate, according to Commerce Department figures. This marks a pullback after the eight-year high in April, but the housing market is showing gradual improvement due to steady job gains and low mortgage rates. Economists attribute the decline to supply constraints, with 201,000 homes not yet started by builders, indicating potential construction growth in the months ahead.

site_title: MTI sees 'modest' impact on S'pore in mid to long term
summary: Singapore expects the direct impact of the UK's Brexit on its economy to be "modest" in the medium- to long-term, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The UK's decision to leave the EU, known as Brexit, may have limited direct impact on Singapore, but its indirect impact on global confidence and major economies could be greater. As a trade-reliant economy, Singapore is more susceptible to market fluctuations, particularly if the pound strength falls. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is monitoring the developments closely, and the government is prepared to respond to any potential economic shocks.

site_title: Markets surge on talk of 'Remain' victory
summary: The UK's financial markets surged after a final poll put the "Remain" camp ahead of the "Leave" camp in the EU referendum, with sterling rising to its highest point this year and the UK and European stock markets powering ahead. The poll, conducted by ComRes, showed Remain leading by 48% to 42%. Bookies and spread-bet sites have odds indicating a 75% chance of Remain winning, prompting a rally in markets and a decline in the value of the pound.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister David Cameron on the campaign trail in Bristol, south-west England, on the eve of the Brexit vote.

site_title: McGregor's dual roles a masterclass in acting
summary: Ewan McGregor stars as Jesus Christ in Rodrigo Garcia's "Last Days in the Desert," a contemplative drama that follows Jesus' 40-day trek in the wilderness. McGregor delivers a masterclass performance, playing both Jesus and the Devil with understated intensity. The film's cinematography by Emmanuel Lubezki brings out the desert's beauty, but the story meanders, failing to offer much in terms of artistic or thematic depth. McGregor's nuanced portrayal is the film's standout, but the overall result is a quiet, introspective drama that doesn't quite live up to its potential.

site_title: Singapore and Germany - partners in 'Industrie 4.0'
summary: Singapore and Germany are partnering in "Industrie 4.0," a fourth industrial revolution characterized by decentralized production, smart technology, and optimized processes. Both countries aim to maintain their technological edge and competitiveness in the global market. They will focus on similar topics, including health, energy, mobility, security, and communications. Singapore's National Research Foundation and Germany's government are funding research in advanced manufacturing, engineering, and digital economy, with a goal of expanding scientific cooperation and knowledge-sharing between companies and research institutes.

site_title: Led Zeppelin did not steal 'Stairway' riff, jurors say
summary: A jury in Los Angeles has ruled that Led Zeppelin did not plagiarize the guitar riff in "Stairway to Heaven" from the 1967 song "Taurus" by Spirit. The trial, which began on June 14, found that the riff used in "Stairway" was not substantially similar to the opening chords of "Taurus." This verdict is a victory for Led Zeppelin, one of the top-selling rock acts of all time, after a week-long trial. Guitarist Jimmy Page testified that he was unfamiliar with "Taurus" and that the riff was not taken directly from the song.

images.alt_text: The guitar riff Led Zeppelin used in the 1971 classic "Stairway to Heaven" differed substantially from one the English band was accused of stealing from the US group Spirit, a jury found on Thursday in a copyright infringement trial in Los Angeles.

site_title: Cityneon stock hits new high as Avengers attraction opens in LasVegas
summary: Cityneon Holdings' stock reached a new high of S$0.905 after its Avengers STATION immersive attraction opened at the Treasure Island Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas. However, the stock ended half a cent lower at S$0.885 due to caution ahead of the Brexit referendum. The company's shares have come a long way from S$0.325 in 2015.

site_title: Singapore's CPI down for 19th straight month
summary: Singapore's consumer prices fell for the 19th consecutive month in May, with inflation dropping to 1.6%, the largest decline since August 1986. The drop was mainly due to the timing of conservancy rebates, which affected the housing maintenance and repair cost component. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport costs, rose to a 14-month high of 1%. Economists predict a temporary decline in headline inflation, with core inflation expected to remain in the lower half of the forecast range for the rest of the year.

site_title: Giving voice to the voiceless
summary: The OPEN festival in Singapore was marred by an incident of censorship when the Media Development Authority (MDA) objected to 15 photos by Iranian photographer Newsha Tavakolian, depicting Kurdish women fighting the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria. The photos, published in Time magazine in 2015, were deemed inappropriate for the exhibition and had black rectangles placed over them. Tavakolian's photography is extraordinary, documenting social and political upheavals in the Middle East, and her exhibition "I Know Why The Rebel Sings" showcases Muslim women as resilient and determined, contradicting common misconceptions.

site_title: Former Bangladesh Bank chief blames global system for theft
summary: Bangladesh's former central bank governor, Atiur Rahman, blames the global money transfer system, specifically the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, for the theft of $81 million from Bangladesh Bank in February. Rahman claims that the system's weaknesses and lack of verification processes allowed the thieves to transfer nearly $1 billion to accounts worldwide. Swift, the system used for international money transfers, has seen similar attempts to steal money, and experts are calling for improved digital security measures to prevent such breaches.

site_title: Market-rate renters keeping up with rising rents in US: study
summary: US renters are keeping up with rising rents, allowing them to save for their first home purchases. According to a study by Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies, 26% of renters paid at least half their income to landlords in 2014, up from 20% in 2001. Meanwhile, market-rate renters' median income rose from $44,000 in 2010 to almost $58,000 this year, enabling them to afford apartments and save for a down payment. However, the poor continue to face affordability challenges in lower-quality apartments.

site_title: Estimated cost to replace California nuclear power with solar: US$15b
summary: PG&E plans to shut California's last nuclear power plant, Diablo Canyon, by 2025, but replacing its output with solar energy would cost an estimated $15 billion, according to Bloomberg Intelligence analysts. The actual cost could be lower due to lower demand and partial replacement. The closure would make meeting California's goal of half its power coming from carbon-free sources by 2030 challenging, and may require increased use of natural gas for backup. The decision is part of a plan to use a mix of renewables, storage, and energy conservation instead.

site_title: Brexit vote already has a winner: the gambling industry
summary: The UK's Brexit vote has generated significant interest in the gambling industry, with betting markets predicting a narrow margin for the Remain side. Despite divided polls, gamblers have largely backed Remain, with wagers worth over £3 million placed on the outcome. The industry expects £20 million in total bets, dwarfing the £3.25 million seen in the 2014 Scottish independence referendum. The betting markets' accuracy may be attributed to economic concerns outweighing politics of identity, with uncertainty presenting an exploitable asset for bookmakers.

images.alt_text: Ask for his opinion, and David Howe eagerly tells you how he hopes Britain will leave the European Union (EU). "We need to take control of our borders," he says.

site_title: Earnings expected to stabilise for Singapore's hospitality Reits
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts Singapore's hospitality Reits will see stable earnings this year, driven by higher visitor arrivals and income from new assets. This is a more optimistic outlook compared to last year, when visitor arrivals were weaker and earnings were forecasted to fall. The report attributes the improvement to the tourism industry's recovery from a tough 2015 year.

site_title: Jury's still out on future of Bordeaux
summary: The Bordeaux 2015 en primeur campaign has concluded, with Château Lafite 2015 priced at 420 euros (S$640) per bottle. The en primeur campaign, which began in 1982, allows wine-lovers to purchase Bordeaux wines at opening prices, making significant savings compared to retail release prices. The campaign is expected to stimulate the Bordeaux market, which experienced a significant decline in 2011 due to a poor vintage and economic factors. The timing of the 2015 vintage and en primeur campaign coincides with signs of recovery in the market, but the future of Bordeaux remains uncertain.

site_title: FCL unit to launch Tokyo serviced residence
summary: Frasers Hospitality, in partnership with Sekisui House, is set to launch its first serviced residence in Tokyo under the Fraser Suites brand. Redeveloped from a four-storey office building, the 23-storey building will feature 223 units, targeting the 2020 Summer Olympics. The project is part of Frasers Hospitality's expansion in Japan, with a focus on cities like Tokyo, Osaka, and Kyoto. With Japan's low interest rate environment and projected visitor growth, Frasers Hospitality expects a rise in room rates, aiming to capitalize on the opportunity.

site_title: Best-performing China fund in US bets on new-economy stocks
summary: The Invesco Greater China Equity Fund, the top-performing US fund with exposure to Chinese stocks, has made a big bet on China's transition to a new economy by boosting holdings of consumer and technology companies. Despite a 19% drop in the Shanghai Composite Index and a 13% retreat in the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, the fund has delivered a 1.54% total return through June 16. Fund manager Mike Shiao attributes the outperformance to a long-term investment approach, focusing on competitive private companies and sectors that can benefit from China's growth, such as consumer and technology firms.

site_title: China housing partly fired-up by speculators, policy tightening seen
summary: China's housing market, driven by speculators, is expected to tighten policies to curb price rises. Cities like Shanghai and Shenzhen have already introduced measures to calm the market, but smaller cities are also seeing significant price increases. Average new home prices rose over 20% in cities like Hefei, Nanjing, and Xiamen, compared to a national gain of 6.9%. Local governments are considering measures such as higher downpayments and reduced land purchase times to curb speculative buying, which is estimated to account for half of transactions in some cities.

site_title: Major Tesla investors support SolarCity deal
summary: Tesla's CEO Elon Musk is moving forward with a plan to buy solar power company SolarCity Corp, despite the electric car maker's stock plummeting over 10% and wiping out $3 billion from its market value. Major investors, including Zevenbergen Capital Investments and Fidelity OTC Portfolio, have expressed support for the deal, citing long-term vision and potential synergies. However, critics point to a conflict of interest and financial concerns about uniting two money-losing companies. Musk will recuse himself from board and shareholder votes, leaving the deal in the hands of outside investors.

site_title: Data is the new, critical asset fuelling tech M&As
summary: Data analytics has become a critical asset for businesses, driving growth and decision-making. According to Ben Legg, group CEO of Adknowledge, data analytics is no longer just an experimental tool, but a means to faster, better decision-making, product creation, and cost reduction. Companies in the B2C sector, such as those in fast-moving consumer goods, insurance, and telco, can benefit from data analytics, using it to track consumer purchases and measure marketing initiatives. A Forrester report highlights data as a critical, acquired asset, citing Microsoft's acquisition of LinkedIn as validation of its value.

site_title: Virtual vintners toppling wine importers in China
summary: China's wine market is experiencing a shift, driven by increasingly price-savvy shoppers. Online trade is booming, with major players such as Alibaba's Tmall selling 45 million bottles of wine last year. Traditional importers like ASC Fine Wines are struggling, with sales down 9% and margins thinner, forcing them to re-strategize. Nimbler local rivals, logistics firms, and small importers are tapping the online market, taking advantage of lower prices and wider selections. This change is part of a wider boom in e-commerce in China, driven by tech-savvy shoppers and investment in online platforms.

site_title: Good show of commitment from owners of Croesus trustee-manager
summary: The trustee-manager of Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) has announced plans to internalize its management, sparking concerns about potential "sell and run" intentions. To alleviate these concerns, the two major owners, Jim Chang and Jeremy Yong, have agreed to own a minimum of S$16 million worth of units in the trust, effectively tying their interests to those of unitholders. The move is seen as a significant milestone for the property trust sector in Singapore, with analysts valuing CRT's manager at 15-16 times price-to-earnings, comparable to other asset managers.

site_title: Television's human shark baits return
summary: Wildlife cameraman Andy Casagrande and filmmaker Jeff Kurr will star in Discovery Channel's Shark Week, featuring 10 programs showcasing their deep-sea shark diving experiences. The duo aims to refute the blood-thirsty shark image by highlighting sharks' intelligence, unique personalities, and need to eat to survive. They share close calls and harrowing experiences, including Kurr falling off a boat onto a Great White Shark, which surprisingly didn't attack. The goal is to raise awareness about shark conservation, as the species faces over-fishing and slow reproduction.

images.alt_text: Kurr hand-feeding sharks from his boat (above) and diving with a lemon shark.
Kurr hand-feeding sharks from his boat and diving with a lemon shark (above).
Treating each shark as a unique individual is important to Kurr (above) - the filmmaker says people should appreciate sharks and also realise that they are in trouble and need our support.
Casagrande in Australia (above) and New Zealand. His goal in filming sharks is to refute the image of them as blood-thirsty man-eaters.
Casagrande in Australia and New Zealand (above). His goal in filming sharks is to refute the image of them as blood-thirsty man-eaters.

site_title: Owners of CRT's manager in move to allay concerns
summary: The individual majority owners of Croesus Retail Trust's trustee-manager, Croesus Retail Asset Management, have pledged to invest at least S$16 million in buying CRT units on the open market before June 30, 2017. This move aims to allay concerns from institutional investors that the owners may be "cashing out and running with the money." The owners, Jim Chang and Jeremy Yong, will receive S$32 million from the sale and will lock up their units until June 30, 2018, and then until June 30, 2020.

site_title: Police shoot dead gunman who opened fire at German cinema complex
summary: A gunman opened fire at a cinema complex in Viernheim, Germany, on June 23, 2016. Police shot the suspect dead after elite forces stormed the complex, with no reported fatalities among cinema-goers. At least 25 people were injured by pepper spray during the standoff. The gunman, wearing a mask and carrying a gun and munitions, barricaded himself inside and took some hostages. The motive behind the attack remains unclear, with no indication of a political or ideological motive. German police have foiled several plots, and the country has been cautious about potential terrorist attacks.

site_title: South-east Asia steelmakers aim to emerge from China's shadow
summary: South-east Asian countries, including Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand, are upgrading steelmaking technology and imposing tariffs to challenge China's dominance in steel imports. The region's steel demand is expected to surge due to a construction boom, with countries like Vietnam and Indonesia aiming to build modern plants to compete with China's vast mills. Tariffs have been introduced in several countries, including Vietnam and Thailand, to protect local industry and support economic development. Despite China's surplus capacity, steelmakers in the region are optimistic about their prospects, with share prices rising in anticipation of increased demand.

site_title: Helping young artistes through their struggles
summary: Young Singaporean artiste Beth Yap, 22, released her debut album "Beauty For Ashes" to No 1 on iTunes and Apple Music charts, showcasing her original songwriting skills. Yap was selected for the SHINE Festival's Talent Development Programme, paired with mentor Charlie Lim, to create original works. Yap's music is deeply personal, stemming from her own struggles and experiences. Lim advises young artistes to work on their craft, perform, and be open to criticism, emphasizing the importance of selflessness and universality in art. Yap's music aims to inspire and highlight the struggles and ambitions of young Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Lim mentoring Yap as part of the SHINE x *SCAPE Talent Development Programme.
"Music is my form of catharsis. I don't intentionally dig deep, but my experiences shape my writing," says Yap.

site_title: Obama to stay away from political issues at Silicon Valley summit
summary: US President Barack Obama will attend a Silicon Valley summit connecting 1,200 entrepreneurs from 170 countries with US technology and venture capital players. The summit, excluding hot-button issues like social media extremism and encryption, aims to foster collaboration and innovation. Obama's absence from discussing these topics reflects a shift towards technology-focused discussions. The event is part of a broader effort to strengthen ties between the US and global tech communities.

site_title: US$15b invested in new Silk Road last year: Xi
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced that his country invested nearly $15 billion in countries participating in the "One Belt, One Road" initiative last year, up one-fifth from 2014. The initiative aims to invest in infrastructure projects in central, west, and southern Asia, as well as Africa and Europe, with a total of $40 billion dedicated to the Silk Road Fund. Trade between China and participating countries exceeded $1 trillion in 2015, accounting for a quarter of China's total foreign trade.

site_title: Capitalising on the South Asian opportunity
summary: India is poised to capitalize on its large and growing economy, with a focus on building partnerships with the international Indian/South Asian diaspora. With a population of over 1.8 billion and an economy of US$8.64 trillion, India is the largest economy in South Asia and a significant player globally. The upcoming South Asian Diaspora Convention (SADC) in Singapore will provide a platform for high-level representatives to foster a climate of trust and cooperation among South Asian nations. India's young population and growing economy make it an attractive destination for foreign investments, and the country aims to harness its demographic dividend by investing in education and skills development.

site_title: Refreshing to see IMF revisiting old taboos
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is revisiting old taboos, including government debt monetization and state-mandated incomes policies, to assess their validity. The IMF is studying debt monetization, a practice already used by the Bank of Japan, and incomes policies, particularly in Japan where personal consumption has been stagnant. The IMF argues that limited debt monetization could be beneficial to stimulate long-term investment and economic growth, as private sector investment is constrained. A formal incomes policy could also aid income distribution and growth in Japan and other countries, including China, Europe, and the US, where wages have been declining as a proportion of national income.

site_title: Margin requirements up amid Brexit tension
summary: Market players worldwide raised margin requirements ahead of Britain's EU referendum, citing potential market volatility. The Singapore Exchange increased requirements for derivatives, while dealers also imposed tougher requirements on clients. Margin hikes range from 2.7-3% to 8-10% in Singapore, with some firms considering extending the higher requirements for a week. Industry experts say the measures are prudent, reducing client exposure and minimizing potential losses.

site_title: S&P's downgrade of Sabana Reit withdrawn on trust's request
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Reit to "BB+" from "BBB-" with a stable outlook, citing a weakened balance sheet due to prolonged industry difficulties. However, the rating was withdrawn upon Sabana's request following the amendment of the CIS code allowing Reits to adopt a 45% single-tier leverage limit without a credit rating requirement. Sabana's FFO-to-debt ratio is expected to be 7-9% over the next 12 months, and the company is considering asset divestments and a potential equity raising to reduce debt.

site_title: Enlarged Panama Canal seen boosting US-Asia trade
summary: Panama's expanded canal, set to be inaugurated, is expected to boost US-Asia trade, with forecasts predicting 600m tonnes of goods per year will pass through the canal within the next decade, doubling current volume. The enlarged canal will allow Neopanamax ships to pass through, reducing costs and emissions for trade worldwide. The US is the canal's largest client, with China next, and the canal aims to attract more trade, particularly in liquefied natural gas from the US to Asia.

site_title: A disappointing effects-laden orgy
summary: Former US President Thomas Whitmore awakens from a nightmare as the alien attackers return in Independence Day: Resurgence, a sequel to the 1996 disaster movie. The film, with a $165-million budget, features the original cast, including Jeff Goldblum and Sela Ward, but lacks the resonance of classic lines. The story follows President Lanford and her team as they prepare for another alien encounter, but Earth's defenses are inadequate, leading to destruction of famous landmarks and a final stand at Area 51. The film is criticized for its cartoonish dialogue and lack of staying power.

site_title: Flash PMI shows muted eurozone business growth in June
summary: EUROZONE business growth remained muted in June, with the composite Purchasing Managers' Indices (PMI) falling to 52.8 from May's 53.1. A slowdown in service industry growth was offset by a surprise bounce in manufacturing activity. French strikes and uncertainty over the UK's EU membership also impacted the eurozone's economic performance. The eurozone is expected to grow at a 0.4% rate in the second quarter, slightly faster than predicted. Companies cut prices, and inflation remains below the European Central Bank's target.

site_title: Jakarta mulls over onshore financial centre as part of sweeping tax revamp
summary: Indonesia is considering forming an onshore financial centre to allow domestic firms to create shell companies without going to tax haven countries. The move is part of the country's sweeping tax revamp, which includes a proposed tax amnesty and a levy on interest payments on global bonds to lower government bond yields. The government aims to increase tax revenue and empower the tax authority, with a projected 165 trillion rupiah (S$16.8 billion) from the amnesty programme. The plan is expected to be presented to Parliament soon.

site_title: MACC chief's quitting, new PwC survey signal faltering anti-graft fight
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft chief Abu Kassim Mohammad is stepping down amid global investigations into scandal-ridden 1MDB, sparking public skepticism about the country's fight against corruption. The decision comes after a PwC survey revealed a sharp rise in bribery and corruption in Malaysia, with 30% of organizations reporting bribery and corruption. The survey also found that 98% of top management acknowledge not condoning bribery or corruption, but employees feel unsupported to report issues. The departure of Abu Kassim and another deputy chief raises concerns about the effectiveness of Malaysia's anti-graft efforts.

site_title: Oil producers to keep output freeze talks on standby if prices weaken
summary: Russian energy minister Alexander Novak says oil output freeze talks are still on standby despite recent price gains, citing market speculators closing short positions and long positions opening. Opec member Saudi Arabia plans to maintain output levels to prevent a drop in prices, driven by fiscal pressures and concerns over global supply. Iran, a key Opec member, aims to reach desired output levels of 3.8-4.0 million barrels per day by September, making a deal on production restraint more likely. The International Energy Forum will meet in Algiers in September to discuss cooperation.

site_title: Thin trading as market awaits Brexit vote
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a lacklustre session on June 23, 2016, with only S$691 million of stocks changing hands, resulting in a 7.7-point gain for the ST Index. The low trading volume was attributed to investors waiting for the Brexit vote. Despite the weak session, UOB and OCBC helped drive the gains, while the broad market excluding warrants recorded 192 rises versus 167 falls.

site_title: Opening up of India aviation a victory for Ratan Tata
summary: Ratan Tata, patriarch of the Tata group, has secured a victory in India's aviation sector with the government's decision to open up the industry, allowing startups to fly overseas sooner. The US$100 billion conglomerate is a major beneficiary of the change, which eases restrictions on domestic airlines. Tata's airlines, Vistara and AirAsia India, have struggled to gain traction in a competitive market, but the new rules aim to boost their fleet sizes and profits by enabling them to fly overseas. Tata's clout and lobbying efforts played a key role in securing the deal.

site_title: Has Gillman Barracks turned the corner?
summary: Singapore's Gillman Barracks art cluster appears to be showing signs of improvement, with new galleries and shops opening, including NTU CCA and Sullivan + Strumpf. The cluster's footfall has increased, with a 35% annual rise in visitors to NTU CCA since its opening in 2013. However, smaller galleries continue to struggle, citing low sales and visitor numbers. The Economic Development Board and National Arts Council have set up a programme office to boost programming and integrate the cluster with the larger arts scene. Despite these efforts, business sentiments remain uncertain, with many galleries relying on a small number of serious collectors and facing high operational costs.

site_title: London stocks close 1.2% higher ahead of Brexit vote result
summary: London's main stock index, the FTSE-100, closed 1.2% higher on Thursday ahead of the Brexit vote result, as investors bet on Britain voting to remain in the EU. The index stood at 6,338.1. This follows a rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day gain, and US stocks, which edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Germany to Brits: '66 World Cup goal was valid if you stay in EU
summary: Germany's top-selling newspaper Bild has offered Britain a deal in exchange for remaining in the European Union: if the UK stays, Germany will acknowledge England's 1966 World Cup goal as valid. This is part of 11 promises made by Bild to persuade Brits to stay in the EU. The move comes as Germany and England prepare to face off in the European championship in France, with both countries reaching the knockout stage. The gesture is seen as a tongue-in-cheek attempt to sway British voters.

site_title: Rocks that tell a story
summary: Singaporean artist Oh Chai Hoo's solo exhibition "Lifetime of Change" showcases his black-and-white paintings of rock formations, inspired by Zen Buddhism and the natural world. The 56-year-old artist, trained at the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts, uses Chinese ink and self-ground pigments to capture the textures and movements of rocks. This exhibition marks a departure from his previous color paintings, and features accompanying ceramic sculptures. Oh's work reflects his fascination with the life force of rocks, which he believes have a life of their own, withstanding time and human intervention.

images.alt_text: Oh Chai Hoo draws inspiration for his art from Zen Buddhism. The Space of a Memory (2015, above) is a 48x70cm piece rendered in black pigments on rice paper.
A Thousand Years as a Fleeting Moment(2016, above), is also done in black pigments on rice paper and measures 68x150cm.

site_title: Jeep's first software fixes for recalled autos start this month: CEO
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) is set to begin providing software fixes for 1.1 million recalled Jeep vehicles by the end of June. The recall, related to rollaway risks, affects models such as the Jeep Grand Cherokee. CEO Mike Manley stated that a thorough investigation into a recent incident involving a Grand Cherokee and actor Anton Yelchin is underway, but no completion date has been estimated. The software updates aim to address the issue and prevent similar incidents.

site_title: China impounds assets of troubled metal exchange after arrests
summary: China has impounded over 70,000 tonnes of non-ferrous metals and other assets of the Fanya Metals Exchange, following the arrest of its head, Shan Jiuliang, and 15 others on accusations of running a multi-billion-dollar Ponzi scheme. The Kunming-based exchange, launched in 2011, was accused of restricting withdrawals and failing to disclose its true financial state, resulting in losses for investors. The move comes after months of protests and regulatory failures were exposed. Authorities have taken control of the assets and funds, with a statement saying they had "basically uncovered criminal facts" in the alleged scheme.

site_title: In Scotland, voters back EU with an eye on 'Scoxit'
summary: In Scotland, voters overwhelmingly backed staying in the European Union, with many aware that a Brexit result could lead to Scottish independence. Pro-EU supporters, including Scottish National Party leader Nicola Sturgeon, hope the EU vote will protect Scotland's interests and potentially pave the way for another independence referendum. However, some voters, like taxi driver James Ballantine, expressed concerns about immigration and the need for "taking back control" by voting to leave the EU.

site_title: Gold hits two-week low as Britain votes on EU membership
summary: Gold prices hit a two-week low on June 23, 2016, as Britain voted on EU membership, with the "Remain" campaign slightly ahead in opinion polls. Spot gold fell 0.4% to $1,262.89 per ounce, its lowest since June 9. Analysts attribute the decline to waning fears of a "Leave" win and the potential for a stable economy, which would reduce gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset.

site_title: M&As outstrip initial public offers as exit route for tech firms
summary: Tech firms are increasingly opting for mergers and acquisitions (M&As) over initial public offerings (IPOs) as an exit strategy, particularly in South-east Asia. This trend is attributed to lofty valuations that are beyond what public markets can pay, combined with intense scrutiny on results and macro market volatility. As a result, companies like LINE and Twilio are pricing themselves low to attract investors in the fragile IPO market. M&As are seen as a more attractive option for tech firms, allowing them to achieve organic growth, product, customer, and talent expansion, and bypass the need to discount valuations.

images.alt_text: "Founders no longer need to go public to get a large amount of capital, and they'd rather stay private and not expose all the numbers to the public."- Pocket Sun, founding partner of SoGal Ventures, described as the world's "first female-led millennial" venture capital firm investing in US and Asian startups
Twilio is seen as pricing itself low, to attract investors in the fragile, desolate IPO market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Britain votes on EU membership
summary: US stocks opened higher for the fourth consecutive day as Britain's referendum on EU membership appears to be leaning towards remaining in the bloc, potentially averting a financial crisis. A recent poll showed 52% of Britons favoring "Remain." The outcome will be announced on Friday. Global markets have been volatile due to speculation on the UK's exit from the EU.

site_title: By joining BEPS, Singapore enhances its reputation in the business community
summary: Singapore joins the OECD's base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS) project, committing to work with the international community to counter artificial profit shifting and ensure a level playing field. The move reaffirms Singapore's position in the business community and supports the OECD's comprehensive package of measures to change national and international tax laws. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasized Singapore's commitment to the BEPS standards, stating that the country will actively participate in ensuring their consistent implementation across all jurisdictions.

site_title: Armed man storms German cinema, several hurt: reports
summary: A masked and armed man stormed a German multiplex cinema in Viernheim, injuring at least 25 people, possibly with tear gas. Witnesses reported hearing shots, but it's unclear if they were live rounds or blanks. The assailant was later shot and killed by police. The incident occurred around 3:00 pm local time, prompting a police response and cordoning off the area. Details of the motive behind the attack remain unclear.

site_title: Learning made fun
summary: Maker Faire Singapore, a family-friendly festival of innovation and creativity, is now in its fifth edition. The event, which started in the US in 2006, aims to show children and adults alike the empowering aspect of creating something with their own hands using STEM principles. This year's fair features over 330 booths and expects 20,000 attendees, with a focus on education through workshops and learning passports. The event has grown exponentially, with the makers' movement in Singapore expanding exponentially since its inception, with Prof Lim noting that it's about what it means to be smart, not just technology.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Brokerages have updated their recommendations on Starhill Global Reit and M1. DBS Group Research maintains a "buy" rating on M1 with a target price of S$3.30, citing upside potential due to funding issues with a proposed joint bid. UOB Kay Hian also recommends buying Starhill Global Reit with a target price of S$0.92, citing a 5.5% base rental uplift. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" rating on Raffles Medical Group, citing a healthy healthcare sector despite delays in the group's Holland Village Mall project.

site_title: Enlarged Panama Canal expected to boost US-Asia trade
summary: Panama's enlarged canal, set to be inaugurated on Sunday, is expected to boost US-Asia trade by nearly tripling the current volume of goods passing through the waterway within the next decade. The expanded canal, costing over $5.5 billion, will allow vessels as wide as 49 meters to pass through, significantly increasing cargo capacity. Asian exporters and US logistical companies are expected to benefit from the modified canal, with costs of doing trade worldwide predicted to decrease and polluting emissions to reduce.

site_title: Barclays ceases to accept FX stop loss orders before UK result: sources
summary: Barclays has stopped accepting new "stop loss" orders, a standard trading element, ahead of the UK's EU referendum result. This move is aimed at limiting the bank's exposure to potential losses if the vote sparks market chaos. Barclays joins Bank of America Merrill Lynch and UBS in taking precautions, as the pound and other major currencies face potential gaps in trading. Sterling rose 1.5% in morning trade, while the euro gained almost 1% against the dollar.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.29 points to close at 1,639.98, driven by 1.12 billion lots valued at RM1.44 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 305-406. The index's gain was attributed to various global market trends, including a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a US stock market edge to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Saudi Arabia steps forward to put some bite back into Opec
summary: Saudi Arabia, the world's swing oil producer, is stepping forward to influence Opec's oil prices after staying on the sidelines for two years. New Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih has pledged to balance supply and demand once market conditions recover, potentially cutting Saudi Arabia's 12.5 million barrels per day of total capacity. This move could ease Opec's economic crisis, which includes a combined current account deficit of US$100 billion in 2015. Saudi Arabia's leadership may help the group agree on a new output target, addressing the 63% drop in oil prices over the last two years.

site_title: US new home sales drop from eight-year high
summary: US new home sales dropped 6.0% in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 551,000 units, the lowest since February 2008. The decline was attributed to weakness in three regions: the South, Northeast, and West, with sales in the Midwest surging 12.9%. Despite the drop, the overall housing market remains intact, with home resales rising to a nine-year high and a chronic shortage of previously owned houses available for sale.

site_title: Singapore shares close slightly higher in thin trading as market waits for Brexit outcome
summary: Singapore's stock market closed slightly higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.4% to 2,793.85 points, driven by gains in UOB and OCBC. The market saw thin trading due to investors waiting for the Brexit outcome, with a low trading volume of 753 million units worth S$691 million. The broad market excluding warrants recorded 192 rises versus 167 falls, with SingPost continuing its slide after the resignation of its COO.

site_title: US jobless claims fall to near 43-year low
summary: US jobless claims fell to near a 43-year low of 259,000 in the week ended June 18, down 18,000 from the prior week. This marks the longest streak of claims below 300,000 since 1973, with economists expecting a continued strong job market. The four-week moving average of claims also decreased to 267,000, suggesting an improvement in job growth after a slowdown in May. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen described the slowdown as "transitory," citing favorable labor market indicators.

site_title: Malaysia central bank says markets well positioned for impact from Brexit vote
summary: Malaysia's central bank stated that domestic markets have ample liquidity and are well-positioned to handle any potential volatility from the UK's Brexit vote. The central bank said market players are ready to support the financial markets and will operate earlier and extend trading hours to facilitate transactions. This move aims to maintain market stability despite the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit outcome.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank said on Thursday that the domestic market has ample liquidity and financial markets are well positioned to face any major volatility from Britain's vote on whether to leave the European Union.

site_title: Swiss bank BSI appeals 95 million Swiss franc penalty over 1MDB links
summary: Private bank BSI is appealing a 95 million Swiss franc penalty imposed by Switzerland's financial regulator Finma due to its ties to 1Malaysia Development Bhd. The bank claims the penalty is disproportionate and flawed in procedure. The US, Swiss, and Singaporean authorities are investigating potential embezzlement and money laundering of up to $4 billion through the Malaysian development fund. BSI maintains its innocence, citing "clear warning signals" ignored by Finma, which also accused the bank of breaking anti-money laundering rules and harming its reputation.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality ties up with Sekisui House to open Frasers Suites Tokyo
summary: FRASERS Hospitality Group has partnered with Japanese developer Sekisui House to open Fraser Suites Tokyo, a 23-storey serviced residence in the Akasaka district, set to open in time for the 2020 Summer Olympics. The building will feature 223 units, ranging from 35 to 60 sq m, and is located near major transport hubs and commercial developments. This marks Frasers' expansion in Japan, a key market, and aims to capitalize on increasing demand and rising room rates. The property will be managed under a contract.

site_title: Tesco recovery on track as sales rise sustained
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, reported its second consecutive quarter of UK sales growth, with 0.3% increase in sales at stores open over a year. The company's recovery is gaining momentum under CEO Dave Lewis, who has focused on lower prices, streamlined product ranges, and simplified relationships with suppliers. Tesco's shares rose 3.3% and analysts believe the company's recovery is on track, despite a challenging market with sustained deflation.

site_title: Merrill Lynch fined US$415m for using customer funds
summary: Merrill Lynch, a subsidiary of Bank of America, was fined US$415 million by US securities regulators for using customer funds to reduce its own trading activities from 2009 to 2012. The firm artificially reduced its cash held for customer accounts, freeing up to US$5 billion, and failed to keep customer securities in shielded accounts. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) also fined Merrill US$15 million for not fully disclosing costs related to structured notes sold to retail customers. The agency deemed the firm's actions a serious breach of investor protections.

site_title: Britain votes on EU membership after tight and bitter campaign
summary: The UK held a referendum on June 23, 2016, on whether to stay in the European Union, with 52% of voters opting to remain and 48% choosing to leave. The outcome was seen as a surprise, with polls suggesting a close vote. The decision is expected to have significant financial and political implications, with potential consequences for the UK economy, trade, and global markets. Prime Minister David Cameron called the vote under pressure from the anti-EU wing of his Conservative Party, and the outcome may lead to a re-evaluation of the UK's ties with Europe.

site_title: Eurozone business growth slows in June as services struggle
summary: Eurozone business growth slowed in June, with the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to a 17-month low of 52.8, down from 53.1 in May. Despite a manufacturing surge, service industry growth was sluggish, and companies cut prices at a sharper rate. This slowdown is attributed to political uncertainty, particularly in France and the wider euro area, and inflation remained below the European Central Bank's target of 2%. The PMIs suggest second-quarter growth of 0.4%, slightly faster than predicted.

site_title: Hong Kong shares close higher for fifth session
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher for a fifth consecutive session, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.35% to 20,868.34, amid Britain's EU referendum vote. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.47%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.32%. The gains were largely unaffected by the uncertainty surrounding the EU referendum, which began in the UK.

site_title: Tata patriarch's aviation ambitions a step closer as India opens up
summary: India has opened up its aviation sector, making it easier for start-ups to fly overseas. The decision benefits the Tata group, which owns airlines Vistara and AirAsia India. Although the airlines have had a slow start, the move is seen as a positive step. The US$100 billion conglomerate, led by Ratan Tata, has been a driving force behind the aviation sector's growth. The move is expected to boost the sector, but Tata's airlines still face competition from established players like IndiGo and Jet Airways.

site_title: S&P withdraws rating upon Sabana Reit's request, after downgrading it to BB+
summary: S&P Global Ratings withdrew all ratings of Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Reit after downgrading its long-term corporate credit rating to "BB+" from "BBB-" with stable outlook. The downgrade was due to weakened balance sheets amid prolonged difficult industry conditions, with a base-case expectation of an FFO-to-debt ratio of 7-9% for the next 12 months. The stable outlook reflected S&P's confidence in Sabana's ability to take creditor-friendly measures to preserve its balance sheet strength.

site_title: 'Modest' direct impact of Brexit on Singapore economy in medium to long-term: MTI
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to experience a "modest" direct impact from the UK's potential exit from the European Union (EU) in the medium to long-term, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI). Analysts predict a limited direct effect, but the indirect impact on global confidence and trade could be greater. Singapore's trade openness makes it more susceptible to market fluctuations, particularly if the pound strength falls. The outcome of the UK referendum, known as "Brexit," will be closely monitored by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and other government agencies.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares inch up ahead of Brexit vote
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5280.70, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index edged 0.58% higher to 6,821.35, ahead of the Brexit vote. Investors awaited the outcome, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Oil rises as investors await Brexit vote
summary: Oil prices rose as investors awaited the Brexit vote, with global benchmark Brent crude trading up 31 cents at $50.19 a barrel. The "Remain" campaign's lead in opinion polls boosted sterling and the FTSE 100 index. Oil defied bearish news of a smaller-than-expected US crude inventory draw, with the Energy Information Administration reporting a 917,000-barrel decrease. If Britain votes to remain in the EU, the oil market may shift focus to fundamentals, potentially leading to higher prices.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged higher on Thursday, shrugging off a smaller than expected draw on US crude stocks as money and equity markets firmed on the last sweep of opinion polls showing Britons favoured to remain in the European Union (EU).

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Key events and facts include: 
- Singapore Exchange (SGX) raised trading margins due to Brexit volatility fears, and Singapore's consumer price index fell 1.6% in May.
- Fitch forecasted that Singapore hospitality Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) should see earnings stabilize this year.
- A majority of professionals in Singapore work longer hours, but work-life balance is improving, according to a survey.
- The Singapore stock market closed slightly higher in thin trading as investors awaited the Brexit outcome.
- Vietnam expressed surprise and sought a lower tariff rate after the US announced a new tariff announcement.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Ltd said it has raised the amount of cash firms must pledge to cover trading positions due to an expected rise in market volatility linked to Britain's vote on whether to exit the European Union.

site_title: Sterling hits 2016 high, stocks climb as UK votes on Brexit
summary: Sterling hits a 2016 high of $1.4847, rising 0.3% to $1.4765, as British voters cast their ballots on EU membership. World stocks climb for a fifth day, with the FTSE and DAX indices up 0.6% and 0.5% respectively. Investors await the Brexit vote outcome, with some expecting a Remain win and a subsequent boost to the pound. Meanwhile, safe-haven bonds and the yen remain stable, while spot gold falls to a two-week low.

site_title: Burning issues at Natural Cool Holdings
summary: Natural Cool Holdings (NCH) has been involved in a series of transactions that have raised concerns among investors. The company, which was listed on Catalist in 2006, has undertaken multiple placements and issuances of new shares, warrants, and convertible loan notes, resulting in a significant increase in issued shares. In the past year, NCH made a series of transactions, including the acquisition of Loh & Sons Paint Co (S) Pte Ltd (L&S) for S$7 million, the disposal of L&S for S$33.888,888, and the disposal of L&S through an Interested Person Transaction (IPT) for S$50,000. The IPT, which was not disclosed to shareholders, resulted in a net loss of S$0.9 million for NCH. The company's board, which includes two executive directors who are also interested persons in the IPT, has been criticized for its lack of transparency and independence. The board's decision to sell the paint business so soon after acquiring it has raised questions about the initial acquisition's value and the board's consideration of the transaction.

site_title: China says debt-for-equity programme not finalised, will exclude "zombie firms"
summary: China's debt-for-equity swap programme, aimed at easing company debt burdens and converting bad loans, has yet to be finalized. The programme will exclude "zombie firms" and companies with poor credit records. Banks have written off 2 trillion yuan worth of bad loans in the past three years, but non-performing loans rose to an 11-year-high of 1.4 trillion yuan by end-March. China's central bank is investigating NPL data accuracy, highlighting policymakers' concerns about rising debt in the country. The plan must follow market and legal principles, according to a state planning official.

site_title: Under scrutiny: Palm oil watchdog to toughen sustainability audits
summary: The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) plans to introduce a more rigorous auditing process in November, aiming to address criticism over inadequate assessments and restore faith in the industry watchdog. Stricter audits could curb deforestation, habitat destruction, and human rights abuses, but may also make it tougher for producers to comply and hurt revenues. The move comes after the RSPO withdrew its sustainability certification from Malaysia's IOI Group, prompting major consumer firms to drop IOI as a supplier. The new process will increase transparency and empower an independent group to conduct surveillance and reassess findings.

site_title: China: Stocks fall ahead of Brexit vote
summary: China stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday ahead of the Brexit vote, with the CSI300 index closing at 3,117.32 points. Investors are also concerned about China's economy and the yuan's stability. The European Commission warned of potential trade sanctions against China if it fails to curb steel output. The decline was across all main sectors, with resources stocks leading the drop.

site_title: Brexit looms over Europe as growth and inflation remain elusive
summary: The euro area's private sector experienced slower growth in June, with a Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 52.8 from 53.1 in May. Business expectations in services activity weakened to the lowest in almost a year, driven by rising political uncertainty ahead of the UK's EU membership vote. The euro-area expansion slowed to around 0.3% in the second quarter, with companies bracing for the outcome of the British referendum. The European Central Bank's scope for reviving growth and inflation is limited, and consumer prices fell an annual 0.1% in May.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end higher as voting starts in Britain EU vote
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.07% as Britain began voting in its EU referendum, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 16,238.35. The broader Topix index gained 1.10% to 1,298.71. The referendum's outcome remains uncertain, but the vote's start is seen as a boost to market sentiment.

site_title: Brexit may prompt MAS easing as Singapore dollar near top of policy band
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) may ease monetary policy if the Brexit vote leads to a strong Singapore dollar near the top of its policy band. The MAS manages the Singapore dollar's movement within a trading band based on its nominal effective exchange rate (NEER). Analysts predict the MAS could intervene to keep the currency within its limits, potentially re-centring the band lower if the Brexit shock is significant. The MAS has already eased policy in April, and experts are monitoring Brexit developments closely, noting the banking system's resilience.

images.alt_text: The strong Singapore dollar may test the upper limit of the central bank's policy band in the event Britons vote to leave the European Union, prompting speculation among analysts of policy easing by the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore inflation falls to the lowest in almost 30 years
summary: Singapore's inflation rate fell to 1.6% in May, the lowest in almost 30 years, according to the country's consumer price index (CPI). This decline was attributed to low oil prices and the impact of macro-prudential measures on housing and car purchases. Economists expect the inflation trend to continue downward, with some predicting it may not return to positive territory until early 2017. The decline in inflation is seen as a positive sign for the economy, with some experts linking it to a similar trough in inflation seen during economic downturns in the past.

site_title: Singapore's consumer price index falls 1.6% in May
summary: Singapore's consumer price index (CPI) fell 1.6% in May, driven by a 6% contraction in accommodation costs and a 7.6% decline in private road transport costs. Food inflation edged down to 2.2% and services inflation rose to 1.5%. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and transport costs, rose to 1% due to a pick-up in services inflation. The decline is attributed to the timing of service & conservancy charges rebates and a larger decline in petrol pump prices.

site_title: Philippine central bank keeps key rate at 3%, as expected
summary: The Philippine central bank maintained its benchmark interest rate at 3.0% as expected, citing strong domestic demand and inflation on track to meet its target. The rate has been steady since October 2014. The central bank had introduced an interest rate corridor (IRC) in June to manage the overnight borrowing rate, which was previously set at 4.0%. The policy stance aims to balance economic growth with inflation control.

images.alt_text: The Philippine central bank held its benchmark interest rate steady on Thursday, as expected, citing strong domestic demand and with inflation on course to settle within this year and next year's target.

site_title: German private sector growth eases slightly in June: PMI
summary: German private-sector growth eased slightly in June, with Markit's flash composite PMI falling to 54.1 from 54.5 in May. Despite this, the index remained above the 50 line separating growth from contraction, suggesting a solid rate of expansion in the second quarter. Manufacturing growth accelerated, driven by strong new export orders, while services growth slowed. Companies appear to be unaffected by Brexit uncertainty, with job creation rates rising. The economy is expected to expand by 0.4% in the second quarter, according to Markit.

site_title: Gold holds near two-week low as Britain votes on EU decision
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,269.60 an ounce, touching a two-week low earlier in the session, amid cautious optimism that British voters would opt to stay in the EU, potentially tipping Europe back into recession and increasing gold's appeal as a counter-cyclical asset. A UK vote to leave the EU could lead to a drop in gold prices to $1,230 an ounce, according to analysts.

site_title: Chief of Malaysia's anti-graft panel to step down
summary: Malaysia's anti-graft chief, Abu Kassim Mohamed, will step down on August 1, two years before his scheduled end of term. The decision was made after Abu Kassim was offered a visiting expert role at an Austrian academy, allowing him to shorten his contract. The move follows investigations into Prime Minister Najib Razak's alleged corruption, including the 1MDB scandal. Najib has denied wrongdoing and was cleared by the attorney-general in January. Abu Kassim's departure leaves a second vacancy as his deputy retires in October, further undermining Najib's ruling coalition's confidence.

site_title: VW owners split for first time on diesel scandal in AGM vote
summary: Volkswagen's owners split for the first time over the diesel scandal, with Lower Saxony, a significant shareholder, abstaining from a vote supporting former CEO Martin Winterkorn and current VW brand chief Herbert Diess. The decision comes amid a tumultuous annual meeting where investors questioned the company's handling of the scandal. The move puts Lower Saxony at odds with the Porsche and Piech families, who supported the executives. The rift highlights the growing distrust among investors and employees, with shares declining 23% since the scandal broke in September.

images.alt_text: The Volkswagen AG's typically close-knit owners publicly split for the first time over the diesel crisis after the German state of Lower Saxony withheld support for two executives under investigation for their role in the scandal.

site_title: French tourism association files complaint against Airbnb
summary: A French tourism association has filed a complaint with Paris prosecutors against Airbnb, alleging unfair competition and a lack of transparency. The AhTop association, representing 30,000 hotel and tourism companies, seeks equal footing with the platform for a healthy competition and to guarantee transparency for consumers. The complaint comes as French lawmakers consider an amendment to require short-term rental registration in cities with over 200,000 residents. Airbnb has responded with a study showing a positive economic impact of €2.5 billion per year in France, its second-largest market.

images.alt_text: A French association of hotel and tourism companies said Thursday it had filed a complaint with Paris prosecutors against websites that offer private holiday rentals, such as Airbnb, for unfair competition.

site_title: Japan firm rolls out smile-rating app
summary: A Japanese cosmetics firm, Shiseido, has developed an app that rates a person's smile on a scale of 0 to 120, measuring facial movements. The app, which uses a tablet device, aims to help users identify their "winning smile." The technology is designed to provide a more objective assessment of a person's smile, allowing users to improve their facial expressions. The app's launch marks a new approach to beauty and self-care, leveraging technology to enhance user experience.

site_title: Rich Swiss bank clients seek refuge from negative rates: study
summary: Wealthy Swiss bank clients are shifting assets to investments such as hedge funds and private equity due to negative interest rates. According to a Capgemini report, high-net-worth individuals in Switzerland kept 21.4% of their assets in cash, down from 28.2% a year earlier. This trend is driven by clients seeking alternative investment opportunities to compensate for low interest rates. The study also found that the Asia Pacific region surpassed North America in terms of high-net-worth individuals for the first time.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at 7-week high, stocks ease as Brexit vote eyed
summary: South Korea's won reached a seven-week high at 1,150.2 to the dollar as investors awaited the Brexit vote results. The won was up 0.4% from Wednesday, while South Korean shares eased 0.3% due to investors taking profits ahead of the vote. Foreign investors bought Kospi shares, and Hyundai Merchant Marine Co Ltd surged 30% after negotiating with a shipping alliance. The Brexit outcome is seen as influencing the outcome of the vote.

site_title: BOJ may need to ease if market shock hits economy: Kiuchi
summary: The Bank of Japan may need to ease monetary policy if a market shock hits the economy, particularly if the UK referendum leads to a severe blow. Board member Takahide Kiuchi stated that Japan's problem is low potential growth, not a lack of demand, and that additional easing steps may not have a positive impact. Kiuchi also expressed concerns that the BOJ has not reached the limits of monetary easing, and it's challenging to come up with steps that outweigh long-term demerits.

site_title: PUB calls tender for expansion of Changi Water Reclamation Plant
summary: PUB has called a tender for the expansion of Changi Water Reclamation Plant to increase its treatment capacity by 44 million gallons a day. The expansion, expected to be completed by 2019, will produce more treated used water effluent for NEWater production and boost the water recycling rate. The project includes the installation of advanced membrane bioreactor (MBR) equipment, making Changi WRP one of the world's largest MBR facilities. The expansion aims to ensure a robust and sustainable water supply for Singapore's future.

site_title: Singapore hospitality Reits should see earnings stabilise this year: Fitch (Amended)
summary: Fitch Ratings forecasts Singapore's hospitality Reits to stabilize earnings in 2016 due to higher visitor arrivals, particularly from China and Indonesia, which increased by 14% year-over-year in January to April. The expected growth is partly offset by an 11% increase in hotel room supply. Fitch also notes that new asset acquisitions and refurbishments by Reits such as Ascott Residence Trust and OUE Hospitality Trust are expected to boost earnings. However, downside risks include weaker fundamentals in Singapore and Australia.

site_title: Honda recalls nearly 150,000 vehicles in Malaysia
summary: Honda Malaysia is recalling 147,894 vehicles to replace the front passenger airbag inflator, affecting 2003-2011 models. This recall follows a similar action by Honda Motor in Japan and comes after auto parts maker Takata Corp agreed to declare more of its airbags as defective in the US. The recall will not affect current selling models, and Honda has previously recalled around 784,000 vehicles in Japan. The company aims to address safety concerns related to the defective airbag inflators.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as voting starts in Britain's EU referendum
summary: European shares rose 0.5% on Thursday as copper prices lifted mining stocks, despite a Britain EU referendum vote expected to be closely contested. The FTSE 100 index was up 0.7% and sterling rose on currency markets. Supermarket Tesco reported UK underlying sales growth for a second quarter, contributing to the market's gains. The outcome of the referendum remains uncertain, with most polls showing a "Remain" and "Leave" tie.

site_title: Singapore ranks 5th for supporting high-potential women entrepreneurs
summary: Singapore ranks 5th globally in supporting high-potential women entrepreneurs, ahead of cities like Hong Kong and Paris, according to a study by Dell and IHS. The Republic's ability to attract and support these women has been recognized, with Singapore being ranked fifth on the list.

site_title: Polls open in historic British vote on EU
summary: Millions of Britons began voting in a historic referendum on EU membership, with 46.5 million registered voters deciding on the UK's future in the 28-nation bloc. The referendum asks whether the UK should remain or leave the EU, with world financial markets on high alert for the result. A "Remain" or "Leave" option will be drawn by each voter, potentially sparking the greatest emergency of the EU's 60-year history if the UK votes to leave. The outcome will determine the UK's economic and diplomatic future.

site_title: Seoul needs structural reforms backed by fiscal, monetary policies: central bank board
summary: South Korea's central bank board emphasizes the need for structural reforms backed by fiscal and monetary policies to stabilize the economy amid external risks. The board cites uncertainties in the US and Chinese economies as a concern for South Korea's export-focused economy. Policy member Hahm Joon Ho warns that the economy could slow if appropriate actions are not taken. This comes amid speculation of a supplementary budget announcement by the government to boost economic activity.

site_title: Hong Kong pro-democracy lawmaker charged with corruption
summary: Veteran pro-democracy lawmaker Leung Kwok-hung, known as "Long Hair," was charged with corruption by Hong Kong's corruption bureau over a payment of HK$250,000 from anti-China media tycoon Jimmy Lai. Leung, a prominent activist, was accused of misconduct in public office and will appear in court on Friday. His arrest comes as fears grow in Hong Kong that China is tightening its grip on the semi-autonomous city, just months before parliamentary elections.

site_title: Bitcoin loses 25% in five days as Brexit odds fall, ether sinks
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 6.1% to $573.84, losing 25% in five days, amid concerns over the UK's Brexit referendum. Investors tracked the odds of a Brexit, which governments warned may spark turmoil. A hack on another cryptocurrency also eroded confidence in digital assets. The price drop follows a two-year high reached just last Friday.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares touch firmer as investors countdown to Brexit vote
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,282.2, driven by a 1% surge in iron ore prices and optimism that Britain would stay in the European Union. The S&P/ASX 200 index had been volatile amid the Brexit vote countdown. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index gained 0.7% as investors' fears of a British exit eased. Air New Zealand and Spark led gains, while Nuplex fell 1.9% due to a delay in EU anti-trust clearance review.

site_title: China concerned about protectionism in US steel sector: Commerce Ministry
