summary: China's Commerce Ministry expressed concern over US protectionism in the steel sector, citing overprotection that has made the US sector uncompetitive. The ministry urged the US to abide by World Trade Organization rules, citing 161 duties imposed on steel products against other countries. China has raised production despite efforts to cut overcapacity, escalating trade spats. The ministry warned that growing trade protectionism will intensify conflicts and disputes, rather than solving problems. China is prioritizing supply-side reform in the steel sector to overhaul its industrial sector.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollar bulls pin hopes on Britain staying in EU
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose on optimism that Britain will stay in the European Union, with the kiwi near a one-year peak. Two opinion polls showed the "Remain" camp ahead of the "Leave" camp just hours before the UK referendum. The Australian dollar traded 0.2% higher at US$0.7517, while the New Zealand dollar was just shy of its peak. This positive sentiment is attributed to the uncertainty surrounding the UK's EU membership, which has led to increased investor confidence in the region's currencies.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars stayed firm on Thursday, with the kiwi a whisker short of a one-year peak, on optimism that Britain will stay in the European Union.

site_title: China's debt defaults will not post systemic risk: govt document
summary: China's debt defaults are unlikely to pose a systemic risk as long as economic growth remains within a reasonable range, according to a government document. The document states that corporate leverage ratios can even increase if economic growth is unstable. China's overall debt risk is considered controllable, and the government is monitoring the situation to ensure stability.

site_title: Oil prices rise ahead of Brexit vote
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia ahead of the UK's Brexit vote, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate up 39 cents to $49.52 and Brent up 34 cents to $50.22. Traders are watching the referendum closely, as a British exit could lead to recession and global spillover effects. Despite polls showing the "remain" side as favorites, analysts note that polls are susceptible to bias, and markets are pricing in a "remain" outcome. Oil prices have rebounded since hitting lows in February but remain far from 2014 highs.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge up, pound rallies as Britain votes
summary: The British pound rallied against the US dollar in Asian trade ahead of the UK's in-out EU referendum, with markets mostly up but traders uncertain about the outcome. The pound rose to 2016 highs, while the US dollar climbed to 104.79 yen. Global markets are closely watching the referendum, with opinion polls suggesting a tight outcome, and Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen signaling uncertainty about short-term growth.

site_title: Indonesia considers onshore financial centre after tax amnesty
summary: Indonesia is considering forming an onshore financial center to allow domestic firms to create shell companies without needing to go to tax haven countries. Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro aims to empower the tax authority and increase tax revenue. The proposed region would offer lower tax rates and easier rules for companies with offshore businesses. The government has proposed a tax amnesty program, which aims to collect 165 trillion rupiah (S$16.64 billion) in additional income. Parliament is close to voting on the bill backing the amnesty plan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher as Britain goes to polls
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.32% on Thursday, extending a five-session rally, ahead of Britain's EU referendum. The Hang Seng Index reached 20,862.59, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.11%. The market reaction was driven by uncertainty surrounding the UK's EU decision, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: China's Xi lauds new Silk Road, says US$15b invested last year
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping lauded the new Silk Road initiative, saying nearly $15 billion was invested in participating countries last year, a one-fifth increase from 2014. The program, announced in 2013, aims to invest in infrastructure projects in Asia, Africa, and Europe. China's trade with Silk Road countries exceeded $1 trillion in 2015, accounting for a quarter of its total foreign trade. Xi's trip to Uzbekistan followed similar visits to Serbia and Poland, with the initiative seen as a key foreign policy. Over 70 countries and international organizations have taken part.

site_title: China to tear up 'poisoned' school running tracks
summary: China's Ministry of Education announced plans to remove substandard running tracks from schools due to industrial waste used to build them, which caused illnesses in students. The tracks were made from scrap car tires, wires, and cables, raising safety concerns. Environmental inspections will be conducted, and officials found negligent in construction will face severe punishment. The move aims to improve safety standards and quality control for school sports facilities.

site_title: Indonesian president sails to South China Sea islands in message to Beijing
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo visited the Natuna Islands in the South China Sea, making a bold move to assert sovereignty over the area. The visit, accompanied by his security minister and foreign minister, was aimed at demonstrating Indonesia's commitment to its territorial claims. Beijing had stated its "overlapping claim" on nearby waters, but Indonesia's foreign minister rejected the stance, stating the waters around Natuna are in Indonesian territory. The visit was also seen as a way to promote infrastructure development in Indonesia's border areas, showcasing the country's ambitions.

site_title: First Pan Pacific hotel in Vietnam to open in October 2016
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group will launch its brand in Vietnam with the rebranding of Sofitel Plaza Hanoi as Pan Pacific Hanoi in the fourth quarter of 2016. The 329-room hotel, acquired in 2001, will feature refurbished lobby and dining areas, and 56 serviced suites. This marks the group's second property in Vietnam, following Parkroyal Saigon in Ho Chi Minh City. The rebranding is part of the group's strategy to establish its presence in key gateway cities in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: KFC launches 'power' meal box in India that charges customers' mobile phones
summary: KFC India has launched a "Watt a Box" meal box with a built-in power bank, allowing customers to charge their mobile phones while eating. The limited edition box is part of the fast food chain's efforts to engage with Indian customers.

site_title: Free early morning MRT rides in city area extended to 2017
summary: Free early morning train rides in Singapore's city area have been extended until June 30, 2017. Commuters can enjoy free rides to 18 stations between 7.45am and 8am, with a discounted fare of up to 50 cents for rides between 7.45am and 7.45pm on weekdays. This promotion is part of the government's efforts to encourage people to use public transport.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.59 points to 1640.67. The index saw a gain of 73 to 50 gainers to losers. Volume reached 47.4 million lots worth RM13.5 million.

site_title: Seoul: Won at 7-week high as Britain seen more likely to stay in EU
summary: The South Korean won rose to a near seven-week high, reaching 1,151.4 per dollar, as the US dollar declined and sterling and the euro strengthened following a poll showing a tilt towards a "remain" vote in Britain's EU membership referendum. Sterling reached its highest level of the year against the US dollar. Analysts say the probability of Brexit materializing is low, and a "stay" vote could renew global risk appetite.

site_title: G7 to issue statement if Britain votes to exit EU: sources
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) finance leaders are preparing to issue a statement if Britain votes to exit the European Union. The statement will reassure markets of their readiness to take necessary steps to calm volatility. The draft statement reconfirms the G7's agreement that excessive currency movement is undesirable. The statement will be issued shortly after the referendum results are clear, emphasizing the G7's commitment to stability.

site_title: SGX, Asian brokers hike trading margins on Brexit volatility fears
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has raised trading margins due to expected market volatility linked to the UK's vote on EU membership. The move aims to protect traders and mitigate potential losses. Several Asian brokers, including Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing, and Australian branch of London Stock Exchange Group, are also expected to hike margins. Market volatility has already spiked, with the CBOE Volatility index up 14% on Wednesday.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi to visit troubled diaspora in Thailand
summary: Myanmar's Aung San Suu Kyi visits Thailand, where hundreds of thousands of low-paid Myanmar laborers reside, seeking better working conditions and labor rights. Suu Kyi's visit aims to promote a new era of prosperity, potentially convincing the Thai army to allow Myanmar workers to return home. The visit is seen as a contrast to Thailand's military-dominated government, which has rolled back democracy in recent years. Suu Kyi will meet with the Thai junta leader and may visit a refugee camp, but her schedule does not include a press conference, reflecting her government's tight control over messaging.

site_title: White House slams Zika funding bill as inadequate
summary: The White House criticized a new Republican legislation aimed at combating the Zika virus, calling it inadequate due to its $1.1 billion funding, which is less than the $1.9 billion requested by President Barack Obama. The plan was also criticized for diverting funds from other health priorities.

site_title: Panama Papers looms large as Iceland votes for president
summary: Iceland votes on Saturday to elect a new president, following the "Panama Papers" scandal that tainted part of the country's elite. Historian Gudni Johannesson leads in opinion polls with 50.9% of votes, ahead of former Prime Minister David Oddsson, who is seen as a representative of the country's past financial crisis. Johannesson's calm tone and promise to modernize politics have appealed to voters, while Oddsson's campaign has been more combative. The president is a non-partisan role, with Johannesson seen as a fresh face and a break from the tainted establishment.

site_title: Yellen calls widening racial wealth gap in US 'extremely disturbing'
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen described the widening racial wealth gap in the US as "extremely disturbing," warning that it could impact consumption patterns. The Fed's report found that blacks and Hispanics suffered the greatest proportional losses in full-time employment during the recession, with median household incomes for blacks recovering only 88% of their 2007 levels. Yellen noted complex linkages between inequality and growth, and emphasized the need to understand the phenomenon.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher ahead of poll
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Thursday ahead of Britain's EU referendum, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.20% to 16,098.61. Investors moved cautiously due to the uncertain outcome of the referendum. The broader Topix index also increased 0.09%. The move is seen as a sign of market resilience despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Taiwan chip designers to lobby for ability to work with China
summary: Taiwan's chip designers, led by MediaTek Inc, are set to lobby the government to relax laws restricting investments from China, aiming to stay competitive in a global sector consolidation. The move comes as Chinese companies, like Tsinghua Unigroup, invest heavily in the chip industry. MediaTek's chief financial officer, David Ku, said the current restrictions would put the company at a severe disadvantage, forcing it to compete with global giants like Qualcomm and Samsung Electronics. The industry association plans to discuss the issue with the government in the coming months.

site_title: Saudi Arabia plans to let foreign investors buy listed bonds
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to allow foreign institutional investors to buy listed bonds, part of reforms to attract more foreign investment into its markets. The Capital Market Authority has proposed amendments to its regulations, which would allow Qualified Foreign Financial Institutions to invest in debt instruments. This move aims to increase the interest of foreign asset managers in Riyadh's securities exchange, although concerns about trading restrictions and economic slowdown may limit flows of foreign money. The reforms are expected to be implemented by mid-2017.

site_title: Currency traders face 3 am Singapore start for Brexit results
summary: Currency traders in Singapore will face a 3 am start on Friday as the UK votes on its future in the European Union. Voting closes at 10 pm in the UK, and traders expect a significant impact on the global foreign-exchange market as the results are expected to be in by 10:30 am in Singapore. With the outcome too close to call, traders are preparing for potential turmoil in the market, expecting a global fallout if Britons vote to withdraw from the EU.

site_title: Brazil speaker Cunha indicted for money laundering, currency dealing
summary: Brazil's suspended speaker Eduardo Cunha has been indicted by the Supreme Court on charges of money laundering and illegal currency dealing in connection with the Petrobras corruption scandal. This is the second time charges have been accepted against Cunha, increasing the likelihood of a plea deal. Cunha denies any wrongdoing and remains defiant despite mounting charges, which could impact his party, the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party.

site_title: EU faces big changes, with or without Britain
summary: The EU is bracing for significant changes, whether Britain votes to leave or remain in the EU on Thursday. A Brexit would trigger a migration crisis, economic woes, and a growing terrorism threat. The EU's survival is uncertain, and major reforms may be needed. The EU's future is tied to the outcome of the referendum, with the consequences of either outcome still unclear.

site_title: Japan negative rates drive biggest lenders from overnight market
summary: Japan's biggest private lenders are avoiding overnight loans due to the country's negative interest-rate policy. A Bloomberg survey found that three of the country's five largest lenders are not participating in the unsecured overnight call market, while two are raising funds to maintain client relationships. The outstanding overnight interbank loans amount is less than half the size it was six months ago. Experts say the negative rate environment makes it difficult for banks to borrow from the market, with some turning to the repurchase market for liquidity. The BOJ has maintained its monetary stimulus unchanged, citing limited impact on lenders.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to close nearly a quarter of branches in Germany
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to close nearly a quarter of its branches in Germany, with around 200 of its 723 branches set to shut down. The job cuts, totaling 2,600 redundancies, are part of the bank's cost-cutting program, which also includes 9,000 staff positions across all of its operations. Despite initial plans to cut 3,250 jobs, the bank has settled for a slightly more positive deal for employees. The bank's strategic overhaul aims to improve its efficiency and competitiveness in the German market.

site_title: Low mortgage rates boost US home sales to nine-year high
summary: US home resales surged to a nine-year high in May, reaching an annual rate of 5.53 million units, driven by low mortgage rates. Existing home sales rose 1.8% from the previous month, with the median house price increasing 4.7% to a record $239,700. Despite a shortage of homes available for sale, demand is being fueled by historically low mortgage rates, improving household formation, and trade-up buyers returning to the market. Economists expect moderate price appreciation to sustain existing home sales through 2016.

site_title: Gambling-mad Vietnamese put their houses on Euro 2016
summary: In Vietnam, the 2016 European Football Championship has sparked a surge in illegal gambling, with many betting their houses on the outcome. Reports of big wins, losses, and suicides have become common, fueled by a deep-seated love for football and a culture of superstition surrounding luck. The government estimates that millions of dollars are being wagered, but exact figures are hard to come by. Those who fail to pay face harassment and threats from bookies, with some even resorting to bankruptcy or hiding from creditors. The industry is estimated to have taken in $340 million in the past year, with bookies and agents reaping the profits.

images.alt_text: Football and a flutter go hand-in-hand in Vietnam making Euro 2016 a golden opportunity for fans to enjoy two national obsessions, even for those who have already bet their houses on the beautiful game - and lost.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on profit-taking ahead of UK referendum
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday due to profit-taking ahead of the UK referendum on remaining in the European Union. The main Taiex index dropped to 8,670.25 points, while the electronics and financials subindices also declined. Taiwanese banks with UK branches were affected, with First Financial Holding Co and Mega Financial losing 0.3% and 0.8% respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.163 per US dollar, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid global market volatility.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares rose 21.05 points or 0.76% to 2,807.18, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Straits Times Index outperformed regional peers, with 28.1 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 32, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: FLASH: PUB calls tender for expansion of Changi water reclamation plant
summary: The Public Utilities Board (PUB) has issued a tender for the expansion of the Changi Water Reclamation Plant in Singapore. The project aims to increase the plant's capacity to treat more wastewater, meeting growing demand for clean water. The PUB is seeking a private partner to implement the expansion, with a target completion date of 2028. The project's cost and funding details have not been disclosed.

site_title: Oil prices rise as markets on tenterhooks ahead of Brexit vote
summary: Oil prices rose in early Asian trading on June 23, 2016, despite a smaller than expected decline in US stockpiles. The market was on edge ahead of the Brexit vote, with trading expected to remain choppy before results were released late Thursday or early Friday. Brent's August front-month contract increased 41 US cents to $50.29 a barrel, closing down 74 US cents or 1.5% the previous day at $49.88 a barrel. The Brexit vote's outcome was anticipated to have a significant impact on global markets.

site_title: S&P says Brexit would prompt swift downgrade of Britain
summary: Standard and Poor's (S&P) chief sovereign ratings officer Moritz Kraemer warned that a vote in favor of Brexit in the EU referendum could lead to a swift downgrade of Britain's AAA credit rating, citing the country's deep ties to Europe. A downgrade would make Britain's financial situation less predictable and rational, with no clear post-Brexit plan in place.

site_title: No safety for traders on Brexit day as liquidity shortages loom
summary: Liquidity shortages are looming in global financial markets ahead of the UK's Brexit vote, with traders facing potential difficulties in buying and selling assets due to decreased liquidity. European sovereign bonds have seen a 33% drop in liquidity, and currency dealers may provide only indicative prices in volatile markets. The yen has seen a surge in demand, while US Treasuries are considered a safe-haven asset. Investors are advised to prepare for volatility by running stress tests and adjusting positions incrementally.

images.alt_text: Bond and currency traders seeking refuge as the UK votes on membership in the European Union may find that the world's financial-market havens aren't so safe.

site_title: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific bans shark fins
summary: Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's flag carrier, has banned the carriage of shark fins on all its flights, effective immediately. The move comes after years of pressure from conservationists and is seen as a victory for animal rights campaigners. The airline has also rejected 15 shipment requests for shark-related products in the past year. The ban is part of a growing trend among airlines, with Thai Airways and Philippine Airlines also banning shark fin carriage. Conservationists praise the move, citing the need for more Hong Kong businesses to follow suit.

site_title: Majority of professionals working overtime, but work-life balance improving: survey
summary: A survey by Morgan McKinley found that while most Singaporean professionals work overtime, the situation has improved since 2014. Nearly half of respondents said their employer offers home-office working, and two-thirds have flexibility in start and finish times. More than a third can take time off in lieu of extra hours worked. The survey suggests that work-life balance is improving, but Singapore-based professionals remain among the hardest working globally.

site_title: US dollar falls as reduced Brexit concern renews focus on Fed plans
summary: The US dollar fell to a seven-week low due to reduced concerns about the UK's potential exit from the EU, shifting focus back to Federal Reserve policy makers' concerns about economic headwinds and interest-rate increases. Fed Chair Janet Yellen's comments reiterated a cautious view of the economy, leading to a decline in the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index. The US currency weakened 0.5% to $1.1296 per euro and 0.3% to 104.41 yen, following a 2.6% decline this month.

site_title: French parliament scraps planned extra tax on palm oil
summary: France's National Assembly scrapped plans for an additional tax on palm oil, amid criticism from major producing countries Indonesia and Malaysia, who claimed the tax was discriminatory and against international trade rules. The government proposed a new tax scheme for vegetable oils, including a tax exemption for sustainable oils, to harmonize taxes and reduce environmental damage from palm oil plantations. The move comes after a previous tax proposal was softened in March and the biodiversity bill failed to pass through the Senate.

site_title: US gun control: Democrats broadcast 'sit-in' on social media after cameras shut down in congress
summary: US Democrats broadcast a "sit-in" on social media after the House of Representatives' cameras were shut down, protesting inaction on gun control measures following the Orlando mass shooting. Representative Scott Peters of California used Periscope to live-stream the protest on the House floor. The move comes as Democrats seek to persuade the Republican majority to take up votes on gun control measures. The protest is the latest in a series of efforts by Democrats to pressure Congress to act on gun control.

site_title: Gold extends drop for fourth day as decision day arrives in UK
summary: Gold prices fell for a fourth consecutive day as investors awaited the outcome of the UK's EU referendum, with voting set to begin. The metal lost 0.4% to $1,260.69 an ounce, its lowest price since June 9. Speculation that the UK will remain in the EU has diminished demand for gold, a traditional safe-haven asset. If the UK votes to leave the EU, prices may rise to $1,400 an ounce, while a Remain vote would likely hurt prices, which have been supported by the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

images.alt_text: Gold dropped for a fourth straight day as investors prepared for the outcome of Britain's referendum on membership of the European Union, with voting set to start at 7 am local time.

site_title: France warns Brexit would be irreversible, single market access at stake
summary: French President Francois Hollande warned that a British exit from the EU would be irreversible, jeopardizing Britain's access to the single market. He stated that such a decision would be "irreversible" and urged joint initiatives to relaunch Europe, regardless of the referendum outcome. Hollande plans to visit Berlin next week to discuss potential solutions.

images.alt_text: French President Francois Hollande warned on Wednesday that if Britons voted to leave the European Union it would be an irreversible decision that could seriously jeopardise Britain's prized access to the bloc's single market.

site_title: US commerce secretary warns of 'digital protectionism'
summary: US Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker warns of "digital protectionism," a rise in measures restricting content, limiting data flows, and imposing standards to keep out foreign competition, threatening access to information and ideas, and potentially harming economic growth. She expressed concern over data localization laws, content controls, and onerous technical standards. Pritzker emphasizes the importance of an open and free Internet, advocating for a "multistakeholder" model that steers clear of government regulation, citing the US decision to privatize the Internet's domain name system as a step towards this goal.

site_title: Asia: Stocks advance as investors await start of Brexit voting
summary: Asian stocks rose as investors awaited the start of Brexit voting, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index gaining 0.1% to 129.71. Polls suggest the outcome is too close to call, with a narrow margin separating the Remain and Leave camps. Despite concerns over a potential UK exit, analysts predict a Remain vote win, but markets remain nervous. Global equity values have been whipsawed this month, wiping over $1 trillion, and central bankers warn of market destabilization if Brexit occurs.

site_title: Iran's mammoth jet orders signal ambition to join airline elite
summary: Iran has signed an outline deal for 109 Boeing jetliners, as part of a larger order for almost 230 planes, signaling its ambition to join the airline elite. The purchase would create a fleet three-quarters the size of British Airways and larger than Etihad Airways, and includes models like the A380 and 777-9. Analysts say Iran aims to emulate carriers like Emirates and Etihad, and that its large population will support point-to-point traffic, giving it an advantage in the market.

images.alt_text: Iran's signing this week of an outline deal for 109 Boeing Co jetliners five months after agreeing to buy 118 from Airbus Group SE underscores the scale of the former pariah state's airline ambitions.

site_title: Oil prices retreat on US stockpiles data
summary: Oil prices fell to below US$50 a barrel after US data showed a small retreat in US petroleum inventories and a rise in gasoline supplies. The US Energy Information Administration reported only a modest drawdown in crude stocks and a jump in gasoline stocks. West Texas Intermediate dropped 72 cents to US$49.13 a barrel, while Brent North Sea oil lost 74 cents at US$49.88 a barrel. The retreat in oil prices came ahead of the British referendum on EU membership and US equities weakened in the afternoon following polls showing the "Leave" faction ahead.

site_title: Vancouver may tax vacant homes, possibly as business investments
summary: Vancouver Mayor Gregor Robertson plans to tax nearly 11,000 vacant homes, potentially treating them as business investments, to address the city's housing affordability crisis. The tax could drive up costs for foreign investors and send new investments to other markets. The city will give the British Columbia government until August 1 to respond to the plan. This move aims to ease the city's expensive property market and reduce the number of empty homes, but may also impact the city's attractiveness to foreign investors.

site_title: ECB offers helping hand to Greek banks
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has offered Greek banks a helping hand by allowing them to participate in its refinancing operations, effective June 29. This move comes after Greece made recent progress in implementing economic reforms demanded by its creditors. The ECB acknowledged the Greek government's commitment to the bailout program and expects continued compliance. The decision aims to lower borrowing costs for Greek banks, which have been kept afloat through the Emergency Liquidity Assistance program since February 2015. The ECB also holds out hope that Greece's sovereign debt will be included in its quantitative easing program, potentially boosting the country's economic prospects.

site_title: Last push for votes as EU leaders sound Brexit warning
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron urged voters to remain in the European Union, warning that leaving the bloc would be "final" with no possibility of rejoining. EU leaders, including Jean-Claude Juncker and Francois Hollande, also expressed concerns about the potential consequences of a "Leave" victory. A referendum on EU membership is set to take place on Thursday, with polls indicating a slim lead for the "Remain" campaign. A "Leave" victory would make Britain the first country to exit the EU, potentially triggering a lengthy exit negotiation and significant economic changes.

site_title: In Silicon Valley, Obama to keep hot-button tech issues off agenda
summary: President Barack Obama will attend a Silicon Valley summit on Friday, focusing on entrepreneurship and international connections. The event aims to bring together 1,200 entrepreneurs from 170 countries with US tech leaders. Hot-button issues like social media extremism and encryption will not be on the agenda, instead highlighting Obama's foreign policy legacy as his term nears an end. This marks the seventh summit in a series of 17 events mainly in Muslim-majority countries.

site_title: Southeast Asia steelmakers bid to emerge from China's shadow
summary: Southeast Asian countries, including Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand, are challenging China's dominance in the steel market by retooling their steelmaking technology or imposing tariffs. Despite cheap Chinese imports accounting for two-thirds of steel consumption in the region, countries are building modern plants to compete. Vietnam's Hoa Phat Group is leading efforts, stating that "China is a major force, but we have solutions to deal with it." The region's steel capacity utilization is currently below 40%, and while China is expected to dominate the market for years, swelling demand is driving change.

site_title: IMF sees US economy 'overall in good shape' despite overvalued US dollar
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that the US economy is "overall in good shape" despite an overvalued US dollar. The IMF forecasts 2.2% US economic growth in 2016 and 2.5% in 2017, with inflation rising slowly toward the Federal Reserve's goal of 2%. The Fund views the US dollar as overvalued by 10-20% based on real effective exchange rates. The IMF warns of challenges such as declining labour force participation, productivity growth, and poverty, urging policymakers to address these issues through measures like increasing the minimum wage and improving early childhood education.

site_title: Clinton offers her vision for US economy, rebukes Trump's
summary: Hillary Clinton offered her economic vision, rebuking Donald Trump's, stating she'll close tax loopholes benefiting the wealthy and corporations if elected. She'll direct the Treasury Department to do so if Congress doesn't act. Clinton's plan includes investing in infrastructure, debt-free college, and national family-friendly policies. She also aims to raise the federal minimum wage, strengthen labor unions, and reject trade deals not benefiting US workers. Clinton's proposal is part of a five-part plan to boost the economy.

site_title: UBS gives IRS records on US citizen's account in Singapore
summary: UBS has agreed to hand over records on a US citizen's account in Singapore to the IRS, ending a legal fight. The records pertain to Ching-Ye Hsiaw, a US client who lives in China. This move comes as the IRS seeks to move beyond Switzerland in its fight against offshore tax evasion. The records were handed over after a federal judge in Miami ordered UBS to produce documents. The agreement marks a significant development in the US's efforts to combat tax evasion through international cooperation.

site_title: Bookmakers bet on Britain staying in EU
summary: Bookmakers are betting heavily on Britain staying in the EU, with Betfair and William Hill reporting record-breaking bets worth nearly 60 million euros and £20 million respectively. The odds favor "Remain" at 74% and 76%, contradicting opinion polls. However, some bookmakers, like Matthew Shaddick at Ladbrokes, express caution, citing uncertainty and the potential for outsiders to win. The EU referendum is seen as the biggest political event in British history, surpassing previous record-breaking bets.

site_title: Pound, euro push higher ahead of knife-edge Brexit vote
summary: The British pound and euro surged ahead of the EU referendum, as investors bet on a "remain" vote. The pound rose 0.7% to $1.4737 and the euro added 0.5% to $1.1313, amid concerns of economic disruption if Britain leaves the EU. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's bearish comments also contributed to the dollar's weakness. Markets are bracing for a potential shock if the "leave" camp wins, with economists warning of significant economic disruption and a sharp slowdown in the British economy.

site_title: Europe: Shares end off highs as Brexit concerns resurface
summary: European shares rose 0.4% on Wednesday, ending off highs as a poll rekindled concerns that Britain may leave the EU hours before voting in the country's membership referendum. The "Leave" camp held a one-point lead in the latest poll, with "Remain" at 44%. Banks and insurance sectors gained, with Deutsche Bank rising 1.9% after investors priced out Brexit risks. Investors are divided on the outcome, with some predicting a 50/50 result and others expecting a "Remain" vote.

site_title: Deutsche Bank ex-trader pleads guilty to rigging Libor
summary: A former Deutsche Bank trader, Timothy Parietti, has pleaded guilty to manipulating the Libor benchmark interest rate in New York. Parietti, a former managing director, submitted fraudulent information to benefit his own and the bank's trading positions. This guilty plea comes after numerous other banks and bankers were prosecuted in the rate-fixing scandal, including two former Deutsche Bank traders and the bank's previous settlement of $2.5 billion. The probe is ongoing in London, where more than 20 people have been charged.

site_title: US: Stocks dip ahead of British EU vote
summary: US stocks ended the day 0.3% lower on Wednesday ahead of the British EU vote, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling to 17,780.83. A "Leave" outcome could lead to stock market downturns, according to analysts. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with ExxonMobil and Chevron losing 0.4% and 0.9% respectively due to oil price drops. Tesla Motors slumped 10.5% after a failed bid for SolarCity, while FedEx fell 4.5% without a full-year forecast.

site_title: Clinton, Trump trade blows in sharpening US election battle
summary: US presidential hopefuls Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump engaged in a heated exchange, trading insults and policy proposals in a bid to sway undecided voters. Clinton accused Trump of being a "world-class liar" and unfit for office, while Trump retaliated by labeling Clinton "corrupt" and promising to protect working Americans. The two candidates clashed on issues such as trade, foreign policy, and immigration, with Clinton vowing to fight inequality and build a new economy, and Trump criticizing her record on these issues. The exchange marked a sharp escalation in the campaign ahead of the November general election.

site_title: Goodbye, password - as banks opt to scan fingers and faces instead
summary: US banks are shifting away from traditional passwords, adopting biometric methods such as fingerprint scans and facial recognition to secure accounts. Several major banks, including OCBC, are using these methods, citing security concerns with traditional passwords. This trend is expected to continue as banks seek more secure and user-friendly authentication methods.

images.alt_text: Secil Watson, head of wholesale Internet solutions at Wells Fargo, using an eye scanner in the company's app to gain access to her Wells Fargo account in her office in San Francisco earlier this month.

site_title: Yellen avoids being overly alarmist about probable global impact of Brexit
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen has sought to avoid being overly alarmist about the potential global impact of Brexit, stating that the UK's exit from the European Union could have "significant economic repercussions" but not necessarily a US recession. Yellen emphasized the uncertainties surrounding the upcoming referendum and said the Fed is prepared to act as needed. Billionaire investor George Soros has warned of a possible 20% slump in the pound if Brexit prevails, while European Central Bank president Mario Draghi has expressed support for the UK remaining in the EU.

site_title: China slowdown casts long shadow over Hong Kong and Singapore
summary: China's slowdown is casting a long shadow over Hong Kong and Singapore, two financial hubs. Hong Kong's economy contracted in the first quarter due to falling retail sales and a weak property market, while Singapore saw a modest expansion, hurt by weak exports and a downturn in financial services. Banks are struggling to grow profits, hiring has slowed, and stock trading is in a slump. The China slowdown is part of a powerful storm affecting Asia-Pacific banks, which will likely hurt profit growth in the industry.

site_title: Hindu-nationalist politician blasts finance ministry adviser
summary: Hindu-nationalist politician Subramanian Swamy has attacked Finance Ministry Adviser Arvind Subramanian, accusing him of backing the US on intellectual property rights and mocking Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has defended his aide, stating the government has full confidence in him. The attack fuels concern that Swamy's real target is Jaitley, amid uncertainty over who will succeed RBI Governor Raghuram Rajan when his term expires in September.

site_title: Sterling and euro firm ahead of Brexit vote
summary: Sterling and the euro rose ahead of the Brexit vote, trading near their highest levels this year, despite uncertainty and fears of economic disruption. The pound recovered 5% from lows after bookmakers shifted odds towards a "Remain" victory. Analysts remain divided on the outcome, with the US Federal Reserve's Janet Yellen hinting at a rate hike if Britain stays in the EU, but interest rate markets price in a low chance of a rate hike if Britain leaves. The outcome of the vote remains too close to call.

site_title: North Korea leader says missile test a success, threat to US
summary: North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un hailed the successful test of a medium-range missile, the Musudan, as a significant boost to the country's nuclear attack capability. The missile, which has a range of 2,500-4,000km, poses a direct threat to US military bases in the Pacific. After a string of failures, North Korea tested two Musudans, with one reaching 400km into the Sea of Japan. Kim stated the test provided a "sure sci-tech guarantee" for developing strategic weapons, and he warned of a potential attack on US military bases in the Pacific.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has hailed the successful test of a powerful new medium-range missile, saying it poses a direct threat to US military bases in the Pacific, state media reported Thursday.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler speeds recall fix for 1.1m rollaway vehicles
summary: Fiat Chrysler has accelerated its software fix for 1.1 million recalled vehicles at risk of rollaways, ahead of schedule. The company began providing software to its 2,400 US dealers last week, with owners set to be notified of the fix's availability on Friday. The software, which includes an "Auto Park" feature, aims to prevent drivers from inadvertently leaving vehicles unsecured. The recall, linked to 41 injuries and 212 crashes, was sparked by the death of actor Anton Yelchin in a 2015 Jeep Grand Cherokee rollaway incident.

images.alt_text: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV said on Wednesday it is speeding up its software fix for 1.1 million recalled vehicles for rollaway risks like the recalled Jeep Grand Cherokee involved in the death of actor Anton Yelchin.

site_title: Surging crude prices test Jokowi's political will to raise fuel costs
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's administration faces pressure to bring back fuel subsidies due to rising crude prices, which have surged since his 2014 decision to scrap subsidies. Economists question whether the move will put additional strain on the budget. Widodo's predecessor had capped aid on diesel, and his decision was supported by investors and credit-rating companies. With oil prices falling at the time, the move did not provoke significant protests. The government's decision to reinstate subsidies could have significant economic implications.

site_title: Starwood selling US malls it got from Westfield: sources
summary: Starwood Capital Group is selling US malls valued at approximately $1.2 billion to Eastdil Secured LLC. The malls, acquired from Westfield Corp, include assets in Chicago, San Francisco, and Cleveland. This sale follows bleak earnings forecasts from department stores and internet shopping, as well as bankruptcy filings, which have dampened demand for malls among investors. The real estate market is experiencing a "very tough environment" for lower-tier malls, with several hundred potentially shutting down over the next decade.

site_title: Joan Rivers' belongings fetch US$2.2m at NY auction
summary: Joan Rivers' belongings sold for US$2.2 million at a New York auction, exceeding estimated values. A 19th-century Faberge photograph frame fetched US$245,000, while a Tiffany silver dog bowl and Louis XVI-style canapes sold for US$13,750 and US$37,500, respectively. The sale includes items from Rivers' estate, including fashion industry and comedy memorabilia, following her death in September 2014 at age 81.

images.alt_text: Items owned by the late television host and female comedian Joan Rivers fetched US$2.2 million at a New York auction on Wednesday.

site_title: IMF cuts US growth forecast, urges 'very gradual' rate hikes
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its US growth forecast for this year to 2.2%, citing a strong US dollar, sluggish business investment, and weak global demand. The IMF urges the Federal Reserve to consider a "very gradual" path of rate hikes, allowing for some modest overshooting of the inflation target to ensure against disinflation. The fund's managing director, Christine Lagarde, emphasized that the near-term US growth prospects are good despite recent setbacks.

site_title: Blackstone buys stake in Marathon
summary: Blackstone Group LP has bought a minority stake in Marathon Asset Management, a US$12.8 billion hedge fund firm, to provide it with permanent capital and help it grow. Marathon will retain its independence and control, with Blackstone's involvement expected to aid succession planning and employee retention. This is the fourth stake acquisition by Blackstone, which has raised over US$3 billion for similar deals.

site_title: Google tackles challenge of building an honest robot
summary: Google researchers have proposed a framework for designing robot minds that align with human goals, reducing the risk of undesirable consequences. The approach involves specifying the robot's objectives and constraints, ensuring that its actions are consistent with its goals. This method, known as "goal-aligned design," is intended to prevent robots from causing harm or damage, such as accidentally knocking over a vase. The researchers' work aims to create robots that can assist humans in various tasks, like household chores, while maintaining safety and reliability.

site_title: HKEx to begin Shenzhen Connect tests on June 27
summary: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEx) will begin testing the Shenzhen Connect trading link on June 27, allowing brokers to prepare for the launch despite no formal implementation timetable from regulators. This comes after nearly 18 months of waiting, with many expecting the official green light in July. Technical specifications for the test environment have been published on the exchange's website to facilitate preparation.

site_title: Britons swop pounds for euros, US$ ahead of vote
summary: Britons are exchanging pounds for euros and US dollars ahead of the European Union referendum, with currency sales increasing 74% year-on-year at the Post Office and 30% online at Travelex. Demand for foreign currency is split evenly between euros and US dollars, with some companies, like Azimo, suspending operations on the day of the referendum due to uncertainty. Forecasts predict the pound will fall sharply if the UK votes to leave the EU, weakening the spending power of British holidaymakers abroad.

site_title: Focus on philanthropy at UBS forum this week
summary: Wealthy individuals in Asia are increasingly focusing on philanthropy and impact investing, driven by the region's rapid wealth creation. According to UBS Wealth Management, philanthropy helps transmit family values and establishes a lasting legacy. Many clients believe that great wealth has a purpose and use philanthropy to express their values and leave a lasting impact. This trend is expected to continue as the wealthy in Asia prioritize giving back to society.

site_title: Australia's MMA catches eye of Singapore tycoon
summary: Singapore-based tycoon Michael Kum has emerged as the largest shareholder of Australia-listed MMA Offshore, holding a 10.6% stake in the marine logistics service provider. His investment comes as O&M stocks have been depressed due to a global sectorial downturn caused by a collapse in oil prices. Observers see Kum's stake as a potential sign that the tide may be turning for O&M stocks, but his motivations for the investment remain unclear.

site_title: S'pore includes yuan investments in foreign reserves
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has included yuan investments in its official foreign reserves, marking a symbolic strengthening of ties with China. The move follows China's efforts to open up its foreign exchange and securities markets to foreign institutional investors. The MAS had begun making such investments in 2012, but previously faced restrictions on repatriating funds. The inclusion is seen as a technical formality, but also reflects Singapore's economic linkage with China, with the RMB becoming the sixth most used currency in the world.

site_title: US biofuel sector shrinks despite flood of cheap soyabean supply
summary: The US biofuel sector is shrinking despite a surge in cheap soybean supply, with imports from countries like Argentina, Singapore, and South Korea reaching a record 538 million gallons in 2015. Domestic production capacity remains underutilized, with the industry operating at 71% capacity. Foreign suppliers are capitalizing on new incentives, federal mandates, and California's stricter emission rules, making it difficult for domestic producers to compete. The US imports 31% of its mandated biodiesel use, with imports set to increase further in 2016 and 2017, putting domestic producers at a disadvantage.

site_title: Existing home sales hit 9-year high
summary: US existing home sales rose 1.8% to a 9-year high of 5.53 million units in May, exceeding forecasts. The increase suggests a solid economy despite a slowdown in job growth. Sales were up 4.5% from a year ago, with the Northeast and South experiencing significant gains. The median house price rose 4.7% to a record $239,700, driven by tight inventories. The strong sales data adds to a positive economic outlook, alleviating concerns about the economic outlook.

site_title: Samsung takes mobile payments fight to Apple
summary: Samsung is taking a different approach to mobile payments, viewing its service as a way to drive sales of its phones and other devices, rather than seeking fees from financial partners. Unlike Apple, which charges banks a 0.15% fee per transaction, Samsung plans to keep its partnerships with banks flexible, allowing it to scale up quickly. Samsung Pay has already processed over $1 billion in transactions in South Korea and is available in Australia, Singapore, and China, with an estimated $1 trillion worth of mobile transactions completed in China last year.

site_title: Tesla offers to buy SolarCity for US$2.8b
summary: Tesla is offering to buy SolarCity for $2.8 billion, with CEO Elon Musk calling it a "no brainer." The deal would allow Tesla to sell customers an electric car, home battery, and solar system in one visit. However, Tesla investors are punishing the company's shares, citing concerns that the deal could distract from Tesla's core business and financially strain the company. SolarCity has significant liabilities, including $6.24 billion in debt, which Tesla claims will be paid through predictable cash flow from solar system sales.

site_title: GIC in talks to sell 2 Paris CBD buildings: sources
summary: GIC Pte Ltd, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, is in talks to sell two Paris CBD buildings valued at approximately 500 million euros (S$757 million) to Societe Generale's insurance unit. The properties, including the French headquarters for law firm Clifford Chance LLP, are part of a growing trend of investors seeking higher returns in the French economy. This sale follows GIC's planned sale of the Westin Paris hotel building, valued at around 600 million euros. Rising demand for offices in Paris's central business district is driving up rents.

site_title: Companies need to act now against tax avoidance
summary: Singapore formally joins other governments in tackling tax avoidance through the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) initiative. The country aims to implement measures against tax avoidance, including countering harmful tax practices, treaty abuse, transfer pricing documentation, and enhancing dispute resolutions. Companies in Singapore must prepare for this new tax reality, as the country is committed to implementing the OECD's BEPS standards. This move is part of a global effort to address tax avoidance and its impact on businesses.

site_title: ARA bidding for 50% stake in Capital Square: sources
summary: ARA Asset Management is bidding for a 50% stake in Singapore's Capital Square, a 16-storey office building, in a deal that could add to the recent spate of transactions in the Central Business District. If successful, the transaction would value the stake at around S$415 million, considering the building's current valuation of S$2,500 per square foot. The sale comes amid falling rents and a large supply of prime space, pushing valuations lower.

images.alt_text: Capital Square, which is spread over 388,215 square feet, was built by developer Keppel Land and completed in 1998.

site_title: Populist, anti-expert mood shaping Brexit supporters' views
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron's final push to persuade the country to stay in the European Union was met with resistance from a populist, anti-expert crowd. Despite warnings from experts, including the OECD, IMF, and Bank of England, a majority of voters remain skeptical. The Brexit vote is seen as a referendum on trust in experts and institutions, with polls showing a tight tie. The "leave" campaign has capitalized on this sentiment, dismissing expert opinions as part of an elitist conspiracy. The outcome will have significant implications for Britain's global role and economy.

site_title: Hao Yuan's Northwave EC likely to be priced at average S$760 psf
summary: Hao Yuan Investment's executive condominium (EC) project Northwave is expected to be priced at an average S$760 per square foot (psf), according to sources. The e-application for the project will open from Saturday to July 7, with booking expected to begin on July 9. The project, located at Woodlands Avenue 12, offers two to five-bedroom units and penthouses, and is near the Sembawang MRT Station. Property consultants deem the price as reasonable, citing the strong supply of ECs in the area and the developer's need to be competitive.

images.alt_text: Northwave is Hao Yuan's fourth residential project in Singapore since 2012.

site_title: Brexit will not be a 'Lehman moment': UBS
summary: UBS analysts say a "Leave" vote in the UK's EU referendum will not be a "Lehman moment," despite potential market disruption. They expect the fallout to be somewhat contained due to central banks' tools to prevent a financial storm. If the UK leaves the EU, markets could fall by 12% in the near term and the pound could decline 5% in trade-weighted terms. However, analysts predict a "Remain" vote will have a muted effect on markets, and UK equities could rally by up to 7% in the near term.

site_title: 77 Robinson Road back on market - again
summary: The 35-storey 77 Robinson Road building in Singapore, formerly known as the Singapore Airlines Building, has been relaunched for sale at a guide price of S$575 million (S$1,960 psf). The building has a 90% occupancy rate and is marketed by CBRE on behalf of Savills Investment Management. This is the third time the building has been put on the market in five years, with market expectations lower than previous attempts. The sale is seen as timely, with improved sentiment towards the office market, and potential buyers include insurance companies, private equity funds, and Hong Kong-based investors.

images.alt_text: 77 Robinson Road is a 35-storey building with a net lettable area of 293,269 sq ft situated on a site with a balance lease term of 77 years.

site_title: Picasso, Modigliani boost Sotheby's sale
summary: Sotheby's London sale of Impressionist and modern art exceeded expectations, with Picasso's Femme Assise selling for £43.3 million and Modigliani's Jeanne Hebuterne fetching £38.5 million. The two paintings accounted for 80% of the £103.3 million total, beating pre-sale estimates. The sale marked a boost to the auction market, which has been scaling back due to uncertainty over Britain's EU referendum. Despite a 42% decline in sales compared to last year's event, the results were encouraging, with many works surpassing high estimates and drawing multiple bidders.

site_title: Cross-selling: key to Aviva Singapore's survival
summary: Aviva Singapore, a composite insurer, has secured a three-year contract worth at least S$40 million to provide group term life and personal accident coverage to servicemen of the Ministry of Defence and Ministry of Home Affairs. The deal is seen as a vital lifeline for the insurer, which has been struggling since its exclusive bancassurance partnership with DBS ended in 2015. Aviva's key to survival lies in its execution of a cross-selling and up-selling strategy, which will require a significant investment in its distribution channel and digital capabilities.

site_title: Lower levies for safety-trained construction workers
summary: Singapore is introducing lower levies for foreign construction workers trained in safety standards, starting October. The levy will decrease from S$650 to S$300, and their maximum employment period will be 22 years, up from 10. The changes aim to improve workplace safety and health in the sector.

site_title: Temasek unit prices US$510m PE fund bonds amid strong demand
summary: Temasek's unit, Azalea Asset Management, has priced and launched US$510 million in bonds backed by a portfolio of 34 private equity (PE) funds, with a US$1.14 billion portfolio of 590 companies. The bonds, rated "Asf" and "BBBsf," were subscribed eight times, with a third allocated to private banks and 29% to fund managers. Analysts warn of high risks and poor disclosure, citing the need for investors to understand the product. Temasek aims to broaden its co-investor base, with plans to offer PE bonds to retail investors in the future.

images.alt_text: A unit of Temasek Holdings has priced and launched US$510 million in bonds that expose investors to a US$1.14 billion portfolio of 34 private equity (PE) funds invested in more than 590 portfolio companies.

site_title: World's first Japan Rail Cafe coming to Singapore: GuocoLand
summary: GuocoLand announced the world's first Japan Rail Cafe, set to open in Singapore's Tanjong Pagar Centre in the fourth quarter this year. Operated by East Japan Railway Company (JR East), the tourist-themed cafe will represent a 70% take-up of retail space at the centre.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the cafe, which will let customers experience Japanese culture through kawaii products, gourmet food and workshops, and also feature items and services to encourage travel to Japan.

site_title: Trump beats Clinton in national poll on investor confidence
summary: A Bloomberg/Morning Consult national poll found that investors with money in the market prefer Donald Trump over Hillary Clinton, with 50% choosing Trump as better for their portfolios. Nearly 8 in 10 Republicans and 6 in 10 Democrats support their respective candidates. Investors plan to alter their asset mix based on the election outcome, with cash and gold being top choices for those who would invest more in these assets if Trump is elected.

site_title: Zen and the art of creating software for driverless taxis
summary: HISASHI Taniguchi, founder and CEO of ZMP Inc, took a sabbatical to study Buddhism, passing a test to become a shrine leader. He returned to his Tokyo office, seeking to balance ancient teachings with AI development for driverless taxis. Taniguchi aims to "sync millennia-old teachings with efforts to make artificial intelligence part of everyday life." This approach reflects his efforts to merge Zen philosophy with AI technology, reflecting a unique blend of spirituality and innovation in the field of autonomous vehicles.

site_title: Europe divided on the way forward after Brexit vote
summary: Europe is divided on the way forward after the UK's vote to leave the EU, with a public hostile to further integration and key EU nations, France and Germany, at odds over the next steps. France's Emmanuel Macron wants to launch a positive project for Europe, including a common budget and parliament, while Germany's Wolfgang Schaeuble suggests focusing on urgent problems and regaining confidence from European citizens. The EU Commission president, Jean- Claude Juncker, also signals a cautious approach, warning against pushing for more integration.

site_title: S'pore well-placed to adopt and drive payment, fintech innovation
summary: Singapore is well-positioned to adopt and drive payment and fintech innovation, with the country's high smartphone penetration and growing fintech industry. The introduction of Apple Pay, Samsung Pay, and Android Pay in Singapore has increased the use of mobile payments, with 79% of respondents likely to use their mobile phones for payments. Local banks are also embracing fintech, with many planning to launch their own mobile wallet payment options. Additionally, blockchain technology could revolutionize the financial services industry, with the potential to become mainstream within five years.

site_title: Populist upheaval supporters have only themselves to blame
summary: The UK's June 23 referendum on leaving the European Union is expected to have a significant global impact, despite the UK's relatively small share of global GDP. The outcome will influence economic and political conditions worldwide due to the global phenomenon of populist revolts against established institutions. The demographic profile of potential Brexit voters is similar to that of supporters of Donald Trump and French National Front candidates, and opinion polls indicate a wide margin of support for the "Leave" campaign. A Brexit victory could lead to a global crisis, with financial markets amplifying economic anxiety and fuelling further anti-establishment anger.

site_title: Commentary
summary: Singapore's stock market remains uncertain due to lack of earnings clarity and external uncertainty. Brokers recommend investors remain selective, focusing on stock picking. Key picks include Singtel, City Developments, and DBS. However, companies like SIA Engineering, StarHub, and M1 are on the "sell" list. Ezion Holdings is expected to benefit from the offshore windfarm industry, maintaining a "hold" rating with a fair value estimate of S$0.55. Meanwhile, Singapore Post Ltd is recommended to be sold due to recent executive resignations and increased competition.

site_title: COE premiums up across the board
summary: COE premiums in Singapore rose across the board, with Category A (cars below 1,600cc/130 hp) increasing to S$55,200 and Category B (cars above 1,600cc/130 hp) to S$57,010. This follows the relaxation of loan curbs nearly a month ago, leading to a surge in orders from dealers. The price hikes reflect the demand for new vehicles in the market, with passenger car COE premiums continuing their upward trend.

site_title: Jho Low owns firm linked to 1MDB scandal
summary: Malaysian financier Jho Low is the sole owner of Good Star Ltd, a company that received $1.03 billion from 1MDB investment fund. Contrary to previous statements, Low, not PetroSaudi International Ltd, is the exclusive beneficial owner of Good Star, according to a regulatory investigation source.

site_title: Brexit or not, markets will stay volatile due to political events
summary: The UK's EU referendum on June 23 is expected to cause market volatility, regardless of the outcome. The Leave campaign has struggled to address economic concerns, shifting focus to emotional topics like immigration and bureaucracy. A high turnout is crucial, with older voters likely to vote "Leave". Bookmakers forecast a Remain victory, but the ruling Conservative Party's internal divisions could lead to a cloud of uncertainty. A Brexit would trigger domestic turmoil, including debate over Scottish independence and potential changes in the Conservative Party leadership. The EU project will face debate about a two-speed Europe, with growing Euroscepticism in some member states.

site_title: Qatari investment fund acquires Balmain
summary: A Qatari investment fund, Mayhoola for Investments, has acquired French luxury fashion house Balmain for 485 million euros (S$733.3 million), surpassing estimates of 300-400 million euros. The fund, which already owns Italian label Valentino, aims to expand Balmain's global presence, particularly in the Middle East and US. The acquisition is expected to provide the brand with financial support to accelerate its development and growth. Balmain, founded in 1945 by Pierre Balmain, has gained momentum under artistic director Olivier Rousteing since 2011.

site_title: FAA issues commercial drone rules; no nod for package delivery
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has issued commercial drone rules, allowing businesses to operate drones under 55 pounds with certain restrictions. Drones must be operated by a licensed pilot, flown below 400 feet, and at least 5 miles away from airports. The rules do not permit package delivery, a goal of companies like Amazon and Google. While the new guidelines bring the drone delivery vision closer to reality, experts predict that federal regulators will eventually approve broader uses, including delivery.

site_title: IE Singapore gives local firms a talent boost
summary: IE Singapore is preparing local firms to capture overseas opportunities by counseling on manpower strategies and partnering to prepare Professionals, Managers, Executives (PMEs) for international careers. Group Director Angeline Chan highlights growth opportunities in urban solutions, digital products, and consumer services in Asia. The organization aims to help Singaporeans and companies overcome manpower challenges and capitalize on emerging markets.

site_title: Britons to make most significant decision in voting lifetime
summary: The UK holds a historic referendum on June 22, 2016, to decide whether to remain a member of the European Union or leave. The decision is seen as the most significant in British history, with 44.7 million eligible voters. The "Remain" camp, led by Prime Minister David Cameron, recommends staying in the EU for economic and security reasons, while the "Leave" camp, led by Michael Gove and Boris Johnson, advocates for Britain's independence and control over its laws. Polls indicate a close vote, with some business leaders warning of economic damage from Brexit, while others believe the UK can succeed as an independent economy.

site_title: Pimco: sterling could hit 30 year-low vs dollar after a Brexit vote
summary: Pimco's head of sterling portfolios, Mike Amey, predicts sterling could hit a 30-year low against the US dollar if Britain votes to leave the EU at a referendum. A "Leave" vote could lead to the Bank of England cutting interest rates to zero, but other central banks may not respond directly. Amey cites China as the biggest risk to the global economy, citing concerns over post-financial crisis credit buildup.

site_title: Trendlines associate ET View to be sold for US$16m
summary: Trendlines Group, a medical tech incubator, will sell ET View Medical to Denmark-based Ambu A/S for US$16 million. The acquisition is a reverse triangular merger, and ET View will become a private company. Trendlines, which holds a 26.46% stake in ET View, expects to receive net proceeds of approximately US$3.3 million and a gain of US$2 million before tax. The deal is subject to certain approvals, including the Office of the Chief Scientist of the Israeli Ministry of Economy.

site_title: Property investment sales in Q2 come to S$6.9b
summary: Singapore's property investment sales in Q2 2016 reached S$6.9 billion, the highest since Q3 2013. The office sector was a standout performer, accounting for 73.6% of total investment sales, with major deals including the S$3.38 billion sale of Asia Square Tower 1 to Qatar Investment Authority and the S$560 million acquisition of the Straits Trading Building. Savills Singapore has raised its forecast for the full year to S$17-19 billion, driven by confidence in the market following the mega deals.

site_title: India's economic policy will be the poorer after Rexit
summary: India's economy may suffer after the departure of Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Governor Raghuram Rajan, who is returning to Chicago's Booth Business School in September. Rajan's departure, dubbed "Rexit," raises questions about the RBI's independence and India's ability to maintain robust institutions free of political interference. The move is seen as a blow to India's reputation and may put pressure on the rupee, with foreign investors potentially losing confidence in the country's economic policies.

site_title: US crude oil inventories stocks fall less than expected
summary: US crude oil inventories fell 917,000 barrels in the week ended June 17, below expectations, marking the fifth consecutive week of drawdowns. Crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub fell 1.3 million barrels. Product inventories rose modestly. The unexpected decrease in crude inventories suggests a tightening market, but the overall impact of the decline is unclear.

site_title: Volatile session as STI sinks into the red
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed with a net loss of 3.32 points, falling to 2,786.13, amidst cautious trading ahead of the UK's "Brexit" vote. Market volume was poor at S$782 million, with only a handful of redeeming features, including a modest rebound in banks and a rebound in Cityneon's shares. The STI's early rise was attributed to traders betting on Britain staying in the eurozone, but later dropped due to concerns over a US rate hike and intensifying competition in Singapore.

site_title: Quitting Olympics an 'over-reaction': Zika experts
summary: Olympic organizers and disease experts have downplayed the Zika virus threat, saying it poses no risk to athletes. The mosquito-borne virus, linked to microcephaly in babies and Guillain-Barre Syndrome in adults, is mainly a concern for pregnant women and those planning a family. Following golfer Rory McIlroy's withdrawal from the Olympics, experts emphasize that Zika is not a significant threat to athletes, allowing the games to proceed as planned.

site_title: Inquiry into Bangladesh hack details missteps by staff at central bank
summary: A Bangladeshi government-commissioned inquiry found that human errors, including a disabled antivirus system and a "secret notebook" of IDs and passwords, played a significant role in the country's $81 million cyber heist. The inquiry identified six central bank employees who made critical mistakes, including a printer issue that missed a red flag. The report blames both Swift, the messaging cooperative, and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for inadequate security measures. The investigation suggests that faster action by employees might have foiled the heist, and a final report is expected to provide more insight into the hackers and steps that could have been taken to thwart them.

site_title: Police report detailing Jackson's porn collection surfaces
summary: A newly surfaced police report from 2003 related to Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch raid reveals his collection of pornography and attraction to children. The report, submitted during his 2005 child molestation trial, contains details about seized books, magazines, and documents, including images of nude young adults, child torture, and animal sacrifice. The report portrays Jackson as a "manipulative, drug-and-sex-crazed predator" who used these materials to groom and abuse children. Despite Jackson's acquittal, the report's release has sparked outrage from his estate and nephew, who claim it is a "sleazy" and "click bait" attempt to smear Jackson's legacy.

site_title: Technology blurring line between physical, digital worlds: panellist
summary: A panel discussion at the 2016 Asia Business Series in Singapore explored the impact of emerging technologies such as the Internet of Things (IOT) and advanced robotics on businesses and consumers. Experts, including a special adviser to the Institute on Asian Consumer Insight, emphasized the blurring of lines between physical and digital worlds, enabling consumers to interact with humans and robots. The panel discussed the potential benefits of these technologies, including improved healthcare outcomes and enhanced customer experiences, while also highlighting concerns around data privacy and security.

images.alt_text: (From left:) Mr Pereda, executive director, The Nielsen Company; Prof Schmitt, special adviser, ACI; Prof Goh, ACI fellow & associate professor at NTU's Nanyang Business School; Mr Rezel, CEO, Rezonate Consulting SG; Prof Sim, deputy chief executive (clinical enterprise), National University Health System & CEO, National University Hospital.

site_title: How to survive being an Airbnb host
summary: A travel writer shares her disappointing experience as an Airbnb host in Austin, Texas, after two guests left a scathing review, citing a lack of supplies in the kitchen and other amenities. The writer initially received high praise from the guests but was devastated by the negative review, which impacted her search placement and star rating. The article highlights the importance of communication, pricing, and hospitality in the sharing economy, and how Airbnb's strict policies can be harsh on hosts who fail to meet expectations.

site_title: Abu Dhabi bank deal likely to be merger of equals, not takeover: sources
summary: Abu Dhabi's planned consolidation of two of its largest banks, National Bank of Abu Dhabi PJSC and First Gulf Bank PJSC, is likely to be structured as a merger of equals, rather than a takeover of NBAD by FGB. Sources close to the matter have confirmed that the deal would be an equal partnership, contrary to speculation that FGB would acquire NBAD. The merger aims to create a stronger, more competitive bank in the region.

site_title: US industry injured by cold-rolled steel from China, Japan: ITC
summary: The US International Trade Commission has found that imports of cold-rolled steel products from China are harming US producers, paving the way for 522% antidumping duties and 71.35% anti-dumping duties on Japanese producers. The original complaint was filed in 2015 by major US steel companies, including United States Steel and ArcelorMittal USA. Chinese companies Angang Group Hong Kong Holdings Ltd, Benxi Iron and Steel (Group) Special Steel Co Ltd, and Qian'an Golden Point Trading Co Ltd, and Japanese producers Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal Corp and JFE Steel Corp will be affected.

site_title: Pricey Swiss mortgages add to Brexit battering of Poland's zloty
summary: Poland's currency, the zloty, has declined 4% against the Swiss franc due to concerns over the impact of a potential Brexit on the country's economy. The franc's value may rise further if Britain leaves the EU, putting more pressure on Polish households and weighing on the zloty. Polish households owe $36 billion in Swiss-franc mortgages, which could become unaffordable if the franc surges. The Polish government is exploring ways to alleviate the pressure, but investors remain cautious due to asymmetric risks. A UK leave vote may be mitigated if the government steps back from policies that anger international investors.

site_title: Are the golden days of Asia-Pac banks behind them?
summary: Asia-Pacific banks are experiencing modest growth and flat returns on equity after years of impressive expansion, according to a McKinsey report. The region's profit pools declined from $548 billion to $538 billion from 2014 to 2015, the first decline since the 2009 global financial crisis. The report warns of three threats - slowing growth in China, fintech disruptions, and weakening balance sheets - that could cripple returns on equity by 2018. To mitigate these risks, banks need to raise $400 billion to $600 billion in additional capital by 2020.

site_title: Online FX broker Azimo halts money transfers for Brexit vote
summary: Azimo, an online FX broker, has halted money transfers for the UK's Brexit referendum, citing uncertainty and the inability to guarantee customer safety. The company suspended operations from Thursday morning and plans to resume on Friday. This move follows similar actions by other major money transfer companies due to the referendum's impact on currency markets.

site_title: Foreign construction workers with additional safety training to get lower levies, longer employment
summary: Singapore has announced that foreign construction workers with additional safety training will receive lower levies and longer employment periods starting October. This move aims to improve workplace safety and health outcomes in the sector, which has seen 17 workplace accidents resulting in 17 deaths since the start of the year. The new framework is a response to deteriorating safety outcomes in the construction sector.

site_title: From Calgary engineer to sommelier: laid-off oil workers try career Plan B
summary: Laid-off oil workers in Calgary are seeking alternative careers due to the industry's downturn, with many opting for more stable fields. The city's unemployment rate has risen to 8.1%, with 25,000 fewer jobs than a year earlier. Industry veterans are leaving the sector, citing instability, and some worry that returning oil workers may not be considered for current jobs. Career changers are being urged to focus on their values and skills to find a suitable career path, with some finding success in fields like finance, accounting, and construction.

site_title: IMF sees US economy in "good shape", too many in poverty
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that the US economy is "overall in good shape" despite an overvalued dollar. The IMF forecasts US growth to be 2.2% in 2016 and 2.5% in 2017, with inflation rising toward the Federal Reserve's goal of 2%. However, the IMF warns that too many Americans live in poverty. The current account deficit is expected to rise above 4% of GDP by 2020, indicating the US dollar is overvalued by 10-20%.

site_title: Gold slides for third day as speculation grows that Britain will stay in EU
summary: Gold prices fell for a third consecutive day, dropping as much as 0.5% to $1,261.27 an ounce, amid speculation that Britain will likely vote to stay in the EU in a referendum on Thursday. This follows a week of losses, driven by bookmakers' assessments that the "Remain" camp is in a strong position. Gold prices have retreated despite a strong showing in exchange-traded funds backed by the metal, with investors adding to holdings for the 16th consecutive day.

site_title: EU hints at new sanctions on China over steel
summary: The European Union is considering new trade sanctions against China over its steel production, citing the country's failure to curb its output. China's annual steel output is nearly double the EU's total, leading to a global steel crisis. The EU has seven ongoing investigations into Chinese steel imports and has urged China to reform its state-led economy and eliminate subsidies for unprofitable steel plants. The European Commission has described Beijing's pledge to cut 150 million tonnes of crude steel production by 2020 as insufficient, and warned that trade defence measures could spread to other sectors if the problem is not remedied.

site_title: Britons' demand for foreign currency surges before EU vote: Post Office
summary: Britain's Post Office reported a surge in demand for euros and US dollars ahead of the EU membership referendum on Thursday. Currency sales are up 74% year-on-year, with a 49% increase in branches and 381% increase online. Customers are exchanging pounds for a mix of euros and dollars. The demand for foreign currency may be related to the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit outcome.

site_title: Boeing's Iran deal covers 109 jets including 747s: Iran official
summary: A provisional deal between Iran and Boeing covers 109 aircraft, including 737 and 777 models, as well as some of the latest 747 jumbo jets. The deal, subject to US government approval, includes 55 narrow-body 737 jets and 27 long-range 777 jets. The acquisition aims to modernize Iran's national airline, IranAir.
