Obama criticized Trump's anti-trade policies, while Biden accused Trump's rhetoric of radicalizing Muslims. Carter emphasized the importance of US alliances, citing NATO and the US-Japan-South Korea relationship. The early attacks on Trump represent an unusual level of scrutiny, ahead of the November 8 presidential election.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama, his vice president and defense secretary took aim on Monday at policies of Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump they said would alienate Muslims globally along with US allies and neighbors.

site_title: English pound soars on easing Brexit fears
summary: The English pound surged 2.3% to US$1.4675 against the US dollar and 2% to 77.08 pence per euro on Monday, amid easing fears of a Brexit vote. This rally could be a precursor to a larger increase if Britain votes to remain in the EU, reducing uncertainty for the UK currency. Analysts note that sentiment on Brexit remains volatile due to the tight polls.

site_title: OKP Holdings wins S$18m PUB contract for drainage works
summary: OKP Holdings has secured an S$18 million contract from PUB for drainage system improvement along Lorong 22 to 44 in Geylang. The project is expected to begin on June 27, 2016, and be completed by Dec 26, 2018. This contract brings OKP Holdings' total contract value in 2016 to S$82.5 million, with a net construction order book of S$394.8 million until 2019.

site_title: Yen shakes off Brexit in longest rally for 5 years; pound wavers
summary: The yen has extended its winning streak for the eighth day, reaching its strongest level in almost two years due to Brexit anxiety. The currency climbed 0.2% to 103.70 per dollar, while the pound slipped 0.2% to US$1.4674. Investors are seeking safer assets amid concerns over a potential British exit from the EU. The yen's rally may continue until the Brexit vote on Thursday, and could be influenced by the outcome, with more yen potentially being bought if the UK votes to leave the EU.

images.alt_text: The yen strengthened for an eighth day, its longest winning streak since February 2011, as anxiety about a potential British exit from the European Union drove investors to the safest assets.

site_title: Oil jumps on easing Brexit fears, weaker US dollar
summary: Oil prices surged on Monday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate jumping $1.39 to $49.37 a barrel, and global benchmark Brent North Sea crude rising $1.48 to $50.65 a barrel. The price increase was driven by easing Brexit fears, a weaker US dollar, and lower Norwegian oil production, which added to the market's abundant supply concerns. Investors shifted back into riskier assets, contributing to the boost in crude oil prices.

site_title: POSB launches rewards programme for NSFs
summary: POSB has launched a rewards programme for National Service Full-Time (NSF) men, offering a 2% annual interest rate, significantly higher than the 0.05% rate for regular savings accounts. The programme aims to recognize the contributions of NSFs.

site_title: Asia: Stocks set for mixed start after best gain in three months
summary: Asia's stock markets are expected to start trading with a mixed tone on Tuesday, following a strong gain in global equities the previous day. The UK's referendum on leaving the EU is still uncertain, with polls showing "Leave" support at 44% and "Remain" support at 42%. Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average futures fell 0.2% due to a rise in the yen, while Australian and Hong Kong equities futures gained. The S&P 500 Index completed its strongest advance in four weeks, but gains faded amid speculation of a "Leave" vote.

site_title: Temer gives Brazil states relief on billions in debt repayments
summary: Brazil's government, led by Acting President Michel Temer, has struck a deal with state governors to alleviate fiscal crises without placing too much burden on federal coffers. The deal, worth 20 billion reais (S$7.91 billion) in 2016 and 15 billion reais in the following years, includes a discount on debt payments and a six-month payment hiatus. The agreement aims to address the country's near-record budget deficit and fiscal crisis, with the federal government set to provide emergency funds to support the upcoming Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro.

site_title: Uber loan programme helps Vietnamese swap scooters for new Hondas
summary: Uber's loan program in Vietnam is helping drivers swap old scooters for new cars, with 70% of car buyers borrowing from banks last year. The program, which finances 80% of the purchase, has enabled drivers like Vu Ngoc Hung to triple their income and improve their lives. With the program, Uber is expanding its presence in Southeast Asia and competing with ride-hailing companies like Grab. The loan program has the potential to deliver similar benefits in other countries and regions, with Uber expecting to increase its car loans six-fold in the next five years.

site_title: Europe: Shares have best day since August as Brexit camp loses ground
summary: European shares have had their best day since August, rising 3.7% on Monday, driven by a rebound in the "Remain" camp in opinion polls ahead of the UK's EU membership vote on June 23. The STOXX 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indexes moved back towards levels seen earlier in June. Heavyweight banking stocks, including Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds, rose 7% and 5.1% respectively, while travel and leisure stocks also surged, with Thomas Cook up 8.3%.

site_title: Japan business mood struggles amid Brexit fears: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business confidence inched up in June, reaching a three-year high, but remains low due to Brexit fears and a strong yen. The Reuters Tankan survey found the service sector's mood fell due to weak private consumption. The yen rose as risk appetite waned ahead of Britain's EU referendum on June 23. Despite this, economists expect a slight increase in confidence ahead of the referendum. The strong yen is also linked to concerns about Japan's economy.

site_title: Australia taxes foreign home buyers as affordability bites
summary: The New South Wales state government has introduced a 4% property tax on foreign buyers of homes in Sydney, amid concerns that a flood of mostly Chinese investors is crowding out locals and driving up prices. The tax aims to address affordability issues and protect the "Great Australian Dream" of owning property. However, analysts warn that the measure could have unintended consequences, including a decrease in construction and a drop in sales volumes.

site_title: Google aims for better health search results
summary: Google is upgrading its health results for its mobile application in English, in collaboration with Harvard Medical School and the Mayo Clinic. The goal is to provide more accurate and reliable information, reducing unnecessary anxiety and stress caused by misleading health content online. Approximately 1% of Google searches are symptom-related, and the new upgrade aims to improve this aspect. By partnering with reputable medical institutions, Google hopes to enhance user experience and promote better health information.

site_title: Ryanair cofounder eyes Argentina for next low-cost airline
summary: Declan Ryan, co-founder of Ryanair, is considering launching a new low-cost airline in Argentina, with plans to start operations in 2017. Ryania Aviation, a company linked to Ryanair, is in talks to buy a local firm to kick off its Viva operation. The airline faces challenges in Argentina, including high airport taxes, but Ryan sees opportunities for growth in the Latin American market. This would be the third low-cost airline in the region, following VivaAerobus in Mexico and VivaColombia.

images.alt_text: One of the founders of Ireland's budget airline Ryanair is eyeing Argentina as the next market for his brand of low-cost flying, following startups in Mexico and Colombia.

site_title: Trump says he's in favour of Britain leaving EU
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump expressed support for Britain's potential exit from the European Union in an interview with The Sunday Times. The remarks came ahead of the June 23 referendum on the issue. Trump stated he would be in favor of the UK leaving the EU, although he did not elaborate on his stance. His comments were seen as a significant endorsement for the "Leave" campaign.

site_title: Birth control via app finds footing under political radar in US
summary: A growing number of apps and websites in the US are allowing women to obtain prescription contraceptives without a doctor's visit. This shift aims to increase birth control usage and reduce unintended pregnancies and abortions. Public health experts believe the development could encourage more women to start or restart using contraception, potentially lowering the country's high birth control rates.

site_title: US Senate rejects four gun-control measures after Orlando shooting
summary: The US Senate rejected four gun-control measures, including expanding background checks and restricting gun sales to those on terrorism watch lists, after the Orlando nightclub shooting. The measures fell short of the 60 votes needed for passage in the 100-member chamber, with all four bills failing in largely party-line votes. Senate leaders, including Harry Reid and Mitch McConnell, criticized each other's efforts, with Reid saying the Republican bills were too weak and McConnell accusing Democrats of not being sincere. Despite a Reuters/Ipsos poll showing 71% of Americans favoring gun regulations, the outcome marks a setback for gun control advocates.

site_title: Record 65m people displaced by global conflicts: UN report
summary: The United Nations reports that 65 million people have been displaced by global conflicts, exceeding the population of Britain. Most are seeking asylum in Western countries, with nearly 100,000 children attempting the journey alone. The European Union is struggling to handle the influx, with hostility toward migrants and refugees surging. The UN high commissioner for refugees, Filippo Grandi, expressed alarm over a "climate of xenophobia" in Europe, while the UN secretary-general, Ban Ki-moon, called for an end to detention and a focus on resettlement and integration.

site_title: Fresh polls show Brexit campaigns neck and neck
summary: Brexit campaigns are neck and neck with three days to go until Britain votes on whether to exit the European Union. New polls show the "Remain" side with 49% support and the "Leave" side with 47%, a two-point lead. The "Leave" side has gained three points in a poll by YouGov, while the "Remain" side has seen a two-point drop in support. The outcome of the referendum is uncertain, with one strategist describing it as "truly coming down to the wire."

site_title: Demystifying corporate strategy decision-making
summary: Corporate strategy decisions in multi-business firms often prioritize corporate advantage over immediate industry or market success. These decisions can be extremely risky and require balancing competing interests, allocating resources, and making decisions based on partial information. Effective decision-making involves recognizing limitations, engaging with experts, and fostering diversity of opinion and clarity of language. In an ideal world, decisions should be made in a logical, informed, and widely accepted manner, weighing the most likely alternatives and considering firm-specific factors.

site_title: KL plans 1-month delay in B10 biodiesel mandate
summary: Malaysia plans to delay the start of its B10 biodiesel mandate by a month, pushing the start date to July instead of June. The new standard aims to use 709,000 tonnes of palm oil annually. The delay is to allow oil companies time to reset blending ratios and procure enough palm methyl ester, the bio component of biodiesel. The full implementation of the new standard is expected to be completed by August.

site_title: LG mulling home appliance deals to fuel global expansion
summary: LG Electronics Inc is considering home appliance acquisitions to fuel global expansion and boost earnings amid a slowing smartphone market. The company's home appliance division is expected to see 10% sales growth this year, driven by premium segments. LG plans to focus on business-to-business targets, such as component makers, and is considering expanding its production footprint to 12 countries. The company's home appliance earnings surged 78% in the latest quarter, with operating profit reaching 505.2 billion won.

site_title: Pitfalls piling up for investments in Australian housing
summary: Australia is introducing foreign investor surcharges on stamp duty and land tax for residential properties in Sydney and Melbourne, aiming to ensure local buyers aren't priced out. The taxes, set to generate A$262 million in Sydney and A$486 million in Melbourne, are expected to affect the country's record A$60.7 billion in foreign investment in 2015. Singapore, the third-largest investor, may be impacted, with A$4 billion spent on Australian residential property in 2014. Tightening lending regulations and a 10% withholding tax on properties over A$2 million are also affecting demand.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to investigate crash that killed Star Trek actor
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) announced it will investigate the fatal crash of Star Trek actor Anton Yelchin, who died when his 2015 Jeep Grand Cherokee rolled away and pinned him against a fence in Los Angeles. The crash occurred just days after FCA recalled over 1.1 million vehicles due to a potential issue with the vehicles' electronic gearshift system, which may cause them to roll away after drivers exit. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is also investigating the incident, with Yelchin's death marking the first reported fatality linked to the defect.

images.alt_text: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV said on Monday it would investigate a crash that killed Star Trek actor Anton Yelchin in his recalled 2015 Jeep Grand Cherokee.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on optimism over Brexit vote
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, reversing last week's declines as polls suggested Britain would vote to stay in the EU, boosting global equity markets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.7% to 17,804.87, while the S&P 500 rose 0.6% to 2,083.25. Key gains were seen in tech shares, with Adobe, eBay, and Expedia climbing 2.5% or more. Other notable movers included JD.com, up 4.6%, and Chevron, up 1.0%. The rally came as investors shifted their focus to the Brexit vote, which is expected to have a significant impact on global markets.

site_title: Incoming Philippine government vows sweeping improvements
summary: Philippine President-elect Rodrigo Duterte's new economic team has vowed to make sweeping changes to boost infrastructure, fix traffic issues, and maintain the country's robust economic growth. The team aims to improve investment frameworks and address concerns about Duterte's ability to manage the country's economy, which has been Asia's fastest-growing. The team's promises come as Duterte prepares to take office, following his May 9 presidential election victory.

site_title: A premature exit, to India's loss
summary: India's central bank governor Raghuram Rajan is returning to academia after a single term, leaving behind a legacy of reforms. During his tenure, Rajan brought down inflation from over 10% to 5.5% and increased economic growth from 5% to 8% within three years. His exit has been attributed to the forces of crony capitalism and "messy politics getting the better of good economics." Rajan's achievements have been widely praised, with economists noting that he would have been a "guaranteed reformer" in any country.

site_title: GLP secures new leases totalling 98,000 sq m in China
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has secured new leases totaling 98,000 sq m in China with five Chinese companies, mainly related to expansion demand from the e-commerce and retail sectors. The new leases are part of GLP's US$36 billion property portfolio, with 57% of its net asset value residing in China. The company's group profit increased by 48% to US$719 million for fiscal 2016, and it has raised its dividend payout every year since 2012.

site_title: Ezra's two deals on Emas Chiyoda Subsea fail to excite investors
summary: Ezra Holdings' shares have failed to excite investors following the announcement of a stake deal involving its 50-50 joint-venture company Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS), which will partner with Japanese shipping giant Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK). Despite a modest comeback before the trading halt, the stock has underperformed since the deal, closing at S$0.078 on Monday. Analysts question the viability of the subsea business unit, citing concerns over its loss-making streak and reliance on cash injections from Japanese partners.

site_title: Man charged for attempting to kill Trump
summary: A 19-year-old man, Michael Sandford, has been charged with attempting to kill Donald Trump at a Republican presidential nominee rally in Las Vegas. Sandford tried to disarm a police officer's gun, stating he had driven from California to kill Trump and had never fired a gun before. He claimed to have purchased tickets to a future rally to attempt the killing again. Sandford faces a charge of act of violence on restricted grounds and had been planning the attack for about a year.

site_title: Rowsley to acquire 65% of engineering firm Squire Mech
summary: Rowsley, a Singaporean real estate company, will acquire 65% of Squire Mech Private Limited, a mechanical and electrical engineering firm, for up to S$19.5 million. The acquisition aims to strengthen Rowsley's multi-disciplinary capabilities. The deal is subject to Squire Mech meeting a three-year cumulative net profit target of S$12 million. Rowsley will issue 130 million new shares to fund the acquisition, with an initial consideration of 36.4 million shares allotted to vendors. The acquisition's completion depends on Singapore Exchange approval.

site_title: China housing in flux as price recovery tapers off
summary: China's housing market is showing signs of slowing down, with new-home prices excluding government-subsidized housing rising in 60 cities in May, down from 65 in April. The recovery in the market, which had boosted the economy in the first half, is likely to taper off in the second half, prompting the government to find alternative drivers of growth, such as infrastructure investment. The government is also expected to step up policies to encourage home-buying in areas with weak demand and high inventory levels.

site_title: CDL is best-performing STI stock in June
summary: City Developments (CDL) is the best-performing Straits Times Index (STI) stock in June, with a 6.3% increase, following its reinstatement to the FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Global Developed Index. CDL's stock fell 1.6% on its addition back to the index due to short-term jitters about "Brexit" risks. Analysts expect further asset divestments to drive CDL's share price.

site_title: Paul Allen's space company nears debut of world's biggest plane
summary: Stratolaunch Systems, a space launch company backed by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, is nearing the debut of the world's largest plane, capable of delivering satellites into precise orbits quickly. The six-engine aircraft has a 385-foot wingspan and can carry a rocket and payload of up to 550,000 pounds. Unlike competitors like SpaceX and Blue Origin, Stratolaunch's focus is on launching satellites into low-altitude orbits, offering a service that will set it apart from competitors. The plane is expected to be finished by the end of the year, with commercial services starting before 2020.

site_title: Enjoying energy savings that don't cost the earth (Amended)
summary: Singapore-based startup Barghest Building Performance (BBP) is offering energy-saving clean technology without upfront costs. Founded in 2012 by Stanford graduates Ong En-Ping and Poyan Rajamand, BBP charges only for the energy savings it helps clients achieve. The company is dispelling the myth that environmental sustainability is expensive, aiming to promote energy efficiency and reduce carbon footprint without financial burden.

site_title: PSA to test 22 battery-powered automated-guided vehicles
summary: PSA Singapore has begun live operational trials of 22 battery-powered automated-guided vehicles (AGVs) at the port of Singapore, aiming to meet growing consolidation and mega-alliances. The 22 AGVs, sourced from Cargotec, Gaussin, and Toyota, will join 8 hybrid-powered AGVs already operating at Pasir Panjang Terminal. The technology is part of PSA's efforts to boost productivity and automate operations ahead of projected demand, with investments in automation and information technology expected to continue.

images.alt_text: PSA Singapore is bringing on board the first 22 automated guided vehicles (AGVs) that will run on batteries, during live operational trials of the technology at the port of Singapore.

site_title: Focus of EgyptAir probe falls on flight recorders
summary: Egyptian investigators are preparing to test the memory units from the EgyptAir plane that crashed in the Mediterranean Sea, killing all 66 people on board. The cockpit voice and flight data recorders were recovered with damage, but the memory units will be dried and then downloaded to help determine the cause of the accident. The recovery of the devices will aid the probe, which had been hindered by the depth of the water and will involve representatives from France and the US National Transportation Safety Board. The investigation is a step closer to finding the cause of the May 19 crash.

site_title: New guidelines on leave benefits, notice for contract staff
summary: The Ministry of Manpower, NTUC, and SNEF have released new guidelines to provide clarity for employers on leave benefits for term contract employees in Singapore. Under the guidelines, employers may pro-rate annual leave, sick leave, and childcare leave benefits based on the length of the term contract. Employers are also encouraged to treat contracts renewed within a month as continuous and give sufficient notice before contract expiry. The guidelines aim to ensure term contract employees receive the same leave benefits as permanent employees.

site_title: MAS closely watching UK developments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is closely monitoring the UK's Brexit referendum, set for this week, due to its potential impact on global markets. Singapore's banking system remains sound, but MAS urges vigilance in case of new risks. Banks in Singapore, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, are taking precautions but do not expect a material impact on their balance sheets if Brexit occurs. The referendum's outcome is uncertain, with one economist joking that the UK's exit is less likely than Donald Trump becoming US President.

site_title: Cornish pasties: the tastiest victims of a Brexit?
summary: The Cornish pasty, a traditional British dish with EU protected status, may face threats if Britain leaves the EU. The pasty, filled with beef, potato, and other ingredients, has been given protected geographical indication (PGI) status, which could be lost if the UK leaves the EU. Manufacturers fear that if the PGI status is lost, similar products made outside Cornwall could be labeled as Cornish pasties, compromising quality. The Cornish pasty industry is worth £65 million annually and employs 2,000 people, with some manufacturers and the Cornish Pasty Association supporting EU membership to maintain the status.

site_title: Sterling rallies as Brexit worries ebb
summary: Sterling surged nearly 2% against a trade-weighted basket of currencies after opinion polls shifted in favor of the UK staying in the EU, boosting risk sentiment. This led to a 1.9% rise in the trade-weighted sterling and a 2.5% jump against the yen. Investors reacted to polls showing a shift towards 'Remain' and cited the killing of pro-EU lawmaker Jo Cox as a factor. The euro fell 1.5% to 77.40 pence, while European shares and US stock futures rose.

images.alt_text: Sterling jumped nearly 2 per cent against a trade-weighted basket of currencies on Monday after opinion polls swung in favour of the campaign for Britain to stay in the European Union, boosting risk sentiment and sending the safe-haven yen tumbling.

site_title: In India's isolated north-east, time for a change
summary: India's north-east region, home to 1.2 billion people, has been without a separate time zone since the country's independence from Britain. The policy, set in 1947, aligns the region with Indian Standard Time (IST), which is 30 minutes behind Dhaka, causing significant heat and productivity issues. Campaigners argue that this has hindered development, adding billions to lighting costs, and exacerbated feelings of alienation among tribal-dominated residents, who are battling separatist insurgencies. A new state government in Assam has proposed revisiting the issue, offering a glimmer of hope for change.

site_title: Embrace the new corporate diplomacy to compete more effectively
summary: US President Barack Obama plans to revive the American brand at a global summit meeting, marking a shift to new corporate diplomacy, a 21st-century strategy of international business. This approach differs from the old-style corporate diplomacy of the 18th century, which relied on military and political power. The new strategy involves transnational firms conducting business in a more gentlemanly manner, with a focus on cooperation and mutual benefit. The summit aims to promote global cooperation and competition, as the US seeks to re-establish its position in the global market.

site_title: Third Reit this year looking to list on SGX
summary: A third real estate investment trust (Reit), EC World Reit, backed by Shanghai-based Forchn Holdings Group, is considering a listing on the Singapore bourse to raise up to S$450 million. The trust owns logistics properties in eastern China, with a gross leasable area of 577,072 square meters and an occupancy rate of 92.3% at end-2015. If successful, it would be the third mainboard IPO in 2016, following Manulife US Reit and Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust.

site_title: China's outbound M&As year to date surpass 2015 record
summary: China has surpassed its 2015 record for outbound mergers and acquisitions (M&As) in the first half of 2016, with a total of $111.6 billion in deals. This includes a $43 billion bid for Swiss agrichemicals maker Syngenta. Despite potential slowdowns due to increased scrutiny at home and abroad, China's investment bank China International Capital Corp expects outbound deals to reach $150 billion this year. The surge in M&A activity is seen as a way for China to temper its foreign reserve outflow, which dropped over half a trillion dollars last year.

site_title: More workshops to be run to help SMEs go global
summary: IE Singapore plans to organize more than 15 workshops for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to help them expand globally. The workshops, which have been running since 2009, provide SMEs with on-the-ground knowledge of overseas markets and connect them with potential business partners. Since 2013, over 450 individuals from 280 companies have attended the workshops, with some companies reporting successful expansion into new markets, such as Xpressflower.com in the Philippines and Tai Sei Hei in Vietnam.

images.alt_text: More workshops will be organised this year to equip small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with information on overseas markets and to connect them with potential business partners, said International Enterprise (IE) Singapore on Monday.

site_title: More clean energy funds needed for systems that channel power to world's poorest
summary: A small fraction of climate change funding is allocated to off-grid systems that could provide power to the world's poorest, according to the International Institute for Environment and Development. This is a challenge for the main international organisation promoting clean energy access, which aims to achieve its goal earlier than the 2030 deadline. The current allocation is insufficient to address the issue, highlighting the need for more funding to support small-scale solar, biogas, and other off-grid systems.

site_title: Japan biotech venture PeptiDream a US$3b business
summary: Japanese biotech venture PeptiDream has become a US$3.2 billion company after developing an artificial ribozyme, or "flexizyme," that enables the creation of stable peptides for drug discovery. The technology, developed by co-founders Hiroaki Suga and Kiichi Kubota, has attracted partnerships with major pharmaceutical firms, including Bristol-Myers Squibb, Eli Lilly, and Novartis. The company's platform can discover drugs for various diseases, including cancer and neurological disorders, and has shown strong interest from big pharma, with 16 established names signing agreements to work with PeptiDream.

images.alt_text: Mr Kubota (right) and Prof Suga, whose lab developed an artificial ribozyme, which he named flexizyme for its "promiscuous" ability to help amino acids couple to form peptides.

site_title: Trump in the dumps
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is no longer seen as a benign celebrity, but rather a figure associated with evil and menace, similar to Hitler and Mussolini. This drastic change in perception is attributed to his aggressive and nationalist foreign policy. Trump's US foreign policy is opening a new chapter, marking a significant shift from his previous approach. The article does not provide further details on the specifics of this shift, but suggests that Trump's actions are having a profound impact on global perceptions of the US.

site_title: Eden Hall GCB plots up for sale again
summary: The British government has relaunched the sale of two freehold Good Class Bungalow (GCB) plots from the garden of Eden Hall, the official residence of the British High Commissioner to Singapore, at a 20% discount from the original prices. The plots were initially put up for sale in January but failed to meet the guide price. The relaunch comes after a new tender period, with the guide prices being slashed to attract more buyers.

site_title: DBS eyes growth from financial institutions business
summary: DBS expects its financial institutions group to double in revenue to S$1 billion over the next three to five years, driven by growth in managed assets in Asia. The bank aims to tap into the region's big growth in assets under management, which is expected to reach US$16 trillion by 2020. DBS is also in advanced stages to apply for a licence in Japan to distribute investment products onshore, expanding its presence in markets outside of Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: To be or not to be
summary: The article discusses various global news stories. Vietnam reacts to US President Trump's announcement of tariffs on Asian imports, with the Asian garment industry anticipating higher costs. In Malaysia, an agency is set to seize RM3 billion in assets from businessman Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026. In Thailand, former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra remains optimistic about his daughter's prospects in an ethics case, expecting a court clearance as PM.

site_title: Toyota to build AI-based cars in five years
summary: Toyota plans to develop AI-based driver assistance systems over the next five years, aiming to improve vehicle safety by enabling vehicles to anticipate and avoid potential accident situations. The company will invest $1 billion in its Toyota Research Institute, focusing on artificial intelligence. This effort aims to enable vehicles to drive automatically on highways by the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. Toyota's CEO, Gill Pratt, also explored the possibility of producing robots to help the elderly and is exploring the potential for acquiring robotics divisions.

site_title: London house prices fall as Brexit jitters, taxes cool demand
summary: London house prices declined 0.2% in June, amid Brexit jitters and a new property-tax regime. The average asking price rose 0.8% to £310,471. This is the first time London prices have fallen ahead of a major UK event, such as a referendum. The decline may be a sign of uncertainty in the market, with Brexit potentially affecting demand.

site_title: Irish central bank sees mortgage limits as permanent
summary: Ireland's central bank expects to make permanent the loan-to-value and loan-to-income mortgage limits introduced last year, despite criticism from politicians. The limits, requiring a 20% deposit, aim to prevent a repeat of the 2008 property crash. The bank's deputy governor, Sharon Donnery, stated that the caps will be a permanent feature, with possible calibration, and may be tightened further if the property market overheats. The central bank plans to review the rules in November.

site_title: 90% of UK bank cuts are in lower-income areas: study
summary: UK banks have disproportionately closed branches in lower-income areas, taking away essential services from communities that need them most. Between 2015 and 2016, 90% of branch closures by HSBC, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays, and Lloyds were in areas with median household incomes below £27,600. The banks claim to target areas with fewest customers, but campaigners argue they specifically target poorer areas. This trend is similar in the US, where 1,600 branches closed in 2015, leading to a decline in lending in low-income areas.

site_title: S Korea trains keyboard soldiers in decades-old war with North
summary: South Korea is training a new generation of "keyboard soldiers" to combat North Korea's alleged cyber army, with a free education in exchange for a seven-year military commitment. The Cyber Defense curriculum at Seoul's Korea University was founded in 2011, as the two countries remain in a technical state of war since the 1950-53 Korean War. South Korea estimates that the North's cyber army has doubled in size to 6,000 troops, prompting efforts to strengthen cyber security cooperation with the US and ramp up its own capabilities.

site_title: Putin seen weighing Rosneft stake sale to China, India
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is considering selling 19.5% of state-owned oil company Rosneft to China and India, seeking to raise at least $15 billion to meet spending commitments. The sale would balance a near 20% stake held by BP and strengthen Putin's geopolitical hand amid strained relations with the US and Europe. Both China and India have expressed interest in the deal, with Indian Oil Minister Dharmendra Pradhan suggesting a joint bid could be possible. The sale is expected to raise funds and cement the companies' footholds in the world's largest energy exporter.

site_title: Brexit: vulnerable pound may hurt UK bond's haven status
summary: The UK government-bond market's reputation as a haven in times of global crisis is threatened by the country's currency vulnerability to a potential Brexit. A vote to exit the EU could lead to a decline in the pound, weakening the UK's finances and potentially hurting foreign investors' returns. The pound has surged in recent polls, but a "Leave" victory could see sterling drop to a 30-year low. Analysts predict a decline in gilt yields, with some expecting the UK's debt to appreciate despite Brexit uncertainty. The UK's economic growth also faces a blow with its economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Poland's star shining bright, but Ukraine's is fading fast
summary: Poland's national football team is making a strong impression at the Euro 2016 tournament, while Ukraine's team is struggling. Poland, led by coach Adam Nawalka, is in second place in Group C with four points, having held Germany to a goalless draw. Ukraine, meanwhile, became the first team to be eliminated from the tournament, losing their first two games to Germany and Northern Ireland. Poland will face Ukraine in their final group match, where a draw will secure their qualification for the knockout stage.

site_title: In Japan, tank-bred lobster larvae may boost fishery stocks
summary: Researchers in Japan's Mie Prefecture Fisheries Research Institute successfully bred tank-bred lobster larvae, known as phyllosomas, to survive on reefs. The larvae, initially fed mussels and artemia, showed a 62.5% survival rate after being released into the ocean. The breakthrough, achieved after 37 years of research, aims to boost fishery stocks of the prized Ise ebi spiny lobster, a luxury food from the seas surrounding Japan.

site_title: Menswear shows falling out of favour
summary: Menswear shows in Europe are experiencing a decline, with 10 top designers, including Calvin Klein and Ermenegildo Zegna, opting out of separate men's fashion weeks this year. Combined events with women's shows are becoming more common, as luxury brands prioritize womenswear due to its higher sales and global publicity. Annual designer menswear sales are expected to reach $40 billion in 2020, while womenswear sales are projected to rise to $75 billion. Industry insiders attribute the shift to increased costs and the influence of social media on demand.

images.alt_text: Unlike women's shows, men's fashion shows don't turn as many heads with their low-key guest lists.

site_title: CityNeon's Victory Hill seen as silver lining for Star (Amended)
summary: CityNeon Holdings' "Avengers" and "Transformers" franchises are expected to boost Star Media Group's earnings this year, despite weaker adex spend in a challenging economy. CityNeon's Victory Hill Exhibitions (VHE) is projected to generate strong earnings, with forecast profits of S$6.7 million and S$16.3 million for FY16 and FY17, respectively. This could raise Star's FY16-18 earnings per share by 9-18%. Despite a hold call on Star, analysts view the company as a "dividend yield play" and prefer it over other Malaysian media groups due to its robust net cash position.

site_title: S&P affirms Singapore banks' credit ratings
summary: S&P Global Ratings has affirmed the credit ratings of Singapore's three major banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, maintaining their "AA-" and "A-1+" long-term and short-term ratings, respectively. The agencies expect the banks' asset quality to remain manageable, with gradual deterioration in the event of a downturn. DBS and OCBC are expected to experience low single-digit loan growth, while UOB's credit costs will rise but be mitigated by its rising margin buffer. The ratings are based on the banks' prudent credit risk management and their cautious expansion strategies.

site_title: World Bank sees robust Indian growth ahead
summary: The World Bank predicts robust growth for India's economy, expecting a 7.6% growth rate in 2016-2017, followed by modest acceleration to 7.7% and 7.8% in the next two years. The country's growth is driven by urban households, manufacturing, and services sectors, with agriculture and rural demand still facing challenges. To sustain growth, the economy must address stalled engines, including agricultural growth and private investment, while ensuring demand from urban households and public investments continues. The World Bank also notes that the banking sector poses a significant risk to growth.

site_title: Breathless in Paris as clean-air battle mounts
summary: Paris, France, will implement stricter air-quality controls starting July 1, banning cars registered before 1997 and motorcycles registered before 1999 from city streets on weekdays. The city aims to reduce pollution by 2020, with a focus on zero-emission and petrol-fuelled cars. However, car owners have protested the measures, and the EU is pushing France to comply with pollution limits or face sanctions. Despite concerns, the city is taking steps to promote green transportation, including doubling bicycle lanes and providing financial aid for electric vehicles.

site_title: UK business opinion moves towards exit
summary: UK business opinion is shifting towards leaving the European Union, with a 7-point increase in support among small and medium-sized businesses in a recent survey. 37% of business owners now favor leaving, with those trading only in the UK or exporting only outside Europe being the most likely to support Brexit. Proponents argue that leaving the EU will allow Britain to design its own regulations, reduce red tape, and improve immigration control, ultimately benefiting businesses and the economy.

site_title: Brexit could be catalyst for reinventing EU
summary: The UK's exit from the EU (Brexit) could potentially revitalize the European Union by prompting a smaller EU to integrate, establish common institutions, and hold direct elections. This unexpected outcome may be influenced by the unconventional US presidential candidate, Donald Trump, who challenges traditional wisdom. The state of Europe is considered grim, and Brexit may serve as a catalyst to jumpstart the EU out of its near-catatonic state.

site_title: Paid cross-border car-pooling services against regulations: LTA
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore has rejected Grab's plan to launch a paid carpooling service between Singapore and Johor Bahru due to non-compliance with local regulations. The original service model failed to meet requirements, and LTA has informed Grab of this. The rejection comes as Grab seeks to expand its services beyond ride-hailing to other areas, including carpooling.

site_title: Visa launches Olympics campaign, undeterred by woes in Brazil
summary: Visa launches its global Olympics campaign despite concerns in host country Brazil, where the Zika virus and political upheaval have raised travel concerns. The company has not seen significant cancellations in trips to Rio de Janeiro and expects 400,000-500,000 visitors to attend the Rio Games. Visa is sponsoring 46 Olympic athletes and promoting its products through a new ad campaign featuring top athletes using chip cards and other Visa products.

site_title: Temasek sells 555m shares in China Construction Bank
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state-owned investment firm, sold 555 million shares of China Construction Bank Corp, reducing its stake from 5.03% to 4.81%. The sale valued the block at HK$2.78 billion (S$481 million) and is part of Temasek's portfolio rebalancing. The firm remains confident in China's banking sector and continues to invest in sectors such as technology and life sciences.

site_title: ONGC to spend on drill ships, rigs as costs drop
summary: ONGC, India's largest oil explorer, plans to spend $5 billion on its largest-ever development program in the Krishna-Godavari Basin. The program aims to boost production and reduce import dependence by 10% in the next six years. With oil prices below $50, the company is taking advantage of lower costs for rigs and services, contracting five deepwater drill ships and dozens of jack-up rigs. This investment is expected to pay off once oil prices revive, as production has declined in existing fields and new assets are needed to meet India's growing energy demands.

site_title: Four Seasons guns for growth in Asia-Pacific
summary: Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts plans to expand its presence in the Asia-Pacific region, with 15 new hotels under development and 5 management contracts signed. The luxury hotel chain is capitalizing on growing outbound travel from China and India, with tourism figures projected to reach 20 million in Jakarta by 2020. Four Seasons sees promising growth markets in China, Australia, Japan, Indonesia, and India, with a focus on first-tier cities and resort hotels. Despite challenges in Singapore's hospitality market, the group remains optimistic about the region's growth potential.

site_title: China central bank says G20 working group calls for expanded use of SDRs
summary: China's central bank reported that a G20 working group, co-chaired by France and South Korea, proposed expanding the use of IMF Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) and improving capital flow monitoring. The proposal also aimed to increase global financial safety net cooperation. This move is seen as a step towards strengthening the global financial system.

site_title: Major shareholder opposes Vanke's 45.6b yuan share-sale plan
summary: China Resources, Vanke's second-largest shareholder, has opposed the company's 45.6 billion yuan share-sale plan to buy assets from Shenzhen Metro, citing the need for a two-thirds majority vote. The proposal, which would make Shenzhen Metro the largest shareholder, has been met with skepticism by China Resources, which argues that the deal would dilute earnings and not provide sufficient benefits. The move adds uncertainty to Vanke's efforts to fend off a potential takeover by Baoneng Group, which has become the company's largest shareholder.

images.alt_text: Construction workers at the site of the China Vanke Co apartments called Fun City in the Fangshan district on the outskirts of Beijing. Vanke defended its proposal, saying it expected the deal to bring "continuous quality project resources" in key Chinese cities at "reasonable" prices.

site_title: IMF predicts that Abenomics will miss targets set
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic policies, known as Abenomics, are unlikely to meet their targets for growth, inflation, and fiscal consolidation by 2020. The IMF urges Tokyo to adopt more realistic and credible goals, and to adopt an "incomes policy" to boost personal consumption. The report also suggests that Japan should raise the national consumption tax by small increments and increase fiscal support for the economy. The IMF believes that sustained higher growth and inflation remain elusive, and that a more substantial policy upgrade is needed.

site_title: Ascott bags 7 properties and expects to grow faster than last year
summary: Ascott, a serviced-residence business unit of CapitaLand, has secured 7 new properties with 1,714 units across 7 cities in Asia. The new properties include 550-unit Citadines Blue Cove Danang in Vietnam, 275-unit Somerset Putrajaya in Malaysia, and 200-unit Somerset West Hongqiao Shanghai in China. Ascott expects to outpace its growth in 2015, with 28,000 operating units and 19,000 units under development. The company's growth is driven by its fastest-growing market, South-east Asia, and second-largest globally after China.

site_title: Dishwashing deal boosts GS Hldgs stock
summary: GS Holdings' shares jumped 38% to S$0.40, after winning a S$1.2 million, two-year contract from Suntec Singapore Convention & Exhibition Centre. The contract includes on-site dishwashing services, night kitchen cleaning, and wet waste management. PhillipCapital praised GS Holdings' differentiating factors, including ISO 22000 and Halal certifications, and its ability to offer a fully integrated solution. The company recently sold 8 million new shares at 28.5 cents each, and its shares closed at S$0.40 on Monday.

site_title: Australia's Big 4 banks face toughest dominance test
summary: Australia's Big 4 banks face the toughest dominance test since the 2008 global financial crisis, with politicians calling for a public inquiry into their operations amid poor conduct charges and rate-rigging allegations. A Royal Commission could compel executives to testify and trigger major reforms, potentially weakening the banks' grip on 80% of the country's lending. Polls predict a tight federal election in July, with the ruling coalition opposing a public inquiry but the main opposition Labor Party and key independents backing a comprehensive probe.

site_title: Boeing, Russian airfreight firm close to US$4b deal to revive B747
summary: Boeing is close to a $4 billion deal with Russia's AirBridgeCargo Airlines to revive the production of the iconic 747 jumbo jet. The US planemaker is in talks to convert a year-old commitment into 10 firm orders for 747-8 freighters, aiming to extend the life of the four-engine aircraft amid waning demand.

site_title: Toyota researcher sees cheap robots made possible by mass production
summary: A Toyota researcher, Gill Pratt, suggests that the company's mass production principles can be applied to create affordable helper robots for ageing societies. Pratt believes that the production system that made cars cheaper and more reliable can also be applied to robots. Toyota is working on various robotic applications, including a motorized wheelchair and a wearable that guides the blind. The company is also exploring the potential for robots in the home, particularly in Japan, where over a quarter of the population is over 65. Pratt is optimistic about the prospects for robots, citing the need for a "robot revolution" in Japan to boost the nation's robotics industry sales.

site_title: China's Xi weaves Poland into 'new silk road' plan
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping signed a strategic partnership deal with Polish President Andrzej Duda on June 20, 2016, aiming to boost investment and trade between the two countries. Poland seeks to reduce the chronic trade imbalance with China, while China aims to utilize Poland's position as a founding member of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank. The deal includes agreements on boosting Polish food products, electronics, and renewable energy technology on the Chinese market. The partnership is part of China's "Belt and Road" policy, which aims to establish land and sea links for European trade.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers' analysis of Singapore's telecommunications and hospitality sectors reveals varying opinions on companies. Circles.Life's new customer service model is seen as a differentiator, but analysts maintain "sell" ratings for Liberty Wireless and M1 due to competitive spectrum auction pressures. In contrast, Singtel is recommended as a "buy" with a target price of S$4.38, driven by its 13% share of group revenue. CDL Hospitality Trusts is also upgraded to "buy" with a target price of S$1.51, despite challenges in its Maldives operations.

site_title: Japan's rickshaw runners take on tour guide role
summary: Rickshaw runners in Osaka are taking on the role of tour guides, offering foreign language services to enhance their services. Some have even studied languages to pursue careers in the entertainment industry, with pop idols aspiring to join their ranks. The rickshaw runners' efforts aim to showcase Japan's unique culture to tourists, with events like Universal Cool Japan 2016 featuring Japanese entertainment. This shift highlights the evolving nature of traditional occupations in modern Japan.

images.alt_text: Rickshaws - called jinrikisha in Japanese - became popular in Kyoto and Asakusa in the 1990s.

site_title: Rajan urges India to 'stay the course' on inflation
summary: India's outgoing central bank governor Raghuram Rajan urged his successor to "stay the course" on lowering inflation, as his term ends in September. Rajan, credited with stabilizing India's economy since 2013, will return to academia. His comments come amid speculation over his future, but he maintained a focus on inflation control.

site_title: Australian 'bitcoin founder' quietly bidding for patent empire
summary: Australian 'bitcoin founder' Craig Wright is quietly building a large patent portfolio around bitcoin and related technology, filing over 50 patent applications in Britain since February through his company EITC Holdings Ltd. Wright's associates confirm the company is still working on filings, despite initial reports that progress had slowed. Britain's Intellectual Property Office has published additional patent applications, indicating the effort continues. Wright's patent bid aims to secure intellectual property rights for his claims to be bitcoin's inventor.

site_title: LVMH is upbeat about thriving in Asia's markets amid volatility
summary: LVMH, the luxury goods conglomerate, is optimistic about its performance in Asia despite global economic volatility. The company secured 37% of its total revenue from Asia in the first quarter of 2016, with Japan accounting for 8% of its total revenue. Despite challenges such as economic uncertainty, cultural complexities, and counterfeit issues, LVMH believes Asia's luxury market continues to offer growth opportunities. The company's partnership with Singapore Management University's Luxury Research Conference aims to drive innovation and understanding of luxury retail in the region.

site_title: CEO Chesky vows to stamp out racism from Airbnb
summary: Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky has vowed to root out racism from his company, following claims of discrimination against guests with African-American-sounding names. However, the company's class-action litigation policy, which requires users to waive their right to sue, makes it difficult for customers to push for substantive changes. Airbnb has removed two hosts who violated its anti-discrimination policy and hired an outside adviser to examine the issue. The company aims to announce preliminary actions in the next 10 days and propose remedies in a full report in September, with a potential class-action suit filed against the company.

images.alt_text: Winners of an Airbnb contest spending a night at the Aquarium of Paris. The company aims to have announcements in the next 10 days about preliminary actions it is taking on discrimination.

site_title: India announces sweeping relaxation of FDI rules
summary: India has announced a sweeping relaxation of foreign direct investment (FDI) rules in civil aviation, defence, and other sectors, aiming to spur investment and create jobs. The government has eased regulations, allowing foreign companies to wholly own local airlines, and raised the cap on investment in defence to 100% subject to government approval. The changes also make it easier for overseas companies to manufacture in India and operate single-brand foreign retailers. The move is expected to boost investment and help India become the world's most open economy for FDI, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi stating that it will make India "the most open economy in the world for FDI".

site_title: Going digital with a clear destination
summary: Companies are embracing digital technologies, but the extent of their engagement varies widely among organizations. A study of 1,160 managers, executives, and board members found that digital initiatives are often driven by specific business needs rather than a unified digital strategy. Successful digital initiatives rely on a combination of technology, effective leadership, and a supportive culture, rather than just the right technology. The study's findings suggest that there is no one-size-fits-all approach to digital transformation, and companies must explore and understand the opportunities and challenges presented by digital technologies to achieve a competitive advantage in the digital world.

site_title: China's Xi weaves Poland into 'new silk road' plan
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping signed a strategic partnership deal with Poland, aiming to strengthen economic ties and integrate Poland into China's 'Belt and Road' policy. Poland is China's largest trade partner in eastern Europe, with bilateral trade reaching $17.1 billion in 2015. The partnership aims to boost investment and trade, further solidifying China's economic influence in the region.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.4% up on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.4% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index increasing 37.45 points to 2,800.87. The gain was attributed to poll results indicating a shift in British voters' stance towards remaining in the EU ahead of the Brexit referendum. The market saw a boost from actively traded counters like Ezra Holdings and Noble Group.

site_title: Germany expects growth to slow after strong Q1
summary: Germany's economy is expected to slow down after a strong Q1, with growth expected to slow to 1.7% for the year, in line with last year's figure. The country's robust start to the year was driven by soaring private consumption, higher construction investment, and state spending, but foreign trade is cooling. The Bundesbank expects a sharp slowdown in Q2 before a rebound later in the year, while the Finance Ministry sees a continuation of the economic upswing, albeit at a less dynamic pace.

site_title: Chinese chip technology now powering world's fastest supercomputer
summary: China's Sunway TaihuLight supercomputer, located in Wuxi, Jiangsu province, has become the world's fastest, powered by Chinese-designed semiconductors. The machine is more than twice as powerful as the previous winner, surpassing US technology dominance. This breakthrough is a significant step for China's domestic chip industry, aiming to reduce dependence on imports. The Sunway TaihuLight's victory is a challenge to Intel's dominance in computer servers, with 96% market share, and may also impact US defense technology and security infrastructure.

site_title: Sustainability reporting rules seen offering flexibility
summary: Singapore Exchange's sustainability reporting rules offer flexibility to listed firms, giving them time to implement the regulations. However, investors and stakeholders must be discerning in evaluating reports, as some important ESG factors may be glossed over due to companies' ability to choose which factors to report on. The process of engaging stakeholders to determine material factors could ultimately benefit all parties. The rules aim to promote transparency and sustainability reporting, but require careful evaluation to ensure compliance.

images.alt_text: SGX's Mr Loh said the reporting of non-financial information will enhance the visibility of SGX-listed companies among investors.

site_title: India wants private sector to explore for diamonds, gold
summary: India is seeking the participation of private companies like Rio Tinto and Anglo American's De Beers to explore for diamonds and gold. The government plans to auction rights to 70 exploration zones this year, aiming to revive the sector and become a major mineral producer. India is the world's second-largest consumer of gold but has not produced diamonds in years. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ambition is to increase private sector involvement in exploration and production, with the goal of reducing reliance on China for rare earth elements.

site_title: Millennials, Generation Xers prone to divorce
summary: A University of Maryland sociology professor, Philip Cohen, estimates that 52.7% of marriages will end in divorce based on recent survey data. This contradicts recent trends that suggest Americans are divorcing less often, with the average marriage lasting longer. The increase in divorce rates among older adults, particularly baby boomers, is attributed to their selective nature and independence, which has led to a rise in midlife divorces. This trend may also apply to millennials and Generation Xers, who are also prone to divorce, with first marriages lasting a median of 12 years.

site_title: Formula One: Mercedes want a re-think on radio ban
summary: Mercedes team chief Toto Wolff is calling for a re-think on the radio communications ban that hindered Lewis Hamilton's podium finish in the European Grand Prix. Hamilton struggled with incorrect engine settings for 12 laps, while teammate Nico Rosberg won the race with a relatively swift fix. Wolff believes the ban restricts driver communication, leading to a lack of racing and complex technology. He suggests adjusting regulations to allow for more driver communication in case of problems.

site_title: Relief rally as Brexit jitters subside
summary: Singapore's stock market surged 1.4% on Monday, driven by polls showing the 'Remain' camp gaining momentum in the Brexit referendum. The Straits Times Index rose 37.45 points to 2,800.87, with blue-chip stocks such as OCBC, DBS, and Singtel leading the gain. Real estate developer City Developments fell 1.6%, while CDL Hospitality Trusts rose 1 cent to S$1.42. Analysts at UOB Kay Hian maintained their 'Buy' call on Singtel, citing its strong mobile business and higher beta.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 10 points higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.05 points to 1,634.230 on Monday, with 1.24 billion lots valued at RM1.40 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 370 to 361.

site_title: GLP secures new leases totalling 98,000 sq m in China
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) secured new leases totaling 98,000 sq m in China with five Chinese companies. The leases are mainly for expansion demand from the organised retail sector, including e-commerce and chain stores. Three of the leases are new customer relationships for GLP, including Cainiao, a data and technology-based logistics platform affiliated with Alibaba Group, and Best Logistics, GLP's largest customer by leased area in China.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: MYP Ltd has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire Straits Trading Building for S$560 million, with completion dependent on shareholder approval by December 15. KOP Ltd has struck off its dormant subsidiary Scorpio East Leisure Pte Ltd from the Register of Companies, while Transcorp Holdings has requested an extension to announce its financial statements for the first half of the year.

site_title: Cambodian PM denies role in Asean U-turn on South China Sea
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen denied involvement in Asean's U-turn on a joint statement condemning China's land reclamation in the South China Sea. The statement was retracted after a meeting of foreign ministers from China and Asean in Kunming, with some Asean nations accused of bowing to Chinese pressure. Hun Sen accused unnamed countries of using Cambodia to counter China and criticized the Permanent Court of Arbitration for being politically biased. The court is expected to rule against China in the coming weeks in a dispute with the Philippines.

site_title: Oil rally fizzles out as Canadian wildfire threat fades
summary: Canadian oil output continues to ramp up after Alberta's wildfires, reducing bets on rising oil prices. Despite a 10-month high on June 9, oil prices tumbled as disruptions in Nigeria and Libya persist. West Texas Intermediate dropped 3.7% to $48.49 a barrel, with prices expected to remain fragile due to a global surplus. Canadian output is expected to return to normal by mid-July, and investors fled risky assets amid concerns over the UK's EU referendum.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound from weekly slide as Brexit concern eases
summary: US stocks rebounded from a weekly slide, with the S&P 500 jumping 1.2% to 2,095.60, its largest gain in four weeks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rallied 1.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index increased 1.3% after polls showed the UK's 'Remain' campaign gaining ground before the Brexit referendum. Odds at betting shops also indicated dwindling support for the 'Leave' camp following the murder of UK lawmaker Jo Cox. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: LG ponders home appliance deals to speed up global expansion
summary: LG Electronics Inc is considering home appliance acquisitions to fuel its global expansion and counter a slowing smartphone market. The company plans to focus on business-to-business targets, such as component makers, with expected 10% sales growth this year. LG aims to innovate in premium segments and expand production in Vietnam and potentially North America, Brazil, and South Africa. The company's home appliance earnings surged 78% in the last quarter, driven by increased competition from Chinese rivals like Midea Group Co and Haier Electronics Group Co.

site_title: FedEx to buy 6 Boeing 767 freighters valued at US$1.2b
summary: FedEx is purchasing six Boeing 767 freighters valued at $1.2 billion, with deliveries scheduled for 2019 and 2020. The wide-body aircraft, originally developed in the 1980s, has seen a resurgence as a freighter due to its fuel efficiency and cost-effectiveness. The purchase is part of FedEx's efforts to modernize its fleet and reduce operating costs. The 767 has also been chosen by the US Air Force for a tanker project and Amazon for its air cargo service.

site_title: New sustainability reporting rules for Singapore-listed companies
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced new sustainability reporting rules for Singapore-listed companies. Starting this year, listed firms must publish a sustainability report at least once a year, detailing material environmental, social, and governance factors, policies, practices, targets, and reporting framework. The report must also include a statement from the board describing the company's sustainability actions. Companies will determine their material ESG factors and choose a reporting framework, with the SGX leaving the specifics to them.

site_title: Surging developer mortgages draw Hong Kong central bank scrutiny
summary: Hong Kong's central bank has urged banks to strengthen risk management as developers offer high mortgage lending to attract home buyers. Developers like Sun Hung Kai Properties are providing mortgages worth up to 120% of a home's value, despite government cooling measures restricting traditional bank mortgages to 60% of property value. The HKMA is studying whether measures are needed to address the increased credit risks. This move comes as the Hong Kong property market has seen a correction of over 13% since prices peaked in September.

site_title: Apple's loss in Chinese patent fight seen emboldening rivals
summary: Apple has lost a Chinese patent dispute, with the Beijing Intellectual Property Office ruling that some iPhone devices violate the design patents of Chinese smartphone vendor Shenzhen Baili. The ruling could lead to a rise in lawsuits against Apple, potentially threatening its sales in China. This loss is the latest headache for Apple in China, where it faces aggressive rivals and a slowing economy. The company has appealed the ruling and is considering settlement fees, but the defeat is seen as a sign that Chinese officials are scrutinizing Apple more closely.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rise as Brexit fears subside
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose on Monday as a poll showed Britons leaning towards staying in the European Union, reducing Brexit fears. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.82% to 5256.80, while New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index gained 0.33% to 6869.54. The gains helped recover from last week's 3% drop sparked by Brexit concerns.

site_title: China outbound M&A beats 2015 record with 6 months to spare
summary: China's outbound M&A activity has surpassed the 2015 record, with $111.6 billion worth of deals announced in the first half of 2016. This includes a $43 billion bid for Syngenta, making up almost 40% of this year's total. However, bankers predict a slowdown in the second half due to heightened scrutiny at home and abroad, as well as uncertainty surrounding global events. Despite this, China's appetite for overseas acquisitions is expected to continue, with a total of $150 billion predicted for the year, according to China International Capital Corp.

site_title: Rowsley to buy engineering firm Squire Mech for up to S$19.5m
summary: Rowsley, a Mainboard-listed real estate company, will acquire Squire Mech Private Limited, a mechanical and electrical engineering firm, for up to S$19.5 million. Rowsley already owns 35% of Squire Mech shares, and the proposed acquisition will give it full control of the company's engineering consultancy services. The deal aims to strengthen Rowsley's multi-disciplinary capabilities and complement its existing architecture, master planning, and civil engineering services.

site_title: Japan approves first reactor life extension since Fukushima disaster
summary: Japan's nuclear regulator approved the life extension of two reactors at the Takahama plant, allowing them to operate until 60 years old. This marks the first reactor life extension since the Fukushima disaster in 2011. The reactors were shut down in 2011 and require safety upgrades costing around $2.57 billion. Kansai Electric Power Co must complete the upgrades before the reactors can be restarted. The move is seen as a significant step towards Japan's nuclear industry resuming operations.

site_title: Stocks surge with pound as Brexit concern fades
summary: Global equities surged, with the S&P 500 Index jumping its most in a month, as the UK's pro-EU campaign gained momentum ahead of the Brexit referendum. The pound strengthened 2% against the dollar, its largest gain since 2008, as emerging-market shares advanced and oil rallied. A poll showed 45% of voters backed staying in the EU, down from 40% the previous day. Riskier assets rebounded from a four-week low, and credit risk fell to its lowest since March, with the yield on 10-year Treasury notes jumping six basis points.

site_title: Human traders strike back at stock market's robot dominance
summary: Human sales traders are regaining ground in the stock market, with sales-trader execution of single stocks rising to 51% in the US and 55% in Europe, according to Greenwich Associates. This growth is driven by big investors seeking the human touch in handling large trades, which can be complex and involve risks such as avoiding detection by algorithmic trading programs. Banks are hiring more high-touch sales traders, and top-tier brokers are offering premium services to big clients, with some firms seeing a 65% of trades by value handled by humans.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks hit 1-week highs, investors rediscover risk appetite
summary: Seoul's won and shares reached one-week highs on Monday, driven by growing speculation that Britain will vote to remain in the European Union, increasing investors' risk appetite. The won rose 1.0% to 1,160.8 to the dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) gained 1.4% to 1,981.12 points. This rebound follows a decline in the previous session.

site_title: Beyond the turmoil, central bankers dread Brexit's shadow
summary: Central bankers worldwide are preparing for the potential economic fallout of the UK's Brexit vote, with the Bank of England already pumping liquidity into banks and the European Central Bank ready to inject cheap funds. A coordinated response from the Group of Seven economies is expected, but experts warn that monetary policy may have limited room to maneuver if the turmoil becomes a long-term downturn, potentially threatening Europe's fragile growth outlook.

site_title: India announces sweeping reforms to FDI rules
summary: India has announced sweeping reforms to its foreign direct investment (FDI) rules, opening up its defence and civil aviation sectors to complete outside ownership and easing restrictions on inbound investments in pharmaceuticals and retail. Apple is expected to benefit from a three-year relaxation on local sourcing norms, while defence contractors can now own local operations outright. The reforms aim to make India the most open economy in the world, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi hailing the changes as a major impetus to employment and job creation.

images.alt_text: India announced on Monday sweeping reforms to rules on foreign direct investment, opening up its defence and civil aviation sectors to complete outside ownership and clearing the way for Apple to open stores in the country.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei posts biggest daily gain in two months as Brexit fears abate
summary: Japan's Nikkei stock index surged 2.3% to a one-week high, its largest daily gain in two months, as Brexit worries receded following weekend polls showing the EU campaign gaining momentum. The Nikkei reached 15,965.30, its highest closing level since June 13, while the broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also rose 2.3%. The yen weakened, contributing to the rally, as investors regained risk appetite.

site_title: Toyota says Brexit may lead to 10% duties on UK-built cars
summary: Toyota warns a UK withdrawal from the EU could lead to 10% duties on cars built in the UK, potentially cutting costs or increasing prices. The automaker exports 90% of UK-built vehicles, with 75% sold in the EU. Toyota has invested $59 billion in the UK and is committed to its factories and employees. A Brexit would pose significant business challenges, and the company's long-term competitiveness would be compromised. Toyota urges continued British membership of the EU for its operations and competitiveness.

site_title: UK's Nassim Road Good Class Bungalow plots up for sale again
summary: The UK government has relaunched two freehold Good Class Bungalow plots on Nassim Road in Singapore for public tender. The plots, part of the Eden Hall land, are priced at S$1,700 psf for the front plot and S$1,630 psf for the back plot. The previous guide prices were S$40.964 million for the front plot and S$31.268 million for the rear plot. The plots are available for sale as individual or combined plots.

site_title: TalkTalk pays CEO £2.8m in year firm hit by cyber attack
summary: TalkTalk's CEO, Dido Harding, received £2.8 million in pay and share bonuses despite the company suffering a cyber attack in October that exposed customer data. Harding will donate her £220,000 annual cash bonus to charity. The majority of the payout was awarded as shares for performance targets between 2012-2015. The company's annual report attributed the payout to Harding's efforts in managing the cyber attack and prioritizing customer concerns.

site_title: World's fastest supercomputer now has Chinese chip technology
summary: The world's fastest supercomputer, Sunway TaihuLight, has been powered by Chinese-designed semiconductors for the first time, breaking US technology dominance. Located in China, the machine is over twice as powerful as the previous winner and marks a significant breakthrough for China's domestic chip industry. This achievement shows China's determination to reduce dependence on imported technology, particularly in defense and security infrastructure. The new machine's processor, SW26010, is a first for China, and its success may challenge US companies like Intel in the computer server market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore-listed companies are expected to adopt new sustainability reporting rules with clearer guidelines on leave benefits and notice periods for contract workers. DBS forecasts doubling of revenue in its financial institutions business over 3-5 years. The Ascott secured 7 new properties, poised to outpace growth in 2015. Singapore shares rose 1.4% on Monday. Meanwhile, international news includes Vietnam's surprise over US tariffs, Malaysia's plan to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, and China's GDP growth set to slow.

site_title: China: Stocks flat on domestic concerns as other Asian markets rise
summary: China's main stock indexes remained flat on Monday due to domestic concerns over yuan depreciation and a regulatory crackdown on speculative trading. Asian markets, however, rose as investors welcomed news of a potential UK decision to remain in the EU. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.1% to 2,888.59 points, while the CSI300 index also rose 0.1% to 3,112.67 points.

site_title: Rio suspends work at Channar iron ore mine after death
summary: Rio Tinto has suspended operations at its Channar iron ore mine in Australia after a worker was killed overnight. The 32-year-old man was working on a drill rig at the time of the incident. The company is working with investigators to determine the cause of the death and has not specified when operations will resume. The Channar mine, 60% owned by Rio Tinto, is a joint venture with China's Sinosteel.

site_title: DBS sees doubling in revenue in financial institutions business over 3-5 years
summary: DBS expects its financial institutions group to double in revenue to S$1 billion over 3-5 years, driven by growth in assets under management in Asia. The bank aims to capitalize on the liberalization of capital markets in the region, now that global banks are exiting. The financial institutions group will target companies offering fund management, insurance, and private banking services, generating transaction fees and proposing fund-raising deals. DBS plans to fill the vacuum left by global banks, leveraging its presence in Asia.

images.alt_text: DBS expects its financial institutions group to double in revenue to S$1 billion over the next three to five years, a senior executive said on Monday.

site_title: IMF calls for overhaul of Abenomics stimulus policies
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Japan's government to overhaul its stimulus policies, calling for a shift towards income policies and labor market reform. The IMF supports more monetary and fiscal stimulus, but warns that the current policies are unlikely to achieve the 2% inflation target by the set timeframe. The IMF recommends a more flexible monetary policy framework and raising the sales tax to at least 15% to balance growth and fiscal sustainability. Without structural reforms, domestic demand may remain sluggish.

site_title: Tesla prepares for South Korea debut in challenge to Hyundai
summary: Tesla is preparing for its South Korean debut, challenging Hyundai Motor Co as the US electric-car maker looks to expand its customer base. Tesla listed positions for sales and engineering in South Korea and registered its corporation, planning to set up an office in Seoul. The company aims to offer its Model 3, a key car for expansion, in the country. Hyundai has already introduced its Ioniq compact and plans to offer a plug-in version by the end of the year, while South Korea's electric auto market is expected to grow. Tesla's move is seen as a challenge to Hyundai's dominance.

site_title: Europe: Banks lead shares higher as Brexit fears wane slightly
summary: European shares rose nearly 3% on Monday, with the banking sector leading the gains as investors became more optimistic about Britain's potential to stay in the EU. This renewed hope spurred investors to take on riskier assets, lifting the Stoxx 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indexes. Despite still being down about 10% for 2016, the Stoxx 600 was poised for its biggest one-day percentage gain since mid-February.

site_title: Death toll from Indonesia floods, landslides rises to 43
summary: Indonesia's death toll from landslides and flooding has risen to 43, according to the country's disaster agency. The disasters, triggered by heavy rainfall, affected the Central Java province, with hundreds of homes damaged or destroyed. 19 villagers are still missing, and 14 have suffered injuries. A La Nina weather system is believed to have contributed to the disasters, which are common in Indonesia due to its tropical location. Evacuation centers have been set up, and the area worst affected is Purworejo district, where 27 people died.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares jump on hopes Britain will vote to stay in EU
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged nearly 2% on June 20, 2016, due to hopes that Britain would vote to remain in the European Union, easing Brexit fears. Three British opinion polls showed the "Remain" camp gaining momentum ahead of the EU membership referendum on June 23.
