The Hang Seng index rose 1.7% to 20,510.20, and the China Enterprises Index gained 1.8% to 8,639.51 points.

site_title: Incoming Philippine minister seeks emergency powers to fix traffic snarl
summary: Incoming Philippine Transportation Minister Rodrigo Duterte seeks emergency powers from Congress to address the country's debilitating traffic crisis in Manila. The proposed two-year powers will allow for quicker release of funds to declog main roads, estimated to generate 2.4 billion pesos (S$70 million) in daily income. This move aims to alleviate the economic impact of the traffic problem on businesses.

site_title: Global migrant tide swells to record 65m
summary: The number of refugees and displaced people worldwide has reached a record 65.3 million by the end of 2015, according to the United Nations. This represents about one percent of the global population and is fueled by conflict, persecution, and anti-migrant sentiment. The majority of displaced people, 40.8 million, remain within their own country, while 21.3 million have fled across borders. The UN is calling for increased international cooperation to address the growing global displacement crisis.

site_title: Asia: Pound extends rally as Brexit fears ease
summary: The pound extends its rally in Asian trade as investors shift their bets following a poll that suggests the "Remain" camp is gaining momentum ahead of the UK's EU vote on June 23. Long-standing fears of a pro-Brexit vote had been weighing on the currency, but the poll's outcome has eased concerns, leading to a pound gain.

site_title: Volkswagen faces shareholder wrath at AGM
summary: Volkswagen faces shareholder wrath at its annual general meeting (AGM) as the company struggles to recover from the "Dieselgate" scandal. Nine months after installing emissions-cheating software in 11 million diesel engines, the costs of the affair remain incalculable. Shareholders, who hold 11% of the voting rights, are expected to express their discontent over management's handling of the crisis, which has led to regulatory fines, lawsuits, and a 40% drop in the company's share price. A special enquiry into responsibility is being demanded by shareholder lobby groups.

site_title: Adidas to pay 50m euros a year to extend deal with German soccer association: FAZ
summary: Adidas has agreed to pay 50 million euros annually, roughly double its current 25 million euro payment, to extend its sponsorship deal with the German soccer association (DFB) for four years starting from 2019. The deal, which was previously reported to be worth 65-70 million euros per year, is part of a larger battle for dominance in the global soccer gear market, with Adidas competing with Nike for contracts with elite clubs and national teams.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares rise as Brexit fears subside
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose 1.2% on Monday as Brexit fears subsided, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 61.84 points to 5,224.50. The latest poll showed Britons leaning towards staying in the EU, causing a move out of safe-haven gold and into banking and mining stocks. Despite the rally, analysts expect the market to remain shaky ahead of the EU vote on Thursday.

site_title: New Philippine government seeks big overhaul to shore-up growth
summary: Philippine President-elect Rodrigo Duterte's new economic team has promised sweeping changes to boost infrastructure, fix traffic woes, and improve investment frameworks. The team, led by Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez, aims to maintain robust economic growth while tackling outdated infrastructure, graft, and protectionism. The government plans to relax investment restrictions, build infrastructure, and lower corporate taxes. Duterte's administration also aims to address traffic gridlock in Manila, seeking emergency powers from Congress to tackle the issue, which costs an estimated $69.65 million daily in lost business.

site_title: Malaysia in talks to move startup of B10 biodiesel programme to July
summary: Malaysia is in talks to delay the start of its B10 biodiesel programme to July, a month later than initially planned, to allow oil companies to reset blending ratios and procure enough palm methyl ester. The new standard aims to increase the minimum bio content of biodiesel to 10% for transport and 7% for industry, supporting local palm oil prices and stabilizing them. The programme's implementation will consume 709,000 tonnes of palm oil annually, exceeding current estimates of 500,000 tonnes.

site_title: Six killed in Mexico during teachers' protest against police
summary: Six people were killed and 53 injured in Mexico on Sunday during clashes between teachers' union members and police at a protest in Oaxaca. The violence was attributed to armed individuals who infiltrated the protest, shooting at police and throwing petrol bombs. The protesters were blocking a highway in response to education reforms implemented three years ago. State officials blamed the radicalized protesters for the violence, and most of the casualties were young people with ties to the union.

site_title: Ascott secures 7 new properties, poised to outpace growth in 2015
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has secured 7 new properties with 1,714 units across 7 cities in Asia. This marks a significant expansion, with over 5,000 units secured in the first half of 2016. The new properties include Somerset West Hongqiao Shanghai and Citadines Blue Cove Danang, with the latter being the largest serviced residence globally with 550 units. The company is poised to outpace its growth in 2015, which saw a record 6,700 units added to its portfolio.

site_title: China's yuan firms as US dollar falls, eyes on Britain's EU referendum
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar as the dollar index fell 0.7% in Asian morning trade. The decline was driven by sterling's rally ahead of Britain's EU referendum on Thursday. Investors are cautious due to the uncertainty surrounding the vote, with one trader stating, "Investors are nervous not to make a wrong bet." The yuan's strength is seen as a sign of market confidence, but the outcome of the EU referendum remains uncertain.

site_title: Gold sinks as Brexit poll favouring 'remain' weakens haven appeal
summary: Gold prices dropped by 1.1% to US$1,286.43 an ounce, as a poll showed 45% of Britons backing the "Remain" camp in the June 23 EU vote, weakening the haven appeal of gold. This marks a reversal from the past three weeks, when gold rose amid Brexit uncertainty. The poll's results also follow last week's death of pro-EU lawmaker Jo Cox, which led to a reduction in bets on a Brexit win.

site_title: Boeing said near US$4b deal with Russian firm to save 747
summary: Boeing is nearing a $4 billion deal with Russian firm Volga-Dnepr Group to convert a year-old commitment into 10 firm orders for 747-8 freighters, helping extend the life of the iconic jumbo jet amid declining demand for four-engine aircraft. The deal could be announced at the Farnborough Airshow next month, providing a crucial lifeline for Boeing's production. The 747 freighter, with a list price of $379.1 million, is Boeing's second-most expensive commercial jet, and the agreement could help preserve production until the air-cargo market revives or shipping companies replace aging fleets.

site_title: Hong Kong stock market to get US$2b boost
summary: Hong Kong's stock market is set for a $2 billion boost as major mainland China financial firms list units in the city. Orient Securities Co and CDB Leasing, backed by cornerstone investors, will raise up to $1.15 billion and $980 million respectively. The deals are heavily reliant on domestic institutions to offset investor concerns over European and US interest rate hikes. The listings come as global markets remain on edge ahead of the UK's EU referendum and US Federal Reserve's interest rate plans.

site_title: Britain's poorer communities, hit hardest by bank closures, may face shutout
summary: Britain's largest banks have disproportionately closed branches in low-income areas, taking away essential banking services from communities that need them most. Since 2015, 600 branches have been closed, mostly in areas with median household incomes below £27,600, while five new branches opened in wealthy areas. Campaigners argue that banks are creating a dual financial system, leaving the poor without access to basic banking services, and warn of a "perfect storm" hindering regeneration in these areas.

site_title: Cambodia to deport 13 Taiwanese fraud suspects to China
summary: Cambodia has announced plans to deport 13 Taiwanese nationals arrested on fraud charges to mainland China, amid heightened tensions between Taiwan and China. The suspects, who were also arrested by Cambodian police, had been prevented from meeting with Taiwanese emissaries. The deportations come as Taiwan accuses China of "abducting" citizens from countries that do not recognize its government.

site_title: Actor Anton Yelchin of 'Star Trek' films dies in freak accident
summary: Actor Anton Yelchin, 27, was killed in a freak accident when he was crushed by his own car against a driveway wall in his Los Angeles home. He was due to attend a rehearsal and was found dead by friends. No foul play was suspected, but the accident was under investigation. Yelchin was known for his role as Pavel Chekov in the Star Trek films, and tributes poured in from his colleagues and fans, remembering him as a passionate and enthusiastic actor.

images.alt_text: Actor Anton Yelchin, best known for playing the young Russian starship navigator Chekov in the rebooted series of "Star Trek" movies, was killed on Sunday when accidentally crushed by his own car against a driveway wall, police said.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.24% at the open on June 20, 2016, following speculation that Britain may vote to remain in the European Union. The Hang Seng Index reached 20,420.65, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose slightly. The market optimism was attributed to the potential EU vote outcome.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks gain in upbeat start to week of uncertainty
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.7% on Monday, following regional sentiment, amid uncertainties in Europe and at home. Export orders data for May is expected to show a decline for the 14th consecutive month, reflecting weak global demand. The upcoming Brexit vote is seen as a volatile event that could impact the global economy. The main Taiex index reached 8,629.94 points, with the electronics subindex and financials subindex gaining 0.7% and 0.4% respectively.

site_title: Among EU nations, 'frenemy' France most keen on Brexit
summary: France has a larger proportion of citizens in favor of Brexit than other EU nations, according to studies. This "frenemy" relationship between France and Britain has been complicated for nearly a thousand years. French Institute of International Relations expert Dominique Moisi attributes this to the complex historical relationship between the two nations.

images.alt_text: From bloody wars to gentle ribbing and occasional cross-Channel bashing, France and Britain's relationship status has been complicated for nearly a thousand years.

site_title: CDB Leasing's Hong Kong IPO said to seek as much as US$980m
summary: China Development Bank Financial Leasing Co, a Shenzhen-based leasing company, plans to raise up to $980 million through a Hong Kong IPO. The company will offer 3.1 billion shares at a price range of HK$1.90 to HK$2.45 apiece, valuing it at 0.9-1.1 times its estimated 2016 book value. This is Hong Kong's second major leasing company IPO this year, following BOC Aviation's $1.1 billion IPO last month.

images.alt_text: China Development Bank Financial Leasing Co, an arm of the nation's biggest policy lender, and existing investors will seek as much as US$980 million from a Hong Kong initial public offering, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Foreign investors shun 'boring' Russian stocks as ETFs shrink
summary: Foreign investors are withdrawing from Russian stocks, with over $435 million pulled from Russia-focused exchange-traded funds in 2016. This is despite Russian stocks posting some of the best returns in the world this year, with a 20% rally in the RTS Index. Economists forecast slow growth in Russia, citing a prolonged recession, and investors are shifting their focus to other emerging markets. Some analysts, however, see opportunities for selective investing in Russia, particularly in sectors that have already reflected the impact of foreign sanctions and lower crude prices.

site_title: Tens of thousands attend Orlando vigil
summary: Tens of thousands of people gathered in downtown Orlando for a candlelight vigil to remember the 49 victims of the Pulse nightclub massacre, one week after the deadliest mass shooting in US history. The event, attended by Orlando Mayor Buddy Dyer, Florida Governor Rick Scott, and others, aimed to show support for survivors and families. The vigil was followed by a memorial service at the Cathedral Church of St Luke and funerals over the weekend. Authorities are set to release limited transcripts of telephone negotiations between Omar Mateen and police during the attack.

site_title: Philippine government to boost 2017 infrastructure spending to 6% of GDP
summary: The Philippine government plans to increase infrastructure spending to 6% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2017, up from 5% this year, according to Budget Secretary-designate Benjamin Diokno. This increase aims to boost economic growth and development.

site_title: New guidelines give greater clarity on leave benefits, notice period for contract workers
summary: The Ministry of Manpower, NTUC, and SNEF released jointly developed Tripartite Guidelines on the Employment of Term Contract Employees, clarifying leave benefits and notice periods for contract workers. The guidelines encourage employers to treat contracts of 14 days or more as continuous, granting or accruing leave benefits based on cumulative contract terms. This aims to provide greater clarity and fairness for long-term contract employees who do not receive statutory benefits due to separate contracts. The guidelines promote better work-life balance and employee satisfaction.

site_title: World's biggest green bond seller China meets fund skepticism
summary: China has become the world's largest issuer of green bonds, with over $8.8 billion raised this year, but some investors are showing skepticism due to regulatory differences and the inclusion of clean-coal projects. Foreign investors own less than 2% of Chinese onshore notes, and standard investment firms require more rigorous environmental and social governance criteria. China's central bank and green finance committee are open to global views, but regulators are unlikely to impose international guidelines, citing China's unique circumstances and the need for domestic standards.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday with a slight increase in the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index to 1624.930 points. The market saw 83 gainers and 45 losers, with a trading volume of 31.5 million lots worth RM13.9 million.

site_title: Japan PM Abe's LDP in solid lead ahead of upper house vote: polls
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) is expected to gain more than twice as many votes as the Democratic Party in the July 10 upper house election, according to polls. The LDP aims to win a majority of the 121 seats to seek a mandate for Abe's decision to delay a sales tax increase. The Democratic Party, however, is focusing on constitutional revision, which Abe has said is premature. The LDP has a two-thirds majority in the lower house, but the upper house election will determine if Abe can revise the pacifist constitution.

site_title: Toyota researcher sees cheap robots possible by mass production
summary: Toyota researcher Gill Pratt suggests that the automaker's production principles can be applied to build affordable helper robots for aging societies. Pratt believes that Toyota's production system, which enabled the mass production of affordable cars, can also be applied to robots. He envisions robots that can assist the elderly in their homes, similar to cars, and is optimistic about the prospects for devices that can help the elderly age in place. Toyota is already working on various robotic applications, including a motorized wheelchair and a wearable that guides the blind, and has the means to apply its production scale to bring down the cost of robots.

site_title: Australian watchdog files suit against e-cigarette retailers
summary: Australia's consumer watchdog has filed a lawsuit against two e-cigarette retailers, Social-Lites and Elusion, alleging they misled consumers about the safety of their products. Tests found the e-cigarettes contained carcinogens and toxic chemicals, despite claims they were non-toxic. The companies face fines of up to A$1.1 million for breaching consumer laws. This case highlights the ongoing debate over the safety of e-cigarettes and their potential to help smokers quit.

site_title: Visa launches Olympics campaign, undeterred by woes in Brazil
summary: Visa Inc launches its global Olympics campaign despite difficulties in host country Brazil, with no plans to cut back on its Olympic presence. The company has seen no significant cancellations in trips to Rio de Janeiro due to Zika virus concerns and political upheaval. Visa expects 400,000-500,000 visitors to attend the Rio Games and is sponsoring 46 Olympic athletes. The company's new ad campaign features athletes using Visa products, marking a change in tone from previous years.

site_title: Seoul: Won, shares rise as Brexit worries fade
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.6% to 1,165.2 per US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) increased 1.2% to 1,976.58 points. Investor concerns about the UK's Brexit referendum eased, boosting shares and the won. Domestic institutions and foreigners were expected to be net buyers, with tech giant Samsung Electronics up 0.5% after a power supply disruption at its China plant. The Kospi index saw advancing issues outnumber losing ones 587 to 210.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars rise as Brexit anxiety eases slightly
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the US dollar and yen, driven by improved risk appetite ahead of the UK's EU referendum. The "Remain" camp gained some traction in opinion polls, reducing concerns of a Brexit vote leading to global market instability. The Aussie rose 0.6% to US$0.7439 and the kiwi rose 0.7% to US$0.7103, while sterling reached a two-week high against its peers. The rise in currency values was seen as a sign of increased risk-taking in markets.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.8% higher on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 22.22 points or 0.8% to 2,785.64 on Monday, following a broader Asian market gain. The index saw 39.9 million shares change hands worth S$69.1 million, with 107 gainers and 27 losers. The rally comes amid rising expectations of a Brexit vote to remain in the EU, boosting risk sentiment.

site_title: UBS seeds communities to grow
summary: UBS, a Swiss bank serving the wealthy, invests in communities globally through its "UBS and Society" platform. The company supports local communities in Singapore through targeted financial support and employee volunteering, focusing on education and entrepreneurship. UBS partners with organizations such as CampVision and Empact Pte Ltd to empower underprivileged youths and charities. The bank evaluates projects based on capacity, financial justification, and growth potential, with the goal of "seeding" and "growing" community investments.

images.alt_text: Ms Tan briefing executives from various charities and UBS volunteers at a 'Done in a Day' workshop.

site_title: Growth in New Zealand services sector dips slightly in May
summary: New Zealand's services sector growth dipped slightly in May, falling to 56.9 from 57.0 in April, according to a Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ index. The sector's expansion remains solid, driven by a rising population and booming tourism. This follows a companion manufacturing survey showing a rise in manufacturing activity in May.

site_title: Uber's upstart rival in Pakistan uses rickshaws, low-tech phones
summary: Rixi, a Pakistani startup, is competing with Uber in the country's ride-hailing market by targeting low-income residents who use rickshaws instead of cars. Rixi hails rickshaws via SMS messages, bypassing poor smartphone penetration in the low-income rickshaw market. The company has registered about 100,000 rides since its launch in 2013 and averages about 100 rides a day, despite facing challenges such as imprecise location-tracking and low literacy rates among rickshaw drivers and passengers.

images.alt_text: As taxi hailing giant Uber enters Pakistan, a little-known local competitor is counting on a mix of new ideas and old technology to tap what could be a big chunk of the market: low-income residents who travel in rickshaws, not cabs.

site_title: German economy had good start to Q2, upswing to continue: finance ministry
summary: The German economy started the second quarter strong, growing 0.7% between January and March, its strongest quarterly rate in two years. Domestic demand, fueled by private consumption, construction investment, and state spending, is expected to drive an overall economic expansion of 1.7% in 2016. Rising employment, wages, and low interest rates are boosting consumer purchasing power, while exports are growing due to strong demand from EU countries, despite weaker demand from emerging markets. The government expects a balanced budget and increased tax revenues.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on British EU vote optimism
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Monday, driven by optimism over Britain's potential stay in the European Union following its upcoming referendum vote. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.72%, and the Topix index gained 1.76%. The positive sentiment was attributed to speculation that the UK's decision to remain in the EU would have a positive impact on global markets.

site_title: Demonstrations greet Chinese president Xi in Poland
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Warsaw on a three-day visit focused on investment and trade with Poland, the EU's largest eastern economy. Rival demonstrations greeted Xi, with dozens of Falun Gong supporters protesting Beijing's persecution of the group. Hundreds of Xi's supporters welcomed him in front of his hotel. Xi will meet with Polish President Andrzej Duda and Prime Minister Beata Szydlo to sign agreements on investment, trade, and infrastructure projects, including a rail link between China and Poland.

site_title: Asia: Stocks gain as Brexit fears ebb slightly, pound surges
summary: Asian stocks rose as investors became more optimistic about Britain's potential to remain in the European Union, lifting risk sentiment. The MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index gained 0.4% and Japan's Nikkei rose 1.5%. The pound surged against peers, contributing to a 0.4% increase in Singapore's STI index. The gains were attributed to reduced Brexit fears and the potential for a "Brexit soft landing."

site_title: Sterling extends bounce on Bremain hopes, yen sags
summary: Sterling rallied 0.9% to US$1.4483, extending a recovery from its two-month trough, as investors took heart from polls showing a shift towards keeping Britain in the European Union ahead of a June 23 referendum. The yen sagged, while the Australian dollar gained 0.4% to US$0.7422. US stock futures rose 0.9%, and the euro edged up 0.5% to US$1.1333. Analysts warn that market sentiment is tentative and moves could easily reverse if the vote outcome turns negative.

site_title: Women take charge as populist surge sweeps Italy
summary: A populist surge in Italy led to the election of two women as mayors in Rome and Turin, respectively. Virginia Raggi, a 37-year-old lawyer, won Rome's mayoral election with two-thirds of the votes, while Chiara Appendino, a 31-year-old politician, took control of Turin with the support of the far-right Northern League. The victories mark a setback for Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's centre-left Democratic Party and are seen as a boost for the Five Star Movement, a populist party founded by comedian Beppe Grillo.

site_title: Ringgit rises as oil rebound boosts sentiment as Brexit dims
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose 0.5% to 4.0798 per dollar, its largest advance in almost two weeks, after oil prices rebounded and a poll showing 45% of Britons favoring the UK to stay in the EU boosted demand for riskier assets. The rebound in energy prices, coupled with improved risk sentiment, supported the ringgit's climb. Despite being Asia's worst-performing currency this quarter with a 4.4% loss, the currency's gain was seen as a positive sign for Malaysia, which derives about a fifth of its government revenue from oil-related sources.

site_title: London house prices fall as Brexit jitters, taxes cool demand
summary: London house prices fell 0.2% in June due to Brexit jitters and a new property-tax regime, according to property website operator Rightmove. The decline, which brings average prices to £310,471, is the first in the capital since 2010. Nationally, house prices rose 5.5% year-over-year, but the market shows resilience to referendum uncertainty, with supply outpacing demand. Fewer new sellers are coming to market, with June numbers 5.3% below average, as buyers hesitate to list properties before the vote outcome.

site_title: Pound climbs with euro, krone after polls show 'Remain' leading
summary: The pound strengthened 1.4% to $1.4546 against the US dollar following a poll showing the "Remain" campaign for the UK's EU referendum gaining momentum, reversing a previous lead for the "Leave" campaign. The euro also rose 0.7% to $1.1351. The polls suggest a shift in investor sentiment, driving a decline in currency volatility to a one-week low. Sterling's gains are seen as a positive sign for the "Remain" campaign, with gains beyond $1.45 only expected if the "Remain" side wins the vote.

site_title: The key arguments in Britain's EU referendum
summary: The UK is set to vote on EU membership, with key battleground topics including immigration, sovereignty, and public services. Leave supporters argue that a points-based system can limit migrant numbers, while EU citizens moving to Britain for at least 12 months raises concerns about housing and welfare. The UK economy has shrunk for the second month, adding to the pressure on policymakers. The outcome of the referendum is uncertain, with significant implications for Britain's sovereignty and relationship with the EU.

site_title: Japan May exports fall 11.3% year on year: MOF
summary: Japan's exports fell 11.3% year-on-year in May, exceeding economists' expectations of a 10.4% decline, due to a strong yen and weak emerging markets. Imports also dropped 13.8%, resulting in a trade deficit of 40.7 billion yen ($523.7 million). This follows a 10.1% decline in April. The strong yen and declining demand are expected to continue impacting Japan's exports.

site_title: New Zealand consumer confidence falls in Q2: survey
summary: New Zealand's consumer confidence index dropped to 106.0 in Q2 from 109.6 in Q1, reflecting households' growing concerns about the economic outlook. A reading above 100 indicates more optimists than pessimists, indicating a decline in confidence. This marks the first decline in consumer confidence since Q2 2015.

site_title: A smarter way of seeking returns
summary: High net worth individuals are shifting focus from maximizing returns to preserving wealth due to prolonged market volatility. Investors are adopting more sophisticated strategies, including exploring alternative asset classes and strategies. Bank of Singapore's Johan Jooste notes that the "simple buy and hold strategy is dead" and that investors should consider hedge funds and private equity, as these offer opportunities for income and stability. As a result, investors are looking to position their portfolios conservatively while still generating income, prioritizing stability over high returns in uncertain markets.

site_title: Iran in deal to buy 100 planes from Boeing: Teheran official
summary: Iran has agreed to purchase 100 aircraft from Boeing to renew its ageing fleet, according to the head of Teheran's civil aviation authority. Ali Abedzadeh stated that the deal needs US Treasury approval before a precise timeline can be set. Iran currently operates 250 planes, with 230 in need of replacement.

site_title: Oil extends gains, up 0.6%, as Brexit fears ease
summary: Oil prices rose 0.6% on Monday, extending gains after six straight days of declines, due to a weaker dollar and easing Brexit fears. London Brent crude for August delivery increased 29 cents to $49.46 a barrel, while NYMEX crude for July delivery rose 31 cents to $48.29 a barrel. Despite US energy firms adding oil rigs for a third week, oil prices recovered, and the pound strengthened against the dollar. The easing of Brexit concerns also supported oil prices, as campaign campaigning for Britain's vote on EU membership resumed after a three-day hiatus.

site_title: 'Limited transcripts' of Orlando shooters exchanges with police to be released
summary: US authorities will release limited transcripts of Orlando gunman Omar Mateen's telephone conversations with police during his attack on a gay nightclub, which killed 49 people. The transcripts, set to be released on Monday, will cover portions of the conversations, excluding Mateen's pledge of allegiance to the Islamic State group and his views on US policy. The decision aims to avoid re-victimizing those who went through the horror, and Mateen's motives remain unclear, with his father citing a history of anger issues and FBI investigations into possible Islamic extremism.

site_title: Sterling gains as risk aversion abates before vote
summary: Sterling rises by over 1% against the US dollar as traders reassess the UK's EU referendum following the killing of pro-EU MP Jo Cox, which led to the suspension of campaigning. The referendum is set to take place on June 23.

images.alt_text: Sterling rose by more than one per cent against the US dollar on Friday as traders evaluated whether the killing of pro-European Union (EU) British Member of Parliament Jo Cox may alter the balance of opinion in Britain's referendum on EU membership.

site_title: Boeing deepens 737 assembly automation with new robotic system
summary: Boeing is introducing a new robotic system, the Spar Assembly Line (SAL), to drill holes and install bolts in the wing spars of its 737 jets at its Renton, Washington, plant. The system, which will speed up the process and reduce the amount of "rework" caused by production glitches, is part of Boeing's efforts to boost output and prepare for future aircraft with radical new manufacturing methods. The company has not yet announced details or said whether any jobs could be affected, but aims to cut injuries and support sharp increases in output.

site_title: Angry Assange starts fifth year cooped in London embassy
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange began his fifth year in the Ecuadoran embassy in London, where he has been since 2012 to avoid extradition for a 2010 rape allegation in Sweden. Assange's supporters held events in European cities, including Athens, Berlin, Brussels, and Madrid, to show support for whistleblowers. Assange's lawyers plan to appeal a Swedish court's decision to maintain the European arrest warrant, which he fears could lead to extradition to the US.

site_title: Tense it is ahead of the UK referendum
summary: The UK is set to hold a referendum on its membership in the European Union, with the results expected to be announced on June 23. Major central banks have warned of potential risks if the UK votes to leave the EU, causing markets to jittery. Analysts say a "leave" vote could trigger a brief market downturn but may also offer a buying opportunity, while a "remain" vote could bring near-term respite but may not provide a clear direction for the market.

site_title: British PM Cameron warns of Brexit pain
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron warned of significant economic pain if the UK votes to leave the European Union, citing loss of free trade access and budget implications. A divisive campaign has paused to mourn the murder of Remain campaigner Jo Cox, which some say has affected the Leave campaign's momentum. Polls show the Remain and Leave camps neck-and-neck, with Cameron urging voters to consider the long-term consequences of a Brexit.

site_title: Populist surge puts first woman in charge of Rome
summary: Virginia Raggi, a 37-year-old lawyer, was elected as Rome's first female mayor, securing around 62-68% of the vote in a run-off contest. Her victory is a major coup for the populist Five Star Movement, giving it a platform to challenge Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi in national elections. Raggi campaigned on promises to tackle corruption and improve public services, winning over widespread anger among voters. Her win marks a significant shift in Italian politics, with analysts predicting a challenge to Renzi's leadership in 2018.

images.alt_text: Virginia Raggi was elected on Sunday as Rome's first female mayor, exit polls showed, in an electoral triumph for the populist Five Star Movement that represents a major setback for Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.

site_title: Viacom director has uphill battle in case against Redstone
summary: Viacom director Sumner Redstone has taken steps to remove five directors, including Philippe Dauman, Viacom's CEO, from the company. National Amusements, Redstone's company, initiated the move after a dispute over the direction of the media conglomerate. The Delaware court will now decide the fate of the directors. This move comes after Redstone's control over Viacom was challenged, and the outcome is uncertain, leaving the future of the company and its leadership in doubt.

site_title: Yamato Asia exploring open locker concept in Singapore
summary: Yamato Asia, the operator of Ta-Q-Bin delivery service, is exploring an open locker concept in Singapore to facilitate parcel deliveries. The company supports the government's nationwide locker system and plans to collaborate with other businesses to set up lockers, aiming to reduce last-mile delivery costs. This initiative is part of Yamato Asia's efforts to be more cost-efficient in the face of growing online shopping. The trial is expected to start soon, with the goal of creating a more efficient and convenient delivery system for consumers.

site_title: EU bank regulator to quit London if there's Brexit
summary: The European Union's banking watchdog, the European Banking Authority (EBA), will relocate from London to another European capital if Britain exits the EU in a referendum on June 23. The EBA, which regulates banking rules across the 28-country bloc, is currently working on an EU single rulebook. EBA Chairman Andrea Enria stated that the work must be completed regardless of the referendum outcome, aiming to ensure a level playing field for all banks. The move would be a response to the potential loss of London as a major financial hub.

site_title: VW says it's ready with US$10b diesel accord, but will devise fix later
summary: Volkswagen has proposed a $10 billion plan to fix or remove 482,000 emissions-cheating diesel cars in the US, with $6.5 billion for car owners and $3.5 billion for the government and regulators. The plan includes an option for owners to sell or terminate leases, but no timetable for repairs. The US Environmental Protection Agency and California regulators have not approved the proposed fixes, and lawyers for car owners will submit the deal to a federal judge by June 28. The judge will consider the proposal on July 26, and Volkswagen faces potential fines and lawsuits in the US and Germany.

site_title: GLP sees lot more room for fund business
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is expanding its fund management platform, with plans to acquire billion-dollar asset portfolios in the US and monetize stabilized logistic assets in China through private funds. CEO Ming Z Mei expects the fund business to grow, with a potential increase in revenue share from 17% to one-third, driven by capital recycling from existing assets in Japan and China. GLP aims to continue recycling capital through its platform, particularly from China, with a focus on long-term growth and enhanced returns on equity.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's NBAD, FGB in talks to form top Middle East bank
summary: Abu Dhabi's National Bank of Abu Dhabi (NBAD) and First Gulf Bank (FGB) are in talks to merge, creating the largest lender by assets in the Middle East with approximately $170 billion in assets. The potential deal would surpass Emirates NBD, the current largest lender, and prompt further consolidation in the UAE's fragmented banking industry. Credit Suisse and UBS are advising on the deal, which could lead to synergies and a competitive edge for the combined entity.

site_title: Tracing the global market thread that Brexit could unravel
summary: A Brexit vote could unravel a global financial market thread, affecting assets like gold, bank stocks, and government bonds. The event risks "adverse spill-overs" to the global economy, with serious consequences for all markets. Global interest rates and bond yields are already at record lows, and central banks have limited options to respond. The Brexit outcome could lead to a stronger dollar, increasing debt burdens for emerging markets, and a potential 14% rise in the Japanese yen, further exacerbating economic uncertainty.

site_title: Microsoft-funded professor builds software to fight terrorism
summary: A Microsoft-funded professor, Hany Farid, has developed software to help scrub extremist content from the internet. The "robust hashing" technology, built with Counter Extremism Project (CEP) funding, can identify and track altered photo, video, and audio files. The software would allow companies like Facebook to automatically remove flagged content, and the CEP plans to create a database to track and flag egregious content. The technology aims to combat terrorism by reducing the spread of propaganda and recruitment materials on social media.

site_title: Qatar warns of cost overruns, delays in infrastructure works
summary: Qatar's $200 billion infrastructure program faces higher costs and delays due to the slump in oil prices, which have dropped by more than half since 2014. The country's economy is expected to run budget deficits for at least three years, with a 7.8% deficit forecast for this year. Qatar will also introduce a 5% value-added tax in 2018. The government warns that continued volatility in oil prices could lead to delays or cost overruns in key infrastructure projects, including the World Cup, which is expected to cost around $30 billion.

site_title: From oblivion rises an Italian white star
summary: Italian white wine Pecorino, named after the Italian word for sheep, has gained international recognition for its distinctive minerally edge and ageing potential. The grape variety was nearly extinct after World War II, but a trailblazing winemaker, Guido Cocci Griffoni, revived it in the 1980s. Pecorino's unique characteristics, including high sugar and acidity, make it suitable for ageing and have led to its DOCG classification. The grape's resurgence has created jobs and revitalized rural areas in Italy, with its export market now expanding to North America.

site_title: Goldman Sachs' new deposit-taking bank is aimed squarely at ordinary Americans
summary: Goldman Sachs has launched a new deposit-taking bank, GS Bank, targeting ordinary Americans with "peace-of-mind savings" and no transaction fees. The bank, which opened in April, offers competitive interest rates and aims to expand its online offerings. Despite initial interest, the company faces challenges, including lack of experience in retail banking and competition from established players. Goldman's CEO, Stephen Scherr, believes technology will be key to its success, and the company is exploring new products, including small-business lending and low-cost exchange-traded funds.

site_title: When the knockout round begins, it's win or go home
summary: The Euro 2016 tournament in France has reached a critical juncture, with 16 teams advancing to the knockout round and the remaining eight packing their bags. Hosts France, Spain, and Italy, along with England, Germany, Switzerland, Croatia, Hungary, and Poland, are virtually certain to qualify. The top two teams in each group and four third-placed teams will proceed, with UEFA using various criteria to separate the teams. The tournament's expanded format, featuring 24 teams, may lead to future expansion to 32 teams, potentially simplifying the qualification process.

site_title: Malaysia paddy fields become battlefield for Najib to woo voters
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak used paddy fields in a rural district to woo voters in a by-election, where his party, Umno, won overwhelmingly. Najib addressed the crowd, promising to take care of them, and a local woman, Fairuzita Mohamad Amir, credited Umno for helping her grow rice. The by-election saw a significant victory for Umno, with Najib's message resonating with rural voters. The win is seen as a boost for Najib's government ahead of the next general election.

site_title: Buying by directors surges, selling resumes (Amendment)
summary: Buyback activity by directors in Singapore fell to 17 companies with 79 repurchases worth S$46.9 million, down from 18 companies and 94 transactions in the previous week. In contrast, directors made 37 purchases worth S$860,000, a sharp increase from the previous week's 11 companies with 25 purchases worth S$590,000.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's regulator bars Deloitte from audit work for 2 years over MMG case
summary: Saudi Arabia's market regulator has barred the local unit of Deloitte & Touche from providing accounting services for two years due to breaches of rules on accumulated losses. The move follows a long-running case involving Deloitte's work for troubled Saudi contractor MMG, which was previously suspended from auditing work for listed firms. Three MMG executives, including founder Mohammad Al-Mojil, were sentenced to prison terms and ordered to pay fines for misrepresenting the company's value. The decision was made by the Capital Market Authority's Committee for the Resolution of Securities Disputes.

site_title: Copper faces tough future as Asia stockpiles rise
summary: Copper stocks are expected to rise by 50% in the next month as Asian countries, including South Korea, Singapore, and Taiwan, stockpile the metal, potentially depressing prices in the near term. The shift away from top consumer China and increased supply from Peru are contributing factors. The global copper market is struggling to absorb metal, with world refined consumption expected to rise only 1.1% this year, and demand in central and south America forecast to fall 5.2%.

site_title: Spain joins forces with Bollywood to boost tourism
summary: Spain is partnering with Bollywood to boost tourism, particularly from India. Madrid will host the annual International Indian Film Academy (IIFA) awards, dubbed the "Bollywood Oscars", to attract Indian visitors. The event aims to showcase Spain's colorful fiestas and historic monuments as potential film settings, capitalizing on India's growing overseas tourism market. This move is part of Spain's efforts to tap into the country's fast-growing tourism sector.

site_title: Logistics players ponder the industry's future as deliveries grow
summary: Singapore's logistics industry is shifting its focus to the "last mile" as e-commerce grows, with consumers demanding more efficient and cost-effective delivery services. Companies like Procter & Gamble and Singapore Post are exploring new models, such as drone delivery and locker services, to reduce costs and increase efficiency. The government and academia are also investing in research and education to help the industry adapt to changing consumer demands. With total online spending in Singapore expected to reach $3.4 billion in 2017, logistics players must innovate to stay relevant and maintain profitability.

site_title: China home prices rise at a faster pace in May
summary: China's home prices rose 6.9% in May from a year ago, accelerating from April's 6.2% increase, driven by quicker growth in second-tier cities and smaller cities. This marks a broader recovery in the property market, which has been a rare bright spot in China's slowing economy. However, growing debt levels and fears of overheating have raised concerns for policymakers and risks for banks, with some cities tightening restrictions on home purchases to keep housing affordable.

site_title: World's largest robots for mine trains fail to deliver
summary: Rio Tinto Group's US$518 million effort to deploy automated trains on its 1,700 kilometres of track in Australia's Outback has been delayed, two years behind schedule, raising doubts about the technology's viability. The project, designed to save money by expanding capacity and reducing labor costs, has encountered mechanical and software challenges. Industry rivals, such as BHP Billiton and Fortescue Metals Group, have also deferred similar investments, citing concerns about returns on investment. The delays have led to reduced output forecasts and raised questions about the project's long-term viability.

site_title: Board performance dashboard
summary: A board of directors' performance dashboard serves as an enterprise wellness indicator, guiding the board to assess and reset direction as needed. The dashboard consists of three duties (strategy, structure, and systems) and three tasks (policy, people, and processes), which work together to deliver sustainable value creation. A well-designed dashboard should include 7-10 key metrics to assess opportunities, risks, and costs, and provide a deep learning tool for the board to understand the linkage of indicators and their impact on the business, enabling them to make informed and dynamic risk assessments.

images.alt_text: About 7-10 dials would be needed to reasonably assess the opportunities, risks, and costs involved in a strategic decision.

site_title: Turning adversity into opportunity
summary: Eng Liat Kiang, 97, founder-chairman of Sin Heng Chan Group, attributes the longevity of his business to "hard work" and believing "things will work out for the better". Born in a rural district of Guangdong province, Kiang credits his hardscrabble childhood with teaching him the value of hard work. He has weathered multiple business cycles, earning him the Honorary Award from Teochew Poit Ip Huay Kuan for his entrepreneurial achievements.

site_title: Cybercurrency project comes under hacker attack
summary: A hacker has stolen over $50 million worth of Ether from the Decentralized Autonomous Organization (DAO) project, which raised over $150 million. The project's organizers have decided to shut it down due to the breach. This incident highlights the vulnerability of cybercurrency projects to hacking and cyber threats. The DAO's shutdown is a significant blow to the experimental virtual currency, which was initially designed to provide decentralized and transparent financial transactions.

images.alt_text: A Hhaker appears to have moved digital money worth more than US$50 million from an experimental virtual currency project that recently raised more than US$150 million - all of it in the form of Ether, an alternative cybercurrency to Bitcoin.

site_title: SMEs have benefited much from cloud computing: GSTF head (Amended)
summary: Cloud computing has enabled small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to leverage infocomm technologies without dedicated ICT teams, according to GSTF president Anton Ravindran. This has increased productivity for SMEs, who rely heavily on technology to stay competitive. The shift to cloud computing has also allowed SMEs to tap into new opportunities, such as increased efficiency and cost savings. Ravindran's comments highlight the importance of technology in driving business growth for SMEs.

images.alt_text: Dr Ravindran argues that even selling hardware and software to SMEs might become a thing of the past because the firms would be able to get the necessary computing resources from the cloud.

site_title: 2000: Millennium bug bites
summary: In 2000, Singapore experienced disruptions in the tech sector, with the Nasdaq plummeting 7.6% in April, and regional tech stocks taking a hit. This led to a shakeout in the stockbroking industry, with Summit Securities closing and UBS Warburg and OCBC Securities forming a joint venture. Local banks were also forced to shed non-financial businesses, with equity stakes valued at S$1.5 billion being sold. The government's decision to separate financial and non-financial activities in the banking sector was a major change, with Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stating that banks were "not property companies".

site_title: Refugees in Indonesia tackle life in limbo through school
summary: A school in Indonesia's Cisarua, founded by refugees, is providing education to 58 students from war-torn countries, including Afghanistan, Iraq, and Sri Lanka. The school, called the Refugee Learning Nest, offers classes in English, mathematics, computer studies, and art, and has become a source of pride for the migrant community. Despite language barriers and limited resources, the school aims to give refugee children a chance to attend school while waiting for resettlement. The initiative is being replicated in other areas, but more support is needed to reach the thousands of refugee children in need of education.

site_title: Brexit vote could influence TPP debate in Japan, lobbyists say
summary: A Japanese expert group opposed to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has launched a campaign to stop the Japanese government from ratifying the treaty, citing concerns over "national sovereignty" and potential compromise of investment policies and health issues. The group, led by former Japan Medical Association chairman Katsumasa Haranaka and former agriculture minister Masahiko Yamada, claims the US and Japan must both ratify the agreement for it to move forward. A Brexit vote in the UK could embolden Japanese opponents of the TPP, potentially turning the issue into a key campaign point in Japan's upcoming upper house election.

site_title: Heavy trading predicted around Brexit vote
summary: US stock markets are expected to experience heavy trading and increased volatility ahead of the June 23 Brexit vote. Fund managers are adjusting their positions for the annual FTSE Russell index rebalancing, set to occur a day after the vote, which could lead to a busy trading week. If Britain votes to leave the EU, US shares could fall sharply, while a "Remain" vote may not result in a significant rally due to domestic economic concerns.

images.alt_text: The June 23 vote on whether Britain remains in the EU could have big implications for the global economy and US stocks.

site_title: Getting up close and personal
summary: A roundtable discussion featuring various business leaders from Singapore and Asia explored their companies' core activities, unique selling points, and future challenges. The panelists, representing companies such as Markono, JK Tech, and Thatz International, discussed their business transformation, milestones, and growth strategies. They emphasized the importance of trust, innovation, and customer satisfaction in driving success. The panelists also highlighted the need to adapt to changing market trends and emerging technologies, such as fintech and digital printing, to remain competitive.

site_title: Phoenix rebuilds downtown as it woos Silicon Valley professionals
summary: Phoenix, Arizona, is rebuilding its downtown area to attract Silicon Valley professionals, with new developments and infrastructure projects underway. However, critics argue that the rapid growth and expansion may be unsustainable, labeling the city "the world's least sustainable city." Despite this, the city aims to capitalize on its appeal to tech industry workers, seeking to rebrand itself and improve its reputation.

images.alt_text: The Phoenix that has been disparaged by so many is undergoing a change. These days, there is hardly an empty lot left in the city's core, and there are as many apartments under construction, or about to be built, as all of those that were built from 1996 to 2008.

Mr Marino (left) and Mr Park worked as software engineers in Silicon Valley before they turned an old hardware store on the southern edge of downtown Phoenix into headquarters for their online mattress business.
The Phoenix Public Market cafe. Eager to transform their city's image, Phoenix leaders are betting big on education-driven urban renewal projects to draw young, tech-savvy residents downtown.

site_title: Israel builds world's tallest solar tower in desert
summary: Israel has begun building the world's tallest solar tower, the Ashalim Tower, in the Negev desert. The 240-meter tower will be covered in stainless steel and feature a field of mirrors to direct sunlight towards a boiler generating steam, producing electricity. The project, costing $761 million, aims to provide 2% of Israel's electricity needs and is part of the country's shift towards renewable energy. While critics argue it's too expensive and complex, proponents see it as a key step towards energy independence and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

site_title: Guarding against cyber attacks
summary: A recent article discusses the importance of cyber security for organisations, citing it as a key business risk. The Singapore International Chamber of Commerce emphasizes the need for awareness among employees and companies to protect against cyber attacks. Meanwhile, other news includes a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, falling US jobless claims, and China's efforts to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Top 3 winners of Prestige Award
summary: The Prestige Award winners are Lennon Tan, Executive chairman & group CEO of Jing King Tech Holdings, Edwin Ng, Managing director of Markono Print Media, and Teo Hark Piang, Executive director of Union Energy Corporation. Jing King Tech Holdings, a leading smartcard producer, took the top spot for its innovative products and services in the Fintech and Trusted Services and Solutions space. Markono Print Media, a full-service print solutions provider, and Union Energy Corporation, a leading supplier of bottled LPG, also received prestigious awards.

site_title: Aircraft maintenance needs high-tech lift-off
summary: Aircraft maintenance is hindered by outdated technology, despite rapid innovation in the aviation industry. Engineers rely on manual and paper-based methods, whereas the industry has seen advancements in aerodynamics, materials, and onboard systems. The shift towards low-cost carriers and larger, more sophisticated aircraft has created a need for modern maintenance solutions. The industry's reliance on outdated technology is holding back improvements in efficiency and safety.

site_title: Schaeuble says global liquidity, debt complicate market turmoil
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that excessive global liquidity and debt are exacerbating market volatility, as central banks reach the limits of measures to boost growth. He also highlighted the threat of a Brexit as a geopolitical risk, alongside Islamist terrorism, armed conflict in eastern Ukraine, and an excess of liquidity and debt. Schaeuble expressed concerns that fiscal and monetary policy measures have reached their limits, and called for caution in the face of uncertainty.

site_title: India hunts for central bank chief as Rajan's term ends in September
summary: India begins searching for a new central bank chief as Governor Raghuram Rajan's term ends in September. Potential candidates include Urjit Patel, who has experience in macroeconomics and was part of the Patel Committee report, and Subramanian, a former IMF assistant director and critic of the government's budget numbers. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley plans to announce a successor shortly, with some speculating that Patel could become the country's first woman governor.

site_title: Ryan stands by Trump despite reservations, citing need for unity
summary: US House Speaker Paul Ryan has pledged to support Donald Trump despite reservations, citing the need for unity and preventing a Democratic win in November's election. Ryan has backed Trump despite rebuking the candidate for questioning a federal judge's impartiality and opposing his plans to temporarily ban Muslims and deport undocumented immigrants. Ryan's motivation is to prevent another Democrat in the White House, with Hillary Clinton leading in national polls. He will speak out against Trump if the candidate puts a bad label on conservatism.

site_title: Canada's oil industry seeks game-changing technology
summary: Canada's oil industry is seeking game-changing technology to reduce costs and increase efficiency amid declining oil prices and growing demand for cleaner energy. Experts, including Harbir Chhina, are experimenting with new technologies, such as steam injection and solvents, to extract oil from the country's oil sands. However, the industry faces significant challenges, including high costs and a lack of investment in research and development. Companies are exploring data analytics and partnerships to drive innovation, but significant investment is needed to replicate commercial-scale technologies and remain competitive in the market.

site_title: China's Xi sees Serbia as milestone on new "Silk Road"
summary: China's President Xi Jinping views Serbia as a significant milestone in his country's "Silk Road" initiative, a plan to boost trade with Europe, Asia, and Africa. During a visit, Xi announced China's readiness for more cooperation with Serbia, with over 20 finance and infrastructure deals signed. Serbia is seen as a key location for the Silk Road, connecting Western China to Central Asia and Europe through the Balkans. The country has already received significant investments from China, with plans to establish a free trade zone and encourage Chinese investment in its troubled industries.

site_title: Air France strike called next week, mid Euro-2016
summary: Air France pilots are set to go on strike from June 24 to 27, amid disagreements with management over pay rules. The strike, called by three unions, follows last week's 20% flight disruption and 40 million euro losses. Management had made "very vague promises" in negotiations, prompting the unions to take industrial action. The strike is the latest in a series of disputes over labour reforms in France, but has not disrupted fan travel for the European football championships.

site_title: China home prices rise faster in May as smaller cities join rally
summary: China's home prices rose 6.9% in May, the fastest pace in four months, driven by growth in second-tier cities and smaller cities. This recovery in the property market has been a rare bright spot in China's slowing economy. However, prices in major cities such as Shenzhen and Shanghai have slowed, raising concerns of overheating and growing debt levels. The broader recovery has eased policymakers' concerns, but banks and policymakers still face risks.

site_title: UAE banks NBAD and FGB confirm merger talks, shares soar
summary: UAE banks National Bank of Abu Dhabi (NBAD) and First Gulf Bank (FGB) have confirmed merger talks, sparking a surge in shares. The potential tie-up would create one of the largest banks in the Middle East and Africa, with assets worth around $171 billion. Analysts see the merger as a sign of consolidation in the UAE banking sector, which is crowded and facing challenges from lower government spending and global capital rules. Local investors welcomed the idea of an Abu Dhabi mega bank, pushing NBAD shares up 15% and FGB shares up 11.5%.

site_title: Top 3 winners of Promising Award
summary: The Promising Award winners include GE Lines, a one-stop logistics solutions provider, Porcelain, a skincare treatment establishment, and Thatz International, an IT Outsourcing and Managed Services provider. GE Lines has grown from a startup with limited resources to a profitable business in 10 years. Porcelain has expanded from a small treatment spa to a well-known skincare establishment in just seven years. Thatz International has grown its workforce to 180 professionals, empowering corporate customers with technology integration. The companies have demonstrated significant growth and success in their respective industries.

site_title: Angst grows over agrochemical mega-mergers
summary: Three agrochemical mega-mergers, including Bayer and Monsanto, have raised concerns among farmers over higher prices and genetically modified food. The mergers will control two-thirds of the global market for seeds and pesticides, reducing choice for farmers, particularly in southern countries. Non-governmental organizations and advocates of small-scale farming have voiced their concerns, warning that the mergers will concentrate power in the hands of a few company boards. The mergers have sparked debate over the impact on farmers, consumers, and the global food chain.

images.alt_text: Three mega-mergers in the agrochemical sector, including Bayer and Monsanto, have raised concerns among farmers who fear higher prices and consumers more genetically modified food.

site_title: Odds on Brexit narrowing
summary: Remainers in the UK can no longer rely on the odds favoring a Remain victory as the June 23 Brexit referendum approaches. Bookmakers have narrowed the odds on a Brexit win, suggesting a shift in public opinion. The disparity between opinion polls and bookmakers' predictions has decreased, indicating that the outcome is becoming less certain. This shift in odds may reflect the impact of public opinion and betting patterns on the referendum's outcome.

site_title: GLP's prospects brighter than what analysts think
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) is expected to achieve strong profits despite concerns over a slowdown in its key China market. Group CEO Ming Z Mei stated that the company will still see strong profits from development completions in China this year. Net operating income from US assets is also expected to be "very strong" due to high rental growth on renewal leases. Mei's comments have alleviated fears about the company's financial performance, potentially making GLP a misunderstood stock with a brighter outlook than analysts initially thought.

site_title: Iran, Boeing reach deal on purchase of 100 planes: Tehran
summary: Iran and Boeing have reached a deal to purchase 100 aircraft to replace the country's ageing fleet. The agreement, worth $17 billion, is pending US Treasury approval. Iran's civil aviation authority head, Ali Abedzadeh, confirmed the deal, citing a need to replace 230 of the country's 250 planes. The contract follows a January agreement with Airbus for 118 planes, which is also awaiting US Treasury approval. Boeing's deal with Iran comes after the US granted partial sanctions relief following a nuclear deal with Iran in January.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Financial plans to buy 20% stake in Ascend Money
summary: Ant Financial, the financial affiliate of Alibaba Group, plans to buy a 20% stake in Thailand's Ascend Money, with an option to increase to 30%. The investment aims to expand Ant Financial's online payments and small loans business in Southeast Asia. The move is part of Alibaba co-founder Jack Ma's global expansion aspirations, following investments in South Korea and India. The deal is pending approval from the Chinese Ministry of Commerce and is seen as a commitment to bring financial services to more users worldwide.

site_title: George W Bush ends exile, helps Republicans raise money
summary: Former US President George W. Bush has ended his self-imposed exile to help Republicans raise money for the 2016 elections, despite initial reluctance. Bush has headlined fund-raising events for several Senate candidates, including John McCain and Kelly Ayotte, and plans to support others. His efforts come as the Republican Party fears Donald Trump's nomination may harm their chances in the November elections. Bush's involvement is seen as a one-off, temporary thing, and he has repeatedly stated he is not interested in being Trump's vice presidential running mate.

site_title: Formula One: Rosberg wins European Grand Prix
summary: Nico Rosberg won the European Grand Prix, increasing his lead in the drivers' championship to 24 points. He outpaced Sebastian Vettel of Ferrari and Lewis Hamilton of Mercedes, who struggled with technical issues. Rosberg's 19th career victory brought him 141 points, while Hamilton slipped to 24 points behind. The result marked a return to form for Rosberg after three poor races.

images.alt_text: Mercedes AMG Petronas F1 Team's German driver Nico Rosberg celebrates on the podium after winning the European Formula One Grand Prix at the Baku City Circuit on June 19, 2016 in Baku.

site_title: A showcase of Scottish ingredients
summary: UsQuBa, a new Scottish restaurant, showcases the country's ingredients with its chef's dishes. A piece of foie gras is served with pickled apples, highlighting the use of Scottish produce. The restaurant is open daily for lunch and dinner. The article does not delve into the world of Scottish cuisine, but instead focuses on the chef's interpretation of Scottish ingredients.

images.alt_text: Seared foie gras.
Singapore Breakfast.
Butter poached whole lobster.
Roast pigeon.
Orkney Islands Scallop Ceviche.

site_title: Fintech: banks at an 'Uber moment'
summary: Banks are facing a "Uber moment" as fintech companies disrupt the consumer banking industry. According to a Citi GPS report, banks in the US and Europe are at a tipping point, struggling to innovate and compete with fintech entrants who have the edge in client experience. To remain competitive, banks must prioritize innovation before fintech companies achieve scale. This shift is particularly pronounced in consumer banking, where fintech companies are often more agile and better equipped to meet changing customer needs.

images.alt_text: The payment space is the segment of finance that has been most challenged by tech-driven new entrants to date. Alipay and PayPal are leaders in ecommerce online payments.
India, with the ubiquity of mobile phones with around 80 per cent penetration, is one of the big opportunity spaces for fintech.

site_title: Boeing deepens 737 assembly automation with new robotic system
summary: Boeing is introducing a new robotic system, the Spar Assembly Line (SAL), to automate drilling and installing bolts in wing spars of its 737 jets, deepening the company's thrust into automation. The system, which will reduce the space used by earlier machinery, aims to cut rework caused by production glitches and support increased output. This move is part of Boeing's efforts to boost production of its best-selling airliner and prepare for future aircraft designed with radical new manufacturing methods. The company has not yet announced details or said whether any jobs could be affected.

site_title: Brexit: How Europe fell out of love with the EU
summary: The European Union is facing a crisis of public support, with a recent survey showing a 17-point drop in favourable views among Europeans, particularly in France. The Brexit referendum, scheduled for June 23, has sparked concerns about the future of the EU, with the Schengen passport-free zone threatened by the migrant crisis. Euroscepticism and populism are growing, and EU leaders are acknowledging that citizens are "stepping away" from the project. The EU's utopian ideals, which led to its creation, are seen as unattainable, and many Europeans are rejecting any kind of idealism, instead prioritizing practical solutions.

site_title: Celebrating the Teochew business spirit
summary: The Teochew Entrepreneur Award, launched by the Teochew Poit Ip Huay Kuan, honored the best of Teochew entrepreneurs and their values in Singapore. The inaugural award recognized 28 winners, including 16 Prestige Award recipients and 12 Promising Award winners, from various industries. The winners were chosen from over 40 participants, who demonstrated outstanding entrepreneurship and embody the Teochew values of courage, perseverance, determination, diligence, and innovation. The award aims to foster a sense of community among Teochew businessmen and women and promote their entrepreneurial spirit.

site_title: India seen pressing ahead with bank clean-up despite Rajan exit
summary: India's plan to clean up its banks' US$120 billion of sour loans is unlikely to be affected by the departure of central bank chief Raghuram Rajan. Despite his exit, bankers and government officials say the direction remains the same, with Rajan's successor likely to be less aggressive in fighting bad loans. The asset quality review ordered by Rajan has reported a surge of 70% in bad loans, but officials believe the clean-up is long overdue and has been institutionalized, making it difficult to reverse course.

site_title: SCDF rescues 11 trapped in vehicles by flash flood in Jurong West
summary: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) rescued 11 people trapped in three vehicles by a flash flood in Jurong West on June 18, 2016. The victims were affected by torrential rain in the area. The SCDF responded quickly to the emergency, evacuating the individuals from the vehicles.

site_title: Sole suspect charged with murdering British MP Jo Cox
summary: British MP Jo Cox was murdered outside her constituency surgery in Birstall, northern England, on Thursday. Thomas Mair, a 52-year-old local man, has been charged with murder and other crimes related to the attack. Cox, a Labour MP and advocate for EU membership and Syrian refugees, was killed by a knife and firearm. Prime Minister David Cameron and US President Barack Obama have condemned the attack, and a fund in Cox's memory has raised over $391,000 for charities. Mair is due to appear in court later Saturday.

site_title: Hang Seng Bank to form China's first foreign majority-owned fund
summary: Hang Seng Bank has been approved to form China's first foreign majority-owned fund management company in Shenzhen's Qianhai special development zone. The company will hold 70% ownership, with state-run Shenzhen Qianhai Financial Holdings Co owning the remaining 30%. This approval marks a step towards linking Hong Kong's financial hub with mainland China's rapid development, offering more flexibility in cross-border lending and services. The joint firm will raise money and offer fund products and asset management services.

site_title: US film industry says 'hola' to Havanawood
summary: Hollywood is increasingly investing in Cuba's film industry, dubbed "Havanawood," after the US relaxed its embargo in January. Productions like "Fast and Furious 8" and "Transformers: The Last Knight" have hired local crew members and extras, creating jobs and showcasing the island's art deco elegance. However, Cuba's independent film industry is struggling due to lack of funding and censorship from the Cuban Film Institute. Industry professionals and filmmakers are calling for support to strengthen the domestic industry and promote Cuban cinema globally.

site_title: China May home prices rise 6.9% y-o-y
summary: China's home prices rose 6.9% in May from a year ago, accelerating from the previous month's 6.2% gain, driven by price increases in second-tier cities. The southern city of Shenzhen saw the largest price rise, with home prices increasing 53.2% from a year ago. This recovery in China's property market has been a rare bright spot for the world's second-largest economy, which has been slowing due to weak demand and excess industrial capacity.

site_title: Twin Malaysia by-elections to reveal level of support for Najib
summary: Malaysia is holding twin by-elections in Sungai Besar and Kuala Kangsar, with over 76,000 voters set to cast ballots on Saturday. The by-elections, triggered by a helicopter crash that killed the incumbents from Prime Minister Najib Razak's party, will test public support for Najib amid funding scandals and concerns about his leadership. A strong win could bolster his grip on power, while losses could raise concerns about his ability to steer the party to another win in a national election by 2018.

site_title: Gold sparkles on Brexit fears
summary: Gold prices hit a near two-year peak of $1,315.71 an ounce amid rising fears of a Brexit vote. New polls showed a rise in support for leaving the EU, increasing concerns over the global economic outlook. Investors sought the commodity as a safe-haven asset, driving the surge in gold prices. The move was also influenced by US President Trump's tariff threats, adding to market volatility. The spike in gold prices suggests investors are seeking protection from potential economic uncertainty.

site_title: Britain's campaign on EU membership restarts as polls show momentum for 'In'
summary: Britain's EU membership campaign resumed on Sunday, five days before the June 23 referendum, after a three-day hiatus following the killing of lawmaker Jo Cox. Polls show the 'Remain' camp recovering momentum, with the 'In' camp now leading 45% to 42% ahead of the 'Out' camp. Prime Minister David Cameron warned voters of an "existential choice" on Thursday, while the 'Leave' campaign claims leaving the EU would improve Britain's economic position.

site_title: Orlando attacks renew focus on security at smaller US businesses
summary: The Orlando nightclub attack has sparked renewed interest in security measures among US businesses, particularly smaller ones, despite concerns over costs. Industry executives note that major attacks often prompt inquiries but fail to translate into sales due to high upfront expenses and ongoing costs. In contrast, European companies have seen increased sales after major incidents. However, some US businesses, especially big ones, are expected to invest in physical security measures, such as metal detectors, in response to the Orlando attack.

images.alt_text: While mass shooting attacks are on the rise, smaller US businesses remain reluctant to invest in more physical security measures such as metal detectors or extra guards even though events like the Orlando massacre prompt a surge in interest, industry executives said.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends week on down note as Apple weighs
summary: US stocks ended the week on a down note, with the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 falling 0.33% and 0.33% respectively, as investors prepared for Britain's vote on EU membership next week. Apple shares also declined 2.3%, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.92%. Fears over Brexit have reduced risk appetite, with the S&P 500's momentum hindered by the potential for market volatility.

site_title: TED Talks aim for wider global reach
summary: TED Talks, known for its "ideas worth spreading", has launched a new mobile application for Android that can be used in 24 languages, aiming to reach nearly a billion people worldwide. The app, which automatically displays instructions in the chosen language and provides transcripts, will help the non-profit organization reach a wider global audience. The app's redesign also includes improved search functionality and the addition of TED Radio Hour audio presentations. The move follows a significant demand from the Asia-Pacific region, with over 70% of online traffic from TED apps coming from outside the United States.

site_title: Disney installs alligator warnings, barriers after boy's death
summary: Disney World is installing alligator warning signs and temporary barriers at its Florida resorts after a 2-year-old boy's death in a lake. The boy was snatched from the shore by an alligator, despite a no-swimming sign at the location. This incident marks the 23rd alligator-related death in Florida since 1948. Disney is also reinforcing training for staff on reporting wildlife sightings and interactions. The resort has shut down beaches and marinas as a precaution.

images.alt_text: Disney World said Friday it was installing alligator warning signs and temporary barriers at its Florida resorts following the death of a toddler who was snatched from the shore of a lake.

site_title: Rio state declares financial emergency, requests funding for Olympics
summary: Rio de Janeiro's governor declared a state of financial emergency due to a slump in revenue tied to the petroleum industry, prompting a request for federal funding to fulfill public service obligations during the Olympics starting August 5. The state expects a budget deficit of over 19 billion reais and has delayed pension and salary payments, shuttering schools and hospitals. The federal government has assured the delivery of Olympic projects, and the local organizing committee relies on private funds for the Games.

images.alt_text: Rio de Janeiro's governor declared a state of financial emergency Friday and requested federal funds to help fulfill obligations for public services during the Olympics that start Aug 5.

site_title: China iPhone sales maintained pending patent appeal: Apple
summary: Apple continues to sell iPhones in China despite a May 19 ruling that said the smartphones violated a patent of Chinese manufacturer Shenzhen Baili. The ruling barred Apple from selling iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus models, but Apple appealed the decision and the order has been stayed pending review by the Beijing IP Court. Apple's iPhone 6s, iPhone 6S Plus, and iPhone SE models are available for sale in China, and the company is maintaining its sales pending the outcome of the appeal.

site_title: Asian buyers play role in overheated Canada housing market: Trudeau
summary: Canada's housing market is experiencing a surge, with Vancouver and Toronto recording double-digit price increases over the past decade. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau attributes the rise to an influx of Asian capital, stating that overseas money is playing a role in the affordability crisis. The Canadian central bank and OECD have expressed concerns, while economists warn of a potential real estate bubble. A Toronto Dominion Bank report warns that the markets are ripe for a correction, but predicting its timing is difficult. The government has set aside funds to study the matter, but no supporting data was provided.

site_title: Teen hacks Pentagon websites, gets thanked for finding 'bugs'
summary: A 10-15 hour hacking session by 18-year-old David Dworken, a high school graduate, found 6 vulnerabilities on Pentagon websites, earning him a $100 reward. Dworken, a computer science student, participated in the Pentagon's "Hack the Pentagon" pilot project, which received 138 valid vulnerability reports from over 1,400 participants.
