Singapore Airlines' passenger loads fell in May, but the removal of a rule in India could benefit the airline. Sinwa Limited's share price was trading at nine times 2015 earnings, with a potential opportunity to expand its customer base with the takeover of NOL by CMA CGM.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on growth worries, Brexit fears
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday as worries about weak economic growth and a potential British exit from the European Union weighed on sentiment. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all declined, with the Dow down 0.6% and the S&P 500 down 0.5%. The declines were influenced by central banks' decision to keep interest rates unchanged, citing the upcoming British referendum as a source of unease. The losses mirrored declines in international markets, including those in Japan and England.

site_title: Opec turmoil could turn IEA's balanced market into shortfall
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts a near-equilibrium between global crude supply and demand in 2017, requiring Opec to pump nearly 1 million barrels per day (bpd) above May's production level. To achieve this, Opec must overcome major output disruptions in Nigeria, Libya, and Venezuela, where militant attacks, political divisions, and economic crises are hindering production. If Opec fails to meet the IEA's forecast, oil inventories would start to shrink rapidly, potentially leading to higher prices.

site_title: Meal delivery service app UberEATS launches in London
summary: Uber launched its meal delivery service app UberEATS in London on June 16, 2016, becoming the second European city where users can order food for delivery. The service is available in 17 cities worldwide and competes with Deliveroo and Just Eat. Britons can download the app from midday and order from over 150 restaurants, with deliveries made in central London until 11 pm, expanding to further areas in the coming weeks.

site_title: Malaysia steps in as 1MDB exits development project
summary: Malaysia's government signed an agreement to take over 1Malaysia Development Berhad's (1MDB) 40% stake in the Bandar Malaysia project, a multi-billion dollar development in Kuala Lumpur. 1MDB sold its remaining 60% stake for $1.7 billion in December to Lim Kang Hoo's Iskandar Waterfront Holdings and China Railway Engineering Corp. The move aims to reduce 1MDB's debts. The finance ministry will now control the project, which includes a public transport hub.

site_title: US consumer price gains slow; underlying inflation supported
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.2% in May, slower than expected, but sustained increases in housing and healthcare costs kept underlying inflation at 1.0% for the 12 months through May. This moderation in price growth could support the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates this year.

site_title: NauticAWT to raise S$2.6m by placing out 15m shares at S$0.174 apiece
summary: NauticAWT, a Catalist-listed oil and gas engineering firm, plans to raise S$2.6 million by issuing 15 million new shares at S$0.174 each. The shares will be allocated to Harps Holdings, a private investment company with marine interests in Africa. The funds will be used for working capital needs and provide financial flexibility. This move comes as NauticAWT faces challenging and volatile conditions.

site_title: Anti-money laundering compliance costs Asia banks US$1.5b a year: report
summary: Asian banks spend around $1.5 billion annually on anti-money laundering (AML) compliance, a recent study found. The cost is expected to rise due to increased scrutiny of financial institutions and transactions. The Monetary Authority of Singapore plans to set up dedicated units to monitor money-laundering risks and boost enforcement action. A survey of 210 respondents from China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand showed that AML compliance costs vary greatly among firms, with top-tier banks spending up to 15.8 million annually, while smaller firms spent around $850,000.

site_title: Temasek Holdings forms Americas' advisory panel with eye on investments
summary: Temasek Holdings has formed an advisory panel for the Americas, comprising executives from multinational companies such as PepsiCo and Honeywell International. The panel, chaired by former US Treasury Secretary Tim Geithner, aims to provide insights and experience as Temasek seeks investments in the region. This move follows the formation of a similar advisory group for Europe in January. The panel's formation is part of Temasek's efforts to expand its investments in North America, Europe, and Latin America, with a focus on navigating a challenging global macro environment.

site_title: POSH set to bag second contract from Shell LNG project
summary: POSH, a Malaysian offshore-and-marine group, is poised to secure its second contract with Shell for a floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) project off Australia. It has pulled ahead of rival Prosafe in the tender for the installation-support work, which is estimated to take six months. POSH proposed a new semi-submersible accommodation vessel, the Arcadia, to support the project. The contract value has not been disclosed, but it could boost POSH's revenue and gross profit.

images.alt_text: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH), a listed offshore-and-marine group partly owned by Malaysian tycoon Robert Kuok, is well-placed to land its second contract with a Shell-operated floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) project.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SingPost introduces a code of business conduct and ethics for its board directors, along with new policies on directors' conflicts of interest and board renewal. Singapore Airlines launches non-stop flights to San Francisco and adds a second daily service to Los Angeles. Singapore commits to OECD tax reform, while SME sentiment in Singapore improves for the first time in seven quarters. The Straits Times Index fell 0.8% on Thursday, with Singapore shares closing at 2,751.56.

site_title: Indonesia's Lion Air removed from EU air safety blacklist
summary: Indonesia's Lion Air, a major airline operator, has been removed from the European Union's air safety blacklist. This means Lion Air is no longer banned from flying in the 28-nation EU. The decision was made by the European Commission, which assessed Lion Air's safety record and determined that it met EU standards. The removal is effective immediately and marks a positive development for the airline.

site_title: Bank of England warns on Brexit but holds rate
summary: The Bank of England has warned that the UK's EU membership referendum is the "largest risk" to financial markets, with a potential Brexit vote leading to a sharp decline in sterling's exchange rate. Despite this, the Bank of England held its interest rate at 0.50%. The warning comes as the UK's economy shrinks for the second month, adding to the uncertainty surrounding the referendum outcome.

site_title: Thai airport operator to spend US$5.5b on expansion
summary: Thai airport operator Airports of Thailand Pcl plans to spend 194 billion baht (S$7.4 billion) over 15 years to expand its six airports, with a revised budget mainly due to increased passenger and budget airline flights at Bangkok's Don Muang international airport. The Don Muang airport expansion will now require 28.7 billion baht, up from 7 billion baht, to construct new facilities including a mass transit line. The new plan aims to handle the growing number of visitors to Thailand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index losing 13.06 points to close at 1,614.90. 1.57 billion lots valued at RM1.55 billion were traded, with 195 gains and 591 losses.

site_title: 'Emerging buyers' flex deal-making muscle, bypass private equity
summary: Emerging buyers, including sovereign wealth funds, pension funds, and private families, are increasingly flexing their deal-making muscles, bypassing private equity firms. Over the past year and a half, these investors have bought 17% of assets sold by private equity firms, up from 2% in 2007. By taking direct stakes in companies, emerging buyers aim to avoid management fees and invest in companies without paying for due diligence and legal fees. Some banks, like Goldman Sachs, are stepping in to support these emerging buyers, recognizing the need for innovative and forward-thinking strategies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall 2% as Brexit worries intensify
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 2% on June 16, 2016, amid Brexit worries and a cautious US Federal Reserve statement on interest rates. The Hang Seng index dropped 2.1% to 20,038.42 points, with energy and IT shares leading the decline. Tencent Holdings Ltd fell 2% despite announcing a major gaming deal, and nearly all main indexes declined. The decline was attributed to intensified fears of a British exit from the EU.

site_title: DBS Foundation announces funding, business advice for aspiring social enterpreneurs
summary: DBS Foundation has launched initiatives to support aspiring social entrepreneurs, including a grant program and business advice, to help them develop their businesses. The foundation has also commissioned research studies on alternative funding methods and working with social incubators. This move aims to provide resources and guidance to social enterprises, enabling them to grow and make a positive impact.

images.alt_text: The DBS Foundation is rolling out new initiatives for 2016 through its grant programme and competition to help aspiring social entrepreneurs with business advice and funding.

site_title: Starbucks to take on Italy's coffee culture
summary: Starbucks is set to open its first store in Milan, Italy next year, marking the global giant's entry into the country's sophisticated coffee culture. The store will be located in a city already dominated by local chains like Arnold Coffee, which offers a similar American-style coffee experience. Starbucks' menu will feature a range of coffee drinks, including espresso and pastries, catering to the city's young and tech-savvy population. The move is seen as a challenge to local chains, but it is unclear how well Starbucks will adapt to Italy's unique coffee culture.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.8% down on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.8% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index dipping 22.69 points to 2,751.56. The decline came after Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen warned of Brexit risks and the Bank of Japan's refusal to ease monetary policies. The bluechip index saw 890.1 million shares traded worth S$964.4 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 287 to 130.

site_title: Scandal-hit VW sets hopes on electromobility
summary: Volkswagen, embroiled in a global engine-rigging scandal, aims to reposition itself as a leader in environmentally sustainable transport by launching over 30 all-electric models by 2025. This move is part of the company's new strategy to focus on the most attractive market segments and prioritize electromobility. The goal is to achieve annual sales of 2-3 million vehicles or 20-25% of global sales, with battery-powered electric vehicles accounting for around a quarter of the global passenger car market. This shift is seen as a key step towards transforming VW's core business.

site_title: China: Stocks fall as economic worries weigh
summary: China's stocks fell 0.7% to 3,094.67 on the CSI300 index and 0.5% to 2,872.82 on the Shanghai Composite Index, amid worries about the struggling economy and a weakening yuan. Investors were also cautious due to concerns about the potential impact of Brexit on the global economy. Resources shares rose, however, as China announced plans to control new production capacity and reduce overcapacity in the non-ferrous metals sector.

site_title: Europe: Stocks resume slide at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Thursday, following a slump in Asia, amid concerns over the global economic outlook. The FTSE 100 index slid 1.0% to 5,909.23 points, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also dropped 1.3%. The Bank of Japan's failure to pump up its stimulus led to a 21-month high for the yen. The Fed's lowered growth forecasts and interest rate warnings have increased concern about the US and global economy, with the Bank of England expected to maintain its interest rate and stimulus.

site_title: Goldman says steel curbs in China are masking weaker demand
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts China's steel demand will continue to shrink despite a short-term supply shock from mills cutting output. The bank estimates a 1.3 million metric ton loss in crude steel production due to the recent conference. However, steel demand is weakening as the effects of credit-led stimulus have worn off, according to the report.

site_title: Australia dollar hold gains after jobs and Fed, NZ dollar boosted by GDP
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars strengthened against the US dollar on Thursday, driven by better-than-expected Australian jobs data and the US Federal Reserve's reduced rate hike projections. The Australian dollar fell against the yen, while the New Zealand dollar rose 0.7% after beating forecasts for GDP growth. Analysts expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to keep interest rates steady until August, with a 58% chance of a rate cut by the end of the year.

site_title: NTU, Delta Electronics set up S$45m lab for smart technologies
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and Delta Electronics have established a S$45 million joint laboratory for smart technologies, focusing on "cyber-physical systems" for homes, learning institutions, and manufacturing facilities. The Delta-NTU Corporate Laboratory for Cyber-Physical Systems will support over 80 researchers and staff, including NTU PhD students. The lab is supported by the National Research Foundation under its Corporate Laboratory@University Scheme, and is NTU's fourth partner under the scheme.

site_title: China's Midea launches offer for German robot maker Kuka
summary: China's home appliance maker Midea has launched a 4.5 billion-euro (S$6.8 billion) offer to acquire more than 30% of German industrial robot maker Kuka. Midea already owns 13.5% of Kuka and plans to acquire the rest through an offer of 115.00 euros per share, valid from June 16 to July 15. The move has sparked concerns among German politicians, but Midea has confirmed it will not enter into a control agreement or other deal with Kuka.

Models Never Talk is one of the highlights of The OPEN.

site_title: Airbnb gets US$1b debt facility from US banks: source
summary: Airbnb has secured a $1 billion debt facility from major US banks, including JPMorgan, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, and Bank of America. The funding is intended to aid the company's new services and expansion plans, and comes after a recent funding round of over $100 million. Airbnb is expected to achieve profitability in 2016, amid increased pressure from startups like Airbnb in the hotel bookings business.

site_title: Quake of magnitude 5.3 in Japan's Hokkaido, no tsunami danger
summary: An earthquake of magnitude 5.3 struck Japan's Hokkaido island on June 16, 2016, with no reported tsunami danger or injuries. The quake, which is common in Japan, did not cause major damage or problems at the area's nuclear plants. It occurred roughly two months after a major earthquake in the southern island of Kyushu.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei stock index drops 3% on yen rally
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index dropped 3.05% on Thursday, reaching 15,434.14, due to a yen rally triggered by the Bank of Japan's decision to hold fire on launching fresh stimulus ahead of Britain's EU membership vote. The yen surged to a 21-month high against the dollar, threatening Japan Inc's profitability and raising concerns about Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's faltering growth blitz. The yen's rally also led to a decline in Japanese stocks, with Toyota, Sony, and Fast Retailing among the biggest losers.

site_title: MNCs based here to submit tax reports as Singapore commits to OECD reform
summary: Singapore commits to OECD's base erosion and profit shifting (BEPS) tax reform, aiming to counter artificial tax avoidance by global corporations. The country will implement the four minimum standards, including countering harmful tax practices and preventing treaty abuse. Large corporations with ultimate parent entities in Singapore and group turnover exceeding $1.1 billion will be required to file tax reports detailing revenue, profits, and staff count. This move is expected to close tax loopholes worldwide, conservatively estimated to save global tax revenue of $100 billion to $240 billion annually.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rise, but global jitters undermine gains
summary: Australian shares rebounded 0.3% to a two-month high, driven by miners and a weaker US dollar, as gold prices rose following the Federal Reserve's lowered economic growth forecasts. Gold miners like Northern Star Resources and Newcrest Mining surged 6% and 3-6% respectively. Crown Resorts jumped 15% after announcing a potential spin-off of its international business. New Zealand's benchmark index edged up 0.2% as Air New Zealand reported a 7.5% annual increase in long-haul passengers.

site_title: Europe car sales up 16% in May as volume, luxury brands surge: Acea
summary: European car sales increased 16% in May, reaching 1.33 million vehicles, driven by double-digit growth in volume and premium brands. The Association of European Carmakers (Acea) expects the market to maintain its positive momentum. Four of the five largest European markets posted double-digit sales gains, led by Italy and France. Mass market manufacturers Renault and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) saw significant growth, while luxury brands like Mercedes, BMW, and Audi also fared well. VW's deliveries in its core European market recovered further in May, rising 8.8%.

site_title: Broker China Securities plans up to US$1b Hong Kong IPO in 2016
summary: Brokerage China Securities Co plans to raise up to $1 billion in an initial public offering in Hong Kong by the end of 2016, according to IFR. The company, partly owned by CITIC Securities Co, has sent requests to banks to pitch for a role in the IPO, with presentations set for next week. The IPO plans were not immediately commented on by China Securities.

site_title: Oil dips 6th day as easing disruptions counter US supply drop
summary: Oil prices fell for a sixth consecutive day, dipping 1.4% in New York, as supply disruptions in Canada and Nigeria began to ease. US crude stockpiles dropped to 531.5 million barrels, but analysts say the surplus will reappear once disruptions are resolved, causing prices to falter. Nigerian militants are pursuing peace talks, while Canadian output is expected to ramp up after wildfires. The 80% rally from a 12-year low in February is faltering, with prices expected to evaporate as supply returns.

site_title: Kidnapper of Hong Kong heiress jailed for 12 years
summary: A Hong Kong court sentenced Zheng Xingwang, 30, to 12 years in prison for his role in the kidnapping of heiress Queenie Rosita Law, 29, in April 2015. Law was held in a mountain cave and released after a ransom of HK$28 million (S$4.9 million) was paid by her family. The judge described the kidnapping as "premeditated" and "meticulously planned", while Law was left to suffer a "harrowing experience" during her three-day captivity.

site_title: Casino titan Packer hives off Macau stake from Aussie assets
summary: Crown Resorts Ltd, controlled by James Packer, plans to spin off its international investments, including a US$2 billion stake in Melco Crown Entertainment Ltd, to isolate its Australian assets from a prolonged downturn in the Chinese gambling hub. The new entity will house Crown's Las Vegas development site, Nobu restaurant, and half of UK casino operator Aspers Group. The move aims to provide greater clarity on the value of Crown's Melco stake and position the company for future growth.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says to acquire US cloud services firm Joyent
summary: Samsung Electronics announced the acquisition of US-based cloud services firm Joyent to boost its cloud computing and "internet-of-things" capabilities. The acquisition, terms of which were not disclosed, aims to strengthen Samsung's cloud-related infrastructure and services. This move follows Samsung's recent acquisitions, such as LoopPay in 2015, to bolster its software and services capabilities. The deal is expected to help Samsung expand its presence in the cloud computing market.

site_title: Credit Suisse, UBS need more action on capital rules, SNB says
summary: Switzerland's Swiss National Bank (SNB) has stated that UBS Group AG and Credit Suisse Group AG need to take further measures to meet the country's new capital requirements. The banks must improve their leverage ratio requirements and meet "gone-concern" requirements, which serve as a buffer against potential shocks. This comes as Switzerland increased the amount and quality of capital required for the country's two largest banks earlier this year.

site_title: Gold tops US$1,300 after Fed's cautious outlook
summary: Gold prices surged to over $1,300 for the first time since early May after the US Federal Reserve indicated it may be less aggressive in tightening monetary policy next year. The Fed kept interest rates unchanged, signaling two rate hikes in 2016, but noted slower economic growth would slow future policy tightening. Gold's price sensitivity to interest rate hikes contributed to the increase, as higher rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-interest yielding metal.

site_title: Fonterra targets China sweet tooth with eat-at-home ice cream tubs
summary: Fonterra, a New Zealand dairy group, plans to trial online sales of its 'Tip Top' ice cream tubs in China through Alibaba Group's T-Mall e-commerce platform. The move aims to capitalize on China's growing ice cream market, which reached $11.4 billion in 2014. Fonterra sees an opportunity to capture a small but growing market for at-home ice cream consumption in China. The company's decision follows a slump in dairy prices, which have fallen by over half since 2014, allowing it to boost profit margins from consumer products like ice cream.

site_title: Seoul: Won nearly steady after Fed as Brexit eyed; stocks down
summary: The South Korean won traded nearly flat after the US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady for the month, as investors had already priced in the decision. The won was trading at 1,171.9, up 0.1% from the previous day. Meanwhile, South Korean shares edged down 0.5% due to investor skittishness ahead of the Brexit referendum in Britain. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell to 1,958.06 points, with Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and Korea Gas Corp among the decliners.

site_title: UOL completes acquisition of 110 High Holborn London for £98.7m
summary: UOL Group Ltd's wholly-owned subsidiary, Success Venture Property Investments Ltd, has completed the acquisition of 110 High Holborn London for £98.7 million (S$189 million). The property, located in Midtown London, features 10,900 sqm of office and retail space. The acquisition marks a significant deal for UOL, further expanding its presence in the global market.

site_title: World's fastest growing airline market opens as India eases
summary: India has unveiled an aviation policy to open its world's fastest growing major air-travel market. The policy allows domestic airlines to fly overseas if they deploy 20 planes or 20% of capacity on local routes, benefiting foreign carriers like Singapore Airlines and AirAsia. The move is expected to attract new investments from Middle Eastern carriers, leading to increased competition and a possible consolidation among local carriers. Air travel in India grew over 20% last year, outpacing China and the US, and the government aims to become the world's third-biggest aviation market in five years.

site_title: Disney's China fairytale begins with US$5.5b park opening
summary: Walt Disney Co has opened its first theme park in China, Shanghai Disney, with a $5.5 billion investment, marking the company's largest overseas investment. The park aims to tap into China's booming domestic tourism market and offset a lacklustre international theme park business. Despite initial rain delays and concerns about competition from local theme parks, Disney sees China as its biggest opportunity since its Florida acquisition. The park features unique attractions, including a Chinese-style tea house and a Tarzan musical, and is expected to attract 330 million visitors within a three-hour radius.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end near 3-week low on global gloom; won flat
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.9% on Thursday, closing near a three-week low, due to concerns over slowing global economic growth. Foreign investors bought a net 42 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while the won remained stable at 1,171.4 to the dollar. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 1,951.99 points, its lowest in three weeks.

site_title: Yen soars to 21-month dollar high as BoJ holds fire on stimulus
summary: The yen reached a 21-month high against the dollar at 104.53 after the Bank of Japan held fire on fresh stimulus, citing concerns over Britain's EU exit. The decision came amid global market turmoil over the economic outlook and Brexit fears. The euro also dropped to a three-year low against the yen. Investors sought safe assets, driving up the yen's value, with one trader stating the yen was bought due to expectations of more easing from the BoJ. The yen's surge contrasts with the dollar's losses after the Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates.

site_title: Foreign protesters' bark unleashes Chinese dog eaters' bite
summary: Protesters against China's annual dog meat festival in Yulin have sparked a backlash, with locals reporting a surge in dog meat sales. The festival, which draws thousands of animals, has been denounced by celebrities and international groups, but residents say the protests have made the event more popular. Local business owners and dog lovers are now defending their cultural traditions, with some even opening dog meat delivery services. The backlash has also led to a shift in tactics, with activists now focusing on education and awareness campaigns to change attitudes towards dog consumption.

site_title: Brazil's interim president Temer involved in Petrobras graft: witness
summary: Brazil's interim president Michel Temer is involved in a massive corruption scandal, according to a key witness. Sergio Machado, former Transpetro CEO, alleged that Temer asked for dirty cash from Petrobras to fund an ally's 2012 campaign. Temer denies involvement, but the allegations could take down more politicians in the sweeping scandal. Two of his ministers have already resigned due to corruption allegations. The Petrobras probe remains a major threat to Temer's government.

site_title: Oil dips in Asia on US supplies, Fed comments
summary: Oil prices in Asia fell for a sixth straight session, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate slipping 46 cents to $47.55 and Brent shedding 34 cents to $48.63, amid concerns about the global economy and supply-side fears. The Department of Energy reported a smaller-than-expected decline in US commercial inventories, suggesting easing demand. Supply disruptions are expected to subside, with Canada's output normalizing and Nigerian rebels considering peace talks. Global uncertainty, fueled by Brexit fears and the Bank of Japan's monetary policy decision, has contributed to the sell-off.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 1.510 points to 1628.89. Volume was 21.68 million lots worth RM11 million, with 72 gainers outnumbering 49 losers.

site_title: MAS and Australian regulator sign deal to support innovative firms
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) signed an Innovation Functions Cooperation Agreement, allowing innovative fintech companies in Singapore and Australia to set up initial discussions in each other's markets faster. The deal will also provide advice on required licenses, reducing regulatory uncertainty and time to market. This collaboration aims to support innovative businesses in both countries and promote economic growth.

site_title: SME sentiment up for first time in seven consecutive quarters
summary: Singapore small and medium enterprises (SMEs) have shown a 1.9-point increase in sentiment, reaching a score of 51.9, marking the first time in seven consecutive quarters. This improvement is attributed to SMEs' optimism about growth prospects and expectations of increased turnover and profits. The business services sector was the most optimistic, with the transport and storage sector recording the largest improvement in sentiment. The survey, conducted by the Singapore Business Federation and DP Information Group, involved over 3,600 SMEs surveyed between April and May 2016.

site_title: ASML to buy Taiwan's Hermes Microvision for US$3.1b
summary: ASML Holding NV is buying Taiwan's Hermes Microvision Inc. for approximately US$3.1 billion, aiming to expand its capabilities for advanced semiconductor manufacturing. ASML, a leading chipmaking equipment producer, will pay NT$1,410 per share, a 31% premium over Hermes Microvision's average price. The acquisition will help ASML negotiate better deals with leading-edge production facility builders, such as Intel and Samsung Electronics.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday, after US stocks fall overnight
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, following a decline in US stocks overnight. The Straits Times Index fell 0.23% to 2,767.86 points, with 27 million shares changing hands. Key losers included HLH, Noble, and Ezra, which dropped 14%, 2%, and 1.3% respectively. The decline came amid concerns over the UK's potential exit from the European Union and the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower as Fed stands pat
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on June 16, 2016, after the US Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.37% and the Topix index lost 0.33%. The move comes ahead of Britain's vote on leaving the European Union, which is expected to impact markets.

site_title: Noble Group shares fall after S&P rating downgrade
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted over 2% after Standard & Poor's downgraded its credit rating to B+ from BB- and assigned a negative outlook, citing the company's troubled finances and dramatic collapse in its share price over a year ago. The downgrade led to the sale of key assets to address financing concerns.

images.alt_text: Noble Group shares fell more than 2 per cent on Thursday after Standard & Poor's cut the Singapore-based commodity trader's credit rating deeper into junk territory, to B+ from BB-, and assigned a negative outlook.

site_title: China economic transition poses risks to Australia: RBA official
summary: China's economic growth is expected to experience a gradual moderation over the next few years, with a risk of a "hard landing" if the economy experiences shocks. Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Assistant Governor Christopher Kent cited Beijing's reliance on accommodative monetary and fiscal settings to support its slowing economy, which may increase the likelihood of a future disruptive adjustment. For Australia, the primary risk is to commodity prices and exports to China, Australia's single biggest export market.

site_title: Uber's Chinese rival Didi completes US$7.3b financing round
summary: Didi Chuxing, China's leading ride-sharing company, completed a $7.3 billion financing round, valuing the company at nearly $28 billion. The funding, led by Apple and prominent Chinese investors, will be used to upgrade technology and improve the experience for riders and drivers. Didi, backed by Alibaba and Tencent, is targeting an initial public offering in New York next year. This comes as the company battles Uber, which has raised $5 billion in financing and is spending at least $1 billion a year in China.

images.alt_text: Didi Chuxing completed a US$7.3 billion round of funding from new and existing investors to give China's leading ride-sharing company more firepower to battle Uber Technologies Inc.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall as Yellen sounds alarm over Brexit
summary: Asian markets fell as Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen expressed concerns about a possible British exit from the EU, which dragged US stocks lower and sent the dollar tumbling. The Fed lowered growth forecasts and signaled slower interest rate rises. Japan's central bank policy meeting also influenced markets, with the yen strengthening against the dollar. Despite a 0.4% gain in Singapore's STI index, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul fell, while Sydney rose 0.4%. The pound held gains against the dollar, awaiting the June 23 EU referendum.

site_title: Yuan swings back to losses as Brexit concerns overshadow Fed
summary: China's yuan fell 0.09% to 6.5847 a dollar, bucking a stronger central bank fixing, amid concerns over Britain's possible departure from the EU. The yuan traded in Hong Kong's offshore market dropped 0.02% as investors sought safe-haven assets. The Federal Reserve's dovish comments and a dovish Fed were overshadowed by the Brexit uncertainty. China's PBOC has been propping up the currency, but investors are now focusing on the UK referendum, driving the yuan lower.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.97% at open on Thursday, following a previous day's gains, amid concerns over Britain's possible exit from the European Union. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 20,268.28, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.31% to 2,878.40. The decline was attributed to Janet Yellen's warning about the potential economic impact of Brexit.

site_title: Gold pinned to Brexit angst as traders see US$1,350 if leave wins
summary: Gold prices are expected to surge to US$1,350 an ounce if the UK votes to leave the European Union, according to a Bloomberg survey of 22 traders and analysts. If the UK remains in the EU, prices are expected to slide 2.8% to US$1,250. The rally is driven by increased uncertainty and demand for a haven asset, with some sellers already preparing for potential market turbulence.

site_title: Argentina ex-minister caught hiding cash in monastery
summary: Argentine former government minister Jose Lopez, 55, was arrested for trying to hide millions of dollars in cash and jewels at a monastery. Lopez, who served as deputy minister for public works for 12 years, was already facing corruption charges. He attempted to conceal the money by throwing suitcases over a wall into the monastery's garden, where police found a rifle and a total of $8 million in value. Lopez's lawyer claims he is mentally unwell, but authorities say he has some explaining to do regarding the corruption allegations.

site_title: BOJ holds policy steady; cuts view on CPI
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy steady, keeping interest rates unchanged and pledging to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen. The central bank slightly lowered its view on consumer inflation, predicting a year-on-year change of slightly negative or about zero percent. This decision was made by an 8-1 vote, with the BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda set to hold a news conference to explain the policy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, SIA, companies with operations in the UK, KLW
summary: SingPost introduced a code of business conduct and ethics, dissolving its Executive Committee and recruiting new board directors. SIA launched non-stop flights between Singapore and San Francisco and added a second daily service to Los Angeles. Companies with UK operations, such as ComfortDelGro and City Developments, are largely insulated from Brexit risks, with many expecting London to remain a key business hub. KLW Holdings requested a trading halt, pending an announcement.

site_title: Tsipras critics seek to harness Greek bailout anger
summary: Thousands of Greeks protested in Athens' Syntagma Square, calling for Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' resignation over new austerity measures. The "Resign" protests drew around 7,000 people, with smaller turnout in Thessaloniki. Tsipras' government has brokered a new bailout with international creditors, including tax hikes and pension reforms, which has sparked widespread discontent. The protests come as Tsipras trails in opinion polls behind the conservative New Democracy party. The government has dismissed the protests as seeking to cause instability at a crucial time for Greece's economy.

site_title: China's MSCI index denial a boon for Singapore's regional plans
summary: Singapore's stock exchange, Singapore Exchange Ltd, is poised to benefit from MSCI's decision to delay adding Chinese shares to its global indexes, as investors opt for offshore centers. The exchange has seen a surge in volumes for its FTSE China A50 contracts, which track the 50 largest Chinese stocks, and its SGX MSCI China Free Index futures. Singapore's established product and "first mover advantage" are expected to attract more international investors, potentially boosting its role in the region.

site_title: GLP announces 2nd additional syndication in US portfolio
summary: Global Logistic Properties Ltd (GLP) announced its second additional syndication in the US portfolio, with a new co-investor agreeing to invest $180 million for a 9.09% stake. The syndication, completed on Wednesday, brings the total syndication in the portfolio to 75.61%. The deal does not impact the company's net tangible asset value or earnings per share for the 2017 financial year. GLP retains interim net cash generated by the portfolio.

site_title: Investors scramble to fend off Brexit risks
summary: Investors are scrambling to mitigate potential Brexit risks ahead of the June 23 referendum, which could redraw the European Union's political map. A surge in support for a British exit from the EU has triggered a rush to hedge against the uncertainty, with incalculable consequences for the project's future. The polls have caught many investors off guard, leading to a scramble for financial shelter and potentially significant consequences for the global economy.

site_title: KLW Holdings requests for trading halt
summary: KLW Holdings, a Catalist-listed door maker, has requested a trading halt in its shares pending an announcement. The company had suspended its shares in January after failing to find a replacement for its sponsor, SAC Capital, which would stop being its sponsor after December 31. In March, KLW announced an option to purchase two units at 2 Kallang Avenue for S$2.28 million, which will serve as an office and showroom. The exact nature of the announcement is unclear.

site_title: Migration, construction, drive New Zealand GDP growth in Q1
summary: New Zealand's GDP grew 0.7% in the first quarter, beating expectations, driven by high migration and construction activity. The country's construction sector saw a 4.0% increase, the strongest quarterly growth since 2014. Strong earnings from tourism and a decline in goods exports, mainly due to falling dairy and meat shipments, contributed to the growth. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand may pause lowering interest rates due to the GDP growth, but low inflation could still influence its decision. The New Zealand dollar rose to a new high following the GDP release.

site_title: SingPost unveils code of business conduct, new corporate governance policies
summary: SingPost has introduced a code of business conduct and new corporate governance policies to strengthen its corporate governance foundation. The code sets the tone for board discussions and will ensure compliance with recommendations from the Corporate Governance Review. Five directors will leave the board by the AGM in July, and eight members will remain, with some seeking re-election. The board will guide the recruitment of new directors, with a lead independent director to be appointed from among the new directors, and is expected to receive recommendations from the Corporate Governance Review by the end of June.

site_title: South Korea to ease banks' forex forward rule starting July
summary: South Korea is easing a key capital control rule, allowing local banks to hold up to 40% of their foreign currency forward positions, up from 30%, starting July. Foreign banks can hold up to 200% of their allowed positions, up from 150%. The move aims to reduce capital outflows amid US interest rate hikes and global economic risks. The easing comes after the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged and signals two more rate hikes in 2016.

images.alt_text: South Korea said on Thursday it will ease one of key capital controls implemented after the 2008-2009 global financial crisis as concerns grow over possible capital outflows in the face of higher interest rates in the US.

site_title: Europe: Miners help European shares snap 5-day losing streak, Zodiac rallies
summary: European shares snapped a 5-day losing streak, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index rising 0.9% and the Stoxx 600 index up 1%. Mining stocks, such as Anglo American and Antofagasta, led the gain, driven by advancing metal prices. The rally was fueled by a reassuring earnings update and bid talk for Zodiac Aerospace, which helped counter concerns over the British EU referendum next week.

site_title: Brazil's Temer denies alleged link to Petrobras scandal
summary: Brazil's interim President Michel Temer denied allegations of soliciting campaign funds from Petrobras, a state oil company, as part of the country's largest corruption scandal. A plea deal by former Petrobras executive Sergio Machado linked Temer to the scandal, but the testimony stated that the contribution was made legally. The allegations threaten to unsettle Temer's coalition, with two ministers already resigning. The Supreme Court's decision may not impact the impeachment trial against President Dilma Rousseff, with odds favoring Temer's conviction at 90%.

site_title: SIA to launch non-stop flights to San Francisco from Oct 23
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will launch non-stop flights from Singapore to San Francisco on October 23, 2016, using Airbus A350-900 aircraft. The airline will also add a second daily service to Los Angeles, re-routing the Singapore-Seoul-San Francisco flight to operate as a Singapore-Seoul-Los Angeles service. This expansion is part of SIA's US operations, replacing current flights that operate via Hong Kong and Incheon, Seoul.

site_title: Europeans warn of Brexit threat to UK's crucial bank 'passports'
summary: The UK's potential exit from the European Union poses a threat to its financial services sector, particularly its "passporting" system that allows banks to operate freely across the bloc. If Britain leaves the EU, its partners, including France, Germany, and Luxembourg, may charge high prices to keep the financial services sector intact. The EU has a two-year negotiation period for withdrawal, and the UK's future relationship with the EU remains uncertain, with some officials suggesting that Britain may need to pay a contribution to EU coffers to maintain access to the single market.

site_title: UN to begin secret voting for next secretary-general in July
summary: The UN Security Council will begin secret "straw poll" voting on July 21 to choose the next secretary-general, with a decision expected by October. Eleven candidates, including women, are vying for the top post, but the decision ultimately rests with the five permanent members of the council. The search for a successor to Ban Ki-moon comes at a time of global anxiety, with the UN facing major challenges such as the refugee crisis and conflicts in the Middle East and Africa.

site_title: Geneva opens criminal probe after Mossack Fonseca complaint
summary: Geneva prosecutors have opened a criminal probe following a complaint from Mossack Fonseca, the law firm at the center of the Panama Papers scandal. The investigation, led by Claudio Mascotto, comes after an IT technician at the firm's Geneva office was arrested on suspicion of leaking confidential data. The probe is Switzerland's first into the scandal, which revealed how Mossack Fonseca worked with banks to create offshore shell companies for wealthy clients, including world leaders and athletes. The move follows a series of reports based on leaked documents, which led to the resignation of Icelandic Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson.

site_title: Brexit could start EU 'disintegration', Germany warns
summary: Germany's foreign minister, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, warned that a Brexit vote could lead to the "disintegration" of the European Union. Steinmeier stated that a Britain outside the EU would be "lacking a lot" and that the EU needs Britain to remain. French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault also expressed concerns, saying Europe needs to evolve and that a static bloc is not possible. The remarks come as the Brexit referendum approaches on June 23, with polls suggesting the "leave" campaign is gaining ground.

site_title: Tencent nears deal to buy majority stake in Supercell: source
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd is nearing a deal to buy a majority stake in Finnish games maker Supercell Oy, valuing the company at over $9 billion. The deal, reportedly in late-stage talks, would be Tencent's latest push into the lucrative gaming industry. SoftBank Group Corp, which owns a majority stake in Supercell, is planning to sell its stake to Tencent and co-investors, including Hillhouse Capital Group. The deal would mark the third major asset reshuffle by SoftBank in less than a month.

site_title: China spy ship shadows US, Japanese, Indian naval drill in Western Pacific
summary: A Chinese observation ship shadowed the US aircraft carrier John C Stennis in the Western Pacific, joining warships from Japan and India for drills near waters China considers its backyard. The US says the patrols are to protect freedom of navigation, while China claims it was acting within the law. The incident comes amid growing tensions between Beijing and Tokyo over territorial claims in the South China Sea, with the US and Japan increasing naval presence in the region.

site_title: US dollar falls as Fed holds rates steady and pares forecasts
summary: The US dollar fell on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady at 0.25-0.50% and revised its growth and rate hike forecasts. The move was seen as a slightly weaker outlook for growth and interest rates, weighing on the dollar. The Federal Open Market Committee also left the benchmark federal funds rate unchanged, as expected.

site_title: Picassos settle sculpture custody battle in New York
summary: An international custody battle for a Picasso sculpture worth over $100 million has been settled in favor of a New York billionaire. The sculpture, "Buste de Femme (Marie-Therese)," was initially negotiated for $47 million by London-based agents Pelham Europe on behalf of the Qatari royal family. However, the Picassos renege on the deal and sold it to Larry Gagosian for over $100 million instead, before it was sold to billionaire Leon Black. A settlement has been reached, with the parties agreeing to a "good faith global settlement" resolving the dispute in all courts.

site_title: Credit downgrade may be positive for Japan's US$10t bond market
summary: A potential credit downgrade of Japan's sovereign debt may actually benefit its $10 trillion bond market, according to analysts. The Bank of Japan's massive buying under quantitative easing will likely absorb any selling by foreign players sensitive to ratings. Japanese investors tend to buy back the yen and government bonds as safe havens, making a downgrade unlikely to cause a crisis. Instead, it may trigger a rally in Japanese bonds and currency, with some analysts predicting foreign investors could increase buying in Japanese government bonds due to lucrative returns when swapped to dollars.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as Fed eyes 'Brexit' vote
summary: US stocks dropped for a fifth consecutive day, closing lower as the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged amid concerns about the UK's potential exit from the European Union, or 'Brexit'. Fed Chair Janet Yellen expressed concerns about the vote's impact on global financial markets and the US economy. Investors sold stocks after the Fed's announcement failed to spark a major rally, with some attributing the decline to mixed Fed views and uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Petrobras said close to US$6b sale of Brazil gas pipelines
summary: Petrobras is close to selling a 81% stake in its Brazilian gas pipeline network, Nova Transportadora do Sudeste SA, for nearly US$6 billion to a consortium led by Brookfield Asset Management Inc. The deal, expected to be signed next month, is part of Petrobras' efforts to reduce its massive debt load amid low crude prices. This sale could be the only divestment in Brazil for the company this year, following a period of significant deal-making. The transaction is a strategic move by Petrobras to restructure and focus on its core business.

site_title: Uber's debt-fueled cheap-price race is on borrowed time: Gadfly commentary
summary: Uber's debt-fueled cheap-price strategy, which has allowed the ride-sharing service to maintain a competitive edge, is on borrowed time. The company's reliance on debt and equity markets to finance its operations has led to a significant burn-through of cash. Despite investors warming up to speculative-grade loans, Uber's long-term sustainability remains uncertain, as the company struggles to turn a profit amidst high operating costs and a vast network of drivers and riders. Uber's reliance on cheap capital may eventually lead to financial difficulties, with the company's chief product officer warning that the "money train" will stop.

site_title: France becomes first major nation to ratify UN climate deal
summary: France has ratified the UN climate accord, becoming the first major industrialized country to do so. President Francois Hollande finalized the ratification at the Elysee Palace, with 17 small island and low-lying coastal countries already having ratified the deal. The US is expected to ratify the accord soon, with Norway also imminent. The accord aims to limit global warming to "well below" 2.0 degrees Celsius and requires significant investment in zero-carbon power by 2040.

site_title: Napster is back as digital music service Rhapsody rebrands
summary: Napster, the pioneering digital music service that popularized online music sharing in the early days of the Internet, is back as Rhapsody rebrands itself. The company, which acquired the Napster brand in 2011, announced the rebranding without any changes to its service, including pricing or features. With an estimated 3.5 million subscribers, Rhapsody trails other online music services such as Spotify and Apple Music, but remains a significant player in the digital music landscape.

site_title: Vopak opens refrigerated LPG facility on Jurong Island
summary: Vopak has opened the region's first independent refrigerated LPG facility on Jurong Island in Singapore, providing an alternative feedstock to naphtha for crackers. The 80,000 cu m facility, in partnership with SK Gas International, began operations in February and aims to cater to growing demand for LPG in Asia. The facility will serve Singapore's growing needs and contribute to the country's "Version 2.0 initiative" to improve energy efficiency and emissions management. Vopak sees long-term growth opportunities in Asia, driven by urbanization and increasing energy demand.

site_title: Oil drops as US stockpiles fall less than expected
summary: US oil prices fell for the fifth consecutive day, dropping 48 cents to $48.01 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The Department of Energy's weekly report showed a smaller-than-expected decline in US crude stockpiles, adding to concerns about demand in a weak global economy. Experts attributed the bearish supply situation, while the International Energy Agency warned that huge inventories would cap future price gains. Oil prices had surged to multi-month highs last week but have come under selling pressure due to worries about the global economic outlook and Brexit.

site_title: 1MDB head Arul briefs civil servants in pre-polls meeting in Sungei Besar
summary: 1MDB president Arul Kanda addressed a closed-door event for civil servants in Sungei Besar, Malaysia, ahead of a by-election, downplaying the fund's problems and stating they would be resolved by next year. The event was seen as an attempt to counter negative publicity surrounding 1MDB's financial dealings. Meanwhile, a dispute between 1MDB and Abu Dhabi's IPIC over $6.5 billion is ongoing, with arbitration proceedings expected to drag on. The issue is part of a larger international investigation into 1MDB's dealings, raising questions about liability and potential recoveries of frozen funds.

site_title: Saudi Aramco's public listing revolutionary in many ways
summary: Saudi Aramco, the state-owned oil company, is considering a public listing valued at $1-2 trillion, making it the largest IPO ever. The company's shares could be listed in New York, London, or Hong Kong, which would be a revolutionary move as it would bring the company into the global financial sphere and subject it to US securities laws. A New York listing would be a significant step towards diversifying the Saudi economy and could ease local economic woes, but it also poses challenges for the Saudi government and the company itself.

site_title: IIF flags heavy debt redemption ahead for emerging markets
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) warns that emerging markets, particularly China, face significant debt redemption pressures ahead, with over $665 billion in bonds and loans maturing by the end of 2016. Total debt in emerging markets has exceeded $52 trillion, or 215% of GDP, with China's corporate debt reaching 145% of GDP. The IIF estimates that non-financial corporate debt has increased by $2 trillion since last year, and redemption pressures are set to rise sharply in 2017, with over $1 trillion in bonds and loans coming due.

site_title: Coral "bright spots" offer clues to protecting threatened reefs
summary: Scientists identified 15 "bright spots" among 2,500 coral reefs in 46 nations, offering clues to protecting threatened reefs. These areas, such as those off Indonesia and Kiribati, have more fish than predicted despite local stresses. The Great Barrier Reef, the world's largest, performed in line with expectations. The study, published in Nature, suggests that coral reefs can thrive under certain conditions and may guide efforts to curb threats like over-fishing and climate change.

images.alt_text: Some coral reefs are thriving and scientists say they may guide efforts to curb threats such as over-fishing and climate change which are blamed for widespread global declines.

site_title: S Korea, Singapore to boost fintech co-operation (Amended)
summary: South Korea and Singapore have signed a memorandum of understanding to boost fintech cooperation, covering the exchange of information on fintech ecosystems and regulatory regimes. The agreement aims to connect fintech startups with local business partners, promoting entrepreneurial activity in the region. The partnership is expected to strengthen the fintech ecosystem in both countries, with Singapore seen as a gateway to the global market.

site_title: Threats against Muslims must stop after Orlando attack: US
summary: US authorities have warned that threats against Muslims will not be tolerated and may be prosecuted, following the Orlando nightclub attack that killed 49 people and injured 53. Authorities are investigating reports of death threats against the Muslim community, including a man who allegedly knew of his husband's plan to carry out the attack. President Barack Obama has condemned the violence and pledged support for the affected community, while officials emphasize that civil rights violations are a priority in the investigation.

images.alt_text: US authorities on Wednesday warned that threats against Muslims would not be tolerated, and possibly prosecuted, after alleged incidents in the wake of the Orlando gay club massacre, which was carried out by a Muslim gunman.

site_title: Future looks bleak for giant container ships
summary: The shipping industry is experiencing its worst recession in half a century, with global growth and trade remaining sluggish. The mega-container ship, once seen as a symbol of globalization, is now struggling due to diminishing benefits and increasing costs. The Benjamin Franklin, the largest cargo ship to dock at a US port, made its last US port visit after its owner realized there was not enough demand for the vessel. This marks a belated realization that bigger is not better in the shipping industry, and ship owners are adjusting to the changing market.

site_title: Data integration key to smart nation vision: Talend
summary: Talend, a data integration platform, emphasizes the importance of data integration in Singapore's Smart Nation vision, where technology is used to gather and analyze data from various sources. The company is part of a consortium training local professionals in data analytics and application development, addressing a significant skill gap. With an open-core model, Talend offers free software and proprietary solutions for organizations, and its business model is attractive in the Asia-Pacific region, where customers are price-sensitive. The company plans to expand aggressively in the region, with a focus on India and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Keppel delivers rig ahead of schedule
summary: Keppel Corporation's US rigbuilding subsidiary, Keppel AmFELS, has successfully delivered a world's largest harsh environment enhanced mobility land rig 41 days ahead of schedule. The delivery was achieved with a strong safety record.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux has achieved financial close for the $185 million Qurayyat Independent Water Project in Oman, with funding from Mizuho Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, and Clifford Capital. Fraser and Neave plans to buy Warburg for $29 million, expanding its vending machine operations. CapitalLand sold its Citadines Hitec City Aparthotel in India for $8.3 million.

site_title: Art Basel enjoys 'steady hum of business' at its 47th edition
summary: Art Basel's 47th edition in Switzerland saw a steady flow of business despite rain and falling stock markets, with 286 galleries showcasing works priced at $500,000 or less selling briskly. Dealers offered discounts, and coveted pieces lingered, with billionaire Steven Cohen's $20 million Gerhard Richter painting selling after being hidden in a gallery closet. The fair is a key indicator of the gallery and dealer segment of the art market, and insurer Axa Art estimates $3 billion worth of works will be on view.

site_title: Pieces of missing EgyptAir plane found: investigators
summary: Egyptian investigators have found pieces of the missing EgyptAir plane's cabin, which crashed into the Mediterranean in May, in a French vessel's search. The Airbus A320 was en route from Paris to Cairo, resulting in the loss of 66 lives. Investigators believe the area of the crash site is approximately 3,000m deep and were warned that the plane's black boxes would stop emitting signals by the end of June. A terror attack has not been ruled out, but the cause of the disaster remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Pieces of the cabin from the missing EgyptAir plane which crashed into the Mediterranean last month have been found, Egyptian investigators said on Wednesday.

site_title: Nike, Adidas replace big-name luxury as China goes casual
summary: Chinese consumers are shifting away from luxury brands and towards Western sports brands like Nike and Adidas due to concerns about the political implications of purchases. Sales of these brands have surged, with Nike's Greater China sales increasing 27-35% and Adidas' sales growing 38% to 2.47 billion euros. The Chinese government's campaign to reduce conspicuous consumption of luxury goods has led to a decline in sales of Pernod Ricard, Hugo Boss, and BMW. As a result, domestic sportswear brands are struggling, with Peak Sport and Wisdom Sports experiencing flat same-store sales and share price drops.

site_title: CMA-PSA venture to operate four mega berths at Pasir Panjang
summary: CMA CGM and PSA Singapore Terminals Pte Ltd formed a joint venture, CMA CGM-PSA Lion Terminal Pte Ltd, to operate four mega container berths at Pasir Panjang Terminal in Singapore. The venture, starting operations in the second half of 2016, aims to better serve mega vessels in the region. The expansion will leverage infrastructure and technologies at the latest Pasir Panjang expansion, providing capacity and scale for mega vessels.

site_title: Vantablack is the world's blackest black material
summary: Vantablack, the world's blackest black material, absorbs over 99.965% of light, rendering 3D objects as silhouettes. Developed by Surrey Nanosystems, it's made from carbon nanotubes grown in a clean room using proprietary technology. Initially for the aerospace industry, its applications now include space, art, and potentially other fields, due to its unique properties. The material is extremely sensitive and requires direct application by Surrey Nanosystems, limiting its uses.

site_title: UK's real estate woes run deeper than Brexit
summary: The UK's commercial property market is experiencing a slowdown, with investors spending £16.9 billion from January to May, down from a record £33 billion last year. The slowdown is attributed to various risks, including a possible return of Europe's debt crisis, faster US interest rates, and a decline in Chinese economic growth. Experts suggest the market is entering a natural decline phase, with prices and rental income expected to slow down, but not collapse. The Brexit vote may further impact the market, with demand for London office space expected to fall.

site_title: MDA seeks proposals for two FM frequencies
summary: The Media Development Authority (MDA) of Singapore has launched a public tender for two FM frequencies, 89.3 and 96.3, to operate commercial or not-for-profit radio stations. The FM 89.3 spectrum is vacant, while FM 96.3, currently occupied by Expat Radio 96.3 XFM, will be vacated by September 2016. Proposals are due to be submitted, with the goal of increasing radio options in the country.

images.alt_text: The Media Development Authority (MDA) has launched a public tender to seek proposals to operate commercial or not-for-profit radio stations on two FM frequencies - FM 89.3 and FM 96.3.

site_title: Shell CEO faces long haul in bid to pass Exxon as top oil major
summary: Royal Dutch Shell CEO Ben Van Beurden aims to surpass Exxon Mobil Corp as the top oil major by increasing free cash flow per share and improving returns. Shell plans to cap annual capital investment at $30 billion and slow new investments in liquefied natural gas to boost cash flows. The company aims to generate $20-25 billion of free cash flow by 2020, which could help it maintain its dividend payout. However, it may take years for Shell to catch up with Exxon in terms of return on capital, assets, and cash flow.

site_title: CFOs need to keep their house and conscience in order
summary: CFOs face immense pressure to meet financial targets while being scrutinized for individual culpability in corporate misconduct. A recent survey found that 36% of CFOs admitted to rationalizing unethical conduct to improve financial performance, while 16% of finance team members below the CFO would engage in cash payments to win or retain business. As global authorities crack down on fraud, bribery, and corruption, Singapore companies may be exposed to fraud risk liabilities overseas, highlighting the need for CFOs to prioritize due diligence, whistleblowing channels, and technology to detect fraud risk.

site_title: Twitter invests US$70m in SoundCloud music service
summary: Twitter invests approximately $70 million in SoundCloud, a music streaming service, to support creators and attract more users. The investment, made through Twitter Ventures, aims to provide needed funds for SoundCloud, which has struggled with losses despite its popularity. This deal may help Twitter clarify its approach to the entertainment industry, where it has faced challenges in the past. SoundCloud has established itself as a platform for new music and has introduced a subscription service with over 125 million songs available.

site_title: Osborne warns austerity budget unavoidable if Brexit occurs
summary: UK Chancellor George Osborne has warned that an austerity budget will be necessary if the UK leaves the EU, citing a £30 billion budget deficit. Osborne, in conjunction with former Labour Chancellor Alistair Darling, suggests tax rises and spending cuts to reduce the deficit. This comes amid uncertainty surrounding the UK's Brexit plans.

site_title: Gawker Media readies for auction after filing for bankruptcy
summary: Gawker Media, a digital media company, has filed for bankruptcy after losing a high-profile lawsuit to Hulk Hogan. The company is seeking to sell its assets by early August, with an auction proposed for July 29. Internet firm Ziff Davis has agreed to assume some liabilities and pay an opening bid of $90 million, but not the $130 million damages awarded to Hogan. Gawker founder Nick Denton will remain a consultant if Ziff Davis wins the auction.

site_title: Clinton wins final 2016 primary as debate turns to terror fight
summary: Hillary Clinton won the final 2016 Democratic primary in Washington, D.C., capturing nearly 79% of the vote against Bernie Sanders' 21%. This marks a shift in the presidential race to her showdown with Republican candidate Donald Trump. The outcome comes after a series of debates focused on national security, including the fight against terrorism. Clinton's victory sets the stage for her eventual matchup with Trump in the general election.

site_title: Closer ties between Scoot and Tiger vital for success
summary: Scoot and Tiger Airways, under a single holding company Budget Aviation Holdings, are expected to merge, driving down costs and increasing integration between the two budget carriers. The new management team, led by Tiger's former CEO Lee Lik Hsin, aims to overcome challenges and push for deeper integration. A full merger is complicated due to individual air operator certificates, but a partnership is crucial for success, with Scoot relying on connecting traffic from Tiger to fill its seats as it expands its network. The merged carriers will account for 42% of LCC seat capacity out of Singapore by October.

site_title: YuuZoo signs deal to run SME e-commerce platform in Nigeria
summary: YuuZoo, a Singapore-based social e-commerce network, has signed an agreement with Etisalat to launch SME Arena, an e-commerce platform in Nigeria. The platform will allow SMEs to market and sell products to Etisalat's 24 million Nigerian subscribers. YuuZoo has bought out its franchisee's contract rights, taking full control of the platform, and will now retain 100% revenue. This marks a new revenue stream for YuuZoo and opens opportunities for expansion to other African and Middle Eastern markets.

site_title: CIMB lays off 12 from Singapore broking business
summary: CIMB has laid off 12 staff from its Singapore broking business, mostly from back-end support functions, amid a dull period for the Singapore equity market. The move is part of the bank's efforts to reduce costs and remain nimble in the face of deteriorating capital markets. This is not the first time CIMB has cut jobs, with around 3,000 employees leaving under a group voluntary retrenchment scheme in Malaysia and Indonesia. The bank's CEO has stated that the company is not cutting jobs in these markets.

site_title: Private housing rents down in May, those for HDB stay flat: SRX
summary: Singapore's private non-landed home rents dropped 0.6% in May, while HDB flats saw no change. The divergence in trends is attributed to liquidity surplus and economic slowdown. Analysts predict prices will continue to rise due to liquidity, while rents may remain stable due to tenant demand. The rental decline for private homes has been significant, with a 16.5% drop from 2013, while HDB rents have increased 5.2% from 2015.

images.alt_text: SRX Property figures showed an overall 16.5 per cent rental fall in private non-landed homes from the peak in January 2013 and a 5.2 per cent drop from May 2015.

site_title: QE policies need a rethink after failure to achieve goals
summary: Central banks' policies are under scrutiny due to their failure to achieve economic goals. Effective monetization, where central banks directly underwrite government bonds, is happening in Japan and the eurozone, but not in the US. This practice, considered unconventional, limits central banks' control over their assets. As a result, they must acquire assets without control, hindering their ability to influence the economy. The lack of transparency in this practice has led to criticism and calls for a rethink of central banks' policies.

site_title: Market wards off fifth straight loss
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 5.92 points to 2,774.25 on Wednesday, marking a fifth consecutive decline, as a firm opening in Europe offset weak local trading. The rebound was attributed to short-covering rather than genuine buying, with a net 170 gains versus 193 falls in the broad market. The STI's decline is largely due to concerns over the UK's June 23 referendum on EU membership, which could lead to currency and stock market volatility.

site_title: Brexit camp seems to have the edge - or does it?
summary: Britain's exit from the European Union, known as Brexit, appears to be gaining momentum as public opinion shifts towards "Leave the EU" ahead of the June 23 referendum. Polls show a 47-44% margin in favor of "Leave" over "Remain," with some surveys indicating a wider gap. Experts warn that a Brexit victory could lead to economic instability, a sell-off in stock markets, and a potential breakup of the EU. Despite this, bookmakers' odds suggest that Remain will still prevail, with some experts believing an automatic correcting mechanism may trigger a backlash against Brexit.

site_title: One year of aid, but little progress in Nepal
summary: Nepal's one-year anniversary of the 2015 earthquake has brought little progress in physical rebuilding and governance system improvement. Despite international aid totaling $4.4 billion, only $2.8 billion has been received, with "very little" spent. Bureaucratic bumbling and a lack of political will have hindered aid distribution, and the Nepalese government's response has been slow. The country faces significant challenges, including inadequate disaster preparedness, poor governance, and economic decline, with tourism and economic growth projected to remain low. The international community must apply consistent pressure on the government to commit to comprehensive development and reform.

site_title: US accounting body to unveil new bank-reserves standard
summary: The US accounting regulator, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB), is set to release new rules on loan-loss reserves for banks, aiming to reduce the likelihood of investors being blindsided by bad loans. The new standard requires banks to estimate costs as soon as a loan is made, rather than waiting for credit quality to deteriorate. However, analysts warn that the estimates will be highly subjective and influenced by individual bankers' forecasts, potentially leading to inconsistent results.

site_title: Facilities manager and maid agency planning Catalist debut
summary: Advancer Global, a maid agency, cleaning and security services firm, has lodged a preliminary prospectus for a Catalist listing. The company reported a net profit of S$4.4 million in 2015 on S$45 million of revenue, up from S$2.6 million in 2014 on S$39 million of revenue. This marks the debut of facilities manager and maid agency planning Catalist listing for Advancer Global.

site_title: S-E Asian firms cut US$ debt to cushion against crisis
summary: S-E Asian firms are cutting US dollar bond offerings to reduce debt costs amid concerns of US currency appreciation. Bond sales decreased 50% to $7.9 billion in 2016, while local currency issuance rose 14% to $30.5 billion. Companies are shifting to local currency notes to manage currency risks, which were a catalyst of the 1997 Asian financial crisis. Strategists predict a decline in regional currencies, particularly Malaysia's ringgit and Indonesia's rupiah, driven by Fed rate increases.

site_title: Virgin Australia welcomes new Chinese stakeholders with cash call
summary: Virgin Australia, backed by five airlines, raised A$852 million in fresh capital through a rights issue, selling new stock at 21 Australian cents apiece for existing shareholders. The airline plans to use the funds to trim its fleet, cut costs, and generate free cash flow by 2019. Despite generating negative returns on equity in four of the past five years, Virgin Australia has outlined a three-year plan to address its debt issue and deleverage its balance sheet. The airline will issue additional new shares to Chinese investors, including HNA Group and Nanshan Group, to take their stakes to 19.99% and 20%.

site_title: Crown Resorts may split assets as cushion against Macau slump
summary: Crown Resorts Ltd, Australia's No 1 casino company, is considering splitting most of its domestic assets into a new listed company to cushion them from Macau's business slump. The company plans to set up a new listed property trust for its Melbourne and Perth hotels, and demerge its international investments into a separate listed firm. This move aims to protect domestic operations from the impact of Macau's decline.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: UG Healthcare Corp is valued at 16 times 2017 forecast earnings, with a potential target price of S$0.33. Global Invacom is expected to benefit from a partnership to deploy VSATs to an Indonesian customer, with a target price of S$0.28. Soilbuild Reit has a yield of 9.1% and a quality portfolio, making it an attractive laggard play among peers, with a target price of S$0.84.

site_title: (Amended) April retail sales sans cars down 3 per cent
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 3.8% in April from a year ago, mainly driven by a 43% increase in motor vehicle sales. However, excluding motor vehicles, sales fell 3% and 0.1% on a year-on-year and seasonally adjusted basis, respectively. Economists attribute the decline to cautious discretionary spending due to a poor economic outlook, with the World Bank downgrading global growth forecasts and Singapore's economic growth showing signs of slowing.

site_title: Who is winning the digital wars in Asia-Pacific?
summary: Local and regional companies in the Asia-Pacific region are embracing digital transformation to meet growing ambitions of becoming global. By 2025, emerging technologies such as the mobile Internet and cloud technology are expected to drive 30% GDP growth in South-east Asia, 20-30% in India, and up to 22% in China. 60% of global companies are undergoing digital transformation, with 75% of local and 64% of regional companies planning to embark on the journey in the next 12-24 months. Companies believe digital will fundamentally change their business models over the next 3-5 years.

site_title: Deal-making excitement builds up in Myanmar
summary: Myanmar is poised for a foreign investment takeoff following the easing of US sanctions in May, with the Asian Development Bank predicting economic growth of over 8% for this year and next. The country's new investment law may increase foreign buyer appeal, and approved foreign investment increased 18.4% to $9.48 billion in the year ending March 31, 2016. Several companies, including Colgate-Palmolive and Kirin Holdings, have already invested in Myanmar, and private equity firms like TPG Capital are scouting for deals in sectors such as banking and consumer businesses.

site_title: Economists pare Singapore's 2016 growth forecast - again
summary: Singapore's full-year growth forecast has been pared for the fifth consecutive time, with private-sector economists now expecting 1.8% growth, down from 1.9% in March. The latest downgrade is attributed to sluggish external conditions, difficulties in the finance and insurance sectors, and a contraction in non-oil domestic exports. Economists warn that more cuts could be in store, citing concerns over the manufacturing sector's growth and the impact of China's structural slowdown.

site_title: India challenging Musk, Bezos with record satellite launch
summary: India's space agency plans to launch a record 22 satellites on June 20, competing with commercial spaceflight companies run by Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos. The launch will include satellites from the US, India, Canada, and Germany, and will demonstrate India's ability to compete in the growing satellite launch industry. India aims to reduce costs and increase its share of the global market, which is expected to surge due to increasing demand for satellite services.

site_title: Making a low-carbon economy profitable for all
summary: The Paris Agreement on climate change, adopted by 175 parties in 2015, sets a framework for transitioning to low-carbon, climate-resilient economies. The agreement aims to reduce carbon emissions and curb global temperature rise. Non-governmental actors, including businesses and investors, have launched numerous initiatives to support this transition, such as the Portfolio Decarbonisation Coalition and the Breakthrough Energy Coalition. The financial sector has also begun to take responsibility, with many companies committing to integrate carbon pricing into their strategies. To make the transition profitable for all, increased collaborations and partnerships between the private and public sectors are necessary to drive down costs and catalyze the transition.

site_title: Yen, Swiss franc slip as Brexit fears abate
summary: The yen and Swiss franc lost ground on June 15, 2016, as concerns over the Brexit referendum temporarily eased. Investors remained cautious ahead of a Federal Reserve policy decision. A poll showed the "Remain" camp leading in the EU referendum, but uncertainty kept markets on edge.

site_title: ChemChina, New Hope, considering China McDonald's franchise rights: sources
summary: China National Chemical Corp and New Hope Group Co are considering bids for McDonald's operations in mainland China, with buyout firm KKR & Co potentially teaming up with a Chinese firm to make a joint bid. The mainland China franchise rights could fetch about $2 billion.
