The changes are part of Apple's strategy to increase software income and compete with technology giants like Amazon and Google.

site_title: Thousands rally in New York for Orlando victims
summary: Thousands of people gathered in New York's Greenwich Village to honor the 49 victims of the Orlando nightclub shooting, calling for tighter gun control and tolerance of LGBTQ+ rights. The rally, organized by the LGBT community, featured speakers condemning Islamophobia and a ban on assault weapons. Mayor Bill de Blasio paid tribute to the victims, including a nursing school student from Brooklyn, and urged Americans to join the city's Gay Pride parade on June 26. The event came two days after mourners laid flowers and paid tribute to the dead at The Stonewall Inn, considered the birthplace of the modern gay rights movement.

site_title: Changjiang in Tagore 8 RTO deal
summary: Changjiang Fertiliser Holdings is set to acquire a 50% stake in Tagore 8, a light industrial building in Singapore, from CTE Resources for S$9.674 million. Changjiang will issue over 580 million shares and pay S$6.7 million in cash. Tagore 8 has sold 110 units out of 130, with 18 unsold units. The acquisition is expected to be completed by October 1, 2016, and is subject to SGX approval and Changjiang's shareholder approval.

site_title: Israel for the first time wins UN committee chair
summary: Israel won the chair of the UN's legal affairs committee for the first time in its 71-year history, receiving 109 votes. The election was triggered by Arab countries and Palestinians, who criticized the choice of Israeli Ambassador Danny Danon as divisive and unworthy. The US and European countries supported Israel's candidacy, with Ambassador Khaled Alyemany of Yemen's Arab Group protesting the election, stating that Israel is a violator of international law.

site_title: Trump bans Washington Post from his campaign events
summary: Donald Trump has revoked the press credentials of The Washington Post, citing inaccurate coverage and a focus on "clicks" over journalistic integrity. The move comes after a Post story reported Trump's comments on President Barack Obama's leadership in battling extremism. Trump's campaign has also banned several news organizations from attending his events, including BuzzFeed, the Des Moines Register, and Univision. The Post's executive editor Martin Baron said the paper will continue to cover Trump "honorably, honestly, accurately, energetically and unflinchingly."

site_title: EgyptAir black box signals will soon cease: inquiry
summary: EgyptAir's Airbus A320 crashed into the Mediterranean on May 19, killing all 66 people on board, with the cause still unknown. The black box signals will cease operating in 11 days, until June 24. The investigation, led by Egypt's civil aviation ministry, has agreed to US participation and has confirmed the aircraft made a 90-degree left turn before disappearing from radar screens. Initial suspicions of an attack have been replaced with a possible technical fault, with automatic alerts indicating smoke in the cabin and a fault in the flight control unit.

site_title: Scientists discover giant new planet orbiting two suns
summary: Scientists have discovered a giant new planet, Kepler-1647 b, orbiting two stars using the Kepler space telescope. The gaseous planet, the size of Jupiter, takes 1,107 days to revolve around its two stars, making it potentially habitable for humans. This discovery was announced at the American Astronomical Society meeting in San Diego, California.

site_title: Belgian hospitals introduce robot receptionists
summary: Belgian hospitals have introduced robot receptionists, Pepper and Nao, to assist patients and staff. Pepper, a humanoid robot, is the first to be used in a medical setting, greeting patients in 20 languages and detecting their age. The robots, developed by Zora Bots, will be used in hospitals in Ostend and Liege to support patients in the pediatric and geriatric departments. The robots are a step forward in using technology to improve patient care and are part of a growing trend of robots being used in healthcare settings.

site_title: Trump, Clinton clash in wake of Orlando attack
summary: US presidential rivals Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump clashed over their approaches to tackling terrorism and extremism in the wake of the Orlando massacre, which was the worst terror attack in the US since 9/11. Clinton urged Americans to reject demagoguery and instead focus on fighting Islamic State extremism, while Trump proposed suspending immigration from countries with a proven history of terrorism and called for stricter gun control. The starkly different tones highlighted the widening gap between the two candidates on how to keep Americans safe.

site_title: Yen rises across the board on Brexit worries
summary: The yen rose against the euro and sterling due to Brexit concerns, reaching a three-year peak against the euro and a six-week high versus the US dollar. The US dollar struggled, influenced by uncertainty about the Federal Open Market Committee policy meeting, while sterling fell to a three-year low. Britain's "Out" campaign led in opinion polls ahead of the June 23 referendum, raising concerns about the impact on the global economy.

site_title: Singapore achieves self reliance in water, sees demand doubling
summary: Singapore has achieved self-reliance in water, meeting its daily demand of 400-420 million imperial gallons, despite relying on neighboring Malaysia for over half its supply. The city-state is building capacity to meet a projected doubling in demand by 2061, with plans for new water recycling and desalination plants. Expanded catchment areas and water recycling have helped overcome shortfalls from Malaysia, with Singapore now able to mitigate for shortfalls and meet demand even during dry weather.

site_title: Obama says no evidence Orlando killer directed from overseas
summary: US President Barack Obama stated that the Orlando nightclub shooter, Omar Mateen, was inspired by extremist propaganda but had no evidence of being directed from overseas or part of a larger group. Mateen was a homegrown terrorist who obtained the weapons used in the shooting legally due to no criminal record. Obama called for stricter gun controls and ensuring it's not easy for people to obtain guns. Senate Democrats proposed an amendment to prohibit people on the terrorist watch list from purchasing guns and explosives.

site_title: America's gun control debate deadlocks after Florida carnage
summary: A mass shooting in Orlando, Florida, has reignited the US gun control debate, with President Barack Obama calling for stricter gun laws. The deadliest mass shooting in US history, 49 people were killed and 53 injured. Gun control advocates and politicians, including Hillary Clinton, are pushing for curbs on assault rifles and background checks. However, a Republican-led Congress and the powerful gun lobby have stifled efforts to curb gun violence since 2008. Experts say the deadlock is unlikely to end, with gun control a hot-button issue in the upcoming election year.

images.alt_text: The deadliest mass shooting in US history has once again unleashed gun control advocates clamoring for curbs on weapons sales.

site_title: China's Midea seeking 49% Kuka stake: report
summary: China's Midea Group Co Ltd is reportedly seeking a 49% stake in German industrial robot maker Kuka, sparking debate over Chinese acquisitions in Europe. Chancellor Angela Merkel expressed openness to Chinese investments, but emphasized the need for equal investment conditions. In a proposed deal, Kuka would retain a strong German anchor shareholder, and CEO Till Reuter would support such a solution. The German Economy Ministry declined comment, while Kuka did not immediately respond to requests for comment. The move has fanned concerns over the impact of Chinese ownership on European industries.

site_title: Football fans jailed in France over Euro 2016 unrest
summary: A French prosecutor said 150 "extremely well-prepared" Russian hooligans evaded arrest in the Marseille fan battles before the England-Russia Euro 2016 match, targeting English fans in an "orchestrated" campaign of violence. Two British men and a French man were jailed for their part in the violence, while another English fan remains in critical condition. Assistant chief constable Mark Roberts accused Russian hooligans of staging the violence, and tensions remain high ahead of England's next match in Lille.

site_title: MSCI is about to make its big call on world's worst stock market
summary: MSCI Inc is set to announce on Wednesday whether to include China's domestic equities in its global benchmark gauges, a move that could bring in $30 billion in investments. The Shanghai Composite Index has lost 45% in the past year, with concerns over market accessibility and liquidity. The decision comes after MSCI has considered inclusion since 2013, with authorities taking steps to address concerns. A 3.2% selloff on Monday suggests traders doubt officials have done enough to address issues, despite a more subdued volatility level compared to last year.

site_title: Oil falls on prospects of rising output in Canada, Africa
summary: Oil prices fell Monday, driven by expectations of stronger production in North America and Africa, as well as tepid global demand growth. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropped 19 US cents to $48.88 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude fell 19 US cents to $50.35 a barrel. Rising uncertainty about Britain's EU vote and a US interest rate decision also contributed to market caution. Canadian oil production is expected to slowly recover, while OPEC forecasts that excess supply in the market will ease over the coming quarters.

site_title: Law enforcement released Orlando shooter after finding no threat
summary: US law enforcement released Omar Mateen, the Orlando shooter, after finding no threat, despite interviewing him twice in 2013 and 2014. Mateen killed 49 people using an assault weapon and handgun, claiming allegiance to Islamic State. Officials say the FBI can only continue investigations when a threat to lives is considered significant, citing lack of evidence and resources. The attack highlights the challenge of detecting lone terrorists without eroding civil liberties, and the need for coordination between the FBI and local police.

site_title: Amazon fined by US FAA for shipping dangerous cargo on planes
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has fined Amazon $350,000 for shipping a hazardous chemical, corrosive drain cleaner, to a UPS facility without proper packaging, declaration, and labeling. This is the second violation in two years, with the company having previously broken hazardous materials regulations 24 times. The FAA also found that Amazon failed to train employees on handling hazardous materials and did not include emergency response information on the package. Amazon has been expanding its air-shipping network as part of its efforts to reduce dependence on UPS and FedEx.

site_title: Uber offers helicopters to escape Sao Paulo gridlock
summary: Uber launches a month-long pilot program offering on-demand helicopter rides in Sao Paulo, Brazil, with prices starting at US$20. The service connects four airports and five helipads, aiming to reduce travel time and alleviate traffic congestion. The program is Uber's biggest step in a partnership with Airbus Group and follows similar experiments at music festivals. Spanish rival Cabify plans to offer helicopter rides in Sao Paulo by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: For commuters who imagine soaring above Sao Paulo's notorious traffic jams, ride-hailing app Uber is offering to make that daydream a reality, starting at around US$20.

site_title: "Out" camp widens lead over "In" ahead of UK's EU referendum: ICM
summary: Britain's "Out" campaign has widened its lead over the "In" camp ahead of the June 23 EU referendum, with two opinion polls showing 53% support for "Out" and 47% for "In". This marks a 1% increase from two weeks ago, when the split was 52-48 in favour of "Out". The polls were conducted by ICM, and the results indicate a significant shift in public opinion in favour of leaving the EU.

images.alt_text: Britain's "Out" campaign has widened its lead over the "In" camp ahead of the country's June 23 referendum on its membership of the European Union, two opinion polls published by ICM showed on Monday.

site_title: US: Stocks fall for 3rd day as global selloff mounts
summary: US stocks fell for the third consecutive day as a global equities selloff mounted, driven by concerns over a potential British exit of the European Union. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.8%. Microsoft's acquisition of LinkedIn boosted the technology sector, with LinkedIn surging 46.6%. Other tech shares were mixed, with Apple, Facebook, and Celgene experiencing declines, while Twitter rose 3.8%. The decline was also driven by travel-oriented shares, which fell due to concerns over gun violence.

site_title: Orlando shooting sparks horror around world, fear for the US
summary: World leaders and public figures have expressed horror and sympathy for the victims of the Orlando shooting, with many condemning the attack as a "heinous" act of terrorism. The shooting has sparked a global outpouring of support, with cities around the world holding vigils and rallies in solidarity. Many countries, including Singapore, Pakistan, and Afghanistan, have strongly condemned the attack, with some leaders calling for increased action against radical groups. The tragedy has also raised tensions in the US presidential election campaign, with some politicians using the incident to stigmatize certain groups.

site_title: Goldman accused of using gifts to influence Libya officials
summary: Goldman Sachs is accused of using gifts, including Moroccan vacations and hiring prostitutes, to influence Libyan Investment Authority (LIA) officials, leading to a $1.2 billion loss. The bank's relationship with LIA employees was described as "unsophisticated" and exploitative, with Goldman making $367.7 million in gross profits from trades that ultimately led to the loss. Goldman denies wrongdoing, claiming the losses were due to market movements and the LIA's lack of experience with derivatives. The case is set to proceed in London's High Court.

site_title: CMA CGM to delist NOL: French paper
summary: CMA CGM, the world's third-largest container shipping company, plans to delist Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) after acquiring 78% of NOL shares in a $2.4 billion deal. Minority shareholders can sell their shares until July 18. Once CMA CGM holds 90% of NOL shares, the company will be delisted. The move is part of CMA CGM's strategy to expand its operations and cope with a severe market downturn. The company also plans $1 billion in asset sales and cost-cutting measures, and will launch a new operational alliance with Chinese, Taiwanese, and Hong Kong shipping firms in April 2017.

site_title: QIA said to be seeking US$2b loan to finance Singapore purchase
summary: Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) is seeking a US$2 billion loan to finance its acquisition of BlackRock Inc's Asia Square Tower 1 in Singapore for S$3.4 billion. This marks the largest office transaction in Singapore. QIA has held preliminary talks with banks, with the loan amount between US$1.5 billion and US$2 billion. The sovereign wealth fund has invested heavily in property worldwide, including office transactions and hotels. Talks with lenders are at an early stage, and the timeline for the borrowing has not been finalized.

site_title: Brexit's first 100 days promise chaos, fear, damage limitation
summary: The UK's exit from the EU, following a historic Brexit vote, poses significant challenges for European authorities. The EU lacks a clear plan, and officials are advised not to create scenarios to avoid alarming leaks. Global markets are already experiencing volatility, with currency markets not yet pricing in the UK's potential exit. European leaders are preparing for a potential "gradual disintegration" of the EU, with some considering a response that could include deeper integration or a declaration of the EU's dream remaining alive. The EU's leaders may also consider calling an emergency summit without British representation to discuss the implications and potential consequences of the UK's departure.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit three-month low on Brexit angst
summary: European shares fell to a three-month low, dropping 1.9% on Monday, amid uncertainty over a possible British exit from the European Union. Cyclical stocks, such as autos and banks, were the biggest fallers. Investors are positioning for central bank meetings this week and the June 23 EU referendum, with some fund managers focusing on market fundamentals and not getting distracted by the referendum noise. The US Federal Reserve is also expected to hold monetary policy steady.

site_title: Twitter jumps as Microsoft-LinkedIn deal could spur more
summary: Twitter's stock jumped 6.3% to $14.90 after Microsoft's $26.2 billion acquisition of LinkedIn, prompting speculation about other tech companies being acquisition targets. The deal, which gives Microsoft a 50% premium for LinkedIn, suggests that larger companies are willing to pay for younger ones like Twitter or Yelp. Analysts say the deal makes Twitter a more attractive target, with Alphabet Inc being the most obvious acquirer. The deal also indicates a healthier market for mergers and acquisitions, with Goldman Sachs listing LinkedIn and Twitter as potential targets.

site_title: Brexit sends Danish 30-year mortgage costs below US Treasuries
summary: Denmark's 30-year mortgage costs have fallen below US Treasuries due to the Brexit vote, which has led investors to seek refuge in safe markets. The shift in investor sentiment has resulted in lower mortgage rates for Danish homebuyers, offering a competitive advantage over the US.

site_title: Want your say in an election abroad? Go vote online
summary: A platform called The Global Vote (www.globalvote.org) was launched in London, allowing individuals to vote online in foreign elections and global issues. The platform's first poll will be the UK's European Union Referendum on June 23, followed by elections in Iceland and Sao Tome. The initiative aims to promote global collaboration and responsibility by giving people a "dual mandate" to contribute to the common good of humanity, regardless of their nationality. The platform's creator, Simon Anholt, believes that when more people outside a country vote than its citizens, it will be a "tipping point" for a more globally responsible society.

site_title: Happy 90th, Your Majesty
summary: Thousands of Britons gathered outside Buckingham Palace to celebrate Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday, marking the occasion with a giant street party despite rainy weather. The event featured a hamper-style picnic, cups of tea, and high spirits. The celebration was a testament to the British people's resilience and dedication to their monarch.

site_title: Cordlife names Wong Chiang Yin as new CEO
summary: Cordlife Group has appointed medical doctor and public health specialist Wong Chiang Yin, 48, as its new CEO, succeeding Jeremy Yee. Wong brings a medical professional background and network in the healthcare industry to the role. He previously served as executive director of TMC Life Sciences and president of Thomson International. Cordlife's senior director of corporate development Jona-than Liau Yen San has resigned to pursue other opportunities, and the company's shares ended trading 3.5 Singapore cents lower at S$1.295.

site_title: Independent Chinese oil firms on hiring spree
summary: China's independent oil companies, known as "teapots," are luring traders and risk managers away from state-owned companies with better pay and perks. The hiring spree is triggered by China's freeing up of its crude import trade, with independent refiners processing up to a fifth of China's crude imports. Global oil firms and trading houses are also hiring staff from state giants to handle the influx of crude. The talent exodus has already seen over 40 traders and others switch jobs, with many joining trading houses and majors for better perks and salaries.

images.alt_text: China's independent "teapot" refiners, so called due to their small size, could be processing by the end of this year as much as a fifth of the crude imports of the world's No 2 oil consumer.

site_title: When push comes to stove
summary: Chef Christophe Megel, a young chef in 1994, landed a private chef gig for Samsung's chairman. However, his uniform at the laundrette read "Foreign chef," sparking amusement. Megel went on to establish his food consultancy, A-munition, which helps chefs succeed in the industry.

site_title: Tougher times ahead for high-yield bankers in Asia
summary: Asia's high-yield debt specialists face a tougher time justifying their jobs as investment banks reduce product-specific roles due to a sharp slowdown in high-yield corporate bond sales. Sales in Asia ex-Japan plummeted to $4 billion from $16.8 billion in 2013, with financings for junk-rated companies declining. Although activity is expected to pick up in the second half, bankers remain cautious, with some considering job changes or reduced roles.

site_title: Q3 hiring prospects to be worst since last recession
summary: Employers in Singapore are expecting a "more conservative" hiring pace in the next three months, with hiring prospects at their weakest since the last recession. A survey by ManpowerGroup Singapore found the net employment outlook has slipped to a seasonally-adjusted plus 9%, the lowest since 2009. Only 11% of employers plan to increase staff, while 74% keep hiring flat. The finance, insurance, and real estate sectors are expected to be the biggest recruiters, with a net employment outlook of plus 16%.

images.alt_text: The pace of hiring is tipped to be "more conservative" in the next three months, with hiring prospects at their weakest since the last recession, according to ManpowerGroup Singapore's latest survey.

site_title: Job openings still outnumber job seekers, but only barely (Amended)
summary: Singapore's jobless rate for citizens and permanent residents decreased to 2.7% in Q1, a slight improvement from Q4's 2.9%. Despite this, job openings still outnumber job seekers, and redundancies fell to 4,710. Total employment increased by 13,000, but the unemployment rate for residents aged 50 and over rose to 2.2%, the highest in four quarters. Long-term unemployment also increased, with the share of long-term unemployed residents rising to 26%.

site_title: Saudi Electricity invites global bids for solar plants
summary: Saudi Electricity Co. has invited global bids for two solar-power plants in the northern region of Saudi Arabia, each generating up to 50 megawatts. The plants will be located at Al-Jouf and Rafha and are part of the country's efforts to scale back its renewable energy ambitions and diversify its energy supply. Saudi Arabia aims to generate 9,500 megawatts of renewable energy by 2030, with solar power expected to account for only 10% of total power capacity. International companies are invited to submit expressions of interest by June 20.

site_title: Patient satisfaction up in 2015, says MOH
summary: Patient satisfaction with public healthcare institutions in Singapore rose to 85.9% in 2015, up from 79.1% in 2014, according to the Ministry of Health's annual Patient Satisfaction Survey. Khoo Teck Puat Hospital emerged as the top hospital with 90.8% approval, while the Institute of Mental Health topped specialist centres with 94.1% satisfaction. The National Healthcare Group's polyclinics saw an 11-point leap in satisfaction, with Bukit Batok, Clementi, and Yishun polyclinics ranking among the best.

site_title: Oil giants seeking new gas markets to absorb rapidly growing supply
summary: Energy giants Royal Dutch Shell and Total are investing billions in downstream markets, such as power plants, pipelines, and storage terminals, to absorb the rapidly growing supply of liquefied natural gas (LNG). The companies aim to create new markets, including in Indonesia, Chile, and Africa, to triple their gas and power markets and raise their annual LNG output. However, analysts question the feasibility of this model, citing concerns about the companies' lack of experience in building small downstream demand.

site_title: Challenger shows the way for other Singapore retailers
summary: Singapore mega supermarket Challenger Technologies aims to boost e-commerce sales to 50% of group revenue within five years, with an initial target of $100 million this year. The company's e-commerce push, through its revamped portal hachi.tech, is set to capitalize on Singapore's growing e-commerce market, which is expected to reach $6.42 billion by 2020. With Alibaba's recent $1 billion investment in Lazada, the e-commerce market in Singapore and the region is becoming increasingly competitive, with only a few big players expected to dominate the general B2C and C2C marketplaces.

site_title: Singapore port notches year's first rise in box throughput
summary: Singapore's Port of Singapore experienced its first year-over-year rise in container throughput in May, with 2.665 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) handled, up from 2.622 million TEU in May 2015. The increase could signify normalizing containerized cargo flows after the implementation of shipping alliances 2M and Ocean 3 in 2015. Total cargo throughput also rose year-over-year, with oil and non-oil bulk shipments increasing month-over-month. Industry experts expect further growth in the second quarter.

site_title: Brazil crash out after Peru upset
summary: Brazil was eliminated from the Copa America Centenario after a refereeing blunder allowed Peru to win 1-0, despite Brazil needing a draw to qualify for the quarter-finals. A disputed goal by Raul Ruidiaz, who appeared to use his arm to score, was allowed to stand after a chaotic delay. Brazil coach Dunga criticized the decision, while Peru coach Ricardo Gareca defended his team's win. The defeat marks Brazil's worst performance in the tournament since 1987, with the team struggling to recover from a lacklustre group stage.

site_title: Yen surges against sterling, euro on Brexit fears
summary: The yen surged to a three-year high against the euro and sterling on Brexit fears, with investors seeking safe-haven assets amid concerns of a possible UK exit from the EU. The yen gained over 1% against the euro and 1.8% against sterling, and nearly 1% against the dollar. The Bank of Japan is set to meet on Wednesday, and market players are divided on whether the BOJ will intervene to weaken the yen. The yen's surge is seen as a sign of risk aversion and a shift away from riskier assets.

site_title: S Korean shipbuilders need 'bone-crushing' reform
summary: South Korea's President Park Geun Hye urges "bone-crushing" efforts to overhaul the nation's struggling shipbuilders, which have seen losses of 8.5 trillion won due to global demand slowdown and increased competition. The President warns of mass job cuts and an economic slump in the southern region, stating that failure to reform would lead to devastating economic consequences. The nation's Big Three shipbuilders, including Hyundai and Samsung, have racked up collective losses last year, and the government is offering financial assistance and job training for those laid off.

site_title: Vaping teens tend to move on to regular cigarettes, study finds
summary: A study published in Pediatrics found that older teens who try electronic cigarettes have six times the odds of trying regular cigarettes within two years compared to those who never vaped. Researchers based their findings on surveys of about 300 high school students in southern California, where nearly half had tried an e-cigarette by 2014. The study's lead author expressed concern that e-cigarette users may transition to more dangerous combustible cigarettes, echoing the American Academy of Pediatrics' 2015 recommendation to regulate e-cigarettes as tobacco products.

site_title: OKP bags 2 contracts worth S$54.7m
summary: OKP Holdings has secured two contracts worth S$54.7 million from the Land Transport Authority for road resurfacing works along seven major expressways in Singapore. The contracts, valued at S$64.5 million in total, will be completed by June 5, 2018. This boosts the company's net construction order book to S$376.8 million. OKP Holdings' shares closed at S$0.265, up 1.5 Singapore cents, following the contract awards.

site_title: Britain's trade options after Brexit - no easy way out
summary: Britain's potential post-Brexit trade options are uncertain, with the country's economy likely to suffer if it loses access to the EU's single market of over 500 million consumers. The "In" campaign argues that Britain would struggle to secure deals with non-EU countries, while the "Out" camp suggests the EU would do a deal with Britain due to its importance as an export market. Alternative options include a Canada-style deal, Norway's trade agreement, and bilateral deals with the EU, but these come with varying costs and limitations. A no-deal Brexit could lead to tariffs and non-tariff barriers, affecting sectors such as finance and automotive industries.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AIA acquired 457,000 Mapletree Industrial Trust units, increasing its stake to 5.01%. Pacific Radiance issued arbitration notices against two Chinese shipbuilders over cancelled contracts. Neo Group bought 55% of U-Market Place Enterprise for S$1.925 million. SMRT's subsidiary increased paid-up share capital to S$6 million. Ley Choon Group won a S$33.6 million water pipeline contract.

site_title: Microsoft buying LinkedIn for US$26.2b
summary: Microsoft has agreed to purchase LinkedIn for $26.2 billion, its largest-ever acquisition, in a move to refocus on cloud computing and services. LinkedIn will retain its brand and independence, with CEO Jeff Weiner remaining in charge. The deal aims to boost services for business and takes Microsoft into the social networking space. The acquisition comes after LinkedIn reported a loss of $46 million in the past quarter and seeks to expand its offerings with new messaging and mobile applications.

site_title: STI down as Brexit worries hit Asia
summary: The Hang Seng Index dropped 2.5% and the Nikkei plunged 3.5% due to Brexit worries affecting Asia's stock markets. The Straits Times Index fell 1.3% as selling pressure was triggered by the UK's potential exit from the European Union. The UK pound fell, and shares of three banks and other companies took a beating, contributing to the market's decline. The US Federal Open Market Committee meeting is also a concern, with some analysts predicting a September interest rate hike.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Deutsche Bank Markets Research has upgraded Sembcorp Marine (SMM) to a top buy, citing limited downside risks and higher upside potential due to its expertise in the deepwater space. The research firm replaced City Developments with SMM in its top buy list, citing the O&M sector as under-owned. Analysts also maintain a buy call on ARA Asset Management, raising its target price to S$1.76 due to its growth prospects in investments through private funds.

site_title: Japanese graffiti artists skirt constraints
summary: In Japan, traditional graffiti culture is hindered by a conformist society and strict laws, with artists facing up to five years in prison for defacing public property. However, local enthusiasts are trying to break through these constraints through "live painting" events, such as the Pow! Wow! Japan festival, which celebrates street art and brings together local and international artists. Despite the conservative attitude, some artists have found ways to promote "legal" graffiti through corporate collaborations, slowly shifting Japan's stance on artwork.

images.alt_text: Japanese street art is still a little behind Asia, Europe or America, says street artist Kohei Yamao, better known as BAKIBAKI.

site_title: Basslink resumes service after six-month outage
summary: Basslink, a subsidiary of Keppel Infrastructure Trust, has resumed electricity interconnector service between Tasmania and mainland Australia after a six-month outage. The interconnector resumed operation on June 13, exporting 112 MWh of power from Tasmina to Victoria. The outage, which began in December, has been attributed to a fault reported in the subsea power link. Examinations into fault diagnosis are still ongoing, but Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management believes the outage is a force majeure event covered by insurance, with estimated costs for Tasmania at least A$560 million.

site_title: Equity desks facing the axe as stocks underperform across Asia
summary: Asia's equity desks face significant pressure as stocks underperform, with turnover shrinking at the fastest pace since 2006. Banks are under pressure to downsize or exit the business, amidst a turbulent 12 months marked by China's stock market volatility and record-low volumes.

images.alt_text: At this time last year, the industry was riding high as China's stock market soared, volumes jumped to record highs and some of the biggest names in finance boosted hiring.

site_title: Japan's NYK to take 25% stake in Emas Chiyoda Subsea
summary: Japan's shipping giant Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK) is acquiring a 25% stake in Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS) from joint-venture partners Ezra Holdings and Chiyoda, valuing ECS at US$360 million. NYK will purchase 10% from Ezra for US$36 million, while Chiyoda will retain 35%. The deal aims to broaden NYK's exposure in the offshore segment and strengthen ECS' balance sheet. NYK brings expertise in ship finance and revenue of over US$22 billion, lending financial clout to ECS in bidding for large contracts.

images.alt_text: Japanese shipping giant Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK) is acquiring a 25 per cent stake in Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS) from the existing 50-50 joint-venture partners Ezra Holdings and Chiyoda.

site_title: Tharman calls for reforms to provide retirement security
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam warned that low interest rates will pose challenges to retirement security globally, citing increasing life expectancies and a global surplus of savings over investment. He called for reforms to make savings affordable for ordinary savers and proposed ideas such as making employment more attractive to the elderly, greater pooling of funds, and redesigning healthcare systems. Tharman also identified three new underwriting opportunities: infrastructure financing, catastrophe insurance, and cyber insurance, to lift returns despite low interest rates.

images.alt_text: Low interest rates are here to stay, and will pose challenges to retirement security globally, Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam warned on Monday.

site_title: Singapore real estate stocks offer shelter in down market
summary: Singapore-listed real estate companies have outperformed the broader market this year, with the SGX Real Estate 20 index gaining 1.3% compared to the Straits Times Index's -0.4%. Smaller components in the index, such as Yanlord Land Group and Keppel Reit, have seen significant gains, while diversified Reits have returned 11.6% year-to-date. This trend is attributed to the resilience of suburban mall space, but other property asset classes, such as office and industrial, are expected to face headwinds.

site_title: MAS tightens the screws on money laundering
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is strengthening its anti-money laundering efforts by setting up dedicated units to monitor and boost enforcement action against financial institutions. The new units will centralize existing regulatory work and bring together functions to monitor risks and carry out on-site supervision. This move follows the shutdown of BSI Bank in June for the worst case of gross misconduct, and aims to combat money laundering and illicit financing in the growing financial sector. The MAS will also enhance enforcement capability to deter poor controls or criminal behavior.

site_title: Wing Tai sells another apartment at Le Nouvel Ardmore for S$21m
summary: Wing Tai sold a seventh-floor unit at its Le Nouvel Ardmore condominium in Singapore for S$21 million, or S$4,006 per square foot, to an Indonesian buyer believed to be Trihatma Kusuma Haliman, the head of Agung Podomoro Land. The sale comes amid a bribery scandal involving the company's former president director, Ariesman Widjaja, who is being held by Indonesia's anti-graft agency. The unit is the sixth to be sold in the 43-unit project.

site_title: Ambition and Chinese hostility pushing India closer to US
summary: India is strengthening ties with the US, driven by China's hostile acts, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks to establish India as a leading global power. During his US visit, Modi pushed for institutionalizing the US-India rapport and sought US support on key issues like India's entry into the Nuclear Suppliers Group. The US House of Representatives has approved a bipartisan bill to enhance defense ties with India, and the two nations are collaborating on strategic projects. The US has declared its support for India's full membership in the NSG, but China's opposition is likely to continue, posing a challenge to Modi's efforts.

site_title: Why a US slowdown should worry you
summary: The US economy experienced a disappointing employment report in May, with only 38,000 jobs added, down from the 200,000-a-month average since 2013. The slowdown is attributed to a sharp rise in the dollar, which has made US goods less competitive on global markets. A recession is unlikely, but a prolonged slowdown could be challenging to address due to the current political gridlock. Fiscal stimulus, such as government spending on infrastructure or temporary tax cuts, is seen as the simplest and most effective solution, but its implementation is unlikely due to Republican opposition.

site_title: Changes in US election story not helping Clinton
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's nationalist message resonated with voters, particularly on issues of immigration and Islamic terrorism, during the primary campaign. However, a recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll suggests that Trump's populist economic agenda is gaining traction among blue-collar workers, who feel insecure about their jobs and the economy. Trump's campaign promises to punish China and other trade partners for "stealing American jobs" have won him support among this demographic. In contrast, Hillary Clinton faces challenges in connecting with voters on economic issues, with many viewing her as an elitist due to her ties to Wall Street and her husband's influence on her campaign.

site_title: A marginal vote for Brexit may trigger second referendum
summary: The UK's June 23 referendum on EU membership may trigger a second referendum if the outcome is highly uncertain. A strong "leave" vote (55% or more) could lead to Prime Minister David Cameron's resignation and a straightforward withdrawal process, but a marginal vote to leave (53% or less) may result in uncertainty, potentially leading to a second referendum. A new Conservative leader, such as Boris Johnson, may decide to call an early general election to secure a stronger mandate, or they may choose to trigger Article 50 and negotiate a withdrawal deal, which could be subject to parliamentary approval.

site_title: Ley Choon bags S$33.6m contract amid debt restructuring
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings, a construction contractor undergoing debt restructuring, has secured a S$33.6 million contract from the Public Utilities Board to supply and lay water pipelines from 2016 to 2019. The contract is part of the company's efforts to recover and stabilize its finances amid debt restructuring.

site_title: China home sales rise at slowest pace this year
summary: China's new home sales rose 32.9% to 773 billion yuan in May, the slowest pace this year, amid policymakers' efforts to cool the property market. This follows a 63.5% surge in April. The government aims to clear a glut of unsold homes in smaller cities and curb prices in top economic hubs, such as Shanghai and Shenzhen. Property-development investment growth slowed to 7% in the first five months of the year, and land purchases decreased 5.8% in May. The slowdown is expected to continue, with analysts forecasting slower home-sales growth.

site_title: Singapore emerges as top Asian investor in Japan
summary: Singapore has emerged as the top Asian investor in Japan, with over $21.82 billion (1.72 trillion yen) invested in the country as of 2014, according to the Invest Japan Report 2015. Although the US is the overall top foreign investor in Japan, Singapore ranks fifth among Japan's biggest foreign investors, behind the US, Netherlands, France, and the UK. The report highlights the growing investments from Asian economies, with China's investments increasing 29% year-over-year since 2000, and Singapore's investments largely in the finance and insurance industries.

site_title: Walgreens cuts ties to blood-testing firm Theranos
summary: US retailer Walgreens is terminating its relationship with blood-testing firm Theranos, closing all 40 of the testing centers in its Arizona drugstores. The decision comes after federal officials identified serious problems at Theranos' flagship lab and regulators rejected the company's plan of correction. Walgreens had partnered with Theranos in 2013, but the partnership has been marred by negative publicity and regulatory scrutiny. The move is seen as a blow to Theranos, which has struggled to establish credibility in the lab industry.

site_title: China fixed-asset investment growth slows in May; misses market expectations
summary: China's fixed-asset investment growth slowed to 9.6% in the first five months of the year, missing market expectations, and private sector investment grew at a record low of 3.9% in May. The slowdown suggests the economy is stabilizing, but the efficiency of recent liquidity injections into the system is being questioned. Experts warn that the lack of funding for private firms, which historically go to state-owned firms, may hinder economic growth. The government's efforts to reduce overcapacity and phase out surplus capacity may be undermined by recent price increases in key industries.

site_title: Top Glove eyes secondary listing on SGX
summary: Malaysia's Top Glove Corporation, the world's largest glove manufacturer, is considering a secondary listing on the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX) to raise funds at a lower cost. The company's chairman, Lim Wee-Chai, sees benefits in future fund-raising and believes the SGX listing will give Top Glove more cachet with lenders and investors. The company has already received conditional eligibility-to-list and plans to sell some shares in the open market. A secondary listing will also allow Top Glove to leverage the money markets, including borrowing USD at lower rates.

site_title: Lotte signals US$4.5 billion hotel IPO will be shelved amid crisis
summary: Lotte Group has announced it will shelve its planned US$4.5 billion initial public offering (IPO) for its hotel unit due to widening investigations pushing the conglomerate deeper into crisis. The group cited the need for additional disclosures and cooperation with authorities in their investigation. This move comes amid a challenging environment for the company, making it "physically difficult" to meet the IPO deadline. The decision marks a significant setback for Lotte's hotel business and further complicates its already precarious financial situation.

site_title: Putting gender parity on today's business agenda
summary: Women remain under-represented in business leadership positions in the Asia-Pacific region, with 6% of seats on corporate boards and 8% of executive committee members being female. Despite close to 70% of industry leaders believing in achieving gender parity, only 13% expect significant growth in women in leadership roles within the next five years. Organizations are urged to adopt strategies such as eliminating unconscious bias, showing the roadmap to the top, reviewing corporate policies, and encouraging other female leaders to step into the spotlight to promote gender parity.

site_title: Fed and other central banks must stand ready to deal with Brexit fallout
summary: Global equity markets continue to decline due to Brexit uncertainty, with sovereign bonds experiencing a significant rally and stocks in Asia and Europe falling. The potential for a "leave" vote in the UK referendum poses a major risk to markets, potentially leading to a recession, dislocations in financial institutions, and a decline in the British pound. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve, should be prepared to respond to any negative market shock, and policymakers must tread carefully in the lead-up to the referendum.

site_title: US money funds pare UK exposure before Brexit vote: JP Morgan
summary: US money market mutual funds reduced their exposure to short-term British bank debt ahead of the June 23 Brexit referendum, cutting holdings by $4 billion from April to $41 billion. Despite year-to-date holdings increasing by $6 billion, analysts expect low volumes in short-term British bank debt due to Brexit uncertainty. Rating agencies may downgrade Britain's credit ratings if Brexit occurs, potentially affecting British banks. However, British banks do not rely heavily on US money markets, according to JP Morgan analysts.

site_title: Officials relook MH370 search zone calculations
summary: Australian officials re-evaluate the search zone for Malaysia Airlines' missing Flight 370 after concluding the plane likely crashed in the southern Indian Ocean. The reassessment focuses on the plane's final descent, specifically how far it traveled after fuel exhaustion and whether it followed a tight or broad spiral. The search area's validity is being tested to ensure no signs of the plane are missed. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau aims to verify assumptions made about the plane's end of flight, which defines the search zone.

site_title: Cordlife names Wong Chiang Yin as new CEO
summary: Cordlife Group has appointed Wong Chiang Yin, a medical doctor, as its new CEO, succeeding Jeremy Yee who unexpectedly resigned in March. Wong previously served as executive director of TMC Life Sciences and president of Thomson International. Cordlife's senior director of corporate development, Jonathan Liau Yen San, has also resigned. The change in leadership comes amid an underperforming core business and a dispute over a pay clause in Yee's contract.

site_title: Asia-Pacific nations' 'spend surge' spurs growth in global arms market
summary: Asia-Pacific nations' increased spending on defence led to a record-breaking $65 billion global arms market in 2016, a 11.3% growth. Defence imports by Asia-Pacific nations surged 71% between 2009 and 2016, driven by states bordering the South China Sea. Countries such as Vietnam, the Philippines, and Bangladesh saw significant growth, while South Korea and Australia rose to fifth and third place in defence imports, respectively. The global arms market is predicted to grow further to $69 billion in 2016, with India expected to remain a major importer.

site_title: Microsoft unveils plan to buy LinkedIn for US$26.2b
summary: Microsoft announced a $26.2 billion cash deal to acquire LinkedIn, a professional social network, on June 13, 2016. CEO Satya Nadella stated that the acquisition will accelerate LinkedIn's growth and complement Microsoft's Office 365 and Dynamics products. The deal was finalized, marking a significant expansion of Microsoft's presence in the professional networking space.

site_title: Traders bearish on Alibaba pending SEC probe
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has seen a surge in bearish sentiment among traders, with the number of outstanding shares borrowed for short selling reaching a record high of over 124 million. Prominent short sellers, including Jim Chanos and John Hempton, have been warning of accounting irregularities and potential growth figures that might be too good to be true. The company faces a regulatory probe and the loss of a key investor, SoftBank Group Corp, which is selling a $10 billion stake. Despite this, most analysts remain bullish on the stock, with 37 advising a buy and no sell ratings.

images.alt_text: Mr Chanos told CNBC last month that he's shorting Alibaba "for accounting reasons".

site_title: Asian sovereign investor confidence stable: study
summary: Asian sovereign investors have maintained stable confidence despite market volatility and low oil prices. According to Invesco's Global Sovereign Asset Management Study, overall confidence among Asian sovereign investors increased from 7.5 in 2014 and 2015 to 7.9 in 2016. Despite average annual portfolio returns falling, 12% of assets were new funding, and only 1% was withdrawn due to funding challenges. The study found that the US has become the most attractive market for sovereign investment, while Brazil, Russia, and China have lost attractiveness due to weaker performance.

site_title: Siemens won't bid for robot maker Kuka
summary: Siemens' CEO Joe Kaeser stated that the company has no interest in bidding for German robot maker Kuka, which is under a 4.5 billion euro takeover bid by Chinese home appliance maker Midea. Kaeser said if Siemens were interested, it would have acted already. German Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel is reportedly relaxed about Kuka's situation, while Berlin considers the technology's impact on the digitalisation of German industry. Midea's bid has sparked debate over Chinese takeovers in Europe, prompting calls for tougher restrictions.

site_title: Airbus says Brexit could hurt UK investment
summary: Airbus has expressed concerns that a vote for Brexit could harm its future investment in the UK, where it employs 15,000 people. The company's UK chief, Paul Kahn, stated that Airbus can invest anywhere globally as long as it remains competitive, and a vote to leave could change its future investment decisions.

site_title: Standard Chartered CEO cracking down on 'above the law' bankers
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters is cracking down on "above the law" bankers, following a culture of ethics rule-breaking and personal gain. The bank has issued memos highlighting misconduct, including improper lending and conflicts of interest, and has beefed up its internal investigation team with former detectives from the FBI and Scotland Yard. The probe has led to the departure of several bankers, including three managing directors in Dubai, and has sparked concerns about the bank's compliance and governance. Winters has vowed to have zero tolerance for rule-breaking, with the risk and control committee set to dock bonuses for non-compliance.

site_title: Glencore says coal an investment opportunity despite CO2 worry
summary: Glencore asserts coal remains an investment opportunity despite growing concerns over CO2 emissions. The company expects global coal demand to increase by 7% by 2030, driven by emerging economies and industrial demand. Without new funds, Glencore's coal operations are expected to be depleted by 2035. This prediction comes as the Paris Agreement on climate change has led to selling in companies heavily exposed to coal, the most carbon-intensive fossil fuel.

site_title: Nokia to build China Mobile's cloud network
summary: Nokia has signed a 1.36-billion-euro deal with China Mobile to create a cloud network, providing "seamless connectivity" for the Chinese operator's 835 million mobile clients. The network will support all connection speeds from 4G to 5G and connected objects. Nokia will deliver a new base station technology allowing multiple radio technologies to be used simultaneously, enhancing the efficiency of data demands. This deal strengthens Nokia's position as a leading provider of next-generation technologies in China.

site_title: Opec sees oil glut shrinking in second half of year
summary: Opec forecasts a shrinking oil glut in the second half of the year, citing reduced supply due to outages in Nigeria and Canada. The organization's production fell by 100,000 barrels per day in May, and excess supply is expected to ease over the coming quarters. Opec maintains forecasts of seasonally higher demand for its crude in the second half of the year, but warns of a 160,000 bpd excess supply if production remains at May's rate.

site_title: US probes whether gunman in nightclub massacre had help
summary: US authorities are investigating whether Omar Mateen, the gunman who killed 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando, had any help in the massacre. Mateen, 29, pledged allegiance to Islamic State militants during the attack and was shot and killed by police. The FBI and other agencies are looking for clues on whether anyone assisted Mateen, with officials stressing that there is no evidence of a threat to the public. The attack has reignited the debate over violent Islamist militancy and has sparked controversy over gun safety measures and Muslim-American relations.

site_title: Eurozone banks face added scrutiny if 'guidance' not followed: Nouy
summary: Daniele Nouy, European Central Bank's top supervisor, warns that Eurozone banks may face added scrutiny and supervisory measures if they don't follow non-mandatory guidance on capital levels. This guidance, called "Pillar 2," aims to ensure prudent capital levels without affecting bonus payouts. Despite banks' already high capital ratios, investors are concerned with weak profitability and high cost of capital. Nouy emphasizes that failing to meet Pillar 2 guidance will lead to intensified supervision and measures to re-establish capital levels.

site_title: Apple expected to showcase new powers for Siri at developer event
summary: Apple is expected to showcase new features for its Siri digital assistant at its upcoming developer event. The company aims to expand Siri's capabilities beyond Apple apps and searching the web, allowing developers to integrate the personal assistant with their own apps. This move is part of Apple's efforts to grow through services, following a slowdown in iPhone sales. Analysts expect the event to also include a makeover for Apple Music, addressing customer complaints about the service's confusing interface and limited features.

site_title: Maersk heir takes top post in holding company
summary: AP Moller-Maersk's holding company has appointed Robert M Uggla, 38, grandson of Maersk Mc-Kinney Moller, as its CEO on September 1. Uggla, CEO of Maersk-owned tug boat operator Svitzer since 2012, has been a board member since 2014. He replaces Uggla, who will lead Svitzer. Henriette Thygesen, former CEO for the Americas in Damco, will take Uggla's position at Svitzer.

site_title: Grab launches JB-SG carpool service
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-sharing app, launches GrabHitch JB-SG, a carpool service connecting Johor Bahru and Singapore. The service, launching June 20, offers affordable, door-to-door rides with safety features and in-app rating systems. Average fares range from S$2.99 to S$14, with Grab claiming to be the region's first and most affordable cross-border ride-sharing service. This move is part of Grab's efforts to localise its offerings and compete with rival Uber, which does not currently offer cross-border services in Singapore.

site_title: Blue Coat to sell itself to Symantec, abandoning IPO plans
summary: Blue Coat Systems, a US$4.65 billion cyber security software company, has abandoned its initial plan to go public and instead plans to sell itself to Symantec. As part of the deal, Blue Coat's CEO will take over as CEO of the combined security software maker. The acquisition marks a significant shift in the company's strategy.

images.alt_text: Blue Coat said late on Sunday that it would sell itself to Symantec for US$4.65 billion.

site_title: India's retail inflation edges up to 5.76% in May: govt
summary: India's retail inflation rose to 5.76% in May, driven by higher food and fuel prices, surpassing economists' expectations of 5.52%. This marks the second consecutive month of inflation increase. Food inflation surged to 7.55% in May, up from 6.40% in April. The inflation rate is higher than the upwardly revised 5.47% in April.

images.alt_text: India's annual consumer price inflation edged up for the second straight month to 5.76 per cent in May, driven by higher prices of food and fuel products, government data showed on Monday.

site_title: Shares in G4S security firm plunge after Orlando massacre
summary: G4S shares plummet 5.71% after it emerged that Omar Mateen, the Orlando nightclub gunman, was one of its employees. Mateen was hired in 2007 and underwent screening in 2013 with no adverse findings. G4S stated it is "deeply shocked" by the tragedy and is providing support to US law enforcement authorities. The company employs 623,000 people worldwide, including 23% in Britain and Ireland and 20% in North America.

site_title: Any way you slice it, Microsoft's LinkedIn deal is rich: Gadfly
summary: Microsoft's $26.2 billion purchase of LinkedIn is the priciest major deal of 2016, with the tech giant paying 91 times LinkedIn's Ebitda in the past year. This is the highest multiple paid for a US$5 billion-plus software and Internet deal in the last decade. Analysts project LinkedIn's Ebitda will grow to $1 billion in 2016, making the deal even more expensive, with Microsoft paying almost $250 per user. The purchase is also criticized for LinkedIn's slow revenue growth rate, which is set to be the lowest in the company's public history.

site_title: Oil prices slip under pressure from economic worries
summary: Oil prices dropped Monday, weighed down by economic worries in Europe and Asia and a stronger US dollar. Brent crude fell to $49.74 per barrel, down 80 cents, and US crude fell to $48.35 per barrel, down 72 cents. Analysts cite Brexit concerns, a faltering Asian economy, and potential interest rate hikes as factors contributing to the decline. Despite some supply disruptions, oil demand in Asia, particularly China, is expected to remain strong, with Chinese crude oil imports projected to grow by 730,000-760,000 barrels per day this year.

site_title: A larger Euro 2016 is a plus for football
summary: Michel Platini's push for the 2016 European Football Championship to feature 24 teams has left a lasting legacy. The expansion added eight more teams, 20 more matches, and a week to the schedule, resulting in 51 fixtures. The decision sparked debate, with some viewing it as reasonable to reflect the sport's growth in Europe. Platini's efforts to increase the tournament's size have had a lasting impact on the sport.

site_title: Indonesia hits back at Singapore in latest haze row
summary: Indonesia has responded to Singapore's attempt to question the director of an Indonesian company suspected of being linked to the 2015 haze that affected Southeast Asia. Indonesia insists Singapore cannot take legal action against its citizens, citing jurisdictional issues. The 2014 law allowing cross-border prosecutions may be violated if Singapore tries to question Indonesian citizens. Indonesia has made progress in preparing for this year's fires, which are expected to begin in the coming weeks. The country rejects Singapore's move, saying it is part of Indonesia's jurisdiction.

site_title: Thai management of Asia Aviation to sell some equity to King Power: CEO
summary: Thai management of Asia Aviation, a major shareholder of Thai AirAsia, plans to sell some of its stake to King Power group, the country's largest duty free retailer. The Thai management, led by CEO Tassapon Bijleveld, owns 45% of Asia Aviation, with the rest held by public. The stake sale will be disclosed to the Stock Exchange of Thailand after the market closes on Monday. This move aims to raise capital for the company.

site_title: China: Shanghai stocks tumble in global market sell-off
summary: Shanghai stocks plummeted 3.21% on Monday, following a global market sell-off, as investors sought to avoid risks amid uncertainties over the global economy, including the US Federal Reserve's meetings and Britain's EU referendum. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index fell to 2,833.07, while the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped to 1,827.36. The decline was in line with heavy losses across world markets.

site_title: US: Microsoft drags Wall St; Fed meet awaited
summary: US stocks opened lower for the third straight trading day, led by Microsoft's 4.5% decline after its $26.2 billion acquisition of LinkedIn. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes fell 0.28% and 0.45% respectively. The Federal Reserve is set to meet on Tuesday to decide on interest rate hikes, with reduced odds of a hike this month and July. The Fed's decision is influenced by dismal May hiring data and Brexit concerns, with traders reducing the odds of a hike to 1% and 33% respectively.

site_title: Gold hits 4-week high as cenbank meets, Brexit vote shake stocks
summary: Gold prices rose to a 4-week high on Monday, driven by a weaker dollar and rising risk aversion ahead of key central bank meetings and the June 23 Brexit vote. The pound fell to a 2-month low against the dollar, pushing gold denominated in sterling to a nearly 3-year high. Gold has rallied 6% since weaker-than-expected US payrolls data, and analysts attribute the surge to fading expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike and increased uncertainty over the UK's EU membership.

site_title: China investment slows to 15-year low, more stimulus seen despite debt fears
summary: China's fixed-asset investment slowed to a 15-year low of 9.6% in January-May, missing expectations of 10.5%. This decline, particularly in private investment, poses concerns about meeting China's growth target of 6.5-7% this year. The International Monetary Fund warns that excessive debt could hinder long-term economic growth, while the government considers further stimulus measures to support the economy. Despite this, China's government spending surged 17.6% in May, and infrastructure projects continue to be announced.

site_title: Asia markets tumble, STI down on global outlook
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday, led by a sell-off in Japan, as investors sought safe-haven investments amid renewed worries about the global economy and uncertainty over Britain's EU future. The Straits Times Index fell 1.46% as the yen strengthened against the dollar. Other markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, and Singapore, also dropped. The decline follows comments from European Central Bank leader Mario Draghi and a Federal Reserve statement that may delay interest rate hikes, fueling concerns about economic growth.

site_title: US refiners gear up for work in 2017 after lull: IIR
summary: US oil refineries are expected to perform slightly below normal maintenance levels in 2016, with the spring 2017 season potentially being the largest since 2014. Refineries that deferred maintenance during the 2014-2016 oil price rout will be due for planned maintenance in 2017, leading to a rebound in turnaround work. The fall 2016 season is expected to be below average, with the largest shutdowns occurring in September and October. Industry analysts predict a return to normal maintenance levels in 2017, with the Gulf Coast being the focal point for most work.

site_title: MAS sets up dedicated anti-money laundering and enforcement departments
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is setting up dedicated departments to combat money laundering and strengthen enforcement, effective August 1, 2016. The anti-money laundering department will streamline existing responsibilities, while the enforcement department will focus on improving regulatory policies. These changes aim to enhance the MAS's ability to combat illicit financing risks and strengthen its regulatory framework.

site_title: Thai pilot jokes about crashing plane carrying ousted PM
summary: A Thai Nok Air pilot made a joke about crashing a plane carrying ousted Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, sparking outrage and an apology from the airline. The pilot's comment, made in a private chat group, was leaked and referred to "CFIT" - a term for a pilot crashing a plane into terrain. Nok Air's CEO apologized, saying the pilot's comments did not reflect the company's values. This incident highlights ongoing hatred towards the Shinawatra clan, two years after the military coup that toppled Yingluck's administration.

site_title: Lubricant manufacturer United Global gearing up for Catalist listing
summary: Singapore-based lubricant manufacturer United Global is gearing up for a listing on the Catalist board of Singapore Exchange (SGX) with a preliminary offer document for an initial public offering (IPO). The company has a distribution network of over 30 countries, manufacturing a range of lubricants and specialty fluids. Revenue for 2015 was US$99.9 million, with a 15.9% decline, but profit rose 85.4% to US$6.2 million. United Global aims to expand into new markets and collaborate with developing countries, with Canaccord Genuity Singapore serving as the issue manager and sponsor.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Brexit worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 1.3% on June 13, 2016, amid Brexit worries, with the Hang Seng Index falling 2.5% and the Nikkei plummeting 3.5%. The UK pound fell following polls suggesting the "leave" camp had a marginal lead, prompting selling of stocks and buying of Japanese yen and government bonds. The three banks in Singapore took a beating, with Singtel, Keppel Corp, and CapitaLand also experiencing significant losses. The outcome of the Brexit vote is uncertain, with polls suggesting a close result.

site_title: Seoul: Shares extend losses on foreign selling, won down
summary: South Korean shares dropped 1.9% on Monday, their largest daily percentage loss since February, amid foreign selling and risk aversion. Foreign investors sold 146.7 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while the South Korean won slumped 0.7% against the US dollar. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 1,979.06 points. Brexit concerns and central bank meetings this week contributed to the losses.

site_title: Pacific Radiance in arbitration to claim US$10.6m on cancelled vessel contracts
summary: Pacific Radiance, the owner of offshore vessels, has issued arbitration notices in Hong Kong against two Chinese shipbuilders, Shanghai Waigaoqiao Shipbuilding & Offshore Co and China Shipbuilding Trading (Shanghai) Co. The arbitration claims a refund of US$10.6 million in pre-delivery instalments paid for two cancelled platform supply vessels, which were not delivered according to obligations. Pacific Radiance is seeking interest on the claim.

site_title: Neo Group buys 55% of Joo Chiat Kim Choo dumpling brand for S$1.9m
summary: Neo Group acquired 55% of Joo Chiat Kim Choo, a dumpling brand, for S$1.925 million. The deal values the company at S$3.5 million. Joo Chiat Kim Choo made a profit before tax of S$251,000 in 2015 with a net tangible asset value of S$847,000. Neo Group plans to use this acquisition to expand its supply chain, complementing its existing catering and manufacturing businesses. Shareholders will hold 30-15% of the company after the deal.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipped 11.45 points to close at 1,629.77, with 1.48 billion lots valued at RM1.21 billion traded. The market saw 203 gains and 643 losses. This article is unrelated to the provided content.

site_title: China auto sales increase in May: industry group
summary: China's auto sales increased 9.8% in May to 2.09 million vehicles, surpassing April's 6.3% gain. Despite a slowing economy, with growth at 6.7% in January-March, the numbers were an improvement on the previous month. Sales of passenger cars rose 11.3% to 1.79 million units, with General Motors and Toyota reporting strong demand. The increase follows a government tax cut in October for passenger cars with small engines.

site_title: Renewable energy to attract two-thirds of power plant investments: study
summary: A new report by Bloomberg New Energy Finance predicts that renewable energy sources, including wind and solar, will attract two-thirds of global power plant investments between 2016 and 2040, with $7.8 trillion invested, compared to $1.2 trillion for new coal plants. Gas investments are expected to be $892 billion. Renewables are expected to overtake coal by 2037, but still fall short of meeting the UN's 2-degree limit for global warming. $5.3 trillion in zero-carbon power investment is needed to meet the target.

images.alt_text: Renewable energy sources such as wind and solar will attract two-thirds of all investment in power-generating plants between 2016 and 2040 in spite of persistently cheap coal and gas prices, a new report has found.

site_title: German home-building hits highest level since 2006
summary: Germany saw its highest home-building level since 2006 in 2015, with 247,700 homes constructed, a 1% increase from the previous year. This still falls short of the government's target of 350,000 new homes annually and the industry's estimate of 400,000. The influx of over 1 million migrants is expected to increase demand for homes, particularly as they transition from shelters to permanent accommodation. Low mortgage rates have also encouraged Germans to buy property, further boosting the market.

site_title: UK commodities broker Marex to set up industrial metals base in Singapore
summary: UK commodities broker Marex Spectron is setting up an industrial metals base in Singapore, expanding its metals business into new regions and products beyond the London Metal Exchange (LME). The move comes after fee hikes at the LME led clients to seek cheaper trading options. Marex aims to target institutional investors and Chinese players, and its presence in Singapore will maintain its investor business. The company has also hired new staff to reach into Japan, adding to its global headcount of over 500.

site_title: Trade disputes loom over Merkel's China visit
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's visit to Beijing was dominated by trade disputes, particularly over China's push for "market economy" status, which would make it harder for the EU to levy anti-dumping tariffs. China accused Europe of unfairly targeting its steel exports, while Merkel reiterated Germany's commitment to promises made in 2001. Merkel also met with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang to discuss the South China Sea dispute, with Merkel urging bilateral talks to avoid new tensions. The visit comes as China's steel industry faces a global supply glut and German robotics firm Kuka faces a potential Chinese takeover bid.

site_title: Singapore destroys tonnes of illegal ivory worth S$13m
summary: Singapore destroyed 8 tonnes of confiscated ivory worth S$13m, crushing and burning it to deter smugglers. The ivory, seized between 2014 and 2015, was the first to be destroyed in Singapore, following international bans since 1989. Activists called for stricter enforcement, citing instances of smuggled ivory being caught at other ports. The destruction aims to send a strong message against the illegal wildlife trade, but critics argue Singapore can do more to enforce anti-trafficking laws.

site_title: Port of Singapore container volume increases in May
summary: The Port of Singapore experienced a year-on-year increase in container volume in May, handling over 2.665 million TEUs, up from 2.622 million in 2015. This marks the first rise in container throughput since the start of 2016. Total cargo throughput also increased to over 52.257 million tonnes in May. The port's growth is attributed to its strategic location and continued investment in infrastructure.

site_title: Hong Kong shares suffer biggest fall in 4 months on global woes
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.5% to 20,512.99, their worst day in four months, amid global economic concerns and the looming UK's possible exit from the European Union. The sell-off follows a surge in market volatility ahead of central bank meetings and the June 23 referendum. The China Enterprises Index also fell 2.4% to 8,619.92 points. Investors are shifting their focus to the UK's referendum and US-EU trade talks, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Chinese and German leaders downplay China market status tensions
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang and German Chancellor Angela Merkel downplayed tensions over China's market economy status, stating China does not want a trade war with Europe. Beijing views Germany as influential in the EU's debate on the issue, which could impact China's WTO membership. China agreed to third-market comparisons in 2001, allowing the EU to assess Chinese imports' competitiveness. Merkel called for more talks, but Li emphasized China's commitment to cooperation and avoiding a trade war. The two leaders aim to resolve the issue through dialogue.

site_title: Grab to launch ride-sharing service between Johor Bahru and Singapore
summary: Grab, a ride-sharing platform, launched a new service called GrabHitch, connecting commuters between Johor Bahru and Singapore. The service, available from June 20, allows passengers to pre-book rides up to 30 minutes in advance and is priced around S$12 or RM36 for a round trip. The fare is calculated based on distance and a fixed cross-border surcharge. Passengers can get S$5 off weekday trips exceeding 10km by using the promo code "hitch2jb" during booking.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide for fourth day as Brexit concerns intensify
summary: European stocks plummeted for the fourth consecutive day, hitting a two-month low, amid heightened concerns over the UK's potential departure from the European Union. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index dropped 1.3% to 328.51, with carmakers and energy companies leading the decline. Investors shunned risky assets ahead of monetary-policy and political events, following a 16% surge from February's low.

site_title: Malaysia shuts down first sharia-compliant airline
summary: Malaysia's first sharia-compliant airline, Rayani Air, has been shut down by regulators following an investigation into administration and safety issues. The airline was launched in December with strict Islamic rules, including halal meals and no alcohol consumption. The Department of Aviation revoked Rayani's Air Operator Certificate, citing safety and security concerns. The decision comes after a series of criticisms and a pilots' strike over unpaid wages. The move follows twin aviation disasters in Malaysia in 2014, including the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17.

site_title: FLASH: Port of Singapore sees container volume increase in May
summary: The Port of Singapore reported an increase in container volume in May, marking a positive trend for the maritime industry. This growth is attributed to the region's strategic location and favorable business environment. The Port of Singapore Authority (PSA) has been investing in infrastructure development to enhance its competitiveness. The news comes amidst a backdrop of ongoing developments in the logistics and transportation sector, including the expansion of Tesla's robotaxi services and FedEx's partnership with QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries.

site_title: Asia stocks plummet, STI down more than 1.5% as risk aversion grips markets
summary: Asian stocks plummeted, with the Straits Times Index down 1.66% and MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan falling 1.7% in the biggest daily drop since February 2016. Risk aversion gripped markets ahead of key central bank meetings this week, with investors awaiting Britain's EU referendum outcome. Japanese stocks led regional losses, with the yen rising to a five-week high against the US dollar. The US Federal Reserve, Bank of England, and other central banks are expected to hold monetary policy steady, heightening caution over a possible Brexit.

site_title: CMA CGM to delist NOL, move traffic from Malaysia: report
summary: CMA CGM, the world's third-largest container shipping company, plans to delist Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) after acquiring over 78% of its shares in a $2.4 billion deal. Minority shareholders can sell their shares until July 18, after which NOL will be delisted. CMA CGM will also move its shipping traffic from Malaysia to a new terminal in Singapore and its Asian headquarters from Hong Kong to Singapore. The move is part of CMA CGM's efforts to cope with a severe market downturn and includes plans for $1 billion in asset sales and cost cuts.

site_title: China home sales rose at slowest pace this year amid cooling
summary: China's new home sales rose 32.9% to 773 billion yuan in May, the slowest pace this year, amid efforts to cool the property market. This follows a 63.5% surge in April. The government aims to curb price growth in smaller cities while maintaining control in top hubs. Property-development investment growth slowed to 7% in the first five months, and land purchases decreased 5.8% in May. Analysts predict further slowdown in home-sales growth in June due to reduced liquidity.

site_title: HK tycoon Woo seeks bidders for US$1b-plus telecoms unit, from KKR to Anbang: sources
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Peter Woo's Wharf Holdings Ltd plans to sell its telecoms business, worth over $1 billion, with bids due by end-June. Companies invited to submit bids include KKR & Co, CVC Capital, and Western buyout firms, as well as Chinese insurers Anbang and Ping An, and technology conglomerate Tsinghua Unigroup. Woo has asked over a dozen potential suitors to submit bids for the telecoms unit, which could be a significant deal in the Asian market.

site_title: Update: Gunman massacres 50 at Florida gay club in worst US mass shooting
summary: A gunman, Omar Mateen, killed 50 people during a gay pride celebration at a nightclub in Orlando, Florida, in the deadliest US mass shooting. Mateen, 29, was armed with an AR-15-style assault rifle and a handgun, and pledged loyalty to Islamic State during the attack. Authorities say the attack was inspired by Islamic State militants but found no direct ties. Mateen's former wife described him as emotionally and mentally disturbed with a violent temper. The attack reignites debates over American gun laws and homeland security.

site_title: Yuan falls most in two months as trading resumes after holidays
summary: The Chinese yuan fell 0.4% to approach a five-year low against the dollar, its largest loss in two months. The currency's decline accelerated amid a strengthening US dollar and China's deteriorating economic outlook. Data due Monday showed May's industrial output rose 6% and retail sales climbed 10.1%, unchanged from April. Analysts predict the yuan may break its January low, citing weak fundamentals.

site_title: Lubricant manufacturer United Global gears up for Catalist listing
summary: Singapore-based lubricant manufacturer United Global is set to list on the SGX's Catalist board, following the incorporation of its wholly-owned subsidiary United Oil Company in September 2015.
