The company has a distribution network of over 30 countries, manufacturing high-quality lubricants and specialty fluids. Despite a 15.9% revenue decline in 2015, profit rose 85.4% to US$6.2 million, driven by higher gross profit margins. United Global plans to expand into new markets and collaborate with developing countries, with the listing date to be announced by SGX.

site_title: Vaping teens more apt to move on to regular cigarettes: US study
summary: A US study found that older teens who try electronic cigarettes have six times the odds of trying regular cigarettes within two years compared to those who never vaped. Researchers based their findings on surveys of 300 high school students in southern California, where about half had tried an e-cigarette by 2014. The study suggests that e-cigarette use may be a gateway to regular cigarettes, particularly among teens who initially intended not to smoke.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down 2% on profit taking, global uncertainties
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 2% on Monday, tracking global uncertainties, as investors took profit after five consecutive gains. The Taiex index dropped to 8,537.61 points, with the electronics subindex sinking 2.2% and the financials subindex losing 1.8%. TSMC and Hon Hai, major electronics manufacturers, also declined. The Taiwan dollar softened to T$32.418 per US dollar. The decline came after a two-and-a-half-month high reached last week.

site_title: High-yield bankers become endangered species in Asia
summary: Asia's high-yield debt specialists face a tough time as investment banks shed product-specific roles due to a sharp slowdown in high-yield corporate bond sales. Sales plummeted to $4.0 billion from $16.8 billion in the same period in 2013. Senior bankers are considering switches to general coverage roles, and some banks are cutting their high-yield ranks. Despite expectations of a potential revival in the second half, bankers remain cautious due to volatility in the Chinese onshore bond markets and stricter regulations.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei stumbles to 5-week low as Brexit woes sap risk appetite
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei share average fell 3.5% to 16,019.18 points, its lowest since May 6, as Brexit woes sapped risk appetite and hit global equities. The yen surged to a six-week high versus the US dollar and a three-year peak against the euro, further pressuring Tokyo stocks. Index heavyweights Fast Retailing Co Ltd and Fanuc Corp declined, contributing to the losses. This marks the third straight day of losses for Tokyo equities.

site_title: Pound at two-month low on British EU exit fears
summary: The pound dropped to a two-month low due to concerns about Britain's possible exit from the European Union, prompting investors to shift into safer assets. Asian stock markets plummeted, with dealers awaiting central bank meetings this week. Few expect the Federal Reserve to make interest rate changes, but the Bank of Japan's policy meeting may announce more stimulus. This flight to lower-yielding investments led to a yen rally. The pound's decline is a fresh blow to UK economy, which shrank for the second month in a row, exacerbating concerns about Starmer's government.

site_title: China condemns protection of corrupt officials in name of human rights
summary: China's top anti-graft body has condemned individuals who protect corrupt officials in the name of human rights, criticizing them for "sheltering corrupt elements." The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection made the statement amid its "Fox Hunt" campaign to track down corruption suspects abroad. China has sought international cooperation to extradite suspects, but Western nations have been reluctant due to concerns over China's human rights record and lack of independent courts. China's President Xi Jinping has led a years-long anti-graft campaign, resulting in the downfall of hundreds of officials.

site_title: Singapore's overall unemployment unchanged at 1.9%
summary: Singapore's overall unemployment rate remained unchanged at 1.9% in March 2016, with declines seen among residents and citizens. Unemployment rates for residents declined to 2.7% and for citizens to 2.6%. The long-term unemployment rate for residents out of work for 25 weeks or more rose to 0.7% from 0.5%.

site_title: Rising oil prices encourage shale producers, dissuade investors
summary: US shale producers are resuming drilling activities as oil prices rise above $50 a barrel, threatening to slow further gains. The number of active oil rigs in the US increased by three last week, marking the first back-to-back gain since August. Experts predict the crude glut is starting to dwindle due to global disruptions, including fires in Alberta and pipeline attacks in Nigeria. Despite this, hedge funds are betting on lower prices, and money managers are cautious about further gains.

site_title: Welcome, Olympic tourists, to Brazil. Please don't mind the mess
summary: Brazil's Rio de Janeiro is struggling to prepare for the Olympics, which begin in two months, due to a lack of funds and infrastructure. The city's sewage-filled harbour, metro line, and public health services are among the unfinished projects. The state's financial crisis is exacerbated by a crushing recession, delayed public-worker salaries, and allegations of kickbacks in Olympic-related infrastructure projects. Many public officials and security personnel are without essential equipment, raising concerns about the safety of tourists and participants.

images.alt_text: A graffiti with the logo of the Olympic Games is seen on a wall in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on June 4, 2016. When Rio de Janeiro won the rights in 2009 to host the Olympics, Brazil planned a blitz of projects to showcase just how far it had risen.

site_title: Despite challenging environment, Asian sovereign investor confidence is stable: Invesco
summary: Asian sovereign investor confidence remains stable this year, despite market volatility and low oil prices, according to Invesco's Global Sovereign Asset Management Study. The study found overall confidence among Asian sovereign wealth funds increased from 7.5 in 2014 to 7.9 in 2016. Invesco's CEO, Terry Pan, stated that sovereigns have expressed confidence in their funding outlooks and long-term investing abilities. The US has become the most attractive region for Asian sovereign investors, with a growing appetite for real estate investments.

site_title: QIA said to weigh loan of up to US$2b for Asia Square Tower 1
summary: Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) is considering a US$2 billion loan to acquire BlackRock Inc's Asia Square Tower 1. QIA has held preliminary talks with banks, aiming to borrow between US$1.5 billion and US$2 billion. The borrowing timeline has not been finalized. This acquisition would be a significant move for QIA, marking its expansion into the global real estate market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) established dedicated anti-money laundering and enforcement departments to combat financial crimes. Meanwhile, Singapore's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 1.9%. In international news, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US's decision to impose tariffs, and the Asian garment industry is preparing for the impact. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and policymakers face pressure to address this. Additionally, Citigroup predicted a mid-2026 target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index, and Thailand's Thaksin Shinawatra expressed confidence in his daughter's chances in an ethics case.

images.alt_text: THE Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said on Monday that it would set up dedicated departments to combat money laundering and strengthen enforcement, respectively.

site_title: Bomb blast in central Beirut aimed at bank: minister
summary: A bomb exploded outside the Lebanese Blom Bank headquarters in central Beirut, causing damage but no fatalities, on Sunday. The blast, which contained 15 kg of explosive material, was aimed at the bank due to its closure of accounts linked to Hezbollah. The US Hezbollah International Financing Prevention Act has ignited a crisis between Hezbollah and the central bank, with the latter pushing for the US law to be applied. No immediate claim of responsibility has been made, but the attack's timing and location suggest a targeted attempt against the bank.

site_title: Bitcoin surges to two-year high as supply seen shrinking in July
summary: Bitcoin surged to a two-year high of US$683.89 on June 13, driven by expectations of a supply reduction in July due to the halving of profits from mining. The cryptocurrency's price has mostly recovered from a steep decline in January, coinciding with weakness in the yuan. Increased attention from venture capitalists and banks on blockchain technology has boosted bitcoin's legitimacy. The nation's currency trades near a five-year low, and the Shanghai Composite Index is this year's worst performer among 93 global stock measures.

site_title: Football: Brazil crash out of Copa America after Peru upset
summary: Brazil was eliminated from the Copa America Centenario after a refereeing blunder allowed Peru to defeat them 1-0. Peru's Raul Ruidiaz scored the goal after using his arm to knock the ball into the net, despite multiple replays showing the incident. The Brazilian team protested, but the referee's decision stood, and Brazil was unable to equalize in the remaining minutes of the game. The defeat marks Brazil's worst performance in the Copa America since 1987, and coach Dunga criticized the lengthy deliberations between officials.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 8.91 points to 1,632.310. The index saw a 122-71 loss-gain ratio, with 59.58 million lots traded at RM36.55 million.

site_title: NZ: Stocks pressured by Brexit woes, lower commodities
summary: New Zealand shares fell 0.7% on Monday, weighed down by heightened risk aversion and weaker commodity prices, amid uncertainty over Britain's EU membership vote. The market was also affected by news of the Orlando nightclub shooting, but trading was light due to the Australian share market's closure. Key losers included Orion Health Group and Ryman Healthcare, while A2 milk rose 4.6% ahead of its potential listing on the ASX 200 Index. Investors will continue to monitor offshore markets for direction.

site_title: Ringgit declines most in two weeks on lower oil, Brexit risk
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell by 0.9% to 4.1040 per dollar, its largest drop in two weeks, due to a decline in oil prices and concerns over the UK's potential exit from the European Union. The drop in oil prices and Brexit risk fueled demand for haven assets, leading to a weaker ringgit. A report is forecast to show Malaysian consumer prices rose 2% in May, the slowest pace since April last year.

site_title: Basslink resumes service
summary: Basslink, a unit of Keppel Infrastructure Trust, has resumed electricity interconnector service between Tasmania and mainland Australia, exporting 112 MWh of power to Victoria. The interconnector resumed operation ahead of its expected return date of June 14, following repairs that began in December after a fault was reported. Examinations into fault diagnosis are ongoing, with Basslink's CEO stating that the outage is considered a force majeure event and covered by insurance. The resumption is expected to save Tasmania approximately A$40 million.

site_title: Massive North Korea cyber attack thwarted after hacking South Korea: report
summary: North Korea was suspected of hacking into over 140,000 computers at large South Korean conglomerates and government agencies, planting malicious codes that were intended for a massive cyber attack. The hacking originated from an internet address linked to the North Korean capital and targeted software used by 160 companies and government agencies. The South Korean police agency thwarted the attack and neutralized the malicious codes, preventing a large-scale cyber attack. This incident comes after North Korea conducted a nuclear test and a long-range rocket launch, leading to new UN sanctions and heightened cyber threat alerts in South Korea.

site_title: Taiwan opposition slams former leader's travel ban to Hong Kong
summary: Taiwan's opposition Nationalist Party criticized the new government for banning former president Ma Ying-jeou from traveling to Hong Kong due to national security concerns. The move came after Ma's China-friendly Nationalists lost to President Tsai Ing-wen and her Democratic Progressive Party in January. The opposition party called the decision "suppressive" and said it hindered internal reconciliation. The Presidential Office cited national security and interests as reasons for the ban, which was made after a review by a government committee.

site_title: China's Uber rival Didi Chuxing raises US$600m from China Life Insurance
summary: China's ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing has secured a US$600 million investment from China Life Insurance, boosting its resources to compete with Uber. The investment includes US$300 million in equity and US$305 million in long-term borrowing. This comes just a month after Didi raised US$1 billion from Apple, and amid a struggle to fend off Uber's expansion in China. The companies plan to collaborate on investment opportunities in mobile transportation and related sectors.

site_title: China's economy steadies in May even as investment growth slows
summary: China's economy steadied in May, with industrial production rising 6% and retail sales climbing 10% year-over-year, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Fixed-asset investment grew 9.6% in the first five months, slightly missing forecasts. The data suggests policy makers' efforts to stimulate the economy through monetary and fiscal support have had a positive effect, with the property market and infrastructure projects showing signs of recovery. This steadying of the economy is expected to continue in the near term, with sequential momentum in economic growth remaining resilient.

site_title: Rising food, fuel prices seen pushing up India inflation in May
summary: India's consumer price data for May is expected to show inflation edging up for a second straight month, driven by higher prices for food and fuel items. Annual consumer prices are likely to have risen 5.52% in May, compared to 5.39% in April. The Reserve Bank of India is still monitoring inflation, which has targeted 5% by March 2017, but good rainfall in the next three months may dampen food prices. The central bank is still looking for room to reduce interest rates, despite concerns over upward pressure on food and commodity prices.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars steady but markets jittery over Brexit, Fed
summary: Australia and New Zealand dollar rates held steady on Monday amidst Brexit fears and ahead of key central bank meetings. Investors avoided major positions due to risk-averse behavior, causing the US dollar to fall. The Australian dollar rose 0.15% to US$0.7380, while the New Zealand dollar fell 0.21% to US$0.7043. Central banks, including the US Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan, will hold policy meetings this week, with the Fed's decision expected to impact markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ezra, OKP, Noble
summary: Ezra Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, announced a subsea joint venture with Chiyoda, as Japanese shipping giant Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK) acquires a stake. OKP Holdings secured two road resurfacing contracts worth S$54.7 million. Noble Group expects the sale of its energy solutions unit to be completed in the second half of 2016. These announcements come ahead of GDP data release, with Singapore stocks experiencing a 5-day rally.

site_title: Sterling falls to 8-week low on Brexit anxiety, yen gains broadly
summary: The British pound fell to an 8-week low against the US dollar, reaching a low of $1.4159, due to Brexit anxiety ahead of the referendum. The yen gained broadly amid a somber mood after a mass shooting in the US. The pound lost 0.2% in early Asian trade, its second biggest fall this year, with experts predicting a tight race in the referendum.

images.alt_text: The British pound fell to an eight-week low against the US dollar on Monday amid trepidation ahead of a referendum that could push Britain out of the European Union, while the yen gained broadly as the mood turned sombre after Sunday's mass shooting in the United States.

site_title: China's fixed asset investment up 9.6% on-year in first five months: govt
summary: China's fixed asset investment increased 9.6% in the first five months of the year, falling short of Bloomberg's forecast of 10.4%. Industrial output rose 6.0% year-on-year in May, while retail sales rose 10.0% year-on-year. The National Bureau of Statistics attributed the growth to a stabilising and progressing trend, but noted the economy remains under downward pressure due to complicated international conditions and domestic structural adjustments.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks dive in early trade, track global losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks plunged over 2% in early trade, mirroring global losses due to concerns over the global economy and the UK's EU future. The Hang Seng Index fell 2.34% to 20,549.6, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.02% to 2,897.27.

site_title: Symantec to buy cybersecurity firm Blue Coat for US$4.65b
summary: Symantec to acquire cybersecurity firm Blue Coat for $4.65 billion, bolstering cyberdefense technology and filling its vacant CEO position. Blue Coat CEO Greg Clark will lead the combined company after the deal closes in the third quarter. The transaction is expected to bring $550 million in annual net cost savings. Symantec CEO Michael Brown will step down, following a major reorganization and a sale of its Veritas data-storage division for $7.4 billion. The acquisition aims to protect large customers and individuals against insider threats and sophisticated cybercriminals.

site_title: South Korea's Park urges 'bone-crushing' reform on shipbuilders
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye urged "bone-crushing" reforms to overhaul the nation's struggling shipbuilders, citing mounting losses due to slowing global demand and increased competition. The industry, dominated by Hyundai Heavy Industries and Daewoo Shipbuilding, faces challenges such as overcapacity and rising Chinese competition. The government and creditor banks have urged intense restructuring efforts, including mass job cuts, to revitalize the sector.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Park Geun-Hye on Monday urged "bone-crushing" efforts to overhaul the nation's ailing shipbuilders faced with mounting losses caused by slowing global demand and increased competition

site_title: Lotte signals US$4.5b hotel IPO is shelved amid crisis
summary: Lotte Group has shelved its planned US$4.5 billion hotel IPO amid widening investigations into the company, which has pushed the South Korean conglomerate deeper into crisis. The probe has led to a delay in the IPO and a widening of investigations into allegations of slush funds and embezzlement. The company's stock has fallen, and the shelving of the IPO is the latest blow to the group, which is already reeling from a feud within its founding family and a delay in a key duty-free business license. Lotte's corporate governance is seen as a major issue.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower after US stocks slide
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 1.24% lower at 2,787.97 points on Monday, following a decline in US stocks due to Brexit fears and a drop in oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, while Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate futures also slid. Trading volume was 63.4 million shares worth S$57.3 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 116 to 28.

site_title: Japanese street art: Not quite Banksy, but trying
summary: In Japan, graffiti culture has traditionally been viewed as vandalism, but local enthusiasts are trying to change this perception. Despite a conformist culture and strict laws, some artists have found ways to express themselves, such as through "live painting" events like the Pow! Wow! Japan festival, which brought together local and international artists to create street art. The festival aims to shift Japan's conservative stance on artwork in a respectful manner, and collaborations with brands have helped to promote "legal" graffiti. Japanese artists are blending traditional styles with modern graffiti, creating a unique and distinctly Japanese art form.

images.alt_text: Beneath the crackle and hum of Japan's neon veneer, graffiti culture has traditionally been viewed as mindless vandalism assaulting the country's highly valued sense of order and cleanliness.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks slump at open, extending global rout
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 1.70% at the opening, extending a global market downturn, as a stronger yen negatively impacted exporters. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell to 16,319.11. Investors are focused on US and Japanese central bank meetings later this week. The decline follows a global market rout, with US and European stocks also experiencing losses.

site_title: Chinese state-owned companies face greater scrutiny of EU deals after ruling
summary: The European Commission has increased scrutiny of deals involving Chinese state-owned companies (SOEs) after ruling that CGN, a Chinese energy SOE, was not independent from China's central administrator. This decision automatically bumped CGN's turnover above the EU threshold for merger clearance, forcing other Chinese SOEs to file for EU merger clearance, creating an extra barrier. The move comes as concerns about Chinese foreign takeovers in Europe and the US grow, with at least 50% of Chinese foreign purchases over the past 18 months involving state-owned companies.

site_title: Noble to complete divestment of Americas unit in H2 (Amended)
summary: Noble Group plans to complete the sale and disposal of its wholly-owned Noble Americas Energy Solutions (NAES) unit in the second half of 2016. The divestment was announced following the resignation of Yusuf Alireza as CEO and the stepping down of founder Richard Elman as executive chairman. Morgan Stanley and HSBC have been appointed to advise on the disposal.

site_title: Oil extends losses as US rigs drilling for crude rise 2nd week
summary: Crude oil futures fell for a third consecutive day, dropping as much as 1% in New York after US rigs drilling for oil rose for a second week. The number of rigs targeting crude in the US increased to 328, the first two-week gain since August. Oil prices have surged 85% since hitting a 12-year low in February due to disruptions and a decline in US output. West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $48.58 a barrel, while Brent crude dropped to $50.54 a barrel.

site_title: Gold at near-four week high as Brexit worries boost safe haven assets
summary: Gold prices rose to a near four-week high, supported by weaker Asian stocks and Brexit worries, ahead of central bank meetings and the June 23 referendum on Britain's EU membership. Spot gold reached $1,278.03, its highest since May 18, and US gold rose 0.1% to $1,276.50. Gold has risen 5% in June and 20% in 2016, seen as a safe haven asset amid economic and financial concerns.

site_title: Australia: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Australia's financial markets closed on Monday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rose for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. The US stock market also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Additionally, eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: Japan corporate sentiment worsens, capex plans revised up
summary: Japan's corporate sentiment worsened for the second consecutive quarter from April-June due to a rising yen. Despite this, companies revised up their capital expenditure plans. The survey results offer relief to the Bank of Japan ahead of its monetary policy meeting. The upgrade in capital expenditure plans supports the central bank's argument that its negative interest rate policy would spur lending. Companies expect sentiment to rebound in July-September, providing encouragement to policymakers navigating weak exports and global economic concerns.

site_title: Asia: Stock futures tip losses amid Brexit angst before Fed, BOJ
summary: Financial markets in Asia are experiencing unease ahead of key events, including the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan meetings, the British referendum on Brexit, and US political party conventions. Asian index futures signal declines, while the yen strengthens due to increased haven asset demand. The pound has slid to its lowest level in almost two months, and crude oil has fallen amid rising US drilling rigs. Optimism in risk assets appears to have peaked, and traders are bracing for potential market volatility.

site_title: Standard Chartered CEO cracking down on 'above the law' bankers
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters is cracking down on employees who flout ethics rules for personal gain, labeling them "above the law." The bank has issued memos detailing "recent transgressions" involving outside business interests, close financial dealings, and excessive expenses. A team of former detectives from various law enforcement agencies has been hired to investigate misconduct. The bank is also reviewing whether senior managers should have their pay clawed back if found guilty. Winters has vowed zero tolerance for rule-breakers, stating that there are no excuses for those who transgress.

site_title: Singapore urges US against tweaking big Pacific trade pact
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang has urged the US against amending the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a massive Pacific trade pact, as it could risk the deal collapsing. The pact, which includes 12 countries and is yet to be ratified by the US, aims to raise gross domestic product by 1.1% in member countries by 2030. Despite opposition from US presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, the US Trade Representative Michael Froman has stated that the US is not intending to renegotiate any aspect of the TPP.

site_title: Australia plans A$1b fund to protect Great Barrier Reef
summary: Australia's government plans to allocate A$1 billion to protect the Great Barrier Reef from climate change and declining water quality. The reef, a UNESCO world heritage site, is facing bleaching due to warming waters and water pollution from farm fertilizers. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull emphasized the reef's economic and cultural significance, stating it will be protected for future generations. The fund aims to address these issues, ensuring the reef's long-term health and economic importance.

site_title: Japan planting seeds of baseball throughout Africa
summary: Japan is cultivating baseball in soccer-crazed Africa, with the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) sending volunteers to teach children to catch, throw, and hit. Since 1970, over 235 baseball volunteers have been sent abroad, with six currently working in four African countries. Japanese grants have helped build ball fields in Uganda and Ghana, and a league in Tanzania has been created. Despite obstacles such as lack of equipment and security concerns, supporters say an Olympic return of baseball and softball could boost the sport in Africa, with potential financial support at a local level.

site_title: Financial boardrooms 30 years away from 30% female representation: report
summary: A report by Oliver Wyman found that it will take 30 years to achieve 30% female representation on executive committees in the global financial services industry, with current numbers standing at 16%. The industry is also criticized for its low representation of women in leadership roles, with only 8% of CEOs being female. The report analyzed 381 organizations in 32 countries and found that women are more likely to leave their jobs due to inflexible working hours, pay inequality, and unconscious bias. The industry is urged to improve its gender balance to drive business success.

site_title: Investors reminded to do homework before buying high-yield bonds
summary: Singapore's retail investors are drawn to high-yield bonds, raising concerns about their risk and the need for credit ratings. Despite defaults in the market, market participants believe a lack of credit rating doesn't necessarily spell trouble, and investors should do their homework before investing. Experts advise focusing on high-quality issuers, reviewing financial ratios and cash flow, and understanding the issuer's business and management team. While some institutional investors avoid unrated bonds, retail investors are exercising discretion, with some bonds receiving final order books larger than others despite lower yields.

images.alt_text: The strong demand from Singapore retail investors for high-yield instruments has raised concerns about whether they should be rated and how risky those instruments actually are.

site_title: OKP wins S$54.7m LTA contracts
summary: OKP Holdings, a subsidiary of Eng Lam Contractors Co Pte Ltd, has won two contracts worth S$54.7 million from the Land Transport Authority (LTA) for road resurfacing works on seven major expressways in Singapore. The contracts, valued at S$64.5 million for 2016, boost the company's net construction order book to S$376.8 million, with contracts set to be completed by June 2018. This win follows Eng Lam's award of a S$9.8 million contract in February for drainage improvement works.

site_title: 'Abenomics' doubts drive foreigners off Japanese stocks, volatility spikes
summary: Foreign investors are fleeing Japanese stocks due to doubts over 'Abenomics' and a weak economy, leading to a surge in volatility. Since January, foreign investors have sold 4.5 trillion yen in Japanese cash equities, causing the benchmark Nikkei share average to fall 13% this year. The yen's rebound has also raised concerns about exporters' earnings, while worries over a possible credit rating downgrade have led investors to reassess Japanese risk. Analysts expect no change in Bank of Japan policy at its upcoming meeting, but the uncertainty has sparked fears of more volatility.

site_title: NYK to buy into Emas Chiyoda (Amended)
summary: Japanese shipping giant Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK) is acquiring a 25% stake in Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS), a subsea joint venture between Singapore-listed company Ezra Holdings and Japanese contracting group Chiyoda. Ezra Holdings will retain 40% and Chiyoda 30% shareholding. The transaction value was not disclosed. This acquisition marks NYK's entry into the subsea joint venture market.

images.alt_text: Japanese shipping giant Nippon Yusen Kabushiki Kaisha (NYK) is acquiring a stake in the subsea joint venture (JV) between Singapore-listed company Ezra Holdings and Japanese contracting group Chiyoda.

site_title: Orlando gay club carnage: Pulsing music, strobe lights, then gunfire
summary: A mass shooting occurred at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Florida, on June 12, 2016, resulting in 50 deaths and 53 injuries. The shooting, which began around 2 am, was initially mistaken for part of the music or a drumbeat, but patrons soon realized it was gunfire. Panic ensued as people tried to escape, with some crawling out of the front or back of the club, while others sought shelter in the bathroom. A three-hour standoff ensued before police used an armored vehicle to ram down part of the building, killing the gunman. The victims were mostly patrons of the club, many of whom were from the LGBT community, who had gathered for a celebration after the annual Gay Days event.

site_title: Wanted: Oil traders who know China, with good heads for liquor
summary: Chinese independent oil companies are poaching staff from state giants and global firms to handle the influx of crude imports, worth up to US$50 million a day. These companies, known as "teapot" refiners, are processing 10% of China's inbound shipments, and could reach 20% by the end of the year. The move is driven by the freeing up of China's crude import trade and offers better pay and perks. Global firms are also raiding state giants for talent, marking the beginning of a talent war in the industry.

site_title: Obama brands Orlando attack an act of 'terror' and 'hate'
summary: President Barack Obama has condemned the Orlando nightclub attack as an "act of terror and hate" that killed 50 people, the deadliest mass shooting in US history. Omar Mateen, the 29-year-old gunman, pledged allegiance to the Islamic State group before the attack. Obama called for unity and resolve to defend the people, while also highlighting the need for stricter gun control laws. The attack is fueling debate over guns, gay rights, and national security, with Republican candidate Donald Trump expected to focus on national security in a speech on Monday.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust looks to take manager in-house for S$50m (Amended)
summary: Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) is considering bringing its trustee-manager, Croesus Retail Asset Management, into its fold. The proposed internalisation, valued at S$50 million, may be the first of its kind for an SGX-listed Reit or business trust. The move aims to reduce costs and increase efficiency.

site_title: UK police say Russia fans were armed for fight: reports
summary: UK police say that Russian football fans were armed for a fight during clashes with English fans in Marseille. Assistant Chief Constable Mark Roberts stated that hundreds of "Russian troublemakers" were involved, wearing gum shields, martial arts gloves, and carrying knives. The clashes were described as "extremely well-orchestrated" and resulted in one England fan being stabbed. Roberts warned of possible clashes in Lille later in the tournament and said that video evidence would be handed over to French authorities to track down Russian hooligans.

images.alt_text: The head of Britain's Euro 2016 policing operation on Sunday said Russian football fans attacked their English rivals wearing gum shields, martial arts gloves and carrying knives.

site_title: India's cash-rich firms may deepen govt bond market, but spur volatility
summary: India's largest IT company, Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), has invested $3 billion in government bonds, joining Reliance Industries and Larsen & Toubro as the third conglomerate to do so. This trend could boost the government debt market but also create volatility. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has expressed support for diversification, but will monitor the market for potential risks. With India's top six cash-rich companies holding $34.56 billion in cash, investing in government bonds offers a safer alternative to declining mutual fund and bank deposit returns.

images.alt_text: An employee of Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) is seen at the company headquarters in Mumbai. India's largest information technology company, Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), has become the third conglomerate to invest large cash holdings in government bonds, a trend that could boost the young debt market but also stir volatility.

site_title: France bans alcohol near Euro 2016 venues after violence
summary: The French government has banned alcohol near Euro 2016 venues and fan zones following three days of drunken violence among fans in Marseille. The Interior Minister, Bernard Cazeneuve, announced the ban to prevent similar incidents, citing the unacceptable violence as "unacceptable for the authorities, society, and football lovers." More than 30 people were injured in the clashes, and UEFA warned Russia and England that they risked being ejected from the tournament if the violence continued. The ban includes public areas, shops, and bars.

site_title: No evidence of direct Islamic State link to Orlando shooting: US officials
summary: US officials say no direct evidence links the Islamic State to the Orlando nightclub shooting, despite the group's claim of responsibility. The shooter, Omar Mateen, had leanings towards Islamic State, but a direct connection remains unproven. The FBI is investigating the motive, which may have been inspired by Islamist militants. The incident occurred during Ramadan, a holy month called for attacks by Islamic State.

site_title: Governing for performance
summary: A company's effective board governance is crucial for delivering value to shareholders and stakeholders while ensuring the company's safety. However, many boards fail to meet their governance responsibilities, leading to poor performance. This can result in shareholders and stakeholders not receiving the returns they expect. Effective board governance is essential for companies to create value within the rules set by the government and society.

site_title: Uefa threaten Russia and England with Euro exit if more violence
summary: Uefa has threatened to kick Russia and England out of the European Championship finals if their fans are involved in more violence. Following three days of violence in Marseille, including pitched battles between Russian and English supporters, dozens of people were injured. A Uefa inquiry will recommend punishment, with the potential disqualification of teams if violence occurs again. The British government has offered to send more police to France, while Russia's Sports Minister blamed the match organisers for failing to separate supporters.

site_title: Assault rifle used in Florida shooting drives US gun control debate
summary: A mass shooting in Orlando, Florida, on June 12, 2016, resulted in 50 deaths and 53 injuries, with the shooter using an AR-15 style assault rifle. The incident has reignited the US gun control debate, with opponents arguing that civilians should not own "weapons of war" and backers claiming they are modern rifles enjoyed by law-abiding Americans. The use of assault rifles in at least 10 mass shootings since 2011 has made them a focal point in the debate, with some politicians calling for a ban on these firearms and large-capacity ammunition magazines.

site_title: Sterling net shorts double - biggest rise in 5 years
summary: Sterling net shorts more than doubled to 66,299 contracts, valued at nearly US$6 billion, in the week ended June 7, the largest net short position in three years. This surge in bets against sterling comes two weeks ahead of the UK referendum on EU membership. Hedge funds and asset managers have taken a defensive stance, indicating a potential decline in the value of sterling. The significant increase is the largest since September 2011.

site_title: Copper market goes bearish as metal floods LME warehouses
summary: Copper prices have declined 11% since April, with warehouses tracked by the London Metal Exchange (LME) seeing a record increase in metal. Copper inventories have fallen 1.2% and are down 28% from a peak in March. Money managers are now betting on further declines, with some predicting the metal may test its year's lows. The decline has also led to losses in copper producers, with the Bloomberg World Mining Index slipping 2.1%.

site_title: US plans to overhaul emergency oil reserve
summary: The US plans to overhaul its Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR), a network of underground salt caverns holding 695 million barrels of emergency oil supplies. The goal is to modernize the system, allowing for faster releases, and address issues caused by the North American oil boom and aging infrastructure. The Energy Department will submit a report to Congress with proposed changes, including building additional terminals and docks to ship oil more quickly. The overhaul aims to improve the SPR's ability to prevent price spikes and maintain national security.

site_title: BP spins off Norway business into billionaire's oil explorer
summary: BP has sold its Norwegian oil fields to Aker BP ASA, a company controlled by billionaire Kjell Inge Roekke, in a 10.8 billion kroner (S$1.8 billion) stock deal. The new business will be the seventh-largest producer in Norway, with daily oil and natural gas output of about 122,000 barrels of oil equivalent. Aker ASA will hold 40% and BP will retain 30%.

site_title: Fed's rate decision key to market volatility
summary: The Federal Reserve's rate decision is crucial in addressing market volatility amid concerns of deflation. Despite Fed Chair Janet Yellen's promise not to raise rates, investors remain uncertain due to weak jobs growth in May and a surge in safe-haven assets. A looming threat to traditional industries, such as malls and the taxi industry, is attributed to technological changes. The election of Donald Trump, who appeals to workers displaced by technology, adds to market uncertainty. Small-cap stocks are quietly outperforming, hinting at a potential shift in market sentiment.

site_title: Thailand's king shows improvement following heart treatment: palace
summary: Thailand's 88-year-old King Bhumibol Adulyadej has shown signs of improvement following surgery for narrowing of the arteries, according to the palace. The king's heartbeat, breathing, and blood pressure were normal, with an electrocardiogram showing an increased supply of blood to the heart. This follows a year-long hospitalization and comes after the palace stated that treatment had "satisfactory results" on June 7.

site_title: Siemens CEO says not interested in robot maker Kuka
summary: Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser stated the company has no interest in acquiring German robot maker Kuka, despite a 4.5 billion euro takeover bid by Chinese home appliance maker Midea. Midea's bid has sparked debate over Chinese takeovers in Europe and prompted German politicians to consider the impact on the digitalization of German industry. Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel has been in talks with German car manufacturers and Siemens about a possible counter-bid, but the idea has met with little enthusiasm. Midea's CEO Andy Gu assured that Kuka would remain independent.

site_title: StarHub: In the business of answering society's call for help
summary: StarHub, Singapore's third telecommunications company, has been giving back to the community since its inception in 2000. The company has launched various initiatives, including the Sparks Fund, which donates 1% of IDD revenue to help the less privileged. StarHub has also sponsored office skills training programs and provided volunteer opportunities for its employees. Additionally, the company promotes environmental sustainability through its RENEW e-waste recycling program, which has won awards and ranked the company among the most sustainable globally.

site_title: Buying by company directors plunges
summary: Singaporean company directors significantly reduced buying activity, recording only 11 purchases worth S$0.59 million from June 6 to 10, down from 23 firms and S$1.95 million the previous week. In contrast, buyback activity remained high, with 18 companies posting 90 repurchases worth S$66.7 million. The low insider activity led to a surge in buybacks, with significant trades recorded in Asiatravel.com Holdings and Singapore Airlines Limited.

site_title: Giant cargo ship used to test expanded Panama Canal
summary: A giant Neopanamax-class cargo ship, the MN Baroque, successfully passed through Panama's expanded canal, marking a significant milestone in the nine-year, $5.3 billion expansion project. The ship, measuring 255 meters long and 43 meters wide, is designed to fit the new locks and can carry more than twice as much cargo as older Panamax ships. The expansion, completed two years late, is set to be officially opened on June 26 with a ceremony led by Panama President Juan Carlos Varela and attended by 70 heads of state.

site_title: Hong Kong eyes shipping boost from China's new silk road, Iran
summary: Hong Kong's shipping trade is expected to benefit from China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative, which aims to boost trade and transport links across Asia and beyond. The city's crucial shipping trade is hoping to tackle the downturn in the seaborne sector and tougher competition by targeting Asia and the Middle East, particularly Iran, after international sanctions were lifted. Hong Kong's container throughput is estimated to grow 4.1% this year, and freight activity with Iran is expected to include food products and consumer goods.

site_title: ABN Amro banker sees pullback of easy credit in trade finance
summary: A top executive at ABN Amro in Asia says that easy credit in trade finance has pulled back due to increased anxiety over counterparty risks, particularly in China. The region's complex economic situation, including ongoing reform to tackle overcapacity, and liquidity chasing yield across various inflationary assets, has led to a slowdown in physical tonnage and lower revenues. The fraud at Qingdao port and the end of arbitrage between onshore and offshore renminbi rates have also contributed to the volatility. As a result, banks are becoming more cautious and focusing on "solid brick-and-mortar transactions" and niche traders.

images.alt_text: "It's rather tempting to go aggressive, because if all I have is a bank risk, why do I care so much? But then you start to have nasty cases - where there is fraud, where people contest and dispute." - Jacqueline Chang, regional head of commodities Asia, ABN Amro

site_title: 1999: Say goodbye to the 20th century
summary: The European Union introduced the euro as its official currency on January 1, 1999, marking a new era of economic union. The currency debuted with a 2% jump in value, boosting European stocks and bonds. Concerns about the Y2K bug, which was largely mitigated, and the creation of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) were also notable events. The euro solidified its status as a major international currency, joining the US dollar, British pound, and Japanese yen, but the European sovereign credit crisis in the following decade would later challenge these early successes.

site_title: Renovation boss wishes he'd started even earlier
summary: Shane Ng, founder of Singapore-based renovation firm One Stop Builders (OSB), wishes he had started his business earlier. At 36, Ng credits his youthful energy and fewer family commitments for his success. Despite facing difficulties, including losses in the first two years, Ng persevered and expanded his business to include two subsidiaries. He aims to expand to Jakarta by the end of the year and eventually establish offices across South-east Asia.

site_title: Air France says 77% of flights maintained amid pilot strike
summary: Air France reported that 77% of its flights remained operational despite a pilot strike involving over a quarter of its pilots. The strike, which began on Friday, coincided with the European soccer championship and was sparked by demands for more work hours without additional pay. The airline aims to maintain 83% of scheduled long-haul flights and 86% of domestic flights on Sunday, with plans to operate over 85% of flights on Monday. The strike is estimated to cost the airline tens of millions of euros, with the union demanding a 11% increase in pilot pay.

site_title: Hitler's Mein Kampf seems to be suddenly in demand again
summary: Adolf Hitler's autobiography "Mein Kampf" has become a bestseller in Europe after a German state copyright expired, making the book widely accessible. The Italian newspaper Il Giornale distributed copies of the book, sparking criticism from Jewish groups, who deemed it "squalid" and "indecent." The publisher claims the annotated version aims to prevent past mistakes, while critics argue it may be used to downplay Hitler's crimes. A right-wing publishing company plans to release an unannotated version, which could face prosecution under German law.

site_title: Brexit referendum outcome too close to call
summary: The UK public opinion on whether to stay in the European Union is too close to call, with recent polls showing 44% support for remaining in the EU and 42% support for leaving, according to a weekend survey. Prime Minister David Cameron warned that a Brexit would lead to a "lost decade" of uncertainty and economic stagnation. The Leave camp has gained momentum, with the UK Independence Party's Nigel Farage claiming that people are "putting two fingers up" to the establishment. The UK's economic future hangs in the balance as the country prepares for the June 23 referendum.

site_title: Junk bonds seen leading comeback for beaten Norway oil services
summary: Norway's junk bond market, heavily impacted by the oil price drop, is showing signs of recovery. Negotiations with bondholders have led to better recovery rates, prompting DNB ASA to reassess its view on the market. Companies such as Seadrill and Polarcus have reached agreements, while others like Prosafe are still negotiating. While the industry still faces challenges, the market's recovery suggests a shift towards a more balanced outlook, with bond prices rising after hitting a low. Shareholders, however, are expected to continue struggling with the industry's oversupply of rigs and vessels.

site_title: Renewables seen maintaining growth
summary: Renewable energy capacity is expected to maintain its share of global installed generation capacity, despite a drop in fossil fuel prices. By 2040, renewables are projected to make up 56% of global installed capacity, with the cost of onshore wind and solar expected to decrease by 41% and 60% respectively. The growth of renewables is expected to reduce demand for gas-fired power plants, but the liquefied natural gas market is expected to continue growing at 3% per year. Coal demand is expected to decline due to China's moratorium on new coal-fired power and a slowdown in electricity demand.

site_title: Hooliganism taints the Beautiful Game again
summary: England and Russia drew 1-1 in their Euro 2016 opener, but the match was marred by hooliganism. After Russian defender Vasili Berezutski's injury-time equalizer, Russian fans charged at English supporters, tearing flags and hurling projectiles. The incident led to UEFA launching disciplinary proceedings and warning of potential disqualification. The violence was part of a broader security concern ahead of the tournament, which is being held in France amidst terrorism fears and labor unrest.

images.alt_text: Barely moments after Russian defender Vasili Berezutski headed in an injury-time equaliser to deny England what would have been an undeserved victory, scores of fans - those of the hooligan variety - decided to take matters into their own hands.

site_title: Cityneon riding high on marvellous transformation
summary: Cityneon Holdings, a Singapore-based company, has seen its share price more than double this year after securing exclusive deals with the Avengers and Transformers franchises. The company's executive director, Ron Tan, attributes the growth to the acquisition of Victory Hill Exhibitions, which has enabled the company to develop interactive exhibitions based on popular movie franchises. However, Tan notes that expanding to a third franchise will depend on expanding the company's creative talent and bandwidth, as he currently lacks depth. Despite the risks, Cityneon is optimistic about its prospects, with Tan stating that he is selective about which franchises to pursue and is focused on scaling up its exhibitions business first.

site_title: EU leaders and bureaucrats under pressure to reform the union
summary: EU leaders are under pressure to reform the union amid growing disenchantment among the populace, particularly in member nations following the Brexit debate. A Pew Research Center poll found that only 51% of respondents in 10 EU nations have a favorable view of the EU, with 42% wanting more power returned to national capitals. The poll's results suggest that the EU establishment may acknowledge the need for reform, with German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schauble warning that a Brexit could be a "wake-up call" for the EU to address its problems.

site_title: Focus likely to shift from US Fed to Brexit
summary: The Singapore stock market is expected to focus on the Brexit referendum outcome, with a "leave" vote potentially triggering dire consequences for financial markets. Analysts predict a spike in UK unemployment and inflation, economic growth and currency decline, and a spillover impact on Europe. Despite this, a "remain" outcome is considered more likely, with some observers advising clients to position themselves accordingly by buying banks and oil and gas plays. The local market's index has been criticized for not being representative of the economy, but its representation is now required.

site_title: Yangon building's 'rebirth' points way for city's crumbling heritage
summary: A colonial-era building in Yangon, Myanmar, known as "491-501 Merchant Street," has received a $325,000 facelift, transforming it into a hub of interfaith cooperation and community activity. The building, home to 80 residents and various businesses, is seen as a model for preserving the city's crumbling heritage. Conservationists hope the project will serve as a blueprint for saving other architectural treasures in the city, which currently lacks laws to protect its recognized 189 heritage sites.

site_title: S i2i CEO's goodwill gesture pays off
summary: S i2i CEO Maneesh Tripathi volunteers to take home S$1 per month until the firm turns a profit, demonstrating his alignment with shareholders' interests. The company, a watch-list firm on the Singapore Exchange, posts a profit of S$960,000 in 2015 after years of losses. Tripathi's gesture is seen as a rarity in corporate Singapore, where big divides between executive pay and firm health are common. The firm's efforts to fortify its distribution network in Indonesia and cut costs lead to a 30% savings and layoffs. S i2i exits the watch-list group after its market capitalization rises above S$40 million.

site_title: Pioneers to get letters on Medisave top-ups from June 13
summary: The Singapore government will send letters to 430,000 Pioneer Generation individuals starting June 13, informing them of Medisave top-ups ranging from $200 to $800, totaling about $190 million. These top-ups will be credited to their Medisave accounts in July.

site_title: L'Oreal turns to Big Data to win customers
summary: L'Oreal, a French cosmetics giant, has opened a tech incubator in San Francisco to leverage Big Data and algorithms to improve its products and connect with customers. The team, led by Guive Balooch, has developed innovations such as an individualized makeup foundation and a virtual reality makeup application, which has been downloaded 20 million times. L'Oreal is also using data analytics to stay on top of trends and better understand fashion trends through its online advertising deal with Google.

site_title: Do good when doing well
summary: Businesses can integrate corporate giving into their strategies to create lasting impact on communities. Companies like OCBC Bank, Ernst & Young, and FairPrice have adopted systematic approaches to philanthropy, leveraging their time, people, and networks to drive social value and competitive advantages. By defining their purpose and embedding corporate social responsibility into their DNA, businesses can create a culture of giving that benefits both the community and the bottom line. This approach can also foster employee engagement, improve reputation, and drive business growth.

site_title: Need we fear a tech bubble?
summary: The tech industry experienced a downturn in the first quarter of 2016, with high-profile unicorns facing layoffs, down rounds, and declining valuations. Only five US venture-backed companies reached the $1 billion valuation mark, while others saw significant markdowns, such as LinkedIn's 40% share price drop and Dropbox's 51% valuation decrease. This suggests that the current technology boom may be different from previous ones, with valuations still stretched despite the challenges.

site_title: Welcome to where negative rates are normal
summary: Denmark, a pioneer in unconventional monetary policy, has been experimenting with negative interest rates since 2012. The country, known for its high standard of living and low unemployment, has seen a steady decline in interest rates, with the deposit rate currently at -0.65%. Despite concerns from mainstream economists, Denmark's central bank has reported no significant negative consequences, with bank earnings and cash circulation levels remaining stable. The experiment is being closely watched by central bankers, who may consider negative rates as a viable monetary policy tool, but experts caution that it's a delicate balancing act.

site_title: China's plan for college spots for poor ignites class conflict
summary: China's government has sparked widespread protests and class conflict by announcing a plan to admit more students from impoverished regions to top universities, while limiting spots for students from affluent cities. The plan, which sets aside 140,000 places, has been met with fierce backlash from parents who feel they are being unfairly denied access to better education. Demonstrations have taken place in at least two dozen cities, with protesters demanding fairness in education and equal opportunities for all. The government's efforts to address inequality in education have been seen as a challenge to President Xi Jinping's "China dream" of national rejuvenation.

site_title: Daimler to unveil long-distance electric car in October
summary: Daimler plans to unveil a long-distance electric car at the Paris Motor Show in October, with a 500-kilometer range. The company's chief development officer, Thomas Weber, confirmed that the prototype is ready and teams are working on the car, with a potential launch in this decade. Daimler aims to sell over 100,000 electric cars by the end of the decade, following investments by European rivals and the German government's subsidies for electric vehicles. The company also plans to launch a fourth-generation electric Smart car and a fuel cell-powered SUV next year.

site_title: Silicon Valley startup takes on Chinese hackers
summary: A Silicon Valley startup, Area 1, is tracking Chinese hackers using a small-town business's computer server. The hackers use the server to plan and stage attacks, but Area 1's sensors detect their activity and provide insights to block them. The C0d0s0 group, a collection of hackers for hire, has breached numerous companies, including banks, law firms, and tech companies. The market for threat intelligence is expected to reach $1 billion next year, with companies like Area 1 offering services to track hackers and thwart attacks before they happen.

site_title: 50 people killed in massacre at Florida gay nightclub; terrorism suspected
summary: A gunman killed 50 people and injured 53 in a massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida, early Sunday. Omar S. Mateen, identified as a potential Islamic State militant, was shot dead by police after a three-hour standoff. The attack, described as a terrorism incident, is the deadliest mass shooting in US history, surpassing the 2007 Virginia Tech massacre. Authorities are investigating the motive, but officials say they consider it an act of terrorism.

site_title: Kuwait orders probe into US Dow Chemical deal
summary: Kuwait has ordered a probe into a scrapped deal with US firm Dow Chemical, worth $17.4 billion, that resulted in a $2.2 billion fine. The government scrapped the deal in 2008 due to a political dispute, and the International Chamber of Commerce later ordered Kuwait to pay the penalty. The government paid the fine in 2013, despite parliament's warning to conduct a probe first. A parliamentary probe report in December charged officials with squandering public funds and making illegal profits, prompting the government's decision to investigate.

site_title: Bonds pip equities in fundraising by firms as investors chase yield
summary: Investors in Singapore are favoring high-yield bonds and perpetual securities (perps) over equity fundraising, driven by low interest rates and market volatility. Recent issuances by Hyflux, Oxley Holdings, and Perennial Real Estate have raised more funds than their market values, with some being oversubscribed. Corporates are shifting away from bank loans and equity issuances towards debt instruments, citing easier access and higher returns. However, experts note that the perp market is still new and not yet a replacement for equity fundraising, with perps offering fixed payouts but also carrying an implicit obligation to call.

site_title: Newest LNG supership comes too late to the party
summary: The world's first modern liquefied natural gas (LNG) supership, PFLNG Satu, was launched last month, but its maiden voyage comes at a challenging time. The vessel was ordered in 2012 when LNG prices were over $15 per million British thermal units, but prices have since dropped by two-thirds to $4.62. This glut in supply has pushed spot LNG prices down, making it difficult for producers to maintain profitability. Despite this, Petronas, the company that ordered the vessel, believes the project is still viable in the long term, citing its ability to provide an additional supply point within its larger portfolio of LNG assets.

site_title: The 'burkini' stirs a swimming pool battle in small German town
summary: A small German town, Neutraubling, has banned swimmers from wearing burkinis at its public pool, citing concerns over modesty and hygiene. The decision was made after a young woman wore a burkini to a water aerobics class, prompting complaints from other women. Town officials stated that conventional swimwear, such as one-piece swimsuits or bikinis, is required. This ban is part of a larger cultural debate over the burkini's place in European public spaces, with similar bans reported in France and other countries.

images.alt_text: The burkini - covering a woman's entire body, except for the face, hands and feet - is becoming more popular.

site_title: China's corporate debt build-up could trigger crisis: IMF official
summary: China's corporate debt has reached 145% of GDP, a high level that could trigger systemic financial problems and a possible banking crisis, according to IMF official David Lipton. The debt issue is critical not just for China but also for the global economy, as disruptions in one country's economy can reverberate worldwide. Despite China's strong economy, little progress has been made in addressing corporate debt and restructuring, with state-owned enterprises accounting for 55% of corporate debt. The IMF urges China to act quickly to address the issue, warning that failure to do so could lead to lower economic growth, a banking crisis, or both.

site_title: British mining CEO faces criminal charges in Liberia
summary: British mining CEO Andrew Groves faces criminal charges in Liberia over allegations of a vast network of corruption, including paying $960,000 in bribes to gain a foothold in the country's iron ore industry. Groves denies the allegations, while former banker Richard Tolbert and Sable country director Klaus Piprek also face charges. President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has requested cooperation with British authorities, and an Interpol alert has been issued for Groves and Piprek. The case is seen as a major corruption probe, with Sable's payoffs allegedly leading to the passage of a 2010 law allowing the mining minister to declare concessions "non-bidding" areas.

site_title: Rebirth of Yangon building points way for city's crumbling heritage
summary: A colonial-era building in Yangon, Myanmar, has received a $325,000 facelift, showcasing a collaborative approach to restoring the city's crumbling heritage. The 80-resident building, known as '491-501 Merchant Street', features a diverse mix of businesses and residents. Experts hope this project will serve as a blueprint for saving other architectural treasures ravaged by years of neglect. With a new government in place, conservationists are optimistic about an urban rebirth, citing the building's successful renovation as a positive example for interfaith cooperation and community involvement in preservation efforts.

site_title: Soccer: France fans in party mode after Euro 2016 win
summary: France fans celebrated their 2-1 Euro 2016 opening win over Romania at the Stade de France, brushing aside security concerns. The home crowd, despite rail transport disruptions and a stormy evening, showed enthusiasm with over 90,000 police and security agents deployed to ensure safety. The match featured a late goal by Dimitri Payet and a pre-game ceremony celebrating French popular culture. Fans attended the match at the Stade de France or the giant fan zone near the Eiffel Tower, with no incidents reported.

site_title: 4 injured at Shanghai Airport after man throws explosives
summary: A man threw homemade explosives at the Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, injuring four passengers, including a Filipino citizen, and killing himself. The incident occurred near check-in counters in Terminal 2. Authorities are investigating the incident, which is rare at China's airports despite tight security. The explosives were reportedly in beer bottles and caused broken glass, leading to the injuries. The airport is operating normally, with three flights affected.

site_title: Hey, Siri, how will Apple keep up with Google and Amazon?
summary: Apple plans to unveil updates to its virtual personal assistant, Siri, at its Worldwide Developer Conference in San Francisco, aiming to keep pace with Google's Google Now and Amazon's Alexa. For the first time, outside developers will be able to integrate Siri with their apps, increasing its capabilities and making Apple devices more indispensable. The updates also include changes to Apple Music and operating systems, as well as a revamped music-streaming service. Apple aims to strengthen its ecosystem and drive sales from services, which have become the fastest-growing part of its business.

site_title: Whetting the appetite for more
summary: Paradise Teochew Restaurant, a new entrant in Scotts Square, offers a unique dining experience with its focus on traditional Teochew classics. The restaurant's dishes, such as suckling pig, Teochew yellow roe cold crab, and braised duck, are highly recommended. The atmosphere is lively, with attentive staff eager to serve. While some dishes, like steamed diced chicken wrapped in an egg white crepe, are less impressive, the restaurant's overall quality and variety earn it a 7-star rating, making it a must-visit for foodies.

site_title: Activists pushing rent control proposals for Silicon Valley
summary: Activists in Silicon Valley and the San Francisco Bay Area are pushing rent control proposals, driven by soaring housing prices and fears of the growing income gap. If successful, these campaigns would lead to the largest expansion of US tenant laws since the 1970s. California is leading the national charge, with advocates hoping it will lead to national change, according to law professor Michelle Wilde Anderson.

site_title: Tech, beauty intersect in Silicon Valley
summary: L'Oreal, a French cosmetics giant, has opened a tech incubator in San Francisco to leverage big data and algorithms to improve its beauty products and connect with customers. The incubator employs 24 people, analyzing data sets to develop innovative products, such as an individualized makeup foundation and a virtual reality makeup application. The company aims to stay on top of trends and improve its products, working with startups and technology firms, including Google, to gain insights into fashion and beauty trends.

site_title: Brexit decision too close to call
summary: A UK poll shows 44% of respondents support staying in the European Union, while 42% back leaving, with 13% undecided. US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew warns of negative economic outcomes and geopolitical instability if the UK votes to exit. The government reported 1.5 million people registered to vote in the final week before the June 23 referendum, with investors grapple with the possibility of a British exit, causing sterling to fall to its lowest point since April.

site_title: Thousands take part in street party for British Queen's 90th birthday
summary: Thousands of guests braved rain to attend a street party in front of Buckingham Palace to celebrate Queen Elizabeth's 90th birthday. The event, organized by her grandson Peter Phillips, featured over 600 charity representatives enjoying food and drinks, with the royal family making appearances, including Prince William, Kate, and Harry. The Queen thanked the crowds for their support and paid tribute to the charities represented, before joking she was ready to move on from the birthday celebrations.

site_title: Lawsuit alleges Glencore warehouse firm falsified zinc documents
summary: A US Federal Court has allowed a private antitrust lawsuit against Glencore to proceed, alleging that the company's warehouse firm, Pacorini Metals USA, falsified documents to manipulate the zinc market. The lawsuit claims Glencore and Pacorini sought to monopolize the market for special high-grade zinc, driving up its price. The judge cited allegations that Pacorini created false bills of lading and manipulated warehouse movements to influence LME prices, which could have serious violations of regulations. The case will proceed to the discovery phase, where both sides will gather evidence.

site_title: Lazard in control as push for Takata solution builds: source
summary: Lazard has taken control of Takata Corp's financial restructuring process, leading talks with carmakers on a solution to the airbag maker's safety recall. The Japanese airbag maker, at the center of the industry's biggest safety recall, has hired the US financial services firm to lead the restructuring process. Potential investors, including KKR and Ningbo Joyson Electronic Corp, have emerged, and carmakers may be bracing for the possibility of forgiving some of Takata's debts. The Japanese government is unlikely to intervene in a traditional Japan Inc. rescue, instead favoring an investor that can guarantee the safety of Takata's product supply.

site_title: India guessing over future of 'rock star' banker Rajan
summary: India is speculating about the future of Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Governor Raghuram Rajan, dubbed the "rock star" banker, whose three-year term ends in September. Rajan has remained tight-lipped about his intentions, while the government has not given any hints. Despite clashes with the Prime Minister's Hindu nationalist government over interest rates and personal attacks, Rajan has been credited with bringing stability to India's economy since his appointment in 2013. A decision on his future is expected in August, with some investors concerned about the uncertainty, but experts believe the RBI institution will ensure stability.

site_title: IMF urges China to tackle 'high' corporate debt immediately
summary: The International Monetary Fund's first deputy managing director, David Lipton, has urged China to address its high corporate debt, estimated at 145% of GDP, to avoid a "dangerous detour" in its transition to a consumption-oriented economy. China's debt has accelerated to 247% of GDP, with a possible $1.3 trillion in loans extended to non-sufficiently income borrowers. The IMF warns that China's plan to reduce debt through debt-to-equity swaps may not work, and that the country must tackle the issue quickly to prevent a debt bubble.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund's No 2 official urged China to take immediate steps to tackle rising corporate debt or risk "dangerous detours" during the country's transition to a consumption-oriented economy.

site_title: Chile's embattled salmon industry intensified antibiotic use in 2015: government
summary: Chile's salmon industry intensified antibiotic use in 2015, with the proportion of antibiotics to salmon production reaching the highest levels since 2007, despite a decrease in total antibiotic use. The industry faces pressure from international buyers and environmental groups, and the government has published antibiotic use per company for the first time. Large seafood companies such as Australis Seafoods and Cermaq reported high and low levels of antibiotic use, respectively. This comes as the industry faces additional losses due to algal blooms and protests from fishermen.

site_title: Oil down 3% as US drillers add rigs, strong dollar weighs
summary: Oil prices fell 3% on Friday, weighed down by a stronger US dollar and a rise in US oil drilling rigs. US oil drillers added three rigs, marking a second week of growth, despite supply disruptions and lower US production. Despite this, crude futures remain up nearly double from 13-year lows, supported by supply chain issues and lower production.

site_title: Brexit would shut UK out of EU trade zone: Schaeuble
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble warned that a Brexit would shut the UK out of the EU trade zone, citing the need for the country to follow EU rules to access the single market. This contradicts Brexit supporters' claims that Britain could negotiate similar deals to Norway and Switzerland. The EU accounts for 47% of British exports and 54% of imports, making a Brexit a costly and damaging move. Senior Labour figures, including Jeremy Corbyn and Ed Miliband, have urged voters to remain in the EU, citing concerns about workers' rights and economic instability.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte does not endorse summary killings: spokesman
summary: Philippine president-elect Rodrigo Duterte's spokesman has clarified that Duterte does not endorse extrajudicial killings, contradicting UN chief Ban Ki-moon's criticism of his plan to kill thousands of suspected criminals in six months. Duterte won the election on a law-and-order platform, offering large bounties to kill drug traffickers, but his spokesman emphasized that these measures are not a form of extrajudicial killings. The spokesman's statement aims to clarify Duterte's stance on the issue amidst international criticism.

site_title: Fujimori concedes defeat in Peru presidential vote
summary: Keiko Fujimori conceded defeat in Peru's presidential election to Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, with Kuczynski taking 50.12% of the vote. Fujimori, daughter of former president Alberto Fujimori, refused to give up despite court challenges, but ultimately accepted the results. Kuczynski called for unity in a country torn by the election, with Fujimori's party set to have a majority in congress from late July.

site_title: Mexico, Singapore leaders back TPP ratification
summary: Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto and Singaporean President Tony Tan agreed to promote the ratification of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) during their meeting in Mexico City. The two leaders aim to deepen bilateral relations and bolster ties between South-east Asia and Latin America. TPP backers claim the deal will slash tariffs and trade barriers for 40% of the global economy, establishing the largest free trade area in the world. The 12 participating countries, including Mexico and Singapore, must ratify the pact for it to take effect.

site_title: US dollar surges vs pound as 'Brexit' fears rise
summary: The pound sank 1.4% to US$1.4250 as investors sought refuge in the US dollar amid fears of a British exit from the European Union. A new poll showed 55% of Britons favor "Brexit", increasing market volatility. The dollar rose 0.6% to US$1.1251 per euro. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to leave interest rates unchanged, but will scrutinize its economic projections for guidance on monetary policy.

site_title: Clinton meets with Warren as they team up against Trump
summary: US Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton met with Senator Elizabeth Warren at Clinton's Washington, DC home, strengthening their joint efforts against Republican candidate Donald Trump. Warren, a Massachusetts senator, endorsed Clinton the day before, and the two discussed advancing progressives' agenda and stopping Trump. Warren's endorsement could help Clinton rally progressive voters who initially supported Bernie Sanders in the primary, and Clinton has hinted at seeking Warren's input on issues like Wall Street regulation. Warren, who has been mentioned as a potential running mate, has said she's qualified for any post and is ready to work against Trump.

site_title: Why Line's two-year wait for IPO cost it US$4b in valuation
summary: Line Corp, Japan's leading mobile messaging service, has finally launched an initial public offering (IPO) after a two-year hiatus. The company aims to raise up to $1.43 billion in July, valuing itself at around $5.5 billion, despite a 40% decline in valuation since its initial filing in 2014. Line plans to use the proceeds to expand its user base beyond Japan, Taiwan, and Thailand, where it dominates, and eventually enter the US market. The company faces stiff competition from larger rivals like Facebook and China's WeChat, with its asking price contrasting with the princely sums paid for rival messaging services.

images.alt_text: Line Corp has finally pulled the trigger on an initial public offering after a two-year hiatus. That period of hesitation may have cost the messaging service US$4 billion in valuation as Facebook Inc. began encroaching on its turf and markets cooled on technology company debuts.

site_title: Energy world's newest supership misses the boat on LNG pricing
summary: The world's first modern vessel for producing liquefied natural gas, PFLNG Satu, has struggled to find profitability due to the current low LNG prices. Ordered in 2012 when prices were over $15 per million British thermal units, the ship's maiden voyage coincides with prices down by about two-thirds. The vessel's production will add to the global supply glut, exacerbating the issue of low margins. Despite its advantages, floating LNG projects are facing a similar problem, with Royal Dutch Shell's Prelude facility also struggling to generate material cash.

site_title: US oil drillers add rigs for 2nd week in a row: Baker Hughes
summary: US energy firms added three oil rigs for the second consecutive week, bringing the total rig count to 328, up from 635 a year ago. The increase follows crude prices reaching an 11-month high of over $51 a barrel. Drillers had cut an average of 10 oil rigs per week, but the recent additions suggest a potential return to drilling after a near two-year slump. Analysts expect the rig count to remain choppy, with potential increases later in the third quarter to early fourth quarter.

site_title: Buffett's auction draws US$3.46m winning bid, tying record
summary: Warren Buffett's annual charity lunch auction drew a winning bid of US$3.46 million, tying the record set by an anonymous donor in 2012. The auction, which concluded in San Francisco, raised over US$20 million for Glide since 2000, supporting homeless and poor individuals. The top bidder and up to seven guests will dine with Buffett at New York's Smith & Wollensky steakhouse.

site_title: Google's Street View plans for India rejected by Home Ministry
