summary: India's Home Ministry has rejected Google's plan to include 360-degree imagery of roads, tourist attractions, and other locations in its Street View service due to security concerns. The decision comes after the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks, where attackers used photographic reconnaissance to identify targets. Google's camera-mounted cars were intended to collect images for its free service, but security agencies cited concerns that the service could be used by terrorists. Google India had no comment on the matter.

site_title: There's more to the UK's economic woes than Brexit
summary: The UK's economic woes may not be solely attributed to Brexit, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. Only one of 31 respondents said Brexit is the dominant factor behind weaker economic growth, with many citing an intensification of the fiscal squeeze, weak exports, and consumer spending as key contributors. Economic growth slowed to 0.4% in the first quarter, and construction orders declined, amid uncertainty. The Bank of England may not raise interest rates soon, with some policymakers expressing concerns about the data's accuracy.

site_title: Pistorius faces return to jail for lover's murder
summary: Oscar Pistorius, the South African Paralympic athlete, will appear in court for a sentencing hearing on Monday, facing a minimum 15-year jail term for murdering his girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp in 2013. Pistorius, 29, was released from jail last October on house arrest after serving one year of his five-year sentence for culpable homicide. The Supreme Court of Appeal upgraded his conviction to murder, and he faces a minimum 15-year term, with the possibility of a reduced sentence due to mitigating factors, including his disability.

site_title: Standard Chartered Europe CEO Richard Holmes to leave bank
summary: Standard Chartered Europe CEO Richard Holmes is leaving the bank after eight years, taking over responsibilities from Tracy Clarke starting August. Holmes will focus on philanthropy and consider non-executive board positions amid Bill Winters's management overhaul. Winters has replaced several executives, cut 15,000 jobs, and reduced regional heads to four, aiming to save US$2.9 billion in costs. The bank has been hit by loan impairments and falling revenue in emerging markets.

site_title: Japan mulls LNG bunker hub at Yokohama
summary: Japan is considering establishing an LNG bunkering hub in Yokohama, one of its major ports, ahead of the global sulphur cap imposed by the International Maritime Organization (IMO) in 2020. The hub aims to "harmonize" with other environmentally advanced ports in Asia and will be developed by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism (MLIT) with a steering committee. Japan is the world's largest importer of LNG, and the move is part of the government's strategy to develop an LNG market.

site_title: Gawker Media files for bankruptcy, to go up for sale
summary: Gawker Media, a pioneering online publishing company, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy and put itself up for sale after a $140 million court judgment against it in a lawsuit by former professional wrestler Hulk Hogan over a sex tape. Billionaire investor Peter Thiel, a co-founder of Facebook, bankrolled Hogan's lawsuit, raising concerns about wealthy individuals silencing the press. Gawker vows to continue operating its seven websites during the bankruptcy process, with media company Ziff Davis entering an agreement to buy its assets for under $100 million.

site_title: Cuba flights by six US airlines including SWA, AAL approved
summary: The US Department of Transportation has approved six US airlines to operate regularly scheduled flights to Cuba, starting this fall. The airlines are American Airlines, Frontier Airlines, JetBlue, Silver Airways, Southwest Airlines, and Sun Country Airlines. Flights will be available from six US cities, including Miami, Fort Lauderdale, Chicago, Philadelphia, and Minneapolis, to nine Cuban cities, excluding Havana. This marks a historic achievement in resuming scheduled air service to Cuba, which was previously limited to humanitarian and educational purposes.

site_title: Seoul prosecutors raid Lotte Group, casting new doubt over hotel unit IPO
summary: South Korean prosecutors raided Lotte Group, a country's fifth-largest conglomerate, amid a bribery investigation into a director. This has cast new doubt over Hotel Lotte's planned IPO, billed as the world's biggest this year. The hotel unit cut the deal size to $4.5 billion and pushed back the listing to July. The group also withdrew from a US-based bid for Axiall Corp, citing "difficult circumstances" and heated competition.

site_title: US: Stocks join global selloff as 'Brexit' fears mount
summary: US stocks plummeted 0.7-0.9% on Friday, joining a global selloff fueled by Brexit fears and concerns over global growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.7%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.9%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.3%. Banks and energy sectors were particularly hard hit due to declining bond yields and falling oil prices. Analysts attribute the decline to growing anxiety about the British referendum and its potential impact on global markets.

site_title: New chemical plant on Jurong Island to use adjacent factories' carbon emissions
summary: Novacap, a French chemicals group, is building a sodium bicarbonate plant on Jurong Island in Singapore, which will capture carbon emissions from neighboring industries. The plant, starting production in 2017, will use the captured carbon dioxide to produce sodium bicarbonate, raising the group's global capacity to 300,000 tonnes per year. This is the first large-scale plant in Singapore to utilize captured carbon emissions, and it aims to meet Asia's growing demand for sodium bicarbonate in healthcare, personal care, food, and industrial applications.

site_title: Q&M to spin off China unit on Catalist
summary: Q&M Dental Group has decided to proceed with the spin-off listing of its China unit, Q&M Dental Holdings, on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The spin-off unit, which operates dental hospitals and clinics, as well as a dental equipment and supplies distribution company, will be listed separately from Q&M's other businesses. The company plans to raise funds through the listing, which is expected to enhance its financial flexibility.

site_title: AT&T seeks to top Verizon as Yahoo reviews new bids
summary: AT&T has made a second-round bid for Yahoo's core internet assets, joining Verizon Communications Inc, as the company reviews new bids. Verizon's offer, valued at over $3.5 billion, is considered low compared to other bids at or above $5 billion. Other bidders include a group led by Quicken Loans founder Dan Gilbert and backed by Warren Buffett, and firms such as TPG Capital LP and Bain Capital Private Equity. A new shortlist of bidders will be assembled, with binding offers to be solicited in the coming days.

site_title: Time to relook emerging markets: Amundi
summary: Asset manager Amundi's head of global equities, Romain Boscher, advises investors to reconsider their underweight positions in emerging markets (EM), citing a "classic J curve story" where depreciated currencies boost competitiveness. Valuations in the region are also considered attractive. Boscher expects retail investors to drive "massive" growth in Asia and Europe's ETF market, driven by dollar asset diversification.

images.alt_text: OUT OF THE COLD: Amundi has an overweight call on EM, particularly for Latin America, Eastern Europe and Russia.

site_title: Maximum cool
summary: Mini's new convertible is the only premium open-air model in its segment, based on the new Mini three-door hatchback. The second-generation model boasts a bigger and wider cabin, 40mm extra knee space in the rear seats, and 25% more luggage space with the roof up. The fabric roof now opens and closes in 18 seconds, with a notification on the multi-function display when complete. The new design aims to balance style with refinement, marking a shift towards a more mature Mini brand.

site_title: Tesla under scrutiny for suspension breakdowns
summary: Tesla is under scrutiny from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration over suspension failures in its Model S luxury cars. The regulator has found that some customers who experienced issues were asked to sign confidentiality agreements, which is a concern. The issue has raised questions about the company's transparency and handling of safety issues. The investigation is ongoing, and Tesla has not commented on the matter. This is the latest issue to hit the electric car maker, which has faced criticism over other safety concerns and production issues.

site_title: Being the younger boss
summary: Younger managers often struggle to manage cross-generational conflict in the workplace, due to differing perspectives, work styles, and priorities. Baby Boomers view work as a means to an end, while Gen Y sees it as an expression of themselves. Gen X is often process-oriented, while Gen Y is more flexible. Subconscious bias and stereotypes can exacerbate conflicts, particularly when younger managers lead older workers. To overcome these challenges, managers must understand and engage with each generation's communication style and needs, and prioritize common goals to foster effective teamwork.

site_title: MOL treasury unit gets Singapore boost
summary: Mitsui OSK Lines (MOL) has secured Finance & Treasury Centre (FTC) status in Singapore, reducing corporate tax rates to 8% on fees, interest, and gains from qualifying services. This move aims to consolidate surplus funds and provide financial services to MOL's 36 regional companies, including forex and leasing arrangements. With FTC status, MOL projects its assets under management to grow to $500 million by 2021, creating more investments and jobs in Singapore, solidifying the city-state as a major maritime hub for the shipping company.

site_title: Riding the K-beauty wave
summary: Korean beauty trends continue to gain popularity worldwide, driven by star power, exotic ingredients, and Asian-centric formulations. Recent launches of new brands, such as History of Whoo and Crystal Moist, cater to various budgets and beauty goals. Korean consumers are known for their sophistication, resulting in innovative products with multi-step regimens and synergy between products. The popularity of K-pop and Korean dramas has also contributed to the global interest in Korean beauty. With investments and collaborations with international brands, Korean cosmetics are expected to remain a dominant force in the beauty industry.

images.alt_text: STAR POWER: Most K-beauty brands recognise and bank on the popularity of Korean entertainers; (above) Crystal Moist K-pop brand ambassador, Ju Eun Young

'What makes people focus on Korean beauty is the popularity of K-pop, Korean dramas and TV shows. As the stars, actresses, and TV personalities became more and more popular, fans abroad became interested in what beauty products they were using.' - Moonshot makeup creative director Jenny Park

site_title: NY regulator seeks details from Goldman on Malaysian fund: source
summary: New York state regulators have asked Goldman Sachs to provide details about its investigation into billions of dollars it raised for 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB), a scandal-hit Malaysian fund. The probe concerns compliance with US anti-money laundering law, specifically the Bank Secrecy Act, related to a $3 billion bond offering. Goldman Sachs has declined to comment, while US law enforcement officials are investigating whether the bank violated federal law after failing to flag a transaction in Malaysia. The investigation is part of a broader money-laundering probe in at least six countries involving 1MDB.

images.alt_text: New York state regulators have asked Goldman Sachs Group Inc for details about probes into billions of dollars it raised in a bond offering for a scandal-hit Malaysian fund, a person familiar with the matter said on Friday.

site_title: RMB outflow curbs continue - but there are other channels
summary: China's temporary suspension of RMB outflow sweeps by the authorities in January remains in force, causing operational cashflow issues for some corporates. However, banks are finding alternative channels, such as notional aggregation and intra-group payments, to help companies manage their "trapped" funds. Despite the restrictions, experts expect RMB internationalisation to continue, driven by China's economic initiatives like the "One Belt, One Road" project, and the PBOC may gradually relax controls on RMB outflows in the longer term.

site_title: EURO 2016
summary: France kicked off the 2016 European Football Championship, also known as EURO 2016, on June 10, 2016. The tournament, held in France, featured 24 national teams competing in various matches. The event is considered Europe's biggest football party, attracting millions of fans worldwide. The championship is scheduled to run until July 10, 2016, with the final match to be held at the Stade de France in Paris.

site_title: Europe: Stocks tumble most since February in sign of anxiety
summary: European stocks plummeted 2.4% in the largest decline since February, as investors sold risky assets ahead of monetary policy and political events in June. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index fell for the second consecutive week, with all but 16 stocks declining. Investors are cautious about the European Central Bank's potential decision not to increase stimulus measures over the summer. The euro-area stock volatility gauge jumped 17% for its biggest weekly gain since January.

site_title: Best World, Noble, oil & gas stocks in play as STI rises for 4th week
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 13 points to 2,822.97 for the week, marking its fourth consecutive weekly gain. Stocks in the oil and gas sector and Best World International, a beauty products seller, were among the notable performers. Despite the rise, liquidity remained low, with a total of 1.02 billion units traded on Friday. The implied probability of an interest rate hike at the Federal Open Market Committee meeting fell to zero, and analysts are now focusing on the June 23 Brexit referendum, with a "leave" vote expected to be disastrous for markets.

site_title: It's time to say 'Get lost' to bloggers
summary: Blogging has become increasingly popular, with various apps and platforms promising to help users become writers and gain an audience. However, the rise of blogging has led to a decline in reading and a lack of attention span. The article suggests that people are more focused on becoming writers rather than actually reading and writing. This phenomenon is often attributed to the ease and accessibility of blogging, which allows users to publish content quickly and easily.

site_title: Revealing Yamato's secrets to success
summary: Yamato, a Japanese logistics specialist, has successfully implemented a unique business model in Singapore that combines Japanese-style management with innovation. The company's Asia Business-Model Innovation Centre (ABIC) tests new technologies and studies ways to implement them in daily operations, resulting in customized solutions for various industries. Yamato's success lies in its "GEMBA" approach, which encourages employees to voice concerns and suggestions, leading to innovative services such as the popular "Ski TA-Q-BIN" service. The company's flexible management style, which empowers employees to make decisions, has fostered a culture of trust and autonomy.

site_title: Cut from a different cloth
summary: Kathryn Sargent, 41, has become the first female tailor to open her own bespoke shop on Savile Row, London, revolutionizing the street's gender imbalance in the luxury menswear industry. Her shop, which offers custom suits with fine fabrics and attention to detail, has attracted a diverse clientele, including younger customers who are more style-conscious and less rigid in their fashion choices. The move is part of a new wave of women entering the traditionally male-dominated world of Savile Row tailoring, with nearly two-thirds of students receiving the street's tailoring diploma since its introduction being women.

site_title: Embraer CEO steps down as 'planned' shift surprises investors
summary: Embraer CEO Frederico Curado steps down after 9 years, marking a planned transition, as the company faces increased competition in the regional jet market. Paulo Cesar de Souza e Silva will take over executive duties, and a full transition is expected by the end of the year. The company's stock fell 2.2% after the announcement, citing market momentum shift and stepped-up competition. Embraer is working to certify its E-Jet E2 family of jets and faces challenges from new competitors, including Bombardier's C Series and Mitsubishi's MRJ.

site_title: Chinese companies tightening hold on Virgin Australia in setback for SIA
summary: Chinese conglomerate Nanshan Group is buying 811 million shares of Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd, giving it a 20% stake in the airline, in a deal worth about A$268 million. This deal comes after HNA Group, the owner of Hainan Airlines Co, last month said it planned to buy 13% of Virgin Australia, potentially disrupting the airline's disparate shareholder structure and impact on key shareholder Singapore Airlines Ltd.

site_title: Russia unveils new navy icebreaker in Arctic military focus
summary: Russia has unveiled its new navy icebreaker, the Ilya Muromets, in Saint Petersburg, marking a significant move in Moscow's military focus on the Arctic. The 280-foot-long icebreaker is designed to aid naval deployment and escort ships in icy conditions. Russia's growing interest in the Arctic, driven by rising temperatures and mineral resources, has led to the construction of a series of icebreakers and military bases. The country aims to assert its dominance in the region, with plans to refurbish its Arctic air force and build a testing range for new technology.

site_title: Amazon muscles in on British grocery market with food delivery
summary: Amazon has launched its British version of AmazonFresh, a food delivery service, in central and east London, stepping up pressure on traditional supermarkets in the £178 billion grocery market. The service will initially offer a full grocery service from a distribution centre and use external carriers for deliveries. AmazonFresh vice-president Ajay Kavan said the company will be methodical in rolling out the service further, and analysts estimate Amazon could take up to 13% of all food sales in the UK by 2020.

site_title: All-weather protection
summary: HL Assurance's MobileCare insurance policy offers coverage for liquid or accidental damage to mobile phones, including repair or replacement costs, with savings up to S$1,000 on buying a new phone. Plans start from S$7.70 per month for 12 months of coverage, and include a "door-to-door express service" for convenience. The policy is designed for Singapore's highly effective economy, prioritizing time and convenience.

site_title: A draw might suit England and Russia
summary: England and Russia are set to face off in a crucial Euro 2016 match, with both teams seeking a point to boost their chances of advancing. England, led by manager Roy Hodgson, are favorites but face challenges in central defense, while Russia, under manager Leonid Slutsky, are well-organized and technically adept. Meanwhile, Wales and Slovakia, the other teams in Group B, are also vying for a spot in the next round, with Wales relying heavily on star player Gareth Bale and Slovakia looking to capitalize on their recent wins.

site_title: Instagram more popular advertising choice than Twitter: survey
summary: ADVERTISING agencies are increasingly turning to Instagram for social media ad campaigns, with the platform now surpassing Twitter as their preferred choice, according to a survey. The shift highlights Twitter's weakness in ad sales, which has been one of the few bright spots for the company. The survey comes as Twitter faces competition from faster-growing platforms like Snapchat. The findings also suggest that Instagram benefits from using its parent company Facebook's advertising technology.

site_title: China regulator rushes to meet MSCI deadline
summary: China's securities regulator has made efforts to meet MSCI's requirements for including yuan-denominated shares in its Emerging Markets Index, with two key demands satisfied, including restrictions on company share suspensions and foreign investor ownership rights. However, concerns remain unaddressed, and a decision on inclusion is uncertain. China has estimated that inclusion could draw $400 billion into its shares over the next decade. Despite investment banks being bullish on the inclusion, MSCI's concerns over rule removal and a Hong Kong-Shenzhen stock connect system remain unresolved.

images.alt_text: MR LIU: Under its new chairman, the China Securities Regulatory Commission has satisfied some of the key requirements of the MSCI.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here are concise 100-word or less summaries of the article content:

1. StarHub's recent share price recovery has led to a downgrade from "buy" to "hold" by OCBC Investment Research, citing a fair value of S$3.69. However, the company's foray into cyber security is seen as a positive move.

2. Mermaid Maritime's short extension of AOD I by two months at a lower day rate of US$125,000 a day has addressed concerns about cancelled jack-up rigs contracts. The company maintains its "add" call with a target price of S$0.16.

3. Japfa Ltd's private placement to KKR Jade Investments Pte Ltd has been viewed positively by DBS Group Research, lifting burden from the group's high net gearing ratio and supporting earnings growth potential.

site_title: CMA CGM buys out Temasek's NOL stake
summary: French shipping company CMA CGM has acquired over 78% of Singapore-based carrier Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) through a tender offer initiated by Temasek Holdings. The acquisition price is S$1.30 per share, valuing NOL at S$3.4 billion. CMA CGM has breached the 50% threshold for its voluntary general offer, making the takeover unconditional. The deal is expected to lead to NOL's delisting from the Singapore stock exchange later this year.

site_title: Time-starved people are happier: study
summary: A new study published in Social Psychological and Personality Science found that nearly two-thirds of Americans would prefer having more money over more time, but those who chose time were happier with their lives. Researchers surveyed over 4,400 people and found a consistent relationship between choosing time over money and happiness, regardless of factors like age, income, and family status. Even when controlling for the amount of money people already had, the study showed the same effect, suggesting that happiness may be more closely tied to time than money.

site_title: A happier workforce for higher productivity
summary: Singapore's economic success is threatened by its lacklustre productivity, with the country ranking 12th for "productivity and efficiency" in the 2015 World Competitiveness Yearbook. Researchers have found that happy workers are 12% more productive, while unhappy workers are 10% less productive. To boost productivity, Singapore can focus on creating a happier workforce through employer-led initiatives such as employee engagement, satisfaction, and non-monetary incentives. Workers can also contribute to their own happiness by following a "HAPPY" recipe, and the government can measure and promote workplace happiness through official statistics and public dialogues.

images.alt_text: PIONEERl: US Internet giant Google/ Alphabet has been on Fortune's list of top employers for 10 years, with 2016 being its seventh time at No 1.

site_title: Industry weighs radical shake-up of European drug pricing
summary: The European pharmaceutical industry is considering a radical shift in drug pricing, proposing a wholesale adoption of pricing based on clinical results. This move aims to reward companies for the clinical benefit of treatments rather than the number of pills sold. The European Federation of Pharmaceutical Industries and Associations (Efpia) will discuss the proposal on June 16, which groups the world's top drugmakers and national trade associations. The concept has gained support from industry figures, but there may be battles ahead as the industry seeks trade-offs, including relief from market mechanisms that weigh on drug prices.

images.alt_text: PRICING MATTERS: Mr Jimenez, the current president of Efpia, supports the pricing concept.

site_title: Up your Gangnam style with these Korean beauty products
summary: Korean beauty products are gaining popularity worldwide, with several high-end brands offering unique products. The Whoo Bichup Ja Saeng Essence balances yin and yang energies to improve skin health, while the Moonshot Microfit Cushion provides anti-darkening and cooling effects. The Crystal Moist Hydra Ion+ Moisturising Face Essence contains deep ocean mineral water and hyaluronic acid for hydration. A new Laneige product doubles as a makeup remover and skincare cleanser, revitalizing skin with antioxidant extracts. These products showcase Korean beauty trends and ingredients.

site_title: UK's Nassim GCB plots up for sale again
summary: The British government is relaunching two freehold Nassim Road Good Class Bungalow (GCB) plots from the Eden Hall residence in Singapore. The guide price has been revised downwards by around 20% from the initial S$2,200 psf to S$1,650-1,700 psf. The plots, carved out from part of the garden land, have a total site area of 34,254 sq ft and could accommodate a large bungalow with a smaller wing. The sale is expected to close in early August, with market watchers predicting a strong interest from potential buyers due to the recent improvement in property market sentiment.

site_title: Final tribute to 'The Greatest' unfolds in Muhammad Ali's hometown
summary: Muhammad Ali, the legendary boxer and social activist, was given a final tribute in his hometown of Louisville, Kentucky. Thousands gathered for a memorial and funeral procession, which ended at Cave Hill National Cemetery with a private burial. Former US President Bill Clinton and comedian Billy Crystal delivered eulogies, while actor Will Smith and former heavyweight champ Lennox Lewis served as pallbearers. Fans praised Ali's courage in speaking out for equality and his stance against the Vietnam War, with many expressing gratitude for his message of self-acceptance and empowerment.

site_title: Samsung Pay on the way, and a mobile-payment war brews
summary: Samsung Pay is set to launch in Singapore on June 16, marking the country's first adoption of the mobile payment platform in South-east Asia. The service, which uses proprietary Magnetic Secure Transmission (MST) technology, allows users to add credit and debit cards and make payments by holding their Samsung Galaxy smartphone near a merchant's contactless card reader. The launch comes as the mobile-payment space in Singapore heats up, with Apple Pay already available and Android Pay expected to follow. Experts say the key challenge will be adoption rates among consumers, with loyalty systems and partnerships with banks seen as crucial to success.

site_title: Philippines may join Asian sovereigns testing sukuk market
summary: The Philippines may issue Islamic bonds (sukuk) to diversify its debt profile, potentially joining other Asian sovereigns in the sukuk market. Success depends on pricing and Middle East investors' response. The country has a history of sukuk issuance and has discussed the format with investors in the past. A sukuk from the Philippines could widen the market, which is currently dominated by Malaysia and Indonesia. The incoming government plans to raise debt via sukuk and yuan borrowings to diversify its debt profile.

site_title: Central bank warns of Toronto, Vancouver housing risks
summary: The Bank of Canada has warned of significant risks to Canada's housing market, particularly in Toronto and Vancouver, where price gains are outpacing economic fundamentals. Governor Stephen Poloz stated that prospective homebuyers and lenders should not extrapolate recent performance into the future. The central bank pointed to a 30% year-over-year price gain in Vancouver and a 15% gain in Toronto, as well as rising mortgage debt. While the risk of a housing crash is considered elevated, the central bank believes it is still relatively low, citing a growing economy.

site_title: Timely makeovers
summary: Four existing eateries have undergone makeovers, transforming their personalities. Fat Lulu's, Thevar 2.0, The Social Kitchen, and CMC Markets' partner Sophia Women are among the establishments. Thevar 2.0 showcases mod-Indian cuisine, while The Social Kitchen now operates at Bank of Singapore. CMC Markets' partner Sophia Women aims to drive financial literacy for women. These revamps reflect the eateries' efforts to adapt and evolve, offering fresh experiences for customers and promoting their unique offerings.

site_title: Tiong Seng wins S$98.3m water pipeline contract
summary: Tiong Seng Contractors, a subsidiary of Tiong Seng Holdings Ltd, has won a S$98.3 million contract from Singapore's Public Utilities Board to supply and install a 4.6 km water transmission pipeline. The project will start on June 17, 2016, and is expected to be completed in 2019. This win marks the company's efforts to innovate and carve a unique proposition, differentiating itself from industry peers. The contract value is significant, with Tiong Seng Holdings holding the highest grading of A1 from the Building and Construction Authority for public sector construction projects.

site_title: Where are we in the roller coaster of investor emotion?
summary: The stock market is currently in a cautious phase, with investor sentiment ranging from neutral to slightly bullish. The American Association of Individual Investors reports that bullish sentiment among retail investors has averaged around 20% over the last few weeks, the lowest it has been in recent years. Meanwhile, a composite measure of US investor sentiment indicates a long way from euphoria. In Australia, shares are viewed as a poor investment choice, with only 7.6% of respondents naming them as the wisest place for savings. This cautious sentiment suggests that the market is not yet experiencing euphoria, but rather a state of "hope" and "relief".

site_title: Why I renewed my COE for five years
summary: A Singaporean car owner chose to renew their Category B car's COE for five years, opting against buying a new car or doing without a vehicle. The main reason was the rapid advancement of electric vehicles (EVs), which now offer superior performance, efficiency, and features over traditional internal combustion engine (ICE) cars. EVs accelerate faster, have more efficient engines, and are more reliable and cheaper to maintain. However, the high cost of batteries and limited charging infrastructure in Singapore remain concerns. The government plans to set up 2,000 EV charging points, and manufacturers are working to make battery charging easier and cheaper.

site_title: FLT prices IPO at top of range at S$0.89 per unit
summary: FRASERS Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) raised approximately S$464.4 million from its initial public offering (IPO) at S$0.89 per unit, pricing at the top of its range. The IPO aims to raise around S$1.27 billion in gross proceeds. FLT's placement tranche was oversubscribed by more than six times, and the trust's initial portfolio consists of 51 industrial properties in Australia, with a weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of 6.9 years, considered one of the best in Singapore's logistics and industrial Reits.

site_title: PropertyGuru unfazed by exit of strategic investor
summary: PropertyGuru, a Singapore-based property-search startup, has found new investors after a strategic investor, ImmobilienScout24, exited the business three years ago. Despite the departure, the company hopes to be profitable in 2017. PropertyGuru has secured a new consortium of investors, including TPG, Emtek Group, and Square Peg Capital, which will bring capital and expertise to the business. The company's co-founder and CEO, Steve Melhuish, believes that the exit was not a significant blow, and the new investors are committed to supporting the business for the next three to five years.

site_title: AIR POWER
summary: Mercedes-Benz has launched the high-performance Mercedes-AMG C63 Cabriolet, its first open-air model. Based on the C-Class Saloon platform, the C63 Cabriolet features a 4.0-litre V8 biturbo engine producing 510 hp and 700 Nm, with a 0-100 kmh sprint of 4.1 seconds. The AMG version boasts a unique composite structure, wider body, and redesigned rear axle. The C63 S also features a carbon fibre centre console and aluminium steering wheel paddles. The cabriolet has four driving modes and a clever Aircap system to minimize turbulence, making it an extraordinary convertible experience.

site_title: Genting Singapore's unlucky streak hits casino staff
summary: Genting Singapore's Resorts World Sentosa has laid off around 400 casino staff as part of a downsizing plan, citing the pressure of Chinese high rollers shying away from gaming tables due to Beijing's corruption crackdown. The move, part of a broader effort to cut costs, comes after the company reported a 4% drop in its stock price this year. In contrast, Las Vegas Sands has not announced any layoffs, with its headcount remaining at 9,600. The move highlights the challenges facing Singapore's casino industry, which generated $3.6 billion in revenue in 2015 and contributes 1.5-2% to GDP.

site_title: Tapping shared space synergies
summary: Two Singapore co-working spaces, The Great Room and Wonder Facility, cater to different mindsets. The Great Room, designed by hospitality specialist Distillery Studio, offers a stylish and refined environment with curated art, bespoke furniture, and amenities like a bar and yoga lessons. Members can choose from hot desks, private offices, and dedicated spaces. Wonder Facility, founded by artist Olivia Lee, is designed for the artistic crowd, with an industrial warehouse aesthetic and flexible workspaces. Both spaces offer day passes and membership options, targeting specific industries and personalities.

site_title: UK house prices expected to fall if Britain leaves EU
summary: UK house prices are expected to fall for the first time in nearly four years due to the European Union referendum and a new tax on landlords, according to a survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. However, most respondents still anticipate an increase in prices over the 12-month horizon. The survey also shows that UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high.

site_title: France kicks off Europe's biggest football party
summary: France kicked off the Euro 2016 football tournament, marking the beginning of a month-long celebration of the sport in Singapore. The quadrennial event, featuring 51 matches across 10 stadiums in France, will attract 2.5 million fans, with a record 24 nations competing. Fans in Singapore can follow the games through various channels, including cable TV, streaming services, and community screenings. The tournament's top two teams will meet in the final on July 11, with favorites including Spain and France.

site_title: Dad's day to shine
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

This Father's Day, consider gifting your dad something unique. Options include the DJI Phantom 4 drone ($1,953.28), a high-definition 4K video camera, the Philips S7710 Shaver ($369), a wet and dry shaving system, the Secretlab Omega Stealth chair ($499), an ergonomic gaming chair, the DGPower Death Star Magnetic Levitation Bluetooth Speaker ($289.90), a levitating speaker modelled after the Star Wars Death Star, the Changi Recommends Overseas Wifi Router ($5-$10 per day), a portable Wi-Fi router rental service, the Samsung Gear Fit2 ($298), a fitness tracker, and the Onkyo DP-X1 Digital Audio Player ($999), a high-resolution audio player.

site_title: For India's surging economy, small is beautiful
summary: India's economy is experiencing growth, driven by small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that are saving their way to growth, helping transform the country into the world's fastest-growing large economy. Despite stressed balance sheets at big firms, SMEs are investing in new machinery and expanding capacity, with sales growing 12% in 2014/15. The government's infrastructure push is also helping, with 10,000 km of new national highways and 50,000 km upgrades. However, major listed enterprises still need to come to the party to consistently grow at or above 8%, which is India's target to generate jobs for a rapidly expanding workforce.

site_title: mm2 hits all-time high on UnUsUaL listing plans
summary: mm2 Asia's shares reached an all-time high of S$0.70 after the company announced plans for UnUsUaL Pte Ltd to list on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The stock rose 4.5% following the announcement. This marks a 180% increase since listing in December 2014. The proposed listing is in its preliminary stages and is dependent on regulatory approvals and market conditions. mm2 Asia aims to expand its presence in the South-east Asia and North Asia markets through the acquisition of a 51% stake in UnUsUaL.

site_title: India's Adani eyeing bid for SunEdison solar assets
summary: Indian conglomerate Adani Group is considering a bid for US SunEdison's local solar assets, which could be worth an unknown amount. SunEdison, facing insolvency after a failed growth plan and $12 billion in debts, is expected to sell or seek equity partners for its 450 MW solar plants in India and other projects. Adani Green Energy, the renewable energy arm of Adani Group, aims to increase its solar generation capacity to 3,500 MW by next year, with plans to build a solar panel manufacturing plant in India.

site_title: Bond yields around the world fall to records on growth outlook
summary: Global bond yields have fallen to record lows due to a weakening economic outlook and political risks. Demand for government bonds remains high, with German 10-year bonds approaching zero yield and Japanese and Swiss bonds reaching new all-time lows. The Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Broad Market Index has gained 4.6% since December, while the World Bank cut its global growth outlook. The yield on the Bloomberg Global Developed Sovereign Bond Index dropped to 0.601%, and investors are seeking safe-haven assets amid Brexit risks and uncertainty.

site_title: China now rivals Europe, US as growth engine for Asian exports
summary: China has surpassed the US and European Union as the primary driver of export growth in neighboring economies, marking a significant shift in the economic pecking order since the 2008 global financial crisis. A record surge in credit in the first quarter has aided China's growth prospects, with the International Monetary Fund upgrading its forecasts for this year and next. China's currency gyrations, particularly the yuan, are increasingly important across the region, and the country's bond markets continue to influence Asian bond trading.

site_title: Sotheby's strikes deals with bidders as art market slows
summary: Sotheby's, a prominent auction house, has introduced a new incentive to attract buyers for guaranteed artworks, offering a fixed fee to those who agree to make a minimum bid before the auction starts. This move aims to reduce the risk of owning unsold artworks in a slowing market. The new perk is part of Sotheby's efforts to become more competitive with Christie's, following a change in leadership and a decline in the company's share value.

site_title: Toyota tells US dealers to disclose future Takata recalls
summary: Toyota has instructed its US dealers to disclose at the time of sale vehicles with defective Takata air bag inflators that will be subject to recalls by 2018. The list includes 2016 Toyota 4Runner and Lexus GX460, as well as new 2015 models from Lexus and Scion. The disclosure comes after criticism from lawmakers, including Senator Bill Nelson, who praised Toyota's move as a positive step for consumers. However, US Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx stated he lacks the authority to require such disclosures.

site_title: Angry banks complicate BOJ's ability to deepen negative rates
summary: The Bank of Japan faces challenges in expanding its stimulus program as major banks, particularly Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, express concerns over negative interest rates. The bank's decision to give up its status as a primary dealer of Japanese government bonds may complicate efforts to deepen negative rates, potentially forcing the central bank to continue printing money for longer. This move is seen as a sign of growing distaste among financial institutions, with some officials concerned about the impact on market liquidity.

site_title: Residential property owner taps crowdfunding for solar installation
summary: A Singapore residential property owner has successfully used crowdfunding to finance the installation of solar cells on her rooftop, marking a first in Asia. The project, launched on May 25, met its target of S$22,500 within 11 days and will produce 4.725 kilowatts of clean energy per year, equivalent to the carbon reduction of 120 trees. Investors will receive a 7% return on their principal amount upon maturity of the loan on June 30 next year.

site_title: GM to add 1,000 jobs in Canada, invest US$10m
summary: General Motors (GM) announced plans to create approximately 1,000 jobs in Ontario, Canada, as part of its research spending on connected and driverless cars. The company will also invest US$10 million in its Kapuskasing facility. Ontario's Economic Development Minister and GM's Canadian president have promoted the province as a hub for connected-car development. Unifor President Jerry Dias expressed concerns that the new jobs may not replace manufacturing jobs in existing plants, and warned of a potential strike in 2016 if new products are not promised.

site_title: Miners cut distressed debt pool by US$60b as recovery firms
summary: Mining companies have reduced the sector's distressed debt pool by at least $60 billion by selling assets and cutting dividends. This decrease has boosted the industry's outlook, driven by a bull market in commodities. The amount of metals and mining bonds trading at distressed levels fell from $86 billion in February to $26 billion. Companies such as Anglo American and Glencore have improved their balance sheets through asset sales and cost-cutting, alleviating concerns over debt.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on growth, Brexit fears
summary: US stocks tumbled on Friday due to declining government bond yields and Brexit fears. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.9% and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.1%. Analysts attributed the losses to "flight from risk" as investors shunned stocks for bonds. The losses were less severe than in Europe, where markets declined by 2% or more due to anxiety over the June 23 Brexit vote.

site_title: Airbus under new pressure over A400M as deliveries slip
summary: Airbus faces pressure from European buyers, including France, to meet performance and delivery deadlines for its A400M military transport plane. Delays in gearbox issues, incomplete defensive systems, and parachute operation limitations have raised concerns, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa and Iraq. France has written to Airbus, demanding clarity on resolving these issues by the end of the year, while German Defence Minister Ursula von der Leyen has threatened to exercise her country's right to compensation for delays. The A400M project, ordered by NATO members, is facing uncertainty and potential compensation claims.

site_title: AsiaMedic appoints new CEO
summary: AsiaMedic Limited has appointed Choo Kin Poo as its new CEO, effective June 10, 2016. Choo, with over 18 years of healthcare experience, will oversee strategies and policies, as well as the company's overall management and financial performance. His appointment is concurrent with his existing role at Luye Medicals Group, but he will dedicate time to AsiaMedic. Choo aims to lead the company to the next level, focusing on innovation, expansion, and enhanced services.

site_title: India's industrial output shrinks in April
summary: India's industrial output contracted 0.8% in April, its first decline in three months, due to a 25% drop in capital goods production and a 9.7% contraction in consumer goods. This marks a departure from economists' predictions of a 0.5% annual rise. The decline is attributed to the new method of calculating India's GDP, which focuses on gross value addition rather than industrial output. Despite this, the country's overall economy grew 7.6% in the fiscal year to end-March.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors to hire auditor to oversee errant tech unit: sources
summary: Mitsubishi Motors plans to hire an outside auditor to oversee its technology division, following recent cheating scandals on fuel economy tests and allegations of a culture of secrecy and arrogance within the unit. The move aims to modernize the division and prevent similar incidents in the future. The company has already made some changes, including restructuring and hiring Nissan experts, but the new auditor will provide additional oversight and ensure that engineers test technology and input data correctly. The goal is to increase transparency and openness to new ideas, as the auto industry faces increasing competitive pressures and stricter regulations.

site_title: Never too young to have heart disease
summary: Young adults, particularly men, are at risk of heart disease due to blocked arteries, with 20% having coronary artery disease (CAD) and 13 out of 1,000 developing a heart attack. Risk factors include family history, high LDL-C, smoking, and obesity. Unlike older patients, younger CAD patients are less likely to have warning symptoms, with three-quarters experiencing an impending heart attack or heart attack without chest pain. Long-term outcomes are poor, with high mortality rates associated with previous heart attacks, diabetes, and severely impaired heart function. Prevention and early intervention are key to reducing risk.

images.alt_text: AS GOOD AS NEW: Young adults with severe blockage of all three major heart arteries may have the option of opening the arteries with polymer stents. These stents eventually get absorbed by the body within three years, giving them "brand new" heart arteries.

site_title: Q & M Dental Group to spin off China unit on Catalist
summary: Q & M Dental Group has decided to proceed with the spin-off listing of its China unit, Q & M Dental Holdings, on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The spin-off unit includes dental hospitals, clinics, and a dental equipment distribution company in China. The group will seek shareholders' approval for the restructuring exercise and spin-off at an extraordinary general meeting. The listing requires certain restructuring steps, which will be announced at a later time. Q & M shares closed 1.3% lower at S$0.735 on the news.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore will become the first market in Southeast Asia for Samsung Pay, launching on June 16. A Singapore residential property successfully used crowdfunding to finance a solar installation, believed to be the first in Asia. Neptune Orient Lines' takeover by CMA CGM is now unconditional after Temasek Holdings tendered all shares. Singapore is prepared to prosecute Indonesian polluters under haze law, and the country's shares closed lower on the day but higher for the week.

site_title: Zurich's Greco reorganizes to streamline operations
summary: Zurich Insurance AG has reorganized its operations to streamline efficiency, merging its global life and general insurance units and reorganizing along geographical lines. New CEO Mario Greco, who took over in March, has implemented the changes to reduce costs, following a year of unexpectedly high claims. The company aims to cut costs by over $300 million this year and will provide an update on savings in the coming months. Greco's restructuring is seen as a necessary step to improve efficiency and earnings, following criticism of the company's complex structure.

images.alt_text: Zurich Insurance AG's new chief executive officer, Mario Greco, is shaking up the largest Swiss insurer after an unexpected jump in claims last year forced it to abandon a takeover and prompted his predecessor's exit.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth II begins 3 days of birthday celebrations
summary: Queen Elizabeth II began her 3-day birthday celebrations on Friday with a thanksgiving ceremony at St Paul's Cathedral, marking her 90th birthday. The monarch, accompanied by Prince Philip, attended the ceremony despite being delayed by traffic. Senior royals and politicians attended, with Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby praising the queen's "wonderful service". The celebrations will continue with a Trooping of the Colour ceremony on Saturday and a street party on Sunday, featuring representatives from the NHS, police, and charities.

site_title: IE Singapore to ink agreements in Mexico (Amended)
summary: IE Singapore to sign memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with Mexico's Secretariat of Economic Development and ProMéxico, a trade and investment promotion agency. The agreements aim to boost collaboration in infrastructure building, urban planning, innovation, and research, as well as trade and investment. This follows a state visit by Singapore President Tony Tan Keng Yam, with Mexico being the second-largest economy in Latin America and boasting a strong business environment, ranking first in the region for "ease of doing business."

site_title: Bill Gates: Chickens, not computers, can solve poverty
summary: Bill Gates, founder of Microsoft, suggests that raising chickens can be a more effective way to alleviate extreme poverty than relying on technology. In an interview on his website, Gates stated that having chickens can improve the lives of the world's poorest individuals. He believes that access to chickens can provide a reliable source of food, income, and empowerment. Gates' proposal emphasizes the importance of addressing the root causes of poverty, rather than solely relying on technological solutions.

summary:

Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, similar to H1's operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: France to formally ratify Paris climate accord on June 15: minister
summary: France's President Francois Hollande will formally sign the Paris climate agreement on June 15, making France the first industrialized nation to ratify the landmark accord. The Senate has authorized the government to ratify the agreement after a near unanimous vote in May. Several other industrialized nations are expected to ratify the agreement by the end of the year. The Paris climate agreement, reached by nearly 200 nations last December, aims to limit global warming.

site_title: Tax scrutiny will open 'Pandora's box' in EU: Greek shipowners
summary: Greek shipowners warn that EU scrutiny of their tax concessions will lead to a "Pandora's box" of revelations about other European countries, potentially causing harm to the entire shipping industry. The European Commission has asked Greece to clarify its tax system for the shipping industry, and a full investigation is likely. The Greek union of shipowners, led by Theodore Veniamis, fears that this could expose similar tax practices in other countries, leading to negative consequences.

site_title: German economy had decent start to Q2, but growth pace to slow, ministry says
summary: Germany's economy started the second quarter on a solid note, but growth is expected to slow due to a less pronounced spring construction recovery. Private consumption remains the main driver of growth for Europe's largest economy. The external environment remains challenging, and the economy is expected to slow somewhat in the second quarter, according to the economy ministry's report.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on the day, higher for the week
summary: Singapore stocks closed lower on Friday but still managed a 13-point gain for the week, marking the fourth consecutive weekly rise. The Straits Times Index rose to 2,822.97 after a weak May jobs report sparked a rally on Wall Street. Implied interest rate hike probabilities plummeted to zero, but profit-taking led to a decline on Friday. Despite the mixed signals, investors remained positive, with the index up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: ECB ready to use all tools if Brexit vote shocks market: Rimsevics
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is prepared to use all necessary tools to stabilize the financial markets if the UK votes to leave the European Union, according to ECB rate setter Ilmars Rimsevics. The ECB has currency swap lines with the Bank of England and will use them if needed to mitigate potential market shock. Rimsevics stated that the ECB has all necessary tools at its disposal, ready to intervene if required, following the UK's EU membership referendum on June 23.

site_title: Tiong Seng awarded S$98.3m PUB contract for water transmission pipeline
summary: Tiong Seng Contractors, a subsidiary of Tiong Seng Holdings Limited, has been awarded a S$98.3 million contract by the Public Utilities Board to supply and install a 4.6 km water transmission steel pipeline from AYE/Henderson Road to River Valley Road. Construction will begin on June 17 and is expected to be completed in 2019, utilizing the company's recently purchased tunnel boring machine. The project aims to differentiate Tiong Seng from industry peers by sharpening its competitive edge.

site_title: China again tightens supervision of baby formula after scandals
summary: China's food safety watchdog has issued new regulations to tighten supervision of baby formula producers, requiring registration and permits to sell products in China. The move follows a series of scandals, including a 2008 incident where melamine-contaminated milk killed six children. Domestic and foreign producers must now register and disclose foreign raw materials, and packaging and instructions cannot make health-related claims. The regulations aim to address consumer concerns and curb the production and sale of counterfeit baby formula, with nine people arrested in April on related charges.

images.alt_text: China's food safety watchdog has issued further regulations to tighten supervision of baby formula, requiring producers to register and secure permits to sell their products, state news agency Xinhua reported on Friday.

site_title: ISR to buy 19.9% stake in Madagascar concession for S$13.3m
summary: ISR Capital has signed a deal to buy 19.9% of Tantalum Holding's shares in Madagascar for S$13.3 million. The purchase will be satisfied by issuing 133 million new shares at S$0.10 each. The acquisition will give ISR Capital control of Tantalum Rare Earth Malagasy, which holds a permit to explore and develop a concession hosting critical rare earth elements. The deal is expected to be in high demand due to the scarcity of these elements, which are essential for clean-energy technologies.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 9.2 points lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended 9.2 points lower on Friday, closing at 1,641.22. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 1.84 billion lots valued at RM1.38 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 461 to 300.

site_title: Singapore to be first market in S-E Asia for Samsung Pay
summary: Singapore is set to become the first market in Southeast Asia for Samsung Pay, with the service launching on June 16, 2016. The Republic is the fifth country worldwide to offer the mobile payment option, following South Korea, the US, China, and Spain.

site_title: Banks gain ground in push to change derivatives capital rule
summary: The European Union and major banks have joined forces to push for changes to the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision's capital rule, citing concerns that it punishes banks for handling derivatives trades. The rule, which forces lenders to have capital against billions of dollars in collateralized trades, has been a point of contention for the industry. Regulators are considering revising the rule to better reflect the clearing industry's needs, which could make it easier to transfer client accounts between banks during times of stress.

site_title: GIC to buy up to 230 million euros of phone carrier Eir's shares
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC plans to buy up to 230 million euros (S$352 million) in shares of Eir, an Irish phone carrier. The acquisition will be made at 232 euros per share from existing shareholders, with hedge fund Anchorage Capital Group remaining the largest owner. This deal comes after Eir pulled plans to raise money through a public share sale in 2014. The acquisition marks GIC's interest in the company, following a 2010 investment by Singapore Technologies Telemedia, which exited its stake in 2012.

site_title: Russia cuts key rate for first time in 10 months
summary: Russia's central bank cut its key interest rate by half a percentage point to 10.50% for the first time in 10 months, aiming to boost its energy-driven economy. The move follows a 25% rise in the ruble since January and a stabilization of inflation at 7.3%. The bank forecasts inflation will hit its long-term target of 4% by the end of 2017 and plans to further cut the key lending rate in the future. This decision aims to stimulate growth and alleviate economic woes ahead of parliamentary elections in September.

site_title: India's Muslim women fight 'triple talaq' divorce
summary: Indian Muslim women are fighting the practice of "triple talaq" divorce, where a husband can instantly end the marriage by writing "I divorce you" three times in Arabic. The practice, banned in many Muslim countries, is allowed in India under the Muslim Personal Law Application Act. Women are speaking out against the practice, with some filing petitions to outlaw it, citing that it discriminates against women and goes against Islamic teachings. A campaign to ban the practice has gathered steam, with over 50,000 Muslims signing a petition.

site_title: Crowdfunding used for solar installation at Singapore residential property (Amended)
summary: A Singapore residential property has successfully used crowdfunding to finance a solar installation, believed to be the first of its kind in Asia. The project raised S$22,500 in 11 days, with the solar photovoltaic system producing 4.725 kilowatts of clean energy annually, equivalent to that of 120 trees. The homeowner pays interest-free monthly installments, while investors earn a 7% interest return. SolarPVExchange, the crowdfunding platform, is now in talks for another residential project.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares fall 0.9%, NZ steady
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% on Friday, marking their largest daily percentage drop since June 1, due to broad-based losses across sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,312.6, its second consecutive weekly loss. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index remained steady at 6,971.78.

site_title: Oil falls on stronger US dollar; high refinery demand lends support
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, driven by a stronger US dollar, which made fuel imports more expensive for countries using other currencies. International Brent crude oil futures dropped 80 US cents, or around one percent, to US$51.45 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures fell 57 US cents to US$49.99 a barrel. Despite this, strong refinery demand and global supply disruptions provided some support.

site_title: China now rivals US, Europe as growth engine for Asia exports
summary: China has surpassed the US and EU as a major driver of export growth in neighboring economies, according to Deutsche Bank research. China's influence is now comparable to or even surpassing the combined influence of the US and EU in Taiwan and Indonesia. The country's credit surge in the first quarter has boosted its growth prospects, with the IMF upgrading its forecasts. China's currency fluctuations, particularly the yuan, are also becoming increasingly important in the region, although the US dollar still drives volatility in most Asian currencies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.2% on Friday, marking their largest one-day drop in over three weeks. Billionaire investor George Soros' bearish bets on China's economy and global economic outlook sparked the decline. The Hang Seng index ended the week up 0.5% despite the losses, with several Chinese companies, including China Resources Power and Kunlun Energy, falling 4.6% and 4.1% respectively. The decline was also attributed to caution ahead of Chinese economic data and the closure of mainland China markets for a long holiday.

site_title: ECB doesn't need new stimulus to reach goal, council member says
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) council member Bostjan Jazbec says the bank has pledged enough stimulus to return euro-area inflation to its goal of 2%, citing updated staff forecasts indicating the central bank's existing measures could be sufficient. This contradicts economists' expectations of fresh stimulus before the end of the year, amid concerns about the effectiveness of central-bank policies and the need for governments to act in tandem with the ECB to boost demand.

site_title: Tesco supermarket to exit Turkey
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, is selling its 95.5% controlling stake in Turkish business Kipa to rival group Migros. This move comes as the supermarket giant focuses on its operations in Central Europe and Southeast Asia. Additionally, Tesco is selling its British restaurant chain, Giraffe, after only three years. The sales are part of Tesco's efforts to turn around its performance after a record annual loss in 2014/15.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall to 2-week low as commodity stocks drop
summary: European shares fell to a two-week low on Friday, with commodity stocks experiencing a decline due to weaker metal prices. The FTSEurofirst 300 index dropped 0.6% and the European STOXX 600 index also fell 0.6%. Shares in mining companies BHP Billiton, Anglo American, and Glencore declined 0.6-1.1%, while energy stocks fell 0.7% due to pressure on oil prices. This is the third consecutive day of declines for European shares.

site_title: Maldives ex-VP Adeeb jailed for plotting president's assassination
summary: A Maldivian court has jailed former Vice President Ahmed Adeeb for 15 years for plotting to assassinate President Abdulla Yameen following an explosion on the president's speed launch in September. The trial was held behind closed doors due to security concerns. Adeeb's lawyer claims the verdict was based on seven anonymous witnesses, but the US Federal Bureau of Investigation found "no conclusive evidence" of a bomb blast. Adeeb's sentencing has raised international concerns over the evidence used to convict him.

site_title: BMW sales rise but China growth keeps Mercedes ahead
summary: BMW delivered 168,129 brand vehicles in May, a 5.6% increase, driven by strong demand for SUVs and its 7-Series saloon. However, Mercedes-Benz maintained its lead in China with a 39% growth in sales. Daimler's global sales jumped 13% to a record 170,625 models, with Audi increasing May deliveries 6.7% to 164,150 cars. BMW's sales growth is on track for profitable sales this year, but it may struggle to retain its luxury sales crown, trailing behind Mercedes with 5-month sales of 797,457 cars.

site_title: Alibaba founder buys up two more French vineyards
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma, founder of Alibaba, has bought two historic French vineyards, Chateau Guerry and Chateau Perenne, for nearly 12 million euros. The 18th-century estates, located in Bordeaux, produce around 500,000 bottles of wine annually. This purchase adds to Ma's existing Chateau de Sours vineyard, as part of a strategy to move away from entry-level wines to top-level appellations. Ma's investments in French vineyards reflect the appeal of owning a noble French chateau as part of their wine-growing property, as China remains the top export market for Bordeaux.

site_title: Messaging app Line set for listing in Tokyo, New York: reports
summary: Messaging app Line is set to list its shares in Tokyo and New York, with reports suggesting it could raise $1-2 billion in its initial public offering, valuing the company at around $600 billion. Line, owned by South Korean Internet provider Naver, has submitted listing documents to Japanese and US market regulators. The offering would be the largest in Tokyo since Japan Post's $11.5 billion IPO in November. Line has over 200 million monthly active users and is popular in Japan and Asian markets, with plans to expand in the US.

site_title: Japanese 'naked restaurant' to ban overweight diners
summary: Japan's first "naked restaurant," "The Amrita," set to open in Tokyo, will have strict rules for entry. Patrons must weigh 15 kilos or less above the average weight for their height to be allowed in. The restaurant also has age restrictions, allowing only those between 18 and 60 years old. Upon arrival, guests must check in their clothes and put on paper underwear provided by the restaurant. The establishment aims to promote a healthy lifestyle and is inspired by similar "naked restaurants" in London and Melbourne.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares under pressure, tracking global weakness
summary: Australian shares fell 1% to 5,309.8, marking the market's first weekly loss, amid heightened risk aversion and uncertainty over US interest rate decisions and Britain's EU referendum. Index heavyweights BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto also declined. New Zealand's benchmark index was down 0.8% on the week. Air New Zealand rose 3.7% after selling a stake in Virgin Australia Holdings to China's Nanshan Group.

site_title: BOJ seen standing pat in June, but easing further in July to meet price goal: poll
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its current monetary policy at its June meeting, but will ease policy further in July to meet its 2% inflation target. A Reuters poll found that 18 of 27 economists predict a policy easing in July, with a combination of measures including deeper negative interest rates and asset buying. The move aims to boost inflation, which fell for a second straight month in April, and is part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" programme.

site_title: Hong Kong Life Insurance sale under consideration, may fetch US$600m: sources
summary: Hong Kong Life Insurance Ltd, a last remaining independent life business, may be sold for approximately US$600 million, according to sources. The company's owners, five Hong Kong financial institutions, are working with adviser Nomura Holdings on the potential sale. Singapore-listed Great Eastern Holdings is considering bidding for the company. The sale follows a trend of insurance assets being put on the block in Hong Kong, driven by strong interest from Chinese suitors seeking steady cash flow in a stable foreign currency.

site_title: Yen rises as Fed meeting, Brexit fears stoke flight to safety
summary: The yen strengthened against the US dollar ahead of central bank meetings in the US and Japan, as investors sought safer investments amid Brexit fears and economic uncertainty. The euro also declined, sitting at three-year lows, while emerging currencies lost ground against the dollar. Analysts warn that a pickup in riskier currencies may be nearing its end, and investors are closely watching the Fed and Bank of Japan meetings for clues on interest rate changes. The British pound also fell, amid growing anxiety over the UK's EU referendum on June 23.

site_title: Seagull falls into vat of curry in Wales and comes out bright orange
summary: A seagull in Wales fell into a vat of chicken tikka masala while searching for food, emerging bright orange. The bird, nicknamed "Gullfrazie" or "Spice Gull," was spotted at a food factory bin on Monday. The incident has garnered attention online, with many sharing photos and jokes about the bird's vibrant new color. The seagull's exact condition is unknown, but it appears to be unharmed and has flown away.

site_title: France may force rail strikers back to work: transport minister
summary: France's transport minister, Alain Vidalies, has threatened to force rail strikers back to work, using "every tool available" to get fans to the Euro 2016 football championship. The strike, now in its 10th day, has been ruled out for new negotiations, with authorities showing "no tolerance" for actions that threaten the event. Vidalies has vowed to issue orders for trains to operate if necessary, despite the union's continued refusal to return to work.

site_title: Twitter says some accounts locked after password disclosures
summary: Twitter locked some accounts to prevent potential security breaches after a password disclosure. The social media platform cross-checked leaked login credentials with its records, identifying vulnerable accounts for extra protection. Users were notified and advised to reset their passwords to regain access. The move aims to prevent hacks and data breaches.

site_title: Malaysia's debt burden eases as loans shifted to mortgage agency
summary: Malaysia's government debt has decreased by about $5.4 billion after transferring $5.4 billion of loans to the Public Sector Home Financing Board, reducing its debt-to-GDP ratio by 2 percentage points. The move aims to reined in government spending and narrow a fiscal deficit. The debt-to-GDP ratio will now be 52.5%, below the country's self-imposed limit of 55%. This shift is part of Prime Minister Najib Razak's efforts to curb government spending and avoid a credit-rating downgrade.

site_title: Trade minister Lim Hng Kiang says Brexit not good for global recovery
summary: Singapore's Trade Minister Lim Hng Kiang stated that a British vote to leave the European Union would have significant long-term consequences for the UK, but would do nothing positive for the global economy. He expressed concerns about the impact on the UK and the global economy, following the June 23 referendum.

site_title: The BSI story: How a 143-year-old Swiss bank took a quick road to ruin in Asia
summary: A 143-year-old Swiss bank, BSI SA, has been thrust into the center of a widening financial scandal involving 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB). In 2009, Coutts bankers Hanspeter Brunner and 70 colleagues defected to BSI, bringing lucrative accounts from 1MDB's growing ranks of millionaires. The bank's operation in Singapore is under investigation, with regulators saying it was the "worst case of control lapses and gross misconduct" seen in the Singapore financial sector. Several bankers, including Yak Yew Chee and Yeo Jiawei, have been charged in relation to the scandal, with millions of dollars in transactions linked to 1MDB and other entities being scrutinized.

site_title: Gold declines from three-week high as US dollar advances, Fed looms
summary: Gold prices declined 0.2% to US$1,267.09 an ounce, retreating from a three-week high, as the US dollar strengthened after an employment report offset concerns about a slowing labor market. The Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting on June 15 remains a risk, but expectations of a June rate hike have evaporated. Gold has gained 19% this year due to low interest rates, a sputtering dollar, and concerns over economic growth.

site_title: NZ, Australia dollars poised for large weekly gains as central banks help
summary: The New Zealand and Australian dollars are poised for large weekly gains as central banks in both countries held rates at record lows, reducing market expectations of a rate cut. The New Zealand dollar jumped 2% this week, reaching a one-year peak, while the Australian dollar climbed 0.6% for a second consecutive week. The gains were driven by the central banks' dovish stance, which reduced the risk of an easing to 2.03% by November, and investors seeking safe-haven assets amid growing concerns over the Brexit vote.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slip as dollar's recovery turns investors risk-averse
summary: The South Korean won declined 0.5% to 1,161.8 per US dollar, easing investor risk appetite, amid a US dollar rebound and declining global oil prices. Analysts expect the won to trade at current levels until the timing of a potential US rate rise becomes clearer.

site_title: Thai AIS to spend about US$200m on broadband network in 2016
summary: Thailand's largest mobile operator, Advanced Info Service Pcl (AIS), plans to invest approximately US$200 million in its broadband network in 2016, aiming to expand its fixed broadband services to 6.5 million households by the end of the year. This investment is part of AIS's strategy to become a full-service telecoms provider, focusing on digital content to boost data usage and offset declining voice service revenue. The company also recently secured a US$2.12 billion 4G mobile spectrum licence.

site_title: China Dairy to delist on June 13
summary: China Dairy Group will delist its shares on June 13, 2016, following an unconditional offer by its majority shareholder, Winner International Investments, at S$0.195 each. Trading of the shares has been suspended since May 12.

site_title: Malaysia's April factory output up 3% on year, below forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production in April increased 3.0% from the previous year, driven by manufacturing and electricity sectors. However, the growth was below the forecasted 3.5% and the private manufacturing purchasing managers' index showed a 14th consecutive month of factory contraction in May. Exports grew 1.6% in April, driven by higher shipments of manufactured goods and palm oil. The contraction in factory activity poses challenges for the country's economic growth.

site_title: In major test, Myanmar scrambles to clear port jam threatening growth
summary: Myanmar's major port is experiencing a severe congestion crisis, threatening the country's economic growth. A surge in demand for goods has caused a backlog of ships, with some vessels delayed for up to two weeks. The crisis has been exacerbated by inadequate infrastructure, poor logistics systems, and a recent crackdown by China on sugar smuggling. The government has implemented emergency measures, including 24-hour port operation and customs clearance, to tackle the congestion and prevent further delays. The situation has raised concerns about the country's ability to attract foreign investment and compete with neighboring countries.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks weaken on US dollar strength, but mark weekly gain
summary: South Korea's won fell 0.8% against the US dollar, but finished the week up 1.5% as the US Federal Reserve's rate hike became unlikely due to weak jobs data. The won quoted at 1,165.5 to the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed down 0.3% at 2,017.63. The Kospi gained 1.6% for the week, its third week of gains.

site_title: Philippines may join Asian sovereigns testing sukuk market
summary: The Philippines is considering issuing Islamic bonds, or sukuk, to diversify its funding options and tap into the growing sukuk market in Asia. The country's incoming finance minister plans to raise debt through sukuk and yuan borrowings, potentially offering a new investment opportunity for Middle East investors. The Philippines' sukuk could help widen the market dominated by Malaysia and Indonesia, and its success may depend on generous pricing and investor appetite. The country has previously discussed sukuk and has a history of recurrent bond issuers, which could help it avoid paying a premium.

site_title: Power cut disrupts Brussels airport
summary: A power cut affected check-in operations at Brussels Airport on Friday, with power restored to a departure area that had been reopened after a March 22 attack. The cause of the power failure was unclear, and further disruptions could occur. Flights continued to arrive and depart, but check-in delays could impact departures later.

images.alt_text: A power cut halted check-in at Brussels Airport early on Friday, a spokeswoman said, although flights continued to arrive and depart for the time being.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.280 points to 1651.650 on Friday, opening slightly higher. The market saw 32.6 million lots traded worth RM16.7 million, with 83 gainers for every 53 losers.

site_title: New debris images examined by MH370 search team
summary: Australian search teams are examining three new pieces of debris, including one found on Kangaroo Island off Australia's south coast and two in Madagascar, in connection with the missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau received photos of the items, which are being analyzed. The search for the plane, which disappeared in 2014, remains ongoing.

site_title: Obama approves broader role for US forces in Afghanistan
summary: US President Barack Obama has approved a broader role for US forces in Afghanistan, allowing American troops to accompany conventional Afghan forces on the battlefield. The decision enables greater use of US air power, particularly close air support, but does not authorize a blanket order to target the Taliban. Under the new policy, US commander General John Nicholson will decide when to accompany US troops with Afghan forces. The move aims to assist Afghan forces battling a resilient Taliban insurgency more proactively.

site_title: IE Singapore inks agreements in Mexico
summary: IE Singapore signed two memoranda of understanding in Mexico to create partnerships in infrastructure and connectivity. The agreements were signed with the Secretariat of Economic Development of Mexico City and ProMéxico, Mexico's trade and investment promotion agency. The partnerships aim to promote trade, investment, and economic growth through collaborations in areas such as urban planning, innovation, and logistics. Mexico's economy, the second-largest in Latin America, has seen significant growth, with a 2.5% GDP increase last year, and has implemented reforms to improve the business environment.

site_title: US dollar enjoys reprieve as euro, sterling feel the heat
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.3% to 94.185, pulling away from its one-month low, driven by a bearish turn in the euro, which slid 0.2% to US$1.1298.
