The euro's decline, attributed to a Reuters report on Commerzbank's plan to park billions of euros in vaults, unsettled the market. The US dollar was down 0.1% against the yen but still up 0.4% for the week. Sterling remained under pressure, trading at US$1.4450, ahead of the UK's Brexit referendum on June 23.

site_title: Coming to a theatre near you: Made-in-China Disney movies
summary: Walt Disney Co plans to produce Disney-branded films in China, partnering with state-owned Shanghai Media Group Pictures. CEO Robert Iger announced the move, citing the growing middle class in China and the country's $180 billion media and entertainment industry. The company aims to maximize profits in the country, competing with Dalian Wanda Group Co, which is expanding its global entertainment empire. Disney's Shanghai Disney resort is set to open in June, and the company is on track for a record year at the Chinese box office, with four out of the five highest-grossing imported films so far this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower after holiday
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.29% to 21,235.15 in the first trading session after a one-day holiday, tracking losses on US and European markets. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a public holiday. The decline followed a five-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Argentine airport workers to begin 48-hour strike on Friday
summary: Airport workers in Argentina will begin a 48-hour strike on Friday amid a salary dispute with the government. The strike, led by the State Workers Association, seeks to recoup salary lost to inflation, estimated at 35%. The union is demanding talks with the government, which has promised to reduce spending. Several airlines have already cancelled flights, and the strike will affect air traffic control and airport operations. The strike will continue until the government agrees to negotiations.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop as Japan's Topix falls with commodity shares
summary: Asian stocks fell for a second day, with Japan's Topix index dropping 0.8% amid concerns about moderate global growth before central bank policy decisions. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index slipped 0.8% to 130.60, with commodity producers, such as oil and copper, declining. Global equities have rebounded from February lows, but lingering concerns about the US economy and Brexit are causing market uncertainty.

site_title: Lenovo looks beyond computers with slick new phones
summary: Lenovo unveiled new smartphones, including the PHAB2 Pro with Tango augmented reality technology, and Moto Z models that can be customized with "mods" for added capabilities. The PHAB2 Pro can sense and map surroundings, enabling holograms to be overlaid on real-world settings. Lenovo also showcased a shatterproof screen and bendable smartphones and tablets. The company aims to expand its product line beyond computers, with Moto Z models available in the US and globally later this year. Lenovo's innovative offerings demonstrate its commitment to the smartphone market, despite being a late-comer.

site_title: Hotel Lotte bribery probe casts cloud over lucrative duty free licence bid
summary: A bribery investigation into Hotel Lotte's director Shin Young Ja has cast a cloud over the company's $4.6 billion IPO and its bid for a lucrative duty free retail licence in Seoul. The investigation revolves around allegations of accepting bribes from cosmetics maker Nature Republic in exchange for duty free store space. Hotel Lotte's reputation and operations could be affected, potentially impacting its chances of securing the licence. The company has delayed its IPO listing to give investors time to assess the risks.

site_title: BOK chief says bank plans to keep monetary policy accommodative
summary: South Korea's central bank governor Lee Ju Yeol announced that the bank plans to keep monetary policy accommodative for a while to address economic challenges, including low growth and inflation. The interest rate was cut to a record low 1.25 percent to stimulate economic recovery. The decision was made due to weak trade and potential risks from corporate restructuring. The governor also highlighted domestic issues such as low birth rates, an aging population, and high household debt. The accommodative policy aims to focus on economic recovery.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower after Wall St drop
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, following a decline on Wall Street, as investors await the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan meetings next week. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.19%, and the Topix index dropped 0.12%. The losses came despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records on the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Instagram attracting more advertising than Twitter: survey
summary: Advertising agencies are increasingly turning to Instagram for social media ad campaigns, with the platform now attracting more advertising than Twitter, according to a survey. This trend is seen as a further indication of Twitter's weakness in its ad sales operation, which has been a rare bright spot for the company. The survey comes as Twitter faces threats from competitors like Snapchat, which is on pace to surpass Twitter in US active users.

site_title: Hot stock: mm2 Asia gains on listing plans of related events firm
summary: mm2 Asia's shares rose 3.7% to S$0.695 after appointing professionals to prepare for a potential listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The company will buy a 51% stake in UnUsUaL Pte Ltd, a production firm, for up to S$26 million. This move is seen as a step towards listing the UnUsUaL group of companies, which includes event and concert production.

site_title: Stocks to watch: NOL, mm2 Asia, Otto Marine
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) said its takeover by France's CMA CGM is now unconditional after Temasek Holdings tendered all shares. mm2 Asia's investee, UnUsUal Pte Ltd, has appointed professionals for a listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. Otto Marine's subsidiary, PT Batamec, secured a US$14 million shipbuilding contract from an Indonesian state-owned enterprise.

site_title: Singapore shares open up 3.6 points on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 3.6 points to 2,847.40 points on Friday, driven by gains from Keppel Corporation and mm2 Asia. US markets closed lower overnight, with US crude oil prices hovering above $50 per barrel. Despite a weak overnight session, Singapore stocks have extended their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with 27.9 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Rivals let rip in Brexit TV debate
summary: Britain's EU membership referendum is on a knife-edge with a fortnight to go, as rival camps traded accusations of lies and scaremongering in a heated TV debate. The debate, featuring six figures, focused on immigration and the economy, with Leave campaigner Boris Johnson and Remain supporters trading barbs. The government's decision to extend the registration deadline has infuriated the Leave camp, who accused the government of trying to rig the referendum. The polls currently show Remain leading 51% to 49%, but bookmakers still favor Remain, and investors remain wary of the uncertainty.

site_title: Air New Zealand agrees to sell 19.98% stake in Virgin Australia to Nanshan Group
summary: Air New Zealand has agreed to sell 19.98% of its stake in Virgin Australia to China's Nanshan Group for A$0.33 per share. The sale, subject to regulatory approvals, would significantly alter Virgin Australia's shareholder register, with Nanshan Group and current investors such as Etihad Airways and Singapore Airlines emerging as top shareholders. This deal comes after China's HNA Aviation announced plans to buy a 13% stake in Virgin Australia earlier this year, which would dilute Air New Zealand's remaining stake to 22.5%.

site_title: Singapore aims to prosecute Indonesian polluters under haze law
summary: Singapore is prepared to prosecute Indonesian companies responsible for last year's haze-producing fires under the country's 2014 Transboundary Haze Pollution Act. Environment Minister Masagos Zulkifli stated that six suppliers of Indonesia's Asia Pulp and Paper Group have been ordered to provide information on steps to prevent fires on their land, with fines of up to S$100,000 per day for every day of fire. Singapore has the right to bring directors to court, and the city-state is seeking international cooperation to address the issue, with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo backing the plan.

images.alt_text: Singapore is prepared to prosecute any Indonesian companies found responsible for the fires that produced hazardous ash clouds afflicting the city state last year, a minister said, standing his ground even as recent efforts to take firms to account drew ire from the country's largest Southeast Asian neighbour.

site_title: Blue diamond sells for US$25m in New York
summary: A blue diamond, the Cullinan Dream, sold for US$25.4 million at Christie's auction in New York, breaking records as the largest Fancy Intense Blue type diamond sold. Cut from a 122.52-carat rough discovered in 2014 at the Cullinan mine, the diamond is part of a series of blue diamonds from the same mine that contributed to the British Crown Jewels. This sale comes weeks after another blue diamond fetched a record US$57.5 million in Geneva, highlighting the surge in value of precious stones among the world's ultra-rich.

site_title: Clinton trolls Trump on Twitter: 'Delete your account'
summary: Hillary Clinton's campaign team responded to Donald Trump's tweet by having her tweet "Delete your account" in response to Trump's claim that President Obama endorsed her. This was seen as a lighthearted jab, but also awkward. The tweet was written by a young staffer and attributed to Clinton. The exchange was a brief moment of levity in the heated presidential campaign.

site_title: After 11-month peak, oil prices take a breather
summary: Oil prices dropped 67 cents to $50.56 a barrel, a day after reaching an 11-month high. This decline is considered a technical correction after three days of gains, rather than a major reversal. Analysts attribute the drop to investors booking profits, with potential for a small decline to develop into a more significant drop.

site_title: Hollande vows 'all necessary measures' to stop Euro 2016 disruption
summary: French President Francois Hollande vows to take "all necessary measures" to prevent disruptions to the Euro 2016 football tournament due to rolling transport strikes. Rail workers have threatened fresh strike action on the lines serving Paris' Stade de France, where the tournament's opening match will take place. The government has mobilized 90,000 police and private guards for security, and Hollande assured that public services will be provided despite the strikes, which come amidst unresolved labor reforms and a train strike in its ninth day.

site_title: US: Weak bank shares lead stocks lower
summary: US stocks finished modestly lower on Thursday as large banks retreated due to dimming expectations of a US interest rate hike. Analysts see little chance of a rate hike following poor May jobs data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. Oil prices and copper also declined, affecting shares of companies like Schlumberger and Freeport-McMoRan.

site_title: Google co-founder fuels flying car labs
summary: Google co-founder Larry Page has secretly invested over $100 million in flying car startup Zee.Aero, located in Silicon Valley. Page, who is also backing Kitty Hawk, a second flying car startup, has kept his involvement hidden. Zee.Aero has nearly 150 employees and is developing a revolutionary new form of transportation. This investment marks a departure from Alphabet's investments in "moonshots" like self-driving cars. Page's flying car pursuits are separate from Alphabet's self-driving car program.

site_title: US woman convicted of conspiracy to export jet engines to China
summary: A California woman, Wenxia Man, 45, has been convicted of conspiring to illegally export fighter jet engines, a military drone, and technical data to China. The engines are used in US fighter jets, and a drone capable of firing Hellfire missiles. Man faces a maximum of 20 years in prison. She worked with a Chinese resident, Xinsheng Zhang, who acted as an official agent for China's arms procurement. Sentencing is set for August 19.

site_title: Pele memorabilia nets £3.4m fortune at auction
summary: Pele's memorabilia sold for £3.4m at auction in London. The sale, held over three days, included a 1970 World Cup winners medal that fetched £346,000. The medals from 1958 and 1962 had collectively sold for £340,000 on the previous day. The auction, held under Julien's, featured items from the Brazilian football icon's career.

site_title: Bidders offering more than US$5b for Yahoo: report
summary: Several suitors are bidding US$5 billion or more for Yahoo's core business, including Verizon, which offered more than US$3.5 billion. Yahoo's board will review offers ahead of a mid-July decision. The company is studying a sale to revive growth, focusing on mobile users, after struggling to compete with rivals like Google and Facebook. CEO Marissa Mayer has failed to revive the company since taking the helm in 2012, and Yahoo is exploring strategic alternatives, including selling itself.

site_title: Hackers selling stolen Twitter log-in data
summary: Hackers are selling tens of millions of stolen Twitter login credentials, reportedly obtained through malicious code that steals data from web browsers. Twitter denies a data breach, stating its systems were not compromised. The leaked data, estimated to be over 32 million records, contains usernames, passwords, and email addresses. The data is being traded on the dark web, where hackers used to gain access to the information by exploiting web browsing programs. Twitter claims to be working to protect accounts by checking the data against recent password leaks.

site_title: In France, overflowing bins, strikes greet Euro 2016 visitors
summary: France is facing significant disruptions ahead of the Euro 2016 tournament, with overflowing bins, transport strikes, and violent protests deterring tourists. The country's image is at risk of being tarnished, with tourism officials fearing a decline in bookings and long-term damage to the economy. Industry figures worry about the impact on business travel and the 2024 Olympics bid, while the government is urging unions to end their disruption and restore order.

site_title: Poetry 2.0
summary: Singapore's poetry scene is evolving, with younger writers leveraging social media and curated events to promote their work. Joshua Ip's SingPoWriMo, a Facebook-based movement, drew 2,800 writers and featured a poetry reading on the MRT train, where commuters appreciated the event. Poetry.sg, edited by Tse Hao Guang, is a web encyclopedia of local poets, and Math Paper Press's sales figures show a growing demand for poetry collections. The Singapore Writers Festival is also exploring new ways to engage with text, including multimedia poetry readings and collaborations with art collectives.

site_title: Midlife fitness cuts chances of a stroke later in life
summary: New US research published in the American Heart Association's journal Stroke found that middle-aged adults with higher fitness levels have a lower risk of stroke later in life. A study of nearly 20,000 adults aged 45-50 found that those with the highest fitness level had a 37% lower risk of stroke after age 65, compared to those in the lowest fitness category. The link between fitness and stroke risk remained even after considering other risk factors, suggesting that exercise can play a unique role in stroke prevention.

site_title: Temasek tenders NOL shares; CMA offer now unconditional
summary: Temasek Holdings, NOL's majority shareholder, has tendered all shares to France's CMA CGM, making the takeover offer unconditional. CMA CGM now owns 78.07% of NOL shares, with the offer price set at S$1.30 per share. The closing date of the offer has been extended to July 18, 2016. As a result, CMA CGM will not preserve NOL's listing status and has changed the composition of NOL's board, with 10 new members appointed.

site_title: Gene editing gets limited backing from US science body
summary: The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine has endorsed continued research on gene editing technology, known as "gene drive", which could alter or eliminate entire wild populations. The technology has the potential to reduce human suffering and ecological damage, but poses risks and its unintended consequences are not yet fully understood. The group recommends "carefully controlled field trials" to study the technology, despite concerns about potential environmental harm. The green light for research is expected to open the door to new funding and regulation.

site_title: Obama endorses Hillary Clinton for US president
summary: US President Barack Obama endorsed Hillary Clinton as the Democratic presidential nominee, signaling unity among Democrats after a contentious primary season. Obama's backing gives Clinton a boost, particularly among black, Hispanic, young, and liberal voters. Clinton, seeking to make history as the first female president, faces Republican nominee Donald Trump, whose divisive rhetoric has brought Democrats together. The endorsement came after Obama hosted Clinton's rival Bernie Sanders in the Oval Office, and Sanders vowed to continue his campaign while meeting with Clinton to work together.

images.alt_text: US President Barack Obama endorsed one-time campaign rival Hillary Clinton to succeed him Thursday, a signal to Democrats that it's time to unify after a bitter primary and take on Donald Trump.

site_title: Wendy's says it finds more unusual card activity at restaurants
summary: US burger chain Wendy's Co has discovered additional instances of unusual credit card activity at its franchise-operated restaurants, widening the scope of a cyber attack. The company initially found activity in 300 restaurants and has since discovered a new malware variant targeting its point-of-sales system. The new malware has been disabled in affected cases, and company-operated restaurants appear to be unaffected. Wendy's now expects a "considerably higher" number of impacted restaurants, with the investigation ongoing.

site_title: China investment a poll issue in sleepy northern Tasmania
summary: China's investment in Tasmania has boosted the state's economy, with up to 1,000 Chinese tourists visiting the area daily and trade ties increasing 37% since 2014. However, not all locals are benefiting, with unemployment rates remaining high in some areas. The issue of foreign investment is a concern for voters, particularly in the lead-up to the federal election. While China's investment may bring economic growth, experts say it's not enough to address the state's underlying issues, such as poor educational standards. The government's appeal to voters will depend on how they address these concerns.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat as profit warning hits Essentra
summary: European shares fell for a second day, weighed down by a 27.7% plunge in Essentra after a profit warning, and a 1% decline in the oil and gas sector due to a softening oil price. The STOXX 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indexes were down 1% each. Analysts cited European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's comments on weak productivity and low growth as a factor, while a weakening euro and Brexit uncertainty also impacted investor sentiment.

site_title: Doha Round failure due partly to lack of MNC interest
summary: The Doha Round of World Trade Organization (WTO) negotiations failed partly due to a lack of interest from large multinational corporations (MNCs). Unlike the Uruguay Round, where pharmaceutical companies drove the negotiations, MNCs in the Doha Round did not actively push for the agreement. The absence of MNC support hindered progress, as the round's key issues, such as agriculture and aid for trade, had little appeal to them. The failure of the Doha Round highlights the need for MNCs to be engaged in global trade agreements, and its impact is felt in the shift towards mega-regional trade agreements, which may favor larger economies at the expense of smaller ones.

site_title: Thousands bid farewell to boxing legend Ali
summary: Thousands gathered in Louisville, Kentucky, for a Muslim prayer service to bid farewell to boxing legend Muhammad Ali, who died at 74. The two-day event, held in Ali's hometown, brought together dignitaries and ordinary fans to honor the civil rights hero and social activist. Ali, a three-time heavyweight world champion, was remembered for his tenacity in the ring and his advocacy for peace and tolerance. The service was followed by a funeral procession and an interfaith memorial service, attended by heads of state and fans, with former US President Barack Obama publishing a video message in Ali's honor.

site_title: US firm scraps plan for China to build LA-Vegas rail line
summary: US firm XpressWest has cancelled a deal with China Railway International to build a high-speed rail line from Los Angeles to Las Vegas. The cancellation was due to "difficulties associated with timely performance" and China's inability to obtain necessary US authority to build the trains domestically. The project was announced nine months ago, but XpressWest cited a federal requirement that high-speed trains must be built in the US as a major obstacle. The deal was reportedly worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

site_title: US Navy admiral to plead guilty in bribery scandal
summary: US Navy Admiral Robert Gilbeau is set to plead guilty to lying to federal investigators in the "Fat Leonard" bribery scandal, becoming the highest-ranking officer to be convicted of a felony charge. The scandal involves Malaysian businessman Leonard Francis, who bribed Navy officials with cash, prostitutes, and other gifts to influence port stops. Gilbeau will admit to making a false statement, but not to taking bribes, and faces potential prison time. This is the latest in a series of convictions and censures of high-ranking Navy officials linked to the scandal.

site_title: Prisoner 24601 returns triumphant
summary: Prisoner 24601, a 31-year-old musical, has returned to Singapore with a new staging at the Esplanade, directed by Laurence Connor and James Powell. The musical, based on Victor Hugo's novel, tells the story of ex-convict Jean Valjean who starts anew and adopts a young girl after her mother's death. The new production features a darker and grittier tone, with a re-orchestrated and shortened score, and has been well-received by audiences. The show stars Simon Gleeson as Valjean, Patrice Tipoki as Fantine, and Emily Langridge as Cosette.

site_title: Airlines exit Nigeria on slowing economy hit by dollar shortage
summary: International airlines, following Iberia and United Airlines, may exit Nigeria or cut flights due to the country's economic slowdown and dollar shortage. Nigeria's foreign exchange reserves have fallen to US$26.4 billion, the lowest in over a decade, and the central bank has restricted access to foreign exchange. Airlines owe Nigeria US$575 million in outstanding air fares, which the government is trying to collect. If not resolved, the situation may lead to a surge in travel costs, affecting the perception of global investors about Nigeria and potentially losing its role as a hub for West African destinations.

site_title: Japan's real estate fervour could lose its mojo all too quickly
summary: Japan's real estate market is showing signs of losing momentum, with rising interest rates potentially eroding the sector's popularity. Despite its high returns in recent years, property in Japan faces challenges due to its aging and shrinking population, low interest rates, and lack of economic growth. However, the sector is expected to continue benefiting from factors such as infrastructure spending, cheap yen, and Chinese tourist arrivals, which could sustain reliable cash flows and drive demand for hotels and malls.

site_title: Singapore's refining margins in 2015 almost double: BP
summary: Singapore's refinery output rose 12.7% to 897,000 barrels a day in 2015, with profit margins nearly doubling to US$4.47 a barrel. Strong gasoline demand, particularly in China and India, drove the growth. However, analysts say current margins are unsustainable and are likely to decrease. Global refining margins also rose, with north-west Europe and US Gulf Coast margins increasing by 84% and 45% respectively. Despite strong demand, global energy demand grew only 1% last year, reflecting a weak global economy.

site_title: mm2 Asia says concert producer UnUsUal eyes Catalist listing
summary: mm2 Asia, a Singapore-based film and TV content producer, says one of its investees, UnUsUal Pte Ltd, has appointed professionals to prepare for a listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The proposed listing is in its preliminary stages, pending regulatory approvals and market conditions. mm2 acquired a 51% stake in UnUsUal for up to S$26 million, seeing synergy between their businesses and opportunities for expansion in South-east Asia and North Asia.

site_title: 2 banks in NZ tighten mortgage lending to non-residents
summary: New Zealand's Westpac and ANZ banks have tightened mortgage lending to non-resident borrowers, reducing risk in the country's booming housing market. Westpac will no longer lend to non-resident borrowers with overseas income, while ANZ requires non-New Zealanders to live in the properties they purchased. The move follows similar policies in Australia and aims to cool the country's housing market, which is growing at a rate second only to Qatar. The central bank has held interest rates steady to avoid fueling the market further.

site_title: Otto Marine jumps on chairman's delisting offer
summary: Shares of Otto Marine jumped 17% after its chairman, Yaw Chee Siew, proposed a voluntary delisting, valuing the company at approximately S$68 million. Siew, who owns 61.2% of Otto, offered to buy out remaining shareholders at 32 cents per share. The move is seen as a positive for the company, which has been struggling in the offshore and marine sector.

site_title: Singapore's prime retail rents continue to fall in Q2
summary: Singapore's average prime retail rents continued their downward trend in Q2, with Orchard Road rents falling 1.1% to S$32.50 per square foot per month, and suburban mall rents slipping 0.7% to S$29.45 psf/pm, according to CBRE Research. This marks the second quarter of declining prime retail rents in Singapore.

site_title: BOJ signals its defiance of monetary policy critics
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has signaled its intention to maintain its monetary policies, including negative interest rates, despite growing opposition from Japanese banks and politicians. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the policies have had their intended impact on the financial market and real economy, and that additional steps may be taken. A major bank, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, is considering quitting its role as a primary dealer in government bond auctions, but the BOJ is confident that the policies will ultimately benefit the banking sector in the long run.

site_title: Olam acquires US peanut sheller for US$85m
summary: Olam International is acquiring US peanut sheller Brooks Peanut Company for US$85 million, strengthening its position as the third-largest peanut sheller in the US. This purchase expands its sourcing network into new areas in Alabama and Florida, further enhancing its market presence. The acquisition comes after Olam's previous purchase of McCleskey Mills Inc in December 2014.

site_title: PM Lee: Blocking Internet on government work computers a necessary move
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that blocking Internet access on government work computers is necessary due to sophisticated cyber attacks, both within and outside the country. The Infocomm Development Authority must take action to protect public officers' work computers. This move aims to enhance cybersecurity and prevent potential threats to the government.

site_title: HDB resale prices stay flat in May: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore remained flat in May 2016, with a 0.2% increase in the SRX Property price index compared to the previous month. The year-on-year index remains unchanged. Resale volume also stayed steady, with 1,826 units sold, a 50% decrease from the peak in 2010. The median transaction over X-value (TOX) was negative S$1,000, indicating buyers are overpaying or underpaying against the estimated market value. Experts expect this trend to continue, with minor price differences recorded each month.

site_title: UK millennials almost miss registration for Brexit vote
summary: Thousands of UK millennials nearly missed the Brexit vote registration deadline due to a massive surge in traffic on the government website, causing server failures and technical error messages. The majority of 500,000 potential voters who applied to vote were under 34, with 132,000 under 25. The British government extended the deadline by 48 hours to allow those who missed the initial deadline to register. Despite initial criticism, many young Brits, including a college student, expressed excitement to participate in the historic vote.

site_title: Keppel Fels set to bag US$500m contract
summary: Keppel Fels, the rig-building arm of Keppel Corp, is close to securing a $500 million contract for a tension leg wellhead platform (TLWP) in southern Vietnam's Ca Rong Do field development. The deal would be the yard's first significant contract this year amid a rig-building slump and low oil prices. The contract, valued at $500 million, could be sealed in the coming weeks, with Repsol and its partners expected to sanction the field development. The deal would provide a boost to Keppel Fels, which has been struggling with an order book drought.

site_title: Collaborate to harness full potential of disruptive technologies: Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam in Singapore emphasized the need for collaboration to harness the potential of disruptive technologies, which he said will bring economic restructuring benefits. Tharman stressed that disruption is inevitable, but Singapore should work to anticipate challenges. He launched IBM's Watson Centre at Marina Bay, highlighting the importance of collaboration to maximize the benefits of technological advancements.

images.alt_text: Mr Tharman says: "If we work together actively, we can make things happen here in Singapore. It will be for the better of everyone."

site_title: Weak Dow futures = weak STI
summary: The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) fell 18.58 points to 2,843.80, closing for the day due to weak Dow futures following Hong Kong's Dragon Boat Festival closure. The index had risen for five consecutive sessions before Thursday. Energy stocks AusGroup and Loyz Energy gained, while Wilmar International lost 0.01 cents. Macquarie Warrants predicted a rise in crude palm oil prices, but First Resources remains the sector's top pick.

site_title: Thai artist weaves the past, present and future in his works
summary: Thai artist Santi Wangchuan weaves together the past, present, and future in his textile pieces, drawing from traditional techniques passed down through his family. As a dying craft, Wangchuan seeks to preserve hand-weaving, which he believes holds cultural significance and speaks to the well-being of family and community. His works, including the "Gift from my Grandmother" series, convey nostalgia and familial love, while also exploring the connections between contemporary art and lived experience. Wangchuan's studio practice combines traditional techniques with contemporary art, inspiring a sense of order and consistency.

site_title: BlackRock looks at green bond funds while Pimco urges caution
summary: Major asset managers, including BlackRock and Pimco, are exploring green bond funds, but concerns remain over supply and demand. Green bonds, issued for environmental projects, have seen a significant increase in issuance this year, with over $25 billion sold, but there's a shortage of bonds to meet demand. Pimco urges caution, citing the risk of forced purchases and non-common-sense prices, while BlackRock is developing funds to compete with other major insurers and asset managers.

site_title: Grim market mood sends yen, US$ up against euro
summary: Global financial markets are experiencing a grim mood, driving investors to the US dollar and yen for safety. The euro is weakened due to concerns over low inflation and negative interest rates. The yen surged to its strongest in three years against the euro and to five-week highs against the US dollar. The New Zealand dollar jumped 1.5% after the Reserve Bank kept interest rates on hold. The Swiss franc also rose against the euro, with dealers citing risks from Britain's EU membership vote. Sterling is down around a third of a percent against both the US dollar and the euro.

site_title: South Korean firms on shopping spree for overseas properties
summary: South Korean firms are investing in overseas properties, driven by low interest rates in their home market. They are targeting high-end hotels and office buildings in popular tourist destinations such as Hawaii and San Francisco, paying record prices. The investments are part of a shopping spree by Asian asset managers seeking better returns abroad.

site_title: Myanmar considering proposal for 'stopover flights' by Singapore carriers: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong discussed a proposal with Myanmar leaders for Singapore Airlines and SilkAir to offer "stopover flights" in Yangon and Mandalay, allowing passengers to make stops and tour or conduct business before returning to Singapore. Lee believes this would boost tourism, but acknowledged Myanmar's anxiety about increased competition from Singapore carriers. He expressed support for Myanmar's new government, which is working to build its nation and overcome years of falling behind its South-east Asian peers.

site_title: Convergence of ICT, media visible with Singapore in global forefront
summary: The Singapore government established the Info-communications Media Development Authority (IMDA) to regulate the converging ICT and media sectors. A PwC study forecasts a 5.2% compound annual growth rate in fixed broadband access revenue, reaching US$952 million by 2020. Singapore's high-speed broadband penetration is expected to reach 100% by end-2016, with online content demand continuing to grow due to the country's high connectivity. The IMDA aims to frame rules and regulations for this rapidly evolving industry.

site_title: Sovereign funds rethink strategies after shock of redemptions
summary: Sovereign wealth funds (SWFs) are rethinking their investment strategies as they face challenges in managing withdrawals after experiencing bumper cash inflows in recent years. With oil prices plummeting, many SWFs are being forced to raid their coffers to cover day-to-day spending, leading to portfolio rebalancing and risk management challenges. To address these issues, some SWFs are shifting towards riskier, less liquid assets, such as private equity and real estate, and are also increasing their use of external managers to diversify their portfolios. This shift is expected to continue, with some SWFs, like Saudi Arabia, revamping their investment approaches to create more diversified and liquid funds.

site_title: State-led overhaul for battered Korean yards
summary: South Korea's government has pledged 11 trillion-won (S$12.8 billion) to help lenders absorb losses in the country's struggling shipbuilding industry. The state-led overhaul aims to revive the sector, which has employed nearly 62,000 people. Shipbuilders Hyundai Heavy, Daewoo Shipbuilding, and Samsung Heavy Industries will raise a combined 8.41 trillion won by selling assets as part of the restructuring. The plan could cost tens of thousands of workers their jobs, but analysts see signs of recovery, with vessel deliveries increasing 39% in May.

site_title: UK bullion dealers get Brexit boost ahead of referendum
summary: UK bullion dealers have seen a significant boost in sales ahead of the Brexit referendum, with demand for gold bars and coins rising as investors hedge against potential economic instability. Sales have increased by 5-10% at some dealers, with online platforms reporting a 59% growth in UK customer base in June compared to the average of the last 12 months. A 'leave' vote is expected to further drive up demand, with prices potentially rising above £900 an ounce.

site_title: Why gain PE exposure without PE returns?
summary: A new bond offering by a Temasek Holdings-controlled fund, Astrea III, aims to provide access to the private equity space for smaller investors. The bonds, backed by 34 private equity funds, offer relatively low returns and come with varying levels of risk. While the bonds may be attractive to some investors, those unfamiliar with the private equity market may be better off with more conventional instruments, as they will not offer private equity-like returns and come with potential default risk. Investors should carefully consider their understanding of the private equity market before investing in the bonds.

site_title: Indonesian power plan delays fuel industry frustrations
summary: Indonesia's ambitious plan to boost electricity capacity by two-thirds by 2019 is being hindered by delays and cancellations in power tenders, threatening to undermine the country's ability to attract finance for $132 billion worth of projects. The power mix is also uncertain due to President Joko Widodo's shift towards renewable energy, which has angered coal miners and project developers. The delays and cancellations have led to investor frustration, with some projects being excluded from the next 10-year energy plan, and may also impact global markets as coal output is earmarked for domestic power plants.

site_title: Internet leaders say innovations in e-commerce and logistics will shape South-east Asia's future
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak predicts that innovations in e-commerce and logistics will shape South-east Asia's future. He praised Malaysian entrepreneurs' potential to become "global champions" in e-commerce, citing his own efforts to improve broadband speeds as a catalyst for the region's thriving Internet economy. Other speakers, including representatives from Singapore Post, Uber, and Ninja Van, highlighted the importance of same-day shipping, cross-border returns, and affordable logistics services to boost productivity and innovation in the e-commerce sector.

site_title: The Weber world-view
summary: UBS Chairman Axel Weber discusses key themes and risks impacting markets and the banking industry. Key points include: Brexit's potential impact on global markets, uncertainty in wealth management, US monetary policy, China's economy, and negative interest rates. Weber notes that a Brexit vote could lead to global market volatility, while the US Fed may hike rates this year. China's economy is expected to rebalance from investment to consumption, but faces challenges such as high corporate and mortgage debt. Negative interest rates may have counter-intuitive effects, including reducing consumer spending. Fintech is expected to disrupt the banking industry, with banks at risk of disintermediation if they fail to adapt.

site_title: A different kind of fairytale
summary: Lead actors Kyle Timson and Lindsay Dunn of the Shrek The Musical world tour share a deep connection to the film, having grown up watching it and identifying with its characters. Timson, who plays Shrek, relates to the character's experiences with bullying, while Dunn, who plays Princess Fiona, admires the character's confidence and independence. The actors feel their youth brings energy to the performance, but also acknowledge the need to keep their roles fresh to avoid repetition. With over 50 performances under their belts, Timson and Dunn strive to bring a new dynamic to their performances each night.

site_title: The global issue of food waste: thinking beyond the table
summary: Singapore and other countries face a significant issue of food waste, with about a third of produced food being lost or wasted annually. The problem has severe environmental consequences, including water and carbon waste, with 800,000 tonnes of food waste generated in Singapore last year. To address this, a circular economy approach is being implemented, with initiatives such as recycling food waste, reducing consumer behavior, and promoting sustainable practices. The United Nations' Champions 12.3 group aims to halve per capita food waste by 2030, and countries like the US and China are also introducing initiatives to reduce food waste.

site_title: A fantasy adventure mostly devoid of entertainment value
summary: A fantasy adventure film, Warcraft, has been in development for a decade and cost around $160 million to produce. Despite its high budget, the movie has received criticism and failed to meet expectations. This is a common issue when adapting video games into movies, as seen in the 1993 film Super Mario Bros, which was also panned by fans and critics. Warcraft's poor reception highlights the challenges of translating interactive video games into sit-and-watch movies while remaining faithful to the source material.

site_title: China's CPI eases in May while producer prices recover
summary: China's consumer inflation rose less than expected in May, easing deflationary pressures on cash-strapped companies. Producer prices recovered more than forecast, suggesting the central bank will maintain a supportive policy stance but may not cut interest rates further. The easing of inflationary pressures is seen as a positive sign for the economy, but China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Japan machinery orders drop the most in 2 years in April
summary: Japan's core machinery orders plummeted 11% in April, the largest drop in two years, due to earthquakes in a southern manufacturing hub. This decline exceeds analyst estimates and raises concerns about weak business investment for most of the year. The decline follows a 5.5% increase in March.

site_title: City buzz
summary: Breitling, a luxury Swiss watchmaker, has partnered with The Hour Glass to showcase its new Avenger Hurricane timepiece in an exhibition at Paragon shopping center in Singapore. The watch features a unique "Breitlight" material, a full-motion jet simulator, and a 3D model of the Breitling Jet Team L-39 Albatros. Meanwhile, graphic designers Veronica Fuerte and Ricardo Jorge, along with Theseus Chan, will be speaking at HELLO 2016, a design-centric talk. The Nanyang Show 2016 exhibition showcases 47 museum-quality artworks representing the Nanyang Style, while The Wormhole exhibition, conceptualized by aheeoee, features multimedia works of four local artists in a custom-designed structure resembling a machiya.

site_title: Another Malaysian developer eyes backdoor listing on SGX
summary: Malaysian developers are seeking backdoor listings on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), with three deals in two weeks. This trend may indicate a desire to access Singapore's capital markets and stable currency. The proposed reverse takeover (RTO) deals could be a sign of Malaysian developers capitalizing on Singapore's advantages.

site_title: Singapore tops financial literacy index, beating 17 Asian markets
summary: Singapore topped the Mastercard Index of Financial Literacy, scoring 71.3 index points, surpassing Taiwan and 17 Asian markets. The improvement in financial literacy is encouraging, with more people recognizing the importance of budgeting and financial planning. The Republic showed improvement in all three literacy components: basic money management, financial planning, and investment knowledge. Despite this, there is still room for improvement in retirement planning, and younger people are less financially literate than those over 30 in most markets.

site_title: The incomparable Montrachet
summary: The article discusses the exceptional qualities of Montrachet, a white wine known for its power, intensity, and complexity. A 1998 Montrachet from Maison Joseph Drouhin was described as having a brilliant gold color, a youthful bouquet, and well-balanced, ripe fruit flavors. While it was considered mature, it was slightly short on finish. The article concludes that Montrachet is a standout wine, rivaled only by a few others, making it a difficult choice for favorite wines.

site_title: Tech incubators on a mission of diversity
summary: Tech startups are launching programs to train underrepresented groups in the tech sector, with a focus on diversity. Founders like Angela Benton and Emile Cambry Jr are creating incubators and accelerators to cultivate talent within black and Hispanic communities. Despite a lack of diversity in the tech industry, these programs have helped alumni secure tech internships and jobs, with some starting their own businesses. Established companies like Google are also supporting these initiatives, recognizing the need for new approaches to seeking out talent.

site_title: ISR Capital and Best World among stocks offering hope in a dull market
summary: Two stocks, ISR Capital and Best World International, have outperformed the market despite weak equities. ISR Capital, connected to a 2013 CAD investigation, saw its stock rise, while Best World International tripled its price in the past three months. In contrast, OSIM International and Eu Yan Sang International faced delisting due to poor performance. These success stories highlight that fundamentally sound stocks can still thrive, challenging the market's tendency to ignore them in favor of others.

site_title: Internet policy part of cyber defence: IDA, CSA
summary: Singapore has separated internet surfing from government networks to combat cyber security threats. The move was made in response to constant attacks from cyber criminals, gangs, and hacktivists. According to CSA chief executive David Koh, the goal is to prevent breaches and disrupt the "cyber kill chain" to raise cyber defensives. This measure aims to protect the government and citizens' information and data from potential threats.

site_title: Training institute the flagship project of Singapore-Myanmar ties
summary: Singapore has established a vocational training institute in Yangon, Myanmar, as part of its efforts to support the country's development. The Singapore-Myanmar Vocational Training Institute (SMVTI) aims to produce skilled labor for Myanmar's industries. The institute, modeled after Singapore's Institute of Technical Education, offers 10 courses, including hospitality, facilities management, and engineering. The top 20 graduates will receive internships in Singapore. The institute has been tasked with addressing transitional issues in Myanmar, including democratization and economic liberalization.

site_title: Best World plunges from dizzying heights
summary: Best World International, a multi-level marketing operator for healthcare and wellness products, plummeted 22.9% or 31.5 cents after reaching an all-time peak of S$1.39. The company's share price has tripled since the start of the year, with over 5.4 million shares changing hands. The drop may be linked to a Straits Times article warning of potential risks in the stock. Despite revenue growth of 160.8% to S$35.2 million and net profit more than 23-fold, the company faces queries from the Singapore Exchange regarding its trading activity and financial results.

site_title: US high speed rail venture axes partnership with Chinese firms
summary: US-based high-speed rail venture XpressWest has terminated its joint venture with Chinese firms China Railway International, citing issues with "timely performance" and obtaining required authority. The decision comes nine months after the partnership was announced, and will impact a proposed high-speed rail line between Las Vegas and Los Angeles. XpressWest will now pursue other development partnerships, citing a federal funding requirement that high-speed trains be manufactured in the US as a major challenge.

site_title: Mapletree bags prime asset in Saigon CBD for over S$400m
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired Kumho Asiana Plaza Saigon in Ho Chi Minh City's central business district for over S$400 million, taking its total assets under management in Vietnam to over S$1 billion. The property, a mixed development with a 21-storey office building, 32-storey serviced apartments, 21-storey hotel, and retail podium, has a net asset value of US$215 million and consistently high occupancies above 90%. This deal aligns with Mapletree's strategy to invest in strong-yielding assets and will continue to seek investment opportunities in Vietnam's major cities.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore property market analysts predict a positive outlook for developers, with Maybank Kim Eng Research stating no major implications from government land sales, and CIMB Research expecting a 5-8% correction in private home prices in 2016. Ascendas Reit's divestment of its Shanghai logistics center for S$26 million is seen as an opportunistic move, aligning with its capital recycling strategy. Analysts maintain "positive" views on property developers, with top picks including CapitaLand, City Developments, and UOL.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, following European bourses downward, after European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi urged eurozone countries to enact fiscal stimulus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.4%, 0.5%, and 0.5% respectively, amid a dip in US oil prices. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: A-Reit to sell logistics facility near Shanghai for S$26m
summary: A-Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has agreed to sell its A-Reit Jiashan Logistics Centre in China for S$26 million, generating a gain of S$5.1 million over the total development cost. The sale will strengthen the trust's resources for other opportunities and reduce its aggregate leverage by 0.2%. The proceeds will be used to repay debts, and the manager will receive a divestment fee of S$0.13 million. This sale comes after the trust's plan to sell its Ascendas Z-link business park property in Beijing earlier this year.

site_title: Remaking fashion's business model in NY
summary: Adam Pritzker and Vanessa Traina are launching an American fashion conglomerate, Assembled Brands, with three brands: Protagonist, Tenfold, and Khaite. The group aims to create a new model for the fashion industry, focusing on lifestyle and less on trend. Unlike European conglomerates like LVMH and Kering, Assembled Brands will not acquire existing brands but instead create its own. The company will use its e-commerce platform, technology, and services to support emerging talent, aiming for 50-200% growth and 50-60% margins.

site_title: Conjuring up new tricks in horror
summary: James Wan's horror film The Conjuring 2, the sequel to his 2013 hit, has been praised for its masterful scares and emotional core. The film follows paranormal investigators Ed and Lorraine Warren as they take on a haunted house in North London, based on the Enfield Poltergeist case. Despite a two-hour-plus runtime, the film keeps audiences riveted, with Wan conjuring up new tricks to chill them. The film's emotional subplot adds depth to the plot, making it a love story as much as a scare flick.

site_title: A 'Leave' vote does not guarantee exit from EU
summary: The UK's June 23 referendum on EU membership may not necessarily lead to the country's exit from the EU, as the 2015 Referendum Act does not bind the government to the outcome. The UK Parliament, not the administration, holds sovereign power. Even if the government accepts the result, it must get the necessary legislation through both Houses of Parliament, making a landslide "Leave" vote unlikely to result in immediate exit. The referendum has exposed democratic shortcomings in the UK's electoral system, with a significant gap between MPs and voters' opinions.

site_title: Institutional asset managers suffer net outflows of US$95.4b in Q1
summary: Institutional asset managers worldwide experienced net outflows of US$95.4 billion in Q1 2016, with equity strategies suffering the largest outflows of US$58.6 billion. Active managed equity portfolios lost US$70.5 billion, while passive equity strategies attracted US$11.9 billion. Fixed income strategies reported US$26.7 billion in outflows, with sovereign wealth funds contributing US$8.8 billion, mainly due to Japanese equity redemptions.

site_title: Having an ale of a time
summary: Beerfest Asia 2016, a four-day festival, offered over 500 varieties of craft and commercial beer, as well as hard liquor, catering to a diverse audience. The event, conceptualized in 2008, aims to promote inclusivity and provide a relaxed setting for visitors to try different beers and spirits. The festival featured tribute bands and electronic music to appeal to younger visitors, and a judging panel for the Asia Beer Awards, which returned after a three-year hiatus. The event saw a 25% increase in beer varieties and is expected to attract 34,000 visitors this year, with plans to take the concept overseas within the next two years.

site_title: An emotional and physical challenge for actors
summary: Singaporean actors performing in Cameron Mackintosh's re-imagined version of Les Miserables face both emotional and physical challenges. Despite the grueling 8-show-a-week schedule, actors Earl Carpenter, Simon Gleeson, and Patrice Tipoki attest that each performance is unique, requiring them to adapt to their characters' emotions and physical demands. The show's physicality has led to injuries, including Carpenter's herniated discs and Tipoki's bruises, but the cast's dedication to the story and characters keeps the show timeless and captivating audiences.

site_title: Malaysia makes arrests in immigration department scandal
summary: Malaysian police have arrested over 10 people, including 5 immigration officers, in an investigation into a scandal at the immigration department where staff allegedly colluded with criminal groups to manipulate information on who entered or left the country. The subterfuge was centered at Kuala Lumpur International Airport and began in 2010. Authorities have also sacked 15 immigration officers and suspended 14 others over security breaches, with around 100 people under investigation.

site_title: Making jazz accessible to the masses
summary: Jeremy Monteiro, known as the "King of Swing," is set to launch his latest album, Brazilian Dreams, with a concert next week. The album, featuring traditional Brazilian tunes in the style of bossa nova, has already cracked the Top 10 on the iTunes Jazz Charts in just three days. Monteiro's music is widely accessible, making jazz appealing to a broad audience. His illustrious four-decade career includes composing national songs and playing for Simon & Garfunkel.

images.alt_text: The way Monteiro delicately balances genres is one of the reasons for his widespread appeal.
Sue-Ann Tan

site_title: Asia: Stocks retreat as stronger Yen weighs on Japanese shares
summary: Asian stocks retreated 0.5% to 131.72, overshadowing gains from energy producers, due to a strengthening yen. The yen's pressure on Japanese shares, despite global equities advancing for a fourth week, weighed on the market. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments signaling a delay in interest rate hikes supported equities, but also strengthened the yen, hindering Japan's shares.

site_title: Beyond sepia-toned snapshots
summary: Drama Box's community theatre project "IgnorLAND of its Loss" tells the stories of Dakota Crescent residents, who will be evicted from their homes. The project, launched two years ago, involves residents and actors in an interactive, open-ended experience. Participants will navigate a scavenger hunt with branching narratives, framing the residents' personal stories through staged scenes and guided interactions. The project aims to create empathy and encourage residents to adapt to their new living situation, while also questioning the commodification of nostalgia and the role of citizens in redevelopment decisions.

site_title: Man of mystery in the spotlight
summary: Artist Ho Tzu Nyen's film "The Nameless" explores the life of Lai Teck, a mysterious figure instrumental in steering the Communist Party of Malaya away from an armed takeover during World War II. Lai Teck, a triple agent, served the French as a spy in Indo-China and allegedly worked with the British to infiltrate the CPM. Ho's 21-minute video installation, featuring Hong Kong actor Tony Leung's film clips, recontextualizes the scenes to tell the story of Lai Teck's enigmatic life. The film will be shown at Art Basel Unlimited in Basel, Switzerland, next week.

site_title: EU warns against isolating non-Euro nations as Brexit vote looms
summary: The European Union has warned against isolating non-Euro nations as the UK prepares to vote on Brexit. European Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis stated that further euro-area integration should not create new barriers within the EU. This comes as Prime Minister David Cameron sought to strengthen the EU's safeguards for the UK, which is outside the euro area. Dombrovskis emphasized the importance of upholding the EU's common market and cohesion.

site_title: Nike, Adidas, Puma squeeze out rivals at Euro 2016
summary: Nike, Adidas, and Puma have significantly increased their share of teams supplying football kits at the Euro 2016 tournament, with Adidas providing kit to 37% of teams, Nike to 25%, and Puma to 21%. This is a sharp rise from 1996, when Adidas and Nike supplied 31% and 6% of teams respectively. The companies are engaged in a "fiercely contested commercial battle" as they seek to dominate the market, with Adidas and Nike having a lead in deals with individual players.

site_title: Concert production firm UnUsUal eyes Catalist listing
summary: UnUsUal Pte Ltd, a film and TV content producer, has appointed professionals to prepare for listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. This follows mm2 Asia's 51% stake purchase in UnUsUal for up to S$26 million. The proposed listing is in its preliminary stages and is dependent on regulatory approvals, compliance with Catalist rules, and market conditions. The directors may decide not to proceed with the listing later on.

site_title: Japan banks now among world's biggest energy lenders
summary: Japanese banks have grown into some of the world's largest energy lenders, with Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group Inc becoming the biggest oil-and-gas lender with 9.2 trillion yen in exposure. Despite this significant shift, energy remains a fraction of their business, and souring loans are a drag on earnings. This growth is unusual for Japanese banks, known for their risk aversion, and highlights the changing global energy landscape.

site_title: Deutsche Bank, Credit Suisse may need capital: Barclays
summary: Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse may need to raise capital to resolve US claims over the sale of mortgage-backed securities, Barclays analysts said. Deutsche Bank could face $4.5 billion in settlement payments, while Credit Suisse may have to pay $2 billion. The banks are struggling to build capital and meet targets, and a capital increase could be difficult due to the structural decline in the investment-banking industry. Barclays downgraded the banks to equal weight from overweight and cut price targets for their stocks.

site_title: Aviva Singapore seen as frontrunner in Mindef-MHA insurance tender
summary: Aviva Singapore is seen as the frontrunner to secure a multi-million-dollar contract with the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) and the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) for group-employee benefits. The contract is expected to be announced soon, with the condition that Aviva fulfills its required terms and conditions. If it fails, the tender can be awarded to another bidder. The contract is crucial for providing coverage for the SAF and MHA, and Aviva's win would solidify its position in the market.

images.alt_text: Incumbent insurer Aviva Singapore is tipped to be the frontrunner in the race to secure a multi-million-dollar group-employee benefits contract to provide coverage for the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) and the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA).

site_title: Mapletree buys Kumho Asiana Plaza in Ho Chi Minh City
summary: Mapletree Investments acquired Kumho Asiana Plaza in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam for US$215 million, the net asset value of the transaction. This is Mapletree's largest acquisition in Vietnam, a prime mixed-use asset with 146,000 square meters of gross floor area, featuring Grade A offices, serviced apartments, and a hotel. Occupancies have been consistently above 90% for the office and serviced apartment components. The acquisition is in line with Mapletree's strategy to invest in strong-yielding assets and marks the group's presence in Vietnam, where it now has over S$1 billion in assets under management.

site_title: Air France CEO vows to protect Euro flights during strike
summary: Air France CEO Frederic Gagey has vowed to protect Euro flights during a four-day pilots strike starting Saturday, despite potential disruptions. The strike, called by unions representing over half of the airline's pilots, may cancel up to 30% of flights. Gagey stated that the airline would minimize disruptions to Euro 2016 soccer matches, which will be hosted in cities served by Air France. The strike is part of nationwide protests against plans to loosen France's strict labor laws.

site_title: DBS reaping success of cashless drive
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reports a sustained decline in ATM cash transactions, with a 400,000 drop in average monthly transactions over the past year. This decline is part of the bank's cashless drive, which is expected to boost mobile wallet volume five times by 2018. DBS also sees strong traction with Apple Pay, with Apple Pay credit card users averaging three contactless transactions per week. The bank aims to raise the contactless transaction limit to beyond S$100 by mid-2017, and expects its mobile wallet volume to contribute 80% of its contactless volume by 2020.

site_title: UBS Americas to cut down on client advisers
summary: UBS Americas is reducing its client adviser positions by 40% to 6,500-7,000, down from around 7,145. This is part of a broader restructuring under new head Tom Naratil, who took over in 2016. The move aims to optimize the business and improve efficiency.

site_title: Rice makes art out of his own heartaches
summary: Irish musician Damien Rice surprised fans at a packed concert in Singapore, showcasing his dry sense of humor. During his set at The Star Theatre, Rice's witty banter left the crowd in stitches. This marks his second visit to Singapore in less than a year, following his headlining gig at the Neon Lights Festival in November 2015. Rice's ability to balance his emotional ballads with humor has delighted fans and set him apart from his usual introspective stage presence.

site_title: Nordic Investment Bank launches US$567m euro green bond
summary: The Nordic Investment Bank launched an 8-year, $567 million euro green bond to finance environmental projects. The bond will be used for renewable energy, energy efficiency, green transport, and wastewater treatment. This is the bank's second euro green bond, attracting investors such as FMO, APG, and AP4. The bond aims to support projects in the Nordic and Baltic countries.

site_title: Air pollution seen reducing China's economy 2.5% by 2060
summary: A new report by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) warns that air pollution could reduce China's economy by 2.5% by 2060 due to extended worker sick days, damaged crops, and increased healthcare costs. The report, which also forecasts a global increase in air pollution-related sick days from 1.2 billion to 3.7 billion, urges governments to enact tougher environmental laws. China's economy will be disproportionately affected due to differences in household savings rates and demographics. The OECD emphasizes the need for strong policy action to mitigate the significant impacts of poor air quality.

site_title: Saudi property stocks named in kingdom's post-oil plans soar
summary: Saudi Arabia's plans to diversify its economy have led to a surge in stocks of property companies, with Dar Al Arkan Real Estate Development Co rising 22% in the past five days. The company's valuation has reached 15 times its estimated earnings, making it the strongest level since January. The National Transformation Program, Saudi Arabia's biggest economic shake-up, has been mentioned alongside Emaar Economic City as key players in the kingdom's post-oil plans. Investors are optimistic about the real estate sector, driven by the country's demographics and government efforts to reduce dependence on oil.

site_title: Spanish home sales up the most since 2008 as economy recovers
summary: Spanish home sales surged 29% in April, the largest increase since 2008, as the nation's economy recovers from the financial crisis. This marks the fastest clip since the data's inception in 2008. Home values rose 6.3% in the first quarter, the largest gain since 2007. The market is recovering from a 40% decline in home values and the nation's US$47 billion bailout for its banks. Experts attribute the surge to banks lending again and buyers' confidence in the economy's recovery.

site_title: Uber, 2 executives fined over UberPop service
summary: Uber Technologies Inc and two executives, Thibaud Simphal and Pierre-Dimitri Gore-Coty, were fined a total of US$961,434 by a French criminal court for allegedly breaking the law with its UberPop ride-sharing service. The service, which allows anyone with a vehicle and driver's license to offer a taxi service, was suspended in France. The fines were imposed for fraudulent commercial practices, encouraging illegal activity, and improper use of personal data. The fines were half suspended, with Simphal fined US$22,621 and Gore-Coty fined US$33,932.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares end down, NZ at 2-week lows
summary: Australian shares fell 0.15% on Thursday, led by bank losses and Amcor Ltd's plant closures. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5361.9 points. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index hit a two-week low, closing 0.3% down at 6970.55. The New Zealand dollar rose to a one-year high after the central bank kept interest rates steady.

site_title: UK trade deficit narrows in April
summary: Britain's trade deficit narrowed to $4.76 billion in April, its lowest level since September 2015, after a record monthly jump in goods exports. Goods exports rose 11.2% in April, the largest rise since 1998, while imports increased 4.6%. The narrowing deficit offers a hint that a weak recent trade performance may be turning a corner, but the UK's large current account deficit remains a concern, particularly if the country votes to leave the European Union.

site_title: Airlines exit Nigeria on slow economy hit by dollar shortage
summary: International carriers are considering halting or cutting flights in Nigeria due to the country's slow economy and dollar shortage. Iberia suspended its route in May, and United Airlines will end flights from the US to Nigeria by the end of June. British Airways and Emirates are also facing difficulties collecting outstanding air fares. The CEO of United Airlines described the decision to pull out of Nigeria as "tortured," citing a lack of demand and trouble collecting payments. The Lagos route has become "untenable" for United.

site_title: German minister wants EU to curb foreign investors
summary: German Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel urged the EU to shield its key industries from foreign investors, citing the recent takeover bid by Chinese appliance giant Midea for German robotics group Kuka. Gabriel expressed concerns that foreign investors, particularly those from countries with state-run enterprises, may pose a threat to EU industries and jobs. He called for the EU to consider the industrial interests of its member states when evaluating foreign investment bids. Gabriel's comments come ahead of Chancellor Angela Merkel's visit to Beijing, where she will discuss economic ties with China.

site_title: After shock of redemptions, sovereign funds rethink strategies
summary: Sovereign wealth funds, worth $6.5 trillion, are rethinking their investment strategies due to a shift from bumper cash inflows to redemptions. To bolster returns, they are moving into riskier, less-liquid territory, including private equity and start-ups. Some funds are also diversifying their portfolios with external managers and tranches of short-term, medium-term, and long-term assets to manage withdrawals and minimize portfolio rebalancing challenges. This shift is driven by the need for yield in low-interest-rate environments, particularly after oil prices crashed to under $30 a barrel in 2016.

site_title: Terratech signs RTO deal with Malaysia's Capital City Property (Amended)
summary: Terratech Group, a Singapore-based marble producer, has signed a conditional SPA with Malaysian property developer Capital City Property for a proposed acquisition worth S$300 million. Capital City will issue 4.29 billion shares at seven Singapore cents per share. The deal is expected to result in a reverse takeover, with the project, Project Capital City, a mixed-use development in Malaysia, set to be completed with 1,635 units. Construction is underway, with the mall scheduled for launch in the first half of 2018.

site_title: "IPO-ready" IronSource waits for more favourable markets
summary: IronSource, a private Israeli tech firm valued over $1 billion, is waiting for more favorable market conditions before considering an initial public offering (IPO). Despite being "definitely IPO ready," the company's Chief Marketing Officer, Omer Kaplan, stated that the timing is not ideal due to market fluctuations. IronSource is instead focusing on private fundraising to finance acquisitions and is exploring seven potential targets, including companies that provide analytics features. The company's revenue is expected to grow 30% in 2016 to $450 million, driven by its mobile app development tools.

site_title: Otto Marine secures US$14m shipbuilding contract
summary: OTTO Marine announced a US$14 million shipbuilding contract from an Indonesian state-owned enterprise. The contract is for a 6500-DWT product tanker, expected to be delivered in Q2 2018. The company expects the contract to positively contribute to its financial results for 2017 and 2018. Following the announcement, Otto Marine's shares rose 37% to close at 31.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: RPC to buy BPI for US$379m
summary: RPC Group Plc agreed to buy British Polythene Industries Plc for US$379 million, expanding into the European polythene films market. The cash-and-share offer values BPI at 940 pence per share, 30% higher than its closing price. The acquisition is expected to generate US$14.4 million in pretax cost savings annually, backed by BPI management. CEO Pim Vervaat called BPI a "compelling strategic opportunity" for RPC, aiming to broaden its portfolio and cut costs.

site_title: Singapore stocks close weaker as STI tracks Dow futures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 18.58 points lower at 2,843.80 on Thursday, tracking a decline in Dow futures due to Hong Kong's closure for the Dragon Boat Festival. The index had risen for five consecutive sessions, with 169 STI components rising versus 213 falls. Energy stocks led the market, with AusGroup gaining 0.006%, while Wilmar International fell 0.01% on volume. The decline was attributed to a correction after a 72-point gain over the past five sessions.

site_title: Brexit would hit poor families hard
summary: The UK's potential exit from the European Union would disproportionately affect low-income households, according to the National Institute of Economic and Social Research. In the worst-case scenario, poorer households could receive between $2,692 and $8,018 less in tax credits and benefit payments by 2020. This is due to Chancellor George Osborne's plan to increase welfare spending to balance the public finances. The economic impact could be severe, with a possible yearlong recession, and low-income families would be particularly vulnerable to the loss of national income and welfare payments.

images.alt_text: Low-income households are set to be among the hardest hit if the UK votes to leave the European Union, according to the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse plans to develop industrial user base for China metals hub
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEx) plans to develop an industrial user base for its metals trading hub in southern China, specifically in Qianhai, a new free trade zone near Hong Kong. This move aims to leverage HKEx's experience in launching new initiatives with the mainland and the London Metal Exchange's (LME) successful model to create a physically deliverable spot commodity market in China. The LME has unveiled LMEshield, a new electronic method of tracking metal in warehouses, which could be deployed in Qianhai and Qingdao port if regulatory approval is granted.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that civil service internet lockdowns are necessary to safeguard government networks, citing "very sophisticated" cyber attacks. Meanwhile, prime retail rents on Orchard Road fell for the sixth consecutive quarter, averaging S$32.50 per square foot. Olam International acquired a US$85 million Alabama peanut sheller, while A-Reit agreed to sell a Chinese logistics facility for S$26 million. The Straits Times Index closed weaker, losing 18.58 points due to the closure of Hong Kong for the Dragon Boat Festival and Dow futures falling.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Thursday with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 7.34 points to 1,650.51. The market saw a trading volume of 1.73 billion lots valued at RM1.61 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 372 to 347.

site_title: BOJ Nakaso: Negative rates having positive effect on economy
summary: Bank of Japan deputy governor Hiroshi Nakaso stated that negative interest rates are having a positive impact on the economy, despite potential side effects. The BOJ introduced negative interest rates in January to accelerate inflation to its 2% target. Since then, monetary policy has remained steady. Nakaso emphasized the need to monitor the effects of negative rates while acknowledging their positive impact.

site_title: Singapore social payment app says it's surpassed S$1.5m in user transactions
summary: Singapore's social payment app Kashmi has surpassed S$1.5 million in user transactions since its launch in January. The app allows users to top up virtual wallets and pay friends using a credit or debit card. Kashmi is launching a "Group Pay" function on June 25, enabling users to collect payments from multiple peers in one click, particularly for group spending situations like sports events. This function aims to ease stress for users and local sports managers.

site_title: JFE pairs with Nucor for US$270m Mexican autosheet venture
summary: JFE Holdings Inc, Japan's second-largest steel mill, has partnered with Nucor Corp to build a $270 million automotive steel plant in Mexico. The 50/50 joint venture, Nucor-JFE-Steel Mexico, will begin production in 2019 with a capacity of 400,000 metric tons per year. The plant aims to tap into North America's growing car market and fulfill JFE's need for a manufacturing base in the region. The partnership is part of JFE's strategy to expand into high-grade auto sheet and diversify its product offerings amid a global steel glut.

site_title: 6.2 undersea quake strikes central Indonesia
summary: A 6.2-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of central Indonesia, 300km south of Lombok, at 12.13pm on June 9, 2016, at a depth of 29km. No tsunami warning was issued, and there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage. Indonesia's disaster agency is checking for potential impacts.

site_title: MOE teachers will still get Internet on work computers
summary: MOE teachers in Singapore will still have internet access on their work computers despite plans to cut off internet access for public servants. This is according to a recent memo from the Ministry of Education. The memo was sent to all teachers under the MOE, contradicting earlier plans to restrict internet access. The exact reason for the exemption is not specified.

site_title: First test for French security on eve of Euro 2016
summary: France faces its first major security challenge of the Euro 2016 football championships with a giant open-air concert in Paris, following the November 13 attacks that killed 130 people. The French government has launched a free smartphone app to warn visitors of potential threats. Meanwhile, industrial unrest and strikes over labor reforms continue to disrupt the city, with uncollected rubbish piling up in streets. High-profile players, including German defender Jerome Boateng, have expressed concerns about safety, and the US State Department has warned of a "high threat from terrorism" at the tournament.

site_title: UK bank investors may have ignored Brexit risk: Citigroup
summary: UK bank investors may have ignored Brexit risk, according to Citigroup analysts. The UK's biggest banks have slumped 28% in the past year due to "weak" earnings, with Brexit fears not fully factored into current valuations. Analysts warn of a material downside risk to UK bank share prices if the UK votes to leave the EU. Senior financiers have also warned of a potential economic downturn and job losses if a Brexit occurs. Despite this, some polls suggest the leave camp is gaining ground ahead of the June 23 referendum.

site_title: Eurozone at risk of suffering lasting economic damage: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi warns that the eurozone is at risk of suffering lasting economic damage due to weak productivity and low growth. Despite the European Central Bank's aggressive monetary policy, growth and inflation remain below targets, with the eurozone growing just 1.6% last year. Draghi urges governments to implement structural reforms to boost productivity and address the issue of low growth, as delaying these reforms could lead to permanent damage to the economy.

site_title: Those Brexit job losses? Recruiters say they've already started
