summary: The UK's impending Brexit vote is already causing job losses, with recruiters stating that companies are pushing pause on hiring and 17% of professionals have frozen hiring. A quarter of FTSE 350 directors are considering relocating at least part of their business outside the UK. The impact is expected to be felt across various sectors, with financial services, tech, and retail facing significant challenges. Economists warn that the slowdown in hiring will "come up in the GDP numbers" and will not recover overnight.

site_title: Japan voices 'serious concern' over Chinese naval ship near disputed islands
summary: Japan expressed "serious concern" over a Chinese naval ship entering disputed waters near the East China Sea, escalating tension unilaterally. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe instructed his government to closely coordinate with the US and other countries to address the incident. The ship sailed into Japan's territorial waters for the first time, prompting Japan to summon the Chinese ambassador in Tokyo. This move aims to demonstrate Japan's resolve to protect its sovereignty and territorial claims.

site_title: Big-brother pizza: Domino's to track customers on way to stores
summary: Domino's Pizza Enterprises Ltd, Australia's largest pizza company, will start using satellites to track customers as they approach stores to pick up orders, starting next week. The company can wait until the last moment to start cooking and ensure orders stay fresh. Customers can choose to be tracked for their mode of transportation, and the tracking is only for the duration of the order. The company aims to minimize the time pizzas sit on the rack to maintain quality, with CEO Don Meij stating "Time is the enemy of food."

site_title: Atlantic Navigation signs shipbuilding deals
summary: ATLANTIC Navigation Holdings signed shipbuilding agreements with a Chinese shipyard for five maintenance vessels and two anchor-handling tug vessels at a total cost of approximately US$45 million. The vessels will be deployed in the Arabian Gulf starting in the third quarter of 2017. The company will fund the construction using a combination of borrowings and internal resources. This deal supports Atlantic Navigation's operations and growth in the Middle East market.

site_title: New Zealand dollar surges on RBNZ surprise, greenback dips
summary: The New Zealand dollar surged to a one-year high, reaching US$0.7148, after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) kept interest rates unchanged but retained an easing bias. The kiwi currency jumped 1.7% due to market expectations of a rate cut, which were not met. Governor Graeme Wheeler stated the central bank would adjust rates if needed, providing some reassurance. Analysts believe the kiwi could continue to rise if US data disappoints, but also see potential risks to the downside, including another rate cut in August.

site_title: HDB resale prices in May edge up 0.2% from April: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in May rose 0.2% from April, with four-room flats decreasing and three-room, five-room, and executive flats increasing. Resale volume remained flat, with 1,826 units sold in May 2016. This marks the fifth consecutive month of flat resale prices, with a 10.9% decline from the peak in April 2013. Resale volume has increased by 15.9% from May 2015, but remains halved since the peak in May 2010.

site_title: Aspen to purchase anaesthetics from AstraZeneca for US$520m
summary: Aspen Pharmacare Holdings Ltd has agreed to purchase an anaesthetics portfolio from AstraZeneca Plc for at least US$520 million. The deal also includes royalties and up to US$250 million in additional sales-based instalments. Aspen will gain seven established medicines sold in over 100 countries, generating US$592 million in annual revenue. The acquisition is Aspen's first major deal since securing new funding, and the company sees anaesthetics as a therapeutic category with significant growth potential.

site_title: Europe: Shares down for second straight day
summary: European equities declined for the second consecutive day, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index losing 0.7% as of 8:19 am in London. The gauge fell despite signs of an improving economy and aggressive European Central Bank stimulus. The Stoxx 600 has struggled to maintain its rebound, closing 5.8% down for the year. Analysts project a 3.2% decline in earnings this year, and stocks like Seadrill, Rolls-Royce, and Essentra fell due to corporate news.

site_title: Update: China May inflation muted but producer deflation eases, policy seen steady
summary: China's inflation eased in May, with consumer prices rising 2.0% year-on-year and producer prices recovering 2.8% from a 3.4% drop in April. Deflationary pressures eased, supporting cash-strapped companies, but consumer inflation remains below the 3% target. The central bank is expected to keep policy supportive but may not cut interest rates further, with analysts predicting one interest rate cut this year. China's economic data shows a recovery, but growth is expected to slow in the second half, leading to further support from the government.

site_title: Civil service Internet lockdown necessary to safeguard government networks: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's government has been hit by "very sophisticated" cyber attacks, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. To safeguard government networks, the government will block internet access from public service computers starting May 2017, affecting around 100,000 computers. The move aims to ensure the security of government networks.

site_title: Dutch to be hit hard by any Brexit: official
summary: The Netherlands is expected to be severely affected by a potential Brexit, with a predicted 1.2% fall in GDP by 2030 and a 10 billion euros trade loss. The Central Planning Bureau warned that strong trade relations between the UK and the Netherlands would exacerbate the impact. The economic loss could be amplified by a 65% decrease in innovation, totaling a 16.2 billion euros loss. The Dutch government's think tank advises that a UK withdrawal from the EU would lead to uncertainty and direct economic losses.

site_title: London appetite for gold bars, coins rises on Brexit nerves
summary: Demand for gold bars and coins in London has surged since the Brexit referendum polls suggested a "leave" campaign lead, with sales rising 5-10% at some dealers. The UK is outstripping other regions in demand growth, with BullionVault.com reporting a 59% increase in UK customers. Investors are buying gold as a hedge against Brexit risk, with prices expected to rise if the UK exits the EU.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall on Japan economy fears, strong yen
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index fell 0.97% on Thursday, snapping a two-day winning streak, due to fresh data aggravating worries about Japan's economy and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 closed at 16,668.41 and the Topix index of all first-section shares slipped one percent to 1,337.41.

site_title: Oil prices add to gains after US supplies drop
summary: Oil prices reached multi-month highs after US commercial stocks fell 3.5 million barrels, exceeding expectations, and easing global supply glut. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 32 cents to $51.55 a barrel, while Brent gained 22 cents to $52.73 a barrel. The weakening dollar and signs of a global economic pick-up have contributed to the price gains, while disruptions to output from Nigeria and Canada have also fueled the increase. Oil prices have almost doubled since January, driven by a combination of factors.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong, Taiwan: Markets closed
summary: Financial markets in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Taiwan were closed on June 9, 2016, due to public holidays. No other key market events were reported in the provided articles.

site_title: Indonesian power plan delays fan industry frustrations
summary: Indonesia's power plan to boost electricity capacity by two-thirds by 2019 has been delayed due to postponed and cancelled tenders, reversals on planned projects, and uncertainty over the power mix. The plan, which aims to increase capacity by 35 gigawatts, has been hindered by changes to the energy mix, including a reduced reliance on coal power. Industry bodies and analysts warn that the delays and cancellations will undermine Indonesia's ability to attract finance for $132 billion of projects and may impact global markets.

site_title: Seoul: Won pares some gains on rate cut, stocks reverse
summary: The South Korean won closed nearly steady on Thursday after a 0.1% gain following the Bank of Korea's interest rate cut. However, the won reversed later in the day due to increased selling by individuals and local institutions. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) also closed down 0.1% at 2,024.17 points. Despite this, offshore investors purchased 325.5 billion won worth of shares, marking a third buying session.

images.alt_text: The South Korean won closed nearly steady on Thursday after giving up earlier gains, reacting to the Bank of Korea's policy decision to cut interest rates sooner than later.

site_title: Prime retail rents on Orchard Road fall for sixth straight quarter: CBRE
summary: Prime retail rents on Orchard Road in Singapore fell for the sixth consecutive quarter, averaging S$32.50 per square foot per month, a 1.1% decrease from the first quarter of 2016. Prime suburban rents also declined, weakening by 0.7% to S$29.45 psf/month. The retail sector is undergoing restructuring, with intense competition making location, visibility, and footfall crucial factors for brands. The lack of new supply until 2019 may support prime rents in Orchard Road for the next half year, according to CBRE Research.

site_title: Ringgit rises to three-week high with oil above US$52 a barrel
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose to a three-week high, reaching 4.0303 to the US dollar, due to a surge in crude oil prices above US$52 a barrel. This boost in oil prices has improved the outlook for Malaysia, Asia's only major net oil exporter.

site_title: British paedophile exploited stigma of abuse in vulnerable communities in KL
summary: A non-governmental organisation in Kuala Lumpur is holding workshops on sex education for children in a poor Indian community, following the conviction of British paedophile Richard Huckle. Despite initial reluctance from families, the workshops were finally agreed upon after weeks of persuasion. The community's stigma and denial about abuse were major barriers to participation, with some residents believing the victims were not among them. The workshops aim to provide a safe space for children to learn about sex and abuse, helping to combat the exploitation of vulnerable communities.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on growth worries, stronger yen
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on June 9, 2016, due to concerns over Japan's economic growth and a stronger yen. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.53% to 16,742.03, while the Topix index declined 0.52% to 1,343.96. Despite a positive lead from Wall Street, investors were cautious about the economic outlook.

site_title: Hot stock: Otto Marine jumps on S$68m delisting offer
summary: Otto Marine shares jumped 37% to 31.5 Singapore cents after executive chairman Yaw Chee Siew proposed a voluntary delisting valued at S$68 million. Yaw offered to buy out remaining shareholders at 32 cents per share, a 39.1% premium over the June 1 closing price. The delisting is subject to bondholders agreeing to extend the maturity date of their multi-currency term notes for six months.

site_title: Gold near three-week high as central banks stay accommodative
summary: Gold prices held near a three-week high, rising 1.5% to $1,262.80 per ounce on Wednesday, as investors expect central banks to remain accommodative. The European Central Bank launched a corporate bond-buying program, while investors predict US interest rates will stay low for longer. This bullish sentiment contributed to gold's highest close since May 17.

site_title: Thai May consumer sentiment at 8-month low
summary: Thai consumer sentiment reached an 8-month low in May, with a fifth consecutive decline, due to economic concerns and drought. The University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce survey found consumers believed the economic recovery was slow, with household debt levels high. The economy grew 0.9% in the first quarter of 2016, but the Bank of Thailand forecast 3.1% growth for the year. The decline in consumer confidence is attributed to the ongoing sluggishness in pivotal exports and domestic demand since the 2014 army seizure of power.

images.alt_text: Thai consumer confidence dropped for a fifth straight month in May, a university survey showed on Thursday, due to concerns over economic prospects at home and abroad, drought and low commodity prices.

site_title: Asia tracks Wall Street higher, kiwi flies as central bank stands pat
summary: Asian stocks rose 0.3% on Thursday, following Wall Street's gain overnight, while the US dollar weakened and commodities like gold and oil surged. The New Zealand dollar hit a one-year high after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand kept interest rates steady as expected. The Dow gained 0.4% overnight, lifting some commodity-related shares, and investors have stepped back into riskier assets globally after a weaker-than-expected US non-farm jobs report.

site_title: Seoul: Won fluctuates after the BOK cuts rates; stocks at 2016 high
summary: The Bank of Korea unexpectedly cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to 1.25 percent, citing stagnant inflation and exports. This move led to a strengthening of the South Korean won, trading at 1,155.7 as of Thursday morning. The decision is seen as a response to the country's economic sluggishness, and investors are cautiously optimistic about the impact on the stock market, which has reached a 2016 high.

site_title: Apple revamps App Store, may not win over developers
summary: Apple has revamped its App Store with enhanced features, including increased advertising and revenue-sharing opportunities for developers. The changes aim to sustain the App Store's lucrative business by making it easier for developers to stand out and customers to find what they need. However, concerns persist that the App Store's sheer volume of over 1.9 million apps makes it difficult for developers to find an audience. The store's success also raises questions about the future of individual apps and the rise of messaging services and artificial intelligence, potentially shifting the balance of power from Apple to Google.

site_title: Obama hopeful Sanders will wind up campaign within a 'couple of weeks'
summary: Barack Obama expressed hope that Bernie Sanders will concede the Democratic presidential nomination to Hillary Clinton within the next couple of weeks. Obama praised Sanders' candidacy, calling it a "healthy thing" for the party and saying it made Clinton a better candidate. Despite Sanders' refusal to concede, Obama plans to meet with him to urge him to formally end his campaign. Obama also emphasized the importance of the presidential election, stating that he has confidence in the American people to make a good choice.

site_title: Thais celebrate 70 years of king's reign, but anxious about his health
summary: Thailand celebrates King Bhumibol Adulyadej's 70-year reign, but anxiety surrounds his health. The king, a semi-divine figure, has been in hospital for over a year and received heart treatment. His son, Crown Prince Vajiralongkorn, is the heir apparent, but lacks the devotion his father enjoys. The monarchy's influence is deeply ingrained in Thai society, with the king's image ubiquitous in education, media, and public life. The kingdom marks the occasion amid a critical political juncture, with a referendum on a constitution that critics say would extend military influence.

site_title: South Korea central bank cuts rates to record low 1.25%, sooner than expected
summary: South Korea's central bank cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to a record-low 1.25% on June 9, 2016, as inflation failed to accelerate and exports showed no signs of rebounding. This was the first rate cut since June 2015. The decision was made slightly sooner than expected, with Governor Lee Ju Yeol set to hold a news conference later. The move aims to stimulate the economy, which has been experiencing a slowdown.

images.alt_text: South Korea's central bank cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to a record-low 1.25 per cent on Thursday slightly sooner than expected as inflation has failed to accelerate and exports are far from a rebound.

site_title: Four killed in shooting at Tel Aviv nightspot
summary: A shooting at a popular Tel Aviv nightspot near Israel's military headquarters killed four people, including two Palestinians who opened fire, and injured five others. The attackers, cousins from the Hebron area, were apprehended and one was wounded, while the others' weapons were recovered by police. Israeli authorities condemned the attack, with the US and UN expressing solidarity. The incident is one of the worst in a months-long wave of violence, which has killed at least 207 Palestinians and 28 Israelis since October.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.140 points to 1657.530. Gainers outnumbered losers 87 to 37, with a total volume of 39.4 million lots worth RM9.73 million.

site_title: US agency endorses plan to cede Internet oversight
summary: The US Commerce Department has endorsed a plan to transfer oversight of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) to a multi-stakeholder model, avoiding control by a single governmental body. The transition aims to preserve a free and open Internet, following a two-year proposal from ICANN and input from businesses, academia, and governments. The plan will not affect user interaction, but ICANN will take technical supervision of the online address system with checks and balances in place.

site_title: China uses Swat teams to crack down on college exam cheats
summary: China's public security authorities have cracked down on college entrance examination cheaters, using SWAT teams to guard test centers and arresting those caught cheating. The "gaokao" exam determines university students' futures, with 9.4 million students competing for limited spots. Those caught cheating risk up to 7 years in prison. Authorities are targeting wireless devices and substitute exam sitters, and experts warn that cheating undermines the exam's credibility and government authority. China will continue to take measures to prevent cheating, according to an expert.

site_title: China May CPI up 2% y-o-y, below forecasts
summary: China's consumer price inflation in May rose 2% from a year earlier, below market expectations of 2.3%. Producer prices fell 2.8% from a year earlier, also below forecasts. The data suggests China's economy is showing signs of slowing, which could raise pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Brazil's central bank keeps 14.25% interest rate: officials
summary: Brazil's central bank held its benchmark interest rate at 14.25% for a seventh consecutive time, amid the country's worst recession in decades and political instability. Despite a forecasted 3.8% GDP shrink in 2016, economists surveyed by the Central Bank's Focus magazine predicted no change in the key rate. The decision was made to maintain stability amid economic uncertainty.

site_title: A-Reit to sell logistics facility near Shanghai for S$26m
summary: A-Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has agreed to sell its A-Reit Jiashan Logistics Centre in China for S$26 million, generating a gain of S$5.1 million over development costs. The centre, located near Shanghai, was sold to Goodman Developments Asia and GCLP Developments No 3 (BVI) Limited. The sale will strengthen the trust's resources to pursue other opportunities in Singapore, Australia, and China, according to its CEO, Chia Nam Toon.

site_title: New London homes delayed as tax hike 'strangling' luxury market
summary: Developers in London are delaying luxury-home projects due to increased sales taxes, which have made building less profitable. A 3 percentage point rise in stamp-duty sales tax for landlords and second-home owners in April, combined with a 2014 increase in charges for all luxury-home purchasers, has led to a 40% increase in upscale homes with planning permission. To mitigate the tax burden, developers are redesigning projects to include smaller apartments and fewer larger homes, which will maintain values per square foot while reducing tax liabilities.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, A-Reit, Otto Marine, Tuan Sing, Trek 2000, Starhill Global Reit
summary: Olam International acquired Brooks Peanut Company for $85 million. Ascendas Real Estate Investment Trust (A-Reit) sold A-Reit Jiashan Logistics Centre in China for $26 million. Otto Marine proposed a voluntary delisting amid industry downturn. Tuan Sing formed a 90:10 joint venture to develop a site in Batam into a mixed development township. site_title: Olam acquires Alabama's largest peanut sheller for US$85m
summary: Olam International has acquired Brooks Peanut Company, Alabama's largest peanut sheller, for $85 million. This acquisition strengthens Olam's market position as the third largest peanut sheller in the US, expanding its sourcing network into new areas in Alabama and Florida. The deal is expected to be completed by the third quarter of 2016 and will be earnings accretive in 2016.

site_title: Undecided voters see Brexit making them worse off: survey
summary: Undecided voters in the UK's Brexit referendum believe they would be 71 pounds worse off annually if Britain quits the EU, with households estimated to be 181 pounds worse off in five years after a "Leave" vote. This contrasts with 110 pounds worse off per annum if Britain stays in the bloc. The survey suggests the "Leave" camp faces a bigger challenge than the "Remain" side, with voters skeptical about the "Leave" camp's arguments and potential economic impacts of Brexit.

site_title: Morgan Stanley penalised US$1m over data theft
summary: Morgan Stanley has been fined US$1 million by the Securities and Exchange Commission for failing to adequately protect customer data. An employee, Galen Marsh, downloaded confidential records of 730,000 clients between 2011 and 2014, which were then posted for sale online. The bank initially claimed no customers were affected, but later acknowledged the breach. Marsh was convicted and sentenced to probation and restitution. The SEC emphasized the importance of data security in investor protection, stating that registrants must have policies and procedures to protect customer information.

site_title: UK house prices set for first fall since 2012 as EU vote weighs
summary: British house prices are forecast to fall for the first time in nearly four years due to the uncertainty surrounding the EU referendum and a new tax on buy-to-let properties. A majority of property valuers polled by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors expect prices to drop over the next three months, despite some still predicting an increase over the next 12 months. The RICS chief economist stated that a fundamental shift is not expected, with prices expected to rise by 4% over the next five years.

site_title: Singapore shares open up 8.4 points on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 8.38 points higher to 2,870.76, driven by top gainers UOB, Keppel Corporation, and Otto Marine. The STI has recorded a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The Nasdaq edged to a fresh record, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average also closed higher. Investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, with 73 gainers outnumbering 37 losers.

site_title: Head of New York City corrections officers union charged with fraud
summary: Norman Seabrook, president of the Correction Officers' Benevolent Association in New York City, and Murray Huberfeld, a hedge fund financier, were charged with orchestrating a bribery scheme involving union retirement funds. Seabrook invested $20 million of union money in Platinum Partners in exchange for kickbacks from Huberfeld. The case is linked to a broader federal corruption probe examining Mayor Bill de Blasio's fundraising practices. Seabrook was released on a $250,000 bond package, while Huberfeld was released on a $1 million bond package.

images.alt_text: The union leader for New York City's prison guards and a hedge fund financier were charged on Wednesday with orchestrating a bribery scheme involving union retirement and operating funds in a case stemming from a wide-ranging federal corruption probe.

site_title: New York City reaches agreement on US$82.1b FY 2017 budget
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a budget agreement for the 2016-2017 fiscal year, totaling $82.1 billion, with increased reserves and a summer youth employment program expansion to 60,000. The agreement boosts reserves by $250 million and includes $1 billion in general reserves and $500 million in the capital stabilization reserve. The budget highlights de Blasio's social mission, including a $2 billion overhaul of the city's public hospital system. The agreement comes ahead of a July 1 deadline and marks the earliest agreement since 2001.

site_title: US hedge fund sues 'Panama Papers' law firm
summary: US hedge fund Elliott Management Corp. has sued law firm Mossack Fonseca, claiming it obstructed justice in its pursuit of Argentina's defaulted debt. Mossack Fonseca is linked to the Panama Papers scandal, which revealed over 200,000 secret offshore companies. The lawsuit alleges that Mossack Fonseca hindered Elliott's efforts to track down assets linked to shell companies in Nevada, resulting in substantial legal fees. The suit comes after Argentina paid off its debts to Elliott and other hedge funds in a multi-billion dollar deal.

site_title: Glencore agrees to sell further stake in Agri unit for US$624.9m
summary: Glencore has agreed to sell a 9.99% stake in its agricultural business to British Columbia Investment Management Corp for US$624.9 million. This sale follows the company's previous sale of a 40% stake to Canada Pension Plan Investment Board for US$2.5 billion in April. The deal will leave Glencore with a 50.01% stake in the business, which will continue to be run by the existing management team. The sale is part of Glencore's efforts to cut debt.

site_title: Medical helicopters tipped for future China boom
summary: China is poised to experience a boom in air ambulance services as it opens up its low-level airspace to civilian aircraft, with Airbus predicting sales of up to 300 helicopters annually by 2025. The country's fleet of air ambulance helicopters is currently minimal due to airspace restrictions, but the liberalization is expected to multiply demand, with estimates suggesting over 3,000 emergency medical choppers could be needed. However, China's creaking and ageing hospital infrastructure may hinder the development of air ambulance services, with some hospitals citing difficulties in accommodating helipads.

site_title: Hillary Clinton and the 'woman card'
summary: Hillary Clinton has been playing the "woman card" in her presidential campaign, highlighting her historic bid as the first woman to run for the US presidency as a major party candidate. She has shattered glass ceilings and is now capitalizing on her opponent Donald Trump's sexist rhetoric, appealing to women voters who overwhelmingly disapprove of him. Clinton's campaign is also focusing on the impact of a female president on women's rights and empowerment, particularly for young female voters.

site_title: US warns banks on cyber threat after Bangladesh Bank heist
summary: US regulators have warned banks to review cyber-security protections against fraudulent money transfers after a hacking group stole US$81 million from the Bangladesh central bank. The warning comes after the US Federal Bureau of Investigation privately urged banks to look for signs of cyber attacks. The Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council advises banks to review risk-management practices and controls over payment systems networks, including authentication and fraud detection. Experts say the warning is a repeat of previous recommendations, but the US government is concerned about potential losses for big US firms relying on the Swift fund-transfer network.

site_title: US: Stocks edge near record; Eurozone shares fall
summary: US stocks edged near record highs on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 adding 0.3% to reach 2,119.12, just 12 points shy of its all-time high. The rally was boosted by higher oil prices and a weaker dollar, with analysts expecting the US Federal Reserve to keep interest rates low. In contrast, eurozone shares fell due to concerns over slowing global growth.

site_title: Oil prices hit new 2016 highs on Nigeria cutbacks, US data
summary: Oil prices surged to 2016 highs for the third consecutive day due to supply disruptions in Nigeria, where the Niger Delta Avengers attacked oil facilities, reducing output from 2.2 million barrels to 1.6 million barrels per day. Lower US petroleum inventories also contributed to the price increase. The disruptions have significant implications for Opec, a major oil-producing nation, and the global energy market.

images.alt_text: Oil prices climbed to fresh peaks for 2016 for the third day in a row on Wednesday due to supply disruptions in Nigeria and data showing lower US petroleum inventories.

site_title: Thousands flock to posh Paris flash mob picnic
summary: A flash mob picnic took place in Paris' Place Vendome, where 7,000 people dressed in white gathered for a fine dining experience. The "Diner en Blanc" event, now in its 28th year, requires secrecy until the last minute, and attendees are expected to conduct themselves with elegance and etiquette. The movement, founded in 1988 by Francois Pasquier, has spread to 70 cities worldwide, with guests tidying up afterwards, leaving the venue as they found it. The event is a unique blend of luxury and spontaneity, showcasing Paris' classiest side.

site_title: Germany urges 'level playing field' in foreign investment
summary: Germany's economy minister, Sigmar Gabriel, has called for an international "level playing field" in foreign investment, citing concerns over Chinese interest in German firms. Gabriel distinguished between open markets and a "state-capitalist interventionist market," referencing China, and emphasized the need for fairness and fair competition. Germany is considering a counter-offer for Kuka, a German industrial technology group targeted by Chinese buyer Midea, amid concerns over the impact of Chinese steel prices on European industry.

site_title: Euro gains on US dollar as ECB launches new bond buying
summary: The euro rose to its highest level in three weeks against the US dollar, reaching above the US$1.14 level, following the European Central Bank's launch of new stimulus operations. The euro slipped back to US$1.1393. Meanwhile, the yen gained ground against both the dollar and euro, while the pound fell due to concerns about a possible pro-Brexit vote. The ECB's actions aim to boost the euro and stabilize the currency amidst global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Fancier, Stone for Gold look for Claude Bernard
summary: Crystal Time has partnered with local leather artisan Xie Hui's Stone for Gold Pte Ltd to offer custom-made leather straps for its Claude Bernard range of watches. This collaboration comes as Crystal Time notices a growing trend of men seeking fashionable watches with interchangeable straps. Stone for Gold's leather straps are hand-made according to customer specifications, with a focus on quality and durability. The partnership aims to provide customers with a personal connection to their watches, aligning with Claude Bernard's values of hand-assembled quality.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as Unicredit and Erste hit financials
summary: European shares fell on Wednesday, snapping a two-day winning streak, due to a drop in Italian bank UniCredit and Austrian bank Erste. Mixed Chinese economic data and a World Bank cut to its 2016 global growth forecast also contributed to the decline. Traders expressed concerns about the outlook for stock markets, citing disappointing Chinese export figures and bearish views on the markets.

site_title: Euro's global role slips in multipolar system
summary: The euro's global role has declined slightly in 2015 and early 2016, slipping to 19.9% of international reserves and 29.4% of global payments, down from previous years. This shift is attributed to China's growing influence, with its yuan becoming a larger reserve currency and trade partner. The European Central Bank acknowledges the decline, stating that market forces determine the euro's international use, and notes a trend towards greater multipolarity in the international monetary system.

site_title: Trek 2000 appoints RSM as forensic accountants
summary: Trek 2000 International has appointed RSM Corporate Advisory as forensic accountants to aid in an independent review of interested party transactions (IPTs) following concerns raised by TSMP Law Corporation. The review will examine past transactions, internal approval processes, and financial impact. The appointment comes after the company faced documentation deficiencies and potential offences under the Penal Code, with four executives, including the CEO, being interviewed by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) and released on bail. The board is engaging business associates to ensure business continuity.

site_title: Modi urges US-India partnership against terror
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi urged the US to strengthen their partnership against terrorism and regional instability. He emphasized the need to isolate those supporting terrorism in the region, without mentioning Pakistan by name. Modi also highlighted the importance of a US-India partnership in ensuring the security of sea lanes of commerce and freedom of navigation. The partnership, he said, would help counterbalance China's maritime territorial ambitions.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi declared on Wednesday that India and the United States should work together more closely to defeat terrorism and head off regional instability.

site_title: S'pore's productivity growth ahead of comparable economies
summary: Singapore's productivity growth outperformed comparable high-income economies, with an average output per worker rising 1.5 percentage points per annum from 2000-2015. The country's strong productivity growth was attributed to positive structural trends such as sectoral shifts towards manufacturing and services, urbanization, and a stable supply of finance. However, Singapore's "prime age" share is expected to stabilize, easing potential productivity drag from aging. The report also notes that the economy's reliance on services growth and competitiveness issues may hinder near-term performance.

site_title: Tennis: Sharapova to appeal 'unfairly harsh' two-year doping ban
summary: Russian tennis star Maria Sharapova has vowed to appeal a two-year doping ban imposed by the International Tennis Federation (ITF) after testing positive for the banned substance meldonium during the Australian Open. Sharapova claims the ban is "unfairly harsh" and that she did not intentionally violate anti-doping rules. The ban is backdated to January 26, 2016, and is set to end on January 25, 2018. Sharapova will appeal the suspension to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS).

site_title: Indonesia to lower 2016 growth target to 5.1%
summary: Indonesia's parliament is set to revise the country's 2016 economic growth target to 5.1% from 5.3%, amid slowing domestic consumption and tax revenue shortfalls. The revision is a downward adjustment from the government's initial target of 7% and reflects the nation's struggles to boost economic growth despite efforts to open up to foreign investors and boost spending on infrastructure. The revised target is a compromise between the government's 5.2% proposal and lawmakers' calls for a 5% target.

site_title: New Zealand leaves interest rates at record low
summary: New Zealand's central bank left interest rates at a record low of 2.25% on June 8, 2016, in line with market expectations. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand stated that more rate cuts may be necessary if inflation doesn't reach its target range of 1.0-3.0%. Governor Graeme Wheeler emphasized the bank's continued monitoring of economic data. This marks the fifth rate cut in the past 12 months, despite inflation remaining low at 0.4% in the year to March 31.

site_title: Iran to seek investors for US$3b refinery
summary: Iran plans to seek international investors for a $3 billion refinery project on its Persian Gulf coast, aiming to boost oil and natural gas sales in Asia. The project, led by Siraf Refineries Infrastructure Co, will produce naphtha for chemical plants and target Asia's growing demand for refined oil products. Iran plans to issue a tender in two to three months, with interest from Japanese and South Korean companies. The project will start in three years and reach full capacity in four years, with a focus on developing Iran's chemicals industry and increasing revenue.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Marine extends standstill agreement for semi-submersible drilling rig West Rigel to Sept 2, 2016. The rig's delivery is contingent on securing a drilling contract or completing an alternative transaction by the deadline. Mary Chia Holdings faces charges against its CEO and subsidiary for failing to obtain valid work passes and maintaining proper employee records. Starhill Global Reit raises base rents for its Toshin master lease by 5.5%, effective June 8, 2016. Logos Property Group sets up a Singapore office and launches an investment venture with an initial commitment of S$150 million.

site_title: Valeant CEO cuts outlook for 'distracted' company, shares dive
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc slashed its 2016 forecasts due to a "distracted organisation" with a debt-loaded balance sheet. The company, maker of toenail fungus cream and anti-depressant drug, missed first-quarter profit estimates and expects full-year adjusted earnings of $6.60-7.00 per share, down from previous forecasts. Valeant's US-listed shares plummeted 14.6% to close at $24.64, and CEO Joe Papa plans to focus on rebuilding the company's reputation and stabilizing operations, including staff recruitment and asset sales, over the next six months.

site_title: India private banks' new loans outpace those of state rivals
summary: India's privately owned banks have extended new loans faster than state-run rivals for the first time, surpassing 3.5 trillion rupees in the year to March 31. This growth has led to a 16-year high stressed-loan ratio of 14.34% for state banks, hindering Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to revive credit growth. Private sector banks' faster loan growth is expected to continue, with their share of total banking assets predicted to rise to 32% by 2025. Timely capital infusions into public sector banks are seen as crucial to aid credit flow.

site_title: Smaller computing chips may depend on technology from grandma's radio
summary: Researchers at the California Institute of Technology are developing ultra-small vacuum tubes as a potential replacement for smaller computing chips. The tiny tubes, made from metal and capable of controlling the flow of electrons, could use less power and work faster than current transistor-based chips. This technology, inspired by the vacuum tubes of old family radios, could be ready commercially in the next decade, particularly for applications in space and aviation. The researchers believe that the limitations of scaling down transistors are being overcome by the principles of quantum tunnelling, which could revolutionize the field of microelectronics.

site_title: Banks to Basel: Back off on credit-risk capital restriction
summary: Banks are pushing back against Basel's proposed credit-risk capital restrictions, warning that regulators risk slowing the global economy with curbs on lenders' ability to assess risks. The Institute of International Finance (IIF) has written to the Basel Committee, suggesting revisions to the proposal that would grant banks more leeway in assessing borrower risk, particularly for large corporations. The IIF argues that the current restrictions could lead to reduced lending and higher borrowing costs, while Basel claims the rules aim to ensure sufficient capital levels. The Basel Committee has set a June 24 deadline for comments on the proposal.

site_title: Zika virus turning Games into an Olympic battle for beleaguered Brazil
summary: Brazil is struggling to host the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro due to a debilitating political crisis, an economy in free fall, and a Zika virus outbreak. President Dilma Rousseff has been suspended and faces impeachment, while key figures behind her ouster are implicated in a graft probe. The Zika virus has been declared a global health emergency, with over 120,000 probable cases in Brazil and concerns about its link to neurological disorders. The International Olympic Committee is set to decide whether to postpone or move the Games to mitigate the risks, with many experts calling for the event to be postponed for public health reasons.

site_title: The next chapter of China-S'pore financial connectivity will be exciting
summary: China's economy is at a major inflection point, balancing growth, restructuring, and financial internationalization. The country is shifting from a labor-intensive to a more skill- and technology-intensive economy, with implications for regional economies. China has become a net exporter of direct investment and is promoting the use of its currency, the RMB, in cross-border payments. Singapore is a key partner in China's financial integration, with the country using Singapore as a gateway to South-east Asia. The next chapter in China-Singapore financial connectivity will focus on capital management, risk management, and infrastructure financing, with a goal of promoting sustainable and vibrant economic growth in the region.

site_title: KKR takes 10.44% stake in Japfa's Indonesian unit for US$80m
summary: KKR, a US private equity firm, has invested US$80 million to acquire a 10.44% stake in PT Japfa Comfeed Indonesia Tbk, its first direct investment in Indonesia. Japfa manufactures animal feed and breeds chicken. The investment is part of a private placement where Japfa issued 750 million new shares at US$52.9 million. KKR's investment is seen as a strategic move into the Indonesian market.

site_title: COE premiums spike after government eases car loan curbs
summary: COE premiums in Singapore surged to their highest levels since December 2015 after the government eased car loan restrictions, sparking a surge in demand. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's move to allow up to 70% borrowing and 7-year repayment periods pushed buyers into the market, resulting in oversubscribed bids and higher premiums. Category A premiums rose by S$6,674 to S$53,694, while Category B and Cat E premiums also increased, with Cat E seeing the steepest rise since December. Experts predict COE premiums will continue to rise in the near term.

site_title: GM's CEO Barra says 'undervalued' carmaker can sustain profit
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra says the company is undervalued and can sustain profits despite slowing US vehicle sales and long-term threats from ride-sharing and self-driving cars. Despite record profits last year, GM shares have fallen 12% this year. Barra attributes this to investors' concerns over the vehicle market's peak and the need for consumers to buy 13 million to 14 million vehicles to break even. GM is investing in ride-sharing and self-driving cars, and has reduced costs by $5.5 billion by 2018. The company expects to maintain profitability even in a downturn, citing its ability to cut work shifts quickly and limit inventory.

site_title: US businesses pessimistic about operating in China
summary: US businesses express pessimism about operating in China, citing a slowing economy, growing fears of protectionism, and rules that could limit their operations. Draft regulations for China's insurance and banking industries, as well as a pending cybersecurity law, are concerns. The US-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue's eighth round failed to deliver significant market-opening reforms, with many US business leaders feeling that commitments made during the talks have not been adhered to.

site_title: S&P warns of sovereign downgrades linked to debt burden
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) warns that sovereign downgrades in credit ratings are possible due to rising interest rates and deteriorating fiscal performance. The ratings agency cites the link between private-sector debt and sovereign ratings, citing the World Bank's concerns about credit booms in emerging markets. China is identified as having the largest private credit outstanding relative to GDP, and energy exporters are seen as being most vulnerable to financial stress. S&P's warning comes as markets speculate on the next US Federal Reserve rate hike.

site_title: Understanding the business case for diversity
summary: Singapore's talent shortage has led to a growing need for strategic human resource management. Companies like Henkel, which employs people from 125 nations, recognize the importance of diversity and inclusion in driving innovation and competitiveness. A study by the National University of Singapore found that companies with diverse workforces outperformed others by nearly five times. Implementing inclusive leadership and respecting individual differences are key to unlocking the full potential of diverse teams.

site_title: Planning and partnerships are key to investing in India
summary: The Modi government in India has completed its first two years in office, focusing on economic reforms, broadening FDI policy, and improving ease of doing business. India emerged as the top FDI destination globally in the first half of 2016, with Singapore being the top foreign investor, surpassing Mauritius. Recent amendments to India's tax treaties with Mauritius and Singapore may change the game for capital gains tax exemptions, prompting investors to reevaluate their investments. Effective planning, partnering, and understanding of India's complex laws and regulations are crucial for investment success in the country.

site_title: Homegrown fintech is first Asian startup to win funding from Wells Fargo
summary: Kuala Lumpur-based fintech startup Jewel Paymentech has won up to US$500,000 in funding from Wells Fargo's Spring 2016 accelerator programme, making it the first Asian startup to be backed by the American financial services company. Jewel, which provides intelligent risk solutions for the banking and electronics payments industry, will join the six-month programme starting this month. The funding is in return for a minority stake in the startup, and will allow Jewel to work closely with Wells Fargo's business units to address various risk issues faced by the industry.

site_title: MAS adjusts securities crowdfunding rules to facilitate retail access
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has modified proposed rules on securities crowdfunding to facilitate retail access. The changes close a loophole that allowed some platforms to bypass licensing requirements and prospectus publishing, while also streamlining rules for licensed platforms to tap the retail market. MAS will seek legislative amendments to remove the exemption for promissory notes, requiring platforms to be licensed and publish prospectuses. Existing platforms will benefit from lowered capital requirements and streamlined rules, with some industry players welcoming the moves as beneficial for an orderly growth of the sector.

site_title: Singapore brand flying high in Yangon
summary: Singapore's presence is growing in Yangon, Myanmar, with multiple Singaporean-owned businesses, including Ya Kun cafes, Krislite, and Keppel Land hotels. The city is becoming a hub for Singaporean entrepreneurs and businesses, earning the nickname "Little Singapore." The government has also announced a visa-free travel agreement for Singaporeans and Myanmar citizens, expected to boost commercial and people-to-people links. With Myanmar's transition to democracy, Singapore sees opportunities for growth in the country, with the city's vibrant and promising economy.

site_title: China exports dip further but import slide eases
summary: China's exports continued to contract in May, with imports falling at their slowest pace in 18 months, indicating a possible recovery in domestic consumption. Despite this, the country's central bank predicts a 6.8% economic growth for this year. The weaker-than-expected export data is attributed to weak global demand, but the easing of import decline suggests a stabilizing economy.

site_title: VW, workers to discuss plan to fix German plants
summary: Volkswagen's executives and labour bosses will discuss a plan to fix the company's German plants, following a pay deal with the IG Metall union. The talks come after industrial relations hit a low in April, with workers accusing VW chief Herbert Diess of betraying them. The company aims to recover from the diesel emissions scandal, which has cost it billions. The meeting signals further rapprochement between top managers and labour leaders, a critical time for Europe's largest carmaker.

site_title: Globalisation in retreat
summary: US business leaders and politicians are increasingly questioning the future of globalization, citing its flaws and defects. GE CEO Jeffrey Immelt argues for a "bold pivot" towards localization, producing goods where sales are made, but this could lead to US economic stagnation. Protectionist policies, such as Trump's proposed 45% tariff on Chinese imports, may have unintended consequences, including shifting production to other low-wage countries and worsening trade conflicts. Despite its shortcomings, globalization has contributed to reduced worldwide poverty and should not be abandoned without a better alternative.

site_title: STI up for 5th day despite late pullback
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose for the fifth consecutive day, driven by a firming oil price and gains in offshore and marine stocks, as well as three banks. The index closed at 2,862.38, a net gain of 14.29 points. The broad market saw 251 gains versus 159 losses, excluding warrants. A weak US jobs report and the upcoming UK referendum on EU membership also contributed to the positive sentiment.

site_title: PM Lee to S'poreans in Myanmar: Still some uncertainties, but press on
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong addressed a dinner reception for Singaporeans in Myanmar, acknowledging that there are still uncertainties in the country's progress but expressing optimism about the future. He announced that Singapore and Myanmar will have visa-free access for ordinary passport holders from December 1 for stays of up to 30 days, and proposed "stopover flights" by Singapore Airlines and SilkAir in Myanmar. The move aims to deepen interaction and cooperation between the two countries, with Lee encouraging Singaporeans to take advantage of new opportunities in Myanmar.

site_title: Tours of Ceausescu's villa eschew mention of his dictatorship
summary: The Romanian government has opened the former palace of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, known as the Spring Palace, to the public as a museum 26 years after his execution. The 30-room villa, with 53,000 square feet of space, features a mix of late Renaissance and Rococo styles, but lacks opulent decorations. Visitors are asked to remove their shoes and are given guided tours that focus on the palace's furnishings and decorations rather than its history under Ceausescu's dictatorship. The government aims to allow visitors to draw their own conclusions about the former leader, but some critics argue that the approach misses an opportunity to address Romania's troubled relationship with its history.

images.alt_text: Known as the Spring Palace, the villa is spacious - 30 rooms, 53,000 sq ft, with gardens for winter and summer - but not quite opulent by palace standards. Visitors are asked to put on blue shoe coverings before stepping inside. More than a dozen rooms are decorated in a mix of late Renaissance and Rococo styles.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has delayed the commencement of the third bus package in Seletar from H2 2016 to H1 2018, with the contract terms to be privately negotiated between the incumbents and LTA. This delay is expected to have little impact on the sector, with OCBC Investment Research maintaining its "neutral" rating. The transition to the new bus government contracting model (GCM) for the remaining nine packages is expected to be punctual by Sept 1, 2016.

images.alt_text: Land Transport Authority (LTA) yesterday put up the third bus package in Seletar for tender, which consists of around 420 buses and is expected to grow to around 500 buses in 2023.

site_title: Local cruise industry to get boost from smart cruise ship next year
summary: Royal Caribbean's Ovation of the Seas, a 347-meter-long cruise ship with a capacity for over 4,900 guests, will homeport in Singapore for a season next year, expected to boost the local cruise industry with an additional 42,000 guests. The ship features high-speed WiFi, an observation capsule, indoor skydiving, and a hi-tech entertainment venue. Its S$1.37 billion investment is seen as a significant boost to the industry, providing a unique and innovative experience for travelers.

site_title: Commercial/residential site next to Woodleigh MRT sparks market interest
summary: A 2.55-hectare site next to Woodleigh MRT Station in Singapore has been added to the second half 2016 Government Land Sales Programme, offering an estimated 825 private homes and 15,000 square meters of commercial space. The site is expected to fetch bids ranging from S$750-920 per square foot per plot ratio, with property consultants predicting a high bid of S$850. This is one of four new sites introduced by the Ministry of National Development, with the other sites being a 0.4-hectare plot near Farrer Park MRT Station and two reserve-list sites.

site_title: Premier Taxi to accept Apple Pay, Visa
summary: Premier Taxi has introduced a new point-of-sale system that accepts Apple Pay and Visa, making it the second taxi operator to do so in Singapore. The system, developed by Wirecard, also accepts other contact and contactless payment modes, including ez-Link and MasterCard. Premier Taxi is expected to start accepting Visa payments later this year, following ComfortDelGro taxis, which reinstated payment services for Visa cards earlier this year. The move aims to provide convenience to commuters and may attract more retailers to adopt the ez-Link system.

site_title: Japanese warming to home auctions amid pain of negative rates
summary: In Japan, public auctions of homes are becoming more common due to negative interest rates, which have sparked a surge in property demand. The Real Estate Auction Circulation Association organized six auctions in Tokyo and surrounding areas, with all homes selling for less than $47,000. The BOJ's negative-rate policy has led to a rise in loans for buy-to-rent property investments, reaching a record high of 21.55 trillion yen in March. Experts warn that Tokyo's office and residential markets are showing signs of overheating, but the BOJ's policy may encourage investors to boost real estate investment.

images.alt_text: Six homes in tokyo and surrounding areas were sold last month at an auction, the first organised by the real estate auction circulation association, with all of the homes selling for less than us$47,000.

site_title: Land for private housing in H2 GLS list up a tad from H1
summary: Singapore's confirmed list supply of private housing, including executive condominiums, has risen 39.1% to 2,170 homes in the second half of the year, mainly due to a matching actual committed supply of 2,130 units in the first half. The total supply for the period will be 7,545 homes, up just 1.8% from the previous period. The government aims to find a balance between supply and demand to ensure sustainable housing prices and a stable property market. Two new sites will be offered, including one in the new Bidadari estate.

site_title: OECD indicator flags US, China turnaround
summary: The OECD's monthly leading indicator shows signs of a turnaround in the US and China economies, with the US index improving to 98.95 in April and China's rising to 98.41, marking the first increase since July 2014. Stable growth momentum is seen in the eurozone, while Brazil and Russia show positive changes in growth momentum. However, the UK economy shrinks for the second month in a row, adding to economic concerns.

site_title: Target wants suppliers to bear more of promotions costs
summary: US retailer Target is asking suppliers to bear 3-5% more of the cost of promotions and price cuts due to slow sales this year. Suppliers have already paid Target $379 million in marketing costs last year. The move aims to minimize the impact of markdowns on profit. Suppliers will have to comply or deliver part of Target's demands to clear out old stock for new products, straining already thin margins.

images.alt_text: Target, the second-largest discount retailer in the US, wants to minimise the impact of markdowns on profit in a tough year as middle-income customers make fewer discretionary purchases.

site_title: Talent shortage stymies Indonesia's tech scene
summary: Indonesia's tech sector is hindered by a severe talent shortage, with only 10% of the workforce being highly skilled. The country needs to attract investment worth $40-50 billion to become a $200 billion internet economy, but a lack of experience, low salaries, and shortcomings in the education system are major obstacles. Investors are offshoring tech work to fill the gap, with some startups in neighboring countries reaching valuations of over $1 billion. The government plans to tackle the skills shortage by putting coding on the public school curriculum and knowledge transfers from foreign investors.

site_title: Le Méridien back in Singapore with rebranded hotel in Sentosa
summary: Le Méridien Hotels & Resorts is rebranding the 191-room Mövenpick Heritage Hotel in Sentosa, Singapore, after a renovation and conversion. The hotel, now called Le Méridien Singapore, Sentosa, will offer modern facilities, including a swimming pool and outdoor private onsen pool, and is part of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide. The brand, which was previously acquired by Starwood in 2005, aims to provide unique experiences for travelers. This marks the return of Le Méridien to Singapore after nearly a decade.

site_title: Techno duo ageing gracefully in a youth-oriented genre
summary: American techno pioneer Juan Atkins and German musician Moritz von Oswald, both 53, performed at the Movement Festival in Detroit, marking the live US debut of their album "Transport". Regarded as techno's spiritual godfathers, the duo has been collaborating since the late 1980s and have released music under the name Borderland. Their recent collaboration has been praised for its depth and complexity, with von Oswald calling it an "aura event". The pair's music has evolved over the years, with Atkins citing a desire to offer people alternatives and von Oswald embracing his age, saying it's "enjoyable, I think".

site_title: Smaller French winemakers turn to crowdfunding
summary: French winemakers are turning to crowdfunding to raise money for investments, with Bordeaux-based entrepreneur Maxime Debure launching a website called Wine-Funding. Producers can raise up to 1 million euros for projects such as renovating properties or expanding wine domains. The platform allows investors to buy a stake in smaller producers, with returns in bottles of finished wine. France is the world's second-largest wine producer, and investing in small and medium-sized enterprises offers a 50% tax deduction. The platform is set to accept projects from other countries, including Italy and South Africa.

site_title: Millions of jobs at risk in Xi's rustbelt revamp
summary: Beijing has pledged up to 100 billion yuan to resettle 1.3 million coal workers and 500,000 steel industry employees in Shanxi province, a key coal-producing region. The province faces a decades-long industrial restructuring, with 500 million tonnes of coal capacity to be closed by 2020. Millions of jobs are at risk, with many workers struggling to find alternative employment. The government's efforts to diversify the economy have been met with limited success, and the region's dependence on coal is expected to remain a challenge.

site_title: World's top three shipyards to raise 8.4t won in revamp
summary: South Korea's three largest shipyards, Hyundai Heavy Industries, Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering, and Samsung Heavy Industries, plan to raise a combined 8.41 trillion won (S$9.8 billion) by selling assets as part of a restructuring following losses in 2015. The move aims to minimize the impact on the economy and bolster the capital of state lenders. The shipyards will sell assets, reduce jobs and salaries, and cut debt to improve efficiency and weather the global slump in the shipbuilding industry, which was hit by a decline in crude oil prices.

site_title: Oil hits 2016 highs, pares gains on US oil inventory data
summary: Crude oil prices reached 2016 highs above $50 a barrel due to supply outages in Nigeria, but gains were pared as US data showed a surprise build in gasoline supplies. US crude stocks fell, while gasoline and distillate stockpiles grew, indicating weaker-than-expected demand. Despite the retreat, oil prices have nearly doubled in value from their 13-year low, with analysts noting an upward trend and warning against picking tops.

site_title: US$ index hits 5-week low over rate hike chances
summary: The US dollar index hit a five-week low against a basket of currencies due to decreased expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The dollar index fell 0.15% to 93.694, while the euro gained 0.15% to $1.1370. Traders believe the dollar will struggle to gain higher ground unless data beats expectations, and investors have reduced the likelihood of a July rate hike to around 26%. The Fed's June policy review and Brexit uncertainty also contribute to the dollar's weakness.

site_title: Singapore to house one of Hewlett Packard Enterprise's four global innovation labs
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) has announced plans to establish one of four global innovation labs in Singapore, focusing on helping companies adapt IoT applications to their businesses. The lab will collaborate with Intel to develop unique IoT solutions for each business, aiming to lower the time to value for customers. The lab is part of HPE's broader efforts to establish a converged IoT system, with other labs located in the US, France, and India.

site_title: EU exit could temper UK house price rises: poll
summary: A Reuters poll found that British house prices will rise faster than inflation if the UK stays in the EU, but may be tempered if the country votes to leave. If Britain remains in the EU, house prices are forecast to rise 5% this year and 4% in the following years, outstripping inflation forecasts. If the UK leaves, prices will rise 3.8% this year and stay flat in 2017 before increasing 2% in 2018. A "Remain" vote is expected to boost the physical and financial housing markets.

site_title: L'Oreal shuts Hong Kong shops amid protests over China 'kowtow'
summary: L'Oreal closed its Hong Kong shops, including Lancome stores, amid protests over cancelling a concert by pro-democracy singer Denise Ho Wan-see, following Chinese consumer calls for a product boycott. The move was seen as a self-censorship, with protesters holding signs urging L'Oreal not to "kowtow to Beijing". The incident highlights the risk of companies doing business in China facing criticism from the government, potentially complicating sales in the country's massive market.

site_title: Clinton, Trump start negative campaign battle with 5 months to go
summary: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump launched a negative campaign battle five months before the US presidential election, with Clinton winning the Democratic primary and Trump accusing her of corruption. Clinton's campaign portrayed Trump as unfit for office, while Trump accused Clinton of having a dark past. A Reuters/Ipsos poll showed Clinton leading Trump by 10 percentage points nationally. Clinton will return the Clinton family to the White House if elected, and Trump faces an uphill battle to unite the Republican party behind him.

site_title: ECB snaps up corporate bonds to boost eurozone
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) took an unprecedented step by buying corporate bonds to boost the eurozone economy. The move aims to encourage major companies to increase investments and create jobs. The ECB, having already lowered interest rates to below zero and injected cash into financial markets, directly financed businesses by purchasing their debt. This step is part of the ECB's efforts to kick-start sluggish growth and inflation in the eurozone.

site_title: Brazil watchdog's ruling on HSBC unit sale seen as key to dividend payout
summary: Brazil's antitrust watchdog Cade is set to decide on HSBC's $5.2 billion sale of its Brazilian unit to Banco Bradesco SA, a decision that could impact HSBC's dividend payout and CEO Stuart Gulliver's plans. The sale is expected to boost HSBC's main capital ratio, making it the largest European bank payer of dividends. The outcome will be crucial for Gulliver's strategy and shareholder expectations.

images.alt_text: Mr Gulliver is counting on the US$5.2b sale of HSBC Bank Brasil Banco Múltiplo SA to boost HSBC's main capital ratio and ensure it remains the biggest dividend payer among European banks.

site_title: Hillary makes history with Democrats' vote
summary: Hillary Clinton became the first woman to lead a major US political party after securing enough delegates to win the Democratic presidential nomination. The AP officially announced her win 24 hours before California's primary results were announced. Her historic achievement sets the stage for a potential campaign against presumptive Republican candidate Donald Trump in November's presidential election.

site_title: Analysts hail Q&M's China acquisition but flag execution risks
summary: Q&M Dental Group plans to acquire a 47.14% stake in Shenzhen New Perfect Dental Research in China for 66 million yuan (S$13.8 million). Analysts hail the deal as consistent with the company's inorganic growth strategy, but flag execution risks due to past delays in completing announced deals. The acquisition is expected to lift Q&M's net gearing and provide a profit guarantee over 12 years, with CIMB raising its target price to S$1.08 and Maybank-Kim Eng to S$1.08.

site_title: India begins settling Iran oil dues via Germany's EIH bank: sources
summary: India's state-run refiners have begun settling their $6.6 billion debt to Iran through Germany's Europaeisch-Iranische Handelsbank AG (EIH) bank, replacing Union Bank of India, which had been handling payments. The first payments were made in May and have continued through State Bank of India. Timely payment is crucial for future crude supplies and securing investments in Iran. Refiners are aiming to clear their debt in three months, with weekly limits set at $500 million.

site_title: Moody's pulls rating on US$1.75b 1MDB notes
summary: Moody's Investors Service has withdrawn its Aa2 rating on Malaysia's US$1.75 billion unsecured notes issued by 1MDB, citing concerns over the fund's reputation amid global investigations. The downgrade was not accompanied by a downgrade of Standard & Poor's AA rating on the notes. Industry executives view this move as a response to the potential impact on Moody's reputation, despite 1MDB downplaying the rating change. The move comes as 1MDB faces ongoing global scrutiny over its activities.

images.alt_text: MALAYSIA'S troubled 1MDB has downplayed international ratings agency Moody's withdrawal of the Aa2 rating on its US$1.75 billion unsecured notes as "undertaken without a downgrade", noting that Standard and Poor's AA rating on the papers remains unchanged.

site_title: Otto Marine's chairman seeks firm's delisting
summary: Otto Marine's chairman, Yaw Chee Siew, is proposing a voluntary delisting of the company amid a protracted industry downturn. The proposed delisting will involve a cash exit offer of S$0.32 per share, a 39.13% premium to the last transacted price, with a total interest of 61.2% in Otto held by Mr. Yaw. The company's efforts to cut costs and improve cash flows are aimed at tiding over the downturn, estimated to last until the end of 2017 or early 2017.

site_title: China's steel exports up 3.7% in May, ignoring trade tensions
summary: China's steel exports rose 3.7% to 9.42 million tonnes in May, defying trade tensions. The country also boosted iron ore imports by 3.4% to 86.75 million tonnes, the highest since December. Total steel exports rose 6.4% to 46.28 million tonnes in the first five months of the year. Despite global rivals accusing China of dumping cheap exports, the country's robust exports remain strong, particularly in South-east Asia. China's steel exports reached a record 112 million tonnes in 2015.

site_title: No-glamour startup SMS Assist becomes a unicorn
summary: SMS Assist, a cloud-based platform connecting property managers with outside vendors, has become a unicorn after raising $150 million in new capital, valuing it at $1 billion. The company, founded by Michael Rothman 13 years ago, enables companies to track upkeep of properties, improve quality, and reduce costs through its digital platform. This round of fundraising, led by Goldman Sachs, is a significant milestone for the company, which has seen explosive growth and profitability.

site_title: It's Clinton vs Trump in 'race to the bottom'
summary: US presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has secured the Democratic nomination, defeating billionaire businessman Donald Trump in a historic and bruising primary campaign. Clinton, a seasoned politician, will face Trump in the general election, promising a battle between two polarizing figures. Trump has vowed to take the fight to Clinton, criticizing her and her husband Bill, while Clinton aims to capitalize on Trump's controversies to boost her campaign. Analysts predict a "race to the bottom" as the two candidates clash, with Trump's lack of substance and Clinton's experience being key factors in the general election.

site_title: Oil & gas stocks surge as oil tops US$50
summary: Oil prices have surpassed US$50 per barrel, lifting oil and gas stocks in Singapore. The FTSE ST O&G Index rose 4.6% to 350.15, with shares of Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Industries increasing by 4.9% and 4.1%, respectively. Analysts remain cautious, expecting a time lag of at least six months for oil price recovery to filter down to share price recovery. Some analysts predict a meaningful recovery in the sector before 2017, while others expect asset impairments to continue affecting share prices.

site_title: Americans spent 0.7% more on health care in the first quarter
summary: US households increased healthcare spending by 0.7% in the first quarter, with finance and insurance spending rising 0.4%. This growth is part of a broader economy that expanded at a 0.8% annualized rate in the first quarter, the smallest gain in a year. Consumer spending rose at a 1.9% pace, contributing to the economic growth.

site_title: US hiring in April at slowest pace in nearly two years
summary: US employers saw the slowest hiring pace in nearly two years in April, with a 3.5% rate of hiring, the lowest since August 2014. Job openings increased to 5.79 million, the highest since last July, with a 3.9% rate. This may indicate a difficulty for firms in finding workers, suggesting a potential labor shortage.

site_title: South-east Asia's startup ecosystem is the one to watch, says Catcha boss
summary: South-east Asia's startup ecosystem is poised for growth, with the region's internet companies having the potential to surpass those in the US. According to Catcha Group CEO Patrick Grove, the region's 280 million mobile users and emerging middle class create a huge opportunity for internet companies. Despite having 10% of global internet users, South-east Asia accounts for only 1% of global internet enterprise value, making it an untapped market. Experts emphasize the need for founders to be adaptable, flexible, and focused on building long-term structural advantages.

site_title: Suzuki patriarch steps down from CEO post as mileage test storm grows
summary: Suzuki Motor Corp patriarch Osamu Suzuki is stepping down as CEO amid a mileage testing scandal, where the company admitted to using flawed methods to calculate mileage for models since 2010. Executive Vice President Osamu Honda will retire, taking responsibility for the research and development team. Suzuki will remain as chairman and oversee efforts to strengthen compliance and improve training for engineers. The company has promised to cut executive pay and slash 2015 bonuses.

site_title: Investment banks voice cautious optimism for Q2 rise
summary: Top US investment banks signal a potential rebound in revenue growth in the second quarter, with revenues expected to be higher than the same period in 2015. JP Morgan, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, and Citigroup executives predict a 15% and 5% increase in revenue, respectively, despite analysts warning that the industry's overall performance may not be as strong. The improvement in revenue growth is attributed to a stronger-than-expected US rates trading and easing market volatility.

site_title: Lufthansa to slim down catering arm
summary: Lufthansa's catering subsidiary LSG plans to cut 2,400 jobs across Europe, mainly in Germany, by 2021, due to falling prices and market changes. The restructuring will also involve closing at least three sites in Germany. The company aims to reduce costs by catering to airlines directly, rather than relying on third-party providers. This move is part of a broader trend in the airline industry to streamline operations and cut costs.

site_title: Japan's GDP grows more than initial reading in 1st quarter
summary: Japan's GDP grew 1.9% in the first quarter, exceeding the initial 1.7% reading, thanks to a revision in private consumption and business investment. The upward revision may provide relief to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who postponed an increase in the sales tax. However, growth remains uncertain due to risks from overseas demand and the yen's strength. Japan posted a 22nd consecutive monthly current-account surplus, and the yen has appreciated 12% against the dollar this year, affecting exporters. The government may take "bold" economic measures in autumn.

site_title: Big foreign banks in US get extension for 'living will' plans
summary: The US regulators have granted a one-year extension to four major foreign banks - Barclays, Deutsche Bank, UBS, and Credit Suisse - to submit their "living wills" plans, which outline how they would sell or liquidate US assets in the event of failure. The deadline was moved from June to July 2017, as the banks are in the process of simplifying their organizational structures. The living will process, required by the Dodd-Frank law, aims to protect US taxpayers from bank bailouts. The extension allows the banks to finalize their plans under a new rule.

site_title: Investors eye company earnings fillip from ECB's bond-buying
summary: Investors expect a boost in euro zone companies' earnings due to the European Central Bank's bond-buying program, which lowers borrowing costs and refinancing debt. Analysts predict a double-digit percentage increase in aggregate corporate earnings, potentially paving the way for share buybacks and merger activity. The ECB's actions have already triggered a surge in borrowing, with companies such as Generali, Telefonica, and Engie benefiting from the lower funding costs.

site_title: UK economy grew at fastest rate since January in 3 months to May: NIESR
summary: The UK economy grew at its fastest rate since January, with a 0.5% increase in the three months to May, according to the National Institute of Economic and Social Research. Despite this, growth remains subdued, with uncertainties surrounding the European Union referendum outcome. If the UK votes to leave the EU, GDP growth would be 0.8 percentage points lower, while a Remain vote could lead to a 2.0% growth forecast for 2016 and 2.7% in 2017.

site_title: Trek 2000 appoints forensic accounting firm to aid TSMP's independent review
summary: Trek 2000 International has appointed forensic accounting firm RSM Corporate Advisory to aid TSMP's independent review of certain interested-party transactions. The review, prompted by documentation deficiencies and investigations into related-party transactions, will assess the financial impact and identify lapses in internal controls. The board is engaging business associates and stakeholders to ensure business continuity. Preliminary findings were presented to the audit committee, and the full inquiry will require further information, which RSM will review and analyze from a forensic financial perspective.

site_title: Panama tax-haven leaks lead EU parliament to form inquiry panel
summary: The European Parliament has formed an inquiry panel to investigate alleged contraventions of EU laws related to money laundering, tax avoidance, and tax evasion. The panel, composed of 65 members, will review the European Commission's and member countries' enforcement of financial laws since 2005. The investigation aims to end secrecy on offshore company ownership and address revenue losses of 50-70 billion euros annually due to tax avoidance. The panel has 12 months to produce a report with policy recommendations.

images.alt_text: The European Parliament set up an inquiry committee in response to the Panama tax-cheating leaks, seeking to put the spotlight on regulators across Europe.

site_title: US oil stockpiles fall more than expected, gasoline builds: EIA
summary: US oil stockpiles fell more than expected, declining 3.2 million barrels in the last week to June 3. Gasoline inventories rose by 1 million barrels, while distillate stockpiles increased by 1.8 million barrels. Crude imports fell by 134,000 barrels per day, and refinery crude runs rose by 211,000 barrels per day. Refinery utilization rates also increased. The data contradicts analysts' expectations, which predicted a decrease in crude inventories and a drop in gasoline stocks.

site_title: Global oil stocks could take 18 months to clear: BP
summary: BP chief economist Spencer Dale predicts global oil oversupply could take up to 18 months to clear, even with a 1 million barrel per day deficit.
