The market is expected to achieve balance by the second half of 2016. A massive stock build of 350 million barrels in developed and emerging economies is cited as a contributing factor.

site_title: China Everbright Water secures Jiangsu waste water treatment projects
summary: China Everbright Water has secured a joint venture agreement with Jiangsu Xinyi municipal government to establish a Public-Private Partnership project company for waste water treatment projects. The 51-49% joint venture has a total investment of 300 million yuan and a designed waste water treatment capacity of 90,000 cubic meters. The partnership aims to contribute to environmental, economic, and social development in Xinyi city, while prioritizing economic efficiency and environmental benefits.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB enters bancassurance partnership with Japanese firm
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings has entered a bancassurance partnership with Sompo Japan Nipponkoa Holdings to distribute Sompo's non-life insurance products through CIMB's Southeast Asian distribution network, comprising 961 branches and over 12 million customers in five countries.

images.alt_text: Malaysian bank CIMB Group Holdings has entered into a bancassurance partnership with Sompo Japan Nipponkoa Holdings to distribute Sompo's non-life or general insurance products.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat ahead of holiday
summary: Hong Kong shares remained flat on Wednesday ahead of the Dragon Boat festival holiday, with the Hang Seng index falling 0.1% to 21,297.88 points. Most sectors, including IT and property, declined, while energy shares were firm. Shares of Xiao Nan Guo Restaurants plummeted 10% to an all-time low after announcing plans for a rights issue.

site_title: Logos Property sets up Singapore office, seals first local warehouse deal
summary: Logos Property Group has established an office in Singapore to focus on expanding in South-east Asia. The company has also launched its Logos Southeast Asia Venture with an initial S$150 million investment from Ivanhoe Cambridge. Logos has secured a stake in two Singapore logistics properties and partnered with Yang Kee Logistics to develop futuristic logistics facilities. The group plans to raise more equity, form partnerships, and explore development projects in Singapore and the region. This marks Logos' first local warehouse deal and its entry into the Singapore market.

site_title: Oil climbs to 10-month high as falling US supplies trim glut
summary: Oil prices surged to a 10-month high, reaching above $50 a barrel, as US crude stockpiles declined by 3.57 million barrels last week. The decline, combined with ongoing supply disruptions in Nigeria, is supporting the market and reducing a glut. Analysts predict continued supply disruptions and a draw in US crude inventories, leading to further price increases. Oil futures rose 1.3% in New York, with West Texas Intermediate reaching $51.12 a barrel, its highest level since July 20.

site_title: Starhill Reit raises rents under Ngee Ann City's Toshin master lease
summary: Starhill Global Reit announced a 5.5% increase in base rents under its Toshin master lease, effective June 8, 2016. The new rate is based on independent market valuations and covers all retail strata area of Ngee Ann City, except level five. The Toshin master lease accounts for about a fifth of the Reit's portfolio gross rent and is held by the Reit's largest tenant.

site_title: Eurozone banks will choose how fast to work off bad loans: Nouy
summary: Eurozone banks will have the freedom to choose how quickly they work off bad loans under new ECB guidelines, set to be published soon. The decision will be made on a case-by-case basis, allowing banks to decide how fast they want to tackle the problem. The ECB's chief supervisor, Daniele Nouy, stated that the process will not start for several months and bankers will still have discretion. The goal is to address the issue without forcing a fire-sale of soured credit, which could hold back fresh lending.

site_title: Tuan Sing, Habitat Properties to build Batam integrated development project
summary: Luxury property developer Tuan Sing has announced a 90:10 joint venture with Habitat Properties to develop a 85-hectare site in Marina City Batam, Indonesia, into an integrated mixed development township. The project will include hotels, retail, tourist facilities, and residential properties, with the initial phase planned for 400-room resort hotel, 30,000 sqm retail zone, and 2,000 residential apartments. The project is expected to launch by end 2017 or early 2018, with Tuan Sing paying S$39.15 million for the stake and other consideration in the form of residential units.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 2.77 points to close at 1,657.85 on Wednesday, with 1.77 billion lots valued at RM1.78 billion traded. The market saw 355 gainers and 445 losers.

site_title: Managers of Britain's BHS blame collapse on 'lying' owner
summary: Britain's BHS retailer collapsed due to a lack of financial backing and retail experience from its owner, Dominic Chappell, according to its management. Chappell's Retail Acquisitions Ltd bought the chain for £1 in 2015, but failed to deliver on promises to revive the business. Administrators have started winding down the 88-year-old chain, threatening 11,000 jobs. BHS Chief Executive Darren Topp and former financial consultant Michael Hitchcock accused Chappell of being a liar and fantasist, saying he had his "fingers in the till" and took millions of pounds from the business.

site_title: Lululemon Athletica's profit narrowly misses as costs rise
summary: Lululemon Athletica's quarterly profit fell 5% to $45.3 million, narrowly missing analysts' estimate due to higher costs. The company reported a slight drop in gross margin to 48.3% and a 5% decline in net income. Despite this, Lululemon raised its 2016 revenue forecast and managed to control inventory levels. The company's shares were slightly down in premarket trading. The decline in profit was attributed to the criticism from founder Chip Wilson, who called for a board election to make directors more accountable for the company's performance.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced that crowdfunding platforms will need to obtain licenses to continue operating, affecting business loan crowdfunding platforms. The government released land for 7,545 private homes and 277,080 sq meters of commercial space. Car COE premiums surged past S$50,000, while oil prices held above US$50 per barrel. Singapore ranked as the 10th most expensive city in Asia for expats, according to a survey.

site_title: Clinton prepares for showdown with Trump
summary: Hillary Clinton clinched the Democratic Party nomination, becoming the first woman to secure a major party's nomination for president. She won primaries in California, New Jersey, New Mexico, and South Dakota, effectively ending her battle with Bernie Sanders. Clinton, now heading to a general election showdown with Donald Trump, must rally the party behind her as she faces criticism over her use of a private email server and perceptions of dishonesty. Trump vowed to go on the offensive against Clinton, while Sanders vowed to continue the fight despite acknowledging the writing on the wall.

site_title: Hot Stocks: Keppel, Ezra shares surge as oil holds above US$50
summary: Keppel Corporation and Ezra Holdings shares surged on June 8 as oil prices remained above US$50 per barrel, reaching a 4.8% and 4.1% gain respectively. Oil prices held above the US$50 threshold, boosting hopes for offshore exploration and production activity. However, analysts warn that US$60 oil is the ideal level for companies to increase capital spending, and a recovery in offshore activity may be gradual.

site_title: StanChart said to mull insurance distribution deal in Asia
summary: Standard Chartered is considering a bancassurance agreement, where it would partner with insurers to distribute non-life products through its Asian branches. The potential partner could pay at least $400 million for access to the bank's network. This comes as demand for insurance products rises in Asia, with CIMB Group and Fairfax Financial Holdings already in talks for similar deals. Standard Chartered has over 700 branches in Asia and has previously partnered with Prudential to distribute life-insurance products. The move is part of the bank's efforts to restructure and turn around its business under new CEO Bill Winters.

site_title: US stocks push higher despite growth worries
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, boosted by gains in energy equities despite concerns about sluggish global growth. Oil prices rose ahead of a key inventory report, lifting shares of ExxonMobil and other energy companies. However, the World Bank's reduced 2016 global growth forecast to 2.4% tempered investor enthusiasm for stocks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices edged to fresh records, despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Hi-P International's deputy CEO Tay Ewee Liang quits
summary: Hi-P International Limited announced the resignation of deputy CEO Tay Ewee Liang, effective June 30, 2016. Tay was appointed deputy CEO in May 2014 and oversaw the company's business and operations.

site_title: France launches attack alert app ahead of Euro 2016
summary: France launched an attack alert app, SAIP, two days before the Euro 2016 soccer championship, amidst a state of emergency following November's Paris attacks. The app flashes a warning on users' mobile phones if there's an attack close by or suspicion of an imminent strike. Users can request alerts for up to eight geographic areas. The app's launch has received mixed reactions on social media, with some finding it reassuring while others questioned its effectiveness in improving security.

site_title: UK industry output jumps at fastest pace since 2012, boosted by pharmaceuticals, cars
summary: UK industrial output rose 2.0% in April, the fastest pace since July 2012, driven by a 8.6% increase in pharmaceuticals, car production, and gas. Manufacturing output also rose 2.3% in April, its fastest pace since July 2012. Despite this, the Bank of England may view the data with skepticism due to volatile economic figures ahead of the EU referendum. The data contrasts with a slowdown in the overall economy, which slowed to 0.4% in the first quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong: Markets closed on Thursday for holiday
summary: Hong Kong's stock and bond markets were closed on Thursday for the Dragon Boat Festival holiday and will resume trading on Friday. In contrast, Singapore's stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. The US markets also saw gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions. Meanwhile, an eSIM platform, Airalo, raised $220 million in new funding, valuing it at over $1 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher with oil and shipping stocks in play
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose for the fifth consecutive day, closing at 2,862.38 with a 14.29-point gain, despite a weakening final minute. The index's gains were driven by offshore and marine stocks, with companies like Ezra and Ezion benefiting from a firming oil price. The Dow futures marginally remained firm, contributing to the positive sentiment. The five-day gain for the STI reached 72 points, or 2.6%, with banks playing a pivotal role in the gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks shed early losses after Japan, China data
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded from early losses, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.93% to 16,830.92, and the Topix index gaining 0.76% to 1,350.97, in response to Japanese and Chinese data releases.

site_title: China says most wanted corruption suspect returned of own accord from Canada
summary: China says 44-year-old engineer Zeng Ziheng, on its list of 100 most wanted corruption suspects abroad, has voluntarily returned to China from Canada. Zeng fled in 2011 and was wanted for unspecified crimes. China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection attributed his return to "successful admonishment" and said the justice and foreign ministries assisted. This marks the 28th person to return from the list, as part of China's efforts to increase international cooperation to bring corrupt officials back to the country.

site_title: IEA sees slower global gas demand growth to 2021
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a slower global gas demand growth of 1.5% per year through 2021, with Europe facing stagnation and China's demand recovering. India will be the only major market to drive growth, at 6% per year. The global gas market is expected to remain oversupplied, with US shale production helping to drive recovery and Gazprom facing increased competition from liquefied natural gas (LNG). The IEA questions the economics of Gazprom's Nord Stream pipeline expansion to Germany, citing potential security of supply concerns.

site_title: Wild weather delays completion of MH370 search
summary: Australia's search for missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 has been delayed due to severe weather conditions, with no progress made in the past month. The search, which covers 120,000 square kilometers, is now expected to be completed by August, with 105,000 square kilometers already covered. Eight pieces of debris have been found, five of which are believed to be from the Boeing 777. If no signs of the plane are found, the search will be abandoned. The fate of the 239 passengers and crew remains a mystery.

site_title: China: Stocks close lower ahead of long weekend
summary: China's financial markets closed lower on Wednesday ahead of a long weekend holiday, with the CSI300 index falling 0.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.3%. Investors are optimistic about the possible inclusion of mainland shares in MSCI's emerging market indexes next week. The markets will close on Thursday and Friday for the Dragon Boat holiday.

site_title: Car bomb hits police station in southeast Turkey, many wounded: sources
summary: A car bomb attack hit a police station in Turkey's southeastern province of Mardin, wounding many people, on Wednesday. The attack occurred in the town of Midyat, north of the Syrian border. No one has claimed responsibility, but Kurdish militants have been known to stage such attacks. This incident follows a bombing in Istanbul that killed 11 people the day prior, making it the fourth attack in Istanbul this year.

site_title: Singapore is 10th most expensive city in Asia for expats: survey
summary: Singapore ranks as the 10th most expensive city in Asia for expatriates, according to a five-year survey by ECA International. The city moved 13 places up the global ranking from five years ago. Tokyo remains the most expensive city in Asia, followed by Hong Kong and Shanghai. Guangzhou experienced the largest jump of 40 places on the global scale, while Hong Kong surged 26 places. The rankings reflect differences in inflation levels and exchange rate movements between countries.

site_title: TomTom wins deal to provide Volvo Cars with maps, data
summary: TomTom, a Dutch navigation company, has won a contract to provide Volvo Cars with real-time maps and traffic data for its vehicles. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but it's a significant win for TomTom, which competes with Google Maps and Here. This contract follows a string of wins for TomTom, including deals with Volkswagen, Uber, and Apple. The contract is seen as a major step forward for TomTom as car driving becomes increasingly automated.

site_title: ECB starts buying corporate bonds in new attempt to revive inflation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has started buying corporate bonds in an effort to revive inflation in the euro zone. The move aims to cut borrowing costs, encouraging companies to invest and fuel faster growth. However, the program faces obstacles, with the market for such debt largely limited to big companies in France and the Netherlands. The ECB expects to buy 5-10 billion euros per month, but success depends on attracting new borrowers and reducing borrowing costs for weaker economies.

site_title: EgyptAir flight to Beijing lands in Uzbekistan after bomb threat
summary: An EgyptAir flight from Cairo to Beijing was diverted to Uzbekistan after receiving a bomb threat. The plane, passengers, and luggage are being searched as the airline deals with the threat as real. This incident comes after a recent EgyptAir plane crashed into the Mediterranean, killing all 66 on board, and a previous hijacking incident in March. The search for the black boxes from the crashed plane continues, with the reasons for the crash remaining unclear. The diverted flight, MS955, is now being searched in Uzbekistan.

site_title: European shares retreat as Erste leads down bank stocks
summary: European shares retreated on Wednesday, falling 0.4% after a two-day gain, as Erste, an Austrian bank, dropped 3.9% following Uniqa's announcement to sell 17.4 million Erste shares. The STOXX 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indexes declined, with the latter having risen for two consecutive days. The decline in Erste's stock led to a downturn in financial stocks, contributing to the overall European market's retreat.

site_title: Lancome faces growing anger and protests in Hong Kong
summary: Lancome faces growing anger and protests in Hong Kong after cancelling a concert featuring pro-democracy activist Denise Ho due to China's state-run media criticism. The company closed some outlets in response. Many Hong Kong residents believe the cancellation was a result of China's pressure, with Ho being a key figure in 2014's mass rallies calling for free elections. The incident highlights the tensions between Hong Kong and China, with many residents expressing frustration over what they perceive as China's increasing influence over the territory.

site_title: Oil holds above US$50 on weak dollar, supplies data in focus
summary: Oil prices held above US$50 in Asia on Wednesday due to a weak dollar, awaiting US inventory data later in the day. Traders expect another drop in US stockpiles, contributing to a 90% rebound in oil since the start of the year. A weaker dollar makes oil cheaper for international buyers, while a recent jobs report and Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's comments on a gradual interest rate hike have boosted market sentiment. Oil prices have surged since hitting 13-year lows, driven by a drop in the dollar and signs of global economic recovery.

site_title: Nissan, Takata face criminal complaint on Japan airbag rupture
summary: Nissan Motor Co and Takata Corp executives face a criminal complaint in Japan over a defective airbag that ruptured in a Nissan X-Trail, injuring a female passenger in October. The complaint was filed by police in eastern Japan on May 30. Both companies are cooperating with the investigation and declined to comment further. This is the first criminal complaint against the companies in Japan.

site_title: Papua New Guinea police open fire on protesting students
summary: Papua New Guinea police opened fire on students protesting against Prime Minister Peter O'Neill, with at least four people injured. The students, demanding O'Neill step aside over corruption allegations, had been locked in a month-long standoff with authorities. The clashes broke out as students marched on parliament, where O'Neill was due to face a no-confidence vote. Witnesses reported police using tear gas and guns, while the hospital denied reports of four deaths, stating two had major injuries and two minor problems.

site_title: Oil hits 8-month highs on US inventory draw, China imports
summary: Oil prices rose for a third day to their highest in about eight months, driven by a larger-than-expected drawdown in US crude inventories and strong Chinese demand. US commercial crude inventories fell by 3.6 million barrels, while China's crude imports jumped 38.7% from a year ago. Worries about global supply disruptions, including attacks on Nigeria's oil industry, also supported the market. Despite some concerns about global demand, oil prices rose to $51.53 a barrel, the highest since October 12.

site_title: China data fails to impress Hong Kong, Shanghai but Tokyo swings
summary: China's imports fell 0.4% in May, the slowest pace in 19 months, beating estimates and hinting at a possible economic pick-up. However, traders in Hong Kong and Shanghai reacted mutedly, with Shanghai ending 0.5% lower and Hong Kong shedding 0.3%. The news had a positive impact on Wall Street, with the Dow and S&P 500 shifting higher, while Japan's Nikkei swung back and forth before closing 0.5% up. The data may influence the Bank of Japan's decision on stimulus, and a weaker yen boosted the currency.

site_title: Competition Commission consults on proposed changes to calculation of penalties
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) is consulting on proposed changes to its penalty calculation method, aiming to align with EU and UK practices. The current method calculates penalties based on the year preceding the decision date, while the proposed method uses the year preceding the infringement's end date. CCS also seeks feedback on clarifying the proposed penalty amount in infringement decisions and incorporating this practice into the enforcement guidelines, with a closing date for submissions on July 8, 2016.

site_title: France to launch smartphone 'terror alert' app
summary: France is set to launch a new smartphone app that will alert users to possible terror attacks, as well as unexpected events such as flood breaches. The app, which will be free to download, will send users a warning within 15 minutes of an incident being confirmed by authorities, and will also provide safety advice and information on how to stay safe. The app aims to help prevent emergency services hotlines from becoming overwhelmed and will be available in both French and English. The launch comes amid growing security concerns over the Euro 2016 football tournament.

site_title: Update: MAS says no Singapore bank received 1MDB bond proceeds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has stated that no Singapore bank received the US$3 billion wire transfer from Goldman Sachs to Malaysian state fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) for a bond issuance. This comes after a Wall Street Journal report suggested that bond proceeds from the 1MDB US$3 billion bonds ended up in a Swiss bank in Singapore. US investigators are trying to determine if Goldman Sachs broke the law when it didn't flag a suspicious transaction, and 1MDB has consistently denied wrongdoing amidst global probes into allegations of money laundering and embezzlement.

site_title: LTA to put out tender for site investigation specialist for Cross Island Line
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will issue a tender for a site investigation specialist for the Cross Island Line (CRL) in Q4 2016. The works, including site investigation for the direct alignment option, will provide detailed information on underground soil conditions. The findings will be used in the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) phase 2, which assesses the construction and operation impact of the two possible alignments. LTA will implement mitigating measures to reduce environmental impact on the Central Catchment Nature Reserve.

site_title: Philippine central bank expects market rates to move closer to policy rate
summary: The Philippine central bank expects market rates to move closer to its benchmark interest rate as banks become familiar with the term deposit facility (TDF) and auction amounts become refined. The central bank's first TDF auction was oversubscribed, indicating significant liquidity in the financial system. Governor Amando Tetangco stated that the central bank will make adjustments to the TDF amounts as conditions warrant.

images.alt_text: The Philippine central bank expects market rates to gradually move toward its benchmark interest rate as banks become familiar with the term deposit facility (TDF) and as auction amounts become refined, its governor said on Wednesday.

site_title: Car COE premiums higher after easing of loan curbs
summary: COE premiums for passenger cars in Singapore increased after the easing of loan curbs, with Category A premiums rising by S$6,674 to S$53,694. Category B premiums rose by S$6,844 to S$56,000, while Category E premiums climbed S$5,400 to S$55,100. The Monetary Authority of Singapore relaxed vehicle financing restrictions on May 27, allowing buyers to borrow up to 70% of the car price over 7 years. The adjustments follow sustained moderation in COE premiums, with only Cat D (motorcycles) seeing lower premiums.

site_title: US dollar index drifts to fresh 4-week lows
summary: The US dollar index fell to a fresh four-week low of 93.740 against a basket of currencies, dropping 0.1% on Wednesday. The drop was partially offset by better-than-expected Chinese import figures, which boosted risk appetite. The dollar index is expected to remain bearish until the Fed's policy meeting on June 15. Other currencies, including the euro, Australian dollar, and New Zealand dollar, also moved against the dollar, with the euro rising 0.2% and the Australian dollar edging up 0.1%.

site_title: Yahoo offering more than 3,000 patents amid strategic reviews
summary: Yahoo is exploring the sale of over 3,000 patents amid a strategic review to monetize its intellectual property. The effort began earlier this year, with proceeds potentially reaching $1 billion to $3 billion. Bidders include TPG, Verizon, and a consortium led by Bain Capital and Vista Equity Partners. The company is retaining around 1,000 patents and hiring boutique investment bank Black Stone IP to sell the patents. This move aims to maximize shareholder value through the sale of non-core patent assets.

site_title: Obama congratulates Clinton, will meet Sanders Thursday
summary: US President Barack Obama congratulated Hillary Clinton on clinching the Democratic presidential nomination, praising her campaign for energizing Democrats and highlighting policy ideas. Obama also plans to meet with Clinton's rival Bernie Sanders at the White House on Thursday, at Sanders' request.

site_title: China's yuan firms ahead of holiday, takes trade data in stride
summary: China's yuan strengthened ahead of the holiday weekend, closing at 6.5682 per US dollar, a 0.04% gain. The currency's value was largely unaffected by soft export data, which fell more than expected in May, and a decline in foreign exchange reserves to $3.19 trillion. Traders are adjusting positions and corporates are buying dollars, with some speculating that the yuan may weaken 0.3% for the week. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.5593 per US dollar.

site_title: Hillary Clinton's mighty challenge: to unify her camp
summary: Hillary Clinton faces a daunting task in unifying her camp after a contentious battle with Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary. Unlike her Republican rival Donald Trump, Sanders has maintained a level of unity among his supporters, but Clinton must now earn the backing of his fans, who view her as calculating and insincere. Democratic leaders, including former President Barack Obama, are expected to play a key role in uniting the party, with Obama's message emphasizing the shared values between Clinton and Sanders.

site_title: Brazil poised to keep rates on hold as inflation remains high
summary: Brazil's central bank is expected to keep interest rates at 14.25% for the seventh consecutive time, defying pressure to lower borrowing costs amid a deepening recession and high inflation. Economists surveyed by Reuters predict this decision, citing a near 10-year high. Interim President Michel Temer aims to shift the economy toward more market-friendly policies, but inflation expectations remain above the official target, with inflation rising 9.62% in the 12 months through mid-May. The next central bank chief, Ilan Goldfajn, signals a focus on rebuilding the economy's pillars before considering rate cuts.

site_title: Indonesia's top fund likes bonds more than stocks on tax amnesty
summary: Indonesia's top fund manager, Alvin Pattisahusiwa, expects the country's tax amnesty to boost bonds more than stocks, as foreign investors pump $4.9 billion into Indonesian debt, causing rupiah-denominated notes to gain over 11% in 2016. The tax plan aims to repatriate $56.8 billion in undeclared income and is expected to support the country's case for a full investment-grade rank. While stocks are predicted to rise 10-12% this year, bonds are seen as a more attractive option due to the tax amnesty's benefits for liquidity and demand.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's planned tax amnesty, aimed at luring back billions of dollars stashed abroad, will boost bonds more than stocks, the nation's top fund manager says.

site_title: China imports, exports fall in May: government
summary: China's exports decreased 4.1% in May, while imports fell 0.4%, resulting in a trade surplus of nearly $50 billion. The country shipped $181.1 billion worth of goods and imported $131.1 billion, according to the General Administration of Customs. This marks the third consecutive month of declining exports.

site_title: Indonesia to lower 2016 growth target to 5.1% in state budget
summary: Indonesia is revising its 2016 economic growth target to 5.1% in the state budget, down from the initial 5.3% due to slowing domestic consumption and potential tax revenue shortfalls. This revision aims to correct the growth assumption, considering issues with exports and private investment. The decision is part of President Joko Widodo's efforts to meet his election pledge of a 7% annual expansion, which has been impacted by drops in commodity prices.

site_title: Gold climbs as investors weigh Fed rates, pause in China buying
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,248.31 an ounce as investors weighed China's pause in gold purchases and diminishing odds for a US Federal Reserve interest-rate increase. The US dollar fell to a one-month low, supporting gold prices. Traders now see no chance of a rate hike at the Fed's June meeting, with odds of a move in July and September decreasing. Gold is expected to be supported by risk in the coming months, including a potential British exit from the EU and US elections.

site_title: New Zealand PM John Key to visit Fiji as coup legacy lingers
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister John Key will visit Fiji, the first in a decade, amid lingering coup legacies. Key downplays human rights concerns, saying Mr. Bainimarama's government is "doing quite well." However, human rights groups, including Amnesty International, criticize Fiji's government for press muzzling, police brutality cover-ups, and opposition lawmaker suspensions. Key's visit comes after New Zealand's support during Cyclone Winston's recovery, but journalists, including a TVNZ reporter, have been affected by Fiji's coup legacy, highlighting ongoing human rights issues in the Pacific island nation.

site_title: MAS to require licences for business loan crowdfunding platforms
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will require licenses for business loan crowdfunding platforms that reach retail investors, effectively ending an exemption for platforms that use promissory notes worth at least S$100,000. Existing rules will be tweaked to make it easier for licensed platforms to tap the retail market, with streamlined requirements and a reduced minimum capital and operational risk requirement. The move aims to strike a balance between improving access to securities crowdfunding and protecting investor interests.

site_title: Broker's take: CIMB warns of M&A risks as Q&M takes on another China buy
summary: Q&M Dental Group plans to acquire a 47.14% stake in Shenzhen New Perfect Dental Research for S$13.8 million. CIMB Research warns that the acquisition may take longer than expected due to Q&M's uncompleted deals from 2014-2015. The acquisition will lift Q&M's net gearing to 0.39 times, but CIMB maintains a "hold" rating on the stock with a target price of S$0.74, citing Q&M's dominant domestic position and growing overseas presence.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares fall as rate views hit banks, NZ also down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Wednesday, snapping a three-day winning streak, as investors sold bank stocks amid concerns the central bank may not cut rates this year. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept rates on hold, but its commentary was seen as upbeat, leading to a surge in the Aussie dollar and a decline in bank stocks. New Zealand shares also dropped 0.3% due to a 3.6% slide in telecoms company Spark.

site_title: China plans oceanic 'space station' in South China Sea
summary: China plans to build a manned deep-sea platform, dubbed an "oceanic space station," 3,000 meters below the surface of the South China Sea to hunt for minerals and potentially serve a military purpose. The project, mentioned in China's five-year economic plan, aims to close a deep-sea exploration gap with the US and other nations. The platform, designed to host dozens of crew members, faces challenges such as typhoons and detection vulnerability, with estimated costs and timelines unknown. China's ambitions in the South China Sea have heightened tensions with neighboring countries, including Vietnam and the Philippines.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near 1-month highs, RBNZ in focus
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached near one-month highs on Wednesday, driven by expectations of monetary policy and higher commodity prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates at a record low of 1.75%, while investors trimmed the risk of a rate cut in August. The New Zealand dollar is expected to be in focus on Thursday when the Reserve Bank of New Zealand makes its policy decision.

site_title: Chinese steel exports rise 4% in May from April: customs data
summary: Chinese steel exports rose 3.7% in May to 9.42 million tonnes, up from April, with total shipments surging 9.1% to 412.15 million tonnes in the first five months of the year. This comes despite concerns over trade tensions and accusations of dumping cheap exports. China's robust exports have been criticized by global rivals, and the country has committed to curbing its steel capacity and winding down weak state enterprises.

site_title: Indonesia markets 3b euros of bonds to plug funding gap
summary: Indonesia is marketing 3 billion euros ($4.61 billion) of bonds to fund its budget deficit, which is approaching the 3% limit. The government is offering 1.5 billion euros of 7-year notes and 1.5 billion euros of 12-year securities at below initial price guidance. President Joko Widodo is considering a larger deficit target to finance a US$360 billion development program and pass a tax amnesty bill to encourage individuals to repatriate undeclared funds. The bond sale is seen as a confidence booster for Asia's best-performing bonds.

site_title: Trek 2000 board clears deputy CEO of conflict of interest
summary: The board of Trek 2000 International has cleared Deputy CEO Edwin Long of a conflict of interest due to his directorship at Digiland (Thailand) Co Ltd, a subsidiary of New Silkroutes, a competing firm in the IT industry. The company stated that Digiland's focus on data storage and IoT products does not conflict with Trek 2000's business, allowing Long to hold the directorship without a conflict of interest.

site_title: China auto sales climb 11% after tax cut, dealer discounts
summary: China's passenger-vehicle sales rose 11% in May to 1.76 million units, driven by a tax cut and dealer discounts. General Motors and Toyota reported increased deliveries, with GM's sales climbing 17% and Toyota's rising 12%. However, high inventory levels and rising production capacity pose challenges for carmakers' profitability. The tax cut hasn't sparked the expected sales gains, suggesting tighter profit margins ahead. With 120 new models launched this year, the Chinese auto market remains a buyer's paradise, at a cost to carmakers' earnings.

site_title: Chinese dream of instant stock-market riches faces harsh reality
summary: Chinese investors' hopes of instant stock-market riches have been crushed, with many experiencing significant losses over the past year. The Shanghai Composite Index has fallen by as much as 49% since its peak in June 2015, prompting a shift in mindset among individual investors. Many are now focusing on other assets, such as real estate and commodities, as they become more cautious and risk-averse. The government's efforts to prop up the market have been unsuccessful, and companies may struggle to raise equity financing, which could have long-term implications for China's economy.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors raid Daewoo Shipbuilding offices
summary: South Korean prosecutors raided Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co's offices in Seoul and Geojae, following an audit committee's request for an investigation into two former CEOs for alleged mismanagement. The raid comes after the company posted its biggest loss last year due to write-offs for delayed projects. The company is restructuring to raise funds after oil prices fell, crushing demand. Computer hard drives, account books, and documents were confiscated during the raid. Daewoo Shipbuilding posted a net loss of 3.19 trillion won in 2015, excluding minority interest.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks down ahead of China figures
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks declined in early trade on June 8, 2016, ahead of China's release of trade data. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.16% to 21,294.27, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.12% to 2,932.38. The decline was attributed to investor anticipation of the China data release.

site_title: MND to offer land for 7,545 private homes including 780 ECs in H2
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) plans to release land for 7,545 private homes, including 780 executive condo units, and 277,080 sq metres of commercial space in the second half of 2016. This is slightly more than the 7,415 private housing units and 272,580 sq m of commercial space for the current first half Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme. The land will be released from both confirmed and reserve lists, with 2,170 private residential units and 15,500 sq m of commercial space on the confirmed list, and 5,375 private homes and 261,580 sq m of commercial space on the reserve list.

site_title: Garuda stalls multibillion-dollar deal in 'buyers market'
summary: PT Garuda Indonesia, the flag carrier of Indonesia, is stalling a multibillion-dollar aircraft order due to the global economic slowdown, with a sluggish Bloomberg World Airline Index. The airline's president-director, Arif Wibowo, says the order, which could reach 250 aircraft, will be finalized in one or two years. Garuda has bucked the trend of declining airline profits, with its share price surging 55% this year, and aims to nearly triple its revenue to $10 billion by 2020.

site_title: 1MDB defends liquidity position after Moody's rating withdrawal
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd defended its liquidity position after Moody's Investors Service withdrew the rating for one of its bonds. The withdrawal occurred two weeks after 1MDB reiterated its commitment to resolving a debt dispute with Abu Dhabi's sovereign-wealth fund. The company stated its liquidity position remains strong and focused on executing its rationalisation plan, with its securities still holding an AA rating from S&P Global Ratings.

site_title: IMF warns of financial risks from further Thai policy easing
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned Thailand of financial risks from further monetary policy easing, urging the country to balance economic support with financial stability concerns. Thailand's economy grew 2.8% in 2015 and is forecast to reach 3% in 2016, but downside risks remain. The IMF advises the Bank of Thailand to maintain its current accommodative monetary policy stance, while also preserving policy space for future changes. The fund also emphasizes the need for structural reforms and financial stability safeguards for a long-lasting recovery.

site_title: Update: China imports fall slows in May
summary: China's imports decreased by 3.4% in May, the slowest pace in over a year-and-a-half, suggesting domestic demand may be recovering. This marks a continuation of the trend since 2014, as the country's economy struggles with manufacturing overcapacity, a slowing property market, and mounting debt. The decrease in imports has significant implications for resource-rich nations worldwide.

images.alt_text: China's imports decreased at their slowest pace in more than a year-and-a-half in May, official data showed Wednesday, in a possible sign domestic demand in the world's second-largest economy may be recovering.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.720 points to 1658.580. Volume was 29 million lots worth RM11.5 million, with 90 gainers outnumbering 51 losers.

site_title: What govt took into account in crafting H2 2016 GLS Programme: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong announced the Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme for the second half of 2016, considering factors such as the drop in unsold private homes and a rise in new sales. The programme includes four confirmed sites, expected to yield around 2,170 new homes, and two sites in suburban areas. The government aims to balance supply and demand, avoiding excessive supply that can lead to price declines and insufficient supply that can result in price spikes. The programme will help meet current demand and add to private housing supply over the medium term.

site_title: Godiva sees sales exceeding US$1b as snackmaker IPO looms
summary: Godiva, the world's largest premium chocolate retailer, is expected to exceed its 2017 revenue target of US$1 billion due to growing demand for Belgian sweets in Asia. The company aims to open 190 stores in mainland China by 2019 and has seen record sales of US$792 million in 2016. Godiva-parent Pladis plans to list its shares in London around 2020, and the company will focus on making the Godiva brand accessible to more consumers. This move is seen as a response to Swiss rival Lindt & Spruengli's target to overtake Godiva as the world's largest premium chocolatier by 2020.

site_title: New study throws doubt on China car emissions data
summary: A new study in Chengdu, China suggests that carbon emissions from cars in the city could be underestimated by more than half due to conventional testing methods. The study, which used data from Uber and taxi firms, found that standard laboratory estimates were off by about 6,500 metric tonnes per day, or 59%. This discrepancy could have significant implications for China's efforts to reduce carbon emissions and meet its climate change targets.

site_title: Disney vs Wanda: how the two theme parks stack up
summary: Disney's US$5.5 billion Shanghai resort is set to open on June 16, marking the company's sixth globally. In contrast, Dalian Wanda Group's Nanchang Wanda City, China's first theme park, has already opened and boasts 50 attractions. Both parks have received significant government support and are expected to attract large numbers of visitors. While Disney's Shanghai resort is expected to draw 15-30 million visitors annually, Wanda's Nanchang park is anticipated to receive 10 million visitors annually.

site_title: China's Xi says laid-off soldiers will be found work
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced that demobilized soldiers, who are laid off due to military reforms, will be provided with civilian jobs. The move is part of the government's efforts to modernize the military and maintain social stability. Xi described demobilized soldiers as "treasures of the party and the state" and emphasized the need to provide them with positions, stating it is not allowed to deny them jobs under any pretext. This comes as China grapples with economic uncertainty and protests from demobilized soldiers over lack of support finding new jobs.

site_title: China says the Philippines is ignoring a maritime talks proposal
summary: China has accused the Philippines of ignoring a proposal for regular talks on maritime issues, despite agreeing to settle disputes in the South China Sea "in a peaceful and friendly manner" in 1995. China claims most of the waters through which $5 trillion in trade passes annually, and has proposed a consultation mechanism with the Philippines. The Philippines has brought a case to an international tribunal contesting China's claims, which China wants to resolve bilaterally. China urges the Philippines to cease its "wrongful conduct" and return to bilateral negotiations.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit more than two-month high; TSMC up
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index reached a two-month high, gaining 0.9% to 8,753.46 points, driven by TSMC's 1.85% gain after announcing its dividend and reaffirming revenue growth forecasts. The electronics subindex rose 1.1%, while the financials subindex gained 0.5%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.220 per US dollar. This marks the highest level since March 31.

site_title: Asia: Markets down ahead of China data
summary: Asia's major markets declined on Wednesday, following a three-day rally, ahead of China's key trade data release. The Dow and S&P 500 shifted higher Tuesday, driven by energy firms, while the World Bank cut its global growth outlook to 2.4% for 2016. Japan's economy grew slightly more than expected, but Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's stimulus plan remains struggling. The release of Chinese import and export figures later in the day is expected to show another drop, dragging the world's number two economy by a long-running growth slowdown.

site_title: Flash: MND to release land for 7,545 private homes
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MND) plans to release land for 7,545 private homes, including 780 Executive Condominiums (ECs), in the second half of 2016. This move is expected to boost the housing market and address demand for private homes. The release of land will also provide more options for buyers, particularly those seeking affordable housing. The MND's decision aims to promote a balanced housing market and support economic growth.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Marine, Mary Chia, TTJ Holdings
summary: Sembcorp Marine extended its standstill agreement for the West Rigel drilling rig delivery until Sept 2, 2016. Mary Chia Holdings faced a further charge for failing to obtain a valid work pass for a foreign employee. TTJ Holdings reported a net profit of S$13.41 million for the third quarter, up from S$1.6 million a year ago, driven by higher revenue and profit margins.

site_title: Singapore shares open 8.8 points higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 8.8 points higher on Wednesday at 2,856.89. The three Singapore banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - were top gainers. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally. US markets closed higher overnight, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Chinese jets in 'unsafe' intercept of US spy plane: Pentagon
summary: US officials say two Chinese jets conducted an "unsafe" intercept of a US spy plane over the East China Sea, but the Pentagon attributes the incident to poor piloting. The US Pacific Command stated that one of the Chinese jets had an "unsafe excessive rate of closure" on the RC-135 aircraft. This incident comes amid heightened tensions between China and the US, with China's military expansion in the South China Sea sparking concerns. US Secretary of State John Kerry urged China to settle its territorial rows peacefully during a recent visit to Beijing.

site_title: South Korea govt, central bank to create 11t won fund to support banks exposed to restructuring
summary: South Korea's government and Bank of Korea plan to create a 11 trillion won (S$12.8 billion) fund to support two state-run banks, Korea Development Bank (KDB) and the Export-Import Bank of Korea (Kexim), exposed to the restructuring of the shipping and shipbuilding firms. The fund will be formed through a loan from the Bank of Korea and government contribution, with plans to buy hybrid bonds from the state-run banks. This move aims to stabilize the banks and mitigate the impact of the restructuring on the economy, which is expected to last for two to three years.

site_title: Clinton wins New Jersey, cements her nomination
summary: Hillary Clinton won the New Jersey presidential nominating contest, cementing her nomination as the first woman to become a major party's US presidential candidate. She secured enough delegates to win the nomination before Tuesday's voting, with a campaign pushing supporters to "stay at this" for remaining contests. Clinton's campaign is now focusing on unifying the party and preparing for the November election against Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: Democrat Hillary Clinton beat rival Bernie Sanders in New Jersey's presidential nominating contest on Tuesday, Fox News projected, adding to her lead a day after she captured the number of delegates needed to become her party's US presidential nominee.

site_title: Vietnam seeks faster bad-debt cleanup with first cash purchase
summary: Vietnam is accelerating its cleanup of bad debt to boost lending in an economy threatened by drought and lower oil revenue. The Vietnam Asset Management Company (VAMC) will make its first cash purchase of non-performing loans this year, aiming to resolve about 30 trillion dong (S$1.82 billion) of bad loans. The move is expected to help banks speed up lending and curb non-performing loans to below 3% of total lending. The government aims to spur economic growth to 6.7% this year and has set a target of reducing the number of commercial banks to 15 by 2017.

site_title: Obama, Modi welcome preparatory work for India reactor project
summary: US President Barack Obama and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi welcomed the start of preparatory work for six nuclear reactors in India, a key step in a US-India civil nuclear accord. The project, delayed by negotiations over liability rules, is expected to be finalized by June 2017. The Nuclear Power Corporation of India and Toshiba's Westinghouse Electric have confirmed engineering and site design work will begin immediately. The US government has expressed satisfaction with India's efforts to address liability concerns, paving the way for the reactor project to move forward.

site_title: Mary Chia CEO slapped with new charge over work pass permit for foreign employee
summary: Mary Chia Holdings CEO Ho Yow Ping has been charged with a breach of the Massage Establishment Act for employing a foreign employee without a valid work pass. This is the fourth charge against Ho, who is also director of two subsidiaries of the company. Despite the new charge, the company's businesses continue to operate as usual. The Singapore Police Force is investigating allegations of failure to obtain prior approval and maintain proper employee records.

site_title: Japan Q1 GDP revised up to 1.9% annualised growth
summary: Japan's economy grew at a revised annualized rate of 1.9% in the first quarter, up from the initial estimate of 1.7%. Capital spending fell less than expected, while private consumption rose 0.6%. However, economists worry about slow consumer spending, weak exports, and a potential decline in the yen, which could lower export profits and discourage investment. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to announce additional economic measures this autumn, but economists question the effectiveness of his piecemeal approach.

site_title: US investors skeptical about China's move to widen markets
summary: US investors are skeptical about investing in China's stock market due to regulatory issues and concerns over the government's handling of the market. China has unveiled measures to attract US buyers, including a 250 billion yuan investment quota, but investors remain cautious. They want to see financial reforms, including a circuit breaker mechanism to stabilize the stock markets, and more credible governance. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index has tumbled 40% over the past year, and investors are waiting for foreign investors to be included in major indexes before pouring in more money.

images.alt_text: US asset managers and hedge funds are wary about pouring more money into China until the government addresses its stock market crash last year and wild swings in the yuan, they said on Tuesday, as China unveiled measures to attract US buyers of its assets.

site_title: Clinton leads Trump by 10 points in White House matchup: poll
summary: A Reuters/Ipsos poll released on June 7, 2016, shows Hillary Clinton leading Donald Trump by 10 points in the 2016 presidential campaign, with 44.3% of likely voters supporting Clinton and 34.7% supporting Trump. The poll's results show little change from a week ago, despite Trump facing criticism over comments about a Mexican-American judge. Trump has since stopped discussing the issue, and Clinton has secured enough delegates to become the first female presidential candidate of a major US party.

site_title: Asia: Stocks near six-week high as oil above US$50; kiwi weakens
summary: Asian stocks near a six-week high as crude oil trades above US$50 a barrel, with benchmark share gauges little changed in Japan and South Korea, but Australia's fell. Equity-index futures for China and Hong Kong advanced, while the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index nears a one-month low. Oil maintained gains from its previous session, when it closed above US$50 a barrel for the first time since July 2015.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 edge higher as oil shares rally
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow and S&P 500 edging higher due to gains in oil shares, which surged after US oil prices closed above $50 a barrel for the first time since July. Chevron and ExxonMobil led the gain, while Biogen and Alexion Pharmaceuticals fell after disappointing clinical results. The Nasdaq finished modestly lower. Other notable movers included Zillow, which rose on a settlement deal, and Tesla, which gained after a billionaire shareholder expressed confidence in the company's future.

site_title: Talent shortage stymies Indonesia's tech scene
summary: Indonesia's tech sector is hindered by a talent shortage, with the country struggling to attract and retain skilled workers. Despite being the most populous country in Southeast Asia, Indonesia has a low ratio of highly skilled workers, with only 10% of total employment holding such qualifications. This has led to a reliance on offshoring tech work to other countries, with some investors opting to outsource core platform development to staff in neighboring countries. The government plans to address the issue by introducing coding in public schools and knowledge transfers from foreign investors, but experts warn that the talent shortage is a major hurdle to the country's growth.

site_title: Singapore public servants' computers to have no Internet access from May next year
summary: Singapore plans to block all official computers from the internet starting May 2024 to enhance security. This move affects all government agencies, ministries, and statutory boards. The decision aims to reduce cyber threats and data breaches. The exact timeline and details of the blockade have not been disclosed, but a memo is set to be sent to relevant parties. The move is seen as a significant step to tighten security measures in the country's public sector.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall as GDP upgrade hits stimulus hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks fell in early trade on Wednesday after Japan upgraded its GDP growth for the first quarter, reducing hopes for fresh stimulus measures. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 14.30 points to 16,661.15, while the Topix index lost 0.92 points to 1,339.85. The downgrade may limit the government's ability to implement additional economic stimulus, causing investors to reassess their expectations for future monetary policy.

site_title: Some investors say "don't panic" over Indian central bank leadership
summary: Indian central bank head Raghuram Rajan's reappointment or departure has sparked concerns among investors, with some describing it as "Rexit." Despite speculation, Rajan's two-year extension at the helm of the RBI still appears likely, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi backing him. Rajan's policies, including inflation targeting and a monetary policy committee, have altered the Reserve Bank of India's decision-making process, reducing the governor's discretion. Investors are concerned about the impact of Rajan's departure, but some believe that his departure would not be catastrophic, as his policies and the RBI's new structure would continue to guide monetary policy.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine's delayed rig delivery to North Atlantic Drilling extended to Sept
summary: Sembcorp Marine has extended the standstill agreement for the delayed delivery of the semi-submersible drilling rig, West Rigel, to North Atlantic Drilling Ltd until September 2, 2016. During this period, NADL will market the rig for a drilling contract, while JSPL can sell the rig at an acceptable price. If no deal is reached by the deadline, the parties will form a joint asset holding company with 23% owned by NADL and 77% by JSPL, and continue to market the rig.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees babies, billionaires key to emerging markets
summary: Morgan Stanley's Ruchir Sharma recommends emerging markets strategies for nations seeking to rise, including having more babies to boost labor growth, controlling borrowing, and having self-made billionaires rather than corrupt ones. Sharma's 10 rules rank countries such as the Czech Republic and Poland as top performers, while China is at the bottom due to a shrinking workforce and high debt levels. Sharma warns that countries with high debt-to-GDP ratios, such as China, risk economic stagnation.

site_title: Thailand first in Asia to eliminate mother-to-baby HIV: WHO
summary: Thailand has become the first Asian country to eliminate mother-to-child transmission of HIV, a milestone in the fight against the disease, according to the World Health Organisation. This achievement is a result of the efforts of Thai health workers who have transformed the nation from one of Asia's most HIV-ravaged societies to a model for effectively tackling the crisis. The WHO described the elimination as a "remarkable achievement" that demonstrates that HIV can be defeated.

site_title: North Korea restarts plutonium production for nuclear bombs: US official
summary: North Korea has restarted plutonium fuel production, a move seen as a defiance of international sanctions and a step towards pursuing its nuclear weapons program. The US assessment comes after the UN nuclear watchdog reported indications of a reactivated plant at Yongbyon, North Korea's main nuclear complex. The reprocessing effort is believed to provide a steady supply of materials for North Korea's nuclear drive, despite tightened sanctions following its fourth nuclear test in January. The US is concerned but has not yet announced a response.

site_title: GE Power chief sees financing hurdles to US$8b sales haul
summary: GE Power CEO Steve Bolze warns that over $8 billion in sales opportunities may face delays due to financing challenges, exacerbated by the stalled US Export-Import Bank and falling commodity prices. Bolze remains bullish on the power market, citing a 50% growth in global electricity demand over the next 20 years. GE Power is investing in services and acquisitions to complement its product offerings, with recent deals including the acquisition of NeuCo Inc.

site_title: Airbnb awaits Berlin ruling on legality of home-sharing
summary: A Berlin city court is set to rule on the legality of short-term home-sharing, with Airbnb and other home-sharing companies challenging a ban on renting out homes for less than two months. The ban, which fines homeowners up to 100,000 euros, has been deemed unconstitutional by the former head of Berlin's constitutional court. A positive ruling could have repercussions throughout Europe, as cities balance the interests of the travel and tourism industry with those of tenants. The verdict is expected to impact the sharing economy and may influence other cities' regulations.

site_title: Europe: Shares boosted by oil prices, Yellen
summary: European shares rose to a one-week high on Tuesday, boosted by firmer oil prices and Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on the US economy. Yellen pushed back expectations for a rate increase, while also acknowledging the disappointing jobs report. The STOXX Europe 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indexes rose 1.2% and 1.1% respectively, with commodities-related stocks and energy companies leading the gains. Despite upbeat sentiment, investors remain cautious ahead of the UK's Brexit vote on June 23.

site_title: Quest for cheaper metals trading driving move to start LME rival
summary: Brokers are exploring alternatives to the London Metal Exchange (LME) amid concerns over expensive trading fees and a "disconnect" between markets and users. A group of brokers, led by Martin Abbott, is studying the potential for a new metals marketplace, including an exchange or trading platform. The LME has faced declining volumes and increased fees under new management, leading some to seek cheaper trading options. However, experts note that liquidity on the LME remains strong, and users are unlikely to abandon the platform for alternatives without a viable alternative.

site_title: UK warning adds to Euro 2016 security fears
summary: Britain has warned British citizens of a "high threat from terrorism" during Euro 2016 in France, citing potential targets including stadiums, fan zones, and transport hubs. This warning comes after Ukraine arrested a suspected far-right French extremist with a massive weapons cache, and amid ongoing rail strikes in France that could disrupt travel to the tournament. The UK's Foreign Office says its warning is not in response to the arrest, while France remains under a state of emergency following November's Paris attacks.

site_title: 1% of world's population holds almost half its wealth: report
summary: A report by Boston Consulting Group finds that 1% of the world's population, approximately 18.5 million households, hold almost half of the world's wealth, totaling $78.8 trillion. This concentration of wealth has grown to 47% of global wealth, with the elite one percent steadily increasing their share since 2013. The Asia-Pacific region, particularly East Asia, has experienced the fastest growth in wealth, driven by booming economies. Offshore financial centers remain a significant factor in the accumulation of wealth, with Latin America and the Middle East being the largest sources.

site_title: Seoul: Won climbs to 5-week high on risk-on mood, stocks wobble
summary: The South Korean won reached a 5-week high of 1,157.8 to the US dollar, driven by a weak US dollar and rising global oil prices, boosting risk sentiment. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) was up 0.2% at 2,015.13 points, with offshore investors purchasing 127.9 billion won worth of Kospi shares. Decliners outnumbered advancers 482 to 308, and shares of Samsung Electronics Co Ltd and Hyundai Motor Co fluctuated. Market analysts expect the won's upward trend to last, but will monitor future economic data for potential US Federal Reserve rate hikes.

site_title: Staying in EU 'the British thing to do', says Cameron
summary: David Cameron stated that staying in the EU is the "British thing to do" in a TV appearance two weeks before the UK's EU referendum. He faced criticism from eurosceptic Nigel Farage, who questioned the UK's immigration policies and referred to Cameron's vision as a "little England" view. Cameron assured the audience that a potential "Leave" vote would not mean Britain was a "quitter."

images.alt_text: David Cameron argued on Tuesday that remaining part of the EU was the "British thing to do" as he faced senior eurosceptic Nigel Farage in a TV grilling two weeks before a knife-edge referendum.

site_title: Spain central bank doubtful on Rajoy deficit pledge
summary: Spain's central bank has expressed doubts about the country's deficit pledge, predicting a 4.1% deficit in 2016, 3.4% in 2017, and 2.9% in 2018, one year behind the government's promise. The bank attributes the difference to moderate revenue increases and the same spending rise. This prediction comes as general elections approach, with critics questioning how the government will achieve the deficit reduction despite promised tax cuts. The European Commission may consider sanctions for public overspending, which would be unprecedented if implemented.

images.alt_text: Spain's central bank warned on Tuesday that the country would not meet the EU-set deficit target until 2018 - a year later than promised by the acting government.

site_title: Australian, Canadian dollars surge
summary: Australian and Canadian dollars surged against the US greenback on Tuesday, with the Australian currency rising 1.2% to 74.56 cents. This follows the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to hold interest rates steady after a strong growth report. Canada's currency also strengthened. The euro remained flat, while the yen edged higher. The economic growth report in Australia outstripped most advanced economies, with a 3.1% year-on-year growth rate in the first quarter.

site_title: Mexico cracks down on capital's car pollution
summary: Mexico's government has announced measures to reduce smog in the capital city by cracking down on corruption at emission inspection centers. The new rules, set to take effect July 1, require inspectors to check emission levels recorded by a car's onboard computer, rather than measuring them through the tailpipe. The move aims to prevent polluting cars from staying on the road despite failing emissions tests. The measures also set new limits for public transport buses and heavy trucks, and will be enforced through regular visits to inspection centers by environmental protection authorities.

site_title: Ford in talks to build Lincoln models in China: sources
summary: Ford is in talks with Changan Automobile Group to produce Lincoln luxury vehicles in Chongqing, China, aiming to make China the top market for the brand. The talks are preliminary, with no agreement on key points such as profit sharing, and output may begin as early as 2018 if Lincoln's growth in China continues. The move would save Ford on a 25% import tax and allow the brand to join other luxury vehicles made in China, such as Cadillac and Infiniti.

site_title: S'pore bond market frenzy distorting credit costs: S&P
summary: Singapore's corporate bond market is experiencing a frenzy, with high demand from investors driving down borrowing costs for weaker borrowers. Recent offerings from major companies such as Temasek Holdings and Singapore Power have been "well over-subscribed," according to S&P Global Ratings. This phenomenon is artificially lowering credit costs and distorting the market, as investors perceive rising risks but are instead seeking safe-haven assets. As defaults continue in the region, S&P analysts expect the market to gradually differentiate credit risk, leading to higher funding costs for more leveraged corporates.

site_title: US obesity epidemic grows in all ages
summary: The US obesity epidemic has worsened, with 40% of women, 35% of men, and 17% of children and teens now classified as obese. Studies found that efforts to encourage weight loss have been ineffective, and obesity rates have surged among teens. The research, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, also found that morbid obesity affects 5.8% of children and that smoking is linked to thinner men, but not women. Overall, 38% of adults and 17% of teens are obese, with another third considered overweight.

site_title: In boost to Paris climate pact, India says it aims to join this year
summary: India agrees to work towards joining the Paris Agreement on climate change by the end of this year, providing a boost to the international fight against global warming. During a meeting with US President Barack Obama, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi also pledged to expand military cooperation and outlined principles for cooperation on cyber issues. The meeting highlighted the strong relationship between the two countries, the world's largest democracies.

site_title: Trump backs down under Republican fire in race row
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump has backed down after facing criticism from Republican leaders for his comments on a Mexican-American judge handling a lawsuit against his defunct university. Trump initially claimed the judge was biased against him due to his parents' Mexican heritage, but later said his comments were "misconstrued" and that heritage doesn't make someone incapable of impartiality. Republican leaders, including House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senator Mark Kirk, condemned Trump's remarks as "racist" and "un-American."

site_title: Brexit or not, Europe's voters cooler on Union: survey
summary: European Union voters, regardless of the Brexit outcome, are increasingly skeptical of the EU's benefits, with 48% of British voters and 38% of French voters expressing unfavorable views. Support for the EU has declined in traditionally positive countries, with only Greeks showing more dissatisfaction with Brussels. Younger voters and left-wing supporters are more supportive of EU membership, while older voters and right-wing populists are less supportive. Concerns about the refugee crisis and EU economic management are widespread across Europe, with many voters calling for greater decentralization and powers returned to national capitals.

site_title: Jitters over prolonged global expansion cycle
summary: Global markets remain uncertain about the prolonged economic expansion cycle, with conventional wisdom predicting another 3 years. Despite the 7-year cycle, the current expansion has been "sub-par" with low inflation, high unemployment, and low capacity utilization. Economists estimate 2-3 years left in the cycle, but predict potential shocks such as energy defaults, Eurozone breakups, or US election surprises. Investors are advised to stay invested in equities during expansion and shift to fixed income during slowdowns, despite the risks of a potential recession.

site_title: Global growth slowdown 'worrying': World Bank
summary: The World Bank has downgraded its 2016 global growth forecast to 2.4% due to sluggish growth in advanced economies, low commodity prices, and weak trade and capital flows. The report warns of a downward spiral in activity if more concerted policy counteractions are not taken. Key risks include deteriorating conditions among commodity exporters, rising private-sector debt, and heightened policy and geopolitical uncertainties. The report also highlights the need for new thinking on policy, including reoriented fiscal spending, promotion of productivity-enhancing technologies, and structural economic reforms.

site_title: China exporting fuel at unprecedented pace
summary: China is exporting fuel at an unprecedented pace, with the country's refining capacity doubling to about 14.5 million barrels a day. The surge in exports is driven by a cooling domestic economy, higher US prices, and weakening freight rates, making it more profitable to ship fuel overseas. China has become a major supplier of jet fuel to Europe and Latin America, with shipments also bound for the Panama Canal. The country's fuel exports are expected to continue, potentially eroding margins for producers in other regions and boosting stockpiles in Singapore.

site_title: Ralph Lauren vows to make slow-moving brand more like H&M
summary: Ralph Lauren is revamping its business model to operate more like fast-fashion retailer H&M. CEO Stefan Larsson aims to reduce the time it takes to get products through the supply chain to nine months, down from 15 months. This will allow for quicker reaction to fashion trends and reduce the need for discounts. The company expects sales to decline by a percentage in the low double digits in fiscal 2017, but plans to stabilize in fiscal 2018 and emerge as a streamlined organization in fiscal 2019. The changes are part of a "Way Forward" program that includes slashing 1,000 jobs and cutting three layers of management.

site_title: Abe not alone in emphasising fiscal stimulus
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has gained recognition for his emphasis on fiscal stimulus in advanced economies, making him an intellectual figure in economics. Nobel Prize-winning economists have advised him on the benefits of fiscal stimulus, a concept often associated with Western economies. Abe's approach has drawn comparisons to other Western leaders, with some suggesting he has become a "good listener" to international economic counsel. This shift in Abe's economic strategy has sparked interest in his approach to economic policy.

site_title: Will Brexit endanger Britain's famous pork pies and real ale?
summary: Brexit may not directly impact Britain's protected food products, such as pork pies, real ale, and Stilton cheese, as EU protection isn't restricted to EU members. Producers like Robin Skailes and Andy Riches are concerned, however, as EU regulations have protected these foodstuffs, and they worry about the potential loss of this protection. The UK Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs emphasizes the value of EU protection, citing its benefits for British products, consumers, and local economies.

site_title: 'Trumpism' takes an ugly un-American turn
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's racist rhetoric has sparked widespread condemnation. Trump's attack on Judge Gonzalo Curiel, who is of Mexican heritage, has been labeled as classic case of racism. The judge's ethnicity was not deemed a basis for questioning his impartiality in a case against Trump University. Trump's comments are seen as a challenge to the independence of the judiciary and have reinforced the narrative that the Republican party is driven by nativist and xenophobic sentiments. The attacks are expected to strengthen Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's position among Hispanics, Asian Americans, and African Americans.

site_title: Addvalue soars on sale-of-unit update
summary: Addvalue Technologies' shares surged 90.6% to 6.1 Singapore cents after the company announced it's working to complete the sale of its wholly owned Addvalue Communications to a Chinese buyer within four months. The sale price has been revised to S$308m from S$330m, down from the original announced price in March 2014. The buyer is believed to be a Beijing-based data security firm, but details remain scarce.

site_title: Companies can help strengthen regional integration: ESM Goh
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong urged companies to support regional integration in the Asia-Pacific, citing the need for economic linkages and inter-dependence between countries. He emphasized the role of the private sector in fostering closer ties, particularly through multilateral institutions like the World Bank and Asian Development Bank. Goh also highlighted the importance of collaboration and trade, calling on companies to put aside differences and work together on infrastructure development initiatives, such as the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.

site_title: Bill Gates, Saudi prince said to be seeking sale of Four Seasons Toronto
summary: Bill Gates and Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal Al Saud are seeking to sell the Four Seasons Hotel in Toronto for nearly C$250 million, with the property's rooms available for C$1 million each, a record price for a hotel in Canada. The hotel, purchased by the group in 2007, comprises 250 rooms and is part of a luxury condo complex in Yorkville. The sale would be a significant transaction, with the group reportedly targeting a sale price of C$250 million.

site_title: IE S'pore-ICBC MOU to power One Belt One Road projects
summary: Singapore's IE SINGAPORE signed a memorandum of understanding with ICBC's Singapore unit to support Singaporean companies in China's "One Belt One Road" (OBOR) initiative. The Chinese bank will set up a team in Singapore to provide project financing and professional services for OBOR basic infrastructure investments. This partnership aims to facilitate Singaporean companies' participation in OBOR projects, enhancing economic cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: Commodities making a comeback, but investors remain wary (Amended)
summary: Commodities have entered a bull market, driven by higher crude oil and gold prices, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index 20.5% higher than its January low. Despite this, investors remain cautious, with 19% of fund managers underweight on the asset class, down from 22% in April. Analysts attribute the recovery to micro fundamentals, including low prices boosting consumption and curbing supply, and structural declines in production and supply disruptions. However, investors are hesitant due to past disappointing returns and concerns over the sustainability of the recovery.

images.alt_text: US rig count has been falling since hitting a high of 1,609 in October 2014, though the pace has slowed. Only 325 rigs were in operation in the week to June 3, says energy services firm Baker Hughes.

site_title: Playboy Mansion to be sold to its neighbour for over US$100m
summary: The Playboy Mansion in Holmby Hills, California, has been sold to Daren Metropoulos for over US$100 million. The 32-year-old son of billionaire Dean Metropoulos will continue to live in the property, which was previously listed for US$200 million. The sale was facilitated by a 20,000 sq ft estate with luxury amenities, including a zoo license. The buyer hopes to eventually connect both properties, and Hugh Hefner will remain a neighbor.

site_title: Great Eastern sells Vietnam business for S$48.2m
summary: Great Eastern Holdings has sold its Vietnam business to FWD Life Insurance Company (Bermuda) for S$48.2 million. The move is part of GEH's strategy to focus on core markets, including Singapore and Malaysia. The transaction is expected to be completed on June 21 and will result in a loss due to accumulated foreign exchange translation losses. FWD plans to retain and grow the employee base and invest in technology infrastructure.

site_title: Jurong Port is site of world's largest port-based solar facility
summary: Jurong Port in Singapore has completed the world's largest port-based solar facility, generating 9.5 megawatts of power, enough to power 2,500 four-room HDB flats annually. The $30 million installation, led by local developer Sunseap, will reduce carbon emissions by 5,200 tonnes and offset 60% of the port's electricity needs, with excess energy exported to the grid.
