summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer for its data center business was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while Creative Technology warned its H2 revenue may fall short of targets due to operating losses. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. In Indonesia, Trafigura employee was detained in a graft case. OCBC Bank announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. Monetary authorities MAS and PBOC agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Weak wages, private school flight belie Australian economic success
summary: Australia's economic success is masked by stagnant wages, private school flight, and job losses in Western Australia, the country's former mining hub. Despite strong iron ore and LNG exports, wages have remained stagnant, and private schools are experiencing a decline in enrollment as families opt for state-funded schools. The state's economy is predicted to contract by 4.25% in 2015-16, and business investment is falling dramatically. This trend reflects the country's difficulty in transitioning from a mining-driven economy to a more diversified one.

site_title: FLASH: Nikkei Singapore PMI at 50.1 in May, after April's reading of 49.4
summary: Singapore's private-sector May PMI reading rose to 50.1, a slight improvement from April's 49.4. The conditions remained "broadly unchanged" despite the slight increase. This indicates a moderate expansion in the country's private sector.

site_title: Malaysia's April exports pick up slightly, imports fall
summary: Malaysia's exports increased 1.6% in April, driven by higher shipments of manufactured goods and palm oil, but fell short of the 2.0% median forecast. Imports declined 2.3% from a year earlier, offsetting the trade surplus, which fell to RM9.1 billion. Exports to China dropped 16.6% due to lower commodity shipments, while those to the US rose 11.7% mainly due to electrical and electronic product exports.

site_title: Updated hot stock: CityDev soars more than 3% on inclusion to major FTSE index
summary: City Developments' shares surged more than 3% on Friday after being included in the FTSE EPRA/NAREIT Global Real Estate Index, Asia region, effective June 20, 2016. The stock hit a high of S$8.84, up 28 Singapore cents, or 3.31%, at 2:17 pm. Credit Suisse analysts predicted a positive market reaction and forecast CityDev's share price to be driven by asset divestments and overseas diversification plans.

site_title: Apple says all services resume after outage
summary: Apple's services, including the App Store, iCloud, and Photos, have resumed after an outage that started Thursday evening. The outage began around 4pm EDT and affected some users, but services were restored by 11:55pm EDT. Apple attributed the issue to "no reported issues" at the time of the update. The company did not provide further details on the cause of the outage, referring users to its support page for more information.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher with Noble, Yeo Hiap Seng in focus during the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 7 points to 2,809.23 last week, driven by a surge in volume on Tuesday. Yeo Hiap Seng's shares jumped 21% to S$1.56 after a query from the Singapore Exchange, while Noble Group's shares rose following its CEO's resignation and a subsequent rights issue announcement. The week's turnover was S$2 billion, with the STI closing at 0.4% on Thursday, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Japanese investigators raid Suzuki Motor over false tests
summary: Japanese investigators raided Suzuki Motor Corp's headquarters on June 3, 2016, to probe the minicar maker's use of improper fuel economy tests. The transport ministry is looking into Suzuki's claims of using data from indoor tests on individual parts, rather than vehicle coasting tests. This is the second raid by the transport ministry on a Japanese automaker, following Mitsubishi Motors Corp's admission of misrepresenting fuel economy readings in April. Suzuki's improper tests involved 14 branded models and 12 models sold under other brands, citing lack of resources and increased pressure to develop models after the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial said to seek S$900m in Singapore IPO
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust is planning a Singapore initial public offering (IPO) seeking up to S$900 million, with units priced at 85-89 Singapore cents each. The trust, backed by 51 Australian properties, is expected to offer a 7-7.5% dividend yield. The IPO would be the largest first-time share sale in Singapore since 2013, potentially boosting the Singapore bourse. About 15 cornerstone investors have agreed to subscribe to 50% of the offer, with Frasers Centrepoint Ltd, a property developer backed by Thai billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, being the main contributor.

site_title: Singapore private-sector May PMI at 50.1, conditions 'broadly unchanged' after April's dip
summary: Singapore's private sector experienced "broadly unchanged" business conditions in May, according to the Nikkei Singapore purchasing managers' index (PMI) at 50.1. This follows a decline in April. Readings above 50 indicate improvement, while below 50 signal deterioration. The result suggests that the sector may require additional stimulus to boost growth.

site_title: Fed likely to avoid rate hike before Britain votes on leaving EU
summary: The US Federal Reserve may delay a rate hike at its June meeting due to concerns over the economic fallout from Britain's vote on leaving the European Union. A "leave" vote is expected to roil financial markets, causing credit spreads to widen and bolstering the US dollar. Fed officials, including Chair Janet Yellen, have expressed caution, with four of the five Washington-based governors warning of the potential impact. The Fed is likely to wait until at least July to consider a rate increase, with some economists suggesting this is a "no-brainer" given the uncertainty surrounding the Brexit vote.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve may be forced to delay a rate hike at its June meeting because of mounting concern over the economic fallout from Britain's vote on whether to leave the European Union.

site_title: Oil prices hold steady on lower US supplies
summary: Oil prices remained steady in Asian trading after a US Department of Energy report showed a 1.4 million barrel drop in commercial crude inventories, indicating a pick-up in demand. The decline in US supplies offset Opec's decision not to agree on production caps, which was expected to lower oil prices. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 2 cents to $49.19 a barrel, while Brent for August increased 4 cents to $50.08 a barrel. Analysts expect continued supply and demand shifts, potentially leading to a "fundamental change in supply and demand" and higher oil prices.

site_title: S$15m in research grants awarded to 6 projects that develop innovative energy storage
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has awarded S$15 million in research grants to six projects focused on developing cost-effective energy storage innovations. The projects, chosen from 30 proposals, aim to enable the widespread deployment of renewable energy sources like solar in Singapore's hot and humid environment. The selected projects, led by researchers from National University of Singapore and Nanyang Technological University, will collaborate with industry players to develop energy storage solutions that can enhance power system stability and reliability. The projects are seen as crucial in supporting Singapore's transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: South Korean, US missile defence talks to continue, but not in Singapore
summary: South Korea and the US will continue talks on deploying the Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (THAAD) missile defense system, but the discussions will not take place at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore. The system is needed to counter the growing threat from North Korea, which has conducted several nuclear tests and long-range rocket launches. US Defence Secretary Ash Carter said the deployment is necessary for improved missile defenses, despite China's opposition. Separate talks are ongoing, with a public announcement expected "soon", according to a South Korean defence ministry official.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales rise again in May
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales rose 3.6% in May, reaching 96,672 units, compared to the same period last year. This marks the third consecutive month of growth and puts the market on track for another record year. SUV sales increased 11.4%, while light commercial vehicles rose 10.6%. Toyota retained the top spot with 17.8% market share, followed by Mazda and Hyundai. The running total for 2016 stands at 469,571 units, 3.8% ahead of the same period last year.

site_title: Flash: Noble resumes trading down 7% after rights issue at steep discount
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 7% after the company issued a rights issue at a steep discount, making it the most active stock on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The move is part of Noble's efforts to raise funds and stabilize its finances.

site_title: China's yuan eases, poll shows currency might weaken further
summary: China's yuan eased 0.16% against the US dollar to 6.5793 per dollar, its weakest midpoint rate in nearly two weeks. A Reuters poll forecasts a 2.5% decline in the yuan over the next year due to a US dollar rally and China's cooling economy. The yuan has posted its second-largest monthly fall on record, 1.6%, in May. Investors are betting on a further decline in the yuan, raising the risk of volatility, as it approaches a US job report that could boost the dollar.

site_title: Pop power couple Taylor Swift, Calvin Harris break up
summary: Taylor Swift and Calvin Harris, the pop power couple, have broken up. After a nearly year-long relationship, Harris confirmed the split on Twitter, stating they ended with "a huge amount of love and respect." Swift, 26, and Harris, 32, were first seen together in 2015 and had been a high-profile couple. Swift has previously spoken about her frustration with media attention on her love life, but the two seem to be parting ways amicably.

site_title: Samsung SDS says considering spinning off some of its businesses
summary: South Korea's Samsung SDS Co is considering spinning off its logistics process outsourcing and IT systems services businesses. Reports suggest Samsung C&T Corp and Samsung Electronics Co Ltd may acquire these businesses, but the companies denied these plans. Samsung SDS has not elaborated on its spinoff plans, leaving the matter uncertain.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up in cautious trade, outlook uncertain
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.1% to 8,565.41, despite an uncertain outlook, as investors awaited US employment data that could impact interest rate hikes. The index had closed down 0.5% the previous session. The rally followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the S&P 500 in the US. The cautious trade was attributed to ongoing uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans and the impact of US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 3.610 points to 1633.750. Volume was 15.4 million lots worth RM6.45 million, with 68 gainers and 46 losers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars calm, set to post weekly gains
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars have held steady against the US dollar, poised for weekly gains. The New Zealand dollar rose 1.8% since Monday, boosted by dairy price recovery, inflation signs, and property price growth. This has led economists to rescind calls for an easing of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's monetary policy.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise before US jobs data as Japanese shares advance
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday as Japanese shares climbed for the first time in three days before a monthly US government jobs report. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose 0.1% and Japan's Topix index rose 0.6%, paring its first weekly loss in a month. Investors are focusing on macro-economic events, including the US jobs report and UK vote on EU membership. US stocks rose to a seven-month high on optimism about the American economy, with economists forecasting 160,000 jobs added in May.

site_title: US dollar edges down ahead of jobs report
summary: The US dollar decreased ahead of the release of the May jobs report, which is expected to show 160,000 new jobs and a 4.9% unemployment rate. This data will influence the Federal Reserve's decision on lifting interest rates, with some economists predicting a June or July hike. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen previously mentioned the possibility of a rate hike "in the coming months" due to the US economy's growth and labor market strength.

site_title: Lafe Corp on SGX watch list
summary: Lafe Corp, a Singapore-based company with property investment and development services, has been placed on the Singapore Exchange watch-list following three consecutive years of losses. The company must fulfill requirements under Rule 1314 within 36 months to be removed from the list; failure to do so may result in delisting or suspension of trading. Lafe Corp will need to demonstrate financial stability and meet listing requirements to avoid delisting.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble down 10% on trading resumption, most active stock on SGX
summary: Noble Group, a commodities trader, resumed trading after a brief halt, falling 10% to S$0.27 with 45.2 million shares changing hands. The company unveiled a one-for-one rights issue at a 60% discount and announced the step-down of its founder and changes to its board of directors. A US$500 million rights issue was also announced, with shares closing at S$0.30 on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Friday after record gains on Wall Street
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) opened flat on Friday after the US shares reversed course and ended with gains, driven by a rise in oil prices and job expectations. The S&P 500 hit a seven-month high on Thursday. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 25, with top stocks by volume traded including Equation, Singtel, and China Sports.

site_title: China confirms its warships to join major US-hosted naval drills
summary: China has confirmed it will send five warships to join the US-hosted Rim of the Pacific exercise (RIMPAC) this summer, despite tensions over the South China Sea. The naval drill, held every two years in Hawaii, has sparked criticism from US Senator John McCain, who suggests the US should bar China from the drills. China's participation in the exercise marks a significant move as the world's two largest economies continue to navigate their complex relationship.

site_title: New Zealand commodity prices improve in May: private survey
summary: New Zealand commodity prices rose 1.0% in May, according to ANZ Bank's commodity price index, reversing a 0.8% decline in the previous month. On an annual basis, the index fell 11.7%, but in New Zealand dollar terms, it rose 2.5% and is 3.5% lower than a year ago. Dairy products, the country's largest export earner, were mostly unchanged, with skim milk powder prices declining 1.8%.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks track Wall St higher at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose in early trade on June 3, 2016, following a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.46% to 20,956.08, while the Shanghai benchmark composite index gained 0.16% to 2,929.79. The gains were attributed to expectations of US jobs data later in the day, which could influence global markets.

site_title: Hyundai Motor plans luxury electric car under Genesis brand
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to launch a luxury electric vehicle under the Genesis brand, aiming to diversify its premium offerings and boost profits. The company's senior vice president, Manfred Fitzgerald, stated that electric vehicles will be crucial for the luxury market, and an electric model is in development. The launch of the electric vehicle will be the second model under the Genesis brand, following the G80 large sedan. Hyundai aims to differentiate itself from group brands and competitors, with a focus on strong branding and design.

site_title: Gold 'without friends' as investors eye monthly US payrolls
summary: Gold prices fell for a third day as investors await the US employment report on Friday, which may confirm the Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike plans. The metal is down 0.2% this week, as investors seek interest-paying assets. Economists forecast 160,000 jobs added in May, and the unemployment rate to drop to 4.9%. The market views gold as "without friends" due to its lack of interest payments, with money managers cutting long positions by 26% this year. A strong payrolls report could see gold prices tested again.

site_title: North Korea accuses South of abducting more restaurant staff
summary: North Korea has accused South Korea of premeditated abduction of three North Korean staff working at a Pyongyang-run restaurant in China. This is the second group defection this year, following a dozen employees from another restaurant in China who defected to the South in April. The North Korean Red Cross claims there is evidence of a well-planned operation to abduct the workers, and demands their immediate return. The South Korean government has rejected the "kidnapping" claims and increased vigilance for revenge kidnappings of South Korean citizens abroad.

site_title: Any Brazil tax hikes have to be temporary, Temer says
summary: Interim President Michel Temer of Brazil stated that any tax increases to address the country's budget deficit must be temporary. He emphasized the need to curb expenditures to rebalance public finances, warning that tax hikes may hinder efforts to pull Brazil out of recession. Temer also expressed concerns about the use of tax hikes to cut the deficit, citing the need to implement short- and long-term deficit-cutting initiatives. He highlighted the growing momentum behind these efforts, citing a "harmony" between lawmakers and his administration.

images.alt_text: Any tax increases to help plug Brazil's sweeping budget deficit have to be temporary, interim President Michel Temer said on Thursday, adding that the government is focused on curbing expenditures to rebalance public finances.

site_title: Facebook board seeks curb in Zuckerberg's control in the event of departure
summary: Facebook's board proposes removing Mark Zuckerberg's majority voting control in the event of his departure, converting his Class B shares into Class A shares. As of June 2, Zuckerberg owned 419 million Class B shares, representing 53.8% of total voting power. The proposal, set to be voted on at the annual general meeting on June 20, aims to ensure a future CEO's management powers aren't limited. This change would prevent Zuckerberg from holding majority voting control even if he leaves the company, and would allow for more shareholder control.

site_title: Oil set for 1st weekly loss in month as Opec skips output limits
summary: Oil prices are set for a weekly loss, marking the first in a month, as OPEC rejected a proposal to adopt a new production ceiling. Despite this, the group remains optimistic about global oil markets improving, with US crude stockpiles dropping by 1.37 million barrels. Oil prices have surged 85% since a 12-year low in February due to disruptions and declining US output. OPEC members agree that a new output target will be set in the future, with some analysts predicting balance in the market before the end of 2016.

site_title: Japan's April real wage gains slow in warning sign for economy
summary: Japan's real wages rose 0.6% in April, slower than the 1.6% increase in March, sparking concerns about the economy. The data suggests upward pressure on pay rises may be waning, which could impact consumption and the government's efforts to defeat deflation. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged companies to increase worker compensation to boost consumption. The slower wage growth may make households more cautious about spending, posing a challenge to the government's economic strategy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Keppel, Sembcorp, Otto Marine (Amended)
summary: NOBLE Group announced a US$500 million rights issue, cost-reduction programs, and changes to its board of directors. Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management denied allegations of covering up a Basslink interconnector outage, which has cost Tasmania at least A$560 million. Sembcorp Industries and Sembcorp Marine denied allegations in a lawsuit filed by US investment company EIG Management. Otto Marine received a letter from RHB Securities Singapore regarding a potential buyer.

site_title: Noble issues 1 for 1 rights issue at steep discount; Elman to step down in a year's time
summary: NOBLE Group has issued a 1:1 rights issue at a steep discount, with each share priced at S$0.11, a 63% discount from its previous close. The move aims to raise US$500 million and will be used to reduce net debt and improve financial flexibility. Founder and chairman Richard Elman will step down as executive chairman within the next 12 months, with a succession plan to be established by a sub-committee chaired by David Eldon.

site_title: Seven-year-old boy missing in Japan forest found alive: officials
summary: A 7-year-old boy missing in a Japan forest for nearly a week was found alive at a military base on Friday. The boy, identified as Yamato Tanooka, was discovered unharmed and in good health. He had been left by his parents on a mountain road as punishment for misbehaving, with no food or water. The parents initially claimed the boy got lost while they were hiking, but later admitted to ordering him onto the road. Police are considering filing neglect charges against the parents, who have expressed remorse for their actions.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher following Wall St gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.22% to 16,599.51, while the broader Topix index climbed 0.12% to 1,333.42. This rebound comes after two sessions of losses.

site_title: Brexit puts 400,000 services jobs at risk in UK
summary: The UK's Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, warns that a Brexit could lead to the loss of 400,000 service sector jobs, with many companies relying on cross-border trade and supply chains. Despite polls suggesting the "Leave" campaign is gaining momentum, Osborne accuses the "Leave" campaign of failing to accurately portray the impact on unemployment. The government's economic message has yet to convince voters, with many saying they don't think leaving the EU would affect their standard of living.

site_title: US: Wall St shrugs off Europe, Japan losses; S&P at 7-month high
summary: US stocks reached a 7-month high on Thursday, closing 0.3% higher despite losses in European and Japanese markets. The S&P 500 gained momentum after a modest rise in oil prices and expectations of a solid jobs report. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also ended the day up 0.3%. The European Central Bank maintained its policy stance, raising growth and inflation forecasts, but the euro fell 0.3% to US$1.1154.

site_title: Apple says some services including App Store facing issues
summary: Apple's App Store resumed services after a two-hour outage, affecting some iCloud and iPhone Photos services. The outage began at 4pm US Eastern Daylight Time and was restored at 6:30pm EDT. The cause of the issue is not specified, but it is not the first time the App Store has experienced downtime. Other services, including iCloud and Photos, remain unavailable for some users. Apple has not provided a clear explanation for the outage.

site_title: Swift CEO expects more hacking surprises as fix is years away
summary: Swift CEO Gottfried Leibbrandt expects more hacking surprises as the network's full defenses are years away from being implemented. The system, used by 11,000 institutions, was breached in the Bangladesh heist, which stole $81 million, and similar breaches have occurred at 12 other banks. Leibbrandt plans to focus on quick wins to improve security in the near term and has unveiled a five-point plan to upgrade defenses, including auditing members' security. The industry's trust-based model is under scrutiny, and Leibbrandt acknowledges that a disconnected bank may have little incentive to shore up its security.

site_title: Number of terrorist attacks fell in 2015: US report
summary: The US State Department reported a 13% decline in terrorist attacks globally in 2015, the first decline since 2012, with a 14% decrease in fatalities. The majority of attacks (55%) occurred in five countries: Iraq, Pakistan, India, Afghanistan, and Nigeria. Despite the decline, the global terrorist threat continued to evolve, with the Islamic State posing the greatest threat globally, despite losing territory in Iraq and Syria. Other countries experiencing increased attacks include Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Egypt, the Philippines, Syria, and Turkey.

site_title: Scientists propose project to build synthetic human genome
summary: A group of 25 scientists proposed the Human Genome Project-Write, aiming to create a synthetic human genome within 10 years. The project, led by geneticist Jef Boeke, could potentially be used to grow transplantable human organs, engineer immunity to viruses, and accelerate vaccine and drug development. The scientists acknowledge the project's controversy and plan to seek public involvement and consider ethical implications. They estimate costs of less than $3 billion, a fraction of the original Human Genome Project's $3 billion budget.

site_title: Chinese military moves key issue at Singapore forum
summary: The Shangri-La Dialogue, Asia's largest security forum, opened in Singapore with a focus on territorial disputes in the South China Sea, North Korea's military provocations, and Islamist extremism. At least 20 defence ministers, including Pentagon chief Ashton Carter, are attending the event. China's claims in the South China Sea are expected to drive up Asia-Pacific defence spending by 25% to $533 billion by 2020. The forum also addresses tensions on the Korean peninsula and renewed concerns over jihadist terrorism in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Two to Tango, please: Uber finally makes inroads in ageing Japan
summary: Uber has finally entered Japan's ageing community, launching its service in the town of Tango, with a population of 5,560 and 40% over 65 years old. The ride-hailing app aims to tap into this demographic demand, offering a solution for Japan's ageing society. Residents will use tablets to book rides, and Uber charges half the rate of the local taxi firm. The company hopes to expand similar services in other depopulated areas in Japan, utilizing existing assets to provide sustainable business models for elderly care homes and communities.

images.alt_text: Ride-hailing app Uber has finally cracked Japan - approved to offer its service in Tango, part of Kyotango city on the west coast, with a population of just 5,560 and abandoned by the local taxi firm eight years ago.

site_title: Fabchem independent director Desmond Ong resigns
summary: Fabchem China Limited announced the resignation of independent director Desmond Ong Tai Tiong Desmond, effective Thursday, citing a need to concentrate on professional and other commitments. Ong had held various committee positions, including lead independent director, chairman of remuneration and nominating committees, and audit committee member. The company is currently identifying a suitable replacement and will announce the decision once finalized.

site_title: The (false) robot invasion
summary: A 2016 article questions the notion of a robot invasion, citing little evidence of significant job displacement due to robots. Despite the hype, the number of industrial robots installed in the US in 2014 was relatively small (26,200) compared to the total payroll employment. Economists argue that robots are not new and have been adopted gradually, with the impact on jobs being similar to earlier labor-saving technologies. The article concludes that the real problem is not job displacement, but rather wage depression, and that workers' wages may increase as the labor force ages and becomes scarcer.

site_title: Negative rates push Japanese investors into US Treasuries, mortgage bonds
summary: Japanese investors are pouring money into US Treasuries and mortgage bonds, driven by Japan's negative interest rate policy, which has pushed them out of safe-havens and into assets that stimulate economic growth. This has resulted in a surge in Japanese investment flows into US bonds, hitting multi-year highs in March. Despite the outflows, the yen's value has strengthened, and investors are hedging away most of the currency risks, eroding returns. This has prompted some Japanese investors to look at higher-yielding US debt, and new schemes have emerged to help firms hedge offshore investments.

site_title: Prince death ruled a painkiller overdose
summary: Prince's death, ruled an accidental overdose of painkillers, was confirmed by an autopsy, with fentanyl being the cause. The 57-year-old pop icon, who weighed 51kg, had no known prescription for the opioid. His death, amid the US opioid epidemic, comes amid growing public alarm over 26,647 opioid-related deaths in 2014. The National Safety Council urged the music industry to raise awareness and create change, as Prince's family scrambles to organize a memorial service.

site_title: Voices from the millennial generation
summary: The Twenty-Something Theatre Festival, featuring eight plays by millennial playwrights, aims to showcase a fresh perspective on issues such as environmentalism, societal expectations, and personal identity. The festival, which runs for two weeks, includes plays that explore topical issues like government decisions and historical memory, as well as universal themes like pregnancy and death. The plays, written by playwrights in their 20s, challenge stereotypes of the millennial generation and offer a nuanced view of their experiences, highlighting their awareness of the world beyond social media.

images.alt_text: Eight playwrights in their 20s present their plays over two weekends. In the first week (left picture, from left) Irfan Kasban, Annabel Tan, Kenneth Chia and Johnny Jon Jon. In the second week, (right picture, from left) Euginia Tan, Joel Tan, David Khoo and Kimberly Arriola (seated).

site_title: Don't roll dice on Brexit, Cameron tells voters
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron urged Britons not to "roll a dice" on Brexit, warning that leaving the EU would be an act of "economic self-harm." In a televised interview, Cameron argued that staying in the EU would safeguard the country's prosperity and security, and that the UK would succeed when it works together with the EU to improve it. With opinion polls finely balanced, Cameron is leading the "Remain" campaign, facing off against the "Leave" camp in several televised interviews before the June 23 vote.

site_title: Cityneon signs term sheet to host, run Marvel's Avengers exhibitions in Australia
summary: Cityneon Holdings has signed a non-binding term sheet with iLive Entertainment Group to host and operate Marvel's Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N. exhibitions in Australia, starting in Sydney by December 1, 2017. The exhibitions will be produced by Victory Hill Exhibitions Pte Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of Cityneon.

site_title: URA makes access to shophouse info easy
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a new online portal, URA SPACE, allowing users to instantly search for allowable and last-approved uses for private shophouses in Singapore at no charge. This move replaces the need for a search fee and wait times of up to seven working days for a response. The portal provides access to land-use and property-related information, including urban design guidelines and past property transactions, and is optimized for mobile usage.

site_title: Oil prices rise on fall in US inventories
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday after the US Department of Energy reported a 1.4 million barrel decline in commercial crude oil inventories, despite historically high levels. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting concluded without agreement to lower production, leaving global supplies abundant. This news lifted oil prices after two days of losses, reversing the market trend.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose on Thursday following two days of losses, getting a lift from a fall in US crude inventories, while a key Opec meeting left production unchecked.

site_title: Former Colliers research head joins CBRE as director
summary: Former Colliers research head Chia Siew Chuin has joined CBRE as director of industrial and logistics for Asia, effective from Wednesday. She will report to Dennis Yeo and oversee the region, aiming to strengthen CBRE's presence in the industrial and logistics sector, engage clients, and provide thought leadership through research reports and symposiums. The move aligns with CBRE's strategic plan to develop the growth prospects of the sector across Asia, including China and India.

site_title: Brazil acting president pushes for quick Rousseff impeachment
summary: Brazil's acting president Michel Temer pushed for speeding up the impeachment process against suspended president Dilma Rousseff, who could be forced from office before the start of the Rio Olympics on August 5. The suspension, which can last up to six months, has sparked controversy, with Rousseff's lawyer calling it a "huge farce" and a "coup." The Supreme Court will decide on the scheduling, which Rousseff's side prefers to be more drawn out. Temer's team argues for a quicker process, while Rousseff faces potential removal from office and Temer staying until 2018 elections.

site_title: Strong push for Kazakhstan's UN Security Council bid
summary: Kazakhstan is pushing strongly for a non-permanent seat on the UN Security Council for the 2017/18 term. Foreign Minister Erlan Idrissov met with international counterparts in New York to promote Kazakhstan's priorities, including global peace and security, sustainable development, and environmental protection. Kazakhstan's bid is based on four central pillars: food security, water security, energy security, and nuclear security. The results of the bid will be announced at the end of June, and Kazakhstan hopes to leverage its experience and expertise to address pressing challenges facing the UN.

site_title: Clinton says Trump dangerous, unfit to be commander in chief
summary: Hillary Clinton criticized Donald Trump as "dangerously incoherent" and "unfit" to be commander-in-chief, calling him "temperamentally unfit" to hold the office. Clinton also questioned Trump's views on NATO, Russia, and nuclear proliferation, stating that he is "not someone who should ever have the nuclear codes." Clinton's remarks were seen as an attempt to unify her base and contrast her own foreign policy expertise with Trump's perceived lack of experience and impulsiveness.

site_title: US$ hits 2-week low against safe-haven yen
summary: The US dollar hit a two-week low against the yen due to uncertainty over a potential interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve in June or July. The euro remained unchanged after the European Central Bank kept interest rates unchanged. The yen's strength was attributed to subdued risk sentiment and doubts over Japan's willingness to intervene to weaken the currency. The greenback had previously reached a two-month high but lost about one percent, with investors pricing in a 20% chance of a rate hike in June.

site_title: Madonna prevails in key copyright case
summary: Madonna has won a copyright case over a sample in her 1990 song Vogue, a brief horn riff taken from the 1980s Salsoul Orchestra song Ooh I Love It (Love Break). The US Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld a 2013 decision that deemed the sample "de minimis," or too trivial to warrant attention, and dismissed a lawsuit by VMG Salsoul, the company that holds the copyright to the earlier song. The ruling could help future artists using samples, contradicting a 2005 decision by the Sixth Circuit that said small samples warranted copyright protection.

site_title: German terrorism insurer mulls over global coverage
summary: German terrorism insurer Extremus Versicherungs-AG is considering offering global coverage due to shrinking premium income. The insurer, backed by the government and major shareholders like Allianz and Munich Re, may start offering international policies within three months. This comes after recent attacks in Paris and Brussels, highlighting the terrorism threat. The coverage is currently limited to Germany, but Extremus aims to expand to meet client demand. The insurer's state guarantee is set to expire in 2019.

site_title: When playing by the rules can lose you points
summary: Donald Trump's unconventional presidential campaign has confounded pundits with his success in breaking and remaking election campaign rules. Unlike traditional candidates who follow strict rules, Trump has employed his marketing know-how and show-business skills to dominate the agenda, choreographing media events and projecting his persona. His unorthodox approach, including insults, profane language, and inaccurate statements, has helped him emerge as the Republican presidential frontrunner, while his opponent Hillary Clinton's nuanced policy proposals have been overshadowed. Trump's ability to control the time and space of the campaign, despite being criticized for his actions, has contributed to his success, leaving many wondering if his unconventional tactics will pay off.

site_title: Uber raises US$3.5b from Saudi Arabia investment fund
summary: Uber has secured US$3.5 billion from the Public Investment Fund of Saudi Arabia, valuing the ride-sharing giant at US$62.5 billion. The investment will help fuel Uber's global expansion, particularly in the Middle East and North Africa. The deal also includes the appointment of Saudi fund head Yasir Al Rumayyan to the Uber board. Uber plans to invest US$250 million in the region, aiming to improve mobility for women in Saudi Arabia, where 80% of riders are female. The investment comes as Saudi Arabia seeks to diversify its economy away from oil production.

site_title: Lead actor in Distance keeps movie going
summary: Anthony Chen, the executive producer of the anthology film Distance, has stepped back from the director's chair, handing duties to three Asian filmmakers. Despite his absence, Chen's influence is evident in the film's dramatic restraint and grounding. The anthology features distinct stories and styles, but maintains a cohesive tone, thanks to Chen's direction in the directors' segment. Taiwanese heartthrob Chen Bo-lin shines in multiple roles, and the film showcases the talents of young Asian directors, including Tan Shijie and Xin Yukun. The anthology is a success, with each segment offering a unique perspective on distance and human connection.

site_title: Overweight high-yield EM bonds: Bank of Singapore
summary: Bank of Singapore's head of managed investments Hou Wey Fook recommends overweighting high-yield emerging-market bonds and underweighting investment-grade developed-market bonds due to low interest rates and market volatility. He expects the US Federal Reserve to raise rates in July and December, citing high-yield bonds as a more attractive asset class, with yields ranging from 4.1% to 8.5%. Hou also suggests selling covered calls on equity holdings to moderate market falls, but remains neutral on equities.

site_title: Zinc to jump further with China likely to cut output
summary: Zinc prices surged 25% this year, the highest since July, due to a decline in raw material supply to smelters in China, the world's largest user of the metal. Chinese smelters may cut production for the first time in four years as they compete to secure the dwindling supply of zinc concentrate. Demand rebounds in China, driven by infrastructure spending and a bottoming property market, further lifts prices. Banks predict further gains, with Macquarie estimating an average price of $2,313 a tonne in 2017.

site_title: Deutsche Bank sees capital hit as Basel rules add to legal woes
summary: Deutsche Bank expects to set aside even more capital or reduce businesses due to new Basel rules, which bar banks from using their own models for operational risk. The proposed rules could lead to "quite a significant inflation in the amount of capital" required, according to CEO John Cryan. The bank has faced the highest legal bills among continental European lenders, with 12.6 billion euros in costs since 2012. Deutsche Bank may conclude its largest legal disputes this year and is concerned that new Basel rules will impinge on its business.

site_title: Europe: Stocks wobble as ECB and Opec disappoint
summary: Europe's main stock indices ended Thursday down, with London's FTSE 100 and Paris' CAC 40 shedding 0.1% and 0.2% respectively. The ECB held fire on monetary policy, but marginally upgraded inflation forecasts. OPEC failed to agree on a production ceiling, causing oil shares to retreat. US stocks also fell, with the Dow shedding 0.2%, despite a lower jobless claims report. The yen strengthened, and Japan's Nikkei index dropped 2.3% due to uncertainty ahead of the country's referendum.

site_title: Risk management a growing challenge for audit committees
summary: Audit committees in Singapore-listed companies face a growing risk management challenge, but there's a lack of consensus on the committee's role. A study by ISCA and NUS found AC chairmen differ in views on risk management. Smaller companies struggle to attract quality directors, and dismissing directors after nine years is considered arbitrary. These findings highlight the need for clearer guidelines and more effective risk management practices among audit committees.

site_title: Temasek, GIC buy US$1b of Alibaba shares
summary: Singapore's state-owned investment firms Temasek Holdings and GIC Pte Ltd have jointly purchased US$1 billion of Alibaba shares, with each firm paying US$500 million at US$74 per share. This marks the second-largest stake sold by SoftBank Group Corp. since 2000. The purchases signal confidence in China's economy and e-commerce sector, boosting national interest in Singapore and South-east Asia. Temasek and GIC have significant stakes in other technology firms, including Tencent Holdings and 21Vianet Group Inc.

site_title: Singtel aims to lead the way for organisations
summary: Singtel, a Singapore-based telecommunications company, has hired its first two employees with disabilities and an intern for its contact centre and infrastructure teams. The company aims to promote diversity and inclusion, believing that people with disabilities bring unique perspectives and skills. Singtel provides training and assistive technology to support their employment, and hopes to encourage other organizations to do the same. The company's efforts are part of its "See The True Me" campaign, which aims to raise awareness and promote inclusion for people with disabilities.

site_title: AEF looks at the big picture in Central Asia
summary: Kazakhstan played a key role in the Astana Economic Forum (AEF), a major conference on Central Asia, bringing together world-renowned experts, politicians, and heads of financial institutions to discuss the region's economic challenges and opportunities. The forum focused on the "New economic reality: diversification, innovation and knowledge economy" and explored topics such as the Great Silk Road, One Belt, One Road, and sustainable development. Kazakhstan Prime Minister Karim Massimov emphasized the country's role in connecting Asia, Europe, and America, while Singapore Minister of State Koh Poh Koon highlighted the importance of trade and investment in the region.

images.alt_text: From left: Zhang Yansheng, secretary-general, academic council of China's National Development and Reform Commission; Nematullo Hikmatullozoda, Tajikistan Minister of Economic Development and Trade; Uldis Augulis, Latvia Minister of Transport; and Koh Poh Koon, Singapore Minister of State for Trade and Industry at the AEF. Dr Koh notes how greater integration can be facilitated between the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU) and the South-east Asian grouping, through the Silk Road which connects both communities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Three mainboard-listed companies - Keppel Corporation, Sembcorp Industries, and Sembcorp Marine - have denied allegations raised in a lawsuit filed by US investment company EIG Management. EIG alleged that the companies participated in an unlawful conspiracy, inducing it to invest over $221 million in Petrobras' rig owning unit. The companies will vigorously defend the action. Meanwhile, Jason Holdings has faced a lawsuit by ANZ over an unpaid debt of approximately $1.69 million, and the Straits Times Index will remain unchanged after the June quarterly review.

site_title: SGX grants 13 firms three-month MTP extension
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has granted a three-month extension to 13 firms on its mainboard, allowing them to avoid being sent to the watch-list for non-compliance with the minimum trading price (MTP) rule. The extension, from June to September, was given due to recent market volatility affecting these companies, with their six-month volume-weighted average prices dipping below the S$0.20 MTP threshold.

site_title: Another year of capex cuts will set oil market up for serious supply crunch
summary: Global oil production is expected to decline for several years due to reduced spending on new exploration and development. According to Statoil's CFO, Hans Jakob Hegge, capital expenditure is set to fall for two years in a row, potentially leading to a third year in 2017. This could result in a supply deficit by 2018-2020, with a four million barrel per day fall in global supplies. The oil industry's volatile nature means delayed responses to price changes, making it difficult to predict future supply and demand.

site_title: S&P maintains Indonesia's junk status
summary: S&P Global Ratings maintained Indonesia's junk status with a BB+ rating, citing weak fiscal performance and forecasts for larger budget deficits. The country's failure to win full investment-grade status may impact its bond market, which has seen a 10% gain this year. The government is relying on a tax amnesty plan to boost revenue, but its implementation has been held up by Parliament. S&P maintains a positive outlook, but economists warn that the government needs to come up with a more certain solution to ensure fiscal risk remains safe.

site_title: Enforcing investors' rights in FTAs
summary: Investors' rights are protected under Free Trade Agreements (FTAs), such as the Asean Comprehensive Investment Agreement (Acia) and the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), which provide for protection against expropriation, discriminatory treatment, and other forms of unfair treatment. These agreements also establish procedures for investor-state dispute settlement, including arbitration and the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID). The Acia and TPP require due process and adequate compensation in the event of a breach, and provide for various options for resolving disputes, including domestic courts, arbitration, and ISDS.

site_title: Insta-sharing at a price
summary: The K+ Instgrm Exhibition, curated by Kinetic Singapore and supported by Scotts Square, features 120 local Instagram photos by 13 artists. The exhibition showcases a broad spectrum of stories, from human-centric images to landscape and street photography. The artworks, priced at S$90 and S$138 for prints, aim to evoke a different perspective by transforming digital content into tactile art. The exhibition, which opened to over 200 people, marks the final show at the current space, but K+ Gallery will move into bigger digs in July, offering a wider range of arts, retail, and community activities.

site_title: Virtual reality could change daily life, say tech leaders
summary: Virtual reality (VR) technology is expected to revolutionize daily life, beyond entertainment for gamers. Tech leaders predict its use in medical, retail, and education sectors, with applications including reducing surgery errors and enhancing learning abilities. The global VR market is forecast to reach $10.9 billion in 2017, with companies like HTC, Facebook, and Samsung investing in the technology. However, concerns remain about the need for a robust ecosystem, cost, and dizziness associated with VR headsets, which may limit its widespread adoption.

site_title: Obama to host PM Lee to White house state dinner
summary: US President Barack Obama will host Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong for a state dinner at the White House on August 2, marking the first official visit by a Singapore Prime Minister in 31 years. The visit coincides with the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two countries and will highlight the progress in their bilateral relationship, which includes strong economic ties, security cooperation, and regional partnerships. The visit will also showcase the US's rebalance to Asia and its commitment to a rules-based order in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Global airline industry cruising towards record earnings this year
summary: The global airline industry is expected to post record profits of $39.4 billion in 2016, driven by strong demand and lower fuel prices. North America will account for the bulk of profits ($22.9 billion), while Asia-Pacific airlines are expected to post $7.8 billion in profit. Africa carriers, however, are forecast to continue generating an overall loss. The industry's return on invested capital is expected to exceed the cost of capital, with airlines generating $10.42 for each passenger carried. This marks the fifth consecutive year of improving aggregate profits for the industry.

site_title: China's booming car market risks petrol glut
summary: China's booming car market is leading to a surge in petrol production, potentially creating a global glut. Petrol stockpiles reached a record in April, and exports increased 36% in the first four months of the year. Despite strong demand for larger cars, refiners are struggling to keep up with production, threatening gasoline margins in the region. China's petrol consumption is forecast to grow 7.4% this year, while diesel may climb only 0.4%. This oversupply could force excess petrol onto overseas markets, posing a threat to refiners abroad.

site_title: Jet Airways beefs up capacity on S'pore-Mumbai route with A330
summary: Jet Airways has increased capacity on its Singapore-Mumbai route by upgauging to a widebody Airbus A330-200 aircraft, boosting seat capacity by 38% and enabling it to cater to premium traffic and connecting passengers from Australia via Singapore. The upgrade, set to be completed in August, follows a 34% growth in traffic on the route over the past two years. The airline is also expanding its services to other destinations, including Bangalore, and studying new routes to launch direct services between India and Singapore.

site_title: Oil prices and US$: do not expect the usual linkage
summary: US oil prices are expected to decline due to a year-on-year contraction in US and non-Opec production, and a mild winter dampening demand in OECD countries. However, a 1-1.5 million barrels/day increase in demand from China and emerging markets is expected. The correlation between oil prices and the US dollar is expected to weaken, with higher oil prices potentially leading to a stronger dollar. In the medium term, Brent prices are expected to reach a neutral level of around $60/barrel, and the US Federal Reserve may increase interest rates to combat inflation.

site_title: Doing good is also great business strategy: panel
summary: A panel discussion in Singapore emphasized the importance of corporate social responsibility (CSR) as a business strategy. Companies can benefit from CSR by building stronger relationships with customers, attracting and retaining talent, and uncovering business opportunities. Panelists suggested that businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), team up with other organizations to carry out CSR projects. The National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre's Company of Good program provides resources and support for businesses to improve their CSR efforts.

site_title: Silicon Valley technophiles not enamoured of Trump
summary: Silicon Valley technologists are largely unenthusiastic about Donald Trump's presidential bid, citing his stance on immigration, manufacturing, and his lack of appreciation for the tech industry. Despite Trump's recent attacks on tech giants, his campaign has received minimal support from Silicon Valley executives, with billionaire Peter Thiel being the only prominent backer. Trump's campaign has also struggled to raise funds from tech donors, with a total of $21,815 raised from tech workers compared to Hillary Clinton's $2.7 million and Bernie Sanders' $6 million.

site_title: Towards a world without wars
summary: Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev has unveiled a comprehensive plan to create a world without wars, citing the need for global cooperation and the devastating impact of wars on humanity. The plan, outlined in a document titled "21st Century: A World without Wars," calls for joint and responsible actions by nations to destroy the "virus of war" and promote peaceful dialogue and constructive negotiations. Nazarbayev warns that the risk of conflict has increased in international relations and that nuclear weapons pose a significant threat, particularly in the hands of terrorists.

site_title: No easy way out for Abbott as deal target faces bribery probe
summary: Abbott Laboratories is facing a difficult situation as its $5.8 billion acquisition of Alere Inc. hangs in the balance due to a US bribery probe. Despite Alere's claims of compliance, the company is being investigated for potential violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. Abbott is auditing Alere's books and has yet to receive a full response, raising doubts about the deal's prospects. Legal experts say that FCPA violations aren't necessarily a deal-breaker, and past examples show that some transactions can proceed despite concurrent investigations.

site_title: Opec fails to agree on output cap; oil extends fall
summary: OPEC failed to agree on an output cap, sticking to its policy of unfettered production. Despite Saudi Arabia's willingness to discuss a new ceiling, Iran refused to participate, citing its desire to restore output following sanctions removal. Oil prices extended their decline, with Brent crude falling to $49.11 a barrel, amid concerns of a worsening conflict between Saudi Arabia and Iran, which could impact poorer OPEC members like Venezuela. Nigeria's Sudirman Said was appointed as the new secretary-general, marking a rare consensus among OPEC members.

site_title: Employers urged to see past people's disabilities to harness true potential
summary: Singapore's National Council of Social Services has launched "See The True Me" campaign to change public perceptions of people with disabilities. A survey found that attitudes towards people with disabilities improved when frequent contact was made, but nearly a third of respondents would not hire someone with a disability. The campaign aims to promote inclusion and equal opportunities, with ambassadors sharing their experiences and advocating for a more inclusive society.

site_title: ECB holds key rates unchanged, stays silent on Greek debt
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) kept key interest rates at historic lows, remaining at 0% since March, during a meeting in Vienna. Despite speculation, the ECB made no announcement regarding Greece's debt, fueling concerns over the country's financial struggles. The decision was seen as a cautious approach, with the ECB opting not to intervene in the Greek economy at this time. The ECB's silence on Greece's debt adds to the uncertainty surrounding the country's future.

site_title: China, US gear up for ruling on South China Sea claims
summary: China and the US are gearing up for a ruling on the South China Sea claims, with diplomatic and public relations efforts underway. The Philippines has brought a case to an international arbitration court in The Hague, which is expected to rule on the status of features China claims and its "historic rights" claim. China claims 80% of the waters, while the US supports free navigation. China has bolstered its capabilities in the area, and the US has resumed "freedom of navigation operations" in the South China Sea. A ruling seen as unfavorable to China could undermine its claims and escalate tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Turning the spotlight back on new directors
summary: Anthony Chen, a 30-year-old Singaporean director, is executive producing the omnibus film Distance, which features three award-winning young Asian directors - Xin Yukun, Tan Shijie, and Sivaroj Kongsakul. Chen's production company, Giraffe Pictures, co-produced the China-Singapore-Taiwan-Thailand co-production, which premiered at the Golden Horse Film Festival in Taipei last year. Chen's involvement marks his first big production after making student films, and he learned the importance of collaboration on this project.

images.alt_text: (From left) Anthony Chen, Chen Bo-lin, Yeo Yann Yann, Cheng Huan Lin and Tan Shijie at the gala premiere of Distance

site_title: A big merger may flatten US beer market
summary: The US beer market may face significant consolidation due to a planned merger between Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller, the world's second-largest brewer. The $107 billion deal would give the combined company control over 29% of the global beer market and potentially stifle consumer choice. Small brewers and independent distributors are concerned that the merger could limit competition, as Anheuser-Busch InBev is already the largest brewer and distributor in the US. Federal antitrust authorities are weighing in on the deal, with some calling for the company to be required to sell off its distribution network and modify its anti-competitive incentives.

site_title: US economy grows modestly as job market tightens: Beige Book
summary: The US economy expanded at a modest pace since mid-April, with the labor market tightening as employers added jobs and raised wages. The Federal Reserve's Beige Book reported modest growth in overall growth, consumer spending, employment, and financial services, with manufacturing results being mixed. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates in the coming months, with a 24% chance of a rate increase this month, according to federal funds futures contracts. The economy is slowly gaining ground, with the labor market becoming increasingly tight.

site_title: Tokyo stocks dive after Abe's tax hike delay
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 2.3% after Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe postponed a scheduled increase in the national sales tax, sparking concerns over the nation's fiscal health and the Bank of Japan's monetary policy. The Nikkei 225 stock average dropped 393.18 points to 16,562.55. The yen rose 2.4% as markets reacted to the uncertainty and potential political turbulence ahead of the July 10 Upper House election. The delay raises questions about the future of Abenomics, Abe's economic policy.

site_title: Inclusion of mainland China stocks a key consideration in MSCI index revamp
summary: MSCI is set to unveil changes to its global indexes on June 14, with the most consequential move being the potential inclusion of mainland Chinese stocks. This could increase China's weighting in the Emerging Markets Index to 39.9% from 25.9%. Pakistan stocks may also be added, while Peruvian equities are likely to be excluded. The inclusion of Chinese stocks has been a long-standing consideration, with 10 out of 23 strategists surveyed expecting a positive decision.

site_title: Otto Marine told of potential offer in letter from RHB Securities
summary: Otto Marine announced a potential buyer is interested in acquiring the offshore marine group, according to a letter from RHB Securities Singapore. RHB intends to submit a formal proposal to Otto's board, but there's no guarantee of a transaction due to regulatory consultations. The company's shares rose last week after the news, and Otto warned that there's no firm intention to make an offer and that the outcome is uncertain. The trading halt has been lifted, with Otto set to make a further announcement soon.

site_title: Intuitive capture of life in its ordinary moments
summary: Melisa Teo, a 41-year-old former publishing editor, discovered her passion for photography after working on a photo book. She quit her job and traveled, capturing ordinary moments with a camera, which became her outlet for existential questions about life. Teo's style evolved through experimentation, guided by intuition and emotion. Her latest exhibition, "The Light Beyond," showcases her journey through Vietnam, Thailand, Cambodia, France, Israel, Morocco, and Taiwan, seeking magic in the ordinary.

site_title: Dono explores 'meaning in the madness'
summary: Contemporary Indonesian artist Heri Dono's exhibition "Zaman Edan" at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute explores the concept of "meaning in the madness" through various mediums, techniques, and styles. Dono's experiments with artmaking techniques, including performance, kinetic sculpture, and printmaking, aim to satirize human behavior, power, and authority in modern life. The exhibition showcases Dono's ability to combine multiple art-making techniques to express life's truths through humor, challenging misconceptions about art and its forms.

site_title: Japanese investors sell overseas debt on Fed hike expectations
summary: Japanese investors sold overseas debt, specifically US bonds, for the first time in seven weeks, citing expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The sales totaled 549.4 billion yen (S$6.95 billion) in the week ending May 27. This move was attributed to the Fed's statement that an interest rate increase may occur in the coming months, and a subsequent surge in demand for UK government securities due to concerns over the UK's potential exit from the EU.

site_title: Aloft at Hermes
summary: French luxury brand Hermes has rebranded its art space, "Aloft at Hermes," after relocating from the third floor to the fourth floor in its Singapore boutique. The space, which has been dedicated to showcasing contemporary young artists since 2006, will now focus on site-specific works and feature annual exhibitions with two invited artists. The Fondation d'entreprise Hermès aims to support artistic vision and craftsmanship, aligning with the brand's core values, and provide a unique space for the community to engage with art.

site_title: Cathay Pacific interested in bigger Airbus A350
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is in talks with Airbus Group about a proposed bigger version of the A350 widebody, the A350-8000, which could have more seats or increased range. The airline, which already has 48 A350s on order, is interested in the stretched variant to serve destinations such as Miami non-stop from Hong Kong. Airbus is assessing demand to determine if investing in the bigger plane is worthwhile, with a decision unlikely before the Farnborough Air Show in mid-July.

site_title: ST Index gains for first time this week
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 4.55 points to 2,795.09, its first gain this week, driven by a play on food and beverage stocks, including Yeo Hiap Seng, Thai Beverage, Jumbo Group, and Sino Grandness. The F&B sector saw significant gains, with Yeo Hiap Seng rising 19% in two days. The index was influenced by uncertainty surrounding the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting, with some analysts expecting a potential rate hike, while others expect a rate cut.

site_title: Apple Pay struggles outside US amid low uptake, bank resistance
summary: Apple Pay has struggled to gain traction globally, with its US$10.9 billion usage in 2023 being less than the annual volume of transactions in Kenya, a mobile payments pioneer. The service is available in six countries, but faces technical challenges, low consumer adoption, and bank resistance. Apple has expanded its partner banks in Australia, Canada, and Singapore, but the service remains limited. Despite its US success, Apple Pay's global impact is still minimal, highlighting the difficulties in replicating its success outside the US.

site_title: Basslink outage seen as force majeure covered by insurance (Amended)
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Basslink cable operator claims the Tasmania-Australia electricity interconnector outage is a force majeure event, with fault covered by insurance. EnergyQuest estimates the outage has cost Tasmania at least A$560m to date, but Tasmania's Energy Minister disputes the estimate, citing government saving of A$40m. The outage occurred in December 2015 and is expected to resume operations around end June 2016. Keppel Infrastructure Trust reported a net profit plunge in Q1 due to Basslink's cable fault.

site_title: US takes further steps to block N Korea's access to financial systems
summary: The US Treasury Department declared North Korea a "primary money-laundering concern" and imposed further restrictions on its access to the US and global financial systems. The move aims to block North Korean financial institutions from opening or maintaining correspondent accounts, which are used to receive and make payments on behalf of foreign institutions. This action is part of efforts to prevent North Korea from using the financial system to fund its weapons programs.

site_title: NY property boom impinging on produce supply
summary: A booming real estate market in New York's Hudson Valley is driving up land values, leading to the decline of family farms and a shortage of fresh produce for the city. To address this issue, a group of lawmakers and preservation groups have proposed a plan to preserve farmland in the region, including a $50 million conservation easement program. The program aims to protect farms that serve the city's neediest neighborhoods, ensuring access to fresh, locally grown food. This initiative is seen as crucial to maintaining a secure regional food system and promoting healthier eating habits.

site_title: EU defers proposals to fight tax-dodging due to Brexit vote
summary: The European Union has delayed proposals to combat tax evasion due to Brexit concerns, with a package potentially including stricter rules on trust ownership, now set to be released in July. The decision, attributed to "technical issues" and concerns over protecting privacy, was influenced by the impact on Prime Minister David Cameron's bid to keep Britain in the EU. The move comes amid public outcry over the Panama Papers and follows a pattern of EU measures being delayed due to Brexit-related concerns.

images.alt_text: European Union proposals to fight tax evasion have been shelved until July, at least in part to avoid hurting Prime Minister David Cameron's bid to keep Britain in the EU in a June 23 referendum, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: SGX's Baltic bid: great prize comes at a price
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is in exclusive talks to acquire the Baltic Exchange, a maritime information provider, as part of its expansion into commodity derivatives. This move comes three months after SGX made a non-binding bid for the company, which has also attracted other suitors, including the Chicago Mercantile Exchange Group. The acquisition would cement SGX's foothold in commodity derivatives, but the journey may not be smooth, given the competition and potential challenges ahead.

site_title: China's Anbang withdraws bid to buy US insurer
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group has withdrawn its $1.57 billion bid to buy US insurer Fidelity & Guaranty Life, citing "various market considerations." However, Fidelity says the withdrawal isn't final, expecting Anbang to refile its application in the near future. This setback adds to Anbang's recent stumbles, including its $14 billion bid to buy Starwood Hotels and Resorts, which it abruptly ended in March. Anbang, a politically connected Chinese insurer, has been making a multi-billion-dollar global shopping spree, but its recent setbacks raise concerns about its ability to complete these deals.

images.alt_text: Anbang Insurance Group has struck a remarkable spate of deals including an agreement two years ago to buy the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York.

site_title: Disappearing into a rainbow
summary: Singapore artist Dawn Ng's "How to Disappear into a Rainbow" is an immersive art exhibition at the newly renovated Hermes store, featuring a pastel labyrinth of colour that physically shifts and morphs around viewers. The installation, which explores themes of time, memory, and space, transports viewers to a "soft, naive and innocent" world evoking the ethereal hues of daybreak. Ng worked closely with the store's architecture to create a unique and immersive environment, incorporating mirrors, high-gloss paint, and strategic lighting to amplify light reflections and angles.

images.alt_text: Singapore artist Dawn Ng says "the use of mirrors, staggered angles, and high-gloss paint in this installation (above) were deliberate choices to play with and amplify light reflections, angles and shadows within the work to create a plethora of horizons and slivers of infinity".

site_title: US unemployment claims fall to five-week low
summary: US unemployment claims dropped to a five-week low of 267,000 in the week ending May 28, according to Labour Department data. This marks the third consecutive week of decline, indicating a tightening jobs market. The decrease in initial jobless claims dispels concerns that the labour market was slowing down.

site_title: From melancholic meditation to crowd-pleasing comedy
summary: Tom Tykwer's adaptation of Dave Eggers' novel "A Hologram for the King" stars Tom Hanks as Alan, a middle-aged American salesman sent to Saudi Arabia to seal a business deal with the king. Despite initial culture shock and personal struggles, Alan finds companionship with a wise-cracking taxi driver and a beautiful doctor, leading to a satirical black comedy that explores themes of mid-life crisis and corporate greed. Hanks brings his signature charm to the role, transforming the melancholic novel into a crowd-pleasing film.

site_title: S'pore's May factory PMI dims hopes for broader upturn
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector continued to contract in May, with the PMI at 49.8, its 11th consecutive month of decline. Economists had been hopeful for a broader upturn, but the dimmed hopes come ahead of Friday's Nikkei PMI release, which captures economy-wide activity. The sector's performance has been mixed, with a marginal expansion in production index, but new orders and exports continuing to fall. This has left economists uncertain about the sector's resilience, with some warning of a potential downside risk to the country's GDP growth forecast.

site_title: Centre for environmental technologies launched
summary: Singapore has launched a new research centre, Separation Technologies Applied Research and Translation (START), to develop and commercialise environmental technologies with applications in healthcare and utilities. The $30 million facility, located at CleanTech Park, aims to build water treatment systems and test them in real-life scenarios. Jointly supported by Nanyang Technological University, the Economic Development Board, and the Public Utilities Board, START will focus on membrane technologies for seawater desalination and environmental filtration. The centre aims to fill the gap in specialist talent and infrastructure to support the commercialisation of research.

site_title: Trek 2000 CFO retires amid CAD probe
summary: Trek 2000's CFO, Gurcharan Singh, has retired amid investigations by Singapore's white-collar crime police unit, the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD). The CAD questioned Singh and three other company executives, including CEO Henn Tan, on May 25-31. The company's auditors found discrepancies in financial statements for the 2015 financial year. Singh, 60, will step down as CFO and executive director, while Edwin Long Ming Fai will take over the roles and Edward Tan Kew Poh has been appointed finance director.

site_title: US crude oil stocks drop less than expected: EIA
summary: US crude oil stocks decreased by 1.4 million barrels last week, less than the expected 2.5 million barrels, according to the Energy Information Administration. Gasoline and distillate stocks also fell. Crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub dropped by 704,000 barrels. The decline was attributed to increased production and lower imports.

site_title: Opec fails to agree new oil production ceiling
summary: Opec failed to agree on a new oil production ceiling, allowing crude output to continue without formal constraints. The cartel's current production of around 32 million barrels per day is deemed reasonable by the market. Opec's secretary general stated that setting a specific target is difficult and that the current production level is acceptable. Iran opposed a new target, instead advocating for individual member quotas. The decision marks a return to the group's previous policy of not setting a formal production ceiling.

site_title: Taking centre stage
summary: Local musicians Tay Kewei, Nathan Hartono, and Gentle Bones are taking the stage at major venues, showcasing growth in Singapore's music scene. Tay Kewei headlines her first solo concert, Chi, at the Esplanade, with her father performing as a tribute to his influence. Nathan Hartono, 25, is marking his 11th year in the industry with a solo concert, aiming to move towards new material. Gentle Bones, 22, is the first homegrown artist signed to Universal Music and featured on Forbes' 30 Under 30 Asia List for Entertainment and Sports, with his first solo concert selling out in a month.

site_title: EgyptAir chairman denies reports that MS804 earlier sent technical warnings
summary: EgyptAir's chairman, Safwat Musallam, denied reports that the crashed MS804 airliner sent technical warnings before its disappearance. Musallam stated the plane was "normal" and no maintenance issues were reported before departure. The search zone for the crashed jet has been narrowed to 2km from 5km after a French warship picked up a signal from one of the aircraft's black boxes. Musallam expressed trust in the aircraft and pilot, saying "we fully trust the aircraft and the pilot."

site_title: Duterte plans wider Philippine deficit in fiscal reversal
summary: Philippine President-elect Rodrigo Duterte's administration plans to adopt a looser fiscal policy, aiming for a 3% deficit target, the highest since 2010. The new government aims to cut taxes, including personal and corporate taxes, and borrow more to fund infrastructure projects and social capital. Investors may support this move, as it could boost growth potential. However, Fitch Ratings expresses concerns over the nature of the planned higher spending, waiting for more details on the targeted level of spending. The government estimates economic growth of 6.2% for the full year.

site_title: President's 100 concrete steps taking Kazakhstan to its goal
summary: Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev has proposed 100 concrete steps to help his country achieve its goal of becoming one of the world's 30 most developed countries. The reforms include modernizing the civil service, strengthening the rule of law, and promoting a business-friendly environment to attract investors. Additionally, the reforms focus on developing national identity and enhancing government accountability. The reforms are part of Kazakhstan's 2050 Strategy masterplan and aim to bring the country into the club of developed nations, with key steps including the establishment of an international financial center and a multi-modal transport corridor.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

The Better Market experience, a combined space of over 80,000 sq ft, brings together furniture store Dream and kitchen appliances company APS for a two-day market featuring over 50 F&B and lifestyle merchants. The event includes food vendors, children's clothing, artisanal goods, and furniture at discounted prices. Meanwhile, a South-east Asian film series, "Painting with Light", showcases classic and contemporary films, and a live music show features experimental duos. Other events include a dinner with chef Hideaki Matsuo, an exhibition on Cathay's 80th anniversary, and a theatrical performance, "Ghost Writer".

site_title: UK economy would be biggest Brexit loser, Euro-area chief says
summary: Dutch Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem warns that the UK economy would be the biggest loser if the UK leaves the European Union, citing higher risks for the UK than the euro area. This comes as the UK Prime Minister and Chancellor seek to shift the debate to economic dangers of a Brexit. The pound has dropped due to polls showing a swing in favor of "Leave," and the EU lacks a contingency plan for a potential UK exit.

site_title: Singaporean businessman buys private island off Tasmania for A$5.5m: report
summary: A Singaporean businessman purchased a 287ha private island off Tasmania's north-east coast for A$5.5 million, about the size of 350 football fields. The island, known as Waterhouse Island, has been privately owned since the 1970s and drew global interest after going on the market last year.

site_title: Ready to Rice again on his own
summary: Damien Rice, an Irish singer-songwriter, is returning to touring after an eight-year hiatus. His latest album, My Favourite Faded Fantasy, was released in 2014, and he has been performing solo shows in Singapore, including a sold-out concert at The Star this weekend. Rice prefers playing solo, citing the freedom and spontaneity it brings, and has expressed his openness to new experiences and musical directions, stating that he aims to not make plans but instead be spontaneous.

site_title: Lexus hybrids pass on fuel savings
summary: Lexus Singapore has launched a corporate social responsibility project, "Power Up with Lexus Hybrid," to celebrate World Environment Day. The project partners with North West Community Development Council to provide utilities assistance to over 200 disadvantaged households in the North West district, with a donation of S$50,000. This initiative follows the success of last year's program, which saw Lexus Singapore donate half of the estimated S$100,000 in combined fuel savings from 400 hybrid vehicles sold, helping families facing electricity disconnection.
